headline: 911 Recordings of Gunman During Orlando Nightclub Siege Are Released
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Nine-One-One (911) (Emergency Phone Number)']
abstract: For the first time, the public heard Omar Mateen talking with the authorities amid his assault on the gay nightclub Pulse.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The 911 call began with about six seconds of Arabic, and then Omar Mateen switched to English: “I want to let you know, I’m in Orlando, and I did the shooting.”

headline: Bundy Verdict Puts a Target on the Backs of Federal Workers
abstract: Federal land managers worry that extremist copycats will become bolder.
lead_paragraph: ESCALANTE, Utah — With the jury acquittals last week of Ammon and Ryan Bundy and their accomplices in the 41-day armed takeover of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon last winter, the lives of federal land managers in the American West got a whole lot more difficult.

headline: Where Mountains of Halloween Candy Go, the Morning After
abstract: In buybacks and donation campaigns, dentists, schools and support-the-troops organizations collect actual tons of surplus candy each year.
lead_paragraph: Overwhelmed by candy?

headline: What Happens to the Markets if Donald Trump Wins?
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A Trump victory probably would lead to an immediate market sell-off, the direction in the days and weeks that follow is not clear.
lead_paragraph: Assume, for a moment, that Donald J. Trump wins the presidency.

headline: James Comey’s Big Mistake
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail', 'Editorials']
abstract: With an inscrutable letter, the F.B.I. director undermined trust in top law enforcement agencies and unleashed innuendo on the Clinton campaign.
lead_paragraph: Four days after James Comey, the F.B.I. director, sent Congress a brief, inscrutable, election-shaking letter about emails that may or may not be new or relevant to the previously concluded investigation into Hillary Clinton’s private email server, his logic makes even less sense than it did on Friday.

headline: Zcash, a Harder-to-Trace Virtual Currency, Generates Price Frenzy
abstract: Unlike Bitcoin, Zcash transactions can be confirmed without recording the addresses involved, which could make it harder to win support from regulators and bankers.
lead_paragraph: Speculators are snapping up a new virtual currency known as Zcash that was designed by university academics and built to be all but untraceable.

headline: Bridge Case Verdict May Hinge on Officials Who Weren’t Tried
abstract: Prosecutors in the George Washington Bridge case have repeatedly brought up Gov. Chris Christie’s name even though his two former aides, and not he, are on trial.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Prosecutors opened the case against two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey with a stunning assertion: The governor himself knew during the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge that they were meant to punish a mayor for declining to endorse him.

headline: Donald Trump's Lawyers' Warnings on Tax Maneuver
abstract: Mr. Trump's own lawyers at Willkie Farr & Gallagher cautioned him about using a a tax avoidance maneuver in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump's own lawyers at Willkie Farr & Gallagher cautioned him about using a a tax avoidance maneuver in the 1990s.

headline: How Donald Trump Avoided Paying Taxes Using Other People’s Money
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Casinos']
abstract: Mr. Trump managed to save millions in personal taxes by borrowing – then losing – other people’s money.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump managed to save millions in personal taxes by borrowing – then losing – other people’s money.

headline: Donald Trump Used Legally Dubious Method to Avoid Paying Taxes
abstract: Thanks to a maneuver later outlawed by Congress, Mr. Trump potentially escaped paying tens of millions of dollars in federal personal income taxes.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump proudly acknowledges he did not pay a dime in federal income taxes for years on end. He insists he merely exploited tax loopholes legally available to any billionaire — loopholes he says Hillary Clinton failed to close during her years in the United States Senate. “Why didn’t she ever try to change those laws so I couldn’t use them?” Mr. Trump asked during a campaign rally last month.

headline: A.P. Poll About to Take a Back Seat to College Football Playoff Rankings
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'College Football Playoff National Championship', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The Associated Press poll once determined the national champion, but now the playoff selection committee, set to release its initial 2016 rankings on Tuesday, has the definitive list.
lead_paragraph: For the past three weeks, No. 1 Alabama has claimed 60 of the 61 first-place votes in the weekly Associated Press college football poll. The only dissenter has stubbornly stuck with No. 2 Michigan.

headline: ‘Going Flat’ After Breast Cancer
abstract: Some women are choosing to defy medical advice and social convention after mastectomies, saying they would rather live without breasts than undergo more surgery.
lead_paragraph: Before Debbie Bowers had surgery for breast cancer, her doctor promised that insurance would pay for reconstruction, and said she could “even go up a cup size.” But Ms. Bowers did not want a silicone implant or bigger breasts.

headline: For the Clintons, Two Investigations, One Protective Reflex
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s reaction to the F.B.I. director has echoes in the response to Kenneth W. Starr, the independent prosecutor who spent years investigating Bill Clinton’s administration.
lead_paragraph: Bill and Hillary Clinton argued that the man in charge of the investigation had grossly overreached. He had been motivated by politics rather than public service. And he had no damaging information to support his relentless pursuit and the daily negative headlines it generated.

headline: James Comey Role Recalls Hoover’s F.B.I., Fairly or Not
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Though Mr. Comey acted publicly, while J. Edgar Hoover maneuvered in secret, Hoover was the last F.B.I. director to be accused of trying to influence a presidential election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since President Obama named James B. Comey director of the F.B.I. in 2013, the 6-foot-8 former prosecutor has spoken often of dark chapters in the bureau’s history, notably J. Edgar Hoover’s order to wiretap the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and use the tapes to try to drive the civil rights leader to suicide.

headline: World Series Drawing Most Viewers Since Red Sox’ Sweep in ’04
abstract: Through five games, the World Series has attracted an average of 19.3 million viewers, the most since 2004, when Boston won its first title in 86 years.
lead_paragraph: Through five games, the World Series between the Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians has attracted the most viewers for the Series since 2004, when the Boston Red Sox swept the St. Louis Cardinals to win their first title in 86 years.

headline: Confidence Even as Hillary Clinton’s Momentum Slows
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Electoral College', 'United States Politics and Government', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s campaign was optimistic that she would weather the F.B.I.’s review of a top aide’s emails, but acknowledged that optimism of gaining ground in places like Ohio and Iowa was fading.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The announcement that the F.B.I. is reviewing newly discovered emails of a top Hillary Clinton aide has slowed the campaign’s momentum and the hopes of expanding support in traditional Midwestern battleground states. Leading Democratic strategists say the news has caused some of Mrs. Clinton’s more casual supporters to drift away.

headline: Investigating Donald Trump, F.B.I. Sees No Clear Link to Russia
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Elections', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: After lengthy investigations, officials also believe that a hacking of Democratic emails was aimed at disrupting the election rather than electing Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For much of the summer, the F.B.I. pursued a widening investigation into a Russian role in the American presidential campaign. Agents scrutinized advisers close to Donald J. Trump, looked for financial connections with Russian financial figures, searched for those involved in hacking the computers of Democrats, and even chased a lead — which they ultimately came to doubt — about a possible secret channel of email communication from the Trump Organization to a Russian bank.

headline: Defense, Though Hard to Gauge, Gives Cubs a Clear Edge
abstract: Some metrics suggest that this year’s Cubs are among the best defensive teams of the last two decades, and they turned in a number of fielding gems to win Game 5 of the World Series.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Defense does not usually get top billing in baseball, and it remains one of the harder aspects of the game to measure. But in Game 5 of the World Series on Sunday night, the Chicago Cubs put on a display of stellar fielding that was hard to overlook and highlighted how important good glove work can be to a team’s success.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, November 1, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “This city is broken in some ways. We have decided that rather than confront the disagreements and the differences of opinion, we’ll simply annihilate the person who disagrees with us.”

headline: In 1997, an Indians Title Was Put in Writing, Until the Story Changed
abstract: Facing deadline pressure, a reporter typed out a sentence in the bottom of the ninth inning in Game 7 pronouncing the Indians the world champions. But the game wasn’t over.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Cleveland Indians remain one victory from winning their first World Series in 68 years. But in an alternate universe, the Indians’ wait for another championship is not nearly that long.

headline: Norman Brokaw, Agent to Marilyn Monroe and Elvis Presley, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Brokaw rose from teenage mail clerk to top mogul at the William Morris talent agency, where he broke ground in the fledgling television industry.
lead_paragraph: Norman Brokaw, who rose from teenage mail clerk to top mogul at the William Morris talent agency, where he broke ground in the fledgling television industry for idled Hollywood stars and a black stand-up comic named Bill Cosby, died on Saturday in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Curly Putman, Writer of ‘The Green, Green Grass of Home,’ Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Putman turned out hundreds of songs, many of them country chart-toppers, after moving to Nashville and signing with Tree Publishing in the early 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Curly Putman, a songwriter whose teary ballad with a twist ending, “The Green, Green Grass of Home,” became a worldwide hit for Tom Jones in 1967, and whose long string of country classics included “D-I-V-O-R-C-E” for Tammy Wynette and “He Stopped Loving Her Today” for George Jones, died on Sunday at his home in Lebanon, Tenn. He was 85.

headline: Launch a Thousand Ships
abstract: Ruth Bloomfield Margolin’s puzzle will have you trying to think up your own theme entries.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — We get mail here at Wordplay, and some of it is from readers who wonder exactly how constructors come up with their ideas. It’s a fair question, but not one that’s easy to answer.

headline: Choi Soon-sil, at Center of Political Scandal in South Korea, Is Jailed
abstract: Ms. Choi, a friend of President Park Geun-hye’s for 40 years, was grilled by prosecutors over allegations that she had manipulated important government affairs from the shadows.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The woman at the center of President Park Geun-hye’s worst leadership crisis was jailed on Tuesday, as prosecutors grilled her overnight over allegations that she had manipulated important government affairs from the shadows.

headline: A Survivor With a Steely Resolve That Can Inspire and Inflame
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hillary Clinton has endured many punches but she seems to always come back stronger and smarter, delighting her supporters and irking her detractors.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton. He is the showman who played to his audience. She is the survivor who kept going after the prize. It has been a four-year journey to a signal chapter in American history. A week ahead of Election Day, here is our essay on how Mrs. Clinton has taken many punches but has seemed to always come back stronger and smarter, delighting her supporters and irking her detractors. (Read our essay on Mr. Trump, too.)

headline: A Showman With an Anger That Ignites, and Limits, His Appeal
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s use of “we” in his speeches — “We’re going to build a wall” — helped him connect with voters until his attacks and boasts came back to haunt him.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump vs. Hillary Clinton. He is the showman who played to his audience. She is the survivor who kept going after the prize. It has been a four-year journey to a signal chapter in American history. A week ahead of Election Day, here is our essay on how Mr. Trump’s use of “we” in his speeches — “We’re going to build a wall” — helped him connect with voters until his attacks and boasts came back to haunt him. (Read our essay on Mrs. Clinton, too.)

headline: Producers of ‘Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812’ Offer to Settle Dispute
abstract: The producers said they would agree to describe the nonprofit that commissioned the Broadway musical as it wished in the show’s program if the group would drop two legal claims.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to end an acrimonious dispute that has cast a shadow over one of this fall’s most promising new Broadway musicals, the producers of “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812” offered on Monday to settle litigation with the nonprofit that commissioned the show.

headline: Americans Blame Obesity on Willpower, Despite Evidence It’s Genetic
abstract: Three-quarters of participants in a new study said obese people should exercise more and eat better, even though science says it’s more complicated than that.
lead_paragraph: Americans believe that obesity is tied with cancer as the biggest health threat in the nation today. But though scientific research shows that diet and exercise are insufficient solutions, a large majority say fat people should be able to summon the willpower to lose weight on their own.

headline: Corrections: November 1, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, November 1, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Fresh Off the Boat’ and Louis C.K. on ‘Conan’
abstract: “Fresh Off the Boat” tackles illegal immigration during the 1996 presidential election campaign. And Louis C.K. joins Conan O’Brien at the Apollo Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Fresh Off the Boat” takes on illegal immigration in a story centered on the 1996 presidential election. The Science Channel investigates how playing video games affects your brain. And Louis C.K. takes the stage of the Apollo Theater on “Conan.”

headline: Hillary Clinton, Michel Aoun, Mosul: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Audemars Piguet on Display in Shanghai
abstract: The watchmaker is exhibiting more than 200 timepieces, its largest show ever staged outside Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: With some 200 timepieces on display until Nov. 13, “To Break the Rules, You Must First Master Them,” an exhibition at the Yuz Museum in Shanghai, is Audemars Piguet’s largest display ever staged outside Switzerland.

headline: François-Paul Journe’s Motto? ‘He Invented It and Made It.’
abstract: The watchmaker still spends part of every day in his company’s workshop.
lead_paragraph: François-Paul Journe is an independent watchmaker who is not afraid to speak his mind, even if it means speaking out against the giants of the Swiss watchmaking industry.

headline: A Family Affair: McGonigle Watches
abstract: John and Stephen McGonigle create timepieces with a Celtic flair (from designs by their sister, Frances).
lead_paragraph: John and Stephen McGonigle’s house was full of clocks when they were growing up in rural Ireland. Their father, a compositor at the Irish Times, had a gift for fixing timepieces and word spread. “Every flat surface had a clock on it,” John recalled. “And instead of pictures, we had other people’s clocks on the walls.”

headline: Reviving Fears for a New Generation of Watch Fans
abstract: A joke at a family lunch prompted Nicholas Bowman-Scargill to try his hand at his family’s 170-year-old watchmaking business.
lead_paragraph: When Nicholas Bowman-Scargill’s mother made a joke at a Sunday lunch about restarting the family’s 170-year-old Fears watch business, he laughed. The company closed 60 years ago, and its revival wasn’t something he had thought much about.

headline: For Melinda Gates, Birth Control Is Women’s Way Out of Poverty
abstract: The philanthropist seeks to get contraception to 120 million by 2020, but the effort is running into barriers.
lead_paragraph: Melinda Gates has made providing poor women in developing countries access to contraception a mission. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which she leads with her husband, has donated more than $1 billion for family planning efforts and will spend about $180 million more this year.

headline: Ford Reaches Tentative Deal With Union in Canada
abstract: The union focused on preserving jobs as much as traditional contract issues like wages, and the agreement mirrors deals it had made with two other automakers.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Unifor, Canada’s largest private sector union, reached a tentative agreement with the Ford Motor Company of Canada early Tuesday, concluding contract talks with the three Detroit-based automakers.

headline: The Female Gaze in Fashion Photography
abstract: An exhibit at PhotoVogue Festival in Milan explores how female photographers are redefining the concept of beauty in fashion images.
lead_paragraph: An exhibit at PhotoVogue Festival in Milan explores how female photographers are redefining the concept of beauty in fashion images.

headline: Surprise: A Trade Deal Wins Approval
abstract: Will the Canada-E.U agreement mark the end of globalization, or a fresh start?
lead_paragraph: The new trade agreement between Canada and the European Union, negotiated over seven years, was finally signed on Sunday after 11th-hour concessions to a rebellious Belgian region that had threatened to kill the entire deal. The question now is whether the agreement spells hope for far larger trade deals in the works — notably American deals with Europe and with Asia.

headline: In Missouri, Strapped to Mr. Trump
abstract: Senator Roy Blunt is trying to ward off an aggressive Democratic challenge from Jason Kander.
lead_paragraph: Being yoked to Donald Trump’s campaign has been harrowing for Republicans like Senator Roy Blunt of Missouri, the presumed early favorite now caught in a surprisingly tight race for re-election. “There you go again,” Mr. Blunt snapped recently at reporters who kept asking about his continuing endorsement of Mr. Trump despite the Republican nominee’s serial vulgarities and campaign gaffes. “Asked and answered like 10 times in the last week, and the answer’s still the same.”

headline: The Long Shadow of J. Edgar Hoover
abstract: The F.B.I. has been trying to escape its past. James Comey isn’t helping.
lead_paragraph: Do the words “extremely careless” ring a bell?

headline: Peter Thiel Wants You to Take Trump Seriously, but Not Too Seriously
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Judge the man who would be president on his vibe, not his words.
lead_paragraph: Washington — It was the perfect way to celebrate Halloween at the National Press Club.

headline: How You Can Fight Donald Trump Right Now
abstract: When future generations ask what you did in the election of 2016, what will you say?
lead_paragraph: One day, Americans who were too young to have followed the 2016 campaign will look back and try to make sense of it. They will want to know how such a dangerous person could have gotten so close to the presidency — a man who spoke of abandoning our allies, admiring foreign despots, weakening constitutional rights, and serially molesting women.

headline: Read Buber, Not the Polls!
abstract: The writings of the Jewish sage Martin Buber offer a distraction from election anxiety.
lead_paragraph: If America were a marriage we’d need therapy.

headline: No Saints for President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Taxation']
abstract: Does anyone look good as the electoral campaigns of Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton hit the homestretch?
lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. One week! One week from today, this campaign will finally end. And we can get on to the important business of contesting the election.

headline: Australia’s Lesson for a Thirsty California
abstract: In its “millennium drought” a society changed citizens’ habits. Conserving water, they kept reservoirs from running dry.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — On his first visit to Melbourne in 2009, Stanley Grant, a drought expert and professor of civil and environmental engineering at the University of California, Irvine, had a question for his taxi driver.

headline: Watches See a ‘Brexit’ Boom
keywords: ['Watches and Clocks', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The decline in the pound since Britain’s vote to leave the European Union has had a big effect on sales.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The effect on the value of the pound of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union has rarely been out of the headlines since the June 23 referendum. But while the markets panicked — an estimated $2 trillion was wiped off world markets the day after the vote — the decline of the currency has proved a boon for Britain’s luxury watch retailers.

headline: The ‘Female Gaze’ in Fashion Photography
abstract: An exhibit at PhotoVogue Festival in Milan explores how female photographers are redefining the concept of beauty in fashion images.
lead_paragraph: Alessia Glaviano is the senior photo editor at Vogue Italia. She has started a fashion photography festival in Milan with Franca Sozzani, the editor in chief of Vogue Italia. The first PhotoVogue Festival will run from Nov. 22 through Nov. 26.

headline: Day of the Dead
abstract: What traditions do you and your family or community have for mourning or celebrating loved ones who have died?

headline: Questions for: ‘Look Who’s Smiley Now: MoMA Acquires Original Emoji’
abstract: Do you think emoji is modern art?
lead_paragraph: Article: “Look Who’s Smiley Now: MoMA Acquires Original Emoji”

headline: How Economic Gobbledygook Divides Us
keywords: ['Language and Languages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: Alienation between haves and have-nots is made worse by the willful impenetrability of financial jargon.
lead_paragraph: As a rule of thumb, texts aimed at a general audience must be written at a 10th-grade level or below. This is what mass media does, and it is also what many great writers do: Emily Brontë, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Jane Austen, Charles Dickens, Mark Twain and Ernest Hemingway all pass the 10th-grade test with ease. That they accomplish so much with simple tools is part of what makes them great writers.

headline: A Powerful Story of Cuban Exiles Has Classical Overtones
abstract: The protagonist of Derek Palacio’s debut novel, “The Mortifications,” is a Cuban-American named Ulises.
lead_paragraph: THE MORTIFICATIONSBy Derek Palacio310 pp. Tim Duggan Books. $27.

headline: How Do You Greet Your Friends and Family?
abstract: Do you hug? Shake hands? Kiss? Or just nod and say “what’s up?”
lead_paragraph: How do you and your friends say hello?

headline: The ‘Normalization’ of Trump, and What Comes After
abstract: The candidate has brought views that used to be unthinkable to the main stage of American politics. Is the damage permanent?
lead_paragraph: Early this year, when a string of primary victories established Donald Trump as a viable presidential candidate and making sense of him became a matter of some national urgency, one of the more incisive assessments came from Newt Gingrich. At a closed-door meeting of the Republican State Leadership Committee in February, Gingrich argued that Trump was not a conservative but rather an “American nationalist” — one whose success suggested he had found “a formula worthy of study.” He noted how Trump seemed bent on not just vanquishing his rivals but on eviscerating them. “He’s the grizzly bear in the room,” Gingrich said. “He’s not normal.”

headline: New York Values: How Immigrants Made the City
abstract: “City of Dreams,” Tyler Anbinder’s history of New York’s immigrant past and present, shows the city’s rich heritage.
lead_paragraph: CITY OF DREAMSThe 400-Year Epic History of Immigrant New YorkBy Tyler AnbinderIllustrated. 738 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $35.

headline: First the Trauma, Now the Grief and the Angst, for Britons in Brussels
abstract: After June’s vote to quit the European Union, hundreds of Britons working in the bloc’s institutions face a new reality as British influence and their prospects recede.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A bereavement. A horrific accident. An emotional spasm. For once, the language coming from the glass and concrete buildings in Brussels is laden not with the dull acronyms of European Union jargon, but with angst.

headline: Trump’s Inconvenient Racial Truth
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Poverty', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: For all he gets wrong on race, the Republican nominee got one thing right: The Democratic Party does take black Americans for granted, and that’s a problem.
lead_paragraph: With the race for the presidency entering its last days, Donald J. Trump last Wednesday once again made his pitch to black America: a new deal aimed just at them. “I will be your greatest champion,” Trump said at a campaign rally in the battleground state of North Carolina. “I will never ever take the African-American community for granted. Never, ever.”

headline: ‘We Don’t Owe Anyone’: Egypt Jousts With Its Chief Benefactor, Saudi Arabia
abstract: Saudi Arabia has injected more than $25 billion into the faltering Egyptian economy in two years, but ties between the two most influential Sunni nations are fraying.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In the tumultuous two years since President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt came to power, one ally has kept the Arab world’s most populous country from economic ruin: Saudi Arabia pumped more than $25 billion into the faltering Egyptian economy, dwarfing aid from the United States.

headline: The View From Two Sides of the Standing Rock Front Lines
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Native Americans', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Police', 'Water']
abstract: For months, Mekasi Horinek and Deputy Jon Moll have lived the pipeline protests in North Dakota. But they fall on opposite sides, reflecting a community as divided as oil and water.
lead_paragraph: CANNON BALL, N.D. — The prairie is seething. Work crews are plugging ahead on the 1,170-mile Dakota Access oil pipeline, inching closer and closer to a river crossing that activists view as a critical juncture in their monthslong fight against a $3.7 billion project that they say will threaten water supplies and that Native Americans say violates their right to sacred land.

headline: Why the Lone EpiPen Competitor Hasn’t Taken Off
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Medical Devices', 'Epinephrine (Drug)', 'ALLERGIES']
abstract: Adrenaclick, a cheaper alternative, has benefited from furor over EpiPen pricing. But its maker is struggling to meet demand, and a generic EpiPen is near.
lead_paragraph: As the list price of a pair of EpiPen devices soared to more than $600 this summer, people scurried to find alternatives, occasionally throwing caution to the wind. Some bought cheap syringes filled with epinephrine, the medication in EpiPens; others made homemade auto-injectors, following the steps in a popular YouTube video.

headline: Scary Dogs! Rigged Machines! Votes From the Grave! This Election, Paranoia Reigns
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A week before Election Day, polarized voters are wary, often without justification, about their fellow citizens and the integrity of the electoral process.
lead_paragraph: There was the myth of Trump supporters sending wild dogs to scare off black voters in Ohio. In Texas, some of the voting booths supposedly became possessed, switching ballots cast for Donald J. Trump to Hillary Clinton. And then there was the amateur genealogist said to be committing voter fraud by jotting down names found on gravestones.

headline: ‘How Much Suffering Can You Take?’
abstract: Over 703 miles, a hardy band of pain enthusiasts tested the limits of both mind and body at the Quintuple Anvil Triathlon — five Ironman-length races in five days.
lead_paragraph: SPOTSYLVANIA, Va. — Crushed by exhaustion, you may dream of a competitor’s head morphing into a Pokémon-like demon — and then open your eyes and still see it. The next day, you will quit the race.

headline: In the Rubble of an Airstrike in Yemen
abstract: The fanciest reception hall in Sana was bombed by a Saudi-led airstrike on Oct. 8, killing more than 100 people who were paying their respects to a prominent family after the death of its patriarch.
lead_paragraph: The fanciest reception hall in Sana was bombed by a Saudi-led airstrike on Oct. 8, killing more than 100 people who were paying their respects to a prominent family after the death of its patriarch.

lead_paragraph: THE WHISTLERBy John Grisham374 pp. Doubleday. $28.95.

abstract: We’ve launched a series of immersive 360-degree videos that let you experience Times journalism in a powerful new way.
lead_paragraph: 360 videos offer a new way to experience the journalism of The New York Times. These immersive videos put you at the center of the scene, allowing you to look left, right, up, down and behind you.

headline: Life Beyond Bars: One Man’s Journey From Prison to College
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Juan Echevarria killed a man. He spent 14 years in prison. Now he desperately wants a college degree. Getting one may be the hardest thing he’s ever had to do.
lead_paragraph: Around midnight on June 30, 1998, Juan Echevarria, a 23-year-old principal in a drug crew, ran into a crack dealer on a Harlem street corner. What ensued, he later told the police, was an argument over money. In those days, Mr. Echevarria would case New York City in a bulletproof vest, often armed with a handgun and sometimes cocaine and cash, overseeing dealers who sold on the streets and in the lobbies of Harlem and Brooklyn apartment buildings.

headline: New York Today: A City for Comedy
abstract: Tuesday: Comedians weigh in on our city, the New York Comedy Festival begins and local milk packaging ends.

headline: In Israel, a New Passion for Palestinian Cuisine
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Restaurants', 'Food', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Palestinians', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Chefs', 'Israeli Settlements']
abstract: Going far beyond hummus and grilled meats, chefs in Israel are showcasing modern Arabic cooking (kubbe made with grouper, crème brûlée with tahini).
lead_paragraph: “This can’t be it,” I told my husband, Hudy, as I steered our rental car past a fluorescent-lit gas station and through a traffic circle.

headline: Adventures in Upscale Brooklyn
abstract: It wasn’t so long ago that “high-end Brooklyn” meant neighborhoods like Brooklyn Heights, Park Slope and Williamsburg. Oh, how things have changed.
lead_paragraph: On a hot September day in Brooklyn, I got off the G train at Metropolitan Avenue and walked through Williamsburg, a neighborhood so thoroughly celebrated it has become something of a cliché.

headline: Want the ‘Real’ Brooklyn? Go Cheap
abstract: Brooklyn is a bona fide cultural capital — but you don’t have to spend a lot to appreciate it.
lead_paragraph: Green-Wood cemetery seemed a natural place to spend a few hours in the midst of a hectic urban tour. I passed under its imposing Gothic Revival gates and began heading uphill on Battle Avenue, named after a Revolutionary War battle that took place across its nearly 500-acre grounds. The views of the surrounding area and New York Bay became impressive after just a few minutes of walking. After several days in Brooklyn, I was realizing not just how huge it was, but how flat — so even the smallest changes in altitude provided for some great panoramas. The highest natural point in Brooklyn, Battle Hill, stands (at a mere 220 feet) within the cemetery.

headline: Morning Agenda: Markets and Trump, Time to Team Up, New Currency Frenzy
abstract: It is extremely hard to predict what markets will do in the event of Donald J. Trump winning the presidential election. It can even be hard to tell the election’s impact on the economy.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say Donald J. Trump were elected president. How would markets and the economy react?

headline: Halloween, Instagram Style

lead_paragraph: Last night Eleven from “Stranger Things” and the Snapchat deer filter may have dominated the Halloween streets, but at parties beforehand a number of celebrities went their own way. Following, our survey of the most creative costumes.

headline: Teaching Children the Real Names for Body Parts
abstract: Matter-of-fact language helps give the message that there are no parts of the anatomy that are shameful or not to be discussed.
lead_paragraph: A presidential election offers many “teachable moments”: a chance to explain democracy, the electoral process and even a certain amount of negative advertising and name-calling. But this may be the first time that a presidential election has called upon parents to discuss slang terms for genitals.

headline: Mosul Is Breached by Iraqi Forces, Heralding a New, Complex Phase
abstract: The advance is a breakthrough in efforts to reclaim the country’s second-largest city from the Islamic State, but a great deal of fighting lies ahead.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — Facing Islamic State artillery, snipers and suicide attacks, Iraq’s elite counterterrorism forces breached Mosul’s city limits on Tuesday, officers said, the first time government forces have entered the city in more than two years.

headline: To Many in China, Bai Ling’s Role in Documentary Is a Step Too Far
abstract: The Hollywood actress’s scenes in a Chinese state TV series on the Communists’ Long March were deleted after complaints from those who see her as anti-China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Nearly 20 years after government officials barred Bai Ling from returning to China, the Chinese-born Hollywood actress has once again found herself at the tense intersection of entertainment and nationalism.

headline: A South Korean Man Adopted by Americans Prepares for Deportation
abstract: Adam Crapser, 41, was denied his last appeal to remain in the U.S. last week and is making plans for a life in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Adam Crapser was adopted from South Korea nearly four decades ago, but today he languishes in an immigration detention center in Washington State awaiting deportation because his American parents never filed citizenship paperwork for him.

abstract: Two drivers and four passengers were killed when a school bus and a transit bus collided Tuesday morning, the police said. No children were on the school bus.

abstract: Chinese social media users have been in an uproar over a 2-year-old killed by an S.U.V. while her mother was distracted by a smartphone.

headline: In Greece, Property Is Debt
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: People are turning their backs on what used to be a pillar of the country’s economy and society: real estate.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — At law courts throughout Greece, people are lining up to file papers renouncing their inheritance. Not necessarily because some feckless uncle left them with a pile of debt at the end of his revels; they are turning their backs on what used to be a pillar of Greece’s economy and society: real estate. Growing personal debt, declining incomes and ever higher taxes as Greece’s depression grinds on have turned property and the dream of easy money into dread of a catastrophic burden.

headline: Why Does Education Translate to Less Support for Donald Trump?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Education', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Some readers say it has to do with intelligence and knowledge gained, while others point to a whole host of factors that could be at play.
lead_paragraph: It’s probably the biggest demographic story of this election: Hillary Clinton has made big gains with well-educated whites, particularly women. And Donald J. Trump has continued recent Republican gains in winning over less educated whites, particularly men. As Nate Cohn wrote in an article last month, education has replaced the culture wars as the defining electoral divide.

headline: Using Microservices to Encode and Publish Videos at The New York Times
abstract: We’re open sourcing our video transcoding API and video encoding presets, as part of our plan to open source our video encoding and distribution pipeline.
lead_paragraph: Video publishing at The Times is growingFor the past 10 years, the video publishing lifecycle at The New York Times has relied on vendors and in-house hardware solutions. With our growing investment in video journalism over the past couple of years, we’ve found ourselves producing more video content every month, along with supporting new initiatives such as 360-degree video and Virtual Reality. This growth has created the need to migrate to a video publishing platform that could adapt to, and keep up with, the fast pace that our newsroom demands and the continued evolution of our production process. Along with this, we needed a system that could continuously scale in both capacity and features while not compromising on either quality or reliability.

headline: College Is the Goal: Will These Teenagers Get There?
abstract: The Times is following three teenagers in Topeka, Kan., on their quest to go to college. Today, Zac and Nate talk about how their plans to take the ACT test fell apart, and an expert gives them some advice on how they can recover.​ We also catch up with TaTy, who dreams of becoming a doctor.

headline: A New Collection of High-Gloss Furniture and Accessories
abstract: Ben Pentreath lends his design eye to James Lowther’s Lacquer Company.
lead_paragraph: For a new line for James Lowther’s Lacquer Company, Ben Pentreath (owner of the London shop Pentreath & Hall and decorator to William and Kate) stays true to his reputation as someone who lovingly upends classic British design. A Georgian-style night-stand, for instance, is done in slick olive green with a shocking robin’s egg blue interior. Craftsmen at Lowther’s workshop painstakingly apply 15 layers of extracted tree sap to every piece, sanding between the coats to achieve an impeccable high-gloss finish. “Nothing compares to the depth and richness of real lacquer,” Lowther says, calling imitations “flaquer.”

Now singing and dancing across the stage of Studio 54 as the star of “Holiday Inn: The New Irving Berlin Musical,” a festive show based on the 1942 movie that gave the world “White Christmas,” the Tony-nominated star tries out the season’s standout overcoats and winter jackets.

headline: What 9 Gallery Hoppers Wore on Their Chelsea Crawl
abstract: On Saturday afternoons, well-heeled art collectors and smartly-dressed culture seekers take their post-brunch stroll through the galleries of Chelsea. Here's what they wore.
lead_paragraph: Like the first day of school and the return of black-tie galas, the Chelsea gallery crawl ushers in a new season in New York. On Saturday afternoons, well-heeled art collectors and smartly dressed culture seekers take their post-brunch strolls through blue-chip galleries like Hauser & Wirth, Gagosian and David Zwirner. Save the deal making for the workweek; Saturdays are for looking, at the art on the walls and the fashion on the streets.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Vote for Clinton’ in Spanish? Ask the Abuelas

They pretend to be busy. “They close the door,” Ms. Cañez, a 65-year-old Arizona Democratic Party field organizer, said here recently, wearing a satisfied smile and a Hillary Clinton button the size of a tea saucer.
