headline: The PG-13 Reporters Covering an R-Rated Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Children ages 10 to 14 have been facing some unusual challenges while covering the primary campaigns and general election for the book publisher Scholastic.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Erik Weibel was at a Bernie Sanders rally for Hillary Clinton in Pennsylvania when he was accosted by a group of young supporters of Donald J. Trump. The boys surrounded him, jeering and chanting, “Trump! Trump! Trump!” One made a crude comment about Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Pakistani Opposition Leader, Imran Khan, Calls Off Protest
abstract: Mr. Khan canceled his plan to shut down the capital, Islamabad, with demonstrations after a court said it would form a commission to investigate corruption.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — After days of police crackdowns on his supporters, Imran Khan, Pakistan’s opposition leader, on Tuesday called off his plan to shut down the Pakistani capital with street demonstrations, averting a potentially violent clash.

headline: Hulu Adds ESPN, ABC and Fox News to Streaming Service
abstract: Hulu has signed deals that will make networks from 21st Century Fox’s and Disney part of its forthcoming live streaming service.
lead_paragraph: Hulu’s new so-called skinny bundle is beginning to take shape.

headline: In Lily Collins’s Beauty Regimen, Rules Do Apply
abstract: The actress dishes on her signature eyebrows and her beauty obsessions.
lead_paragraph: In her latest film, “Rules Don’t Apply” (out on Nov. 23), Lily Collins, 27, plays an aspiring actress, but in real life her career is red-hot. Along with the film (and three more movies arriving in 2017), she has written a memoir titled “Unfiltered,” to be released in March. Raised mostly in Los Angeles, Ms. Collins spent summers in England, where her father, the musician Phil Collins, lives. Here, she shares her skin-care and beauty regimen.

headline: Pope Francis Says Ban on Female Priests Is Likely to Endure
abstract: In an exchange aboard his plane, the pontiff cited an apostolic letter by Pope John Paul II as a foundation for continuing the prohibition.
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic Church’s teaching that women cannot be ordained as priests is likely to last forever, Pope Francis said on Tuesday as he flew back to Rome from Sweden.

headline: Wendy Whelan to Open the Joyce Theater’s Spring Season
abstract: Ms. Whelan will perform with the choreographer Brian Brooks in “Some of a Thousand Words,” a suite of duets that opens on Feb. 28.
lead_paragraph: “Some of a Thousand Words,” a suite of duets performed by the former New York City Ballet dancer Wendy Whelan and the choreographer Brian Brooks, will have its New York premiere in February at the Joyce Theater.

headline: Presidential Election: Ryan Voted for Trump; Jay Z to Join Clinton
abstract: The candidates head to battleground states; recent polls have better news for Donald J. Trump; the House speaker votes early; and a hip-hop star will stump for Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton are making their closing arguments in the battleground states of Pennsylvania and Florida on Tuesday, courting undecided voters and trying to motivate their supporters with just one week to go until Election Day.

headline: In Exile From the Knicks, but Still at Home in Cleveland
abstract: In Cleveland, they recently unveiled a street sign for Charles Oakley. In New York, he has been estranged from the Knicks organization for years.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Charles Oakley pushed his hands into his pockets and peered at the small photo of himself on the street sign that bore his name. The younger version of himself in the photo was vintage Oakley: the high-top fade, the furrowed brow, the familiar blue and orange of his Knicks jersey.

headline: Nearly 50 Years After Leaving, a Composer Returns to Cuba to Conduct Her Work
abstract: Tania León said that going back to conduct her music in her native land is “spectacular” — and moving.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since she left for the United States nearly 50 years ago, the composer and conductor Tania León will perform in her native Cuba later this month, conducting the National Symphony Orchestra of Cuba in a program featuring one of her own works.

headline: Leuca, Andrew Carmellini’s Latest, Opens in Williamsburg
abstract: Vegetarian plates in Brooklyn, Augustine in Lower Manhattan opens, and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: LEUCA Andrew Carmellini, the chef known for the Dutch and Locanda Verde, and his partners in NoHo Hospitality have established several spaces in the new William Vale Hotel in Brooklyn, and this is the main event. It’s Mr. Carmellini’s first trip to the south of Italy; he named the restaurant for a town in the Salento area of Puglia. Chickpea Pugliese with bottarga, black spaghetti with cuttlefish puttanesca, and Sicilian pistachio cake are some of the regional fare. The dining room is wood-paneled. And under the executive chef Anthony Ricco, a wood-burning oven and grill deliver a few pizzas, roasted cabbage with Caesar flavors, smoked beets, and lamb mixed grill with eggplant Calabrese. (Thursday): William Vale Hotel, 111 North 12th Street (Wythe Avenue), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-581-5900, leuca.com.

headline: Gannett’s Failed Bid for Tronc Underscores an Ailing Industry
abstract: The newspaper industry is facing a relentless downturn, and success will require even more radical ideas.
lead_paragraph: Gannett ended its takeover bid for its rival Tronc and in the process put a new era for newspaper moguls into prominence.

headline: 5 Must-See Shows if You’re in New York This Month
abstract: The theater critic Charles Isherwood offers a look at adventurous new musicals, a revival he calls nearly “perfect,” Sutton Foster, and Shakespeare.
lead_paragraph: With the Broadway season getting especially busy, we’re here to offer monthly help on what you should see in New York. Here, the New York Times theater critic Charles Isherwood offers a look at two adventurous new musicals soon to open and a revival he calls pretty much “perfect.” There’s more: a chance to see Sutton Foster kick up her heels, and a bold take on Shakespeare’s history plays.

headline: Donald Trump’s Taxes and Hillary Clinton’s Emails
abstract: Readers discuss the latest developments in the campaign.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mets’ Jeurys Familia Arrested in Domestic Violence Case
abstract: Familia, the Mets’ top reliever, was arrested in Fort Lee, N.J., earlier this week.
lead_paragraph: Jeurys Familia, the Mets’ All-Star closer, was arrested this week in Fort Lee, N.J., in connection with a domestic violence altercation, according to a complaint filed in the town’s municipal court. Major League Baseball said it was investigating the matter.

headline: In ‘The New Negroes,’ Unpacking the Politics Behind a Word
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'New York Comedy Festival', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Baron Vaughn and Open Mike Eagle, hosts of a show at the New York Comedy Festival, want to challenge ideas about black entertainment.
lead_paragraph: This year’s New York Comedy Festival is underway, and one of its shows wants to do more than simply provoke laughter. Specifically, “The New Negroes” and its hosts, Baron Vaughn and Open Mike Eagle, want to challenge ideas about what constitutes black entertainment and expand the discussion about black life in America.

headline: In Robocall, White Nationalist Accuses Utah’s Evan McMullin of Secretly Being Gay
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: William Johnson says he believes Mr. McMullin, who is running close to Donald J. Trump in Utah, is “a closet homosexual.” Mr. McMullin called the attack “baseless lies.”
lead_paragraph: A prominent white nationalist who supports Donald J. Trump has started a smear campaign against Evan McMullin, the independent candidate who is running close with Mr. Trump in Utah, with a robocall accusing him of secretly being a homosexual who supports open borders and amnesty.

headline: Review: Verdi’s Requiem, in All Its Theatricality and Resonance
abstract: The London Symphony Orchestra performed two concerts over the weekend, including one with the star pianist Yuja Wang.
lead_paragraph: The White Light Festival, the annual Lincoln Center affair devoted to spirituality, loosely defined, reached a climax on Sunday afternoon with a stirring performance of Verdi’s Requiem, which purveys spirituality, theatrically conceived.

headline: Hatched From Peanuts, the South’s Hot New Oil
keywords: ['Peanuts', 'Oils and Fats', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Chefs', 'Food']
abstract: A small farmer’s experiment pressing green peanut oil has inspired big-name chefs.
lead_paragraph: PITTS, Ga. — There may be more improbable culinary trails than the one that leads from a red clay road here in the country’s most prolific peanut-growing state to Beyoncé’s plate at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles. But as zero-to-hero food tales go, this is a good one.

headline: A ‘High-End Hoarder’ Sells His Stuff
abstract: A sampling of memorabilia from Brett Ratner’s auction.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of memorabilia from Brett Ratner’s auction.

headline: Brett Ratner Is Selling His Stuff
abstract: A film-industry player plans to pare down his trove of Hollywood memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: A Richard Avedon portrait of Marilyn Monroe taken in New York in 1957. A newspaper front page made for the 1987 Coen brothers kidnapping caper “Raising Arizona,” complete with the headline “Where Is Nathan Jr.?” And a clapboard from the “X-Men” set.

headline: Chief Who Guided Herbalife Through Troubles Will Step Down
abstract: Michael O. Johnson, chief executive as the company endured struggles with a hedge fund manager and a federal inquiry, will become executive chairman.
lead_paragraph: As the chief executive of Herbalife, Michael O. Johnson has weathered a number of prominent struggles, including a bruising battle with the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman and a settlement with government regulators over the nutritional supplement maker’s business practices.

headline: Move Over Bill Murray and Eddie Vedder! I’m a Cubbie
abstract: How I went to Chicago for the weekend and became a Cubs fanatic.
lead_paragraph: When I got to Chicago on Thursday, I felt disoriented.

headline: The Best New TV Shows and Movies on Netflix
abstract: Every month, Netflix adds a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Some of those movies and TV shows are bad. Some are good. Here is a list of the good.
lead_paragraph: ‘Paddington’ (Nov. 16)

headline: The Price of Certainty
keywords: ['Psychology and Psychologists', 'Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Brain']
abstract: There's more to what you believe than you think.
lead_paragraph: There's more to what you believe than you think.

headline: The Price of Certainty
abstract: There’s more to what you believe than you think.
lead_paragraph: It’s alarming to see how polarized politics have become in the United States. The wider the gulf grows, the more people seem to be certain that the other side is wrong. Certainty can be a dangerous thing.

headline: Halloween Dress-Up for a Cause
abstract: Bette Midler hosts the Hulaween Bash, MoMA P.S.1 hosts “White House of Terror,” and the Harlem School of the Arts holds a masquerade ball.
lead_paragraph: Bette Midler hosts the Hulaween Bash, MoMA P.S.1 hosts “White House of Terror,” and the Harlem School of the Arts holds a masquerade ball.

headline: Clinton-Connected Consulting Firm Sues Republican Strategist Ed Rollins
abstract: The lawsuit, filed in New York State by Teneo, claims defamation and breach of contract over comments Mr. Rollins made on a Fox Business program.
lead_paragraph: Teneo, the corporate consulting firm with ties to the Clintons, filed papers to sue Ed Rollins, a veteran Republican strategist and chairman of a Donald J. Trump super PAC, for defamation and breach of contract over comments made about the firm in recent days.

headline: The Khizr Khan Voters
abstract: American Muslims will have a say in this election.
lead_paragraph: As this ghoulish, absurd spectacle of an election sputters to the finish line, we can confidently say there is one winner: American Muslims.

headline: Review: Marina Abramovic’s ‘Walk Through Walls,’ a Memoir of Masochism and Pretension
abstract: The performance artist, who had a popular 2010 retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, implicitly bids readers to warm their hands on the blaze of her greatness.
lead_paragraph: Marina Abramovic’s first major performance art piece was based on an old Russian drinking game. In front of an audience in 1973, she took a series of sharp knives and stabbed each as quickly as she could into the spaces between her fingers. (In the game, there is only one knife and you take a drink for each nick.) Blood went everywhere.

headline: What You Should Watch Tuesday Night
abstract: This evening, check out the season finale of “Atlanta” and a “30 for 30” documentary.
lead_paragraph: ‘30 for 30: Hit It Hard,’ 8 p.m., ESPN

headline: Review: ‘Hacksaw Ridge’ Has the Guts and the Glory. But Where’s the Gun?
abstract: Mel Gibson’s new film tells the true story of Desmond Doss, a conscientious objector who refused to bear arms but still won the Medal of Honor in World War II.
lead_paragraph: Mel Gibson can be accused of many things, but subtlety is not one of them. Even at his worst — I mean as a filmmaker, not a political thinker — he consistently proves to be an able craftsman and a shrewd showman. “Hacksaw Ridge,” the first feature he has directed since “Apocalypto,” a decade ago, is a bluntly effective faith-and-flag war drama, the true story of a remarkable hero with a knot of moral tension at its center.

headline: Costumes for a Cause
abstract: Bette Midler hosts the Hulaween Bash, MoMA P.S.1 hosts “White House of Terror,” and the Harlem School of the Arts holds a masquerade ball.
lead_paragraph: Costumes aside, Halloween offered philanthropic causes a festive way to raise money and awareness. Bette Midler brought back her “Hocus Pocus” character to life for her annual Hulaween Bash on Oct. 28, which benefits the New York Restoration Project. MoMA P.S. 1 and Susanne Bartsch (center, in red cape) held its fifth annual Halloween party on Oct. 29. And the Harlem School of the Arts held a masquerade ball on Oct. 31 at the Plaza Hotel.

headline: Review: In ‘The Eagle Huntress,’ a Girl From Mongolia Soars
abstract: A teenager from a nomadic family bucks gender norms by raising a bird and training it to hunt in this documentary.
lead_paragraph: Aisholpan is a 13-year-old girl who lives in Mongolia, dividing her time between a boarding school and her nomadic family’s campsite. With the release of “The Eagle Huntress,” a thrilling new documentary directed by Otto Bell, she may well become something else: a pop-culture heroine with the power to inspire girls (and not only girls) everywhere. It would not be surprising on future Halloweens to spot a handful of Aisholpans, dressed in traditional fur-and-embroidery hunting gear, pigtails fastened with pink bows, amid the throngs of Elsas and Katnisses.

headline: Review: ‘Anastasia,’ a Grand Duchess or a Great Pretender?
abstract: Kenneth MacMillan’s ballet, performed by the Royal Ballet with Natalia Osipova, revolves around a woman who claimed to be the surviving daughter of Czar Nicholas II.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Royalty, revolution, madness, memory. These are the potentially explosive ingredients of the choreographer Kenneth MacMillan’s “Anastasia,” his 1971 full-length ballet currently being performed by the Royal Ballet here for the first time since 2004, and offering the enticing prospect of the Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova making her debut in the title role.

headline: Review: ‘Don’t Call Me Son’ Considers Identity and Fluidity
abstract: In this Brazilian film from Anna Muylaert, an androgynous teenager discovers that the woman who raised him isn’t his biological mother.
lead_paragraph: Who are you? That question nags at Pierre (Naomi Nero), the brooding androgynous protagonist of Anna Muylaert’s “Don’t Call Me Son.” This Brazilian film’s title takes on a double meaning after Pierre discovers that Arcay (Dani Nefussi), the woman he presumed to be his biological mother, stole him from the hospital when he was a baby. That upsetting news arrives when the authorities burst into their shabby apartment, slap handcuffs on Arcay, then immediately subject her and Pierre to DNA tests.

headline: In Ukraine, Not Even the Top Banker Trusts the Banks
abstract: A new law in Ukraine required lawmakers and officials to declare their assets, and the results did not inspire confidence in the country’s economic and banking institutions.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Many of the lawmakers and officials responsible for inspiring public trust in Ukraine’s economic and banking institutions have little faith that their own wealth would be safe in the country’s banks, according to recently mandated financial disclosures.

headline: There Are Many Ways to Map Election Results. We’ve Tried Most of Them.
abstract: There’s not always one form that reveals every trend in the most contextually accurate and accessible way.
lead_paragraph: There’s not always one form that reveals every trend in the most contextually accurate and accessible way.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Fernanda Santos, John Schwartz and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Mosul, Clinton, Pakistan: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: South Africa’s Rising Art Star Builds His New Stage in Chicago
abstract: Kemang Wa Lehulere’s work can seem very abstract, but a closer look reveals allusive, layered references to his own personal history and that of his country.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — High above a gallery at the Art Institute of Chicago, balancing on a bright red ladder, Kemang Wa Lehulere worked intently on a school blackboard, his slashes of white chalk gradually cohering to reveal a rounded form. A video of a cigarette slowly burning played as male voices sang.

headline: Review: In ‘Sagittarius Ponderosa,’ New Self Confronts Old
abstract: This MJ Kaufman play centers on a transgender character who finds solace in an enormous tree as he deals with issues of identity, intimacy and family.
lead_paragraph: Archer, the central character in the transgender playwright MJ Kaufman’s “Sagittarius Ponderosa,” used to be Angela. He still is, as far as his family knows, and he doesn’t tell them otherwise when he goes home to Oregon as his father is dying. At 29, he can’t quite work up the courage to explain to them who he really is.

headline: Clinton, Trump, Mosul: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Court Opinion in Airbnb Case
abstract: The ruling by Judge Christopher R. Cooper of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia in a case against Airbnb by Gregory Selden.
lead_paragraph: The ruling by Judge Christopher R. Cooper of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia in a case against Airbnb by Gregory Selden.

headline: Federal Judge Blocks Racial Discrimination Suit Against Airbnb
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION']
abstract: Claims that Airbnb hosts discriminated against customers must be settled in private arbitration because of the service’s user agreement, the judge ruled.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb on Tuesday avoided a potential class-action lawsuit by customers who accused hosts of racial discrimination when a federal judge ruled that the company’s arbitration policy prohibited its users from suing.

headline: FilmStruck Streaming Service Places a Big Bet on Cinephiles
abstract: Turner Classic Movies and the Criterion Collection hope FilmStruck appeals to viewers who want to supplement other streaming services or cable.
lead_paragraph: While the cable industry wonders how many of us will be willing to cut the cord and do without a traditional television package, its online rivals have moved on to a more timely question: How many cords — albeit invisible, cheaper cords — will we be willing to pay for at once?

headline: YouTube Agrees to Pay Royalties, Ending German Music Dispute
abstract: The disagreement between the internet service and Germany’s main music rights organization had restricted access to music videos on YouTube since 2009.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For years, YouTube users in Germany have searched for music videos on the online streaming service, only to be confronted with one of the most hated icons on the internet here: a small red TV-shaped symbol informing them they were unable to view the video.

headline: Obamas Have Fun With Trick-or-Treaters
abstract: President Obama danced to “Thriller” and sang “Purple Rain” to trick-or-treaters at the White House Halloween celebration.
lead_paragraph: President Obama danced to “Thriller” and sang “Purple Rain” to trick-or-treaters at the White House Halloween celebration.

headline: Asserting a Muslim Fashion Identity
abstract: From Vogue Arabia to New York Fashion Week, Muslim consumers and designers are demanding global recognition and respect of their cultural and commercial clout.
lead_paragraph: Last week, quietly and without much fanfare, the 22nd global Vogue went live.

headline: David H. Brooks, 61, Dies Serving Time for Insider Trading
abstract: The founder of the military armor maker DHB Industries was serving 17 years for insider trading and fraudulently enriching himself.
lead_paragraph: David H. Brooks, a former military contractor who was found guilty of insider trading and fraudulently enriching himself through company funds, died on Thursday in prison in Danbury, Conn. He was 61.

headline: What Does Modest Fashion Mean?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Religion and Belief', 'Women and Girls', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The term bridges religions and borders, bringing together women in unexpected ways.
lead_paragraph: A Muslim, an Orthodox Jew and a religious Christian walked into a room, but it wasn’t a bar and this was no joke. On the contrary, representatives from each of the Abrahamic religions had gathered during fashion month at New York University for the Meeting Through Modesty fashion symposium to discuss something they take very seriously: modest style.

headline: Donald Trump’s Math Takes His Towers to Greater Heights
abstract: When Mr. Trump wants his buildings to seem bigger than they actually are, he enlarges them the same way he has thwarted long odds and defied reality throughout the election season: with sheer bluster.
lead_paragraph: Of the many rivals Donald J. Trump has accumulated over four decades in business and, now, presidential politics, one of the earliest was a New York City skyscraper with the boldness to stand taller than his own.

headline: City Unveils Possible Routes for Streetcar in Brooklyn and Queens
abstract: The route would have a dedicated lane in traffic where possible, an effort that could prompt anger among drivers over the loss of street space and parking.
lead_paragraph: As Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration moves forward on plans for a new streetcar line from Queens to Brooklyn, city officials on Tuesday unveiled the different routes they are considering for the project.

headline: Glaxo’s Fallout in China
abstract: A whistle-blower working for GlaxoSmithKline began sending anonymous tips about fraud and corruption at its operation in China. Here’s what happened next.
lead_paragraph: After a whistle-blower working for one of the world’s biggest pharmaceutical companies began sending anonymous tips about fraud and corruption inside its operation in China, authorities there moved in. They arrested top executives and corporate detectives the company had hired to track down the whistle-blower. Here is how the events transpired.

headline: Drug Giant Faced a Reckoning as China Took Aim at Bribery
abstract: China sought to make an example of GlaxoSmithKline in a case that involved bribery of doctors and investigators and ended with guilty pleas and record penalties.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Peter Humphrey was in the bathroom of his Shanghai apartment when the police kicked the door off its hinges and knocked him to the ground. Nearly two dozen officers stormed his home. They confiscated files, laptops and hard drives related to his work as a corporate investigator.

headline: World Series: Here’s How the Chicago Cubs Won Game 6
abstract: An offensive outburst by the heart of Chicago’s order gave Jake Arrieta plenty of room to beat the Indians, who struggled defensively and at the plate.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Game 7 here.

headline: College Football Playoff Ranking: Texas A&M Is a Surprise No. 4
abstract: The first three teams were, as widely expected, Alabama, Clemson and Michigan. But the Aggies slid ahead of undefeated Washington in the selection committee’s first rankings.
lead_paragraph: The College Football Playoff selection committee inaugurated a month of debate Tuesday by releasing the initial rankings of its third season. Alabama, the defending national champion, held the top spot, followed by Clemson, Michigan and Texas A&M.

headline: Plays Coming Soon From a Movie Screen Near You
abstract: “Terms of Endearment” and “Clue” are among several films being adapted for the theater.
lead_paragraph: The recognizable brand of Hollywood movies has led to a parade of musical adaptations and, more recently, a surge of plays. Despite a poor track record — “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” and “Misery” were neither critical nor commercial hits — “Dead Poets Society” and “Terms of Endearment” are both onstage now, and more attempts are on the way. Even Quentin Tarantino has publicly mused about “The Hateful Eight” onstage. In the meantime, here’s a look at movies-turned-plays that are further along:

headline: For Jason Sudeikis, It’s Time to Seize the Stage in ‘Dead Poets Society’
abstract: The former “S.N.L.” star Jason Sudeikis plays the stage version of John Keating, the teacher made famous by Robin Williams.
lead_paragraph: Still soaking in the happy haze that surrounds you after you’ve welcomed a new life into the world, Jason Sudeikis was contemplating his expanding obligations as an adult.

headline: Infections, Not Antibiotics, May Be Tied to Childhood Obesity
abstract: Some studies suggest giving antibiotics to infants may raise the risk of childhood obesity. But the infections themselves may be to blame.
lead_paragraph: Is the use of antibiotics in infancy tied to childhood obesity? Some studies suggest so, but a new analysis suggests the link may be with infections rather than antibiotics.

headline: As South Sudan Troops Killed and Raped, U.N. Forces Didn’t Stop Them
abstract: An investigation found that a peacekeeping mission failed to act in July as government soldiers carried out an attack on civilians, including aid workers.
lead_paragraph: As South Sudanese troops entered the Terrain Hotel and began attacking the civilians — many of them Western aid workers — who had sought refuge inside, frantic pleas for help to United Nations peacekeepers stationed less than a mile away went unanswered.

headline: Wells Fargo to Pay $50 Million to Settle Home Appraisal Overcharges
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Appraisals and Valuation (Property)']
abstract: The bank will reimburse more than 250,000 customers after claims they were overcharged for home appraisals ordered after they defaulted on their mortgage loans.
lead_paragraph: In the latest hit to the battered bank, Wells Fargo has agreed to pay $50 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused the bank of overcharging hundreds of thousands of homeowners for appraisals ordered after the homeowners defaulted on their mortgage loans.

headline: Maurice Sendak’s Estate Is Awarded Most of a Book Collection
keywords: ['Wills and Estates', 'Museums', 'Archives and Records', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The estate mostly prevailed in a legal dispute with the Rosenbach Museum and Library, which contended that Mr. Sendak had pledged many rare books to it in his will.
lead_paragraph: The estate of the author Maurice Sendak has emerged mostly victorious in a legal battle with the Rosenbach Museum and Library in Philadelphia, which had been the repository of thousands of his original drawings and parts of his book collection before his death in 2012. In a ruling in Connecticut probate court, a judge awarded the bulk of the disputed book collection to the Sendak estate, not to the museum.

headline: Jurors’ Questions Hint at Division in Trial on Lane Closings
abstract: Lawyers for Bridget Anne Kelly and Bill Baroni, former associates of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, accused the judge of encouraging a guilty verdict.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Jurors deliberating the fate of two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey accused in a bizarre plot to close lanes at the George Washington Bridge sent back three questions on Tuesday hinting that they may be divided.

headline: Montreal Police Face a Storm of Criticism Over Surveillance of a Journalist
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Investigators looking into corruption within the Montreal police force for almost six months focused their attention on a reporter who had no apparent connection to the case.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Investigators looking into corruption within Montreal’s police force for almost six months focused their attention on one of Quebec’s most prominent journalists even though he had neither reported on the corruption case nor had any strong connection to it.

headline: Seeking a Bargain in a Bottle of Water
abstract: A New Yorker decides that she shouldn’t have to pay tourist prices.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Review: ‘Attorney Street,’ a Gothic Elegy for a Fleeing Here and Now
abstract: Edgar Oliver’s performance piece delves into life’s evanescence, from the father he never knew to a cracked curb on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Oliver conducts the most extraordinary séances. In “Attorney Street,” his seriously haunting new performance piece at the Axis Theater Company, the phantoms summoned by this one-of-a-kind monologuist are both vivid and elusive, as such manifestations must be.

headline: 7 Men Accused in Sex-Trafficking Ring in U.S. and Mexico
abstract: Federal officials announced an indictment in Manhattan and the arrests of six of the defendants, who they said forced women and girls into prostitution.
lead_paragraph: Seven men have been indicted on sex trafficking charges in what federal officials said on Tuesday was an international organization that exploited adult and underage women for more than a decade in Mexico and the United States.

headline: Avoiding Taxes, Trump-Style
abstract: Having spent his career trying not to pay taxes, why would Donald Trump want to fix the system?
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s claim that he was smart for figuring out how not to pay federal income taxes was obnoxious when he said it, at least for the millions of Americans who pay their fair share. Now we learn that he was able to avoid some of those taxes decades ago with a tactic that is illegal now and was highly dubious even then.

headline: Behind Closed Doors, Measures to Reform City’s Campaign Laws Raise Concerns
abstract: With as many as 12 bills in the works, the City Council’s efforts to reform campaign finance laws have some worried that the changes might come at a cost.
lead_paragraph: Three years after the 2013 elections revealed serious flaws in New York City’s campaign finance laws, the City Council may finally be moving to fix some of the worst problems — but not without including a few changes that would benefit individual Council members.

headline: Fox Honors Ailing Director Who Makes All the Plays
abstract: Instead of being back in a production truck at the World Series, Bill Webb is dealing with injuries from a fall in addition to having been battling brain cancer.
lead_paragraph: You know Bill Webb by his work. He directs baseball broadcasts for Fox and Mets games for SNY, distilling live shots, graphics and replays into cohesive narratives with verve and urgency. He is perhaps the best baseball television director ever.

headline: Cosby Lawyers Want to Suppress Testimony About Quaaludes
abstract: The lawyers want to have criminal charges dismissed against Mr. Cosby.
lead_paragraph: Norristown, Pa — Lawyers for Bill Cosby argued Tuesday that deposition testimony he provided in a civil suit more than 10 years ago, including an acknowledgment that he gave women Quaaludes in an effort to have sex with them, should be suppressed in his criminal trial next year.

headline: A Union of Politics and News Ends With Both Contaminated
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: CNN has tried to distance itself from the actions of Donna Brazile, its paid political operative, but the moment will be wasted if boundaries are not reset.
lead_paragraph: The decision by ABC News to hire George Stephanopoulos in 1996 tripped alarms throughout American journalism.

headline: Safer to Puff, E-Cigarettes Can’t Shake Their Reputation as a Menace
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'E-Cigarettes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A growing number of experts say that the portrayal of e-cigarettes as a public health threat is a profound disservice to smokers who could benefit from them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A decade after electronic cigarettes were introduced in the United States, use has flattened, sales have slowed and, this fall, NJoy, once one of the country’s biggest e-cigarette manufacturers, filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Black Turnout Soft in Early Voting, Boding Ill for Hillary Clinton
abstract: The numbers in several states have begun pointing to a slump many Democrats feared might materialize without the nation’s first black president on the ticket.
lead_paragraph: African-Americans are failing to vote at the robust levels they did four years ago in several states that could help decide the presidential election, creating a vexing problem for Hillary Clinton as she clings to a deteriorating lead over Donald J. Trump with Election Day just a week away.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, November 2, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I’m just a headline — the bad president, the bad guy, who is killing the good guys. You know this narrative. The real reason is toppling the government.”

headline: Indians’ Heavy Reliance on Bullpen Probably Won’t Resume in Regular Season
abstract: Cleveland Manager Terry Francona has been quick to turn to relievers like Bryan Shaw and Andrew Miller in the postseason, but over a 162-game schedule that tendency would soon wear them out.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — No pitcher in the majors has been more durable the last four seasons than Bryan Shaw of the Cleveland Indians. Shaw has pitched in 299 games, the most in the major leagues in that time, and led the Indians with 10 postseason appearances before Game 6 of the World Series against the Chicago Cubs on Tuesday.

headline: New Research Center to Explore Ethics of Artificial Intelligence
abstract: The president of Carnegie Mellon University, which will establish the center, said injecting ethical discussions into A.I. is necessary as the technology advances.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Mellon University plans to announce on Wednesday that it will create a research center that focuses on the ethics of artificial intelligence.

headline: F.B.I.’s Email Disclosure Broke a Pattern Followed Even This Summer
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: At the Justice Department’s urging, the F.B.I. did not actively pursue cases on the Clinton Foundation and a former Trump campaign chairman so close to the election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. and Justice Department faced a hard decision in two investigations this past summer that had the potential to rock the presidential election. The first case involved Donald J. Trump’s campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, and secretive business dealings in Ukraine. The second focused on Hillary Clinton’s relationships with donors to her family foundation.

headline: Can Turkey’s Democracy Survive President Erdogan?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Editorials', 'Kurds']
abstract: As more people are arrested and media outlets closed, other countries need to speak the bitter truth to Turkey.
lead_paragraph: What is unnerving in President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s march to authoritarianism is how dismally familiar it is: the coup that becomes a pretext for a massive roundup of real and imagined enemies; the claims to be the one man who can withstand the onslaught of foreign foes; the invocation of purported historical slights; the silencing of the news media. The world has seen this before in other countries. The pattern is tried and true; the tough question is how to break it.

headline: Criminal Complaint in Jeurys Familia Case
abstract: Familia, the Mets’ top reliever, was arrested in Fort Lee, N.J., earlier this week.
lead_paragraph: Familia, the Mets’ top reliever, was arrested in Fort Lee, N.J., earlier this week.

headline: Natalie Babbitt, 84, Dies; Took On Immortality in ‘Tuck Everlasting’
abstract: Ms. Babbitt’s book (one of many) about a family that cannot die found a fervent readership and inspired two films and a Broadway musical.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Babbitt, a celebrated children’s author and illustrator whose ruminative novel “Tuck Everlasting,” about a family’s immortality, found a fervent readership and inspired two films and a Broadway musical, died on Monday at her home in Hamden, Conn. She was 84.

headline: John Hicks, Star Lineman at Ohio State and Top Rookie for the Giants, Dies at 65
abstract: An Outland Trophy winner under Woody Hayes with the Buckeyes, he played for the Giants in the N.F.L. after being drafted third over all.
lead_paragraph: John Hicks, a standout offensive lineman at Ohio State University who became a first-round draft pick and rookie of the year for the Giants in 1974 but whose professional career rapidly fizzled, died on Saturday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 65.

headline: Just Dandy
abstract: Andrew Kingsley answers a poser.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I do love a riddle, and Andrew Kingsley provides us with a classic one today, one purported to have no answer but with an interesting literary history.

headline: With Win Over Barcelona, Manchester City Begins to Write Its Own History
abstract: The 3-1 victory does not mean that the mission set by Manchester City’s owners, to turn a once-unfashionable team into a member of the elite, is complete.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — It was not an end — Pep Guardiola was quite clear — but a start. The night Manchester City beat Barcelona, the night “the best team in the world” was swept aside by Sergio Agüero, Kevin De Bruyne and Ilkay Gundogan did not represent the end of Guardiola’s work.

headline: ‘Rabbit Lady’ Challenges Police in Brooklyn Cruelty Case
abstract: In very small steps, proceedings began in the opening day of the trial of Dorota Trec, who is charged with 126 counts of cruelty and is acting as her own lawyer.
lead_paragraph: The detective took the stand to talk about the defendant and her rabbits. There were a large number of them — nearly 200, it turned out.

headline: Weakened by Scandal, South Korea’s President Picks New Premier
abstract: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea replaced her prime minister on Wednesday as she struggled to regain some of the authority lost to a growing political scandal.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea replaced the country’s prime minister, the No. 2 official in her government, on Wednesday as she struggled to regain some of the authority lost to a growing political scandal.

headline: After an Eternity, the Cubs and the Indians Will Have to Wait One More Day
abstract: With six R.B.I. from Addison Russell, the Cubs forced a Game 7, giving them a chance to become the first team to rally from a three-games-to-one World Series deficit since 1985.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Chicago Cubs, who have endured 108 years without a championship, and the Cleveland Indians, who have waited a mere 68, are nothing if not patient.

headline: 37th World Series Game 7 Represents Rare Opportunity for Cubs or Indians
abstract: Chicago’s victory in Game 6 forced a decisive game in Cleveland, where one or the other long-suffering team will soon be able to celebrate winning baseball’s championship.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — It was 71 degrees at game time — which was 7:10 p.m. back in Chicago — when Josh Tomlin threw a baseball with 108 stitches to Dexter Fowler. This was the start of Game 6 of the World Series on Tuesday, when the Chicago Cubs faced elimination against the Cleveland Indians.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Syria, Pope Francis: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘The Story of Cats’ and Marilyn Manson in ‘Salem’
abstract: “The Story of Cats,” a “Nature” program, is hard to resist. And Marilyn Manson joins “Salem” as a Sweeney Todd-like barber.
lead_paragraph: “The Story of Cats,” a two-part “Nature” presentation, is hard to resist for pure visual beauty. Marilyn Manson joins the cast of “Salem” as a bloodthirsty barber. And Triumph the Insult Comic Dog tries to find humor in the final days of the presidential election.

headline: Report on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Narrows Search Area, if Not Mystery
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: The report said debris indicated that the plane had not been configured to prepare for a landing or for ditching in the sea.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Extensive tracking of debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared more than two years ago in the southern Indian Ocean with 239 people onboard, has further narrowed the search area in a remote swath of ocean off the coast of Western Australia.

headline: Word + Quiz: maverick
abstract: This word has appeared in 224 New York Times articles in the past year.

abstract: Kacper Kowalski’s passion for paragliding led him to ditch an architectural career for one as a flying photographer chronicling stunning, everyday scenes in his native Poland.
lead_paragraph: Kacper Kowalski’s passion for paragliding led him to ditch an architectural career for one as a flying photographer chronicling stunning, everyday scenes in his native Poland.

headline: Indians Would Like to Forget Their Adventures in the Outfield
abstract: Cleveland’s unraveling in Game 6 began early, when Lonnie Chisenhall and Tyler Naquin couldn’t decide who should catch a seemingly routine fly ball.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Indians’ unraveling that eventually forced a decisive Game 7 against the Chicago Cubs began in the first inning on Tuesday at Progressive Field. Addison Russell lifted what appeared to be a harmless fly ball to the right side of the outfield for the final out of the inning. But given some of the adventures the Indians’ outfield has endured in this series, the play was anything but routine.

headline: Hillary’s Male Tormentors
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Clinton’s story is one of men’s weaknesses as well as a woman’s strength.
lead_paragraph: Weiner or no Weiner, Hillary Clinton is likely to be our next president.

headline: How Health Care Hurts Your Paycheck
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Employers make the health insurance decisions for many employees. It is time to give workers more control.
lead_paragraph: If there is a coherent theme to this year’s election, it is the growing economic frustration of working Americans. While trade has been the chief scapegoat, a major culprit has received much less attention: the rising cost of health insurance.

headline: An Election Is Not a Suicide Mission
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'ABORTION', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: When is a cause worth courting chaos?
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 22, 1973, the Supreme Court of the United States, by a 7-2 majority, discovered a sweeping constitutional right to terminate a pregnancy and struck down abortion laws across the country. Within five years, the number of abortions in America annually climbed above a million, where it would remain for 20 years.

headline: Donald Trump Voters, Just Hear Me Out
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Fellow Americans, your concerns should be taken seriously. But let’s also look seriously at the candidates.
lead_paragraph: This is my last column until after the election, so I’d like to address the people least likely to read it: Donald Trump voters. Who knows? Maybe I’ll get lucky and a few of them will buy fish wrapped in this column, and they’ll accidentally peruse it! Desperate times call for desperate measures.

headline: What’s Wrong With Politics? Let’s Start With the Benches
abstract: Maybe architecture can help shift parliamentary politics into a new era.
lead_paragraph: It’s ironic, really. Citizens have never been more distrustful of government, yet to alter certain sacred spaces would be considered sacrilege. We wouldn’t dare tamper with the chambers of Capitol Hill, for example … but what if we did?

headline: A Judge Keeps His Eye on Police Spies
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Muslim Americans', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Editorials']
abstract: A proposed settlement to lawsuits over the New York Police Department’s surveillance of Muslims doesn’t go far enough to protect citizens.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department has had a long history of trampling on the constitutional rights of law-abiding citizens engaged in political movements and other activities through illegal and suspicionless surveillance.

headline: The Secret Lives of Hotel Doormen
keywords: ['Doormen', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mobile Applications', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Building Service Employees']
abstract: Technology can seem a plague to the many service workers it displaces. But one hotel doorman knows there are things an app cannot do — things that make him indispensable.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — If the entrance of a hotel is its own sort of stage, then few actors have commanded one quite like Gary Sykes, head doorman at the Thompson Chicago.

headline: Taking On Militants After Acquittals in an Armed Standoff
abstract: What effect will militia members' court victory have on future confrontations?

headline: Photographing Everyday Beauty From Above
abstract: Kacper Kowalski’s passion for paragliding led him to ditch an architectural career for one as a flying photographer chronicling stunning, everyday scenes in his native Poland.
lead_paragraph: For those of us who take our passions to the extreme, it can be difficult to find a middle ground. With the Polish photographer Kacper Kowalski, who began his career as an architect reaching for the skies above and now is a photographer who works in the sky shooting the ground below, the situation was literal. But Mr. Kowalski didn’t start flying to photograph — he photographed to fly, and he did so in order to fuel what he describes as an addiction.

headline: Across the Fence
abstract: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to current events?
lead_paragraph: This is an illustration that went with a recent Op-Ed essay in The Times.

abstract: Why does it make some people uncomfortable when a successful businessman creates jobs and hires refugees?
lead_paragraph: Article: ‘For Helping Immigrants, Chobani’s Founder Draws Threats’

headline: The Story of the S.A.S., Britain’s First Special Operations Unit
abstract: Ben Macintyre’s “Rogue Heroes” is a history of Britain’s — and the world’s — first special operations unit.
lead_paragraph: ROGUE HEROESThe History of the SAS, Britain’s Secret Special Forces Unit That Sabotaged the Nazis and Changed the Nature of WarBy Ben MacintyreIllustrated. 380 pp. Crown. $28.

headline: Trevor Noah Wasn’t Expecting Liberal Hatred
abstract: The host of “The Daily Show” on his childhood in apartheid-era South Africa and getting comfortable in Jon Stewart’s chair.
lead_paragraph: Your memoir, “Born a Crime,” is a striking depiction of your life in South Africa both under and after apartheid. How has that experience formed your perspective on the divisions we’re seeing in America because of the election? America is the place that always seems to treat the symptoms and not the cause. In South Africa, we’re very good at trying to go for the cause of racism. One thing that really never happened here, which is strange to me, was a period where white America had to reconcile with what it had done to black Americans.

headline: Roads to Happy
abstract: If you want to be happy for the rest of your life, new books suggest working hard and playing nice; taking it a few steps at a time; watching your pocketbook; and just not trying so much.
lead_paragraph: I’m a happy person. Here’s my secret: Every day I anticipate things will go horribly wrong, and when they don’t I am surprised, grateful and a little bit elated. For example, today I don’t have a brain tumor! My children can be obnoxious, but they’re not (as far as I know) plotting ways to trigger my life insurance policy! There’s always tomorrow, of course, but right now things look good. I’m the Queen of Low Expectations, and proud of it.

headline: He’s Not O.K., and Neither Is She: A Romance
abstract: A. L. Kennedy’s “Serious Sweet” considers whether two people with crippling anxieties can take any real comfort in each other.
lead_paragraph: SERIOUS SWEETBy A. L. Kennedy483 pp. Little A. $24.95.

headline: A Town’s Secret Propels ‘The Mothers,’ a Lauded Debut Novel
abstract: A mother’s suicide and her daughter’s pain drive Brit Bennett’s “The Mothers.”
lead_paragraph: THE MOTHERSBy Brit Bennett278 pp. Riverhead Books. $26.

headline: Is It O.K. to Double-Cross a Swindler?
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Lying', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Consumer Protection', 'Doctors', 'Religion and Belief', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when to renege on a deal with a scammer, what is owed the seller of used goods and whether a doctor should offer to pray for her patients.
lead_paragraph: I manage my elderly father’s financial affairs and was unable to stop payment on a check he sent to a tech-support scammer. His bank investigated and determined, properly, that they could not intervene because he had signed the check. My phone calls to this company bore no fruit, so I offered them a choice: If they didn’t return half the money, I would report them to the consumer-affairs division of their state’s attorney general’s office and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, register complaints on websites and so forth. My instructions were that they were to send me a certified check, made out to my father, by a certain date. They did send me a check, which cleared. But it was not certified, and it arrived after the due date. Do I have an obligation to uphold my end of the deal, by not registering complaints about an outfit that is clearly scamming elderly people? Charles W. Mitchell, Parkton, Md.

headline: When Hillary and Donald Were Friends
abstract: The story of their transactional relationship offers a window on rarefied New York.
lead_paragraph: The sensational, spidery plot of the most gripping game of thrones in modern history is best captured by two images. The first is from Donald J. Trump’s extravagant third wedding at his Mar-a-Lago estate in 2005: The junior senator from New York, glowing in gold silk and pearls, smiles up at the mogul in white tie with genuine delight as he says something that cracks up Hillary, Bill and Trump’s bejeweled bride, Melania. Donald and Hillary look “just like teenagers in love” in the flashbulb moment, as David Patrick Columbia, the editor of the website New York Social Diary, notes dryly. The second, more sinister image is from the St. Louis presidential debate last month: A Tang-colored Trump looms behind Hillary like a horror-movie fiend as she makes a point, while three of Trump’s guests in the front row, women who accused Bill of sexual assault, give her the stink eye and Chelsea and Bill sit nearby looking grim. What a difference a decade makes: from a Babylonian celebration, with Hillary and Bill cozying up to Donald, to a seething face-off, with Donald summoning ghosts from Bill’s scandalous past and threatening to throw Hillary in the clink if he’s elected.

headline: The Party That Wants to Make Poland Great Again
abstract: In just a year, Law and Justice has shown how a far-right nationalist government in Europe really governs — and how far it can push the limits of democracy.
lead_paragraph: Last May, Poland’s ruling Law and Justice Party, a right-wing nationalist party committed to upending Poland’s established liberal order, convened an “audit” of the previous government in the high-Modernist Parliament building in Warsaw. Since winning a decisive electoral victory in October 2015, Law and Justice had set about dismantling many of the structural checks and balances designed to prevent a return to the authoritarianism of the Soviet era. The audit, called with little advance warning, was intended to discredit Civic Platform, the centrist, pro-European party that ruled Poland from 2007 to 2015.

headline: Presidential Election: Trump Hits $100 Million in Small Donations in October, Team Says
abstract: Will gender be a consistent theme as Hillary Clinton makes her final argument? Will Republicans “come home” to Donald J. Trump? What to look for as Election Day nears.
lead_paragraph: With only six days left in the presidential race, Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump are working overtime to turn out voters, but their power to shift the direction of the race diminishes every day.

headline: In ‘Fantastic Beasts,’ Rowling Cloaks Politics in a Tale of Magic
abstract: The writer has spoken out against “Brexit” and Trump, and her “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them” script imagines parallels in 1920s New York.
lead_paragraph: When “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them” opens on Nov. 18, it will be the first time fans of J. K. Rowling’s wizards and witches will get to see her cast a cinematic spell that isn’t based on one of her novels.

headline: How the Internet Is Loosening Our Grip on the Truth
keywords: ['Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Hoaxes and Pranks']
abstract: A wider variety of news sources was supposed to be the bulwark of a rational age. Instead, we are roiled by biases, gorging on what confirms our ideas and shunning what does not.
lead_paragraph: Next week, if all goes well, someone will win the presidency. What happens after that is anyone’s guess. Will the losing side believe the results? Will the bulk of Americans recognize the legitimacy of the new president? And will we all be able to clean up the piles of lies, hoaxes and other dung that have been hurled so freely in this hyper-charged, fact-free election?

headline: Trump, Waking a ‘Sleeping Giant,’ Helps Clinton Build an Unlikely Firewall
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s alienation of key voting blocs has bolstered Democrats in the West and South, and Republicans fear it could be a grim glimpse of their future.
lead_paragraph: CASA GRANDE, Ariz. — Since moving to Arizona 15 years ago, Nieves Lorenzo watched as Hispanics grew in numbers but only haltingly asserted themselves as a political force. Then came Donald J. Trump’s presidential candidacy.

headline: Despite Similarities, Candidate for New Jersey Governor Says He’s No Corzine
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'George Washington Bridge Scandal (2013)', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Philip D. Murphy, a former Goldman Sachs executive, appears to have wrapped up the Democratic nomination a year before the election.
lead_paragraph: EDISON, N.J. — A year before the election to succeed Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, the race for the Democratic nomination has become more of a coronation than a contest, with one name emerging as the likely candidate: Philip D. Murphy.

headline: Living in Bethel, Conn.
abstract: Bethel’s relatively low home prices and well-regarded schools draw young families, and retirees are attracted to amenity-rich condos.
lead_paragraph: Bethel’s relatively low home prices and well-regarded schools draw young families, and retirees are attracted to amenity-rich condos.

headline: Bethel, Conn.: Bucolic and Affordable
abstract: Bethel is a mix of young families attracted by the relatively low-priced homes and strong schools, and retirees living in amenity-rich condos.
lead_paragraph: When Sally Cuneo Ajello and her husband, Tom Ajello, went house hunting a few years ago, their three children, now ages 9, 7 and 4, were uppermost in their minds. “We wanted open spaces for them to run and play and a school district that we felt confident in,” said Ms. Ajello, 39, a freelance marketing consultant.

headline: Candidate Selfies as the New Souvenir
abstract: Forget the handshake. Clinton’s supporters want a social media souvenir this election season.
lead_paragraph: Forget the handshake. Clinton’s supporters want a social media souvenir this election season.

headline: Would You Want to Go to a School Like This One?
abstract: At this school, meeting the basic needs like electricity, hot water and food are students’ responsibilities.
lead_paragraph: The Midland School in Los Olivos, Calif., is a prep school that prepares students for entry into competitive colleges, but it also teaches them how to raise livestock, grow vegetables and chop wood. And meeting the basic needs like electricity, hot water and food are a big part of the students’ responsibilities.

headline: In Muhammad Dahlan’s Ascent, a Proxy Battle for Legitimacy
abstract: The former Gaza strongman is the focus of intrigue as Arab leaders seek change over the objections of Mahmoud Abbas, who has no designated successor.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Muhammad Dahlan lives 1,300 miles from his Palestinian brethren in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. His spacious home here in Abu Dhabi, in the United Arab Emirates, features plush sofas, vaulted ceilings and chandeliers. The infinity pool in the back seems to spill into the glistening waterway beyond.

headline: How to Be Mindful With Your Cat
abstract: Take a moment for yourself while your cat is on your lap.
lead_paragraph: “Cat people are different from dog people. We must accept that felines are independent, and also cherish the moments when our cat curls up and starts to purr. Cats make it easy to be mindful.” — Nancy Scanlan, executive director of the American Holistic Veterinary Medical Foundation.

headline: ‘Hair by Sam McKnight,’ the Story of an Image Maker
abstract: The London exhibition is a retrospective on 40 years in hair as well as a testament to the stylist’s influence on modern culture.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Somerset House, the lavish palace perched on the banks of the Thames River that houses restaurants, the Courtauld Institute of Art and numerous galleries, has been home to exhibits on Big Bang Data, Bjork and the possibilities of a future Utopia. But until this week it had never been a frame for … hair.

headline: Morning Agenda: Wells Fargo Hit Again, Bygone Times
abstract: Wells Fargo has been hit with a $50 million payment to settle a class-action lawsuit for the overcharging of home appraisals.
lead_paragraph: The dust hasn’t even settled on the scandal over fake accounts at Wells Fargo. And now, the bank has even more bad headlines to deal with, with a $50 million payment to settle a class-action lawsuit.

headline: F.B.I., Mosul, Standing Rock: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Guide to Getting a Bachelor’s Abroad
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'International Study and Teaching', 'Americans Abroad']
abstract: Opportunities for earning an undergraduate degree on foreign soil, taught in English, are growing by the year. And the price is right: In some countries, it’s free.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when the self-confident undergraduate took a semester or two abroad to taste an unfamiliar culture and dip a toe into the waters of higher education on a foreign shore. Today, tasting is timid stuff.

headline: Hostels and Shared Hotel Rooms Take Root in America
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Budget Travel', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: A new breed of lodging, with a focus on shared rooms, thrift and style.
lead_paragraph: Hostels, budget havens of the post-college European travel circuit, traditionally offer bare-bones bunks in communal dormitories. Now for those whose tastes have graduated beyond the backpacking years but whose finances have not, a new breed of hybrid hostel sprouting up on this side of the Atlantic bundles better design, lively bars and restaurants and even some private rooms, all still nicely priced.

headline: What Ken Jeong Can’t Travel Without
abstract: When the star of the ABC comedy series “Dr. Ken” takes a trip, he always brings multiple chargers and honey cough drops.
lead_paragraph: Ken Jeong, a doctor-turned-actor, was on the critically acclaimed “Community” and played the gangster Leslie Chow in “The Hangover” movies before starring in his own ABC comedy series, “Dr. Ken,” now in its second season.

headline: Fitness Trackers Might Help Us Live Longer (if Only We Used Them)
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Walking', 'Running', 'New York City Marathon', 'Wearable Computing', 'Exercise']
abstract: Two new studies underscore the promise and perils of using activity trackers.
lead_paragraph: Activity monitors could improve our health and extend our lives — if only we could be motivated to use them. Those are the conclusions of two new studies about the promise and perils of relying on fitness trackers to measure and guide how we move.

headline: New York Today: Revving Up for the Marathon
abstract: Wednesday: Preparing for the New York City Marathon, springlike weather and Día de los Muertos.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:28 a.m.

headline: Iowa Police Arrest Suspect in ‘Ambush’ Killings of 2 Officers
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The officers were shot early Wednesday in Des Moines and in Urbandale. A suspect, described as a troubled loner familiar to the police, soon surrendered.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — They were each on overnight patrols early Wednesday, a rookie police officer and a veteran a few miles apart in the Des Moines area, when officials say they had the lethal misfortune to cross paths with an armed, disturbed man whose life was unraveling. Each officer was gunned down in the driver’s seat of his patrol car, without so much as a chance to unholster his weapon.

headline: Why Republicans Don’t Even Try to Win Cities Anymore
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Urban Areas', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a fundamental realignment in which race plays a key role, population density has become a strong predictor of how people vote.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Reagan visited the South Bronx in the summer of 1980, when Charlotte Street was still lined with vacant lots and the rubble of toppling tenements. The place looked like London after the blitz, he said, and he wanted to do something about it.

headline: Glenda Jackson Hopes to Scale Mount Lear in Her Stage Return
abstract: After a quarter-century in politics, the Oscar winner, at 80, will play one of the most challenging roles in theater in a production at the Old Vic.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It’s one of the most demanding roles in theater, but Glenda Jackson, the two-time Oscar-winning actress, will open a new production of “King Lear” on Friday having not stepped onstage for 25 years. In the interim, she worked to keep a realm together as a member of the British Parliament; her first act in her return to the theater will be to play a monarch who breaks one up.

headline: South Korean Prosecutors Say They Will Bring Charges Against President’s Friend
abstract: Prosecutors intend to charge Choi Soon-sil, who is at the center of a scandal engulfing President Park Geun-hye, with influence peddling and other crimes.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korean prosecutors said on Wednesday that they intended to bring criminal charges against a longtime friend of President Park Geun-hye who is the central figure in a scandal engulfing her administration.

headline: Alibaba Earnings Show It Again Defying China’s Slowdown
abstract: Advertising helped the e-commerce company overcome slowing sales growth on its platforms, but it still posted losses in newer, growth-oriented businesses.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Amid concerns about a slowdown in the growth of the Chinese economy, China’s largest e-commerce company is showing that — for now — business on its platforms is holding steady.

headline: Is Coal’s Political Heft Plunging? One State May Be Canary in Mine
abstract: Activists in Washington State have fought the industry, largely successfully, on building export terminals, and a ballot measure to tax carbon there could create a national model.
lead_paragraph: BELLINGHAM, Wash. — The American coal industry, with its billions of dollars and army of lobbyists, has a storied history of muscle and might. But in this northwest corner of Washington, people like Christopher Grannis, a 69-year-old building contractor and stalwart in local civic causes, are standing up to coal.

headline: Early Vote in North Carolina Seems Consistent With a Clinton Lead
abstract: The data suggests pre-election polls are largely right about the composition of the state’s electorate, but it doesn’t mean the pre-election polls will be right.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina has become perhaps the most important state in the election. It has the potential to decide the Senate and the presidency.

headline: California Today: The Proposition That Has Jerry Brown Up in Arms
abstract: Wednesday: The governor goes after Proposition 53, a BART janitor earns eye-popping pay, and the question of ballot selfies gets court scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Radical Supreme Court Talk
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Refusing to fill a seat on the highest court, simply for ideological reasons, represents a worrisome break with democratic tradition.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: New York Times Co. Reports an Advertising Drop, Though Digital Results Grew
abstract: Print advertising revenue fell 19 percent in the third quarter, the company reported, though digital advertising revenue jumped 21 percent.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company on Wednesday reported a steep decline in print advertising revenue for the third quarter, adding to the newspaper industry’s woes.

headline: 2 Iowa Officers Killed in ‘Ambush-Style’ Attacks
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The officers were shot dead in their patrol cars in two assaults in the Des Moines area early Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The officers were shot dead in their patrol cars in two assaults in the Des Moines area early Wednesday.

headline: Europe’s Mosquito-Free Island Paradise: Iceland
abstract: No one knows for sure why mosquitoes have never spread to Iceland. If climate is the reason, look out: It’s changing.
lead_paragraph: They suck your blood and buzz annoyingly around your ears. Their itchy bites can turn a festive barbecue miserable or ruin a bucolic walk in the woods. The most baneful ones spread diseases.

headline: Pope Says Women Will Not Be Ordained as Priests
abstract: Pope Francis said the Catholic Church’s ban on female priests will most likely continue forever. The comment came during a press briefing aboard the papal plane late on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis said the Catholic Church’s ban on female priests will most likely continue forever. The comment came during a press briefing aboard the papal plane late on Tuesday.

headline: Broadcom to Buy Brocade Communications for $5.5 Billion
abstract: It is the latest deal in the rapidly consolidating semiconductor sector, where companies are seeking greater scale and a larger array of products.
lead_paragraph: The chip maker Broadcom said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire Brocade Communications Systems, a maker of routers, switches and other computer networking equipment, for $5.5 billion in cash.

headline: Philippines’ Deal With China Pokes a Hole in U.S. Strategy
abstract: American efforts to contain Chinese ambitions in the South China Sea depend on a ring of allies, but the region’s united front may be crumbling.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For years, the United States and its allies have struggled to contain China’s ambitions in the South China Sea, even as China steadily seeded the waters with artificial islands and military installations.

headline: Russia Extends Aleppo Cease-Fire and Urges Rebels to Leave
abstract: Already accused of war crimes in Syria, the Kremlin is anxious to avoid a blood bath and humanitarian crisis while ousting antigovernment forces.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia said on Wednesday that it would extend a moratorium on airstrikes in the Syrian city of Aleppo until Friday to give embattled antigovernment rebels a chance to leave the city and to “avoid senseless victims” of continued fighting.

headline: What You Get for … $750,000
abstract: A contemporary in Memphis, a Queen Anne in Denver and a stucco cottage in Oregon
lead_paragraph: A contemporary in Memphis, a Queen Anne in Denver and a stucco cottage in Oregon
