abstract: A contemporary in Memphis, a Queen Anne in Denver and a stucco cottage in Portland, Ore.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS

headline: Farmers’ Unchecked Crop Burning Fuels India’s Air Pollution
abstract: The burning of straw is a major contributor to New Delhi’s winter air pollution, and it could be stopped if the government got serious.
lead_paragraph: MAULVIWALA, India — Desperate to reduce the pollution that has made New Delhi’s air quality among the worst in the world, the city has banned private cars for two-week periods and campaigned to reduce its ubiquitous fireworks during holiday celebrations.

headline: Former BlackRock Fund Manager Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
abstract: Mark Lyttleton, who left BlackRock, the world’s largest investment firm, in 2013, was accused by British authorities of trading two stocks using inside information.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A former fund manager at BlackRock pleaded guilty to insider trading charges in a London court on Wednesday, the British authorities said.

headline: 7 Fall Shows You Should Be Watching — And How to Catch Up
abstract: Need help sorting through TV’s endless array of shows and platforms? Here are seven new ones you should check out and where you can watch them.
lead_paragraph: TENS of thousands of movies, thousands of TV shows, hundreds of channels, dozens of streaming services. There are more movies and series to watch than ever before and more ways to experience them. It can all be a little overwhelming. But we’re here to help. The New York Times recently debuted a website called Watching, designed to help you decide what to watch. British period pieces, Scandinavian crime dramas, sci-fi adventures, oddball dark comedies — tell us what you’re in the mood for, and we’ll help you find your next favorite show or movie.

headline: Loss Haunts A Tribe Called Quest’s First Album in 18 Years
abstract: Recorded just before the death of Phife Dawg in March, “We Got It From Here, Thank You For Your Service” is heavy with his presence.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J. — On March 22, at 3 a.m., Q-Tip and Phife Dawg were on the phone. The two rappers — lifelong friends from Queens and half of the influential hip-hop group A Tribe Called Quest — were “yucking it up,” Q-Tip recalled, and talking about a project few people outside their inner circle knew was in the works: a new Tribe album, the first in 18 years.

headline: Treating Battered Horses in the Shadow of Egypt’s Pyramids
abstract: Jill Barton, an Australian nurse, faces resistance in a poor community that has long seen horses and donkeys as a source of income, with little regard for their pain.
lead_paragraph: GIZA, Egypt — In a dank stable in the shadow of the Pyramids, a stallion lay on the ground, his broken leg at an odd angle despite the cast wrapped around it.

headline: 1966: Josef Stalin Makes a Comeback in Russia
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The leader of the Soviet party, Leonid I. Breznev, attacks Communist China and praises Josef Stalin in Tbilisi, Georgia, in November 1966.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Soviet party leader Leonid I. Breznev today attacked Communist China and praised Stalin, a hero of China’s current cultural revolution, as an Old Bolshevik who played an important role in the 1917 revolution. Soviet history books never have denied Stalin’s revolutionary role. But since the de-Stalinization campaign began in 1956, it has been extremely rare for any Kremlin leader to give unqualified public praise to the late dictator.

headline: Why America Needs a Female President
abstract: I hope my children grow up thinking it’s normal to have a woman lead the country.
lead_paragraph: GREAT FALLS, Va. — When I was in third grade, my teacher asked who among us wanted to run for class president. I raised my hand along with a few boys, and the teacher told me to come to the front of the class. He turned me around to face the class and slapped my hands with a ruler, hard, and said, “That’s for thinking that a girl can be president of anything.”

headline: The Season's Most Cheery, Beachy Carryalls
abstract: Practically a holiday in themselves, these capacious totes can take you from day to overnight with room for shopping in between.
lead_paragraph: Practically a holiday in themselves, these capacious totes can take you from day to overnight with room for shopping in between.

headline: An Artist and a Poet Consider Failure
abstract: As part of an ongoing series, artist Camille Henrot responded to a poem by the writer Erin Belieu.
lead_paragraph: For T’s ongoing series, the artist Camille Henrot responded to a poem by the poet Erin Belieu.

headline: Obama Says Alternate Routes Are Being Reviewed for Dakota Pipeline
abstract: In an interview with NowThis, Mr. Obama called on protesters and law enforcement officers to show restraint as protests continue.
lead_paragraph: President Obama, in his first remarks on the violent standoff over an oil pipeline near the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota, called on both sides to show restraint and revealed that the Army Corps of Engineers was considering an alternative route for the project.

headline: Running a Marathon With a Daughter to Cheer Me on
abstract: After my struggle with postpartum depression, it’s not just a race. It’s a celebration of how far my family has come.
lead_paragraph: I’ve had the vision in my head for years: I’m running the New York City Marathon and I find my daughter, Bee, in the crowd. It’s a simple moment, but one I’ve wanted so badly for so long, I get choked up just thinking about it.

headline: What to Look For When the Polling Drought Ends
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Keep an eye on Donald Trump’s vote share: A key is whether he can consolidate Republican-leaning voters.
lead_paragraph: There have been surprisingly few election polls since the F.B.I. director James Comey’s letter to Congress last week. The dearth of polls has actually been a pattern all year: The number of live-interview polls in the battleground states fell to 36 from 80 compared with a similar period in 2012, according to FiveThirtyEight’s Harry Enten.

headline: Can You Take a Voting Selfie? States Wage Legal Battles Days Before Election
keywords: ['Photography', 'States (US)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Law and Legislation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Elections']
abstract: If you take a photo of yourself with your ballot, you may be breaking the law in some jurisdictions.
lead_paragraph: If you’re hoping to document your vote by taking a photo of your ballot, you may be headed for a legal gray area that in some states has grown only murkier in the days leading up to Election Day.

headline: Separatist Hong Kong Lawmakers Draw Fears of Intervention by China
abstract: Two Legislative Council members altered the wording of their oaths of office, potentially setting off a rare legal battle.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It started with an oath of office that two young, newly elected lawmakers altered to insert a derogatory term into the formal name of Hong Kong’s sovereign ruler, the People’s Republic of China, with one also adding a crude epithet.

headline: Keeping Lee Krasner Visible: Foundation Chooses New Gallery
abstract: The Pollock-Krasner Foundation announced the move to the Paul Kasmin Gallery, saying, “We want the work of Lee Krasner to be seen and appreciated.”
lead_paragraph: Holdings of artworks by Lee Krasner, a leading — though largely unsung — Abstract Expressionist painter and the widow of Jackson Pollock, will now be represented by the Paul Kasmin Gallery, the Pollock-Krasner Foundation announced Wednesday.

headline: Nonprofit Employees, Already Underpaid, Face Special Challenges in Retirement
keywords: ['401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Financial Planners', 'Personal Finances', 'Series']
abstract: Short on time and money, small nonprofits often have little of either left for researching and adopting the best savings vehicles for their workers.
lead_paragraph: There are untold numbers of crusading Roman Catholics in the annals of world history, but there probably has never been one quite like Mary Brunson.

headline: Malta’s Emerging Capital by the Sea
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: With a history as rich as it has been dramatic, Valletta has become a laid-back coastal destination with a thriving creative class.
lead_paragraph: People love to invade Malta. The Mediterranean island nation, situated between Sicily and Tunisia, counts among its unwelcome guests the Romans, the Ottomans, Napoleon and, in the early 20th century, hundreds of Russian aristocrats fleeing the fall of the czarist autocracy. For the most part, the Maltese were having none of this. Napoleon was forced out after just two years, and the Knights of Malta — effectively, and against all odds — defeated the Ottoman Empire’s much larger forces. In Valletta, Malta’s capital, people still bring up the Great Siege with enormous pride, boasting about it as if they had actually been there.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
abstract: The election is around the corner, but don’t just sit on the couch watching prognosticators shout: Get into the kitchen!
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: The Creator of ‘Rectify’ on Why You Can’t Watch and Multitask
abstract: Ray McKinnon discusses the themes of his SundanceTV show, which recently began its fourth and final season.
lead_paragraph: “Rectify,” the critically praised but sparsely watched SundanceTV drama, was never intended for halfhearted viewing. Languid and contemplative — the first season covered a mere seven days — it follows Daniel Holden (Aden Young) as he returns to the stifling confines of his rural Georgia hometown after 19 years of death-row solitude. His conviction for the rape and murder of his high school girlfriend, Hanna Dean, has been vacated because of new DNA evidence. But though he is free, he’s not exonerated.

headline: Why Sexual Harassment Persists in Politics
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: At its core, sexual harassment is about power, and politics is the ultimate power profession. And young people are particularly at risk.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Claire McCaskill, Democrat of Missouri, got her first tutorial about life as a woman in politics as a college intern at the statehouse in Jefferson City in 1974, when male lawmakers made lecherous remarks to her in the elevator; she took the stairs after that. When she became a state legislator in 1983, the lessons became more explicit when she asked the House speaker on the dais his advice for getting legislation passed.

headline: Start-Ups for the End of Life
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Start-ups', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Small Business', 'Wills and Estates', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of']
abstract: A crop of tech start-ups is looking to capture a slice of the funeral sector and end-of-life care. Many of them are founded by millennials, who have grown up online.
lead_paragraph: Death and dying can be costly, but they are rarely considered a business by consumers. Many would rather not ponder critical decisions about feeding tubes, funeral homes and other end-of-life issues until the need is thrust upon them.

headline: Microsoft Puts Slack in Cross Hairs With New Office Chat App
abstract: The tech giant introduced Microsoft Teams, an addition to its Office 365 suite, which resembles Slack but adds features like threaded conversations and videoconferencing.
lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash. — In the last couple of years at Microsoft, some old habits have been tossed away, like obsessively placing Windows software at the center of all the company’s big bets. But the company would still dig trenches to protect Office, its $23-billion-a-year software franchise.

headline: Put Your Phone to Work Doing Some Good
abstract: You can support a variety of causes through donation apps, and some are set up to draw the funds from a corporate sponsor, not out of your pocket.
lead_paragraph: WITH the holidays upon us, some smartphone apps can let you help someone in need with just a few taps of your finger.

headline: First Gentlemen Around the World
abstract: This is the closest America has come to having a woman as president, and to having a first husband in the White House. What would that look like, and what would Bill Clinton’s role be?
lead_paragraph: This is the closest America has come to having a woman as president, and to having a first husband in the White House. What would that look like, and what would Bill Clinton’s role be?

headline: Video Feature: First Gentlemen Around the World
abstract: What will Bill Clinton’s role look like if Hillary Clinton becomes president? He could look to these countries for guidance.
lead_paragraph: First Husband? First Gentleman? Presidential spouse? What will we call former President Bill Clinton if his wife, Hillary, wins on Nov. 8?

headline: 'Kids' Director Larry Clark Lends His Eye to Dior
abstract: Plus: Are rental tuxes tacky? (Not necessarily.)
lead_paragraph: Plus: Are rental tuxes tacky? (Not necessarily.)

headline: You Don’t Need a No-Fly Zone to Pressure Russia in Syria
abstract: The president shouldn’t leave his successor with no options to move ahead with diplomacy. Here’s how he can put the pressure on now.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s Syria policy has collapsed under the weight of a brutal assault on Aleppo by the forces of President Bashar al-Assad and Russia. Shrugging off global condemnation, Russia and Mr. Assad have dispatched their aircraft to attack schools and hospitals, singling out civilian targets to make the city uninhabitable and force its remaining population to flee.

headline: Obama’s 3-Day Swing Will Try to Push Blacks and Millennials Hillary Clinton’s Way
abstract: The president’s next appearances are planned in the battleground states of North Carolina and Florida, in what’s being called “the last big campaign swing of his political career.”
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — With Democrats concerned about lagging early turnout among blacks and younger voters, President Obama on Wednesday began a three-day swing aimed at galvanizing a couple of the pillars of his political coalition in two states that could deny Donald J. Trump any route to the presidency.

headline: Veterans, Feeling Abandoned, Stand by Donald Trump
keywords: ['Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Many who served in Iraq and Afghanistan are proud of their service but exhausted by its burdens, and they distrust the political class that reshaped their lives.
lead_paragraph: The roster of retired military officers endorsing Hillary Clinton in September glittered with decoration and rank. One former general led the American surge in Anbar, one of the most violent provinces in Iraq. Another commanded American-led allied forces battling the Taliban in Afghanistan. Yet another trained the first Iraqis to combat Islamic insurgents in their own country.

headline: Updated Uber App Will Connect Your Calendar With Your Ride
abstract: In the biggest changes to its app since 2012, the service will also allow riders to use their contacts to set destinations and to order food though UberEats.
lead_paragraph: Uber has redesigned its app with new features that anticipate more of a passenger’s needs as the company works to differentiate its ride-hailing service in a crowded field of rivals.

headline: How a Changing Climate Is Shaping a Leaf Peeper’s Paradise
abstract: A warming planet is responsible for the glorious colors of fall lasting so late in the year, scientists say, but they warn it could have a negative effect on the foliage over the longer term.
lead_paragraph: IONA, Nova Scotia — A century ago, the flaming fall foliage in Nova Scotia would have long faded by early November. But today, some of the hills are still as nubbly with color as an aunt’s embroidered pillow.

headline: William Weld, Libertarian, Sticks Up for Hillary Clinton, a Rival
abstract: Mr. Weld, his party’s vice-presidential nominee, is making the unusual move to use his remaining time in the race to question Donald J. Trump’s “common decency or truthfulness.”
lead_paragraph: William F. Weld, the Libertarian Party nominee for vice president, defended Hillary Clinton on Wednesday against attacks from Donald J. Trump, insisting her character should not be impugned by someone as flawed as he is.

headline: Tech-Minded Performances Are Coming to the Coil Festival
abstract: The lineup for the 2017 edition of Performance Space 122’s annual event includes virtual reality, multimedia theater and robot-aided dance.
lead_paragraph: With virtual reality, a multimedia take on Euripides and dance accompanied by 64 robotic instruments, technology will reign at the 2017 edition of Coil, Performance Space 122’s annual festival of innovative theater, music and dance.

headline: James Burke, Ex-Suffolk County Police Chief, Is Sentenced to 46 Months
abstract: Mr. Burke’s efforts to cover up the 2012 beating of a man who stole a bag belonging to him set in motion a scandal that has reverberated through Long Island politics.
lead_paragraph: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y. — The once popular and swaggering chief of the Suffolk County Police Department, James Burke, was sentenced to 46 months in federal prison on Wednesday for a series of misdeeds that began after a duffel bag belonging to him was stolen from his parked sport utility vehicle.

headline: Obama Faults F.B.I. on Emails, Citing ‘Incomplete Information’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: He implied that the decision by James B. Comey to announce the discovery of new emails possibly related to the Hillary Clinton case had violated investigative norms.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — President Obama threw the power of the White House behind Hillary Clinton on Wednesday. He faulted how the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, handled new emails related to the investigation into Mrs. Clinton’s private server, and then shouted out to college students here in a pivotal battleground state that it was crucial that they vote because the “fate of the world is teetering.”

headline: Daily Report: How to Think About ‘Thinking’ Machines
abstract: One of the country’s top universities gets $10 million to work on the ethics of artificial intelligence. As always, it’s a question about the ethics of humans.
lead_paragraph: If you can’t invent the future the way you used to, maybe you can help us get ready for it.

headline: Sleep Poorly? You May Eat Too Much the Next Day
abstract: After a night of limited sleep, researchers found, people consumed an average of 385 extra calories the next day.
lead_paragraph: Not enough sleep last night? You may overeat today.

headline: How to Change the Way You Pay in Google Play
abstract: What to do if you need to remove or change your stored credit card — or want to switch to a different payment method entirely.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I delete the stored credit card from the Google Play store on my Android tablet and change it to a prepaid Google Play gift card?

headline: 3-D Printing Pioneer Goes Low Tech, With a $5,800 Watch Made in Brooklyn
abstract: Bre Pettis left MakerBot and started an old-school watch company called Bre & Company, with timepieces inspired by origami and a DeLorean.
lead_paragraph: Seven years ago, Bre Pettis established himself as a Silicon Alley futurist when he helped found MakerBot, a pioneering Brooklyn company that helped make 3-D printing more widely accessible with affordably priced desktop machines.

headline: Gawker and Hulk Hogan Reach $31 Million Settlement
abstract: In a privacy feud, the former wrestler had been awarded $140 million in damages and the media site was forced to sell itself.
lead_paragraph: In fighting a lawsuit filed by the former professional wrestler Hulk Hogan, Gawker Media lost nearly everything — the verdict, its founder, its independence — but it maintained its resolute conviction that it would win on appeal.

headline: For Schoolchildren, Weights Rise Along With Summer Temperatures
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Obesity', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Summer (Season)', 'Seasons and Months', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: Younger elementary students have a far higher chance of gaining excessive weight during the summer than when they are in school.
lead_paragraph: Summer is the season when children play outdoors tirelessly until nightfall, burning up all the energy they had stockpiled throughout the school year, right?

headline: Volkswagen Parts Ways With the Historian Who Chronicled Its Nazi Past
abstract: A group of prominent academics has accused the company of reverting to secretive ways over its use of forced labor during World War II.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Volkswagen has been struggling for a year to repair the damage caused by a scandal over its cover-up of diesel emissions, promising honesty and transparency. Now historians are accusing the company of reverting to secretive ways on a different subject: the Nazi past of German automakers.

abstract: To streamline the process, embrace the uncertainty of life and be open to possibilities.
lead_paragraph: A big life change does not come easily.

abstract: A reader says thank goodness Elizabeth Warren is minding the store.

abstract: A reader calls for more funds to “help make transportation more accessible and efficient.”

headline: Mosul Neighbors Wake Up to a Day Without ISIS
abstract: Residents of one district celebrated their liberation from the Islamic State, but Iraqi commanders acknowledged that there was still a degree of support in Mosul for the group.

headline: ‘Black Votes Matter’
abstract: Readers are surprised by a report of a drop in African-American turnout in early voting this year.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Ballerina Who Got Away Comes Back
abstract: Carla Körbes, edging away from her recent retirement, will perform three short works as part of Vail Dance Festival: ReMix at City Center.
lead_paragraph: When the Pacific Northwest Ballet principal dancer Carla Körbes announced in 2014 that she would retire at the end of the next season, at 33, it came as a bit of a shock. Ms. Körbes, whose performances were a marvel of musicality and clarity, surely had many more years of dancing ahead of her. New Yorkers were especially stricken — they had had only a few glimpses of her in the past decade.

headline: Reducing the Debt, Creatively
abstract: Readers offer their own prescriptions for lowering the federal debt.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Game 7, and the Indians Ask Corey Kluber to Beat the Cubs Again
abstract: Cleveland is at home, with its best pitcher on the mound. The Cubs counter with Kyle Hendricks, who has a 1.31 E.R.A. in four postseason starts.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The last time the Cleveland Indians won the World Series, in 1948, they had two Hall of Famers in the rotation, another in the bullpen, and three more in the starting lineup. The Indians team that will try to win this World Series, in Game 7 on Wednesday night against the Chicago Cubs, is different.

headline: Andreas Gursky’s Vibrant Photography at Gagosian
abstract: This German artist has turned his lens on tulip fields.
lead_paragraph: The German artist Andreas Gursky’s photography has given us aerial views of cattle in muddy Colorado stockyards and a serpentine Grand Prix racetrack in Bahrain. Now he has turned his lens on tulip fields. These works, along with several others never before exhibited in the United States, will be on view at Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea starting Thursday, Nov. 10.

headline: Atlantic Theater Company Has a New Musical From David Yazbek
abstract: In this adaptation of the movie “The Band’s Visit,” an Egyptian band that arrives in Israel ends up stranded in a remote village after a mix-up at the border.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, the composer and lyricist David Yazbek, who wrote for “Late Night With David Letterman” for a stint in the early 1980s, told a Toronto newspaper: “I’d always wondered if I could write a song that could get the kind of laughs that a good sketch could get.” His career in musical theater has made that possible, starting in 2000 with his delightful Broadway debut “The Full Monty,” a charming musical that was funnier than the 1997 movie. He has since worked in many mediums, including television and cabaret, but has written a new musical about every five years. His latest, which starts previews Off Broadway at the Atlantic Theater Company on Friday, Nov. 11, is another adaptation, this time of the movie “The Band’s Visit,” about an Egyptian group that arrives in Israel to play a show but ends up stranded in a remote village after a mix-up at the border. Itamar Moses wrote the book, and David Cromer, who replaced Hal Prince, directs a cast that includes John Cariani and Tony Shalhoub. (atlantictheater.org)

headline: ‘Rules of the Game,’ a Multilayered Dance, Is Coming to BAM
abstract: Jonah Bokaer’s choreography links each dancer to someone in the Italian dramatist Luigi Pirandello’s “Six Characters in Search of an Author.”
lead_paragraph: Life can involve game upon game. Jonah Bokaer, a former member of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, relishes choreographic games. And “Rules of the Game,” his new dance production, is a puzzle of artistic layers. It takes its title from a work by the great Italian dramatist Luigi Pirandello, as well as another play that is being rehearsed by actors in Pirandello’s “Six Characters in Search of an Author,” who find themselves invaded by characters from still another, but unfinished, drama. Mr. Bokaer said that although his creation is plotless, his choreography subtly links each dancer to someone in “Six Characters.” It haunts the production, designed by Daniel Arsham (with new music by Pharrell Williams), with Pirandello ghosts. Mr. Bokaer’s program, which celebrates 10 years of collaborating with Mr. Arsham, also includes “Recess,” a solo, and — more games — “Why Patterns,” in which dancers interact with multitudes of table tennis balls. (Thursday, Nov. 10, through Saturday at 7:30 p.m., BAM Howard Gilman Opera House, Fort Greene; 718-636-4100, bam.org.)

headline: Drones, So Useful in War, May Be Too Costly for Border Duty
abstract: Investments in sensor and radar technologies and increased staffing might be the best and most cost-efficient way to patrol America’s borders with Mexico and Canada.
lead_paragraph: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — Cameras on drones stare down at the Canadian border from as high as 28,000 feet, scanning vast stretches of mountains, rivers and forests for potential terrorists and drug smugglers.

headline: Mary J. Blige and Maxwell at the Garden
abstract: These R&B stalwarts tap the emotional well as they bring their “King and Queen of Hearts Tour” to New York.
lead_paragraph: Depending on the artist, when the personal bleeds aggressively into the professional, it can be a recipe for either messiness or motivation. For Mary J. Blige, the veteran R&B belter who’s at her best when emotionally charged, heartbreak is inspiration. This summer, she filed for divorce from her husband of more than a decade and longtime manager, but instead of cowering from tabloid headlines, she has worked them into her live show. A recent single, “Thick of It,” from her coming album “Strength of a Woman,” is similarly defiant: “Who’s gonna love you like I do? Who will you trust? I gave you too much.” That combination of vulnerability and resilience can be expected when Ms. Blige and Maxwell, the progressive soul seducer, headline Madison Square Garden on Thursday, Nov. 10, as part of their “King and Queen of Hearts Tour.” “I don’t hold back,” Ms. Blige said recently, “and there’s no way I am going to start changing now.” (ticketmaster.com)

headline: Trump Adviser’s Slur Is a Sign of Things to Come
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Discrimination', 'Republican National Convention', 'Debates (Political)', 'Women and Girls', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity']
abstract: An anti-Clinton tweet is just the latest example. This language reminds women of what we’ve been through.
lead_paragraph: One night, after the Democratic convention, I caught a train back to downtown Philadelphia. Some men boarded the train a few stops after me, shouting about Hillary Clinton. I took out my earphones to listen. “She’s a slut who belongs in jail,” one of them said.

headline: ‘Deep Water,’ a Crime Thriller, Comes to Acorn TV
abstract: Yael Stone plays a police detective investigating a vicious killing with sexual undercurrents in a suburb of Sydney, Australia.
lead_paragraph: Fans of “Orange Is the New Black” know her as Lorna Morello, the hard-on-the-ears, sweetly delusional Litchfield Penitentiary inmate whose romantic travails have kept Netflix viewers in stitches for four seasons. But somewhere beneath Morello’s ruby-red lipstick, cockeyed accent and histrionics lurks the Australian actress Yael Stone. And in “Deep Water,” a crime thriller debuting Monday, Nov. 7, on Acorn TV, she’s virtually unrecognizable. Her face scrubbed bare and her vowels subdued, Ms. Stone plays Tori Lustigman, a police detective investigating a vicious killing with sexual undercurrents in a suburb of Sydney. But when a clue links the case to a similar one from 26 years earlier, Tori uncovers 70 possible murders of gay men spanning decades along New South Wales’s glorious shoreline — and the possibility that the culprit is back at it. “Every day, Tori, you come to work prepared to give up your life to protect others,” her boss says. “But you’ve got a son. Why would you do that?” Some secrets can’t be washed away.

headline: Fed Signals It’s on Track to Raise Interest Rates in December
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The central bank held steady on rates, but its statement reinforced expectations that officials do not plan to wait much longer to raise them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Wednesday continued its slow march toward higher interest rates, signaling that it remains on track to raise its benchmark interest in December for the first time this year but holding off on an increase this month.

headline: Where’s Outrage Over F.B.I. Disclosure? Not Among Voters
abstract: A survey shows that views are sharply divided along partisan lines on what is appropriate for prosecutors before an election.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and President Obama are outraged about the F.B.I. director James Comey’s decision to disclose further inquiries into her handling of confidential email, but are the American people?

headline: 3 Big Shows for New Music in New York
abstract: Tim Munro, Zeena Parkins and Pauline Oliveros, three important contemporary-music performers converge on the city.
lead_paragraph: Three important contemporary-music performers converge on New York, starting on Wednesday, Nov. 9, at Roulette in Brooklyn, where the harpist and composer Zeena Parkins will perform a solo called “The Captiva Pieces,” created at the Rauschenberg Residency on Captiva Island, Fla. (8 p.m., roulette.org)

headline: Laura Poitras and Her Films at the Museum of the Moving Image
abstract: Ms. Poitras’s so-called 9/11 Trilogy will be shown, and she will take questions after “The Oath” and “Citizenfour.” Also coming up: the Doc NYC festival.
lead_paragraph: With the surreal election season about to end, documentaries move to the fore, starting at the Museum of the Moving Image in Queens with “Pushing the Envelope,” a program of nonfiction films that won or were nominated for Cinema Eye Honors. On Sunday, Nov. 6, Laura Poitras’s so-called 9/11 Trilogy will be shown. “My Country, My Country” follows an Iraqi physician who runs for office; “The Oath” introduces a Yemeni cabdriver who was once Osama bin Laden’s bodyguard, and his brother-in-law, a prisoner at Guantánamo. “Citizenfour,” of course, is her Academy Award-winning account of meeting with the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden in Hong Kong. Ms. Poitras (and the cinematographer Kirsten Johnson) will take questions after “The Oath” and “Citizenfour.” (718-784-0077; movingimage.us)

headline: The Worst Party of the Year? Election Night
abstract: This bitter, divisive election has left supporters on both sides wondering whether there will be much to celebrate on Nov. 8.
lead_paragraph: Way back before the primaries, when the coming presidential election seemed like just another quadrennial exercise of our nation’s democratic ideals and not a referendum on our nation’s soul, Molly Rose Quinn decided she was going to give a party on Nov. 8.

headline: A Cyberattack and Medical Devices
abstract: Two experts write that a recent attack exposed the pervasive lack of cybersecurity for medical devices.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mergers Could Help European Investment Banks Compete With U.S.
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: As European investment banks struggle, they may conclude that they should join forces to take on their American competitors.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse’s chief executive, Tidjane Thiam, is clearly frustrated with the investment banking operations of the institution he oversees.

headline: The Last Word, an Imitation Speakeasy, Opens in Queens
abstract: Hidden behind a fake hardware store, the bar imports downtown cocktail culture to Astoria.
lead_paragraph: By now, the imitation speakeasy is familiar territory. Dozens have opened in Manhattan and Brooklyn, behind unmarked doors, Potemkin coffee shops and hidden alleyways. But Queens is proudly behind the curve.

headline: Opera Lover Apologizes for Scattering Ashes and Silencing the Met
abstract: “I find myself needing to extend a heartfelt apology to all concerned,” the man wrote about the disturbance at the Metropolitan Opera last weekend.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas opera lover who scattered a friend’s ashes in the orchestra pit at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday — causing a terrorism scare, and forcing the Met to cut one performance short and cancel another — apologized Wednesday in a letter emailed to Met officials.

headline: Wearable Devices That Could Heal Themselves When They Break
abstract: Magnetic inks might be a fast and cheap way to create flexible batteries, sensors and wearable circuits and make smart clothing more skin-like.
lead_paragraph: A sports bra that monitors your workout. A suit that lets you swap business cards digitally. A beanie hat that tracks your newborn’s vitals. Smart garments like these hint at a future coming up fast, with wearable electronics integrated into our clothing or even our skin, capable of constantly monitoring our biology and tracking our social interactions.

headline: Jacob Zuma’s Administration Should Be Investigated, South Africa Watchdog Says
abstract: A report by the public protector’s office fell short of providing clear evidence of malfeasance by Mr. Zuma, the president, but is likely to raise pressure on him to resign.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — A South African government watchdog group recommended on Wednesday that President Jacob Zuma’s administration be officially investigated for possible corruption.

headline: Trump Probably Avoided His Medicare Taxes, Too
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Medicare', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: According to his disclosure form, the Republican didn’t receive a salary from the 200 companies he lists, so didn’t pay Medicare or Social Security.
lead_paragraph: In the final debate, Hillary Clinton said she would secure Social Security and Medicare by raising taxes on high-income earners, including herself and her opponent, Donald J. Trump, “assuming he can’t figure out how to get out of it.”

headline: Hindu Temples and Homes in Bangladesh Are Attacked by Muslim Crowds
abstract: The ransacking took place on Sunday and Monday amid anger over a Facebook post that included an image of the Hindu god Shiva appearing at a Muslim holy site.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Crowds of Muslims attacked Hindu homes and temples in eastern Bangladesh this week, raising concerns that the authorities are not taking steps to curb rising religious tensions.

headline: Review: Traces of Anachronism in an All-Steve Reich Evening
abstract: Carnegie Hall celebrated the composer’s 80th birthday with a concert that warned of technological hubris and showed no fear of seeming dated.
lead_paragraph: An inventor and master of Minimalism, Steve Reich turned 80 on Oct. 3. And proving that a composer in late career need not grasp at obvious innovation, he celebrated on Tuesday in the soaring Stern Auditorium at Carnegie Hall with three works — even a brand-new one — unafraid of seeming dated.

headline: NYC Winter Jazzfest to Honor Thelonious Monk
abstract: This year’s edition will include Andrew Cyrille as artist in residence, a broad range of styles, and its centerpiece marathon, on Jan. 6 and 7.
lead_paragraph: The NYC Winter Jazzfest has announced its 2017 edition, which will take place Jan. 5 through Jan. 10, with about 140 groups drawing on a range of styles across 13 different stages. As always, the centerpiece will be a smorgasbord-like Winter Jazzfest Marathon, on Jan. 6 and Jan. 7.

headline: Review: Jarrod Spector’s Jersey Tour, Valli to the Boss and More
abstract: After playing Frankie Valli and Barry Mann on Broadway, Mr. Spector brings his autobiographical “Jukebox Life” to Feinstein’s/54 Below.
lead_paragraph: Scattered throughout Jarrod Spector’s opening-night performance of “Jukebox Life,” his entertaining autobiographical show at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Tuesday, were video clips of Mr. Spector as a child performer. There he is as an eager 3-year-old vaudevillian belting the Jolson standard “Toot, Toot, Tootsie! (Goodbye)” with the enthusiasm of the very young Michael Jackson, and as a 10-year-old singing “Mack the Knife.” His parents, he explained, were obsessed with Bobby Darin. Not surprisingly, the grown-up Mr. Spector has a knack for mimicry.

headline: Swinging the Vote: Jazz Inspired by the Presidential Race
abstract: Music that takes its themes from this election is popping up in albums from Delfeayo Marsalis, Marcus Roberts and Ted Nash, who will perform his work next week.
lead_paragraph: Nine months ago, when the term “election fatigue” had a much more hypothetical ring, the jazz pianist Marcus Roberts released a digital EP titled “Race for the White House.” It consisted of a handful of compositions inspired by the presidential field, each a character portrait in brief.

headline: Charity That Begins With Spaghetti Sauce
abstract: The actor Paul Newman’s charitable acts inspired other celebrities to become involved in philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: Mention the name Paul Newman and many movie buffs will describe the charismatic actor with the piercing blue eyes who starred in films like “Cool Hand Luke,” “The Sting” and “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid.” But many people will identify Mr. Newman as the philanthropic kingpin, whose Newman’s Own food brand has raised hundreds of millions of dollars for charity.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Issa Rae Reads ‘Even in Real Life, There Were Screens Between Us’
abstract: The “Insecure” actress reads the story of a long-distance couple who grew so close online that they decided to see if it would work in real life.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s podcast, the actress Issa Rae (“Insecure,” “The Misadventures of Awkward Black Girl”) reads “Even in Real Life, There Were Screens Between Us,” which won our 2011 college essay contest.

headline: Black Church Burned in Mississippi, With ‘Vote Trump’ Scrawled on Side
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'ARSON', 'Hate Crimes', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: The attack, determined to be arson, reinforced fears of potential violence as a polarizing and racially charged presidential race nears its conclusion.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, Miss. — A predominantly African-American church here was badly burned on Tuesday evening, with the words “Vote Trump” spray-painted on the side of the building, an episode that comes amid rising concerns over possible violence in the final days of a polarizing and racially charged presidential race.

headline: In New TV Fare, National Geographic Sustains Its Climate Focus
keywords: ['Coal', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Energy and Power', 'Global Warming', 'News and News Media', 'Television']
abstract: National Geographic focuses on climate change through a documentary featuring Leonardo DiCaprio and a series taking David Letterman to India’s unlit slums.
lead_paragraph: Remember that wave of angst and suspicion among environmentalists when the Murdoch family’s 21st Century Fox paid $725 million to form a for-profit joint venture with National Geographic? The logic of the move for the venerable publishing, education and science society lay in creating a predictable and large flow of money to support its work. The fears centered on the prospect that the Fox News approach to issues like climate change would spill across National Geographic, from the magazine to the TV programming. There were tough staff cuts right away, but where in media companies (including this one) is that not the case these days?

headline: Mosul, Jacob Zuma, Federal Reserve: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Mark Rothko’s Dark Palette Illuminated
abstract: An exhibition at Pace Gallery is the first on its scale to trace this painter’s experimentation away from his sunny earlier work.
lead_paragraph: One evening in 1968, Mark Rothko regaled the art dealer Arne Glimcher, who had dropped by his studio on his way home from Pace Gallery in New York, with the story of a visit from a collector that day.

headline: The Campaign Tour: Pop Musicians Get on the Bus (Mostly Clinton’s)
abstract: Musicians like Jay Z and Jon Bon Jovi are supporting Hillary Clinton for president, though such involvement was not always assumed in an election between two unpopular candidates.
lead_paragraph: It sounds like the lineup for an eclectic all-star music festival: Jay Z, Katy Perry, Jon Bon Jovi, the National, Steve Aoki. And it is, almost, though the musicians will be spread across political swing states in the coming days, volunteering their services in support of Hillary Clinton.

headline: James Comey’s Self-Righteous Meddling
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Was the F.B.I. director’s announcement last week about party loyalty? Or was it about claiming the moral high ground?
lead_paragraph: There are two possible explanations for James Comey’s decision to announce last week that he was examining emails that “appear to be pertinent” to the investigation of Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server.

headline: What Would Michelle Do?
abstract: Make Election Day a celebration of the style of the first lady.
lead_paragraph: Make Election Day a celebration of the style of the first lady.

headline: Alasdhair Willis, Hunter Boot Man, Doesn’t Mind the Rain
abstract: As he unveils a line of wet-weather gear, the British marketing guru talks about family life with his wife, Stella McCartney, and their four children.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Talking about the weather is a British national pastime. For Alasdhair Willis, the creative director of Hunter and the husband of the fashion designer Stella McCartney, inclement weather is a work-related subject of discussion.

headline: Lifesaving Cancer Drugs May in Rare Cases Threaten the Heart
abstract: Drugs called checkpoint inhibitors that harness the immune system to fight cancer can, in rare cases, cause heart damage. Patients may need extra heart tests during treatment.
lead_paragraph: Powerful drugs that enlist the immune system to fight cancer can, in rare cases, cause heart damage, doctors are reporting.

headline: Behind the Scenes of Athi-Patra Ruga’s ‘Over the Rainbow’
abstract: The artist takes T to a makeup trial, a fitting, a rehearsal and the final Performa event.
lead_paragraph: The artist takes T to a makeup trial, a fitting, a rehearsal and the final Performa event.

headline: A Performance Artist Tackles South African Identity, for a New York Audience
abstract: Athi-Patra Ruga staged “Over the Rainbow” — and introduced his newest avatar, Versatile Queen Ivy — for Performa’s fall gala.
lead_paragraph: Draped in billowing, Champagne-colored satin with a haphazard stack of tiaras strapped to his head, the artist Athi-Patra Ruga sprawled on a dance-studio floor in Brooklyn last Saturday, holding court. “There are so many South Africas, and that’s the story of South Africa,” he proclaimed to those listening, the director and chief curator of Performa RoseLee Goldberg among them. He then paused to collect his thoughts; in Ruga time, both a stray millisecond sans speech and a minute-long interruption for dramatic effect seem entirely intentional. “Maybe,” he determined, “I should start with the whole ‘rainbow’ thing.”

headline: Accord Reached in Battle Over ‘The Great Comet’
abstract: Hard feelings remain despite a decision to revise the show’s Playbill to give more specific credit to Ars Nova, which commissioned the play.
lead_paragraph: An uneasy peace has broken out on West 45th Street.

headline: The Best New TV Shows and Movies on Amazon Prime
abstract: This month, Amazon Prime adds “The Night Manager,” “Green Room” and many others to its library.
lead_paragraph: ‘Legally Blonde’

headline: World Series: Here’s How the Chicago Cubs Won Game 7
abstract: It’s true. The Cubs won their first World Series title since 1908. In Game 7, the Cleveland Indians rallied to force extra innings, but the Cubs prevailed.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Throughout more than a century of baseball in America, where teams have risen to championship heights and fallen to miserable lows several times over, and where cities have lost teams, gained them and lost them again, there was always the Chicago Cubs and their futility.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger: American Dreamer
abstract: The designer and friends celebrate the publication of his memoir.
lead_paragraph: The designer and friends celebrate the publication of his memoir.

headline: Gigi Hadid, Naomi Campbell and More Celebrate Tommy Hilfiger
abstract: It was an all-American evening in honor of the designer’s memoir on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, the Clocktower restaurant on Madison Avenue had a red, white and blue look. The walls were hung with vintage photographs of American icons: Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey, the Guggenheim, the entrance to Radio City Music Hall, Audrey Hepburn, James Dean and Muhammad Ali.

headline: Fancy a Little Embellishment? Holiday Pop-Ups Are Arriving
abstract: Kenzo x H&M and Carine Roitfeld x Uniqlo are here; Sacai is at Saks Brookfield Place; and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Julie Heller, curator of the SoHo vintage gallery EraLuxe and the summer Hamptons multibrand retail space Cabana, is bringing the beach to Manhattan with a holiday pop-up opening Thursday. You’ll find dreamy gifts like a ’90s Tom Ford for Gucci blue velvet tuxedo ($895) and a Hunting Season navy lizard cross-body ($1,195). At 42 Hudson Street.

headline: The Washington Legacy of James Galanos
abstract: How the designer and the first lady Nancy Reagan worked together to create a memorable political image, and what we can learn.
lead_paragraph: The designer James Galanos, who died last Sunday, left a legacy of elegance and restraint to the fashion world. But he also left something to the political world, which is worth remembering, especially as we teeter on the verge of a new presidential administration.

headline: Some Who Saw Change in Obama Find It Now in Donald Trump
abstract: A small subset of the electorate who supported Mr. Obama’s call to change in 2008 and 2012 now hear that message in the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: GRANTVILLE, Pa. — It didn’t take long for Jack Morris to regret voting for President Obama. A few months after Mr. Morris, a lifelong Republican, cast his first vote for a Democrat in 2008, he learned that the carpet company where he worked planned to lay off 36 people in Pennsylvania and move his job to Maryland.

headline: Mary-Louise Parker: The First Time I Performed in New York (With Actual Egg on My Face)
abstract: Ms. Parker was 15 when she was drawn to a newspaper photo of a boy at an arts college; later, his play would draw her to New York.
lead_paragraph: I was 15. My dad brought me the newspaper, open to an article about an arts college. A whole department was devoted to what I secretly wanted to pursue, drama, but I was drawn to a photo of a boy. He was close to my age, with unruly blond hair, and looking like a badass while riding a unicycle and juggling. When I showed up for my first day of college two years later, seeing this boy in the flesh was like spotting a superhero in a cafeteria, eating cereal. There he is, I thought. Peter Hedges. That dreamy newspaper boy who juggles.

headline: Review: ‘The Attention Merchants’ Dissects the Battle for Clicks and Eyeballs
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Books and Literature', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: Tim Wu’s new book, subtitled “The Epic Scramble to Get Inside Our Heads,” examines the history of mass media and marketing, not least on the internet.
lead_paragraph: Does anyone remember when Rolling Rock beer ran a campaign on highway billboards back in 2008, promising that the company would project its logo onto the next full moon? It turned out that the whole thing was a hoax dreamed up by the advertising firm that handled Rolling Rock, though other companies, including Coca-Cola, had investigated this idea in earnest years before.

headline: A Senator’s ‘Bullseye’ Joke Echoes Trump
abstract: Senator Richard Burr has been copying Donald Trump’s rhetoric about gun rights and Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Echoes of Donald Trump’s worst campaign instincts — on gun control and the news media — are registering down ballot in North Carolina, a crucial toss-up state where Senator Richard Burr, a Republican, is in a tight re-election race.

headline: Samara Scott’s Suspended Animation
abstract: The artist combines bits of discarded material and organic matter in liquid pools.
lead_paragraph: The artist combines bits of discarded material and organic matter in liquid pools.

headline: One Artist’s Curiously Beautiful Works, Created from Detritus
abstract: In her site-specific pools, Samara Scott submerges bits of yoga mat, Halloween blood, eyeshadow, fruit juice and more in water and oil.
lead_paragraph: The week before her first Los Angeles show, on her first visit to the city, the London–based artist Samara Scott rented a car and slowly cruised around the dryness, “ingesting the landscape” under “the presence of the sky that is so intense here that everything feels like a backdrop, like it’s been flat-packed.”

headline: Review: ‘Big Baby D.R.A.M.’ Finds a Rapper-Singer in Whimsy Mode
abstract: The album, D.R.A.M.’s full-length debut, has a joyous mood, festive and also deeply felt.
lead_paragraph: D.R.A.M., the Virginia rapper-singer who crash-landed into pop last year with the earnest goof “Cha Cha,” is one of the first breakout stars of hip-hop’s whimsy era, a rapper and singer who switches without trepidation among vocal approaches, moods and stylistic lanes, but never loses his grin.

headline: Cubs, Indians, Election: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Place for Family and Italian-American Cocktails in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Italian-Americans', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES']
abstract: Alyssa Sartor’s parents didn’t want her to go into the family business. After the opening of August Laura, they’re glad she did.
lead_paragraph: When John Sartor came back from the Vietnam War, he and a buddy opened a bar in Cliffside Park, N.J., called R. Jay’s Pub, a no-frills hangout for his family and friends.

headline: Bolshoi Gives Building Pass to Dancer Involved in Acid Attack on its Director
abstract: Pavel V. Dmitrichenko, who was released from prison in May, said he received the pass this fall from the Bolshoi’s new artistic director.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The scandalous acid attack that has shadowed the storied Bolshoi Ballet here for almost four years took yet another bizarre twist on Wednesday, as the ballet confirmed it had allowed the dancer convicted in the assault to take practice classes there again.

headline: No Tofurkey for You (and Other Thanksgiving Cooking Advice)
abstract: You will make vegetables for your vegetarian guests, and you will call them by their proper names.
lead_paragraph: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? My job is to answer them, as I have here with readers’ Thanksgiving inquiries. Ask me anything: foodeditor@nytimes.com.

headline: Netanyahu Criticizes American Jewish Leaders Over Western Wall Protest
abstract: A stalled government plan for equal prayer rights for men and women underscored deepening discord between the Israeli authorities and many non-Orthodox Jews abroad.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In a sign of a growing rift, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized American Jewish leaders on Wednesday as a struggle over a stalled plan for equal prayer rights for both sexes at a Jerusalem holy site erupted with mutual recriminations and a tumultuous protest led by liberal rabbis wielding Torah scrolls.

headline: Comparing Medicare Prescription Drug Plans
abstract: Experts advise those covered by Medicare to check the changes in their prescription drug plans and consider changing plans before the Dec. 7 deadline.
lead_paragraph: People covered by Medicare have a few more weeks to change their prescription drug plans, during the program’s annual open enrollment period.

headline: Bill Cosby Trial on Sexual Assault Charges May Be Held Earlier Than Expected
abstract: The judge in the case ruled on Wednesday that if pretrial hearings are completed on schedule in December, he hopes to start the trial earlier than June, as was expected.
lead_paragraph: Norristown, Pa. — The long-awaited criminal trial of entertainer Bill Cosby on sexual assault charges could be held earlier than currently planned if pretrial hearings are completed on schedule in December, the judge in the case said Wednesday.

headline: Universal’s Deal for Prince’s Song Rights May Bring a Wider Audience
keywords: ['Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Wills and Estates', 'Royalties', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: The first major deal for Prince’s music has been reached, with star’s songwriting rights going to the Universal Music Publishing Group for an undisclosed sum.
lead_paragraph: For months, the most closely watched contest in the music industry has been for the songs of Prince, who died in April.

headline: These Are the Bad (and Worse) Options James Comey Faced
abstract: When federal officials concluded their investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server as secretary of state, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, had a decision to make on how to announce that news. The choices he made in July set the F.B.I. on the path toward the predicament it faces today.
lead_paragraph: When federal officials concluded their investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server as secretary of state, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, had a decision to make on how to announce that news. The choices he made in July set the F.B.I. on the path toward the predicament it faces today.

headline: Facebook Defies Social Media Gravity With User and Profit Growth
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Social Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The social network remained strong, topping 1.79 billion monthly visitors and nearly tripling its profit, to $2.38 billion, in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — To paraphrase Isaac Newton’s third law of motion, what goes up must, inevitably, come down. Now try telling that to Facebook.

headline: Connor McDavid and Auston Matthews Are Hockey’s Latest Legends-in-Waiting
abstract: The rivalry between McDavid and Matthews, like Gretzky-Lemieux and Crosby-Ovechkin before them, holds the hopes of a league.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The hype began to build hours before the puck dropped Tuesday night — unusual for an N.H.L. game just a few weeks into the regular season.

headline: Robert Weber Dies at 92; His New Yorker Cartoons Twitted the Overprivileged
abstract: The people Mr. Weber drew over 45 years for the magazine were nothing if not entitled, going about with what some might see as skewed expectations.
lead_paragraph: Robert Weber, whose elegant and witty cartoons about the privileged and the self-involved were staples of The New Yorker for 45 years, died on Oct. 20 in Branford, Conn. He was 92.

headline: A Day Late for ‘Hamilton’
abstract: A theatergoer picks up two coveted tickets she won’t be able to use.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Stanford Lipsey, 89, Publisher Whose Nebraska Weeklies Won Pulitzer, Dies
abstract: Mr. Lipsey’s Omaha chain, the Sun Newspapers, won in 1973 for exposing fund-raising excesses by Boys Town, the charity for orphaned children.
lead_paragraph: Stanford Lipsey, a publisher who persuaded Warren E. Buffett to invest in newspapers and whose chain of Nebraska weeklies won a Pulitzer Prize for exposing fund-raising excesses by Boys Town, the charity for orphaned children, died on Tuesday at his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 89.

headline: Don Marshall, Who Made Casting History in ‘Land of the Giants,’ Is Dead at 80
abstract: Mr. Marshall, one of the first black actors to have a starring role on an American network television series, also appeared in television movies and feature films.
lead_paragraph: Don Marshall, one of the first black actors to have a starring role on an American network television series, as a spaceship’s efficient, levelheaded first officer stranded on a mysterious planet on “Land of the Giants,” died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 80.

headline: ‘Serial Human Rights Abuser’ in Iran to Get 135 Lashes in Graft Case
keywords: ['Corporal Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The former prosecutor, Saeed Mortazavi, once known as the “butcher of the press,” was sentenced in a corruption case.
lead_paragraph: A former high-ranking Iranian judicial official who came to symbolize Iran’s violent suppression of rights activists and journalists has been sentenced to 135 lashes in a corruption case.

headline: Reaching the Top, the Cubs and the Indians Are Poised to Stay There
abstract: It is easy to imagine a World Series rematch of the Cubs and the Indians. A lot can go wrong, but few teams are positioned better for sustained success.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — It is easy to imagine a World Series rematch, someday soon, of the Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians. Both teams have young players just entering their primes, and several stars on long-term contracts.

headline: Filling Harry Reid’s Nevada Senate Seat
abstract: While Joe Heck was serving his party in Congress, Catherine Cortez Masto was fighting for Nevadans battered by the housing crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Senate race in Nevada between Catherine Cortez Masto, a Democrat, and Representative Joe Heck, a Republican, is gripping on several levels. Nevada is the only state where Republicans have a solid chance of winning a Democratic Senate seat this year. The seat has belonged for 30 years to Harry Reid, the current minority leader, who is not seeking re-election. A Republican victory would thus be not only a loss for the Democrats but a personal embarrassment for a venerable power broker. It would also be a triumph for the Koch brothers, who say they’re seeking poetic justice after years of being denounced by Mr. Reid for their conservative politics, and are spending lots of money to make that happen.

headline: David Ross, Oldest Player in World Series, Ends Career in Climactic Game 7
abstract: Cubs catcher Ross, 39, began his career in 2002 with the Dodgers and will end it after the Cubs attempt to end their 108-year championship drought.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — For more than eight months, from the start of spring training to the start of Game 7 of the World Series on  Wednesday night, David Ross felt as if his baseball life had become the stuff of big-screen fiction, if not straight-up fantasy.

headline: Readers React After Pope Francis Says Ban on Female Priests Is Most Likely Permanent
abstract: In a news conference on Tuesday, the pope cited an apostolic letter in which Pope John Paul II said women could not be ordained because Jesus chose men as apostles.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis said on Tuesday that the Roman Catholic Church’s teaching that women cannot be ordained as priests was likely to last forever.

headline: Collusion Caused Dodgers TV Blackout, Justice Department Says
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Television', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The government accuses DirecTV of making moves that corrupted negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Most of the Los Angeles market has been unable to watch Dodgers games on the team’s cable channel since 2014, an impasse that this season deprived many fans of the farewell tour of Vin Scully, the broadcaster who retired last month after 67 seasons as the voice of the team.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, November 3, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t want pity. I just want people to care. Do you know what your politicians are sending us to do?”

headline: College Is the Goal: Will These Teenagers Get There?
abstract: The Times followed three teenagers in Topeka, Kan., on their quest to go to college. Follow their paths here.
lead_paragraph: The Times followed three teenagers in Topeka, Kan., on their quest to go to college. Follow their paths here.

headline: Outrage in Bronx as Barnes & Noble Is Set to Close
abstract: A rent increase has prompted the store to shutter in January, leaving the underserved borough without a general-interest bookstore.
lead_paragraph: Every day after school, 4-year-old Nicholai Rose demands that his mother take him first to the park then to the Barnes & Noble in the Baychester neighborhood of the Bronx. There, they snuggle in a corner in the children’s section and, each time, read “I Need My Monster,” his favorite picture book.

headline: Acclaimed Novels and Memoirs That Call the Bronx Home
abstract: While Brooklyn and Manhattan might be better known from book titles, the Bronx has been home to famous authors and host to venues that provided them with their muse.
lead_paragraph: While Brooklyn and Manhattan might be better known from book titles, the Bronx has been home to famous authors and host to venues that provided them with their muse.

headline: City College Gets Interim Leader After President’s Sudden Exit
abstract: Vincent G. Boudreau, dean of the Colin L. Powell school at City College, was appointed to take over for Lisa S. Coico, who quit last month amid a federal inquiry involving her personal expenses.
lead_paragraph: Hoping to restore some stability to the City College of New York after the unexpected resignation of its president, the City University of New York announced on Wednesday that it had selected an interim leader for its flagship college.

headline: Carousel Locale
abstract: Mel Rosen returns to offer us a fairly easy Thursday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — There is a point in developing one’s solving skills where you finally get good enough to drop in quite a few answers without having to think about them very much and that, to be honest, is when most people get a little cocky. There’s nothing wrong with that; confidence is a wonderful thing, especially when you’ve spent so much time battling the grid.

headline: Review: Anna Deavere Smith’s ‘Notes From the Field’ Delivers Voices of Despair and Hope
abstract: Anna Deavere Smith’s new performance piece explores the cursed intersection of two American institutions, the school and the prison, in a racially divided nation.
lead_paragraph: Just listen, if you would, to how she listens.

headline: Review: ‘Kingdom Come,’ About Meeting (but Not Cute) Online
abstract: In this comedy-drama by Jenny Rachel Weiner, two women in Carson, Nev., establish an internet bond, though one of them has assumed the guise of a man.
lead_paragraph: Two lonely women search for connection online, with unexpected results, in “Kingdom Come,” a low-key but likable new comedy-drama by Jenny Rachel Weiner that opened at the Roundabout Underground on Wednesday.

headline: Bronx Man Dies After Police Use Taser on Him
abstract: Officers responding to a 911 call confronted the man, who was emotionally disturbed and threatened them with a glass bottle, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: An emotionally disturbed Bronx man who threatened a neighbor with a knife died after a police sergeant used an electric stun gun on him, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: Not-So-Ordinary ‘Joe’: Final Round for an Arena Named for an Athlete
abstract: Joe Louis, which will be torn down after the Redwings move out next year, is one of a tiny number of high-profile stadiums or arenas named for an athlete.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Red Wings have begun their final season at Joe Louis Arena. And when they move out next year, it will be the end for an arena with a feature that is exceedingly rare in major North American sports.

headline: With Mosul Under Siege, ISIS Leader Breaks Silence to Issue a Rallying Cry
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The recording by Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the professed caliph of the Islamic State, was his first in nearly a year and came days after Iraqi troops entered Mosul.
lead_paragraph: After a nearly yearlong silence, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi, the self-declared caliph of the Islamic State, released a blistering audio recording imploring his forces to remain firm in the face of the American-backed Iraqi offensive in Mosul and excoriating those who might consider fleeing.

headline: Knicks, Lacking Coordination Against Rockets, Fall Again
abstract: The Knicks stand at 1-3 after a second consecutive double-digit loss on a second consecutive day, with James Harden exposing defensive deficiencies.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony sat on the Knicks’ bench, sifting through another drubbing — a second consecutive double-digit loss on a second consecutive day — and addressed the frustration bubbling out. He soothed himself by once again taking the long-term view and by telling himself that it will get better for these Knicks.

headline: Renewable Energy Grows in an Unlikely Place: the Sunny Mideast
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: The Middle East, long a bastion of oil and gas production, is moving toward solar power.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When it comes to energy, the Middle East and Persian Gulf are best known for their oil and gas. But across the region, governments, power companies and investors are beginning to exploit another abundant resource: the sun.

headline: Energy Giants Turn to Drones and Sensors in New Embrace of the Digital World
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Amid continuing low oil and natural gas prices, companies are again turning to tech advances to cut costs, raise productivity and expand exploration.
lead_paragraph: When Chris Blackford started pitching Sky-Futures, the drone company he had co-founded, to oil and natural gas companies, there initially was not much interest.

headline: Five Places to Shop Around Brick Lane in London
abstract: With its bohemian flair and cultural mix, Brick Lane and the surrounding streets have become a destination for vintage lovers and trend seekers alike.
lead_paragraph: The sinuous, narrow streets and low-slung buildings around Brick Lane in London’s East End were once a part of a rough-and-tumble neighborhood. Nowadays, seedy has given way to charming, as scores of young Londoners gather on the sidewalks or sit on the curbs, happily eating takeout curry from a number of places. Indie rock music wafts through the air, adding to the festive vibe. With its bohemian flair and appealing mix of cultures, Brick Lane and the surrounding streets have become a destination for vintage lovers and trend-seekers alike.

headline: A Global Climate Deal Was Reached. Next Up Is Pollution Monitoring.
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Global Warming', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: The new phase of turning agreements into a real reduction of emissions starts on Monday at the next major United Nations climate change summit conference.
lead_paragraph: The Paris climate agreement is, obviously, a very big deal: Last year, nearly 200 nations agreed to take on the challenge of a warming world. Their stated goal was to hold the increases in world temperature since the beginning of the industrial revolution to well below 2 degrees Celsius.

headline: Why Light Bulbs May Be the Next Hacker Target
keywords: ['Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Research']
abstract: Wireless “smart” devices may be the tech wave of the future, but researchers have found flaws that let hackers spread malicious code through them.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The so-called Internet of Things, its proponents argue, offers many benefits: energy efficiency, technology so convenient it can anticipate what you want, even reduced congestion on the roads.

headline: Pollution Accord Is Set for Global Flights, but Tasks Remain
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Global Warming', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: The new agreement for world aviation aims to cap greenhouse gas emissions, but doubts emerge about the plan’s use of complex offsetting credits.
lead_paragraph: The great and the good of world aviation gathered in Montreal last month to do something that seemed impossible even a couple of years ago. They agreed to cap greenhouse gas emissions from international flights.

headline: Batteries That Make Use of Solar Power, Even in the Dark
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Batteries', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Lithium (Metal)', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Solar farms are increasingly common, but they depend on the sun. A new technology harvests that energy so it can be sold when prices are high.
lead_paragraph: HARTWELL, ENGLAND — A new cash crop has sprung up on Nicholas Beatty’s enchanting farm near here. Rows of gray solar panels range over about 25 acres, turning sunlight into electricity, as dog-size muntjac deer hop by.

headline: ‘Everyone Needs to Act’: What to Expect From Climate Talks in Morocco
keywords: ['United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Ahead of the global climate change conference, four experts explain why it is an important, if less momentous, follow-up to Paris.
lead_paragraph: When representatives of 200 nations meet at a crucial two-week climate change conference in Marrakesh, Morocco, on Monday, their goal will be to put some force behind the pledges they made a year ago in Paris to reduce the emissions responsible for global warming.

headline: Big Oil Slowly Adapts to a Warming World
abstract: Major oil and gas companies, facing future loss of demand for their products as a result of climate change policies, search for new strategies.
lead_paragraph: In a warming world, Big Oil doesn’t look quite so big anymore.

headline: Big Question on Climate Crisis: How to Inspire Innovation
abstract: The world’s governments have committed to slashing greenhouse emissions, but it is not clear the necessary technology exists yet.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — On the edge of this northern German port city, the industrial giant Siemens is testing a way to offset the erratic nature of renewable power, by storing energy in hot rocks.

headline: After the Florence Flood: Saving Vasari’s ‘Last Supper’
abstract: A Renaissance masterwork, severely damaged in 1966, is restored and reinstalled in Florence, Italy.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, ITALY — In early morning light, the low buildings lining both sides of the Arno River here glow in their myriad shades of ochre, like the shallow river itself, which flows calmly through the city.

headline: Chicago Cubs, Mosul, Jacob Zuma: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘All the President’s Men’ and ‘The Good Place’
abstract: Email “scandal”? Gain some perspective with “All the President’s Men,” about Watergate. And “The Good Place” goes on hiatus — but not before Michael tries to weed out the bad.
lead_paragraph: Email “scandal”? Gain some perspective with “All the President’s Men,” Alan J. Pakula’s Watergate classic. And Benedict Cumberbatch and Rachel Maddow chat up Jimmy Fallon.

headline: Cubs End 108-Year Wait for World Series Title, After a Little More Torment
abstract: The Chicago Cubs shattered their championship drought in epic fashion: with an 8-7, 10-inning victory over the Cleveland Indians in Game 7 of the World Series.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — If you are going to endure years — no, generations — of futility and heartbreak, when you do finally win a World Series championship, it may as well be a memorable one.

headline: With a Curse-Breaking Hit, Ben Zobrist Lives a Dream He Never Expected
abstract: Zobrist, who grew up in Illinois, delivered a one-out double in Game 7 that put the Cubs ahead for good and helped clinch an elusive championship.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — As the clubhouse cleared out early Wednesday morning, after the Chicago Cubs had forced Game 7 of this rollicking World Series with the Cleveland Indians, Ben Zobrist was asked if he had dreamed of a chance like this.

headline: Review: Netflix Does Queen Elizabeth II in ‘The Crown,’ No Expense Spared
abstract: This new series explores the ascendance of Elizabeth II of Britain with performances that linger.
