abstract: This word has appeared in 41 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: 1. used of old persons or old trees; covered with knobs or knots

headline: Let the Public See Police Officers’ Records
abstract: The de Blasio administration has shut down access to records that had been available to the news media for decades.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio recently called on the State Legislature to rewrite a 40-year-old law that has been interpreted as barring the public release of just about any information from the employment histories of police officers — even some who have committed crimes. The law, the only one of its kind in the nation, is indeed overly broad. But Mr. de Blasio, who ran for office as a champion of transparency, has more latitude in interpreting it than he has thus far used.

headline: The Election Polls That Matter
abstract: Smart campaigns ignore public polls and use “little data” to target appeals to voters.
lead_paragraph: With just days left in the 2016 presidential election, Americans are wondering if polling is accurate or if we’ll see a Brexit-style shock.

headline: Trump Is an Existential Threat
abstract: You can’t say yes to Trump and yes to common decency.
lead_paragraph: There are only a handful of days until Election Day and an end to this phase of a nation’s — and the world’s — ebb and flow of anxiety. The day after the votes are cast and counted that anxiety will either dissipate or become a fixed feature. Which of these it will be is very much in flux.

headline: 5 Reasons to Vote Trump
abstract: With Donald Trump, we’d have our own Kim Jong-un.
lead_paragraph: 1.) Who needs experience to be president? It’s true that Donald Trump would have less public service experience than any president in American history, but knowledge is lame. Maybe the Know-Nothing Party in the 19th century captured this spirit in its name — and Trump is the apotheosis of knowing-nothing. In my journalistic career, I’ve never met a national candidate as ill informed, evasive or puerile as Donald Trump.

headline: Republican Candidates, Admit It’s Hillary You’re Voting For
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: How can you trust a senator if he can’t even bring himself to choose a president?
lead_paragraph: Look, you need a rest. Let’s talk about the Senate races.

headline: A Stronger Court for Crimes Against Humanity
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The international community cannot let the war crimes tribunal wither as African nations start to defect.
lead_paragraph: Since it began operations in 2002, the International Criminal Court has secured just four convictions, fueling the perception that it has been largely ineffectual as a tribunal of last resort for the world’s worst criminals. Making matters worse, Gambia, Burundi and South Africa have announced their intention to leave the court, which some African leaders see as a vestige of colonialism because it has so far tried cases only from  their continent.

headline: The Political Awakening of a Fashion Power Player
abstract: Raúl Martinez, the most powerful Latino in glossy publishing, finds his voice.
lead_paragraph: American fashion has never been afraid of declaring its political allegiance, at least in an insider kind of way. During the last two presidential elections, for example, numerous designers created pieces to raise money for the Obama campaign in initiatives called Runway to Change (in 2008) and Runway to Win (in 2012), and Anna Wintour, the artistic director of Condé Nast, is a famous bundler.

headline: A Whimsical Slice of British Life
abstract: Homer Sykes photographed local festivals and ceremonies that call to mind unusual and obscure sides of British society.
lead_paragraph: A Westminster School annual Shrove Tuesday pancake toss in London. A tar barrel parade in Northumberland. Hammering a nail into a man’s shoe in Berkshire. The Grovely Forest Rights in Wiltshire.

headline: A Whimsical Slice of British Life
abstract: Homer Sykes photographed local festivals and ceremonies that call to mind unusual and obscure sides of British society.
lead_paragraph: Homer Sykes photographed local festivals and ceremonies that call to mind unusual and obscure sides of British society.

headline: The Winning View From Chicago
abstract: Step into the crowd outside Wrigley Field in the bottom of the 10th inning, moments before the Cubs’ World Series win.
lead_paragraph: Step into the crowd outside Wrigley Field in the bottom of the 10th inning, moments before the Cubs’ World Series win.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Juggling Act
abstract: She is paying a political price for her allegiance to three different wings of the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Has the Democratic Party joined the Republican Party in becoming inhospitable to the accommodation of intraparty factions?

headline: Carl Edwards Jr., the String Bean Slinger, Helps Cubs Get to the Finish Line
abstract: Edwards and Mike Montgomery combined to finish off the Indians in the pressure-packed final moments of Game 7, but not without a bit of unsteadiness.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Just before Game 7 of the World Series resumed in the top of the 10th inning following a 17-minute rain delay, Chicago Cubs reliever Mike Montgomery turned to his fellow reliever, Carl Edwards Jr., with a prediction.

headline: How a Philosophy Professor Found Love in a Hidden Library
abstract: In “American Philosophy,” the professor John Kaag writes about a discovery that gave him a new sense of self and transformed his notions about life.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN PHILOSOPHYA Love StoryBy John Kaag259 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $26.

headline: I’m Not the Nanny: Multiracial Families and Colorism
abstract: Lori L. Tharps’s “Same Family, Different Colors” is an urgent and honest unveiling of how color operates in the most intimate spaces of American families.
lead_paragraph: SAME FAMILY, DIFFERENT COLORSConfronting Colorism in America’s Diverse FamiliesBy Lori L. Tharps203 pp. Beacon Press. $25.95.

headline: Not All Ragùs Are Italian
abstract: A simplified take on a Chinese takeout dish that became a New York restaurant classic.
lead_paragraph: “It’s just a complete rip-off of mapo tofu,” the chef Tien Ho said. Ho was once David Chang’s chief lieutenant at Momofuku Ssam Bar in New York, and he was talking about the origins of one of the restaurant’s greatest hits: spicy pork sausage and rice cakes, born in 2006. “We would always order mapo tofu from that Sichuan place on St. Mark’s, after work,” he said, “and Chang thought we could make something like it for the restaurant.”

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘Pinky and the Brain’
abstract: It’s typically insulting to call a show formulaic, but sometimes the genius is the formula.
lead_paragraph: During an interview I did with Conan O’Brien a while back, we drifted onto the topic of rules: when it was prudent, as a creative person, to flout conventions, and when it made sense to obey them. As O’Brien saw it, only ever flouting, without a healthy dose of obeying, was unsustainable and, on balance, unfunny. To illustrate, he told me a story, one that didn’t make it into the piece I wrote but stuck with me nonetheless: A well-known comedian with a raucous persona, interested in developing his own talk show, once sought O’Brien’s advice. “He showed me a prototype of what it would be: He comes out, he runs through the audience, he’s never in one place. He’s everywhere, he’s nowhere, he’s wearing different clothes, spray-painting on the walls — total anarchy,” O’Brien recalled. “And I said, O.K., here’s my take: You’re a brilliantly funny person, but you need to be constrained, because when you break those constraints, it’s enormously satisfying.”

headline: Do Laws That Ban Offensive Words Make the World a Better Place?
abstract: Should the right to free speech trump our desire to end the use of hateful words?
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in South Africa want to make hate speech a crime. Backers of the draft law say racist language can violate human rights and is not compatible with the nation’s values. Opponents say that criminalizing hate speech will erode freedom of expression and do little to heal the country’s racial wounds.

headline: The Healing Powers of Laughter Yoga
abstract: Two decades ago, in a land of sensory overload and spiritual abundance, a doctor mixed together meditation and hilarity.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, in a land of sensory overload and spiritual abundance, a doctor mixed together meditation and hilarity.

headline: Want to Know What Virtual Reality Might Become? Look to the Past
abstract: Nineteenth-century diversions could offer some clues about the medium’s potential.
lead_paragraph: The Scottish scientist David Brewster was one of those 19th-century characters with no real equivalent today. An ordained minister in the Church of Scotland, he took an early interest in astronomy and became for a time one of the world’s leading experts on the science of optics. He also harbored a great fondness for popular amusements, and at some point in the early part of the century, he began frequenting a theatrical horror show in the West End of London called the Phantasmagoria. He went in part as a debunker, a skeptic hoping to reveal the secret craft behind the spectacle. But he also sensed that something profound was lurking in the trickery. He suspected that the showmen were exploiting some intrinsic quirks in the human sensory system — perhaps, he hoped, rendering them more intelligible to the scientist. Brewster called the world of scientifically produced illusion “natural magic.”

headline: Worth the Wait: A Westchester One-Bedroom
abstract: Salvatore Di Vittorio and Santa Maria Pecoraro Di Vittorio found what they wanted in Larchmont, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: When Salvatore Di Vittorio and Santa Maria Pecoraro met nearly 20 years ago at Orvieto Musica, a music festival in Italy, he was splitting his time between New York and his hometown, Palermo, Italy, and she was living at home in her native San Diego.

headline: Presidential Election: Melania Trump and Bernie Sanders to the Rescue
abstract: Ms. Trump and Mr. Sanders hit the campaign trail as Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump barnstormed across North Carolina on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump barnstormed across North Carolina on Thursday, each seeking to bolster support in a battleground state that has switched from Democrat to Republican in the past eight years.

headline: Review: ‘Doctor Strange’ and His Most Excellent Adventure
abstract: This film is so giddily enjoyable and visually transfixing, you might forget that it’s part of Marvel’s strategy for world domination.
lead_paragraph: Most Marvel movies open like Robert Downey Jr.’s stand-up routine in “Iron Man” before it goes south. They deliver quips and silky come-hither nonsense, only to end up like a big green monster stuck on rewind: “Hulk smash!” again and again, ad infinitum. In between start and finish, there are moments of levity and discovery in the machined product, but too often you can’t see the movie for Marvel’s action plan. Its latest, the giddily enjoyable “Doctor Strange,” is part of Marvel’s strategy for world domination, yet it’s also so visually transfixing, so beautiful and nimble that you may even briefly forget the brand.

headline: A Rare Moment of Unity on Capitol Hill, Thanks to Trump’s Taxes
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Taxation', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Revelations that Donald J. Trump paid no federal income tax for years, or decades, have energized bipartisan efforts to overhaul the loophole-ridden tax code.
lead_paragraph: There may be a silver lining in the revelation that Donald J. Trump paid no federal income tax for years or even decades: a comprehensive overhaul of the nation’s loophole-riddled revenue-gathering system.

headline: A Cashless Economy in Zimbabwe? With Little Cash, There’s Little Choice
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Debit Cards', 'Currency', 'Text Messaging', 'Cellular Telephones', 'US Dollar (Currency)']
abstract: Debit card machines are proliferating in churches, supermarkets and nightclubs as anxious Zimbabweans hoard American dollars or take them out of the country.
lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — The time came for worshipers to surrender their tithes on Sunday morning. But instead of dropping bills into a collection plate, the congregants at a large Pentecostal church rose and filed toward the deacons clutching hand-held card-reading machines. With a swipe, they were done.

headline: Five Possible Hacks to Worry About Before Election Day
abstract: Rigged election? Not likely. But much can go wrong, from hacking the voter rolls to slowing the internet on Nov. 8. And the N.S.A. has its eyes on Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia dismisses the idea that he has the power to interfere with Tuesday’s election. “Does anyone seriously think that Russia can affect the choice of the American people?” he asked during a foreign policy conference last week in the resort city of Sochi. “What, is America a banana republic? America’s a great power. Correct me if I’m wrong.”

headline: Questions for: ‘Behind 2016’s Turmoil, a Crisis of White Identity’
abstract: What is happening today to cause this crisis in the United States and elsewhere in the West?

headline: Crypt Believed to Be Jesus’ Tomb Opened for First Time in Centuries
keywords: ['Tombs and Tombstones', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The tomb was opened as part of a renovation of the shrine that was built around it long after Jesus’ death in what today is known as the Church of the Holy Sepulcher.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The only mystical power visible was the burning light from seven tapered candles. And yet for ages, the tomb that sits at the center of history has captured the imaginations of millions around the world.

headline: How the University of Alabama Became a National Player
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'States (US)', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Tuition', 'Student Loans']
abstract: State schools like Alabama are following a new survival strategy: lure top students, boost reputation, raise tuition, go big.
lead_paragraph: It’s only fitting that the admissions tour for the University of Alabama starts in Bryant-Denny Stadium. On game days, the campus’s iconic quad — a painterly expanse of lawn, majestic trees and bell tower — becomes a crimson and white tent city of numbered tailgating plots, some with electricity.

headline: Bottom Line: How State Budget Cuts Affect Your Education
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'States (US)', 'Tuition', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Doing more with less is the new norm. Some public universities are even finding fresh ways to ease students’ burden.
lead_paragraph: Higher education has been an easy target for budget cuts since the 2008 recession, forcing many public universities to lay off faculty and staff members, postpone investment in new facilities and raise tuition and fees (up an average 31 percent for in-state students). State support for public two- and four-year colleges — funding is nearly $10 billion below what it was just before the recession — has begun to recover, though officials at the nation’s flagship universities say that doing more with less is the new norm. Some are even finding fresh ways to ease the financial burden on students.

headline: Those Hidden College Fees
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Tuition', 'States (US)', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Schools are tacking more and more extra charges onto students’ bills, much of it for basic educational services. Some call it “backdoor tuition.”
lead_paragraph: The parade of fees on college campuses never seems to end. There are extra charges to start college, such as orientation fees and freshman fees, and extra charges to finish, such as senior fees and commencement fees. There are nickel-and-dime fees, like $8.50 at Indiana University to drop a class after two days, and large ones, like $3,049 to major in digital media and animation at Alfred State College, State University of New York.

headline: The Strong Women of ‘Star Wars’
abstract: Leia, Rey and now Jyn Erso are the best known, but they’re hardly alone. And they all can match lightsabers with Darth Vader.
lead_paragraph: Leia, Rey and now Jyn Erso are the best known, but they’re hardly alone. And they all can match lightsabers with Darth Vader.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: What We Know About ‘Rogue One’
abstract: The new movie in the “Star Wars” universe looks to be an international affair, with actors from many countries, and a story with some familiar themes.
lead_paragraph: Yes, a new movie in the “Star Wars” universe is coming to theaters Dec. 16. Yes, that movie, “Rogue One: A Star Wars Story,” will have rebels and droids and Stormtroopers. And yes, the Death Star factors in heavily. But it is the first stand-alone story for the big screen, meaning that it doesn’t directly continue the saga unfolding in the previous films. Here’s what else we know, culled from a variety of sources.

headline: Morning Agenda: Fed Holds Steady, Teaming Up or Divesting?
abstract: The Federal Reserve decided not to raise rates, but struck a more positive note than in September. Why all the indecision?
lead_paragraph: Steady as she goes.

headline: Trevor Noah: By the Book
abstract: The “Daily Show” host and author of “Born a Crime” travels a lot, but doesn’t read when he flies: “I can’t stay awake when I try to read on a plane. Planes are for watching movies based on books.”
lead_paragraph: The “Daily Show” host and author of “Born a Crime” travels a lot, but doesn’t read when he flies: “I can’t stay awake when I try to read on a plane. Planes are for watching movies based on books.”

headline: Exploring the Speakeasies of Rome
abstract: Hidden from sight in the Eternal City, high cocktail culture is flourishing in a host of secret bars.
lead_paragraph: Rome’s cobbled, snaking alleyways lend themselves to mystery, and today’s best places to raise a glass in the Eternal City are fittingly clandestine, with entrance gained by a knock, a phone call or a membership card.

headline: How Female Fans Made ‘Star Wars’ Their Own
abstract: Podcasts and websites are part of a universe of fandom that revolves around women.
lead_paragraph: The premiere of “Rogue One,” the first stand-alone “Star Wars” film, is six weeks away, and fans have gathered online to speculate about what treasures the film will hold. What’s the deal with the set photo of a shaggy alien that looks a little like a robo-sasquatch? What are the chances that all the rebel heroes will survive to the end? Is Darth Vader going to murder any of them personally? Oh, and how is this movie going to treat women?

headline: 10 Things to Know About Being a Sperm Donor
abstract: First off, it’s anything but simple, and your chances of being accepted are low. You’ll be poked, prodded and questioned, and you’d better be productive.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of sperm banks across the country are recruiting men to help them build up a supply of frozen sperm to meet the growing demand from women looking to start families.

headline: New York Today: Our City’s Other Presidential Candidates
abstract: Thursday: Write-in candidates, marathon quadruplets and the savage campaign of 1824.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:20 a.m.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Will Require a Vote in Parliament, U.K. Court Rules
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The High Court decision on negotiations over Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union seemed likely to slow — but not halt — the process.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government’s plan for leaving the European Union was thrown into uncertainty on Thursday after the High Court ruled that Parliament must give its approval before the process can begin.

headline: The Striking Humanity of ‘Moonlight’
abstract: A.O. Scott joins to talk about the coming-of-age film. We also discuss Solange’s “A Seat at the Table” and how to unwind.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while a movie shows up that everyone agrees is perfect. This year, that unanimously adored film is Barry Jenkins’s “Moonlight,” about one Miami boy’s coming-of-age. His name is Chiron. He’s poor. He’s black. And he’s gay. The miracle of the movie is how it’s interested in none of that. The only condition it cares about is the human condition. Not many movies about black men share that concern.

headline: 2 U.S. Soldiers and 30 Afghans Killed in Kunduz Battle
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Officials said the Afghan dead were civilians killed by airstrikes near the provincial capital, but differed on whether strikes were Afghan or American.
lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — Two American soldiers and more than 30 Afghans were killed Thursday in the midst of heavy fighting around the northern provincial capital of Kunduz, officials and local residents said.

headline: World Series Champions
abstract: What is the most exciting sports win — at any level — that you have ever watched or participated in?

headline: Voters Express Disgust Over U.S. Politics in New Times/CBS Poll
abstract: Most voters say that their minds are made up and that late revelations about Mrs. Clinton and Donald J. Trump made no significant difference to them.
lead_paragraph: An overwhelming majority of voters are disgusted by the state of American politics, and many harbor doubts that either major-party nominee can unite the country after a historically ugly presidential campaign, according to the final pre-election New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Summary of High Court Ruling on Article 50 and ‘Brexit’
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']

headline: An 80-Year-Old Model Reshapes China’s Views on Aging

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Before cranking up the techno music at his 80th birthday party, the man known as “China’s hottest grandpa” paused from his D.J. duties to poke fun at the country’s staid traditional celebrations for the elderly.

headline: Arizona’s Scarred Generation
abstract: Two daughters of Mexican immigrants who crossed the border illegally. Two different futures for young Latinos. Which will we choose?
lead_paragraph: Two daughters of Mexican immigrants who crossed the border illegally. Two different futures for young Latinos. Which will we choose?

headline: Review: A Revival of ‘The Dresser’ in London
abstract: Ronald Harwood’s play features Ken Stott as a barnstorming actor who is devoted to the role of King Lear.
lead_paragraph: In a week that finds Glenda Jackson returning to the British stage for the first time in 25 years, and playing no less a role than King Lear, at least one thing is clear: Ken Stott in the wan London revival of Ronald Harwood’s 1980 play “The Dresser” is offering little in the way of competition.

headline: Why Are Ballot Measures So Confusing?
abstract: Voters are often mixed up by the opaque language they face in the polling booth.

headline: Will the Ax Fall on Nigeria’s National Parks?
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Forests and Forestry', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Biodiversity']
abstract: A highway project threatens to cut a swath through priceless rain forest, home to many endangered species.
lead_paragraph: Among the unfortunate headlines about Boko Haram and email scams, it is easy to overlook that Nigeria boasts seven national parks and some of the richest biodiversity in West Africa. Nearly all of that flora and fauna is concentrated in Cross River State in the country’s southeast corner, abutting Cameroon. There, the Nigerian government hopes to have the magnificent Cross River National Park listed as a Unesco World Heritage Site.

headline: Thailand Court Clears U.K. Labor Activist of Defaming Fruit Company

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A British labor activist who accused a Thai fruit company of abusing migrant workers was cleared of a criminal defamation charge by Thailand’s highest court on Thursday.

headline: California Today: An Invasive Beetle Threatens State’s Southern Palm Trees
abstract: Thursday: Hungry palm weevils endanger the landscape, Silicon Valley startups put their spin on Marijuana products, and ski resorts gear up for the season.

headline: What to Expect While Voting, a Short Guide
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Voting may be a basic right, but it can be a complicated one to exercise.

headline: Don’t Bother With National Polls
abstract: Tightening national polls don’t deserve as much attention as they get.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: What’s Your Ideal Community? The Answer Is Political
abstract: There is a clear correlation between where people live and their chances of being conservative or liberal. Less clear is why.
lead_paragraph: The American political map that has emerged over the last half-century, with blue cities and red beyond, is a product of both the ideological realignment of the two parties and geographic sorting among voters. It also raises a fascinating question about how our politics are shaped by where we live.

headline: Twitchy, Sweaty, but Triumphant: Cubs Go Home as Winners at Last
abstract: An insanely melodramatic, extra-inning affair in the World Series pushed both teams into the embrace of exhaustion before Chicago was crowned king.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The game began with what sounded like an ax striking a tree as a Cubs leadoff batter hit a soaring home run to the deepest recesses of center field; it ended with a helplessly grinning Cubs third baseman scooping a slow-rolling bouncer and tossing it to first base.

headline: Google Home vs. Amazon Echo: A Face-Off of Smart Speakers
keywords: ['Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Speakers (Audio)', 'Voice Recognition Systems']
abstract: Which is a better helper, Google Home or Amazon Echo? A side-by-side test for six days revealed strengths and weaknesses.
lead_paragraph: TO get an idea of how annoying it can be to say “O.K., Google” multiple times a day, try replacing the word Google with another brand.

headline: Is Donald Trump an American Hugo Chávez?
abstract: The Republican candidate and the deceased Venezuelan president are both populists by posture, if not ideology.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — To dramatic music, the video starts with a clip of the Republican nominee for president, Donald J. Trump, threatening to jail his rival, Hillary Clinton, before the words “Te recuerda a alguien” (“Does this remind you of someone”) pop up. The image switches to the former Venezuelan president Hugo Chávez, founder of the self-declared Socialist revolution, who steered his oil-rich nation to meltdown.

headline: Transit Worker Fatally Struck by Subway Train in Brooklyn
abstract: Three workers were on the tracks near the Fort Hamilton Parkway station to set up a work zone when a G train hit two of the workers around 12:05 a.m., transit officials said.
lead_paragraph: A transit worker was struck and killed by a subway train in Brooklyn on Thursday morning while he was working on the tracks, officials said.

headline: E.U. Official, Under Pressure for Having Disparaged the Chinese, Apologizes

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Günther H. Oettinger, a European commissioner from Germany, apologized on Thursday for describing Chinese people as “slit-eyes” and “sly dogs,” an about-face that came only after several days of pressure to acknowledge the offensive nature of his remarks.

headline: Putting Sugary Soda Out of Reach
abstract: Workplaces are banning the sale of soft drinks as part of a growing effort to curb their consumption around the country.
lead_paragraph: Can public health officials force Americans to break their soda habit?

headline: In Italy, a Town Still ‘Broken’ by a Quake. The One 7 Years Ago.
abstract: L’Aquila, devastated by a 2009 earthquake, is Italy’s largest construction site. Yet much of it still feels like a ghost town, a sobering sign for cities struck by more recent quakes.
lead_paragraph: L’AQUILA, Italy — As three big earthquakes rattled central Italy last month after a major quake there this summer, thousands more Italians were left homeless, and Prime Minister Matteo Renzi pledged anew on Wednesday that every stricken town would return to what it had been.

headline: Donald Trump Can’t Count on Those ‘Missing White Voters’
abstract: The white voters who have joined the electorate since 2012 are younger and likelier to support Hillary Clinton than those who were already registered.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and his supporters hope to overcome sweeping demographic shifts by rallying the support of “missing white voters” — disaffected, conservative populists who sat out the 2012 presidential election.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Trolls’
abstract: The director Mike Mitchell and co-director Walt Dohrn narrate a musical scene from “Trolls” featuring Anna Kendrick.
lead_paragraph: The director Mike Mitchell and co-director Walt Dohrn narrate a musical scene from “Trolls” featuring Anna Kendrick.

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Recent arrivals from Africa and Afghanistan have been living in pup tents in the city’s northern neighborhoods, creating a new crisis for the French.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The migrant crisis in France has shifted from the “Jungle” of Calais to the streets of Paris, with hundreds camped out in tents in the city’s northern neighborhoods and dozens more arriving each day.

headline: Video Review: McLaren 570GT Is a Rare Blend of Speed and Comfort
abstract: The company takes a softer approach, including a quieter cabin, with the GT compared with the 570S, but it still goes from 0-60 m.p.h. in 3.3 seconds.
lead_paragraph: LIKE many red-blooded American children, I spent high school study hall poring over the pages of car magazines. I ignored my English homework (surprise, Mrs. Oberg! I’m that Tom Voelk); my interest was in art. Ferrari and Lamborghini sculpture, that is.

headline: Justin Trudeau and the Sludge of Canadian Mining Companies
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The prime minister promised to be the opposite of his predecessor, but he now has to match words to deeds.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — “Canada is back,” says Justin Trudeau, the charismatic and bilingual prime minister of Canada, at international gatherings, seeking to showcase the imprint he wants to put on Canadian foreign policy in contrast to that of his predecessor, Stephen Harper. The prime minister has used very precise terms in his speeches: justice, environmental care, democracy and human rights. He even dared to invoke some of them during his official visit to China in September, although the Chinese did not applaud him for it.

headline: How Economic Data Is Kept Politics-Free
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Statistics', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Despite what partisans may say, career civil servants who compile employment reports follow ground rules that undermine claims that the results are rigged.
lead_paragraph: Talk about an October surprise. The post on Twitter warning of a government conspiracy to swing the presidential election in the Democrats’ favor popped up just moments after the Labor Department reported the biggest monthly decline in the unemployment rate in nine years.

headline: Guggenheim Helsinki Supporters Revise Plan
abstract: A new proposal to keep the museum project alive was presented by the Guggenheim Helsinki Supporting Foundation and the City of Helsinki on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: In an attempt to keep a Guggenheim Helsinki alive, supporters of the project on Thursday morning presented an updated proposal for the construction of the museum.

headline: Mike Mitchell and Walt Dohrn Discuss a Scene From ‘Trolls’

lead_paragraph: The animated comedy “Trolls” brings the fuzzy-haired toy dolls to enthusiastic life on the big screen. In this scene, Anna Kendrick provides the voice of Poppy, a troll setting off on a dangerous journey, cheerfully indifferent to the hazards along the way.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Painter’s Headaches
keywords: ['Brain', 'Nerves and Nervous System', 'Magnetic Resonance Imagers', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: What is causing this artist’s devastating headaches and odd changes in the way he sees the world? Enter our contest.
lead_paragraph: The Challenge: A 63-year-old painter develops headaches that become increasingly devastating, associated with changes in the way he sees and interacts with the world. Can you explain why?

headline: Octavia Spencer Cracks a Few Hollywood Equations
abstract: Ms. Spencer has built a sturdy résumé as a character actor, but she is moving past “nurse face” roles to play a mathematician in “Hidden Figures.”
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — On a film set in Canton, Miss., two decades ago, Octavia Spencer got a big break, and a foreshadowing that others might be harder to catch. She was in her mid-20s, working as a production assistant on the Matthew McConaughey-Sandra Bullock thriller “A Time to Kill.” She asked the director Joel Schumacher if she could read for a small part: perhaps the woman who starts a riot?

headline: South Korea’s Metastasizing Crisis
abstract: As a growing scandal consumes the presidency, only an independent investigation may save it.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s President Park Geun-hye is embroiled in a lurid corruption scandal that threatens to hamstring her remaining year in office. The scandal has plunged Ms. Park’s approval ratings to record lows, sent thousands of angry demonstrators into the streets, and sparked demands that she resign.

headline: 1916: French Push On North of Somme Despite Downpour
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The French forces at the Somme make a push toward Sailly-Saillisel and Lesboeufs and take 736 prisoners, in November 1916.
lead_paragraph: The persistence of the rain on the Somme front is seriously hindering infantry operations, but despite this the Allies continue to display a certain activity. During Wednesday night and yesterday [Nov. 2] the French troops never relaxed their efforts between Sailly-Saillisel and Lesboeufs, and as a result have considerably improved their position.

headline: Nashville Celebrates Its Heroes and Welcomes Beyoncé to C.M.A. Awards
abstract: The pop star performed her song “Daddy Lessons” with the Dixie Chicks at the 50th annual ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Nashville extolled its heroes and loyal insiders at the 50th annual Country Music Association Awards on Wednesday night, honoring Garth Brooks, Dolly Parton, Randy Travis and Merle Haggard. But it also made a point to demonstrate its pop-world openness with a rousing performance by Beyoncé and the unexpected return of Taylor Swift, who has long since outgrown her country side.

headline: Venezuela’s Tone-Deaf President
abstract: It is bewildering to watch Venezuela’s embattled president as he livestreams ever more hours of his life.
lead_paragraph: It was a curious week for President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela to launch a jovial radio show.

headline: Family Disputes and a Nasty Can of Beans: Hillary Clinton as Litigator
abstract: A tour of Mrs. Clinton’s early work as a litigator reveals how unglamorous it often was (a lawsuit on rat parts in a can of pork and beans). It also gives hints of what kind of politician she would become.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — They called him Tiny, naturally, because he was anything but. A bouncer at a pawnshop here, the man significantly outweighed most of the store’s customers and would-be robbers. Now, he stood accused of roughing up his girlfriend.

headline: 36 Hours in Manhattan, Below 59th Street
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Art', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The center of the world — filled with restaurants and glamorous nightclubs — lies between Central Park and the Battery.
lead_paragraph: The center of the world — filled with restaurants and glamorous nightclubs — lies between Central Park and the Battery.

headline: The Importance of Facial Equality
abstract: I call myself ‘disfigured’ because of the power the word carries.
lead_paragraph: I have never seen someone who looked like me on a mainstream television show. I have never seen someone who looked like me, playing anything but a villain in movies, or in an ad or on a billboard. I am invisible. That is, until I walk down the street. That is, until strangers stare just a little too long and rudely whisper, “look at her eyes.”

headline: Why English Keeps On, Like, Totally Changing
abstract: John Simpson’s “The Word Detective” and John McWhorter’s “Words on the Move” look at the progress of the English language.
lead_paragraph: THE WORD DETECTIVESearching for the Meaning of It All at the Oxford English DictionaryBy John Simpson364 pp. Basic Books. $27.99.

headline: Leïla Slimani Wins Prix Goncourt, France’s Top Literary Award
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Prix Goncourt', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Her novel “Chanson Douce” is loosely based on the real-life killing of two children in New York while in the care of their nanny in 2012.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Leïla Slimani, a French-Moroccan novelist, was awarded France’s top literary accolade, the Prix Goncourt, on Thursday for her book “Chanson Douce” (“Sweet Song”), a thriller that opens with the killing of two young children by their caretaker.

headline: Article 50: Reviewing the Road Map for ‘Brexit’
keywords: ['Treaty of Lisbon (2007)', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Britain voted in June to leave the European Union, but the process did not begin until the government invoked a previously unused treaty provision.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain voted in June to leave the European Union. But the process truly began on March 29, when the government invoked a treaty provision — Article 50 — that set out the basics of a withdrawal.

headline: About Time
abstract: Test your knowledge of the science and philosophy of time.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of the science and philosophy of time.

headline: What ‘Locker-Room Talk’ Sounds Like in the Philippines
abstract: It’s a country where men use misogyny to destroy their enemies — and get away with it.
lead_paragraph: Machismo isn’t quite what it used to be. Backlash and hashtags now hold politicians accountable for their so-called locker-room talk in much of the world. Yet the Philippines remains a glaring example of how men use language and law to try to emasculate opponents and maintain power.

headline: Lead Plaintiff in N.F.L. Concussion Settlement Had Advanced C.T.E.
abstract: Researchers at the Boston University C.T.E. Center said Kevin Turner, who died in March, had the fourth and highest stage of the degenerative brain disease.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The former running back Kevin Turner, one of the lead plaintiffs in the landmark N.F.L. settlement over concussions and brain trauma, had the most advanced form of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, the degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head hits, researchers said Thursday.

headline: Google Rebuts Antitrust Claims in Europe
abstract: The search giant faces three cases accusing it of hampering consumer choice and crippling competitors, all of which it denies.
lead_paragraph: To many Europeans, Google represents Silicon Valley’s perceived stranglehold on the digital world. But on Thursday, the American search giant tried to portray itself as a stalwart of online competition as it responded to European antitrust charges that it had restricted consumers’ choices and hamstrung its competitors.

headline: Mark Leckey Captures the Exuberance of Pre-‘Brexit’ Britain
abstract: A leader of Britain’s art revival mines the intoxicating atmosphere before ‘Brexit’ unmoored the art world in this show at MoMA PS1.
lead_paragraph: No one Pauline Kael knew voted for Richard M. Nixon, and no one I know voted for “Brexit.” I lived in London for a little over three years, and that catastrophic British referendum of June 23, and the political meltdown, legal uncertainty and racist violence it has unleashed, have obliterated a place I thought I knew, and left the British art world unmoored.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte Plays U.S. and China Off Each Other, in Echo of Cold War
abstract: The Philippine president’s strategy of balancing between the powers by threatening to change loyalties was used successfully by leaders throughout the era.
lead_paragraph: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines traveled to Beijing recently, promising to announce his country’s “separation” from the United States and alarming the White House and his own defense secretary.

headline: For Beyoncé, an Unexpected Performance in an Unexpected Look

lead_paragraph: Beyoncé, an artist known for dominating R&B and pop charts, performed at the Country Music Awards in Nashville on Wednesday, causing a few of the genre’s fans to scratch their heads and all of her fans to go into the usual paroxysms of delight.

headline: More Than 200 Migrants Drown Off Libya Trying to Reach Europe
abstract: The Mediterranean crossing has been increasingly deadly this year, even as fewer asylum seekers try to make it to Europe.
lead_paragraph: More people are dying while attempting to cross the Mediterranean from Libya to Europe: at least 239 drowned in two separate shipwrecks, the United Nations reported on Thursday.

headline: Growing Up Gay to a Glam Rock Soundtrack
abstract: Freddie Mercury, David Bowie and Alice Cooper send signals to a semi-closeted gay teen in the ’70s.
lead_paragraph: In early 1976, I saw Freddie Mercury stage one of the greatest charades in rock history. He was appearing with his band Queen at the Beacon Theater at a pivotal time, just three months after the release of “Bohemian Rhapsody” but a season before the song entranced the pop mainstream.

headline: Donald Trump’s Income Isn’t Always What He Says It Is, Records Suggest
abstract: Records of Mr. Trump’s tax appeals and other documents indicate that actual income from some of his businesses may be nowhere near what he has reported on financial disclosures.
lead_paragraph: On the financial disclosure forms that Donald J. Trump has pointed to as proof of his tremendous success, no venture looks more gold-plated than his golf resort in Doral, Fla., where he reported revenues of $50 million in 2014. That figure accounted for the biggest share of what he described as his income for the year.

headline: Cubs Players React to Win
abstract: The Chicago Cubs ended a 108-year drought on Thursday when they won the World Series. The Cubs topped the Cleveland Indians, 8-7.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Cubs ended a 108-year drought on Thursday when they won the World Series. The Cubs topped the Cleveland Indians, 8-7.

headline: Ebola Evolved Into Deadlier Enemy During the African Epidemic
abstract: A mutated version of the virus was more effective at entering human cells, scientists report. The finding may help explain the vast scope of the last outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The Ebola epidemic that tore through West Africa in 2014 claimed 11,310 lives, far more than any previous outbreak. A combination of factors contributed to its savagery, among them a mobile population, crumbling public health systems, official neglect and hazardous burial practices.

headline: The Best New Movies on Hulu
abstract: Every month, Hulu adds a new batch of movies to its library. Some of those movies are bad. Some are good. Here is a list of the good.
