headline: Elite Runners Ryan and Sara Hall Add Parenting to Their Workouts
keywords: ['New York City Marathon', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: The couple adopted four sisters from Ethiopia last fall. Then Ryan retired.
lead_paragraph: When the elite distance runners Sara and Ryan Hall adopted four sisters from Ethiopia in October 2015, it was the start of a year of seismic changes for them.

headline: Lindsey Adelman on Sharing a Visual Language With Her Husband
abstract: Considering glass sea creature pieces that her then-boyfriend made in 1994, the cult lighting designer offers a glimpse into her world — and marriage.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the writer and author of “Worn Stories,” Emily Spivack, interviews creative types about their most prized possessions.

headline: Make Siri Hear You on a Mac Mini
abstract: Not every Mac model comes with a microphone, but you can still command Apple’s virtual assistant with an external accessory.
lead_paragraph: Q. MacBooks and iMacs have built-in microphones, but how do you use Siri on a Mac Mini?

headline: In Russia, a Western Taste for High-End Auto Sales
abstract: Overall vehicle sales are down, but affluent Russians spur a demand for more expensive cars and Western-style dealerships.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — The automotive history of the former Soviet Bloc resonates with cars like the funky Lada, the futuristic Tatra, the clunky but lovable Trabant and the luxurious Volga. Then there was the tanklike Zil — always in black — that shuttled Nikita S. Khrushchev and Alexei N. Kosygin through Red Square.

headline: The History of Southern Africa, by Train
abstract: It’s the best way to make sense of the continent’s epic scope, wild splendor and bloody colonial history.
lead_paragraph: JUST A FEW HOURS INTO our train ride, we know the passengers in the cabins on either side of ours: On one side are two young Canadians on a monthslong, round-the-world backpacking trip. On the other are four middle-aged women on a trading expedition from their towns in Zambia to Dar es Salaam, where they’ll buy supplies for their shops, including clothes and spare parts for cars. They’re not waiting to get to Dar to get started: At every whistle-stop town along the way, vendors try to sell things through the window — often produce at prices far below those in the Tanzanian metropolis. So the women are stocking up on items they can sell for a profit when we arrive in a day or two: tomatoes, oranges, passion fruit, boiled peanuts and, just this morning, roasted caterpillars.

headline: Parks and Jubilations
abstract: The top galas of the past week were hosted by Fashion Group International, the Central Park Conservancy, Performa and Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The top galas of the past week were hosted by Fashion Group International, the Central Park Conservancy, Performa and Lincoln Center.

headline: Whose Life Should Your Car Save?
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Research']
abstract: It can be programmed to minimize risks to passengers — or to pedestrians.
lead_paragraph: The widespread use of self-driving cars promises to bring substantial benefits to transportation efficiency, public safety and personal well-being. Car manufacturers are working to overcome the remaining technical challenges that stand in the way of this future. Our research, however, shows that there is also an important ethical dilemma that must be solved before people will be comfortable trusting their lives to these cars.

headline: The New York Times Best Illustrated Children’s Books of 2016
abstract: Here are the winners of the New York Times Best Illustrated Children’s Books Awards for 2016.
lead_paragraph: Every year since 1952, the Book Review has convened an independent panel of judges to select the New York Times Best Illustrated Children’s Books. Judged purely on artistic merit, it’s the only annual award of its kind.

headline: Parks and Jubilations
abstract: The top galas of the past week were hosted by Fashion Group International, the Central Park Conservancy, Performa and Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The Fashion Group International held its annual Night of Stars gala on Oct. 27 at Cipriani Wall Street, where luminaries like Tommy and Dee Hilfiger were honored. The Central Park Conservancy autumn gala took place Oct. 27 under a clear tent at the park’s Naumburg Bandshell. Performa hosted its fall gala on Tuesday at the Altman Building and honored the curator, art critic and poet Okwui Enwezor. And Lincoln Center honored Laurie M. Tisch at its fall gala on Tuesday at the Jazz at Lincoln Center Frederick P. Rose Hall.

headline: Rodrigo Duterte’s Pledge to Stop Cursing Lands in the Gutter
abstract: The president of the Philippines, known for his salty language, broke his “promise to God” to stop swearing.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines vowed last week to stop cursing, at God’s direct request, few people in the deeply Catholic country questioned his faith or the logistics of the apparently divine intervention.

headline: A Souvenir for Anthony Rizzo, a Gift for All Cubs Everywhere
abstract: The final out found first baseman Rizzo’s glove, and he would not let the ball go. “It happened. It happened,” he said. “We’re the champs.”
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Anthony Rizzo was 3 years old when his father, John, first knew he might be a baseball player.

headline: Donations to Religious Institutions Fall as Values Change
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Philanthropy', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Methodist Church']
abstract: Fewer people identify with a religious group, and others may withhold donations over ideological differences.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that many people gave to their particular house of worship to get a prominent pew or extra blessings. Or because their grandparents and parents had always attended that church or synagogue or mosque.

headline: If I Were President . . . of My Club, My Class, My College, My Country
abstract: We asked students what they would do if they were in charge, what their concerns and hopes for the future would be.
lead_paragraph: We asked students what they would do if they were in charge, what their concerns and hopes for the future would be. Empathy and forgiveness — a plea for more — and climate change were recurring themes, as well as issues political and personal. Here are condensed selections. Add your own ideas in the comments section at the bottom of this page (student submissions will be highlighted). Photos and drawings that interpret the question can be submitted via email, to edlife@nytimes.com.

headline: Daily Report: A New Helper in the Virtual Assistant Race
abstract: Google will introduce Home, its rival to Amazon’s Alexa, at the end of this week.
lead_paragraph: Gadget geeks will get their chance to size up a new toy at the end of this week when Google brings out Home, its voice-activated smart speaker powered by a virtual assistant.

headline: Killing of Saudi Student Shakes Wisconsin College Town
abstract: The police in Menomonie, Wis., have no motive in the death of Hussain Saeed Alnahdi, 24, but a $20,000 reward has been announced.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a week, the police in Menomonie, Wis., have been at a loss to identify a suspect or a motive in the fatal beating of a Saudi Arabian college student outside a pizza restaurant. Now, the city is trying to change that by raising money for a reward. The tally so far? $20,000.

headline: Art Museums Are Looking for That Next Big Gift
abstract: Museums are honing their strategies as a new generation of art collectors succeed the deep-pocketed, like bankers, hedge fund managers and high-tech moguls.
lead_paragraph: Public museums, too tight on money these days to compete for major artworks in the marketplace, long for the collector’s gift of world-class art that can broaden their offerings and attract new audiences.

headline: Violet’s Bake Shoppe
abstract: The golden banh mi ratio lives at this storefront in Forest Hills, Queens.
lead_paragraph: The golden banh mi ratio lives at this storefront in Forest Hills, Queens.

headline: For Banh Mi, Violet’s Bake Shoppe Has the Math Down
abstract: Sandwich ingredients are in ideal proportions at this Chinese-Vietnamese place in Forest Hills, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Some argue that banh mi, the Vietnamese sandwich, lives and dies by its bread, a cloud in crisp armor, preferably made with a pinch of rice flour for extra spring and crackle.

headline: Cubs, Nerds and ‘True Baseball’
abstract: Critics look down on data-driven teams like the Cubs and Indians. They shouldn’t.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a question about last night’s exhilarating, stomach-churning, 10-inning seventh game of the World Series between the Cubs and Indians: Was it “true baseball”?

headline: It Was 74-17 at Halftime. Then the Score Got Out of Hand.
abstract: Maryland, the No. 6 women’s basketball team in the country, won its preseason game against Bluefield State, 146-17.
lead_paragraph: If you gambled on women’s college basketball on Wednesday night, and you had Bluefield State plus 128, you lost.

headline: The Philharmonic to Stream Young People’s Concerts
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Youth', 'Music', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The orchestra is putting videos, educational materials and games online for free streaming in a “Young People’s Concerts Play!” initiative.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Philharmonic televised its Young People’s Concerts from 1958 through 1972, it introduced new generations to classical music. Now the orchestra is updating the program: It said Thursday that it was putting videos of Young People’s Concerts, and additional educational materials and interactive games, online for schools and families to stream for free.

headline: A Joyful World Series for a Weary Country
abstract: Game seven was a reminder that a hard fight needn’t be an ugly one.
lead_paragraph: It was 10 innings that to both sides felt like 10 months or 10 generations, this midnight final contest between benighted Midwestern teams, each so deserving and so long denied.

headline: A Shortage of Oncologists
abstract: Cancer occurrences are on track to outpace oncology services, hurting patients and doctors alike.
lead_paragraph: In the crucible of cancer treatment, the bonding of patients with physicians often makes the unendurable endurable. The difficulty of finding and then keeping the right oncologist can therefore be fraught. Yet this problem, not uncommon today, is on track to grow worse.

headline: A Healthy Dressing Recipe From L.A.’s Newest Feel-Good Cafe
abstract: Honey Hi combines the best of all the health food trends that have become synonymous with West Coast wellness.
lead_paragraph: Dietary dogma is so strong in Los Angeles that even Dodgers Stadium offers vegan and gluten-free options for fervent-but-sensitive gamegoers. And down the road at Honey Hi in Echo Park, Eastsiders are catching a new wave of nutrition. It’s not strictly vegetarian, vegan, paleo, raw, plant-based, ayurvedic or superfoodist. The restaurant’s guiding principle is what they call a radical inclusivity. But according to its co-owner Kacie Carter, a chef and nutritionist, Honey Hi isn’t a movement, it’s simply “a little cafe with delicious food that makes you feel good.”

headline: On the Trail: Wednesday November 2
abstract: Donald Trump held rallies in Florida and Hillary Clinton held a rally in Arizona, visited Las Vegas and made a surprise stop in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump held rallies in Florida and Hillary Clinton held a rally in Arizona, visited Las Vegas and made a surprise stop in Florida.

headline: Your Questions About the U.S. Election, Answered
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'News and News Media']
abstract: We invited readers to tell us what they want to know about the presidential campaign. Here are some responses ahead of the election.
lead_paragraph: Declan Walsh, who has been reporting on the U.S. presidential campaign as a foreign correspondent, is answering questions from readers as the election nears. Below, he responds to  readers interested in the tenor of the campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump; the practice of voters who split their ballot; and what states will ultimately decide the election.

headline: What Lady Gaga’s ‘Bad Romance’ and Other Earworm Songs Have in Common
abstract: In the largest ever study of songs that play on repeat in your head, researchers found earworms had unusual intervals along with fast melodies.
lead_paragraph: You should stop reading this now. No really, just don’t. You’re still reading. O.K., you asked for it:

headline: 10 Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Halloween may be over, but the world still feels very dark. This week, our critics and editors at the Book Review recommend 10 grim books for grim times.

headline: Why Washington Needs Wall Street
abstract: Many government jobs could be filled by someone with a Wall Street background to the benefit of the American people.
lead_paragraph: The latest round of drumbeating has begun to prevent anyone with a Wall Street background from filling the top economic positions in the next administration. Not only is that not right, it hurts the American people by preventing those who have the best understanding of how financial markets work from taking a much-needed role in policing and fixing them. It is a form of discrimination. The time has come for it to stop.

headline: A Photographer’s Homage to an Architect’s Modernist City
abstract: Martien Mulder’s “The City Beautiful” is an exploration of the quiet weight of the relationship between light and space in Le Corbusier-designed Chandigarh, India.
lead_paragraph: Martien Mulder’s “The City Beautiful” is an exploration of the quiet weight of the relationship between light and space in Le Corbusier-designed Chandigarh, India.

headline: Russian Sports Agent and U.S. Marathon Officials Under Federal Investigation
abstract: Authorities are looking into whether Andrey Baranov conspired with American marathon organizers to allow athletes using banned substances to compete in their events.
lead_paragraph: The Russian sports doping scandal has led United States law enforcement officials to an unlikely spot: Manhattan’s Upper West Side.

headline: 19 Countries, 43 States, 327 Cities: Mapping The Times’s Election Coverage
abstract: New York Times political reporters filed some 2.98 million words during the 2016 election. We tracked their stops.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times.

headline: Credit Suisse’s Cost-Cutting Is Hindered by Rising Risks
abstract: Profitability is under pressure in Credit Suisse’s wealth management and trading businesses.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Credit Suisse, Tidjane Thiam, recently described Europe’s banks as “uninvestable.” His bank’s third-quarter results make Credit Suisse look just as bad.

headline: Rebuilding After Hurricane Sandy
abstract: A community group says failure to rebuild homes in communities like the Rockaways and Coney Island will further destabilize low-income families.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Really Happened to Raoul Wallenberg?
abstract: The International Raoul Wallenberg Foundation writes that the details “are likely buried in the K.G.B. archives.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Donald Trump’s Tax Maneuvers
abstract: Trump’s tax avoidance may not have been illegal, “but it was sleazy, and unbefitting of someone aspiring to the highest office in the land,” a reader says.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Melania Trump, Solo in Pennsylvania, Tries to Smooth Husband’s Rough Edges
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: The appearance came as Donald J. Trump’s campaign tries to sway undecided voters and women who have been wary of the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: BERWYN, Pa. — Melania Trump made a rare appearance on the campaign trail in the battleground state of Pennsylvania on Thursday, seeking to soften her husband’s coarse image by proclaiming to voters that Donald J. Trump respects all Americans and promising that as president he would promote values of compassion and charity across the country.

headline: From Sliced Bread to Gas Prices, Obama Takes Stump Speech Off Script
abstract: With every rally, President Obama has been adding another aside to a stump speech touting his record, condemning Donald J. Trump and praising Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — President Obama is savoring what is likely to be the last intensive political campaign of his life, and his speeches have been running so long that 30 minutes were tacked onto his official schedule Thursday to compensate.

headline: Iraqis Fear ‘Bloodshed Will Continue’ After Mosul if Sectarian Tensions Aren’t Addressed
abstract: Analysts warn that even a complete military victory over the Islamic State in Mosul will not change the reality that there is still no political agreement in place.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — As Iraq comes closer to ejecting the Islamic State from its last major stronghold in the country, the question is no longer whether it can succeed.

headline: The ’90s Designer Making a Big Comeback — All Over the Runways
abstract: Jean Colonna — who launched his business in 1987 — is a spiritual ancestor of some of the most exciting designers currently working.
lead_paragraph: Even during his heyday of the early- to mid-’90s, the French designer Jean Colonna was an insider name — but today, his style is all over the runways. In 1993, The Times dubbed him “the popularist of Drugstore Cowboy dressing”: a pithy acknowledgment of his aesthetic, which relied heavily on synthetic fabrics, especially pleather, machine-made lace and machine-sewn sequins, animal prints and brash color combinations of black with violet, hot pink or lipstick red. It looked trashy — it did then, and it does now.

headline: When It Comes to Success, Age Really Is Just a Number
keywords: ['Age, Chronological', 'Science and Technology', 'Careers and Professions', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research', 'Productivity', 'Classical Music', 'Physics', 'Chemistry', 'Records and Achievements']
abstract: A new study points to a combination of personality, persistence and luck as leading to success, and scientists say that those same forces are at play at all levels of a discipline.
lead_paragraph: The question hangs over the career of every ambitious soul: Is there still time to make a mark?

headline: Veterans and the Candidates
abstract: Trump “has used veterans as political props,” an Army vet writes, while Clinton “has put veterans at the center of her public service.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Egypt Floats Currency, Appeasing I.M.F. at Risk of Enraging Poor
keywords: ['Currency', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The move, which effectively devalues the Egyptian pound, is part of an effort to secure a desperately needed rescue loan from the International Monetary Fund.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s central bank on Thursday said it would soon allow the country’s currency to trade freely, part of a broader effort to save a free-falling economy and combat an increasingly prevalent black market for American dollars.

headline: Saying No to Breast Reconstruction
keywords: ['Breast Cancer', 'Plastic Surgery', 'Mastectomy', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Readers weigh the value of the procedure and the role of choice.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: America's Test Kitchen Lawsuit
abstract: Read the complaint filed in Suffolk County Superior Court in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: Read the complaint filed in Suffolk County Superior Court in Massachusetts.

headline: Food Fight Heats Up as America’s Test Kitchen Sues a Founder
abstract: A lawsuit accuses Christopher Kimball and others of theft in creating a new cooking empire, Christopher Kimball’s Milk Street.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Kimball was dressed in a Victorian costume and heading out the door to trick-or-treat with young relatives Monday evening when he got word that one of the food media’s messiest divorces was about to get a lot messier.

headline: Kid-Wrangling 101
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Their videos poured in. Except for when they didn’t.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Andy Newman, a metro reporter, shares what’s involved in helping a group of middle-school-age city kids produce the stories of their lives.

headline: My First Film Fest: A Mix of Dark Themes and Sunny Attitude
abstract: This new festival, the first for children from the Film Society of Lincoln Center, offers a mix of contemporary works and classics, with movies for teenagers, too.
lead_paragraph: You wouldn’t expect someone who had just created a movie festival for children — especially one that began on Thursday with a sneak preview of DreamWorks Animation’s cheerful-looking “Trolls” — to heave a sigh and exclaim, “Oh, my God, so many dark films!” Yet that was how Florence Almozini, associate director of programming for the Film Society of Lincoln Center, recently characterized her latest venture.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Killing of Brooklyn Pizzeria Owner
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Restaurants', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: The suspect, captured on surveillance video, will be charged with murder in the shooting of Louis Barbati, an owner of the well-known L&B Spumoni Gardens restaurant.
lead_paragraph: In the days after the killing of an owner of a well-known Brooklyn pizzeria, speculation grew: Could it have been the settling of a score, perhaps related to a long-simmering feud over a tomato sauce recipe?

headline: Review: Fold. Spindle. Mutate. Oh, It’s Gibney Dance.
abstract: The choreographer Gina Gibney work since 2013, “Folding In,” is being performed by her company and ends with five dancers curled up on the floor.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes, Gina Gibney is a force in the New York dance world, presiding over two dance centers along lower Broadway. She’s long been a choreographer, too, and this year she celebrates the 25th anniversary of Gibney Dance. With that comes “Folding In,” her first work since 2013.

headline: Mosul, ‘Brexit,’ Donald Trump: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Diary of a New York City Marathon, Now With a Finishing Kick
abstract: A 2012 examination of the route, published in one-mile increments, was truncated by Hurricane Sandy. The writer returns, four years later, for the final two miles (and 385 yards).
lead_paragraph: In 2012, I set out to examine the atmosphere, history and landmarks along the New York City Marathon route, one mile per day, in the 26 days leading up to the race.

headline: Iggy Pop’s Life Drawing Class
abstract: The artist Jeremy Deller organized a live drawing class in which students from art schools around the city drew the music icon.
lead_paragraph: The artist Jeremy Deller organized a live drawing class in which students from art schools around the city drew the music icon.

headline: Iggy Pop: Musician, Icon — and Now, Live Nude Model
abstract: In February, the rocker posed nude for a group of students from New York art schools. This week, their portraits open in a show at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: Ever since James Newell Osterberg Jr. emerged from a Detroit trailer park and reinvented himself as the snarling, bleached-blond, Dionysian rock god Iggy Pop, he has been one of the most iconic figures in music. With his sinewy frame and defiant stare, Iggy’s image has been immortalized by the likes of photographer Mick Rock (on the cover of his band The Stooges’ third album, “Raw Power”) as well as the artists Peter Hujar and Gerard Malanga. “I knew him from the imagery before the music, actually,” recalls the Turner Prize-winning British artist Jeremy Deller. “Even in photos you can tell he has a presence and is clearly quite a character.” For Deller, it was Iggy’s baring of his torso and soul onstage that struck him: “He’s not stopped performing,” Deller says. “From the age of 20 to 69, it’s been a continuous piece of performance art and documentation of his body. It’s interesting to me for a man to parade his body so much, and parade it as it changes.”

headline: The Voter Fraud Lie We Can’t Shake
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Discrimination', 'Racial Profiling', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Cheating at the polls basically doesn’t happen. But that hasn’t stopped generations of Americans from using it to keep minorities from voting.
lead_paragraph: Early voting is underway, and according to Donald J. Trump, so is voter fraud. Almost daily, he proclaims that “large-scale voter fraud” is happening and that the election is “rigged.” Politicians across the spectrum have criticized this nonsense as divorced from reality, deleterious to our democracy and unprecedented in our elections.

headline: Connections to a Cause: The Millennial Way of Charity
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Millennial Generation', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: A generation shaped by transparency, digital storytelling and social media redefines philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was an otherwise routine bus ride through the Costa Rican countryside several years ago that changed the way Chase Adam thought about what makes people give.

headline: ‘Luke Cage’ Made Him a Fashion Hero
abstract: Mike Colter describes how the character he plays has changed his wardrobe.
lead_paragraph: Mike Colter plays the coolest superhero going these days, on the binge-worthy Netflix show “Luke Cage.” Mr. Colter, who grew up in St. Matthews, S.C., let us in on his favorite clothing, explained how his role as a Marvel character has changed his wardrobe, and revealed why he prefers boots with zippers.

headline: In a Bar in Chicago, the Real M.V.P.s of the Series Got It Done
abstract: The bartender’s lucky walnut may not show up in the box score, but. ...
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Fifth inning, Game 7 of the World Series, and the Chicago Cubs were comfortably ahead by four runs. What more auspicious moment could there be for an out-of-town visitor to sneak into a friendly bar full of happy fans who were watching their team coast to victory?

headline: The Virtual Splendor of Paris’s Glass House
abstract: Known largely for a forward-looking house he designed in Paris, Chareau gets his due in an illuminating show at the Jewish Museum that features his interiors, furniture and art collection.
lead_paragraph: Discovering the existence of the Maison de Verre in Paris can be a major aesthetic epiphany. When you see a photograph of this translucent structure in glass, steel and expanses of glass brick — completed in 1932 — the impression is of startling modernity, something very much of its time yet strikingly ahead of it, too, like Picasso’s “Les Demoiselles d’Avignon” or Duchamp’s “The Large Glass.”

headline: Going Head to Head With Pierre Chareau
abstract: Four virtual reality environments at the Jewish Museum delve into every nook and cranny of the designer’s creations, with Gallic touches.
lead_paragraph: The spare simplicity of the introductory galleries of the Jewish Museum’s new exhibition on the interior designer Pierre Chareau — even the inventive moving silhouettes on scrims there — do not prepare you for the fully immersive virtual reality experiences in the show’s second-to-last gallery.

headline: Green-Wood Cemetery, Where Presidential Aspirants Enjoy an Afterlife
keywords: ['Presidential Elections (US)', 'Tombs and Tombstones', 'Cemeteries', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Walking']
abstract: Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn will pay tribute to those who tried but failed to make it to the White House with a tour of graves of also-rans.
lead_paragraph: LET us now consider a particular presidential candidate who made a fortune in business and real estate, who reveled in being famous, who had never held elective office before and who urged his supporters to cancel their subscriptions to a newspaper that had called him an idiot.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on James Comey, the post-election prognosis, and other news. Susan Lehman is host.
lead_paragraph: Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on James Comey, the post-election prognosis, and other news. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: Unlocking the Secrets of Boxwood Miniatures
abstract: An exhibition of centuries-old beads, spheres and pendants, with elaborately carved tableaus, will travel from Toronto to New York to Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: Dutch woodcarvers once sculpted slivers of boxwood into biblical scenes smaller than walnut shells, and for a few decades in the 1400s and 1500s, elite clients, including Henry VIII, vied to own the miniature works. Yet no one seems to have recorded much about the sculptors’ techniques or even their names. In notes from the 1630s about an antique boxwood sphere with portraits of martyred saints, a Dutch art collector lamented, “It is regrettable that the maker of this ingenious piece has not made himself known with any sign.”

headline: Echoes of an Exposition, and an Assassination
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A tour finds traces in Buffalo of the Pan-American Exposition of 1901, featuring dazzling technology, cultural exploitation and the death of President McKinley.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — THE Pan-American Exposition of 1901 was meant to celebrate America’s ingenuity and dominance over the Western Hemisphere — you know, when America was “great again.” Eight million people paid about 50 cents each to see buildings edged in light bulbs, sprawled across 350 acres at the suburban northern edge of this city. They also flocked to the nearby Niagara Falls to watch daredevils try to survive the rapids.

headline: Review: In ‘Trash Fire,’ a Familiar Formula Fails
abstract: Adrian Grenier stars in this black comedy from Richard Bates Jr.
lead_paragraph: “For as long as I can remember, I’ve been waiting for my parents to die, so I could commit suicide without feeling an overwhelming sense of guilt.” With this opening line, “Trash Fire” lets you know that its writer-director is committed to commanding your attention. And also that he has seen, and admires, “Goodfellas,” which begins with a similar phrase.

headline: Review: Dance Arrives From India. If Only It Could Stay Longer.
abstract: Two troupes, Nrityagram and Kerala Kalamandalam Kathakali, appeared in New York as part of the White Light Festival’s “Sounds of India” series.
lead_paragraph: “You’ve been there?” friends said in envy after Wednesday’s Nrityagram Dance Ensemble performance in the Gerald W. Lynch Theater. Yes, I’ve seen Nrityagram in India, at its home village near Bangalore and in Chennai — and yet the New York audience is in no way shortchanged. These are among the world’s greatest dancers; on Wednesday they gave as complete and fulfilling a vision of their art as any I have seen anywhere.

headline: Megyn Kelly: By the Book
abstract: The Fox News anchor and author of “Settle for More” says “Bridget Jones’s Diary” reads “like my own journals from pretty much every phase of my life and made me laugh so hard I cried.”
lead_paragraph: The Fox News anchor and author of “Settle for More” says “Bridget Jones’s Diary” reads “like my own journals from pretty much every phase of my life and made me laugh so hard I cried.”

headline: Review: ‘The Pickle Recipe’ Is a Sweet and Sour Caper
abstract: In this comedy, a grandson in need of money plots with an uncle to steal the recipe for his grandmother’s famous pickles.
lead_paragraph: The pickles in “The Pickle Recipe” apparently have quite a kick. The movie, though, is pretty flavorless.

headline: Former Napa Valley Winemaker Arrested in Fraud Scheme
abstract: A grand jury charged Jeffry James Hill with stealing grapes and deceiving customers about the source and type of grapes in the wines he sold.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Federal prosecutors have brought eight fraud charges against Jeffry James Hill, a former Napa Valley winemaker and vineyard manager who was accused of stealing grapes and deceiving customers about the source and type of grapes in the wines he sold.

headline: Young Adolescents as Likely to Die From Suicide as From Traffic Accidents
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Women and Girls', 'Social Media', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: There are concerns that the pervasiveness and pressures of social media are contributing factors to a rising suicide rate for children ages 10 to 14.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is now just as likely for middle school students to die from suicide as from traffic accidents.

headline: There Are No Wrong Thanksgiving Wines
abstract: For the holiday, selecting the wines is the easiest task of all. All bottles are good, though some are better.
lead_paragraph: No sooner did last Thanksgiving end than here we are again, deciding what to serve, how to cook it and what to drink. It worked out pretty well in 2015, didn’t it?

headline: The New York Times to Offer Open Access on Web and Apps for the Election
abstract: The New York Times is inviting readers to take advantage of its reporting, analysis and commentary from the lead-up through the aftermath of the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times is inviting readers to take advantage of its reporting, analysis and commentary from the lead-up through the aftermath of the 2016 election. Readers will have unlimited access to NYTimes.com for 72 hours from 12:01 a.m. ET on Monday, November 7 until 11:59 p.m. ET on Wednesday, November 9.

headline: Delivering Fresh Attention to Josef Albers
abstract: Works created by this German-born artist, who died 40 years ago, have acquired a new energy in the art world.
lead_paragraph: Last year, abstracts by the German-born artist Josef Albers were selling for $150,000 to $250,000 at auction: not bad for a guy who died 40 years ago.

headline: 5 Twombly Sculptures to Join His Paintings at Philadelphia Museum
abstract: The bronze sculptures, which he considered to be related to his “Iliam” paintings already at the museum, are gifts of the Cy Twombly Foundation.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Museum of Art is one of the nation’s pre-eminent destinations for the work of Cy Twombly, who died in 2011 and whose monumental Homeric painting cycle “Fifty Days at Iliam” has been on permanent display there since 1989. Now, a group of five important bronze sculptures by Twombly, which he considered to be related to the paintings, will enter the museum’s collection, gifts of the Cy Twombly Foundation.

headline: Rococo Bad Boy Rebels in ‘Fragonard: Drawing Triumphant’
abstract: The 18th-century artist’s rebellion occurred largely on paper, in strokes of red and splashes of brown that went counter to his training.
lead_paragraph: Among the 18th century’s lesser-known declarations of independence was that of Jean-Honoré Fragonard, the Rococo artist who was a rising star of the French Academy system when he decided, rather abruptly, that he’d had enough of it. As we see in “Fragonard: Drawing Triumphant — Works From New York Collections” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, this rebellion took place largely on paper, in sprightly strokes of red chalk and splashes of brown wash that were, in form and spirit, the opposite of the history paintings he had been trained to produce.

headline: The Paris Agreement on Climate Change Is Official. Now What?
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: Top energy policy makers and corporate leaders say it will be challenging to meet even the deal’s modest goals to reduce emissions and greenhouse gases.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the landmark Paris Agreement to address climate change officially goes into effect on Friday, the Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe will be floodlit green to celebrate the occasion. Now comes the hard work: figuring out the details.

headline: Review: ‘The Prison in Twelve Landscapes’ Reveals the Invisible Tentacles of Mass Incarceration
abstract: An unexpectedly moving look at the elements of the confinement industry that hide in plain sight.
lead_paragraph: In “The Prison in Twelve Landscapes,” a meditation on mass incarceration in the United States, the Canadian filmmaker Brett Story arranges a series of oblique, geographical vignettes into an unsettling mural of systemic damage.

headline: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 9
abstract: Look for a productive game from Cowboys quarterback Dak Prescott against the Raiders and roll the dice with the 49ers’ Colin Kaepernick against the Saints.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: New York Area Has the Nation’s 3 Worst Airports, Study Says
abstract: A travel website’s examination of timeliness, accessibility and amenities at the United States’ 30 busiest airports found fault with La Guardia, J.F.K. and Newark.
lead_paragraph: Those who fly to or from New York are fully accustomed to long security lines, labyrinthine paths to the terminal, flight delays, cancellations and other unpleasant happenings, not to mention the arduous or expensive journey to the airport itself.

headline: Review: In ‘Rainbow Time,’ Big Brother’s Watching (and Lusting)
abstract: Linas Phillips’s film revolves around a developmentally disabled 40-year-old virgin — a bully who uses his condition to guilt others into excusing his bad behavior.
lead_paragraph: The engine of unpleasantness that drives “Rainbow Time” is a sex-crazed, 40-year-old virgin who answers to the nickname Shonzi (played by the writer and director, Linas Phillips). Denied sufficient oxygen at birth, Shonzi is developmentally delayed; he’s also a bully who’s not above using his mental status to guilt those around him into excusing his offensive behavior.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Ludlow 38, MINI/Goethe-Institut Curatorial Residencies 38 Ludlow Street, near Hester Street, Lower East Side Through Nov. 13

headline: Review: ‘My Dead Boyfriend’ Shares a Life, After the Fact
abstract: Heather Graham plays a woman in 1990s New York who begins to learn about her boyfriend only after he’s dead, in this film directed by Anthony Edwards.
lead_paragraph: “My Dead Boyfriend” desperately tries to look and sound like a quirky indie hit, but that’s not an achievable goal when you have an unlikable lead character indifferently rendered by a name star.

headline: Review: ‘We Are X’ Explores the Travails and Triumphs of a Rock Band
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'Music']
abstract: This documentary is about the Japanese group X Japan, which, like so many bands around the world, found fame, then fell apart. But this one rose again.
lead_paragraph: If “We Are X” proves anything, it’s that rock bands the world over can experience similar trials: acrimony and fatalities, but also, sometimes, glorious comebacks. This fascinating and assured documentary, directed by Stephen Kijak (“Stones in Exile”), tells the story of the group X Japan, a cultural institution in its native country, framed around the group’s 2014 reunion concert at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Review: It’s 1996, and Jack Reacher Is Playing Nice With Others
abstract: Lee Child shakes up his book series by taking his famously solitary character and turning him into a team player, in “Night School.”
lead_paragraph: “Night School” is the 21st book in Lee Child’s Jack Reacher series, but who’s counting? Most of us can merely marvel at the continuing allure of Reacher, think “you’ve come a long way, baby” and leave it at that.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: The Times Opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on James Comey, the postelection prognosis and other news. Susan Lehman is the host.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Nov. 3, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Doctor Strange,” “Hacksaw Ridge” and “Loving.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Doctor Strange,” “Hacksaw Ridge” and “Loving.”

headline: Review: Tending the Tempest Within in ‘Peter and the Farm’
abstract: Tony Stone’s documentary portrait of an irascible 68-year-old Vermont farmer has a cosmic dimension, evoking the natural world and the big questions of life.
lead_paragraph: The irascible 68-year-old Vermont farmer and focus of Tony Stone’s wondrous documentary portrait, “Peter and the Farm,” is a man who contains multitudes. With his snowy beard and imperious bearing, Peter Dunning, at his most eloquent, conveys the authority of a biblical prophet but without a religious platform. As he surveys the 187-acre farm he has tended for more than 35 years, he also suggests a latter-day Prospero ruefully aware that his powers are waning.

headline: ‘The Voter Suppression Trail’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Find out if your vote can survive the great, flawed adventure of American democracy.
lead_paragraph: Find out if your vote can survive the great, flawed adventure of American democracy.

headline: Lending a Hand (and Fingers, and Fingertips) to Myths
abstract: Akram Khan’s choreography informs “Chotto Desh,” in which an exchange between a man and a youth summons stories Mr. Khan heard from his grandparents.
lead_paragraph: The man in the photograph at right is angled slightly to one side, his arm curved and his fingers — held together, sharply separated from the thumb — pointing down into what appears to be an upside-down fish. Above him floats a bee, and a snake curls languorously over a branch, appearing to watch his activities with interest.

headline: Review: In ‘Loving,’ They Loved. A Segregated Virginia Did Not Love Them Back.
abstract: Jeff Nichols’s “Loving” is a fictionalization of the story of Mildred and Richard Loving, an interracial couple whose civil rights case went to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: There are few movies that speak to the American moment as movingly — and with as much idealism — as Jeff Nichols’s “Loving,” which revisits the era when blacks and whites were so profoundly segregated in this country that they couldn’t always wed. It’s a fictionalization of the story of Mildred and Richard Loving, a married couple who were arrested in 1958 because he was white, she was not, and they lived in Virginia, a state that banned interracial unions. Virginia passed its first anti-miscegenation law in 1691, partly to prevent what it called “spurious issue,” or what most people just call children.

headline: Cubs, Clinton, Mosul: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: The ‘Trolls’ Embark on a High-Haired Rescue Mission
abstract: This DreamWorks film, voiced by stars like Anna Kendrick and Justin Timberlake, follows the adventures of a colorful group and their nemesis.
lead_paragraph: Exuberant, busy and sometimes funny, DreamWorks Animation’s “Trolls” is determined to amuse. You remember Trolls — not the rude lurkers online writing nasty remarks, but those little toys with round tummies, beatific expressions and abundant hair shooting upward. Here they’re players in a fairy-tale Cold War parable.

headline: The Joys and Pains of Shared Birthdays
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Birthdays', 'Breastfeeding', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Friendship', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Also, the etiquette of breast-feeding, where’s that wedding invitation, and the private reference letter.
lead_paragraph: My friend and I have the same birthday, so I know he remembers when it is. In our 20s, we exchanged gifts. But as we aged, he stopped acknowledging my birthday (and is generally less likely to pick up the phone to keep in touch). This hurts my feelings. Still, he was incredibly supportive when my dad died last year. And if I ever have an important issue to talk through, he will spend as much time with me as I could possibly ask. So I’m conflicted. And our shared birthday is coming up. What would you do?

headline: Review: ‘Dog Eat Dog’ Is a Pulpy Tale With Nasty, Bumbling Crooks
abstract: Nicolas Cage, Willem Dafoe and Christopher Matthew Cook star in this crime movie about some bad guys with hate in their hearts.
lead_paragraph: Despite its slim running time — barely over an hour and a half — “Dog Eat Dog” somehow feels like six different movies. The first one, which depicts an especially appalling double murder through the speedy, sickly colorful perspective of an extended drug binge, is probably the least effective of the batch. But it lets you know that the filmmakers are not coming at you from a benevolent place, and that impression never lets up.

headline: A Blast from Campaigns Past ... A Grab Bag of Vintage Swag
abstract: The New-York Historical Society is exhibiting memorabilia from four presidential campaigns, including items that were watchable, wearable, drinkable and playable.
lead_paragraph: IN an age of social media, it is easy to forget about old-fashioned presidential campaign memorabilia: posters, fliers, advertisements. The New-York Historical Society has not forgotten. Its exhibition of memorabilia from four presidential campaigns includes items that were watchable, wearable, drinkable and playable.

headline: Review: ‘Ivory. A Crime Story,’ or the Plight of African Elephants
abstract: This documentary from Sergey Yastrzhembsky treats the unpleasant subject of the elephants and ivory smuggling with the harshness it deserves.
lead_paragraph: The animals seem more humane than people in “Ivory. A Crime Story.” This roughly constructed yet passionate documentary isn’t shy about showing the massacre of elephants or about calling out the groups implicit in the killings. That bluntness and courage usually overrides the uneven filmmaking.

headline: Review: ‘The Ivory Game’ Follows the Fight to Protect Elephants
abstract: This documentary, filmed in Africa and China, ruminates on the high stakes of poachers killing these animals for their tusks.
lead_paragraph: After learning that a beloved wild elephant has been slaughtered by poachers, Craig Millar, a conservationist, wonders aloud “how we got to this stage, as a human race, when we just lay waste to anything we value — anything we see just gets consumed.” Still, he vows to fight on. “I don’t know if it’s ever going to make a difference, and if we’re ever going to do enough, but we’ve got to try.”

headline: No Laptop, No Phone, No Desk: UBS Reinvents the Work Space
abstract: The bulk of UBS’s employees will no longer have a fixed desk at its new building in London as the Swiss bank embraces a more mobile work environment.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A desk is like a home away from home for many in the working world.

headline: Election Day 2016: Teaching Ideas for Before and After the Votes Are Tallied
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, Senate', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Here are some ideas for helping your students understand what to pay attention to now and on election night — and an invitation to share your own ideas.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Nov. 15.

headline: In Chicago, the Cubs’ Win Brings Baseball Unity, for Now
abstract: On the day after the Cubs won their first World Series title in 108 years in an epic, 10-inning game, loyalties were briefly scrambled in a two-team town.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Margaret Pinkston, a 69-year-old housekeeper who lives on the South Side, was waiting for a friend to bring over her breakfast tray at the Valois Cafeteria on Thursday morning when she leaned in conspiratorially. “I’m going to be honest,” she said, lowering her voice. “I don’t know one person who wasn’t rooting for the Cubs.”

headline: 1976 | ‘Metropolitan Diary’ Opens Its Pages
abstract: One of the most popular features among Times readers (if not necessarily among Times Metro editors) started 40 years ago this month.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 28 through Nov. 1 with 1,561 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,333 said they were registered to vote.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 28 through Nov. 1 with 1,561 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,333 said they were registered to vote.

headline: New York Times/CBS News Poll Finds Challenges for Next President
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump limp into Election Day locked in a tight race and saddled with voters’ unfavorable views of them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The poll finds deep challenges awaiting the next president after a bruising election.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump limp into Election Day locked in a tight race and saddled with voters’ unfavorable views of them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The poll finds deep challenges awaiting the next president after a bruising election.

headline: How States Moved Toward Stricter Voter ID Laws
abstract: Voters in seven states will be required to show photo identification at the polls this year.
lead_paragraph: Voters in seven states will be required to show photo identification at the polls this year.

headline: A Narrower Majority for Republicans Could Widen the House Divide
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Freedom Caucus members look to increase their clout as a check against a potential Clinton presidency, and possibly against their own party leadership.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The contest for control of the House of Representatives will probably yield an even more polarized chamber, leaving a smaller, more conservative Republican majority that may challenge the re-election of Paul D. Ryan as speaker and greet Hillary Clinton with a fresh round of investigations — whether she wins the White House or not.

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 4-10
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Retail Magic in the Meatpacking District
abstract: Jeffrey Kalinsky, the founder of the Jeffrey boutiques, says, “To me, it’s all about the art of the sell.”
lead_paragraph: If you find yourself walking the Belgian-block streets of the meatpacking district, you are likely to be near a clothing boutique. It wasn’t always that way. Jeffrey Kalinsky, the founder of the high-end chain Jeffrey, was something of a retail pioneer when he opened the second location of his namesake store in the neighborhood in 1999. “Everyone thought it was radical,” he said.

headline: News of Charges in Price-Fixing Inquiry Sends Pharmaceuticals Tumbling
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Investors worry new controls may be in the offing as a news report says the Justice Department may bring charges by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: The generic drug industry was jolted on Thursday as shares of many major companies tumbled after a news report said that a federal inquiry into drug price-fixing was wider than previously believed and could lead to charges by the end of the year.

headline: Guards Were ‘Negligent’ in Fatal Encounter With New York Inmate, Judge Rules
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A judge said Leonard Strickland was subjected to excessive force and faulty medical care at the Clinton Correctional Facility, but there was no evidence that a beating directly caused his death.
lead_paragraph: Officers at the Clinton Correctional Facility used excessive force when they dragged a handcuffed inmate face down through prison corridors and then, when he was near death, provided faulty medical care, a judge in a New York State Court of Claims has ruled.

headline: Beyoncé’s C.M.A. Awards Performance Becomes the Target of Backlash
abstract: Some country fans argued online that this singer was out of place at a country music show, but her supporters did not take kindly to that opinion.
lead_paragraph: On live television, Beyoncé’s improbable performance with the Dixie Chicks at the 50th annual Country Music Association Awards couldn’t have gone more smoothly. With a giant band and brass section, the pop star blew through an extra twangy version of “Daddy Lessons,” the southern-fried track from her latest album, “Lemonade,” even working in a section of the Dixie Chicks’ own “Long Time Gone” in the middle. The Nashville crowd was on its feet.

headline: E. Lee Hennessee, a Leading Woman in Hedge Funds, Dies at 64
abstract: Ms. Hennessee created one of the first indexes to track the hedge fund industry’s secretive transactions.
lead_paragraph: E. Lee Hennessee, a pioneering woman in the male-dominated hedge fund industry and the creator of one of the first indexes to track its secretive transactions, was found dead on Oct. 29 at her home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 64.

headline: Parliament’s Power Over Brexit

abstract: A court decision leads to uncertainty about Britain’s departure from the European Union, but it does add legal clarity to the nonbinding vote.
lead_paragraph: Someday the British  court ruling on Brexit may be studied as a milestone in parliamentary democracy. For now, though, it throws Britain’s fateful move to part ways with the European Union into considerable disarray.

abstract: Andres Fernandez was arrested Thursday in connection with the fatal shooting of Louis Barbati, an owner of a well-known Brooklyn pizzeria, on June 30.
lead_paragraph: Andres Fernandez was arrested Thursday in connection with the fatal shooting of Louis Barbati, an owner of a well-known Brooklyn pizzeria, on June 30.

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Mr. Scott was portrayed as an imperfect figure whose own behavior contributed to his shooting, which was recorded on video.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The judge faced the jury on Thursday morning and spoke solemnly about “what many have called the greatest justice system ever created.” Then the murder trial of a member of the most visible arm of the justice system — a police officer — began in earnest.

abstract: Some Senate Republicans say their refusal to consider President Obama’s nominee to replace Antonin Scalia would continue in a Clinton administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Jeff Flake was startled a few months ago when a constituent pressed him on whether he was willing to hold up any Supreme Court nominee chosen by Hillary Clinton if she was elected president.

headline: As Strollers Roll Through New York City Grit and Muck, an Industry Is Born
keywords: ['Baby Carriages, Strollers and Carriers', 'Cleaning Services', 'Small Business', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Businesses are vying for a slice of the stroller-cleaning market in New York, where the buggies, often doubling as grocery carts or portable playpens, can become particularly filthy.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing more emblematic of New York City baby life than the beat-up stroller. In this walking city, strollers become homes on wheels, where babies and toddlers log long hours eating, napping and playing.

headline: An Old Hand Once Again Tries His Luck at an Around-the-World Race
keywords: ['Sailboats and Sailing', 'Vendee Globe Challenge', 'Age, Chronological', 'Records and Achievements']
abstract: Rich Wilson, a 66-year-old from Marblehead, Mass., will compete in his second Vendée Globe, which begins Friday from the French port of Les Sables d’Olonne.
lead_paragraph: MARBLEHEAD, Mass. — When José Luis Ugarte, the oldest sailor to finish the Vendée Globe yacht race, finally arrived back on terra firma in 1993, he soberly pronounced the solo, round-the-world race “an inhuman event” that should be done no more than “once in a lifetime.”

headline: Miriam Weinstein, Mother and Backbone of Original Miramax, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Weinstein had no plans to stop contributing (advice or pastries), even after Miramax grew in fame and value.
lead_paragraph: Miriam Weinstein, the mother of the filmmakers Harvey and Bob Weinstein and an inspiration for the name of their first film company, Miramax, died on Wednesday at her home in Westport, Conn. She was 90.

lead_paragraph: Much is yet to be determined about the future of Fox News, especially with the contracts of the star anchors Megyn Kelly and Bill O’Reilly soon to run out.

headline: Wells Fargo Faces Scrutiny for Black Marks on Ex-Employee Files
abstract: Three senators asked for data on forms filed by the bank, which former employees say contained negative comments as retaliation against whistle-blowers.
lead_paragraph: Three senators fired at Wells Fargo’s new chief executive with fresh ammunition on Thursday: the hundreds of termination notices the bank filed with an industry overseer over the last five years as employees left the company in connection with its sales scandal.

headline: Kay Starr, Hillbilly Singer With Crossover Appeal, Dies at 94
abstract: Ms. Starr found fame in the big-band era, hit it big as a pop and country artist, and continued her career well into her later years.
lead_paragraph: Kay Starr, the self-described hillbilly singer who crisscrossed jazz, country, pop, blues and rock ’n’ roll in the 1950s with hits like “Wheel of Fortune” and “Rock and Roll Waltz,” died on Thursday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 94.

headline: Sorting Through the Clinton Email Case and What the F.B.I.’s Options Are
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: What do the Clinton Foundation and F.B.I. infighting have to do with the renewed investigation? Let’s work it all out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A week ago, the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, jolted the presidential race by sending a letter to Congress saying the bureau had discovered new emails that might be relevant to Hillary Clinton’s use of a private server. The disclosure set off widespread criticism of Mr. Comey and unleashed a hurricane of news about Mrs. Clinton’s family foundation, Russia and F.B.I. infighting. Let’s sort it all out.

headline: Time to Move the Standing Rock Pipeline
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Native Americans', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Water', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama sees a possible solution to a dispute over environmental dangers and over yet another insult to American Indian heritage.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has pointed a way out of a dangerous standoff over an oil pipeline being built in North Dakota. He told an interviewer on Tuesday that the Army Corps of Engineers was looking for a new pipeline route, presumably away from the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation, whose members and allies have been protesting the project for months, saying it threatens the tribe’s sacred lands and water supply.

abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: At Trader Joe’s, Good Cheer May Hide Complaints
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Organized Labor', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Some workers at Trader Joe’s stores, including one who says he was fired for lacking a “genuine” smile, have complained about their treatment and of safety lapses.
lead_paragraph: To explain their infatuation with Trader Joe’s, fans of the offbeat grocery chain typically cite three factors: low prices, an appealing selection of high-end products and, perhaps above all, irrepressibly friendly employees.

headline: Donald Trump’s Impeachment Threat
abstract: Republicans are indicating that if they can’t gain control of government fairly, they’ll simply undermine it.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and other embattled Republican candidates are resorting to a particularly bizarre and dangerous tactic in the closing days of the campaign — warning that they may well seek to impeach Hillary Clinton if she wins, or, short of that, tie her up with endless investigations and other delaying tactics.

headline: Penn State Faces Record Fine in Sandusky-Related Case
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Football (College)', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: The federal government said the university did not comply with a federal law requiring public alerts about safety threats and is seeking a $2.4 million fine.
lead_paragraph: Four years after Jerry Sandusky, a former Penn State assistant football coach, was convicted of sexually abusing 10 young boys, the federal government is seeking to fine the university nearly $2.4 million for failing to alert the public about Mr. Sandusky’s conduct and other campus dangers.

headline: C. E. Morgan Among Winners of $50,000 Kirkus Book Prizes
abstract: Ms. Morgan won the award for her novel “The Sport of Kings.” Susan Faludi and Jason Reynolds also took home prizes.
lead_paragraph: C.E. Morgan, Susan Faludi and Jason Reynolds were honored on Thursday at the third annual Kirkus Prizes ceremony in Austin, Tex. Each prize comes with an award of $50,000.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Donors Are Avoiding Democrats in State Senate Races
abstract: In 2014, Mayor Bill de Blasio’s allies gave generously to Democratic groups outside New York City amid his bid to remake the State Legislature. That money has dried up this year amid fund-raising inquiries.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Alex Lodde, a Texas transportation magnate, made his first political donation in New York a meaningful one: He gave $100,000 to a small county political committee in the Hudson Valley to support an all-out effort by Mayor Bill de Blasio to deliver control of the State Senate to his fellow Democrats.

abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Harvard Cancels Rest of Men’s Soccer Season Over Lewd Ratings of Female Players
abstract: The action came after it was uncovered that male players had been sharing sexually explicit descriptions of recruits for the women’s team.
lead_paragraph: Harvard announced on Thursday that it was canceling the rest of the season for its men’s soccer team after university officials uncovered what they described as a widespread practice of the team’s players rating the school’s female players in sexually explicit terms.

headline: You Might Be Paying Too Much for Your Chicken
keywords: ['Poultry', 'Chickens', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Investors contend that the way a chicken pricing index used by grocery stores is compiled has kept the retail price of chicken artificially high.
lead_paragraph: Beef prices at grocery stores are lower. So, too, are pork prices. But chicken? Steady as she goes.

headline: Longtime Prospect Park Carousel Operator to Stop Making His Rounds
abstract: Lucio Schiavone, one of the craftsmen who helped renovate the Brooklyn attraction in the late 1980s, is retiring after 26 years.
lead_paragraph: For the past 26 years, when children have raced through the doors of the carousel at Prospect Park in Brooklyn, Lucio Schiavone has gently called out, “Tickets, tickets please.” Once they have all settled, he rings a brass bell, presses his palm against a big red button and then perches himself on a tall stool to watch.

headline: Seeing the New York City Marathon From the Other Side of the Starting Line
abstract: Mary Wittenberg, former president of New York Road Runners, who directed the race for 10 years, will be running it for the first time.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Mary Wittenberg, the former president of New York Road Runners, will tour New York City’s five boroughs on foot — one of about 50,000 entrants in the New York City Marathon, a race she directed for 10 years but has never run. Wittenberg, 54, is a longtime resident of the Upper East Side, where she lives with her husband and two sons. Since taking over Virgin Sport, a company started by Richard Branson, in 2015, she has learned to merge training trips with work trips. A onetime competitive marathoner, Wittenberg spoke about preparing once again for the other side of the starting line.

abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Much Is on the Line for California Chrome at the Breeders’ Cup
keywords: ['Horse Racing', "Breeders' Cup (Horse Races)", 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)']
abstract: Chrome is the even-money favorite to win the $6 million Breeders’ Cup Classic and retain his title: Baddest Horse in the World.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — There is no racetrack on earth with a backside kitchen as chic as Clocker’s Corner at Santa Anita Park. This open-air bistro beneath the rouge-tipped San Gabriel Mountains is where the toned and the tan bask each morning in eternal sunshine as tens of millions of dollars of horse flesh circles the oval before them.

headline: ‘Cowardly’ Killings of Officers Strike a Raw Nerve in Iowa
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police']
abstract: A gunman’s fatal shooting of two officers near Des Moines on Wednesday has police officials trying to deal with another tragedy.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — For law enforcement officers here, it feels like a still-raw wound being torn open anew. Less than eight months after a drunken driver killed two police officers in a fiery crash, two other officers were shot to death in separate episodes on Wednesday.

headline: Cubs Clinched Title Before Baseball’s Largest TV Audience in Decades
abstract: Chicago’s decisive victory over the Cleveland Indians drew the largest World Series audience since Game 7 in 1991.
lead_paragraph: After Games 5 and 6 of this year’s World Series were seen by about 23 million viewers each, many began to wonder: How many more people would watch the Chicago Cubs and the Cleveland Indians play Game 7 on Wednesday night?

headline: Clinton Pushes Minority Turnout as Trump Tries to Rally His Base
abstract: Seldom have the candidates’ divergent approaches to campaigning been on more vivid display than in the final days of the race.
lead_paragraph: Saturating swing states with powerful campaign surrogates and mobilizing a vast field organization, Hillary Clinton on Thursday intensified her public attacks on Donald J. Trump as a threat to minorities in the hope of driving them to the polls in decisive numbers.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, November 4, 2016.

headline: As Trump Ally, Rudy Giuliani Boasts of Ties to F.B.I.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former New York mayor claims that he has a pipeline into the F.B.I. and that agents are “outraged” about the outcome of the Clinton email investigation.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York, seemed in a giddy mood when he was interviewed last week on the “Fox & Friends” morning television show.

headline: San Francisco Files Lawsuit Against Sinking Millennium Tower
abstract: A luxury condominium is fast shaping into a huge legal battle involving developers, the city and owners, and one with stakes befitting Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Five years ago, when Frank Jernigan, a retired Google software engineer, and his husband bought a 50th-floor apartment in downtown San Francisco for $4 million, they felt on top of the world. And judging by the commanding view of San Francisco Bay from the plate glass windows of their living room, they were.

headline: Well, Señor Kaine, Hablaste Español Muy Bien
abstract: Steadily, confidently, but far from flawlessly, Tim Kaine gave a speech entirely in Spanish in a heavily Hispanic neighborhood in Phoenix, a language that is a synonym for immigration.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — “No hablo español perfectamente,” Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia told an audience of 150 guests here on Thursday, during a political event billed as historic by the Hillary Clinton campaign. For the first time, a candidate on a United States presidential ticket delivered a speech entirely in Spanish, a language that is a synonym for immigration in this state.

headline: Something No One Can Sing
abstract: David Steinberg grows up.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Ah, our young constructors ... they grow up so quickly, don’t they?

headline: Review: The Jobs Are Gone in ‘Sweat.’ So Are People’s Hopes.
abstract: In Lynn Nottage’s latest play, the bonds among working-class friends and family unravel as the local economy falls apart.
lead_paragraph: In Lynn Nottage’s scorching play “Sweat,” the bonds among a group of working-class friends and family are frayed to the breaking point by the pressure of an eroding economic future. Keenly observed and often surprisingly funny — but ultimately heartbreaking — the work traces the roots of a tragedy with both forensic psychological detail and embracing compassion. Ms. Nottage, a Pulitzer Prize winner for “Ruined,” is writing at the peak of her powers, and the superb cast and the director, Kate Whoriskey, rise to the occasion.

headline: Missing South Carolina Woman Found in Metal Container
abstract: A registered sex offender was arrested in connection with her disappearance, according to officials and news media accounts, as an investigation continues.
lead_paragraph: A South Carolina woman who was reported missing with her boyfriend in August was found alive on Thursday in a metal storage container on a remote 100-acre property and a registered sex offender was arrested in connection with her disappearance, according to officials and news media accounts.

headline: Turkey Detains Leaders of Kurdish Opposition Party
abstract: The leaders, Selahattin Demirtas and Figen Yuksekdag of the Peoples’ Democratic Party, were detained as part of a counterterrorism investigation, state news media reported.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish police detained the two co-leaders of Turkey’s main Kurdish opposition party and several of its lawmakers on Friday during early-morning raids as part of a counterterrorism investigation, the state news media reported.

headline: Oilers Equal Rangers’ Speed but Can’t Match Their Stamina

lead_paragraph: Cam Talbot, the Edmonton Oilers’ goaltender, stayed down on one knee for a while, stunned after Rick Nash had scored what proved to be the winning goal for the Rangers with 1 minute 21 seconds left in the third period on Thursday night.

headline: The Post-Truth Presidency
abstract: We choose to believe what we want. Perhaps a third of American adults now believe a few Big Lies.
lead_paragraph: We can say with absolute certainty that the Chicago Cubs ended a 108-year spell of futility and won the World Series. The Curse of the Billy Goat is dead. We also know with absolute certainty that on the dawn following the last out, the sun rose over Chicago, my dad’s hometown, at 7:26 a.m.

headline: The Banality of Change
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hillary Clinton is the bigger change agent this year, because she can get things done in government.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago I met a guy in Idaho who was absolutely certain that Donald Trump would win this election. He was wearing tattered, soiled overalls, missing a bunch of teeth and was unnaturally skinny. He was probably about 50, but his haggard face looked 70. He was getting by aimlessly as a handyman.

headline: Who Broke Politics?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Medicare', 'Taxation']
abstract: Republican leaders have spent decades trashing democratic norms in pursuit of economic benefits for their donor class.
lead_paragraph: As far as anyone can tell, Paul Ryan, the speaker of the House — and the leader of what’s left of the Republican establishment — isn’t racist or authoritarian. He is, however, doing all he can to make a racist authoritarian the most powerful man in the world. Why? Because then he could privatize Medicare and slash taxes on the wealthy.

headline: Dalai Lama: Behind Our Anxiety, the Fear of Being Unneeded
keywords: ['Happiness', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'ANGER (EMOTION)']
abstract: There has never been a better time to be alive, and yet in the richest countries, there is a growing sense of unease and helplessness because people no longer feel useful.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, there has never been a better time to be alive. Violence plagues some corners of the world, and too many still live under the grip of tyrannical regimes. And although all the world’s major faiths teach love, compassion and tolerance, unthinkable violence is being perpetrated in the name of religion.

headline: Gary Johnson, Queen Maker
abstract: The impact of third-party candidates on federal and state elections is as significant as it is overlooked.
lead_paragraph: With just a few days before Election Day and all eyes fixed on the two leading candidates, it’s easy to overlook a remarkable fact: The Libertarian candidate for president, Gary Johnson, may tilt the election for Hillary Clinton. And if he does, it wouldn’t be the first time — not even close. The impact of third-party candidates on federal and state elections is as significant as it is overlooked.

headline: Are Voting Booth Selfies Fun or Dangerous?
abstract: By now you’ve heard about Justin Timberlake’s photograph at his polling station. Was he wrong to snap the pic?

headline: Suket Dhir, Men’s Wear Designer, From Delhi to the World
abstract: A self-described former “slacker” who once sold mobile phones for AT&T has made himself into India’s rising fashion star.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In a stifling office on the second floor of an anonymous building along a dusty lane in Lado Sarai — the new hub for young artists in a corner of the southwestern part of this capital city — a 38-year-old men’s wear designer Vogue.com has called a “global fashion superstar in the making” sat in semidarkness.
