keywords: ['Infant Mortality', 'Sudden Infant Death Syndrome', 'Sleep', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: A look at the data behind new guidelines should reassure exhausted parents.
lead_paragraph: New parents get a lot of advice. It comes from breast-feeding “lactivists” and Ferberizers, attachment parents and anti-helicopter ones. It’s not enough to keep babies fed, rested and changed — they also need to learn grit and sign language.

headline: Review: A Concerto in Which East Meets West, and Peace Reigns
abstract: The New York Philharmonic is performing Ravi Shankar’s “Raga-Mala,” in which the soloist is an orchestral chameleon.
lead_paragraph: Ravi Shankar’s first concerto for sitar and Western orchestra, from 1971, is a tame, lush, quite pretty piece. The ensemble serves as a kind of velvety pillow, atop which Mr. Shankar weaves coppery skeins for himself, as soloist.

headline: Four Cozy Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
abstract: A by-no-means exhaustive list of items we like (especially now that there’s a chill in the air).
lead_paragraph: If Ariana Bohling’s alpaca slippers look insanely soft, it’s because they are. Available exclusively at NoLita’s eco-friendly design boutique Côte à Coast, they are made in Peru, where alpacas are a protected species, from animals that die naturally while roaming freely in their native habitat. The slippers are beyond cozy, not to mention the bonus entertainment factor: They make your feet look like Dr. Seuss characters. $175, available in men’s and women’s sizes,  350 Bowery, New York, NY. — MARY KAYE SCHILLING

headline: Review: Shakespeare’s Take on the Game of Thrones
abstract: In “Kings of War,” the director Ivo van Hove adapts five history plays into a conflagration of corruption, factionalism and political viciousness.
lead_paragraph: During the more than four thrilling hours of Ivo van Hove’s “Kings of War,” an omnibus adaptation of five Shakespearean history plays at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, you may feel that those disturbing noises coming from the stage are just echoes of what you’re hearing in your own head these days. Sometimes there’s the amplified ticking of a clock, a bursting heartbeat, a mismatched thrum of tentacular chords or a brass fanfare sliding into sinister dissonance.

headline: How Is Your Family Coping With Delhi’s Air Pollution?
abstract: The Times would like to hear from parents whose children are staying home from school to avoid exposure to dangerous levels of air pollution.
lead_paragraph: More than one million students will be out of school on Saturday in India’s capital after the authorities decided to close public primary schools to protect children from exposure to dangerous levels of air pollution.

headline: If China Meant to Chill Hong Kong Speech, Booksellers’ Case Did the Job
abstract: A report by PEN America outlines the circumstances behind the disappearances of five booksellers last year and the fear that their case has sown in the industry.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The metal door of Causeway Bay Bookstore is locked, just as it was month after month after the disappearances last year of five Hong Kong booksellers. The five men had tended the shop and published many of the gossip-filled volumes on Chinese politics that lined its shelves.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: However much time you have this weekend, we have recommendations for you.
lead_paragraph: ‘Midnight Diner,’ Netflix

headline: J. Crew Shutters Its Bridal Business
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Dresses', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: J. Crew, which helped break the mold with its inexpensive ready-to-wear bridal gowns, is leaving the business.
lead_paragraph: When word spread earlier this week that J. Crew, the catalog and clothing retailer, was leaving its bridal business at the altar, the reaction was one of collective dismay.

headline: A City Laid Low, Its Team Even Lower
abstract: In economically challenged Sunderland, the local side runs the risk of becoming the worst team the Premier League has ever seen.
lead_paragraph: SUNDERLAND, England — Just outside the dressing rooms at Sunderland’s Stadium of Light, the walls are decorated with outsize portraits of the club’s players. They are pictured with arms crossed, eyes narrowed.

headline: Review: Kristin Chenoweth, That Perky Performer With the Powerhouse Pipes
abstract: Kristin Chenoweth’s concert show, “My Love Letter to Broadway,” displayed her enthusiasm, playfulness, superb voice and entertaining choice of material.
lead_paragraph: A Big Gulp plopped on top of a Steinway piano isn’t something I ever expected to see. But there it was, almost towering over Kristin Chenoweth, the petite performer with a powerhouse voice, in her enchanting Broadway concert debut, “My Love Letter to Broadway,” which plays through Nov. 13 at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

headline: Elon Musk Says SpaceX Rocket Launches Might Resume Next Month
keywords: ['Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Space and Astronomy', 'International Space Station']
abstract: The chief executive of SpaceX outlined some details of what caused a rocket explosion in September.
lead_paragraph: Engineers investigating the explosion of one of SpaceX’s rockets in September have figured out what went wrong, and launches could resume in mid-December, Elon Musk, the company’s chief executive, said on Friday.

headline: SundanceTV’s Identity Crisis: Indie by Night. Innocent by Day.
abstract: This channel’s new daytime block includes “All in the Family” and “The Mary Tyler Moore Show.” Good shows, but they don’t quite scream, “independent film.”
lead_paragraph: Jason Bourne knows it. As do Sarah Manning, the “Orphan Black” character, and Jane Doe, the tattooed woman in “Blindspot.” Identity is a slippery thing. Sometimes you’re pretty clear about who you are; other times, you seem to be someone else, or someone else seems to be you.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from KJ Dell’Antonia, Tara Parker-Pope and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Why Isn’t Blackface Taboo for Australians?
abstract: Indigenous and other nonwhite Australians are tired of telling the country what is wrong with the degrading practice.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — In the United States, painting yourself black to impersonate a person of color is considered a particularly grotesque form of racism. In Australia, it keeps happening. Indeed, 2016 has been a notable year for Australian blackface incidents.

headline: Clinton, Trump, Christie: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Painter’s Headaches Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a painter with terrible headaches.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 63-year-old artist who, over the course of several months, developed excruciating headaches, along with changes in his personality, his thinking, even in the way he painted. We provided you with some of the doctor’s notes and medical imaging results that led the doctor who finally made the diagnosis in the right direction.

headline: #MyRunLooksLike: The Road to the Marathon Start Line
abstract: We asked to see photos of your marathon training, and you delivered. Here's what #MyRunLooksLike.
lead_paragraph: We asked to see photos of your marathon training, and you delivered. Here's what #MyRunLooksLike.

headline: Wall St. Scion Gets 4 Years in Prison for Fraud
keywords: ['Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Gambling']
abstract: Andrew Caspersen, a Wall Street executive from a well-off family, received a far shorter sentence than prosecutors sought after a doctor testified he had a gambling addiction.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Caspersen, the disgraced scion of a wealthy Wall Street family, was sentenced on Friday to four years in prison for robbing his friends, family members and a large hedge fund foundation in a Ponzi-like scheme.

headline: The World Series Sports Page That Wasn’t
abstract: C’mon, man, these are the Cubs; they’ll surely cooperate, as they have for the past 108 years.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. Here, Wayne Kamidoi, a Times art director, reveals the very special image that was planned for the Sports section front had the Cleveland Indians triumphed in the World Series.

headline: United Loyalties
abstract: What a World Series — especially if you’ve played for both the Cubs and Terry Francona.
lead_paragraph: As a baseball analyst for ESPN, I have to remain neutral, but that doesn’t erase my history. I was a Chicago Cub, and I also played for Terry Francona, now the Cleveland Indians manager, what seems like a lifetime ago. So amid the excitement of seeing my first professional organization have a chance to win it all, and get further than I ever reached in my major-league career, I knew that someone had to lose. And I had friends on both sides.

headline: Tense Jurors in Michael Slager Trial See Video of Killing of Walter Scott
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The jury in South Carolina viewed the cellphone footage that spurred Mr. Slager’s prosecution and became a symbol of the national debate over race and policing.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Before court began here on Friday, the county’s chief prosecutor stepped into the gallery and spoke quietly to the family of Walter L. Scott, a black man who was shot and killed by a white police officer last year.

headline: Bill Simmons’s HBO Program Is Canceled
abstract: HBO was eager to tap Mr. Simmons’s base of readers of his sports column, but that audience failed to materialize.
lead_paragraph: After premiering to sky-high expectations this summer, Bill Simmons’s weekly HBO show has been canceled.

headline: Ruling Preserves Voting Rights for Thousands in North Carolina
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Elections', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: A federal judge, rejecting a challenge by Republican operatives, prohibited three counties from revoking registrations just before the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge barred three North Carolina counties on Friday from revoking the voting rights of thousands of residents whose eligibility to cast ballots had been challenged by Republican political operatives only weeks before the presidential election.

headline: Looking Back (Sigh) at the End (Sigh) of the Indians’ Great Season (Sigh)
abstract: An Indians fan looks back on the World Series, without rancor or second-guessing, and finds it will take time to recover.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — This one hurt.

headline: David Seeley, Educator Who Fought Against Segregation, Dies at 85
abstract: Dr. Seeley worked to provide equal opportunity to young people, through political actions and community alliances, for more than 50 years.
lead_paragraph: David S. Seeley, a lawyer and educator who devoted his career in government and academia to racially integrating the United States’ schools and to upgrading them through a collaborative movement involving students, teachers, parents and community organizations, died on Oct. 30 on Staten Island. He was 85.

headline: Kobe Bryant’s Next Step, New Shoes and Moves With Los Angeles Artists
abstract: Mr. Bryant, who retired from basketball, has entered several other ventures.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles — Ancient Buddhists believed reincarnation was instantaneous upon death. Jewish texts have long foretold an afterlife of revolving souls. Many Catholics swear by the transformative power of holy water. For sports celebrities, reinvention is much easier. Sometimes all it takes is a shoe launch and presto — the end is a beginning.

headline: Clinton Forwarded Daughter Email Chain Most Likely About Climate Talks
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: The information contained in the chain in 2009 was later declared to be classified by the State Department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton forwarded a chain of emails in 2009 to her daughter, Chelsea, that included information, most likely about climate talks, that the State Department later declared to be classified, according to a new batch of emails released on Friday.

headline: Bob Miller, a Veteran Los Angeles Announcer Younger Than Vin Scully and Unready to Retire
abstract: Miller, after quadruple-bypass surgery, returned for his 44th season calling Kings games, though other broadcasters like Jiggs McDonald will fill in for some road games.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Before their home opener last month, the Los Angeles Kings kicked off a yearlong celebration of their 50th anniversary with a pregame ceremony that featured many of the team’s greats, including Wayne Gretzky. But one of the loudest ovations was accorded Bob Miller, a Hall of Fame broadcaster who enters his 44th season as the voice of the Kings.

headline: Federal Investigation of New Jersey Transit Finds Numerous Safety Violations
abstract: At a hearing with state lawmakers, the new leader of the agency, Steven Santoro, called the issues “unacceptable” and pledged improvements.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — A federal investigation of New Jersey Transit’s railroad this year revealed that workers used personal cellphones while on duty and train crews failed to properly test brakes or blow horns at crossings, among other problems, the agency’s executive director told state legislators at a hearing here on Friday.

headline: Last Gasp Election Briefing
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: You say you have some last-minute questions?
lead_paragraph: O.K., guys. It’s election time. You probably have a few last-minute questions. Fire away.

headline: Yonkers Schools Flouted Rules on Special Education, U.S. Agency Says
abstract: As a result of an investigation, the federal Education Department announced that the city agreed to revamp its procedures.
lead_paragraph: Public schools are required to educate children with disabilities in regular classrooms as much as possible, but according to a federal investigation, the Yonkers school system routinely flouted that rule. And instead of creating a specific plan for each student, as is required, the district essentially copied and pasted language from one child’s file to the next.

headline: ‘We Almost Have Riots’: Tensions Flare in Silicon Valley Over Growth
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Referendums']
abstract: As the region has become more congested and expensive, there are growing demands to rein in the physical space that many technologists call home.
lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Silicon Valley is bent on disrupting the world. Its products affect how millions upon millions of people live and work. But when it comes to the physical space that many technologists call home, there are increasing demands to leave things alone.

headline: Review: From Balanchine to Jookin, a Sampler of Summer Souvenirs
abstract: “Vail Dance Festival: ReMix NYC” features ballet rarities and premieres, including Alexei Ratmansky’s “Fandango,” as well as collaborations like Lil Buck and Yo-Yo Ma.
lead_paragraph: Damian Woetzel, impressively ambitious, has been making dance history for 10 years in Vail, Colo. As artistic director of the two-week Vail International Dance Festival, he assembles each August a top-class gathering of performers in multiple genres. No single program is performed twice. World premieres by front-rank choreographers (notably Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon) occur. So do unexpected partnerships between dancers from different companies and far-apart disciplines.

headline: What Is Bull Riding’s Scariest Beast Afraid Of? You Name It
abstract: Inside the ring, Air Time — a 1,650-pound black-and-white compact car of an animal — lives up to his name, but outside it he is a timid creature easily spooked by even his own shadow.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a secret about the toughest, most feared bull on the professional bull-riding circuit: He’s a big baby.

headline: Seeking Shelter After Fleeing Mosul
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The battle for Mosul raged on Friday and streams of civilians continued an exodus from the city.
lead_paragraph: The battle for Mosul, Iraq, raged on Friday and streams of civilians continued an exodus from the city.

headline: An Odd Homecoming Precedes a Knicks Road Win
abstract: The former Bulls Derrick Rose and Joakim Noah returned to Chicago on Friday night and were greeted by boos and cheers as they helped the Knicks win, 117-104.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Tyler Pleiss was home from college on April 28, 2012, a date that sticks in the minds of many here. Pleiss was on the couch at his parents’ home in Omaha, watching the Bulls rough up the Philadelphia 76ers in a first-round playoff game. Thinking the game was essentially over, he had lost interest. And then it happened.

headline: On Assisted Suicide, Going Beyond ‘Do No Harm’
keywords: ['Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Doctors']
abstract: Fewer people experience a “natural death” anymore. Doctors should rethink their opposition to right-to-die laws.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — Out of nowhere, a patient I recently met in my clinic told me, “If my heart stops, doctor, just let me go.”

headline: Beyond Lying: Donald Trump’s Authoritarian Reality
abstract: In denouncing him as a liar, the media didn’t go far enough.
lead_paragraph: As the Republican candidate for president in 2016, Donald J. Trump has accomplished many things. He engaged in rhetorical tactics unprecedented in recent American electoral history. He was straightforwardly misogynistic. He repeatedly endorsed obviously false claims. There were frequent open discussions of the intentions behind his many odd comments, retractions, semi-retractions and outright false statements.

headline: Lost in Game 7’s Dazzle, Another Fan’s Senseless Injury
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Sports Injuries', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'World Series']
abstract: This was the season Major League Baseball was going to get serious about reducing fan injuries, by extending protective netting. A woman’s injury in Game 7 of the World Series proved otherwise.
lead_paragraph: At Wednesday night’s glorious Game 7, there was only one real down moment for baseball. In the top of the seventh inning, a fan was knocked out cold by a scorching foul ball.

headline: Builders That Got Tax Breaks Must Set Aside Some Units for Homeless, City Says
abstract: Moving to reduce the number of New Yorkers in shelters, Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration is requiring developers that got 421-a subsidies to give some units to homeless people.
lead_paragraph: As the number of New Yorkers living in shelters continues to rise, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio has told real estate developers they must make room for the homeless in buildings that received tax breaks under a program designed to increase the stock of affordable housing.

headline: Harvard Men’s Soccer Team Is Sidelined for Vulgar ‘Scouting Report’
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Colleges and Universities', 'College Athletics', 'Women and Girls', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Assigning sexually demeaning rankings to incoming members of the women’s soccer team leads the prestigious university to cancel the remainder of the men’s season.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — They rated the women on a sexual appeal scale of 1 to 10, including explicit descriptions of their physical traits and musings about the women’s preferred sexual positions.

headline: Faster, Farther, More Frequent: Ultramarathon Runners Keep Pushing Limits
abstract: Pete Kostelnick, who recently set a record for running across the United States, is among Americans shattering marks in a historically reclusive sport.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t the truck plowing into his support crew’s van that rattled him, or the fever that left his teeth chattering into the night or even the severe desert sunburn that streaked his flesh pink. But when tendinitis seized his ankle and crept up his shins until they swelled, Pete Kostelnick second-guessed himself for trying to log the fastest run across America ever recorded. He was still only in Nevada.

headline: Republicans and the Myth of Election Fraud
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination']
abstract: In Iowa and Florida, it’s actually been Republican supporters accused of fraud. Yet their party continues to try to disenfranchise minority voters.
lead_paragraph: In recent years Republicans in state legislatures have expressed grave concern about voter fraud as they presented a “solution” of tough voter ID laws and other restrictions that deprive low-income and minority voters of the ballot. Many of these voter-suppression measures have become law despite clear evidence that voter fraud is practically nonexistent.

headline: New York Police on Alert After Warning of Terror Attack Before Election
abstract: An F.B.I. bulletin said that Al Qaeda might be planning attacks for Monday, but an official said there was skepticism about the credibility of the information.
lead_paragraph: The Police Department will be on heightened alert in coming days in response to a warning about possible terrorist activity that could occur the day before the presidential election, Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Friday.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, November 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Let me be clear once again. I had no knowledge prior to or during these lane realignments, and had no role in authorizing them. No believable evidence was presented to contradict that fact.”

headline: ‘I Saw My Father Dying’: A View From Aleppo’s Government-Held Side
abstract: A rare visit to the city’s western side revealed weariness and violence despite President Bashar al-Assad’s claims that residents are safe.
lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria — The government-held side of Aleppo looks halfway normal: bustling with restaurants, parks, hotel swimming pools and commuters. President Bashar al-Assad’s main pitch to his people is that they are safer in the territory he controls, a far cry from the bombs and hunger on the rebels’ half of the storied and strategic city.

headline: Liam Scarlett Named to Queensland Ballet Post
abstract: Li Cunxin, the artistic director of the Australian company, said Mr. Scarlett would create new works for the ballet and stage some of his existing pieces, including “No Man’s Land.”
lead_paragraph: The British choreographer Liam Scarlett, an important name in the ballet world, will become an artistic associate of the Queensland Ballet in 2017. The appointment, announced on Friday by Li Cunxin, the artistic director of the Australian company, follows the ballet’s work with Mr. Scarlett in April on his production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”

headline: U.S. Diplomat Who Helped South Sudan Says He’s Appalled by Strife There
abstract: Ambassador David Pressman, who helped shape Obama administration policy on South Sudan, said he was “horrified and disgusted” at the violence.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — An American diplomat who helped shape the Obama administration’s efforts to steer South Sudan to independence in 2011 says he is appalled by the actions of its leaders, including those he personally knows.

headline: Trump Tower in Toronto Is in Receivership After Poor Sales
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The hotel and condominium tower is in receivership after the owners failed to make debt payments for a year and a court ruled that investors were deceived.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — The first building in Canada to bear the name of Donald J. Trump — a 65-story hotel and condominium in downtown Toronto — did not get off to an auspicious start. Shortly after it opened in 2012, it started shedding glass, and for the first of many times, the police had to close the surrounding streets because of falling debris.

headline: Self-Defense for Novelists
abstract: Krav maga lessons started as research but became an enjoyable punishment.
lead_paragraph: My lessons in krav maga — a self-defense system — started with workouts that left me gasping for breath, including a nearly endless number of push-ups and burpees. Whenever I was about to give up, my instructor, Serge, would say, “Don’t give up, you do it!” He was clearly a man who wouldn’t take no for an answer, and I didn’t want to disappoint him.

headline: Not Going by the Book
abstract: David Phillips returns with a Saturday challenge, and a unique new building at Hampshire College in Massachusetts offers clues of its own.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — David Phillips seems to be primarily a late-week constructor, but he’s ventured into weekday constructing as well. He needs only a Monday and a Wednesday puzzle to have hit for the cycle.

headline: Donald Trump’s Denial of Economic Reality
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Editorials']
abstract: The candidate refuses to acknowledge what the official data show: that the country is doing better than it was just a few years ago.
lead_paragraph: To listen to Donald Trump describe the American economy is to hear about a horrifying alternate reality in which the recession that started at the end of 2007 is still with us. The truth is very different. The recovery that began in the middle of 2009, though not perfect, has steadily created jobs and lifted wages.

headline: The Revival of Gun Controls Out West
abstract: Ballot initiatives in four states seek to circumvent the gun lobby’s intimidation of state legislators.
lead_paragraph: While Congress shamefully fails to face up to the toll of gun carnage, California’s lawmakers and voters are forging ahead with innovative safety measures, including mandatory background checks for the purchase of ammunition, not just guns.

headline: The Election That Obliterated Euphemisms
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Social Media', 'Editorials', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: Donald Trump has made it difficult to avoid describing his behavior as racist.
lead_paragraph: The Donald Trump campaign inadvertently performed a public service when it exposed the weakness and vulnerability of the euphemisms long used by political journalists. News organizations have been forced to acknowledge that phrases like “stretched the truth” and “fudged the facts” are useless for describing a candidate who speaks falsely in virtually every breath. Genteel circumlocution has given way to calling out lies as lies.

headline: Rick Steiner, Producer of Broadway Hits, Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Steiner worked a broad variety of jobs and was, among other things, a poker champion.
lead_paragraph: Rick Steiner, a Broadway producer who compiled a remarkable string of box-office hits that included “The Producers,” “Hairspray” and “Jersey Boys,” died on Thursday at his home in Cincinnati. He was 69.

headline: On the Trail: Week of Oct. 31
abstract: In the last full week of the campaign, Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump both held rallies in swing states around the country.
lead_paragraph: In the last full week of the campaign, Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump both held rallies in swing states around the country.

headline: Alexis Tsipras Shakes Up Cabinet to Soothe Greece’s Creditors
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The Greek prime minister, apparently with an eye on debt-relief talks, replaced the ministers of energy and labor but retained his finance minister.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece shuffled his cabinet on Friday, dismissing ministers who have objected to economic changes and austerity measures demanded by the country’s creditors.

headline: Gene La Rocque, Decorated Veteran Who Condemned Waste of War, Dies at 98
abstract: After retiring from the Navy, Admiral La Rocque founded a think tank to promote peace and to monitor the influence of the military-industrial complex.
lead_paragraph: Rear Adm. Gene La Rocque, a decorated Navy veteran who spoke out against the wastes of war, was labeled a traitor by some and went on to found the Center for Defense Information, a private think tank that was described as both pro-peace and pro-military, died on Monday in Washington. He was 98.

headline: After Violent Encounter Between Police and a Black Man, Something Rare — An Apology
abstract: Frank Baker of St. Paul was bitten by a police dog and kicked by an officer in June, an encounter captured on newly released dash camera footage.
lead_paragraph: On the day in June that Todd Axtell became police chief in St. Paul, he happened to meet Frank Baker, a local resident who wished him well in his new job. Then, the next night, a police dog bit Mr. Baker on the leg and a police officer kicked him, leaving him hospitalized for two weeks with collapsed lungs and large lacerations.

headline: Canada Today: Espionage, and Newfoundland’s Hospitality Comes to the Stage
abstract: A town that hosted thousands of travelers after Sept. 11 is the subject of a musical opening this month in Toronto. Plus, revelations that the police spied on journalists.
lead_paragraph: When terrorist attacks grounded air travel on Sept. 11, 2001, Gander, Newfoundland, population 11,000, found itself playing host to 6,700 stranded travelers, most of them American. While that made the town famous for hospitality worldwide, its residents tend to play down their contributions.

headline: On the Trail: Friday, Nov. 4
abstract: Donald J. Trump campaigned in New Hampshire, North Carolina and Pennsylvania while Hillary Clinton campaigned in Detroit and Pennsylvania before holding a concert with Beyonce and JAY Z in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump campaigned in New Hampshire, North Carolina and Pennsylvania while Hillary Clinton campaigned in Detroit and Pennsylvania before holding a concert with Beyonce and JAY Z in Cleveland.

headline: Presidential Election: A Closing Act, With Clinton, Trump and a Tiny ‘Future Construction Worker’
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump campaigned in Florida, with Mrs. Clinton basking in the rain and Mr. Trump sharing the stage with a (very) young fan.
lead_paragraph: A man was apprehended at a Donald Trump rally in Reno, Nev., on Saturday night, after someone shouted about a gun, but no weapon was found and the man was released.

headline: Win Puts Andy Murray on Verge of No. 1 Ranking
abstract: Murray can pass Novak Djokovic, who lost in the Paris Masters quarterfinals on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic, a three-time defending champion, lost in the Paris Masters quarterfinals on Friday, leaving his No. 1 ranking open to being snatched by Andy Murray. Murray can rise from No. 2 to No. 1 in the ATP list for the first time if he reaches the final. He beat No. 11 Tomas Berdych, 7-6 (9), 7-5, to reach the semifinal, where his opponent will be Milos Raonic.

headline: A Hip-Hop Political Rally, Starring Beyoncé, Jay Z (and Hillary Clinton)
abstract: To the cheers of thousands, top artists headlined a Cleveland event to urge millennial and African-American voters to go to the polls on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In an election year when Hillary Clinton is depending on young black voters to turn out, she may have gotten her biggest boost yet here on Friday.

headline: Corrections: November 5, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Dancing Back the Spirit of an Old Friend
abstract: John Bernd inspired a series exploring the impact of the AIDS epidemic on dance.
lead_paragraph: The dancers performing at Danspace Project over the weekend were too young to have known John Bernd, the choreographer whose work they were interpreting. Yet in “Variations on Themes From Lost and Found: Scenes From a Life and Other Works by John Bernd,” which opened on Thursday, they seemed to be communing with the spirit of an old friend, coaxing him into the room, so that everyone there could know him.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: Benedict Cumberbatch Hosts ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: Benedict Cumberbatch, in theaters as “Doctor Strange,” hosts “S.N.L.” And Alex Gibney investigates the potential for cyberwarfare in “Zero Days.”
lead_paragraph: Benedict Cumberbatch, now flying into theaters as “Doctor Strange,” hosts “Saturday Night Live” for the first time. Alex Gibney investigates the potential for cyberwarfare. And ponder presidents past — some fictional, some not so much — in the final weekend before the election.

headline: In the Media Pen at a Trump Rally
abstract: Donald J. Trump encourages his supporters to heckle journalists, whom he requires to sit in a separate section, during campaign appearances. Experience the boos.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump encourages his supporters to heckle journalists, whom he requires to sit in a separate section, during campaign appearances. Experience the boos.

headline: Another Philippine Mayor Accused of Drug Crimes by Duterte Is Killed
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Rolando Espinosa Sr., the mayor of Albuera, was killed in his jail cell in the central Philippines, in what the police called a “firefight.”
lead_paragraph: MANILA — A Philippine mayor who had been accused of drug trafficking by President Rodrigo Duterte was shot and killed by police officers in his jail cell on Saturday, the police said.

headline: New Item on the College Admission Checklist: LinkedIn Profile
abstract: Social media experts are advising high school seniors to create professional profiles on LinkedIn and draw them to the attention of college admissions officers.
lead_paragraph: Applying for admission to many American colleges already has high school students jumping through hoops.

headline: ‘Who Is Left to Counterbalance the Extreme Partisanship?’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers debate a new look at Hillary Clinton’s emails, Donald Trump’s tax dodges and a World Series for the ages.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: The Closer: Michelle Obama
abstract: Dismissed early on by critics, the first lady has evolved into a powerful presence on the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The emails to Michelle Obama began flooding in minutes after she spoke out at an October rally in New Hampshire, her voice shaking, about Donald J. Trump’s treatment of women. Sexual assault victims recounted their trauma, fathers poured out anxieties about unhealthy influences on their sons, and a distraught parent agonized over how to explain rape to a 10-year-old.

headline: The Tricky Etiquette of Co-Working Spaces
keywords: ['Co-Working', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: To get a glimpse of what manners will be like in the office of the future, it behooves us to look at the co-working spaces of today.
lead_paragraph: In the future, will we be kind?

headline: The Case for Shopping in Real Life
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Families and Family Life', 'Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: Online shopping is easy, fast and completely devoid of any experiential pleasure.
lead_paragraph: When I was 6, my aunt took me shopping at Hutzler’s, the fancy department store in my hometown, Baltimore. Although it was the mid-1970s, ladies with blue-tinted hair ate sandwiches without crusts in the tearoom. And as we shopped, I wandered through what seemed like endless displays of textures, shapes, colors and smells.

headline: Western Michigan’s Perfect Record Could Give Way to Pain Off the Field
abstract: Western Michigan is 9-0, but the program’s success will most likely not provide a chance to play for a national championship and could result in the loss of its coach.
lead_paragraph: KALAMAZOO, Mich. — When Western Michigan hired P. J. Fleck before the 2013 season, he was, at 32, the youngest head coach in the Football Bowl Subdivision. With indomitable energy, offensive smarts — he had been a receivers coach in the N.F.L. — and a penchant for quirky motivational mantras like “Row The Boat,” he has turned the Broncos from a 1-11 doormat in his first year to a 9-0 team that is No. 17 in this week’s Associated Press poll.

headline: Gentrification Protesters in Los Angeles Target Art Galleries
abstract: Spray paint and hurled bottles draw the notice of the police as a neighborhood’s Mexican-American residents fear being displaced.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The message on the steel roll-up gate of Mihai Nicodim’s gallery could not have been clearer: With obscene language, the spray-painted words condemned what they labeled “white art.”

headline: What Would You Serve With Gin and Juice? At the Table With Martha Stewart and Snoop Dogg
abstract: On their new television show, “Martha & Snoop’s Potluck Dinner Party,” an odd couple dispense wit and kitchen wisdom.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Martha Stewart arrived for dinner at the back-room chef’s table of the Nice Guy restaurant here recently, on what happened to be Taco Tuesday. The specialty of the house, the waitress told her, was its own interpretation of a Jack in the Box taco, a staple of Southern California drive-through fast-food cuisine.

headline: The Money Management Gospel of Yale’s Endowment Guru
abstract: The mammoth Yale endowment fund run by David Swensen has been a training ground for investment managers, its alumni now scattered through the nonprofit world.
lead_paragraph: As he has done for decades, once a week David F. Swensen convenes his staff — including his cadre of apprentices — for a morning-long meeting among the Gothic revival flourishes and crenelations of the Yale University campus to debate investment ideas.

headline: What’s Selling Now in New York Stores
abstract: A sampling of the best sellers that have been flying off shelves and onto New York City streets.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of the best sellers that have been flying off shelves and onto New York City streets.

headline: How to Have a Culturally Rich Vacation
abstract: For a more fulfilling getaway, avoid set tours, hire a local guide and stay at small, locally owned hotels.
lead_paragraph: Whether your next vacation is to a big city, the beach or someplace rural, why not make the trip more fulfilling by soaking up the destination’s culture? “Getting exposed to local culture is enriching and shows us a world beyond ourselves,” said Ashish Sanghrajka, the president of Big Five Tours & Expeditions, a Stuart, Fla.-based travel company specializing in custom cultural immersion trips.

headline: For Many Underpaid Professionals, a High-Cost Retirement Plan
abstract: The workplace plans offered to teachers and social workers cost too much. But there are ways to fix the problem.
lead_paragraph: For several years, Tara Siegel Bernard and I have been hearing stories from teachers, preachers and other employees of nonprofits of all sorts about the problems in their workplace retirement plans. Eventually, we started collecting the reports and seeking more information about 403(b)s, which are like 401(k)s for people who work at charities, universities and the like.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Living in Georgetown, Washington, D.C
abstract: Georgetown is a picturesque area with cobbled streets, historic homes and a lively shopping and dining district.
lead_paragraph: Georgetown is a picturesque area with cobbled streets, historic homes and a lively shopping and dining district.

headline: Georgetown, Washington, D.C.: Postcard-Pretty
abstract: Georgetown is a picturesque area with cobbled streets, historic homes and a lively shopping and dining district.
lead_paragraph: The pair of mules looked happy, snacking on hay, carbo-loading before their appointed stroll down the leafy towpath of the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal.

headline: Push to Give Marcos a Philippine Hero’s Burial Finds an Ally in Duterte
abstract: Ties, possibly financial, between President Rodrigo Duterte and the family of the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos have raised questions of motives.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The torture was more than 40 years ago, but Loretta Rosales remembers it vividly.

headline: Nusrat Choudhury and Michael Early: After a Month in Limbo, a Connection
abstract: She expressed interest in him on @Hingeapp, but then left him in limbo for a month.
lead_paragraph: Nusrat Jahan Choudhury and Michael Alexander Early were married Nov. 5 at the Armour House, an event space in Lake Forest, Ill. Imam Senad Agic officiated, with Judge Barrington D. Parker Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit taking part.

headline: Caroline Harrison and Nicholas D’Addario: Baby, It’s Cold Outside (Inside, Too)
abstract: A broken boiler in her apartment building rekindled the flame.
lead_paragraph: Caroline Hurst Harrison and Nicholas Francis D’Addario were married Nov. 5. The Rev. John E. Denaro, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Club Giraud in San Antonio.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Gaming as Prophylaxis to Elections
abstract: Mike is a medieval witch hunter, as Farhad retreats into Mario. Microsoft’s grab for Slack’s lunch is discussed. And Amazon could do better at inspiring shopping.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Randi Dennett and Barry Altmark: Sweethearts at Age 3, and Now Forever
abstract: “‘I’m Barry Altmark,’” he said. “‘I have loved you since I was 3 years old.’”
lead_paragraph: Randi Faryl Dennett, the daughter of Stacey Dennett and Dr. Jay A. Dennett of Old Westbury, N.Y., was married Nov. 5 to Barry Altmark, a son of Aileen Altmark and Moshe Altmark of Hewlett Bay Park, N.Y. Rabbi Scott N. Bolton led the ceremony at the Pierre hotel in Manhattan.

headline: Veronica Siverd and Cooper Pickett: When Doctors Doubted Her, He Stood By
abstract: When she was hospitalized, he jumped into bed with her and they watched “Breaking Bad” together.
lead_paragraph: Veronica Leigh Siverd, the daughter of Bonita M. Siverd and Robert J. Siverd Sr. of Indian Hill, Ohio, was married Nov. 5 to Cooper Alexander Pickett, a son of Linda J. Pickett of New Milford, Conn., and Richard M. Pickett of Brooklyn. The bride’s father, who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated at 632 on Hudson, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: How LinkedIn Drove a Wedge Between Microsoft and Salesforce
abstract: Once so close they flirted with a merger, the software giants became archrivals when they realized the value of the data amassed by social networks.
lead_paragraph: This is a story of love lost after a fight over social media.

headline: A Roommate Dies; Must His Estate Pay the Rent?
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Wills and Estates', 'Roommates', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A landlord can sue any or all of those named on the lease, so it’s best to keep paying the rent.
lead_paragraph: Q. My boyfriend and I were both named on the lease of a garage apartment that we shared in Woodmere, N.Y. He died in July 2014 and I remained in the apartment, continuing to pay the full rent. Is my boyfriend’s estate liable for the balance of his half of the rent for the remainder of the term of the lease? I filed a claim with the surrogate court, but I am still waiting for a response.

headline: Britain’s Increase in Hate Crimes Is Tied to Changes in How They Are Reported
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation', 'Police', 'Minorities', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The rise can be attributed to increased public awareness and changes in British law stemming from a perception-based definition of what constitutes a hate crime.
lead_paragraph: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — On the surface, Britain would seem to be in the throes of an alarming wave of hate crimes.

headline: A Lawyer With a Taste for Soy Sauce and a High Tolerance for Pain
abstract: Although Jonathan Blum had spent his legal career advising businesses, turning his passion into a company wasn’t as straightforward as he had expected.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, Jonathan Blum, a corporate lawyer in the Bay Area, rented a U-Haul truck and loaded it with three pallets of soy sauce bottles. Mr. Blum, 49, had recently begun importing the sauce from Japan for his new business, Shiso Soy. This should have been a triumphant moment in his long quest to bring high-quality, artisanal Japanese soy sauces to the United States. Instead, he was headed to the town dump.

headline: South Koreans ‘Ashamed’ Over Leader’s Secretive Adviser
abstract: Many are infuriated by the notion that President Park Geun-hye has been in thrall for decades to a family of religious charlatans.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In 1973, a newspaper advertisement in the South Korean city of Daejeon announced the arrival of “The Messenger From the Spiritual World,” a messiah who embodied the best of Buddhism, Christianity and other religions.

headline: Preventing Factory Explosions by (Safely) Blowing Stuff Up
abstract: Jenny Chao, who tinkered in the garage as a child, is a mechanical engineer specializing in industrial explosions for a commercial property insurance company.
lead_paragraph: Jenny Chao, 40, is a senior lead research scientist at FM Global.

headline: Criticized by Candidates, Comey Has Tense Days Ahead After Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Despite the controversy that has entangled the F.B.I. in presidential politics, its director, James B. Comey, has no plans to leave office, colleagues say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, sometimes rattles off the exact amount of time left in his decade-long term as if he is eagerly watching the clock.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon bring us some mixed up clues, cryptically speaking.
lead_paragraph: There is usually more than one way to get to a cryptic crossword answer (I know this, because you’ve told me when I’m wrong even when I manage to wiggle my way to the right answer), although the recipe is always the same. There is a definition or synonym for the answer, some indication that you need to do something like anagram a part of the clue and then the part of the clue that needs to have something done to it. Your job, as the solver, is to figure out which part is which.

headline: After High-Profile Shootings, Blacks Seek Prosecutor Seats
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Elections, District Attorneys', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: Black lawyers, racial justice groups and liberal donors, led by the hedge fund billionaire George Soros, are combining forces to try to propel more African-American district attorneys into office.
lead_paragraph: African-American lawyers, racial justice groups and the liberal hedge fund billionaire George Soros are combining forces to try to elect more black prosecutors in response to what they see as an insufficient response by incumbent district attorneys to the killings of black people by the police.

headline: Cautious Optimism Over Efforts to Combat ISIS in Baghdad
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: A series of new security measures implemented after a car bombing killed more than 300 in July have been largely successful, though fears of attacks remain.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In July, the Islamic State carried out one of the deadliest car bombings in Iraq since the American invasion in 2003, killing more than 300 people in Baghdad.

headline: A Gmail Rival Sent to Siberia by a Mysterious Google Glitch
keywords: ['Search Engines', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Mail', 'Consumer Protection', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: For 10 months, until Google “fixed something,” ProtonMail was pushed deep into Google’s search results, a reminder of the conflict of interest at the company’s core.
lead_paragraph: Certain institutions in the world are so powerful and popular that we are just lucky that they are a force for good. Like Oprah. If she decided one day that she would like to try out villainy, we would all be in a lot of trouble.

headline: Tense Senate Tussle in New Hampshire Illustrates Murky Finish Line
abstract: A state that once seemed promising for Democrats in their bid to take back the Senate is now seeing a fight for every vote.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.H. — Maggie Hassan, the Democratic governor of New Hampshire now running for the Senate, squeezed by an older woman grimly examining some potatoes at a grocery store here last week. “I hope you’ll consider me,” Ms. Hassan said. The woman, still glowering, grumbled, “I might.”

headline: Hillary Clinton and the Return of the (Unbaked) Cookies
abstract: “I suppose I could have stayed home and baked cookies,” Mrs. Clinton once said, to her regret, as her husband ran for president. Now the line is back.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — With a single response in 1992 to a question about her legal career, Hillary Clinton became a radical feminist in her critics’ imagination, the Lady Macbeth who was an affront to the choices so many other women had made.

headline: Yoenis Cespedes Opts Out of Mets Deal, Ringing Opening Bell of Free Agency
abstract: Cespedes, who hit .280 with 31 homers last season, opted out of the last two years of his contract and may attract offers worth $100 million or more.
lead_paragraph: Eight hours after the final out of the World Series on Thursday, the first of many critical periods in the Major League Baseball off-season calendar began. Starting then, teams knew they had until Monday to extend a $17.2 million qualifying offer to any of their players eligible for free agency, who would then have a week to accept.

headline: Forget the Cost to the Candidates. This Campaign’s Cost America More.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Regardless of who wins the presidency, a brutal election battle has left the nation’s image tarnished, in the eyes of its own people and the world.
lead_paragraph: The world, too, is waiting anxiously for this election to be over:

headline: Arizona Can Ban ‘Ballot Harvesting,’ Supreme Court Says
abstract: Justices revived a state law that bans people from collecting other voters’ completed absentee ballots and submitting them to election officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court issued an order on Saturday allowing Arizona to enforce a law banning so-called ballot harvesting, in which others collect voters’ completed absentee ballots and submit them to election officials. The court’s two-sentence order stayed a ruling from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit that would have temporarily blocked the law.

headline: Fact-Checking Can Change Views? We Rate That as Mostly True
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: It does not appear we have entered a post-truth era, but partisanship still plays a big role in holding onto false beliefs.
lead_paragraph: A lot of time and effort has been spent correcting the falsehoods, lies, rumors and conspiracy theories promoted by politicians during this election — most notably by Donald J. Trump. Does it do any good? Or have we entered a “post-fact” age?

headline: Suspected Leader of Basque Separatist Group ETA Is Captured
abstract: Spain said it had been a year since Mikel Irastorza took over ETA, which has killed more than 800 people in a decades-long fight to establish an independent homeland.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The man believed to be the leader of the Basque separatist group ETA was arrested Saturday in southwestern France, in what the Spanish government described as “a hard blow” to the group’s ability to carry out attacks using the weaponry still in its hands.

headline: Facing Death, Brooklyn District Attorney Spoke of Doing What ‘Is Right’
keywords: ['District Attorneys', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: In his last interview, Ken Thompson, who died last month at 50, described his proudest accomplishments and a desire to reform “fundamentally unfair” aspects of the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: I asked Ken Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, for his thoughts about why there were so few elected black prosecutors across the country.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Women Are the Focus in Campaigns’ Last Advertising Push
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s team hammered away at Donald J. Trump’s character. The Trump campaign offered a portrait of him as a loving father.
lead_paragraph: The final week of the 2016 presidential race has seen a blitz of television ads in swing states, with more than $86 million in airtime reserved by the campaigns and their allies. Both campaigns are airing ads devoted to winning over women.

headline: The Curse Needs a New Home. Snow or Surf?
abstract: With the Cubs ending their 108-year title drought this past week, the Curse needs to reside somewhere else, and Buffalo and San Diego top the list.
lead_paragraph: The Curse is homeless, and it is hungry.

headline: ‘I’m With Her’: The Strengths of Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', "State Children's Health Insurance Program (S-CHIP)", 'United States International Relations']
abstract: There are many good reasons to vote for her, even if Donald Trump weren’t her opponent.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the great misperceptions of this political year, among many Democrats and Republicans alike, is that Hillary Clinton is a third-rate candidate with no core or convictions — oops, wrong word, but you get the point.

headline: Iran’s Latest Propaganda Tool: The Clinton-Trump Debates on Live TV
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'Debates (Political)']
abstract: “We only need to sit back and let these candidates show themselves how idiotic they are,” said Hamidreza Taraghi, a conservative analyst.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — In the past, Iranians looking to mock the United States would burn cardboard effigies of Uncle Sam or Lady Liberty. But in recent months, as the American presidential election took a series of bizarre turns, Iranians seeking to make fun of the “Great Satan” have ditched the arts and crafts and simply switched on their TV sets.

headline: The Election Choices
abstract: The 2016 candidates have left many readers disaffected. “I will show up at my polling place with a clothespin on my nose,” says one.
lead_paragraph: Readers reflect on their deliberations in a race that has left many unhappy with the options.

headline: Australia Doubles Down on Cruel Refugee Policy
abstract: A proposed lifetime ban on migrants who attempt to reach Australia by boat is absurd, shortsighted and cruel.
lead_paragraph: The government of Australia has come under withering criticism for its harsh anywhere-but-here approach to refugees and other migrants who attempt to reach the country by boat. But instead of revisiting a cruel and costly policy — which involves sending everyone intercepted at sea to offshore prisons — Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has decided to double down.

headline: The Post-Familial Election
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Families and Family Life', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: How the thinning out of families created fertile ground for Trump.
lead_paragraph: HOW did we get here? How did it come to this? Not just to the Donald Trump phenomenon, but to the whole choice facing us on Tuesday, in which a managerial liberalism and an authoritarian nationalism — two visions of the president as essentially a Great Protector: a feisty grandmother or fierce sky father — are contending for the votes of an ostensibly free people?

headline: Is There Life After Trump?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If the G.O.P. loses the presidential election, its reconstruction must begin Nov. 9. If it wins, we have to start over.
lead_paragraph: With only hours left before Election Day, here’s the painful, self-evident truth facing lifelong Republicans like me: The 2016 presidential campaign has revealed dark and disturbing things about not only Donald J. Trump but also the party that nominated him.

headline: Egypt Averts Economic Collapse, for Now
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Foreign Investments', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Black Markets', 'Editorials', 'Currency']
abstract: The recent moves are important, but will the country’s poor be able to hang on until changes are seen?
lead_paragraph: Egypt took an important step toward saving its economy from collapse when it decided on Thursday to allow its currency to float freely, thus paving the way for a $12 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund. Yet much more remains to be done to bring the country back from the edge of economic disaster, where it has teetered since the 2011 Arab uprising, which pretty much destroyed tourism and ushered in years of political instability.

headline: Imagining America on Nov. 9
abstract: Averting the worst effects of this year’s political storm means electing Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: The United States has seen worse than Donald Trump. It has endured political crises and corruption, war abroad and bloodshed at home. But that doesn’t make it any easier to contemplate the catastrophe that looms if we wake up Wednesday morning to President-elect Trump.

headline: Consider a Monarchy, America
keywords: ['Royal Families', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: There is a salve for broken politics, bitter voters and bad choices: royalty.
lead_paragraph: Southmoor, England — As a foreigner with dual British and Russian citizenship, it is not for me to comment at length on the merits of the rival candidates for the presidency of the United States. But it seems uncontroversial to say that neither appears to be a Washington or a Lincoln, and that the elective presidency is coming under increasingly critical examination.

headline: Time to Dump Time Zones
abstract: Designed for the railroad era, they have no place in our globalized, interconnected world.
lead_paragraph: We will awaken Sunday to yet another disturbance in the chronosphere — our twice-yearly jolt from resetting the clocks, mechanical and biological. Thanks to daylight saving time, we get a dose of jet lag without going anywhere.

headline: Why This Election Terrifies Me
abstract: The remote chance of a Donald Trump win is only one reason to tremble.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Tuesday nears, after such epic ugliness. “It’s almost over,” friends say. “We’ll finally be done with this.” What a lovely thought. What a naïve fantasy.

headline: The End Is Nigh
abstract: It has been a long, long, long year and a mad, mad, mad election. Time to vote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When historians write about this bizarre, ugly and dispiriting campaign — and oh, my, will they ever! — the epic dark saga will unfold this way: A man, filled with fear and insecurity, created a hatemongering character and followed it out the window. And a woman, filled with fear and insecurity, hunkered down and repeated bad patterns rather than reimagining herself in an open, bold way.

headline: The Men Feminists Left Behind
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s candidacy shows that women have changed. Men haven’t. What happens next?
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 8, Americans may elect our first female president. While many of us are exhilarated at the idea of this feminist victory, the toll we’ve paid for coming so close to that historic barrier has been the most graphically sexist election in living memory.

headline: A Muted Alarm Bell Over Russian Election Hacking
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'E-Mail', 'Newspapers', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: Why is an act of foreign interference in an American election on a scale we’ve never seen the also-ran of Times coverage?
lead_paragraph: LAST winter, as primary voters in Iowa and New Hampshire headed to the polls, a covert and cunning Russian plot was underway to disrupt the American political process. With aliases like Guccifer 2.0 and Fancy Bear, Russian hackers were targeting critical computer systems.

headline: Latina Hotel Workers Harness Force of Labor and of Politics in Las Vegas
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Casinos', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: The 57,000-member Culinary Union, which is 56 percent Latino and includes guest room attendants, is a powerful supporter of Nevada Democrats.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — She begins her day in black, the natural black before dawn and the requisite black of her uniform: the T-shirt, the pants, the socks, the shoes with slip-resistant treads, all black. The outfit announces deference.

headline: On Street Where U.S. Soldiers Died, Afghans Say: Taliban? What Taliban?
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: At least five dead coalition soldiers, 14 dead Taliban and 36 dead civilians after a battle near Kunduz — and then there are the unanswered questions.
lead_paragraph: BOZ QANDAHARI, Afghanistan — A day after a battle in this village on the outskirts of Kunduz, residents readily pointed out the smears of what they said was American blood on a packed-dirt street. But they were less forthcoming about whether there had been any Taliban in their neighborhood when the Americans were killed on Thursday.

headline: Beyoncé’s True Political Statement This Week? It Wasn’t at a Clinton Rally
abstract: The pop star’s appearance with the Dixie Chicks at the Country Music Association Awards was powerful — and sly.
lead_paragraph: I feel bad for anyone who still hasn’t learned to speak Beyoncé. Her language is the body. It’s stagecraft. It’s Instagram posts. She doesn’t speak; she signifies. And her performance on Friday at a Hillary Clinton rally in Cleveland won excitement and dismay over the possibility that she had reached some partisan peak by announcing that she was officially “with her.”

headline: Sergeant Who Was Killed in the Bronx Is Recalled as a Genial Family Man
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: Colleagues and neighbors of Sgt. Paul Tuozzolo, who was killed in a gunfight on Friday, expressed their condolences.
lead_paragraph: To those who knew him, Sgt. Paul Tuozzolo was one of the good guys.

headline: In the Cubs’ New Kingdom, Bliss and Wonder Reign at Every Level
abstract: Five central characters in the team’s title chase reflect on their experiences during the dramatic postseason.
lead_paragraph: About a month ago, when the Chicago Cubs had baseball’s best regular-season record but were still far better known for what they had not won, I spent a week embedded with five central characters in the team’s taut drama. It was a way of assessing the temperament and zeitgeist of the club, and by extension its national following.

headline: Thin Line Splits Donald Trump’s Politics and Businesses
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Would he be into this White House thing for the country’s benefit or his own? His business record reveals a willingness to change course to suit his needs.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump was building casinos in Atlantic City in the 1990s, he spoke of his dream of bringing jobs and development to the hard-luck community. In the end, after all the bankruptcies, layoffs and stiffed contractors, it was Mr. Trump who walked away with tens of millions of dollars in management fees and huge tax deductions that may have helped him avoid paying personal income taxes for nearly two decades.

headline: Three Political Movies to Stream This Weekend
abstract: If you’re looking for a classic biopic, a documentary or a foreign language drama, Monica Castillo has recommendations for this pre-Election Day weekend.
lead_paragraph: We’re finally in the homestretch of the 2016 presidential election. And while you’re waiting to vote on Nov. 8, here are a few political movies to pass the time. Or to soothe your anxiety, if that’s what you need.

headline: My Deathbed Playlist (and Yours)
abstract: The music that gave our lives meaning can bring comfort at the end.
lead_paragraph: Now that I’m approaching my mid-40s, I’ve finally gotten around to some basic end-of-life planning. Health care proxy? Check. Power of attorney? Signed. My playlist for dying? It’s done.

headline: In 1 Unscripted Moment, Hillary Clinton Finds Joy in the Rain
abstract: Days from the end of a grueling presidential contest, Mrs. Clinton relinquished her script at a Florida rally.

lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Voting With My Head and Heart
abstract: Thankfully, the election is imminent. I hope a Hillary Clinton presidency is too.
lead_paragraph: I have tried, for the duration of this election, to stay informed, without being obsessive. It hasn’t been easy. The media has been frenzied, at best, particularly as they cover Donald J. Trump. Early on, cable news networks aired entire Trump events before he was even his party’s nominee. They created an unhealthy demand for “news” that they were more than happy to supply. There is no escape.

headline: Our Reactionary Age
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Politicians worldwide have discovered that nostalgia can be a powerful motivator.
lead_paragraph: Hope, said the philosopher Francis Bacon, is a good breakfast, but an ill supper. Only a quarter-century ago, hope was an active force in world politics. The Cold War ended peacefully, and functioning constitutional democracies took root in Eastern Europe. The European Union was formally established, and membership was steadily extended eastward. The Oslo accords between Israel and the Palestinians were signed, and Nelson Mandela became president of South Africa after spending three decades in prison.

headline: The ICC, Out of Africa
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations']
abstract: Before African states began withdrawing from the court, the court was moving away from cases on the continent.
lead_paragraph: In just a few weeks, Burundi, South Africa and Gambia have announced that they would withdraw from the International Criminal Court, a permanent tribunal investigating war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity. Since its creation in 1998, the I.C.C. has been hobbled by the refusal of major countries like the United States, China and Russia to subject themselves to its jurisdiction. But the recent defections by member states, on grounds that the court is biased and undermines peace, seem like an unprecedented blow to its legitimacy.

headline: On Election Eve, a Brexistential Dread
keywords: ['Nausea', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Philosophy', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: On both sides of the Atlantic, we are feeling a nausea Sartre knew well.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — During these last days of the seemingly endless election campaign, we are all living with enormous and ever-rising levels of anxiety. The days pass in a fever of worry, with waves of nausea that subside only to return and rob us of our breath. Many people are having difficulty sleeping. Many others wake up in fright, their bodies drenched with the sweat of Trump terrors. What will America look like after Tuesday? What will the world look like?

headline: U.S.-Backed Militia Opens Drive on ISIS Capital in Syria
abstract: A Kurdish-Arab militia aims to isolate the city, Raqqa, and prepare for a final assault in the near future, an American military official confirmed.

headline: A One-Cent Soda Tax Gets Expensive in California
abstract: Spending on ballot initiatives in two counties has drawn more money than the Senate race and votes on marijuana and gun control — combined.
lead_paragraph: In this most contentious of elections, you wouldn’t think that a soda tax would be the issue to attract the big bucks. But measures in just two California cities have drawn more money than that state’s Senate race and statewide referendums on marijuana legalization and gun control — combined.

headline: How a Shop Owner in the Hamptons Knows Who Will Be President
abstract: In every presidential race since 2004, Valerie Smith has tracked the number of candidate cups sold at her store, the Monogram Shop. So far, she has correctly predicted every election.
lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Sometimes, Valerie Smith reminds herself that she is not a pollster, she is just selling cups — plastic drinking cups with the presidential candidates’ names. But she has been keeping track, just like a pollster, and hoping that her cup count is as reliable as it was in the last three presidential races.
