headline: Going the Distance Before They Reach the Starting Line
abstract: Entrants from Australia and other far-flung places endured long flights and jet lag on their way to the New York City Marathon.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Cooper, one of more than 50,000 runners in Sunday’s New York City Marathon, left his home in Perth, on the west coast of Australia, on Wednesday, he started the timer on his smartphone. He drove to the airport; flew 11 hours to Doha, Qatar; boarded an even longer flight to New York; and then rode several trains to reach the apartment he had rented on the Upper East Side.

headline: Who Wins if California Voters Tax E-Cigarettes?
abstract: Proposition 56 would tax e-cigarettes in the state for the first time, despite evidence suggesting e-cigarettes are less harmful and may help people quit smoking.
lead_paragraph: Wearing a white lab coat, the doctor looks straight at the camera and explains why Californians should vote against higher taxes on tobacco products.

headline: Simon Rattle: The Maestro With the Busy Baton
abstract: The conductor has, to no small extent, defined New York’s classical music scene, from “Tristan und Isolde” at the Met and his engagements at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: In an airy practice room atop Carnegie Hall recently, Simon Rattle, one of the most sought-after conductors in the world, was leading a rehearsal. It felt, at times, like a master class with a group of young musicians who were preparing an unusual take on a standard work: Hans Zender’s orchestration of Schubert’s song cycle “Winterreise.”

headline: Bonding Over Broken Wrists
abstract: Seated beside one another on a No. 1 train, a teenager and a much older man find they have something in common.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Mary Keitany of Kenya Wins 3rd Straight New York City Marathon
abstract: The 34-year-old ran away from the field before the midway point and was never challenged. Ghirmay Ghebreslassie, 20, won the men’s race, becoming the youngest winner ever.
lead_paragraph: Mary Keitany, a 34-year-old mother of two, went out for a run on Sunday morning. She started at the foot of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Staten Island and worked her way through the city.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 7
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Giants Become the Aggressors to Change Their Trajectory From Last Season
abstract: Quarterback Eli Manning threw four touchdown passes, and the Giants’ defense made a late stand to preserve a victory against Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Last season, the Giants not only were a bad team but also seemed hopelessly star-crossed, losing four close games in the final 75 seconds of play. But this season, the Giants, who reached the midpoint of their schedule Sunday, have already protected leads in the final minutes of four tense games, winning each by 5 points or fewer.

headline: Temple of the Dog Reunites, Headliners at Last on a Mini-Tour
abstract: Members of the former Seattle supergroup that began a quarter-century ago have reconnected and are on their first tour.
lead_paragraph: UPPER DARBY, Pa. — Last Thursday afternoon, at the Tower Theater outside Philadelphia, the five members of Temple of the Dog were onstage grappling with a common problem faced by men in their early 50s: trying to remember just how they did things in their 20s. The next night, the roughly 3,000-seat hall would be packed, the rock band’s first headlining concert appearance since, well, pretty much ever, but in rehearsal the band’s only audience was stagehands and lighting techs. After plowing through the crunching riffs of “Pushin Forward Back,” however, something didn’t sound quite right.

headline: Review: ‘Labyrinths,’ Emma and Carl Jung’s Complex Marriage
abstract: Catrine Clay’s book explores Carl Jung’s tortured soul, his wife’s challenging discoveries and their role in the early years of psychoanalysis.
lead_paragraph: Carl Jung called his separate selves “Personality No. 1” and “Personality No. 2.” No. 1 was a magnificent extrovert, performing his brilliance, steamrolling his colleagues, blowing away admirers with gusts of charm. No. 2, on the other hand, was a kettle of insecurities: introverted, anxious, tortured by voices and dark waking fantasies. At least once in his adult life, he seemed to suffer an episode of psychosis; as a young boy, images both psychedelic and profane would rudely obtrude on his thoughts, including a vision of God seated on a throne high above a cathedral and shattering its roof with a well-aimed bullet of ordure.

headline: Defensive Lapses Cost Knicks Against the Jazz
abstract: The Knicks continued to score at a sufficient pace, but Utah shot 50 percent from the field and took 35 free throws in rallying from a double-digit deficit.
lead_paragraph: Derrick Rose heaved his head up and rolled his eyes back, letting out a groan audible enough to demonstrate his disgust.

headline: Review: For This Young Chorus, It’s Never Too Early for Six World Premieres
abstract: The Young People’s Chorus of New York performed recently commissioned works on Friday at National Sawdust in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Even professional contemporary-music ensembles don’t often perform six world premieres on a single night. But on Friday at National Sawdust in Brooklyn, some 90 teenagers between the ages of 14 and 18 did just that. The excellent Young People’s Chorus of New York City presented the next installment of Transient Glory, its program that commissions composers to write challenging works for young voices.

headline: Review: An ‘Aida’ at the Met That May Not Be Zeffirelli’s, but It’s Big
abstract: Marco Armiliato conducted this production, which starred Liudmyla Monastyrska in the title role and managed to make the stage seem crowded.
lead_paragraph: To re-encounter “Aida” at the Metropolitan Opera in the 1988 production by Sonja Frisell is again to wonder what Franco Zeffirelli had proposed for his staging that made the Met shy away from the expense. For starters, perhaps, elephants as well as horses in this ancient Egyptian setting?

headline: Shadow Runners in the N.Y.C. Marathon
abstract: Join runners on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, near the start of the 40th New York City Marathon, which travels through all five boroughs of the city.
lead_paragraph: Join runners on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, near the start of the 40th New York City Marathon, which travels through all five boroughs of the city.

headline: Prayer Hands or Heart Eyes
abstract: Bruce Haight wears his professional hat today.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — The theme of today’s puzzle will come as no surprise to those of you who know what constructor Bruce Haight does for a living. As he says below in his notes, he’s an ophthalmologist, so he was born to make a puzzle like this one. Frankly, I’m surprised he didn’t submit it sooner.

headline: Ads Focus on Relief From the Presidential Campaign
abstract: Making light of the presidential race was easier in previous cycles, marketers said. This year? Ease the pain.
lead_paragraph: HEFTY is “trashing” the campaign, Excedrin is curing headaches caused by the caustic debates, and Ringling Brothers wants to remind the public that it is the real circus, despite what the last few months may have seemed like.

headline: To Create a Quieter City, They’re Recording the Sounds of New York
abstract: Researchers in a new project are installing microphones in the city to build an aural map and, perhaps, eventually reduce noise pollution.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, microphones mounted outside two buildings in Manhattan went live.

headline: Where Burning Effigies (Not Just Guy Fawkes’s) Is Part of the Fun
abstract: Bonfires, blazing crosses and firecrackers are all part of the celebration in an English town that takes a centuries-old tradition very seriously.
lead_paragraph: LEWES, England — Though it is never flattering to be burned in effigy, Donald J. Trump was in good company on Saturday when his image went up in flames not far from those of the British prime minister, Theresa May, and of a 17th-century pope.

headline: The Risk to Civil Liberties of Fighting Crime With Big Data
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Police', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Technology that allows the police to analyze and share data helps prevent crime. But those sophisticated tools may put civil liberties in danger, too.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — People talk about online security as a cat-and-mouse game of good guys and bad guys. It’s true for good old-fashioned crime, too.

headline: Bill Clinton Evokes Past, but From the Periphery of His Wife’s Campaign
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s aides, helped by data models and experience in the elections of 2008 and 2012, have long shifted their focus away from the “Bubba” voters.
lead_paragraph: PUEBLO, Colo. — After obliging a request for a selfie from a woman in the lobby, Bill Clinton left his hotel here on Friday and rode to his rally, where he made the case that Hillary Clinton cared more about restoring jobs to forgotten workers than Donald J. Trump did.

headline: Disappointed in Rio, Tatyana McFadden Returns to Form in New York City Marathon
abstract: McFadden won the women’s wheelchair race by almost two minutes for her fourth consecutive sweep of the world’s four major marathons.
lead_paragraph: As Tatyana McFadden churned the hand rings of her racing chair, she climbed the slope of the Queensboro Bridge. Head down, legs tucked underneath, her bent elbows jutted into the air like the hind legs of a grasshopper. It was Mile 16, one of the toughest climbs of the New York City Marathon, the critical spot where triceps scream and biceps throb.

headline: A Day of Finishes Both Dramatic and Determined
abstract: Mary Keitany of Kenya won her third straight New York City Marathon, and Tatyana McFadden became a five-time women’s wheelchair champion.
lead_paragraph: Mary Keitany of Kenya won her third straight New York City Marathon, and Tatyana McFadden became a five-time women’s wheelchair champion.

headline: When Gluttony Dons Racing Shoes
abstract: To conquer the world’s six major marathons, running’s extremists must balance their passion with everyday life.
lead_paragraph: Six of the world’s largest and most prestigious marathons — in Tokyo, Boston, London, Berlin, Chicago and New York City — band together and call themselves the World Marathon Majors. Some people try to run all six in the same year.

headline: In Boomers’ Sunset, Election Reawakens an Old Divide
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Baby Boomers', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This race has been a rematch between two boomer factions: one yearning for the return of an idealized postwar America, the other calling to tear down whatever societal barriers remain.
lead_paragraph: They came of age in the 1960s and ’70s, in the traumatic aftermath of the assassinations of John F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. They fought and protested a war together, argued over Nixon and Kissinger together, laughed at Archie Bunker together. As children, they practiced air-raid drills; as adults, they cheered the fall of the Berlin Wall.

headline: Europeans View Obama’s Exit With a Mix of Admiration and Regret
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: While the president remains popular, there is disappointment in his failures, coupled with criticism that his caution may have contributed to Europe’s problems now.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When a Democratic presidential candidate named Barack Obama stood at the Berlin Victory Column in 2008 espousing his vision of hope and change, he was surrounded by 200,000 exuberant Europeans, eager to give him a chance.

headline: Traders Hold Their Breath as the U.S. Chooses a President
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Steel and Iron']
abstract: Global markets are bracing as Americans head to the polls, while in Europe, HSBC and UniCredit prepare to share their third-quarter results with analysts.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at what’s coming this week:

headline: Wall Street Bonuses Are Expected to Sink for 3rd Straight Year
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Bonuses', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Merger and acquisition talks have been active, but the deals’ advisers get paid on completion. This year, antitrust officials thwarted some large mergers.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street bonuses are expected to decline for the third consecutive year, reflecting a period of busted mergers, limited trading activity and muted hedge fund returns.

headline: Media’s Next Challenge: Overcoming the Threat of Fake News
abstract: Plunging print ad sales and an explosion of online outlets spreading inaccurate information threaten to diminish, and in some cases extinguish, the impact of traditional media companies.
lead_paragraph: The last year has turned the United States into a country of information addicts who compulsively check the television, the smartphone and the good old-fashioned newspaper with a burning question: What fresh twist could our national election drama and its executive producer, Donald J. Trump, possibly have in store for us now?

headline: After Bill Cosby, States Shift on Statutes of Limitations in Sexual Assault Cases
abstract: The specter of accusations against Mr. Cosby has surfaced in many of the efforts to revise state laws.
lead_paragraph: Lise-Lotte Lublin started a petition and testified before lawmakers in Nevada last year, part of a successful effort to extend that state’s statute of limitations for sexual assault.

headline: How Moscow Uses Interpol to Pursue Its Enemies
abstract: The international police organization’s system of wanted notices has extended Russia’s reach. In one case, a Russian involved in anticorruption work was detained in Cyprus in connection with the supposed theft of a $1.55 drawing.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Facing trial in Russia over the theft of a street-art drawing valued by its creator at $1.55, Nikita Kulachenkov, a Russian forensic accountant involved in anticorruption work, fled to Lithuania to avoid what he decided was a doomed battle against trumped-up charges.

headline: How Comcast and NBCUniversal Used Minions to Fuse an Empire
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Supporters of the AT&T-Time Warner deal have pointed to the success of a similar one between Comcast and NBCUniversal, where both sides are thriving.
lead_paragraph: Minions, the impish fire hydrant-shaped yellow misfits who exist to serve the world’s most evil villains, would appear to be unlikely mascots for corporate synergy at Comcast, one of the world’s largest media conglomerates.

headline: Jean-Jacques Perrey, Electronic Music Pioneer, Dies at 87
abstract: He created some of the earliest electronic pop albums and was one of the first musicians to use the Moog synthesizer after it appeared in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Jacques Perrey, the electronic music pioneer whose jubilant compositions turned up in settings as disparate as Disneyland and “The Simpsons,” died on Friday in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 87.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Scramble to Make Their Final Pleas
abstract: Racing across the electoral map, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump begged voters to see Tuesday’s vote as a choice of almost apocalyptic significance.
lead_paragraph: They campaigned urgently, even frantically, at airfields and arenas, on a college campus in Wisconsin and in a Philadelphia church. Hillary Clinton and Senator Tim Kaine, their prospects brightened by news that the F.B.I. had found no new troublesome emails in a review of Mrs. Clinton’s private server, pleaded with Americans on Sunday to get out and vote as if their very way of life were on the line.

headline: Impact Top Red Bulls on Piatti’s Two Goals and Advance in M.L.S. Playoffs
abstract: Ignacio Piatti scored each of his goals in the second half, and Montreal moved on to the Eastern Conference finals after sweeping both legs of its series against the Red Bulls.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — Yet another promising autumn ended in familiar, exasperating fashion for the Red Bulls, who were knocked out of the M.L.S. Eastern Conference semifinals Sunday after a second successive defeat, 2-1, to a supposedly inferior opponent that had dropped its last seven matches at the stadium in Harrison.

headline: Under the Din of the Presidential Race Lies a Once and Future Threat: Cyberwarfare
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Voting Machines', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Mail', 'Elections']
abstract: A defining marker of the 2016 presidential race is that it is the first time a foreign power used cyberweapons to influence an election in the United States.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — The 2016 presidential race will be remembered for many ugly moments, but the most lasting historical marker may be one that neither voters nor American intelligence agencies saw coming: It is the first time that a foreign power has unleashed cyberweapons to disrupt, or perhaps influence, a United States election.

headline: Gunman Who Killed Police Sergeant Had History of Desperation and Defiance
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Friends and family members of Manuel Rosales, who was killed in a shootout with officers last week, spoke of his many personal struggles.
lead_paragraph: The red Jeep wedged between a parked truck and a patrol car, the bloodied body hanging out the window and the evidence markers scattered across the sidewalk — they all told of a fleeing ex-convict trapped on a dead-end street, and a heavy firefight that followed, leaving a New York City police sergeant and his assailant, Manuel Rosales, dead.

headline: Listening to This New Podcast Could Save Your Life on Election Day
abstract: A new podcast from The New York Times and Stephen J. Dubner, the host of “Freakonomics Radio,” turns the idea of a quiz show inside out. In our first episode: the hidden dangers of going to the polls.
lead_paragraph: People on both sides of the aisle are concerned that this election might pose an existential threat to society. But did you know there’s one particularly dangerous time of day to vote? It has nothing to do with voter intimidation — but everything to do with how you get to the polls. Hear about the hazards of Election Day — and other types of “Strange Danger” — on the debut episode of Tell Me Something I Don’t Know with its host, Stephen J. Dubner.

headline: Beyond White House Race, Host of Issues on the Ballot
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Referendums']
abstract: As the 2016 campaign rumbles into its final hours, there are other things going on around the country on Election Day almost as important as the White House race.
lead_paragraph: Forget the fight for the White House, if just for a moment. As the 2016 campaign rumbles into its final hours, there are other things going on around the country on Election Day that are just as important and engaging. Well, almost.

headline: Jewish Voters, Prized in Swing State Florida, Tell What Drives Them
abstract: Israel, Iran and anti-Semitism play a part in decisions at the polls, but so do Hillary Clinton’s experience and Donald J. Trump’s charisma.
lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — Some pro-Clinton videos circulating in this part of South Florida do not feature Barack Obama, Bernie Sanders or Elizabeth Warren. Instead, the praise comes from Shimon Peres, Henry Kissinger and the son of Yitzhak Rabin.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, November 7, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Based on our review, we have not changed our conclusion that we expressed in July with respect to Secretary Clinton.”

headline: Fear of Donald Trump Helps Democrats Mobilize Hispanics
abstract: Angry at Mr. Trump and energized by Democratic outreach efforts, Latinos are turning out in droves, and could be the difference in the outcome in highly contested states.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump maligned undocumented immigrants as murderers and rapists. Hillary Clinton hired a woman who had lived undocumented for many years as her national director of Latino outreach.

headline: The Dangers in Every 911 Call for Police Officers
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Officer Henry Walburger was fatally shot in Manhattan in July 1964 after responding to a burglary call, a reminder then and now that not every officer killing has a reason or motive.
lead_paragraph: The call came in at 6:40 a.m., a burglary in progress in the Village. Two police officers, with 80 minutes left on their midnight tour, responded to the address on East 12th Street in Manhattan.

headline: Donald Trump’s Extremist Supporters Feel Like Winners Either Way
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Even if Mr. Trump loses, his candidacy has emboldened groups whose views have long been thought to be well outside the political mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, Jim Gilchrist was waging a lonely battle.

headline: The Drama Down the Ballot: 2016’s Other Wild Races
abstract: Outlandish politics are not limited to the top of the ticket. Consider these contentious, crazy — if somewhat less consequential — campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Campaign 2016 is nearly over, to the relief of many Americans exhausted by the contentious, crazy and very consequential race between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump. But the year of outlandish politics is not limited to the top of the ticket. Consider these contentious, crazy and somewhat less consequential races.

headline: John D. Roberts Dies at 98; He Revolutionized the Field of Organic Chemistry
abstract: He popularized nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, a tool used to understand chemical structures, and was a leader in understanding how organic reactions occurred.
lead_paragraph: John D. Roberts, an organic chemist who pioneered the use of nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and other techniques to reveal the structures of molecules and the dance of atoms as they rearrange in chemical reactions, died on Oct. 29 at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 98.

headline: Review: ‘Homos, or Everyone in America,’ Urban Gay Life in Bittersweet Focus
abstract: Jordan Seavey’s play follows a couple who comes together, breaks apart and just about everything in between.
lead_paragraph: A couple comes together, breaks apart and just about everything in between in “Homos, or Everyone in America,” a daringly frank, funny and affecting new play by Jordan Seavey that’s really — despite the second part of the title — about urban gay life in America, its complexities, its pleasures and, sadly, its dangers. How it applies to “everyone” else isn’t altogether clear.

headline: Review: ‘Finian’s Rainbow’ and the Perils of a Pot of Gold
abstract: Melissa Errico stars in an adaptation of this midcentury musical that includes elements of thievery, racism and whimsy.
lead_paragraph: Though Og the leprechaun doesn’t look a day over 25, no one in the audience at the Irish Repertory Theater gasps when he confesses he’s 459 years old. But there might be some murmurs of incredulity should the sweet colleen he’s been duetting with step forward to declare she’s a 46-year-old mother of three who first played this part on this stage in 2004.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Season 1, Episode 6: The Tipping Point
abstract: The world as Maeve understood it is gone, as the show again forces viewers to reflect on how their own lives are constructed, too.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the bleakest in a catalog loaded with bleak albums, Radiohead’s “Kid A” closes with “Motion Picture Soundtrack,” a song that obliquely suggests the end of a relationship but is, more broadly, about disillusionment and death. “It’s not like the movies,” singer Thom Yorke laments. “They fed us on little white lies.”

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 7, Episode 3: The Ballad of Daryl and Dwight
abstract: Sunday’s episode introduced viewers to life in the Sanctuary, the Savior stronghold.
lead_paragraph: “I must break you.”

headline: On the Trail: Sunday, Nov. 6
abstract: Hillary Clinton, Donald J. Trump, Senator Tim Kaine and Gov. Mike Pence held rallies during the final stretch of the campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton, Donald J. Trump, Senator Tim Kaine and Gov. Mike Pence held rallies during the final stretch of the campaigns.

headline: ‘Tragic and Savage’ Stabbings Leave Newark Residents Outraged
abstract: The authorities said a person of interest in the weekend attack that left three people dead and three others injured had been taken into custody.
lead_paragraph: Even for a city wrestling with a stubbornly high murder rate, a grisly stabbing at a home in Newark, where a knife-wielding attacker killed two children and a woman in a rampage on Saturday afternoon, was almost too much to bear.

headline: Hong Kong Elected 2 Separatists. China Took Drastic Action.
abstract: By acting against two dissident lawmakers, Beijing is asserting an authority to set policy in the territory, challenging its semiautonomous status.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In the nearly two decades since Hong Kong returned to Chinese rule, the Communist government in Beijing has tolerated all manner of activity in the city that it generally finds intolerable on the mainland: annual vigils for those killed in the Tiananmen Square massacre, newspapers publishing scurrilous gossip about China’s leaders, huge demonstrations for free elections.

headline: Support, and Dismay, for Brooklyn Assemblywoman After Charges She Hit Her Son
abstract: Diana C. Richardson, who is running for re-election this week, was arrested on Saturday and is facing several charges after her son, 13, told the police she hit him with a broom handle.
lead_paragraph: The arrest of a state assemblywoman from Brooklyn who is charged with hitting her 13-year-old son with a broom handle has sent ripples of support and dismay through New York City’s political circles.

headline: ‘Super PACs’ Spend Freely as Control of New York Senate Hangs in Balance
abstract: About a dozen groups have reported spending about $14 million in Senate races since the September primaries, all for a chamber in which Republicans hold power by a single seat.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The 39th Senate District in New York, a puzzle piece made up of three suburban Hudson Valley counties, hardly seems a place to attract much attention, let alone be a magnet for lavish campaign spending.

headline: ‘Insecure’ Season 1, Episode 5: Making the Cut
abstract: What happens when your dreams come true?
lead_paragraph: Fantasies are great precisely because they aren’t real. It’s fun to imagine finding a partner as eager for commitment as you are. And it’s fun to picture how different life would be if you were bold enough to go after that ex. But our fantasies don’t often take into account the ripple effects. This week’s episode of “Insecure” explores some uncomfortable territory about how the dreams we cling to can reveal troubling truths about ourselves.

headline: Toronto’s Onslaught of Goals Finishes N.Y.C.F.C.’s Season
abstract: Toronto earned a 7-0 win on aggregate in the home-and-home series and will face Montreal for a spot in the M.L.S. Cup final.
lead_paragraph: When Major League Soccer announced the three finalists for most valuable player last week, Sebastian Giovinco, who won the award last year, was absent despite his 17 goals and 15 assists — the league’s highest combined total.

headline: Khizr Khan Revs Up Rally Before Introducing Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a call and response with voters, Mr. Khan, the father of a soldier killed in Iraq, portrayed a dark vision of the country if Donald J. Trump were to win the election.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — In a call and response with voters here on Sunday night, Khizr Khan, the father of a soldier killed in Iraq, portrayed a dark vision of the country if Donald J. Trump were to win Tuesday’s presidential election.

headline: For Renewable Energy, Brexit Spurs Mixed Prospects
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Energy and Power', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: The vote to leave the European Union raises complex issues about costs and profitability, but analysts and executives see reasons for optimism.
lead_paragraph: When Mark Meyrick sat down with a developer to review plans for two solar farms the company he works for is building in Wales and southwestern England, one number jumped out at him. With the value of the pound sliding since Britons voted to leave the European Union, the cost of the imported solar panels Good Energy must buy has risen.

headline: Power Couple: Tie-Up Shows How Batteries and Solar May Link
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Batteries', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Sunlight']
abstract: The planned Tesla-SolarCity merger may produce a process to improve solar output, meet renewable goals and sell new system services.
lead_paragraph: The solar panels — 15,000 of them — sweep down the hill from a former dairy farm here, gleaming rows of silver and blue nestled between fields of recently harvested corn. The installation, a project developed in partnership with SolarCity, the leading rooftop solar provider in the United States, and the local electric cooperative, is meant to help create more green energy options for customers, mainly a handful of utilities operating in the state.

headline: Oil Industry’s New Threat? The Global Growth of Electric Cars
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobile Service and Charging Stations', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Global Warming', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: Aided by tax breaks, Norwegians have embraced the vehicles, and experts say the rest of the world may not be far behind.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — “The Scream” was screaming, as usual, from the wall of the Edvard Munch museum one recent day. Out in the parking lot, Pal Valsgard wore a milder expression— a trace of impatience — as he gazed at his electric car.

headline: Donald Trump, ‘Brexit,’ Hillary Clinton: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: He’s 106. And Knows the Score.
abstract: John Risher has been recording statistics as a volunteer at Virginia’s home football games since 1963, and he shows no signs of stopping anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — John Risher drove north on Route 29, a briefcase resting in the car’s back seat.

headline: No Corrections: November 7, 2016
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, November 7, 2016.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Martha & Snoop’s Potluck Dinner Party’ and ‘The 2016 S.N.L. Election Special’
abstract: Need a laugh? Dine with Martha Stewart and Snoop Dogg, bar hop with the Vanderpump brigade or watch “S.N.L.” spoof an election like no other.
lead_paragraph: Need a laugh as Election Day looms? Dine with Martha Stewart and Snoop Dogg, bar hop with the Vanderpump brigade or watch “S.N.L.” spoof a presidential campaign like no other.

headline: Photographing the Impact of California’s Water Crisis
abstract: Mustafah Abdulaziz photographed in California for the latest installment of his “Water” series, which explores various human interactions with the environment.

abstract: A reader offers some simple advice.

The soldiers who stormed the Dhaka residence of the president, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, who was also my grandfather, shot and killed him, along with 18 other members of my family. They included my grandmother, three of my uncles (one of whom was only 10 years old) and my pregnant aunt.

abstract: The core issue in the Dakota Access Pipeline fight is Sioux rights, not oil.

The current pipeline path is being bitterly, and appropriately, opposed by the Standing Rock Sioux and a growing array of allies for threatening sacred sites and the environment in lands and waters that were never ceded under treaties.

Below are five ways the candidate and the Republican Party are working to suppress voting this year, drawn from recent editorials:

headline: What Really Makes Us Vote? It May Be Our Parents
abstract: Research indicates that lifelong voting habits are formed in childhood and adolescence.

But there’s some evidence to indicate that voting habits are just that, habits, shaped in part by the practices and routines of our parents when we’re still too young to vote.

headline: Hand-Harvested Salt for the Thanksgiving Host
abstract: Sal del Mar’s 16-ounce bags of salt are packed in hand-stitched cloth bags.
lead_paragraph: You have a gazillion choices when it comes to sea salt, but the salt that’s hand-harvested from natural ponds in Sonora, at the edge of the Sea of Cortez in Mexico, has a soft texture that sets it apart. It’s on the coarse side, rustic, with a slightly bitter finish and is fairly moist. It comes in homespun bags that are hand-embroidered with mermaids, seashells and other motifs by women in a Sonoran village, work that permits these craftswomen to earn money yet stay at home with their children. Consider a modest sprinkling of this salt on your pumpkin pie (especially if store-bought). The bags make a lovely gift for a host: Sal del Mar, $14 to $15 for a 16-ounce cloth bag, saldelmar.com.

headline: Grandma, Grandson ... Colleagues
abstract: Cocktails, the evening news and dinner with the host, Alexander Heffner, and the executive producer, Elaine Heffner, of “The Open Mind” on PBS.
lead_paragraph: If you have not, over the course of the last six decades, tuned in to various public television stations to watch “The Open Mind,” here’s what you have missed: a 30-minute public-affairs-focused interview program that covers topics ranging from civil rights to pornography to baseball, and features guests running the gamut from blues musicians to judges to Nobel laureates.

headline: Skip Credit Cards and Preload Monthly Payments Instead
abstract: Before your next big purchase, use the preload method by setting up a savings account and automatically transferring the monthly payment to it.
lead_paragraph: Let’s play a little game. Assume there is something you want to buy, and you will pay for it with a monthly payment plan. It could be a house, a car, tuition or something as simple as a new smartphone.

headline: Suggest a To-Do List for the Next President
abstract: What should the next president focus on in the first 100 days in office? We invite your thoughts.
lead_paragraph: The election is finally here, and regardless of who the next president is, he or she will face major national and international problems. We invite you to list three things the new president should do in the first 100 days in office.

headline: Larry Ellison’s Hardball Tactics Win NetSuite for Oracle
abstract: Fear that Oracle would back away led NetSuite shareholders to accept a $9.3 billion offer over the objections of a major investor, T. Rowe Price.
lead_paragraph: Larry Ellison, Oracle’s founder, has stored some hardball merger and acquisition tactics in the cloud. He has won his $9.3 billion battle for NetSuite, even though T. Rowe Price, NetSuite’s biggest independent investor, made a strong case for a higher offer.

headline: Earthquake and Aftershock: The Elections of 2008 and 2016
abstract: If 2008 was an emblem of progress as America elected its first black president, 2016 has required the grim acceptance of limits, disappointments and blind spots.
lead_paragraph: It was nearly eight years ago, somehow.

headline: Jeezy Winds Up on Top in Three-Way Battle for Billboard No. 1
abstract: The rapper’s “Trap or Die 3” defeated Kenny Chesney’s “Cosmic Hallelujah” and Meek Mill’s “DC4” on the chart with a combination of sales and streams.
lead_paragraph: Three new albums vied for No. 1 on the latest Billboard chart, and the contest this week shows how complex the charts have become as the music industry juggles the multiple ways people consume their music.

headline: U.S. Enforcing Insurance Law to Help Fight Opioid Abuse
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs']
abstract: The move, intended to help fight opioid addiction, forces insurers to provide coverage for drug treatment that is comparable to that for any other medical condition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one of President Obama’s last major health care initiatives, the administration is stepping up enforcement of laws that require equal insurance coverage for mental and physical illnesses, a move officials say will help combat an opioid overdose epidemic.

headline: Mannequin Challenge Is the New Viral Video Sensation You Probably Can’t Avoid
abstract: People are freezing themselves in place, often in elaborate poses and scenarios. It has become popular with teenagers and victorious football teams.
lead_paragraph: Remember the Ice Bucket Challenge? Or the Harlem Shake? Planking? Lip Dubs?

headline: On the Trail: The Final Day of Campaigning
abstract: Candidates on the major-party tickets spent Monday visiting important states to try to put votes in their columns on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Candidates on the major-party tickets spent Monday visiting important states to try to put votes in their columns on Election Day.

headline: N.B.A. Schedule: Here’s What to Watch This Week
abstract: The Clippers meet the Thunder in Oklahoma City on Friday, and six N.B.A. games are scheduled for election night on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: After two weeks and some change, we’re into the meat of the N.B.A. season and starting to see some results.

headline: Janet Reno, Former U.S. Attorney General, Dies
abstract: Janet Reno, the first woman to serve as United States attorney general, died on Monday at 78. She died of complications from Parkinson’s disease, according to her family.
lead_paragraph: Janet Reno, the first woman to serve as United States attorney general, died on Monday at 78. She died of complications from Parkinson’s disease, according to her family.

headline: After Dinosaur Extinction, Some Insects Recovered More Quickly
keywords: ['Research', 'Paleontology', 'Insects', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Endangered and Extinct Species']
abstract: Researchers studied fossilized leaves from the Patagonia region to conclude it took about 4 million years for insects to recover following the Chicxulub asteroid.
lead_paragraph: The asteroid that smashed into the Earth near Chicxulub, Mexico, some 66 million years ago annihilated the dinosaurs and obliterated about 75 percent of all plant and animal species on Earth. The devastation affected insects living thousands of miles north and south of the impact zone as well.

headline: Determining a Punishment That Fits the Crime
abstract: It can be difficult for a judge to decide an appropriate sentence in cases in which the defendant shows remorse and the financial harm is difficult to measure.
lead_paragraph: One of the vexing issues in white-collar crime is figuring out the appropriate sentence for someone who usually has an otherwise spotless record and poses no physical threat to the community. Recent cases show how hard it is to determine a just punishment for defendants who have so much going for them yet engaged in criminal conduct.

headline: What Ivanka Trump Can’t Sell
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Dresses', 'Sexual Harassment', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: She has remained loyal to her father. Will that cost her?
lead_paragraph: Ivanka Trump can do it all. Throughout this interminable campaign, she has been able, with very little backlash, to promote for her $100 million apparel brand, which she markets with the female empowerment hashtag #womenwhowork, and also support her father, whose campaign is rife with misogynistic language, and who has been accused of sexual harassment by more than a dozen women.

headline: Why Facebook Showed You That Ad for the Candidate You Hate
abstract: The reason you saw a particular campaign ad on Facebook may have nothing to do with your political views, or even your demographic profile.
lead_paragraph: You may be a reliable Democratic voter in a solid-blue city. Maybe you have a graduate degree; maybe you’re a member of an ethnic or religious minority; maybe you are a woman.

headline: Woman Thrown in Front of Train at Times Square Subway Station Is Killed
keywords: ['Subways', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A woman was taken into custody in connection with the attack, which an initial investigation by the police suggests was unprovoked.
lead_paragraph: A 49-year-old Queens woman was killed after being pushed in front of a subway train in Times Square on Monday, the New York Police Department said. The attack disrupted traffic at one of the city’s busiest transit hubs as trains were diverted and emergency workers converged on the scene.

headline: Debating the Dakota Access Pipeline
abstract: Readers discuss the pros and cons of the project.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Our Best Digital Storytelling of the 2016 Election
abstract: Graphics, videos, podcasts and other digital features from The Times have offered an innovative look at the presidential race. Here are some of the most notable ones.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has presented some of the most innovative digital storytelling of the 2016 presidential election. Here’s a look back at some of our most notable projects.

headline: Affecting Drawings by LGBTQ Prisoners
abstract: To create the group show “On the Inside,” Tatiana von Fürstenberg worked with the prison-reform activist newsletter Black and Pink to solicit artwork.
lead_paragraph: To create the group show “On the Inside,” Tatiana von Fürstenberg worked with the prison-reform activist newsletter Black and Pink to solicit artwork.

headline: What the Election Means for the Markets
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: In the short term, markets seem to expect less volatility from a Clinton presidency. But things get more complicated in the long term.
lead_paragraph: What will happen to financial markets after the election? More so than usual, we have a decent idea.

headline: A Moving, Diverse Show of Drawings by Incarcerated LGBTQ Artists
abstract: “On the Inside,” curated by Tatiana von Fürstenberg, was a labor of love intended to empower one of society’s most marginalized communities.
lead_paragraph: “I made a pledge to do an act of love every day for 30 days between Martin Luther King Day and Valentine’s Day of 2012. It was a simple online pledge — it had to be an act of love not for friends and family,” explains the filmmaker and musician Tatiana von Fürstenberg. It was this promise that ultimately led her to create an arts initiative empowering LGBTQ prisoners — people who, as von Fürstenberg notes, “discovered art on their own and have been making art, sometimes before they were incarcerated and sometimes after they were incarcerated.” “On the Inside,” the first group show of prisoner work she’s curated through the initiative by prisoners around the country, is on view now at Abrons Arts Center.

headline: A Letter from the Harvard Women’s Soccer Team
keywords: ['Athletics and Sports', 'Men and Boys', 'Soccer', 'Women and Girls', 'Youth']
abstract: Members of the soccer team respond to a lewd “scouting report.”
lead_paragraph: You may have heard that Harvard cancelled the rest of its men’s soccer season after reports that male players had discussed female players in crude sexual terms. Six members of one Harvard women’s soccer team wrote this brilliant op-ed for The Harvard Crimson, and I’m republishing it here with permission. I admired the op-ed for its cogency and eloquence, but also because I thought it might be effective in changing mores. —Nicholas Kristof

headline: Voting Guide: How, When and Where to Vote
keywords: ['States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Where do you vote? What happens when you get there? Here’s what you should know on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: [Here’s how to vote in the 2020 election.]

headline: Covering Elections: ‘Hours of Boredom, Minutes of Terror’
abstract: A former longtime political reporter for The Times reflects on Election Days past.
lead_paragraph: The plight of a political journalist on Election Day is akin to that of a pilot or a police officer: hours of boredom, minutes of terror. For most of the day, there is nothing to do. The only thing that matters is how you perform in a few frantic post-midnight moments, often with your bosses literally looking over your shoulder in a packed newsroom as you type.

headline: This Time, There Really Is a Hispanic Voter Surge
abstract: Early voting data unequivocally indicates that Hillary Clinton will benefit from Hispanic turnout that is vastly exceeding numbers from four years ago.
lead_paragraph: Hispanic voters were largely credited with President Obama’s victory in 2012, but they weren’t  as crucial  as many believed. Mr. Obama didn’t even need to win the Hispanic vote to put him over the top, thanks to high black turnout and support among white voters in the North. The turnout among Hispanic voters didn’t surge, even though exit polls implied that it had.

headline: Are There Really Hidden Trump Voters?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: A special survey suggests there are more Trump supporters than other polls indicate. But they also seem unlikely to actually vote.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton is favored to become the next president of the United States. Yet many in Donald J. Trump’s camp remain undaunted, arguing that hidden supporters will carry him to the White House. As the polls have narrowed in the last few days, the question of whether pollsters could be missing Trump voters has become paramount. Do these unseen supporters exist?

headline: Zadie Smith’s ‘Swing Time’ Explores Friends’ Diverging Paths
abstract: Ms. Smith takes on a familiar theme: how family and politics affect identity. But her portrait of a famous singer and would-be humanitarian is clumsy and tedious.
lead_paragraph: Doubles — pairs of friends, rivals and families; contrasting ideologies and views of the world — animate Zadie Smith’s novels, as surely as doubles and doppelgängers haunt many Hitchcock movies. Her astonishing debut novel, “White Teeth” (2000), recounted the story of two World War II vets — polar opposites and best friends — and their extended families, opening out into a teeming, Bruegel-esque portrait of a multicultural London. “On Beauty” (2005), another magical big-city novel (set mainly in Boston), also depicted two very different families with intertwined lives. And the disappointing “NW” (2012) used the diverging stories of two childhood friends to look at the potent and ever shifting dynamics of money and class.

headline: Trump Campaigns in North Carolina
abstract: Donald J. Trump is holding a campaign rally in Raleigh the day before Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is holding a campaign rally in Raleigh the day before Election Day.

headline: Captain Licorish, Agent Pickles, Swamp Justice: Highlights from the Bridgegate Trial
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: Kate Zernike, a Times reporter who covered the Bridgegate trial, takes a spirited look back at the courtroom characters and antics.
lead_paragraph: Start with a premise that should have seemed absurd: political operatives shut down access lanes to the world’s busiest bridge to punish a Democratic mayor who did not endorse a Republican governor who wanted to be leader of the free world. It was bound to be a colorful story — and trial — even without the New Jersey swamp setting and larger-than-life central figure, Gov. Chris Christie.

headline: Theresa May, Daniel Ortega, China: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Justices Won’t Revive Order Barring Voter Intimidation in Ohio
abstract: The Supreme Court turned away a bid to reinstate a trial judge’s order that barred Donald J. Trump’s campaign from harassing or intimidating voters in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday refused to intercede in a lawsuit brought by the Ohio Democratic Party against Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign. The justices turned away a last-minute bid from the party to reinstate a sweeping order from a trial judge that had barred the Trump campaign from harassing or intimidating voters in Ohio.

headline: Did the F.B.I. Play the Email Controversy Right?
abstract: Readers take sides about the director’s actions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: China, Meet Hockey. Russia, Meet a Huge Untapped Market.
abstract: Kunlun Red Star, a new franchise in the Russian-based K.H.L., has faced challenges but been competitive as it tries to develop the sport in China.
lead_paragraph: After 678 games with six N.H.L. teams, Alexei Ponikarovsky thought he had seen everything by the time he played three seasons with SKA St. Petersburg of the Kontinental Hockey League.

headline: Hopes for U.K. Trade Deal With India Hit a Snag: Immigration
keywords: ['Visas', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Foreign Workers']
abstract: Prime Minister Theresa May has received a rocky reception on a visit to India that was billed as a test of Britain’s ability to prosper outside the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was supposed to be an auspicious moment: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain traveling to India to prepare the ground for what could be the country’s first trade deal after it leaves the European Union, and show that Britain can thrive outside the bloc.

headline: Splayed Turkey With Herbs
abstract: This cooking technique yields perfectly cooked Thanksgiving turkey.
lead_paragraph: This cooking technique yields perfectly cooked Thanksgiving turkey.

headline: A New (Faster, Juicier) Way to Roast a Turkey
abstract: To get the dark and white meat to both cook perfectly, pick up your paring knife and splay the legs.
lead_paragraph: There’s an age-old problem with roasting a whole turkey. How do you cook the dark meat to juicy tenderness without desiccating the white meat?

headline: While Pregnant, Women Should Get Health Care 8 Times, W.H.O. Says
abstract: Women should see a doctor, nurse or local health worker at least eight times during each pregnancy, doubling the previous guideline for visits.
lead_paragraph: Women should see a doctor, nurse or trained midwife at least eight times during each pregnancy, with five of those visits in the last trimester, the World Health Organization said Monday as it issued 49 recommendations to prevent deaths in childbirth.

headline: Tatiana von Furstenberg Curates an Exhibit of Art From Inside Prisons
keywords: ['Art', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: The daughter of the designer Diane von Furstenberg has many interests, but her desire to tell stories is the common thread.
lead_paragraph: Dressed in loosefitting pants, a military jacket and black-and-cream heels, her hair curly and buoyant, Tatiana von Furstenberg walked languidly through an exhibition at Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side on a sunny November afternoon.

headline: ‘Fired Up’ Obama Makes Final Push for Clinton, and His Legacy
abstract: His travels to three crucial states were part victory lap and part nostalgia tour. But his core mission was to rally voters behind Hillary Clinton — or see his agenda defeated.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — President Obama was feeling a little sentimental.

headline: Traveling While Muslim Complicates Air Travel
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Airport Security', 'Racial Profiling', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Sikhs and Sikhism', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Muslim fliers, particularly women who cover their hair, are often subjected to extra screening, which requires more time to navigate security.
lead_paragraph: Passing through airport screening can be time-consuming for any business traveler. But Nafees Syed, a lawyer and writer in New York, has additional obstacles.

headline: Review: Capturing Childhood’s Wonder in Dance and Mime
abstract: “Chotto Desh,” at the New Victory Theater, is a time capsule by Akram Khan, and it starts with the voice of a 12-year-old Bangladeshi boy on a help line.
lead_paragraph: In Bengali, “chotto” means “small.” And so “Chotto Desh,” the title of the Akram Khan work at the New Victory Theater, means “small homeland” but also signifies a smaller version of this celebrated British choreographer’s 2011 solo “Desh.” It’s smaller in the sense that it’s an adaptation for children, but that doesn’t mean it’s inferior. If anything, this adaptation is an improvement.

headline: Donald and the Dead
abstract: For all its outrage and rancor, Trump’s campaign has, from the beginning, been mostly about grieving.
lead_paragraph: At recent rallies, Donald Trump’s warm-up playlist, the one the candidate famously insists on choosing himself, has featured “Funeral for a Friend/Love Lies Bleeding,” the opening medley from Elton John’s 1973 album “Goodbye Yellow Brick Road.” Like a lot of the playlist, it’s an endearingly perverse song for a political event, opening with a somber minor-key dirge performed on a chorus of analog synthesizers. The track played at least a couple of times at the Giant Center arena in Hershey, Pa., on Friday night, as we waited for Trump to arrive, and whenever the dolorous synths cut through the fried-dough-scented air, I felt as if I were at some hybrid of a monster-truck rally and a requiem Mass.

headline: Election Day Weather Not Expected to Hurt Voter Turnout
keywords: ['Weather', 'States (US)', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: There will be cold spots and scattered showers but not enough to affect voter participation, forecasters say.
lead_paragraph: If any events are likely to affect voter turnout on Election Day, the weather won’t be one of them. Cold and rain are predicted in some key states on Tuesday, but nationwide the weather is expected to be mild enough to have little impact, forecasters say.

headline: The Lighthouses of Ireland
abstract: Lighthouses in Ireland are finding new life not just for their beautiful vistas but for stories from people who illuminate pieces of modern history.
lead_paragraph: Lighthouses in Ireland are finding new life not just for their beautiful vistas but for stories from people who illuminate pieces of modern history.

headline: Washington Faces Breakdowns and Paralysis, and That’s Just the Metro
abstract: Chronic delays and major overcrowding have led commuters to flee the subway in droves, clogging roads and leading people to ride-sharing services.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Usually when people talk of dysfunction and gridlock in Washington, they mean the relationship between the White House and Congress.

abstract: This evening, you can watch Martha Stewart and Snoop Dogg host a dinner party and the season premiere of ‘Vanderpump Rules.’
lead_paragraph: ‘Martha and Snoop’s Potluck Dinner Party,’ 10 p.m., VH1 (New Series)

headline: What Time Will the Polls Close? (And When Will We Know Who Won?)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: An hour-by-hour look at when states finish voting.
lead_paragraph: An hour-by-hour look at when states finish voting.

headline: Optimism From Hillary Clinton and Darkness From Donald Trump at Campaign’s End
abstract: The candidates and their surrogates hopscotched across the United States in the final, frenzied hours of the campaign, with the nation reduced to a string of must-win states.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump hopscotched from Pennsylvania to North Carolina to Michigan on Monday in the final, frenzied hours of the presidential campaign, offering clashing closing arguments as the sprawling map of the United States was reduced to a string of must-win states.

headline: The Supreme Court Ruled That Voting Restrictions Were a Bygone Problem. Early Voting Results Suggest Otherwise.
abstract: Reports from North Carolina and elsewhere suggest a constitutional right still in need of protection.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow, and the early voting leading up to it, mark the first presidential election since the Supreme Court clipped the protective wings of the Voting Rights Act. In 2013, speaking for a conservative majority of five, Chief Justice John Roberts effectively eliminated the safeguards created by a provision of the law called Section 5, saying that Congress could no longer require states and counties with a history of racial discrimination to get the approval of the Department of Justice before changing local voting rules and practices. Roberts said things had “changed dramatically” since the 1960s, and these jurisdictions, which are mostly in the South, didn’t need oversight from the D.O.J. anymore. They could be trusted to treat minority voters fairly on their own.

headline: So Close and Yet So Far Away: On the Trail With Michelle Obama
abstract: A White House correspondent’s valiant attempts to get inside the first lady’s bubble.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Julie Hirschfeld Davis, a Times White House correspondent, shares what counts as “major access” in the tightly controlled world of this beloved first lady.

headline: Changing Time at The Times
abstract: Kenneth R. Rosen explains whose job it is to keep the clocks in the Times newsroom current, even when we switch to daylight saving time.
lead_paragraph: Since arriving here nearly three years ago, I’ve been turning over in my mind a line from Gay Talese’s book about The Times, “The Kingdom and The Power.”

headline: The Triumph of Tracy Flick?
abstract: Americans may finally be ready to pick the smartest girl in the room.
lead_paragraph: You go, Tracy Flick.

headline: Ezekiel’s Wheel Ties African Spiritual Traditions to Christianity
keywords: ['Slavery (Historical)', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Symbols', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Archaeologists in Maryland have discovered artifacts linking African practices and Christianity on the land of a former slave plantation in Maryland.
lead_paragraph: African-Americans have long been among the country’s most fervent Christians, from the choir to the pulpit to the affirming voices from every “amen corner.”

headline: For Shirley Collins, a Folk Revival of Her Very Own
abstract: After decades of silence following her prominence in the 1960s and ’70s, the traditional British folk singer yields to pleas and records a new album, “Lodestar.”
lead_paragraph: Fans of traditional British folk music used to find Shirley Collins’s voice angelic. “Now, the word they use is austere,” Ms. Collins said with a laugh. “It’s not a bad word, but it’s not the voice I used to have in those days when I could just sing by opening my mouth.”

headline: Robert Durst Pleads Not Guilty to 2000 Murder in Los Angeles
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Mr. Durst is accused of having shot his friend Susan Berman in order to stop her from revealing what she knew about his first wife’s disappearance, in 1982.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Robert A. Durst, the multimillionaire whose bizarre life of privilege and mayhem was the subject of a 2015 documentary, was arraigned here on Monday on charges of murdering a onetime confidante 16 years ago.

headline: America on Election Day, and Beyond
abstract: Will the divisiveness of the campaign persist? Will supporters of the loser accept the winner’s “mandate”?
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Look at Gray Matters’s First Collections
abstract: The independent designer Silvia Avanzi, whose shoes launched in stores last month, uses the same Italian factories as big fashion brands.
lead_paragraph: The independent designer Silvia Avanzi, whose shoes launched in stores last month, uses the same Italian factories as big fashion brands.

headline: Brand to Know: Simple Architectural Heels, Made in Italy
abstract: The designer Silvia Avanzi launched Gray Matters with the help of a company that counts Dior and Fendi as clients.
lead_paragraph: Before putting pencil to paper — and nappa-leather uppers to outsoles — the designer Silvia Avanzi spent two years developing and fine-tuning the concept behind her shoe line. “I asked myself, ‘What do women want today, and what do we need, really?’ We feel everything has been done and redone,” she recalls, “and I’m not the type of person who simply wants women to spend money. I want her to be happy with her purchases.” Using “a marketing-trained brain,” the fashion branding and advertising vet noticed a gap: avant-garde heels. From there, Gray Matters — her line of sleek glove shoes, mules and flatforms that launched in stores last month — began to take shape.

headline: Review: Makeup Tips Galore, but Not How to Handle Cancer, in ‘Ultimate Beauty Bible’
abstract: The characters in Caroline V. McGraw’s play run up against a problem that makeup can’t fix.
lead_paragraph: Caroline V. McGraw’s wry and artful “Ultimate Beauty Bible,” produced by Page 73 at the New Ohio Theater, is a play for anybody who has ever believed that the right lipstick, the right shoes, the right lover might meaningfully alter the course of one’s existence. Which is a lot of us.

headline: Review: ‘Lost Voices’ Confronts the Rising Tide of Climate Change
abstract: In this program of two one-act plays at Here, the company Eagle Project examines how natural disasters take their greatest toll on minority residents.
lead_paragraph: Water is rising all around them, and it’s past time to flee. Two cousins are marooned on the rapidly diminishing patch of land where their families have lived for generations. They have no boat. They don’t even know how to swim.

headline: Funny and Eerie Vintage Images of Women Handling Snakes
abstract: In the artist Clare Strand’s new book, archive images meet computer-generated poetry.
lead_paragraph: Despite a longstanding fear of snakes, for many years the British artist Clare Strand sought out images of women with serpents. “People usually collect what they like, not what repels them,” she admits, but she felt somehow compelled.

headline: ‘Girl Plays With Snake’
abstract: The artist Clare Strand’s new book comprises images of women with serpents found over a number of years, many from the archives of British tabloid newspapers.
lead_paragraph: The artist Clare Strand’s new book comprises images of women with serpents found over a number of years, many from the archives of British tabloid newspapers.

headline: How the Artist Adrian Ghenie Became an Auction Star
abstract: Bidding wars have broken out over the work of this Romanian painter, who has benefited from demand, limited output and a pool of eager buyers.
lead_paragraph: Many say it was the 2011 exhibition at the Palazzo Grassi museum in Venice that first ignited art buyers’ interest in a young Romanian artist named Adrian Ghenie, whose heavy palette-knife paintings are haunted by historical figures like Stalin, Hitler and the Nazi doctor Josef Mengele.

headline: Sailing Couple Seized by Somali Pirates in 2008 Are Apparently Abducted Off Philippines
keywords: ['Sailboats and Sailing', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Piracy at Sea']
abstract: The German couple, who were held by Somali pirates in 2008, were said to have been abducted by Abu Sayyaf, an insurgent group.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A ship in harbor is safe, but that is not what ships are built for, the old maritime saying goes. A German sailing couple, seized and held for ransom eight years ago by Somali pirates, apparently lived by that rule.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

lead_paragraph: A new book features a collection of homes from around the world — from the Slovenian Alps to Montauk — all built with nature in mind.

headline: If Janet Reno Had Lived to See Tomorrow
abstract: The pioneering victory of her appointment to attorney general is about to be writ large.
lead_paragraph: I got my first “big” story as a cub reporter at The Miami Herald in 1983, thanks to Janet Reno. Or rather, thanks to her family’s peacocks.

headline: Smog Chokes Delhi, Leaving Residents ‘Cowering by Our Air Purifiers’
abstract: Levels of the most dangerous particles soared over the weekend in some places to more than 16 times the limit India’s government considers safe.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — For days, many in Delhi have been living as if under siege, trying to keep the dirty air away from their children and older parents.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Environmentalists Target Bankers Behind Pipeline
keywords: ['Pipelines', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Native Americans']
abstract: Environmental groups urged the banks to halt loan payments to the Dakota Access pipeline, which they say threatens Native American lands and has no place in a world fighting climate change.
lead_paragraph: In early August, just as protesters from across the country descended on North Dakota to rally against an oil pipeline near the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation, some of the world’s biggest banks signed off on a $2.5 billion loan to help complete the sprawling project.

headline: Saving Refugees on the Mediterranean: a Luxury Yacht With a New Purpose
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Drownings', 'Boats and Boating', 'Rescues']
abstract: Since it started its mission last May, the Astral has helped rescue about 15,000 refugees trying to reach Europe by boat, mostly from Libya.

headline: Janet Reno Refused to Let Parkinson’s Define Her
abstract: The former attorney general first received the diagnosis in 1995, but “never wanted to talk about that,” said Donna E. Shalala, who served in the Clinton administration with Ms. Reno.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Janet Reno sat in a wheelchair with a blanket over her knees, her fingers curled inward so she could not shake hands. She was skinny — very skinny — almost unrecognizable as the prosecutor who had shot to fame as President Bill Clinton’s attorney general, the first woman to hold that position.

headline: Cyprus: Why One of the World’s Most Intractable Conflicts Continues
abstract: The island nation has been divided since 1974 in a complex dispute. Leaders of both sides began five days of talks on Monday to resolve it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is home to one of the longest-serving peacekeeping missions in United Nations history. It has been called a diplomatic graveyard, having frustrated generations of negotiators. It has been compared — in complexity and duration, not bloodshed — to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

abstract: Out of 650,000 emails found last month, only a small portion were potentially related to Hillary Clinton, and many of those were duplicates of messages already examined.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Out of hundreds of thousands of emails seized last month from disgraced former Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a substantial number turned out to be copies of documents already reviewed by F.B.I. agents and analysts, allowing the agency to wrap up in days a review that some had feared would take weeks, if not longer.

headline: Grandmother’s Killing Lays Bare a Dilemma in Child Welfare Work
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Heroin', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: Carmen Irizarry, 60, was killed by her drug-addicted partner in the Bronx, but her 9-year-old granddaughter, Heaven, escaped, avoiding the grim tally of children killed by the people closest to them.
lead_paragraph: The girl named Heaven lay curled up asleep next to her grandmother on the mattress they shared on the living room floor. The woman, Carmen Irizarry, had been the 9-year-old’s legal guardian for years, a stand-in for the girl’s troubled mother. Now, Heaven’s protector was sick, breathing from an oxygen tank after a long hospital stay for acute lung disease. It was early in the morning of May 11, quiet in the half-light in the eighth-floor apartment in the South Bronx.

headline: Click, Run, Click Again

headline: The Marijuana Election
abstract: On Tuesday, voters in nine states will have the chance to loosen restrictions on pot.
lead_paragraph: I must be the most maladapted pothead in Maine. Since 2013, I have had a Maine medical marijuana authorization card, for treating painful nerve damage in my elbows and hands. The thing is, though, I don’t actually like being high; it makes me feel a little sad, a little disengaged. I like everything about marijuana, you could say, except the being stoned part. Fortunately for me, the cannabis crème I use on my joints doesn’t mess with my head.

headline: Ralph Cicerone, Scientist Who Sounded Climate Change Alarm, Dies at 73

lead_paragraph: Ralph J. Cicerone, who as a researcher and the president of the National Academy of Sciences issued an early warning about the grave potential risks of climate change, died on Saturday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 73.

headline: Fear Is Driving Voting Rights Advocates and Vigilantes to Watch Polling Stations
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Election officials and observers say they are hoping for an orderly final day of voting as these groups plan to deploy at polling places nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans will cast their ballots on Tuesday under intense scrutiny both from vigilantes who fear the election will be rigged and from thousands of voting rights advocates who fear the tally will be distorted by intimidation and, perhaps, the suppression of a minority vote that may be crucial to the outcome.

headline: If Trump Wins Florida, It’s Because of These People
abstract: Among the faithful the day before the election.
lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — People started lining up at 4 a.m. to catch one last glimpse of their hero. It was Donald J. Trump’s first campaign stop on his Monday push through battleground states, and his supporters here in Florida seemed to understand that the whole country would be watching them. So, what are the Trump voters in Florida thinking, and where does this movement — or whatever we should call it — go after Tuesday?

headline: Spread of Early Voting Is Forging New Habits and Campaign Tactics
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Absentee Voting', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: A record number of Americans have already voted in the presidential election, reshaping how campaigns are waged and how voters see the race in its final days.
lead_paragraph: In 1977, a flood control measure on the ballot in Monterey, Calif., became what historians say was the first modern American election decided by people who voted before Election Day.

headline: Chief of New York’s Struggling Public Hospital System Is Resigning
abstract: The departure of Dr. Ramanathan Raju comes several months after the mayor announced a plan to overhaul the system, which is facing a large financial shortfall.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of NYC Health & Hospitals, which runs New York City’s public hospitals, is stepping down from his post atop the nation’s largest municipal health care system, a move that City Hall officials described on Monday as voluntary and expected.

lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — A federal jury on Monday ordered Rolling Stone and one of its writers to pay $3 million in damages to a University of Virginia administrator over a discredited article two years ago about a supposed gang rape at the university.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, November 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Whatever credibility I’ve earned after eight years as president, I am asking you to trust me on this one.”

headline: Review: ‘“Master Harold” … and the Boys,’ a Searing Indictment of Racism
abstract: Athol Fugard has directed his own masterwork at the Signature Theater, which returns to the stage at a time when it feels painfully pertinent.
lead_paragraph: There is good reason that “‘Master Harold’ … and the Boys” ranks among the South African writer Athol Fugard’s most celebrated and popular plays. As the sterling new production that opened on Monday at the Signature Theater attests, this quiet drama remains a powerful indictment of the apartheid system and the terrible human cost of the racism it codified and legalized. At a time when systemic racism and its roots are once again a subject of national discussion in America, it feels particularly, and sorrowfully, pertinent.

headline: South Korea Charges 21 With Match Fixing

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The South Korean police said Monday that they were pressing criminal charges against 21 people, including two professional baseball pitchers in the KBO League, on suspicion of match fixing.

keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Some citizens have needed judges’ help just to cast ballots.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — The casting of a ballot is the most fundamentally American act that any of us takes. It connects us to the Enlightenment ideals of the country’s founding — the once-radical notion that human beings should think for themselves, rather than merely obey kings and priests. “Dare to know!” Immanuel Kant wrote, offering a motto for the Enlightenment. “Have the courage to use your own understanding!”

headline: Up in the Sky, Help to Keep Africans From Starving
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Livestock', 'Drought', 'Satellites', 'Shariah (Islamic Law)', 'Nomadic People', 'Poverty', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Satellite images help insurers predict when drought is likely to kill cattle, so they can aid herders whose own lives depend on their livestock.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Mude, a Kenyan economist, has a way of explaining satellites. When he’s talking to pastoralists in his country’s north — people who roam the earth with a dozen head of cattle and very little else — he talks about the stars that don’t act like other stars. “They’re actually taking pictures of the ground,” Mude says. Herders, a stargazing people, understand.

headline: What Does Life With Quadruplets Look Like?
abstract: A student photojournalist started out documenting the lives of a couple who gave birth to quadruplets. She now plans to stay with the story until they turn 18.
lead_paragraph: Courtney Larson really wanted to have children. But after marrying her college sweetheart, Cameron Larson, in 2009, she learned she had fertility issues. The Larsons, who are Mormon, prayed, but, unable to get pregnant after a year, they turned to medical treatments, including intrauterine insemination. After several attempts — and thousands of dollars — she became pregnant.

headline: Choking in New Delhi

lead_paragraph: It is no longer safe to breathe in New Delhi, one of the most polluted cities in the world. The problem has grown steadily worse, but little has been done beyond stopgap measures like allowing cars with odd- or even-numbered license plates to be used only on alternate days.
