lead_paragraph: Have you read any books so gripping you couldn’t put them down? Books that made you laugh, cry or even sweat as you read? Books that changed the way you think or see the world?

headline: Presidential Election Live: Donald Trump’s Victory
abstract: The 2016 campaign has been about changing demographics and shifting party coalitions as much as the two main candidates.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s victory in the presidential race on Tuesday night capped a remarkable election in which several Democratic Senate candidates fell short and Republicans retained their majority in the House of Representatives. Here are some key takeaways from a stunning result that upended conventional expectations and set the stage for a drastic reordering of politics in Washington:

headline: Plan to Rein In New York’s Street Fairs Prompts Unexpected Backlash
abstract: Amid criticism, officials have shelved new rules that would limit the number of fairs, spread them into more areas of the city and require a greater diversity of offerings.
lead_paragraph: They hold the promise of vibrancy, the allure of a city thoroughfare repurposed with the tent-lined look of a traveling circus. But the street fairs that can sometimes clog the corridors of Manhattan are also the bane of many, from drivers caught in the resulting snarl to those grown weary of the fairs’ banal ubiquity.

headline: In Remote Settlement High on Tibetan Plateau, Buddhist Spirituality Soars
abstract: Crowded into ramshackle homes on a remote peninsula at the bend of a river is one of the largest communities of nuns in the world.
lead_paragraph: YARCHEN GAR, China — Even by the standards of the phenomenal sights of Tibet, Yarchen Gar is a wonder on the high plateau: thousands of ramshackle homes clustered on a remote peninsula at the bend of a river, each one the domicile of a nun who has come here to study Tibetan Buddhism.

headline: My Journey Into Aleppo: Watching a Moonscape of War Turn Into a Functioning City
abstract: Video and photos taken by a Times reporter, Anne Barnard, show both scenes of destruction and a seemingly normal city: people just continuing on with their daily lives.
lead_paragraph: I took this video while on what often felt like a surreal bus ride through war-torn Syria. The video begins on the edge of the city of Aleppo, its western, government-held half. The area we drove through is all government held but has been intensely fought over, again and again, and has changed hands several times. The route we took connects the city to a key supply route — whoever controls the road determines if the eastern, rebel-held part of the city is besieged or not.

headline: What Russia After Putin?
abstract: A recent conference of Russian exiles was perhaps a preview of what Russia will look like when it decides what to be next.
lead_paragraph: Vilnius, Lithuania — If only because nothing lasts forever, because no one lives forever, the Putin era in Russia will eventually end. President Vladimir V. Putin is 64 years old, and those who oppose his regime are focusing their attention on imagining what will happen after him — especially since his government’s ongoing crackdown makes it so difficult to focus on the present.

headline: Student Winners From Our 2016 Editorial Cartoon Contest
abstract: Teenagers used humor, wit and irony in their cartoons to comment on Donald Trump, Syria, dress codes and more.
lead_paragraph: We invited students 13 to 19 years old to submit their original illustrations to our second annual Editorial Cartoon Contest, and they responded by using humor, wit and irony to comment on the issues they care about: the 2016 presidential campaign, Syria, dress codes, gentrification, gender equality and more.

headline: Keeping the Fire of Irish Lighthouses Alive
keywords: ['Lighthouses and Lightships', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The golden age of lighthouse construction is long gone, but in its wake are beautiful vistas and stories that bring modern Irish history to life.
lead_paragraph: To get to the Clare Island Lighthouse in County Mayo, in the west of Ireland, you climb up to the island’s northern cliffs along a road of stones, past damp sheep chewing grass, around the bend through an alley of fuchsia hedges in bloom. Keep walking until you reach the lighthouse and slip your key in the lock, hang your parka by the door and take a seat beside the peat-burning fireplace. Someone may be nearby to take your drink order, and the reward for a long walk will be a cold gin and tonic and the soft heat of the fire.

headline: Philippines Can Give Hero’s Burial to Ferdinand Marcos, High Court Rules
abstract: The decision clears the way to bury the dictator in a heroes’ cemetery. Rights groups saw it as part of an effort to whitewash an ugly period of history.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippines’ highest court ruled on Tuesday that the dictator Ferdinand E. Marcos may be granted a hero’s burial, resolving a divisive issue in a country where passions over his brutal 20-year rule still run high.

lead_paragraph: In a breezy neighborhood west of downtown Vancouver, there’s a tree-lined stretch of Denman Street where you’ll find what amounts to a global buffet: Korean, Chinese, Vietnamese, Middle Eastern, Spanish, African fusion, Italian, Mexican, Pacific Northwest (lest we forget where we are) — the list of cuisines served in this profusion of mostly small and unassuming restaurants is long.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — And so the politicization of dress continues. Now it is the poppy — the sartorial commemoration of soldiers who lost their lives in wartime that Britons wear in the days before Remembrance Day, Nov. 11 — that has generated controversy.

headline: A Fat Dad Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 1972', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Weight', 'Voting and Voters', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: We walked to a McGovern rally, not even stopping for my dad’s favorite soft pretzel or the warm chestnuts that usually called his name from blocks away.
lead_paragraph: It was 1972, and George McGovern was running against Richard Nixon for president.

headline: On Election Day, Little Chance of Changing That Early Vote
abstract: With the exceptions of absentee voters in New York, Pennsylvania and Mississippi, people who have already voted cannot still change their minds.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you didn’t gather enough information in the first year and a half of the campaign. Perhaps you thought you had made up your mind and cast your ballot early, only to have a last-minute change of heart.

headline: 1966: Ten Dancers in Cuban Ballet Defect in Paris
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Ten ballet dancers from the Cuban National Ballet, including one of its stars, Eduardo Recal, defect and ask for political asylum in France while touring in Paris in November 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Ten dancers skipped away from the Cuban National Ballet this weekend and asked for political asylum in France because of “the arbitrary persecution which has developed in our country.” It was the largest group of artists to defect here in recent years. It was also an embarrassing blow to the Havana government, which had given the successful company a proud sendoff when it left to open in the prestigious Fourth International Dance Festival last Wednesday.

headline: After These Days of Rage
abstract: Extremes of inequality lie at the root of voters’ anger. We can’t repair the political center without fixing the economics of that.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Whatever the result of the United States election, politics has been “changed, changed utterly,” to use the words of the poet W. B. Yeats on Ireland after the 1916 Easter Rising. And not just in America. Across the Western world, there is a rising anger at “the system.”

headline: How We’re Watching Election Day
abstract: How the end of a long campaign looks to Times Opinion writers across the country
lead_paragraph: How the end of a long campaign looks to Times Opinion writers across the country

headline: Four Prominent Suffragist Grave Sites in the Bronx Anticipating a Surge in Visitors This Election Day
abstract: At Woodlawn Cemetery, the grave sites of four prominent suffragists are waiting for some “I Voted” stickers.
lead_paragraph: Susan B. Anthony’s grave site, in Rochester, is a perennial destination for women celebrating their freedom to vote, but on Election Day, Woodlawn Cemetery in the Bronx would like to remind New Yorkers to share the love.

headline: California Today: What to Watch For on Election Day
abstract: Tuesday: Races on the ballot to watch, Robert A. Durst makes a long-awaited appearance in a Los Angeles court, and one of the deep-down reasons we vote.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Why Long Voting Lines Could Have Long-Term Consequences
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Shortages', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Minorities', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Early voters, urban voters and minority voters are all more likely to wait and wait. And that makes them less likely to vote in the future.
lead_paragraph: In Charlotte, N.C., the lines for the first wave of early balloting last month forced some voters to wait more than two hours. In Las Vegas last weekend, voters were still waiting outside a polling place in a Mexican grocery store two hours after it was set to close. In New York City on Election Day, voters who spilled out of polling sites snaked through schoolyards and around entire city blocks.

headline: Prince Harry Denounces Media Coverage of His Girlfriend, Meghan Markle
abstract: Queen Elizabeth’s grandson attacked the “racial undertones” in newspaper and social media reports of his relationship with Ms. Markle, an American actress.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince Harry on Tuesday attacked the “racial undertones” of British news coverage and social media harassment of his new girlfriend, the American actress Meghan Markle.

headline: Clinton vs. Trump: Voters Have Their Say on Election Day
abstract: Voters across the United States reflect on their decisions.
lead_paragraph: In Harmony Township, Pa., west of Pittsburgh, early voters were rewarded with cinnamon rolls from Oram’s bakery, on sale to raise money for the volunteer fire department. Culinary Union members in Las Vegas knocked on doors to get out the vote. And in Exeter, N.H., voters arrived early at their polling place to avoid lines — only to find that scores of others had the same idea.

headline: What’s the Top Issue Driving Your Vote Today?
abstract: What’s driving you to the polls today? We may feature your response on our home page or on social media.
lead_paragraph: Today is Election Day in the United States. Whether you cast your vote today or earlier in this election season, we’d like to know: What issue is driving your vote, and why? Please tell us in the comments. Your response may be featured on the nytimes.com home page or on our social media channels, including Twitter and Facebook.

headline: The Hoaxes, Fake News and Misinformation We Saw on Election Day
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Don’t be confused by false fliers, online pranks or websites that exist to deceive voters.
lead_paragraph: Fake stories and memes that crop up during live news events have been a problem on social media for years, but a wild election season has highlighted the news media’s slow response to them.

headline: On the Trail: Monday, Nov. 7
abstract: Candidates on the major-party tickets spent Monday visiting important states to try to put votes in their columns on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: Candidates on the major-party tickets spent Monday visiting important states to try to put votes in their columns on Election Day.

headline: Share Your Ballot Selfie
abstract: Ballot selfies are legal in 18 states and the District of Columbia.
lead_paragraph: Did you take a ballot selfie? In 18 states and the District of Columbia, ballot selfies are legal. If you live in the nation’s capital or one of those states, share your ballot selfie using the hashtag #NYTballotselfie on Twitter, Instagram or Facebook. Also mention the state you voted in, and we may use it in a follow-up post.

headline: Casting Ballots
abstract: People arrived at polling stations nationwide on Tuesday to vote on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: People arrived at polling stations nationwide on Tuesday to vote on Election Day.

headline: After the Election, a Nation Tinged With Racial Hostility

headline: Hungary’s Lawmakers Reject Plan to Block Resettlement of Refugees
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Constitutional Amendments', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Prime Minister Viktor Orban had proposed a constitutional amendment to stop a European Union program that would see the country accept migrants from the Middle East and Africa.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Lawmakers in Hungary on Tuesday rejected a proposed national ban on refugees relocated from the rest of the European Union, dealing a rare defeat to Prime Minister Viktor Orban.

headline: How I’ll Watch Election Night

abstract: All night, I’ll be looking for (and worried about) signs that the polls are wrong.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

abstract: Before you take a selfie of your ballot (or of yourself) at the polls, refer to this updated map of ballot selfie laws by state.
lead_paragraph: If you’re tempted to take a selfie at the polls on Election Day, you may find yourself on the wrong side of the law.

abstract: At watch parties around the country, supporters kept their eyes on the results.
lead_paragraph: At watch parties around the country, supporters kept their eyes on the results.

abstract: In a plan reminiscent of a famed 1962 escape, the men had arranged pillows under sheets to fool the guards, British news outlets reported.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was a flourish worthy of the 1962 escape from Alcatraz.

headline: Nick Cave’s “Anthrocene”

lead_paragraph: A line from “Anthrocene,” a new song by the Australian songwriter Nick Cave.

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When Bill Clinton introduced “the finest surrogate, supporter any candidate for president ever had,” everyone on Philadelphia’s Independence Mall knew the person he was talking about.

abstract: Neighbors and supporters swarmed around Mrs. Clinton and former President Bill Clinton to catch a glimpse of her filling out her ballot.
lead_paragraph: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. — On a bright Election Day morning, Hillary Clinton cast a vote for herself for president, the final step of a turbulent 19-month campaign.

headline: Stephen Curry’s 13 3-Pointers: Shot for Shot
abstract: After a recent 0-for-10 night on 3-point attempts, Curry made 13 of them in a 116-106 victory over the Pelicans on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: Night after night, in good games and bad games, in wins and losses, Stephen Curry made 3s.

headline: Election Night at The New York Times

lead_paragraph: Twelve Times journalists relay their most memorable anecdotes from election nights past.

headline: Did Democrats Regain Control of the Senate? No. Here Are 10 Races We Watched.
abstract: Republicans and Democrats battled fiercely for control of the Senate. Here are 10 pivotal races we watched.
lead_paragraph: Republicans and Democrats battled fiercely for control of the Senate. Here are 10 pivotal races we watched. Update: Republicans kept control.

headline: Can The Times Relax Its Style and Still Be The New York Times?
abstract: Exactly what is fit to print? The standards editor, Phil Corbett, talks about language, the election and changing Times style. Susan Lehman is host.
lead_paragraph: Exactly what is fit to print? The standards editor, Phil Corbett, talks about language, the election and changing Times style. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: The Appeal of Sporty, Lightweight Anoraks
abstract: Featherweight jackets bring a youthfulness to long skirts and studious turtlenecks.
lead_paragraph: Featherweight jackets bring a youthfulness to long skirts and studious turtlenecks.

headline: An ‘I Voted’ Sticker Can Get You Free Stuff, but It Shouldn’t
abstract: In a federal election, voters are not allowed to receive anything of value. But companies are rarely penalized for Election Day freebies.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is upon us, and that means (among other things) that the American voter is entitled to a bunch of free stuff: doughnuts, pizza, cheese dip, you name it. It is all provided by businesses looking to get a bit of publicity by encouraging everyone to fulfill their civic duty.

headline: Can The Times Relax Its Style and Still Be The New York Times?
abstract: Exactly what is fit to print? The standards editor, Phil Corbett, talks about language, the election and changing Times style.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump uses vulgar words to describe women; does The Times repeat the vulgarity in its report? In headlines? What about racial slurs? Does The Times reprint hate speech when it arises during a political campaign?

headline: The Voting Booth Calls. Some, It Calls Early.
abstract: It's Election Day. We dispatched photographers throughout the country to meet the early birds among us— the first people in line— and asked them what brought them to the polls.
lead_paragraph: It’s finally here: Election Day. People across the country are turning out to vote on Tuesday morning. We dispatched photographers throughout the country to meet the early birds among us — the first people in line — and asked what brought them to the polls.

headline: A Love Letter to Drinking in Bars
abstract: From dingy dives to Old World establishments, watering holes are one writer’s paradise.
lead_paragraph: From dingy dives to Old World establishments, watering holes are one writer’s paradise.

headline: The Meaning of Selena
abstract: How the Latina icon became a makeup phenomenon, more than 20 years after her murder.
lead_paragraph: One morning last month, Maria Herrera, a 28-year-old makeup artist, got in line outside the MAC store in downtown Chicago. It was 1:30. There were already 18 people ahead of her waiting to buy a limited-edition makeup collection inspired by the Mexican-American singer Selena Quintanilla Pérez. By 9:30, their numbers had grown by dozens.

headline: Long Avoided by Tourists, Iran Is Suddenly a Hot Destination
abstract: With the nuclear deal and a more welcoming attitude, the country is attracting flocks of visitors, particularly from Europe, and even from the U.S.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — For all of Iran’s attractions — breathtaking scenery and numerous World Heritage sites, among other things — there are plenty of downsides to vacationing in the Islamic republic. Alcohol is forbidden. There is very little night life, at least in public. All women, including visiting foreigners, are obliged to wear a head scarf.

headline: Splayed Turkey, Step by Step
abstract: Three simple steps to splaying a turkey for faster and more even roasting.
lead_paragraph: Three simple steps to splaying a turkey for faster and more even roasting.

headline: An Anthropocene Journey
abstract: Humans have become a planet-scale disruptive force. What next?
lead_paragraph: If you need a diversion as the extraordinary election aftermath plays out in the United States, here’s one option.

headline: An Apron Made for Women by Women
abstract: Money raised from Tilit’s latest chefs’ apron will benefit a grant fund for women’s culinary education.
lead_paragraph: Do you care whether your apron is flattering? The new wrap apron certainly is. Designed by Jenny Goodman, a founder of Tilit, a company on the Lower East Side that specializes in chef’s gear, this apron is made from soft gray recycled hemp and cotton. It has an adjustable halter strap and a waistline tie that slips through one side to create the wrap effect. Ten dollars from the sale of every gray apron is being donated to the Bad Bitches Grant Fund in Charleston, S.C., for women’s culinary education. The company also makes good-looking aprons for men: Wrap Apron, $75, tilitnyc.com.

headline: Donald Trump, Amid Cheers and Jeers, Casts His Vote
abstract: Mr. Trump voted at a school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, joined by his wife, Melania, and daughter Ivanka.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump cast his ballot at Manhattan’s Public School 59, a school just blocks from his home and office at Trump Tower, on Tuesday.

headline: Make Your Phone Easier to Read
abstract: If you find yourself squinting to read mail and web pages on your smartphone, you can bump up the font size to give your eyes a break.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is it possible to make the text on my smartphone bigger so that I can read emails more easily?

headline: Toblerone Alters Shape of 2 Chocolate Bars, and Fans Are Outraged
abstract: The maker of the Swiss chocolate has shrunk and reconfigured two milk-chocolate versions, with narrower triangles and a wider gap between peaks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The peaks are slimmer and the valleys are wider, but the price hasn’t changed.

headline: 1916: “Herald” in the Making Shown in Pictures
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers']
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The Broadway Theatre shows the Paramount Pictograph’s motion picture, “A Newspaper in the Making,” filmed at the Herald Tribune building in New York, in November 1916.
lead_paragraph: At the Broadway Theatre last night the spectators at the motion picture entertainment displayed a deep interest in “A Newspaper in the Making,” a part of the Paramount Pictograph, which was featured by itself. The remarkably close attention which the undramatic picture attracted seemed, judging by the comments of the spectators, to be caused by the clear exposition of a little understood and widely interesting subject — how the news gets from its happening onto the folded white pages of a newspaper.

headline: Jim Harbaugh Gives Jabrill Peppers’s Uphill Heisman Climb a Big Push
abstract: Michigan Coach Jim Harbaugh has used Peppers in various roles to make him more than just a defender in the eyes of Heisman Trophy voters.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Early in the second quarter of No. 2 Michigan’s 59-3 demolition of Maryland on Saturday, the Wolverines’ Jabrill Peppers ran the ball 13 yards from Maryland’s 16-yard line, leaving Michigan, already up by 14-0 and clearly primed to be the victor, needing someone just to punch it in.

headline: Tech Tools for Election Day
abstract: A sampling of articles from The New York Times about how technology can help voters.
lead_paragraph: What a long road it has been. And now we are finally here: Election Day.

headline: ‘I Feel Very Happy to Be a Part of This’: New Yorkers Flock to the Polls
abstract: As many voters waited and waited, the New York City Board of Elections struggled to handle the crowds and address reports of problems at polling places.
lead_paragraph: The lines snaked through school hallways and public libraries and down sun-dappled sidewalks, filled with New Yorkers in business suits and exercise attire, alone and with relatives, as they cast their votes on Tuesday.

headline: Jhumpa Lahiri Judges Books by Their Covers
abstract: Having mastered Italian, Jhumpa Lahiri sets her sights on the visual language of book covers.
lead_paragraph: In “The Clothing of Books,” a pocket-size treatise out this month, Jhumpa Lahiri takes on the visual language of book jackets and the search for the perfect fit. “The right cover is like a beautiful coat, elegant and warm,” writes the Pulitzer Prize winner. Her latest is a smart lapis blue with simple lettering. Here, she shares five of her all-time favorites.

headline: Third Body Found in South Carolina After Chained Woman Was Rescued
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The bodies were removed from the property of Todd C. Kohlhepp, a registered sex offender who has been charged with kidnapping.
lead_paragraph: Two more bodies were found Monday on the remote property in South Carolina where a missing woman was rescued from a storage container in which she had been chained and held captive, the authorities said.

headline: At the Former Home to Borders Books, a Tech Hub Now Sprouts
abstract: In Ann Arbor, Mich., where the flagship store and headquarters of the former Borders chain once stood, restaurants cater to students and tech workers.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — A patch of sidewalk on the south side of East Liberty Street, four blocks from the main University of Michigan campus, has returned from the dead with remarkable speed.

headline: Austrian Authorities Thwart Group Trying to Sell Fake Picassos
abstract: The country’s criminal intelligence service arrested six suspects who were said to be trying to sell artworks purported to be Picasso originals.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Austria’s criminal intelligence service announced this week that it had uncovered a group selling forgeries of high-profile art, including fakes that had been attributed to Chagall and Picasso.

headline: Silicon Valley Style Puts Gloss on Tesla’s Bid for SolarCity
abstract: To sell the deal, Mr. Musk turned Tesla into an integrated solar company with SolarCity the crucial missing piece, and investors appear to be buying in.
lead_paragraph: If Tesla Motors’ proposed acquisition of SolarCity wasn’t a Silicon Valley deal through and through, it would have been dead on arrival.

headline: How the 50 Million Early Voters May Shape the Election’s Outcome
abstract: Their impact partly depends on how many of them voted on Election Day in 2012, and how many are new this time around.
lead_paragraph: With the number of people who voted before Election Day expected to approach 50 million, a lot remains unknown about who these voters are and whether this surge of early voting will change the outcome of the election.

headline: Can the Media Recover From This Election?
abstract: James Poniewozik, chief TV critic for The New York Times, and Jim Rutenberg, media columnist at The Times, discuss the good and bad of election coverage.
lead_paragraph: This has not been your typical presidential election — not for the voters, the candidates or the news media. James Poniewozik, chief television critic for The New York Times, and Jim Rutenberg, media columnist for The Times, discuss how the election season went, good and bad, for members of the press.

headline: What to Read About ‘The Crown’
abstract: Netflix’s lustrous drama about the life of Queen Elizabeth II premiered last week. Here’s what people have been saying about the first season.
lead_paragraph: The first season of “The Crown” hit Netflix on Friday. Since then the new series, a luscious dramatization of the life of Queen Elizabeth II, has generated conversations about historical accuracy and about how we mythologize the British royal family. Netflix plans to dramatize six decades of the Queen’s reign, and the first season opens with Princess Elizabeth juggling her responsibilities and her relationship, like so many modern women.

headline: Celebrities Are Voting, Then Putting Stickers on Their Faces
abstract: Here’s a live roundup of famous faces at the polls, on the campaign trail and outer space.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago the hip hop mogul Sean Combs, or P. Diddy as he was known then, sought to drive people to the polls with the slogan “Vote or Die!”

headline: What We’ve Learned About the Media Industry During This Election
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Media']
abstract: The story of the 2016 election is not one of new media replacing old media, but of both struggling to define their roles.
lead_paragraph: When the 2016 campaign began, legacy news organizations already faced dim industry projections. Slides in print revenue at newspapers and magazines were accelerating; online advertising, the escape plan for these businesses, teetered.

headline: How to Spot and Report Voter Intimidation
abstract: A guide to what exactly constitutes voter intimidation and what to do if you encounter it on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: As many Americans endured long lines to cast their vote on Election Day, there was concern about voter intimidation. But some may be unsure about what exactly that entails.

headline: Did Tom Brady and Gisele Bündchen Back Donald Trump? She Says No, and He’s Not Saying
abstract: Mr. Trump told a crowd that Mr. Brady was voting for him, but Ms. Bündchen wrote on Instagram that it wasn’t true.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election has divided the country, pitting friends against one another and even straining marriages.

headline: Late-Night Comedians Get the Last Laughs of the 2016 Election
abstract: Jon Stewart stopped by “The Late Show,” and Benedict Cumberbatch read a grim fairy tale to viewers of “The Late Late Show.”
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, the late-night comics got their last crack at the 2016 election.

headline: Fashion Election: Brock Collection Wins the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Prize
abstract: The night before the election, the fashion set had more than one contest in mind.
lead_paragraph: So, I said to Steven Kolb, the chief executive of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, who’s going to win?

headline: Obama’s Election Day Ritual: Dribbling and Jump Shots
abstract: The president played basketball Tuesday morning to ensure victory for Hillary Clinton, adhering to his victorious pattern on the day when votes are cast.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Don’t jinx it now, President Obama thought.

headline: Picturing the Next President
abstract: Photoshop allows us to create images today that may become our reality after the election.
lead_paragraph: The images below are not real, but the scenes that Photoshop allows us to create today may become our reality after the election.

headline: Valeant’s Struggles Are a Bad Omen for the Entire Industry
abstract: Intensifying pressure stands to upend business models heavily dependent on raising prices.
lead_paragraph: A disastrous quarter for Valeant Pharmaceuticals is a bad sign of things to come for a whole industry.

headline: Behind the Famed Tartine Bakery, a Gluten-Free Talent
abstract: Elisabeth Prueitt is finding sweetness beyond wheat at the San Francisco bakery she founded with her husband.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Elisabeth Prueitt opened the San Francisco bakery Tartine in 2002 with her husband, Chad Robertson, she was already in on the cosmic joke: Here she was, a brilliant pastry chef who loved her work, married to a bread baker and collaborating on what would become one of America’s great bakeries. And she was gluten intolerant.

headline: When Police Surveillance Violates Civil Liberties
keywords: ['Police', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: A civil rights lawyer and an activist offer their views on a proposed settlement.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why ‘Locker Room Talk’ is No Excuse
abstract: In using the phrase “locker room talk” in a headline, The Times diminished the offensive language and actions of the Harvard men’s soccer team.
lead_paragraph: I have never been in a men’s locker room, but the news in recent weeks has offered a lesson in what to expect. First it was Donald Trump, who passed off the debasing remarks he was caught on tape making about women as mere “locker room talk.” Now it’s the Harvard men’s soccer team that was found to have crudely sexualized members of the women’s team, systematically and continually over many years. Once again, there are some who pass this behavior off as the stuff of “locker rooms.” Like who, you might ask? The New York Times, for one.

headline: Ohio State University, on Alcohol Sales
abstract: A university official writes that allowing regulated beer sales and increasing security lowered the number of alcohol-related incidents.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Spice Market Chef Puts His Spin on Chinese Food at Chaan Teng
abstract: New restaurants from Pichet Ong and Jared Sippel, and other New York openings.
lead_paragraph: CHAAN TENG The versatile chef Pichet Ong is best known for his Asian-fusion desserts, especially at Spice Market (which closed recently). But this Bangkok native has done plenty on the savory side, with Thai and Western food. His latest venture, for which he is the creative director, is in Hell’s Kitchen, turning out Chinese dishes, a cuisine that’s not new to him since he’s part Chinese and has worked at 66, Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s Chinese restaurant in TriBeCa. “It’s never been a better time to open a Chinese restaurant now with the awareness of ingredients,” he said. And he’s having some fun making his own versions of the old standards: chicken skin dumplings, moo shu pulled beef, crispy mapo tofu, Singapore chile crab cakes and General Tso fried chicken. Desserts like flourless chocolate cake with green tea are not the usual banal afterthoughts. The room has atmosphere to spare, with lacy dark wood trellis work and Portuguese tile on the walls and underfoot. (Opens Thursday): 698 Ninth Avenue (48th Street), 212-235-1886, chaantengnyc.com.

headline: His Play Is Set on Election Night. He Still Hasn’t Finished It.
abstract: “Women of a Certain Age,” about this year’s presidential election, has its premiere on Tuesday. We spoke with the playwright hours before the actors got his final changes.
lead_paragraph: Talk about writing on deadline: The acclaimed playwright Richard Nelson is crafting a drama that is set tonight and opens tonight, pegged to this crazy election.

headline: What the Election Could Mean for the Markets
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index"]
abstract: When the presidential election is called, there is no guarantee how markets will react. But stocks, currencies and commodities have already provided clues.
lead_paragraph: Investors generally do not like uncertainty. Now, the biggest unknown hanging over the markets — the outcome of the United States presidential election — is about to be known.

headline: 7 Great Reads to Distract You From the Election
abstract: If you’re waiting in line to vote, or simply waiting at your desk for election results to pour in, this is a great time to take a virtual escape.
lead_paragraph: This anxiety-inducing campaign season is at long last done. As we process the results, this is a great time to take a virtual escape. That’s where we come in. Here are seven articles that will mentally transport you off the grid or into a great yarn. Take advantage of  the temporarily paywall-free New York Times to dive into some great reads.

headline: How Does the Electoral College Work?
abstract: On Election Day, we’re electing the electors who elect the president. And it takes 270 of the 538 electors to win. Got it?
lead_paragraph: What is the Electoral College?

headline: Acquittal of the Bundy Gang
abstract: A reader is shocked by a jury’s decision not to punish the takeover of a wildlife refuge.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Stranded. And Don’t Expect Help From Those Animals.
abstract: John Fleck veers into gothic horror spoof in his solo show, “Blacktop Highway,” at Dixon Place. With video and puppetry, it is gory and gleefully dark.
lead_paragraph: Hush, the movie’s starting.

headline: Manhattan School in Zoning Battle Is Struggling, but It Has Its Fans
abstract: P.S. 191 has been described at hearings as dangerous and an academic failure. Some parents have found it to be quite different from its reputation.
lead_paragraph: When Andrew Chu first took his son to prekindergarten at Public School 191, he was unsure of what he would find: How good would the teachers be? Would parents show up for school events?

headline: Japan Uses Speed, Not Size, to Take Women’s Basketball to New Heights
abstract: The sport has gained popularity in Japan after the team’s eighth-place showing at the 2016 Olympics, especially with the 2020 Games set for Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For two quarters during a game at the Rio Olympics in August, Japan made the vaunted United States women’s national basketball team appear mortal. Late in the first half of their quarterfinal game, Japan even cut the Americans’ lead to 2 points, at 48-46, on a layup by Ramu Tokashiki.

headline: Julian Assange Releases More Emails and Defends WikiLeaks’ Mission
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: WikiLeaks published another installment of the hacked email trove on Tuesday, bringing the total number of messages made public to more than 58,000.
lead_paragraph: Julian Assange operates from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London, where his internet connection was recently cut off. But that has not stopped him from being one of the most significant and unusual players in the 2016 election campaign in the United States.

headline: Suicide Attempts in Prison
abstract: A reader calls on President Obama to issue an executive order banning solitary confinement.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Suspect in Fatal Subway Attack Pleads Not Guilty to Murder Charge
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Subways', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Prosecutors said two witnesses saw Melanie Liverpool-Turner push a woman to her death in a Times Square subway station Monday, but she denied doing so.

headline: How a Mastodon’s Teeth Found in Michigan May Tell Us How It Died

headline: A New Shop for Simple, Handmade Housewares
keywords: ['Wood and Wood Products', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The founder of Blackcreek Mercantile & Trading Co. created a space for his own designs alongside equally elemental works by artist friends.
lead_paragraph: For most people, wood is an unsexy material — the workaday stuff of foundations and flooring and furniture — but for the sculptor and designer Joshua Vogel, it is one of the most dynamic and vital substances on earth. For more than a decade, Vogel has been making deceptively simple wooden objects — tiny salt spoons, elegant sawhorse tables — according to the most rigorous principles of craftsmanship. Under the name Blackcreek Mercantile and Trading Co., which is perhaps best known for a range of understated black cutting boards, he and a small team craft by hand one-of-a-kind pieces that honor the unique qualities of the wood they carve, from the curve of a branch to artful cracks. “When I founded my studio,” Vogel explained on a recent Saturday, “I felt like I needed to break everything back down to one part, one piece, and then start over again. I wanted to focus on these very basic, pure aspects of woodworking and also the wood itself.”

headline: Robbie Robertson of the Band Tells All in ‘Testimony’
abstract: The guitarist and songwriter’s memoir ends in 1976, as the group performs its farewell concert, but it’s a smart place to stop.

abstract: James Monroe Iglehart, best known for his Tony-winning role as the Genie in “Aladdin,” takes audiences on a genial journey in his show at Feinstein’s/54 Below.
lead_paragraph: “How the Heck Did I Get Here?” That’s the jolly, mystified title of James Monroe Iglehart’s lighthearted show at Feinstein’s/54 Below, in which he traces his path from a choirboy growing up in Hayward, Calif., to Broadway glory. Two years ago, Mr. Iglehart, 42, won a Tony Award for best featured actor in a musical  as the Genie in “Aladdin.” His show on Monday evening was a casually friendly career survey devoid of the preening grandiosity that often accompanies such autobiographies.

headline: Why You Don’t Have Much Neanderthal DNA in Your Genome
abstract: As a large population of modern humans interbred with a smaller number of Neanderthals, natural selection purged Neanderthal DNA from the genomes of their descendants.
lead_paragraph: Neanderthals and modern humans diverged from a common ancestor about half a million years ago. Living in colder climes in Eurasia, Neanderthals evolved barrel chests, large skulls and strong hands. In Africa, modern humans acquired shorter faces, a prominent chin and slender limbs. Then, roughly 50,000 years ago, the two species encountered one another and interbred, as modern humans spread out of Africa.

headline: Homeless in America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Americans’ feeling of having lost their community may explain Trump’s victory, but that victory now makes me feel lost.

Surveying our political scene a few years ago, Lesley remarked to me: “You Americans kick around your country like it’s a football. But it’s not a football. It’s a Fabergé egg. You can break it.”

headline: Catherine Cortez Masto Wins Nevada to Become First Latina Senator

lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — After a close race fueled by record outside spending, Catherine Cortez Masto, a Democrat, won the Nevada Senate contest on Tuesday to become the first Latina senator. She defeated Representative Joe Heck to fill the seat of Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic minority leader, who is retiring after three decades in the Senate. Outside groups spent nearly $90 million on the tight race, but the biggest factor might have been Donald J. Trump.

Trump, won his bid for re-election on Tuesday, in a blow for Democrats who had hoped to put Katie McGinty in office as Pennsylvania’s first female senator.

headline: A ‘Dewey Defeats Truman’ Lesson for the Digital Age

On Monday, Beijing took a  step away from that commitment, putting at risk the political stability and rule-based governance that have made Hong Kong a free-market mecca.

Few issues get the city more riled — or put liberal values more to the test — than battles over housing and schools, complicated by old injustices and deep divisions of ethnicity and class.

Byrd Williams IV is the last member of a Texas photography dynasty, one that spans 120 years and three centuries, as his family’s interests went from snapshots and landscapes to studio work and art.

headline: Cheering for the First Female President, Until They Weren’t

Anthony’s grave in Rochester and at the corner of President and Clinton Streets in Brooklyn. Women with terminal diseases cast their votes with hope, saying that at least they would live to see the election of a female president.

headline: South Korea’s President Must Go
abstract: President Park Geun-hye has always appeared above the fray, which is why she has fallen so hard.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea was destined to be a political leader. She grew up in the presidential residence as a daughter of South Korea’s longest-ruling dictator, Park Chung-hee. After her mother died in a 1974 assassination attempt against her father, Ms. Park became the country’s de facto first lady. She later was a lawmaker for 15 years, crafting an image as a deft politician while helping to build a conservative party with national security and economic growth as its core message. She became the country’s first female president in 2013.

headline: How the Actress and Entrepreneur Jessica Alba Stays Healthy on a Trip
abstract: The actress, the co-founder of the brand the Honest Company, often travels with her daughters. Hydration is a priority.
lead_paragraph: She may have first become famous as an actress, but these days, Jessica Alba, 35, is equally well known as a founder of the Honest Company, a Los Angeles-based brand selling nontoxic personal care and household products. Now the company, which some retail analysts have valued at $1.7 billion, is expanding its range of products in travel-friendly sizes — there are more than 50 options in the line, and more are in the works — and is also planning to sell them at kiosks in airports in the United States.

headline: Anti-Trump Demonstrators Take to the Streets in Several U.S. Cities
abstract: Protesters angered by the election of Donald J. Trump gathered in cities across the nation, some chanting “Not my president.”
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Chanting “Not my president,” several hundred protesters streamed through the streets of Berkeley and Oakland in the predawn hours of Wednesday venting their anger at the election of Donald J. Trump as president. Demonstrations were also reported in Pittsburgh, Seattle and Portland, Ore.

headline: For Stephen Colbert, a Very Uncomfortable Election Night
abstract: As it became clear that Donald J. Trump had won the presidency, Mr. Colbert’s special live show on Showtime became surreal and sometimes hard to watch.
lead_paragraph: Presumably, when it was announced over the summer that Stephen Colbert was planning a special, live election-night broadcast on Showtime, the expectation was that he would riff on a once-in-a-lifetime political event, as momentous as anything he regularly satirizes as host of “The Late Show” on CBS.

headline: A Pennsylvania Town in Decline and Despair Looks to Donald Trump

headline: How Did the Media — How Did We — Get This Wrong?
abstract: At 3:30 a.m. on election night, I talked with my colleagues at The Times about how Donald Trump pulled off such a stunning victory.
lead_paragraph: It’s 3:30 a.m. in the newsroom, and we’re in a state of shock. Donald J. Trump, against what we thought were all odds, collected swing state after swing state after swing state. Hillary Clinton has conceded the race. Mr. Trump has won.

headline: Rage and Suspicion Reign as Americans, Painfully Split, Cast Their Votes
abstract: As millions voted for two candidates about whom the nation, it seemed, could not disagree more, polling sites became jittery scenes of a nation at the end of its rope.

lead_paragraph: The slick entrance hall at one of Modern Education’s Hong Kong centers has the look and feel of a movie theater lobby, crowded with teenagers after school lets out. But the matinee idols in the portraits lining the walls aren’t movie stars — they’re tutors.

headline: Mike Pence, Vice President-Elect, Is Bridge to Establishment
abstract: With deep mistrust of Donald J. Trump among Democrats as well as some Republicans, Mr. Pence might be the administration figure to offer some measure of reassurance.
lead_paragraph: He is all the things Donald J. Trump could not be. A career public servant who has served in Congress and run a state. A hero to conservatives who adore his strong Christian faith and resistance to the country’s rapid social liberalization. A disciplined messenger who keeps his opinions from erupting on Twitter.

abstract: Natalie MacMaster explains the difference in the two techniques.

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Sharbat Gula, the green-eyed Afghan woman whose photograph as a young refugee girl was published on the cover of National Geographic magazine three decades ago, received a warm welcome on Wednesday from Afghanistan’s president after she was deported from Pakistan.

headline: Viacom’s Earnings Plunge After Battle for Control

lead_paragraph: After months of tumult in Viacom’s leadership, it came as little surprise that the company had a bad year.

headline: ‘Strange New Land’: America in a Time of Trump

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Trump presidency will plunge the United States into an era of unknowns that has little parallel in the nation’s 240-year history.

lead_paragraph: Ashley MacIsaac discusses the techniques of rolls and cuts.

headline: As Americans Look North to Flee Donald Trump, Canada Peers Back in Worry
abstract: Canadians reacted to the election of Mr. Trump with concerns, anxiety and a whiff of pride.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The move-to-Canada memes started spreading in earnest shortly after Donald J. Trump looked increasingly likely to win Florida: “Election Night Starter Kit,” read a post on Instagram, above photos of United States passports and an Air Canada plane. Another post depicted a machine-gun-toting man riding a moose, with the words “Canadian Border Patrol Watching for Illegal Americans.”

headline: 1966: The Beatles May Never Tour Together Again
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The Beatles may never tour again, their manager Brian Epstein reveals in November 1966.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On top of all its other troubles, Britain got another shock today. The Beatles may never tour together again. There are rumors that these four frenetic symbols of modern Britain, pioneers of the undisguised beat and controversial mop tops, may appear together no more. Their astute manager, Brian Epstein, while declining to kill the rumors about future tours, said tonight that the Beatles were not splitting up as a group. He noted that the foursome already has a movie commitment for next year.

headline: Fire Engulfs Former Bethlehem Steel Factory in New York
abstract: The police urged residents to shelter in place Wednesday after the fire broke out in the complex, which was used primarily for storage.
lead_paragraph: A fire broke out at a former steel factory in Lackawanna, N.Y., on Wednesday morning, the Lackawanna Police Department said.

headline: Now What?
abstract: Thanksgiving is going to be complicated this year (not that it ever isn’t). It’s time to start planning for that.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: A State of Alienation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: Donald Trump won a North Carolina divided against itself.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL — The 2016 election pushed the boundaries of common sense in many ways. Here in North Carolina, Donald J. Trump — the religiously indifferent, penthouse-dwelling germophobe — somehow emerged as the victorious defender of the pig farmer and the country church. Meanwhile, our state Republicans spent huge amounts of time stoking fear, not about the sluggish economy or the deteriorating state of public education, but about the grave dangers of open access to public bathrooms.

headline: Daily Report: The Tech Companies That Won on Election Day

headline: An Ancient Tsunami That Ended a Civilization Gets Another Look
abstract: New research finds ash and lava from the Santorini volcano in the Aegean Sea spawned the tsunami that struck the island of Crete, the center of Minoan culture.
lead_paragraph: In the 17th century B.C., Santorini was a small volcanic island in the Aegean Sea, home to Akrotiri, a Late Bronze Age outpost of Minoan civilization, which preceded ancient Greece. Then the volcano erupted, burying Akrotiri in ash and obliterating much of Santorini, turning it into a few smaller islands.

headline: Finding a Non-Mac Alternative to Microsoft
abstract: If Windows 10 annoys you and you don’t want to switch to a Mac, consider Linux or even a Chromebook instead.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’ve always used a Windows desktop for all my business needs. My heart is with Microsoft Office, and I need to upgrade my computer, but I really dislike Windows 10. Aside from buying a Mac with Microsoft Office, can you suggest any alternatives that won’t break the bank?

headline: A Quick Roundup of Non-Election 2016 News
abstract: Things happening in the world that don’t include Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: While you were refreshing your electoral-vote map every few seconds, looking up countries to move to or running out to buy more Champagne, events unrelated to the American elections were happening in the world. Here are a few of them:

headline: The Trump Administration Could Test Whether Deficits Help the Economy
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Donald Trump appears likely to enact a fun-house mirror version of something many liberal economists have advocated for years.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a surprising conclusion you reach when you start to game out what economic policy will look like in Donald J. Trump’s administration: While many details of his policy agenda are likely to be staunchly opposed by the left, Mr. Trump appears likely to enact a fun-house mirror version of what many liberal economists have advocated for years: Keynesian fiscal stimulus.

headline: How Trump’s Presidency Will Change the Justice Dept. and S.E.C.
abstract: Leadership changes are expected, as well as a shift in the focus of prosecutors, and the S.E.C. will be a target for restrictions.
lead_paragraph: The surprise election of Donald J. Trump as president raises questions about the changes he will make to the leadership of the Justice Department, including the possibility of a shift in the focus of prosecutors to different areas. Just as important, with Republicans still in control of Congress, there may be an opening to change the Securities and Exchange Commission’s enforcement program.

headline: Review: Election Night With the Gabriels, a Play in Real Time
abstract: Richard Nelson’s “Women of a Certain Age,” Part 3 of a cycle, at the Public Theater, focuses on a family gathering on the night of voting, and what comes next.
lead_paragraph: It was not, as was mentioned several times by the friendly, anxious people preparing dinner, an evening that anyone should spend alone. And though they often broke my heart as I listened to them trying so hard to sound hopeful, I am grateful to have spent Tuesday night with the members of the Gabriel family of Rhinebeck, N.Y.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 1-8, 2016
abstract: We hope you’ve been following the news closely this week.
lead_paragraph: The long, unusual and often ugly presidential race is over, and the result was a shocking upset of the result that many, including The New York Times, had predicted.

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In the middle of a long bicycle ride several weeks ago, I pulled over for a rest and took out my iPhone to send a text message to my wife. I had a feeling she might be watching me.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The election of Donald J. Trump means that Justice Antonin Scalia’s seat, vacant since he died in February, will almost certainly be filled by a conservative nominee. Back to full strength, the court will again tilt right, as it has for decades.

lead_paragraph: The beverage industry spent a lot of money to defeat soda taxes in four American cities Tuesday, but it lost in every one of them.

headline: Wireless Brain-Spine Connection Overcomes Paralysis in Monkey
abstract: A wireless connection between the brain and spinal cord allowed monkeys with a partially severed spinal cord to direct the movement of a paralyzed leg with brain signals.
lead_paragraph: Monkeys with spinal cord damage that paralyzed one leg quickly regained the ability to walk with a wireless connection from the brain to the spinal cord below the injury, scientists reported Wednesday.

headline: American Elections Will Be Hacked
keywords: ['Voting Machines', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Our voting systems are vulnerable to cyberattack. This year, we got lucky. Next time, maybe we won’t. Here’s what we need to do.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — It’s over. The voting went smoothly. As of the time of writing, there are no serious fraud allegations, nor credible evidence that anyone hacked the voting rolls or voting machines. And most important, the results are not in doubt.

headline: Change Ahead: Shifts on Immigration, Climate, Health and Taxes

Trump as president and the re-election of a Republican-controlled House and Senate will usher in sweeping change to the nation’s policy course that will most likely amount to a repudiation of much of President Obama’s legacy and will reorient the United States’ position on the world stage.

headline: A Once-Charming English Trophy Loses Its Luster and Its Fans
abstract: The Checkatrade Trophy, which had occupied a curious but cherished niche in England’s soccer firmament, has become its least-loved competition.
lead_paragraph: NORTHAMPTON, England — No sooner had the final whistle blown than the public-address system crackled to life. Most fans were already out of their seats, donning hats and gloves, preparing to head out into the night, steeling themselves to face the bitter cold and the driving rain.

abstract: A would-be headline captures a missed historic moment — and betrays a handful of hard truths.

lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Julia Child was a regular customer, scouring the Out of Town News kiosk here for German and Italian cooking magazines.

headline: Obama Calls for Unity, but Signature Acts Remain in Jeopardy
abstract: The president said he was heartened by Mr. Trump’s tone in a phone call at 3:30 a.m., and he promised a smooth transition despite their differences.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Standing in the Rose Garden, where he once marked the Paris climate accord, celebrated the Supreme Court decision saving his health care law and unveiled the Iran nuclear deal, President Obama promised on Wednesday to “root for” Donald J. Trump, even though Mr. Trump has vowed to topple those and other pillars of Mr. Obama’s legacy.

headline: Vote Highlighted a Gender Gap, With Both Sides Feeling They’ve Lost Ground
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Gender', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This election showed how much we still talk past one another when we talk about gender, revealing a divide in how men and women perceive one another’s lives.
lead_paragraph: Call it pink and blue America.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Democrats were particularly crestfallen that Hillary Clinton had a slender lead in the popular vote but lost in the Electoral College, a fate similar to Al Gore’s in 2000.
lead_paragraph: The American political establishment reeled on Wednesday as leaders in both parties began coming to grips with four years of President Donald J. Trump in the White House, a once-unimaginable scenario that has now plunged the United States and its allies and adversaries into a period of deep uncertainty about the policies and impact of his administration.

headline: Want to Move to Canada? Europe? Somewhere? Trump’s Impact Will Follow You
abstract: It has become a reflexive postelection threat, and this time is no different.
lead_paragraph: It has become a reflexive pledge, often half-joking, after an election: Worried about the next president? Move to another country.

headline: The Old (Jazz) Masters, They Keep Getting Better
abstract: The pianist Barry Harris; the drummer Jimmy Cobb; the trumpeter Jimmy Owens; and the saxophonists George Coleman and Jimmy Heath will play Flushing Town Hall.
lead_paragraph: Great jazz musicians don’t age out of their art. In many cases they just get better, trading impetuousness and flash for a deeper, more judicious, more emotionally resonant style. This has long been a reason to applaud the National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters program, a lifetime achievement award presented to a handful of artists every year since 1982. A concert at Flushing Town Hall on Friday, Nov. 18, will feature five such jazz masters: the pianist Barry Harris; the drummer Jimmy Cobb; the trumpeter Jimmy Owens; and the saxophonists George Coleman and Jimmy Heath. Three are in their 80s — Mr. Heath recently turned 90, and Mr. Owens will be 73 in a few weeks — and all have remained active in the clubs, in the studio and in the classroom. They’ll perform in an all-star group with one younger outlier, the bassist David Wong. Not counting him, there will be well over 300 years of professional experience onstage. (8 p.m., 137-35 Northern Boulevard, Queens, 718-463-7700 x222, flushingtownhall.org.)

headline: Forget the Coasts. Look to the Hinterlands.
abstract: “Southern Accent: Seeking the American South Contemporary Art,” at the Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University, includes 60 artists.
lead_paragraph: When people think about contemporary American art, they tend to think only in coastal terms: New York and Los Angeles. Big mistake. There are alternative histories being written through the huge amounts of work going on elsewhere in this country. “Southern Accent: Seeking the American South in Contemporary Art,” at the Nasher Museum of Art at Duke University in Durham, N.C., gives a rich and complex sense of this.

headline: Monteverdi’s ‘Ulysses’ at the White Light Festival
abstract: William Kentridge’s staging of the opera will include puppetry.
lead_paragraph: In his brilliant productions for the Metropolitan Opera of Shostakovich’s “The Nose” and Berg’s “Lulu,” the South African artist William Kentridge filled the house’s enormous stage with animations, activity and dazzling sets. Mr. Kentridge will reveal another, smaller, dimension to his artistry in his production of Monteverdi’s opera “The Return of Ulysses” for Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival. His staging of the opera, based on Homer’s tale, will use puppetry from Handspring Puppet Company posed before animated images. Monteverdi’s great score will be performed by a cast of singers and the Ricercar Consort, under Philippe Pierlot. (7:30 p.m., Monday, Nov. 14, through Wednesday, Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, 212-721-6500; whitelightfestival.org)

headline: Going Inside the Studio in ‘Soundbreaking’ on PBS
abstract: The people behind the sounds of Elvis Presley, the Beatles, Johnny Cash and more are part of this series exploring the recording process.
lead_paragraph: The performer is often only the public face of a well-known song; its body is formed in the studio. That part of the creative process is explored in the richly detailed PBS series “Soundbreaking: Stories From the Cutting Edge of Recorded Music,” an eight-parter that begins Monday, Nov. 14.

headline: Out-of-State Students: Winners and Losers
abstract: States that lost the most incoming freshmen to public universities elsewhere, and states that gained the most.
lead_paragraph: States that lost the most incoming freshmen to public universities elsewhere, and states that gained the most. Data is from the Department of Education for 2014.

headline: Smooth, Complex, Potent: Nederlands Dans Theater
abstract: The troupe moves to sounds as varied as Bach and Jeff Buckley at New York city Center.
lead_paragraph: If the world’s dance companies occupied the shelves of a bar, Nederlands Dans Theater would sit comfortably on the top like a fine liquor — smooth, complex, potent. In 2011, Paul Lightfoot became the artistic director after serving as the company’s house choreographer, along with his creative (and romantic) partner Sol León, since 2002. On this visit, the company presents their works “Stop-Motion,” where dancers slide through white dust like ghosts on a ski slope, and “Safe as Houses,” where they are chased by a massive rotating wall to the sounds of Bach. Also on the program are new creations by the sharp associate choreographers Crystal Pite and Marco Goecke. She sets the action on a long table and clads her dancers in suits and ties, like a corporate thriller; he interprets the acoustic love songs of Jeff Buckley. On Tuesday, Nov. 15, the company will offer a preview as part of the Guggenheim’s Works and Process series. (Wednesday through Saturday, New York City Center; nycitycenter.org)

headline: Early Tom Hanks, Headed for a Raucous Party
abstract: A tribute to Mr. Hanks at the Museum of Modern Art includes a screening of his 1984 comedy “Bachelor Party.”
lead_paragraph: Tom Hanks has been getting plenty of work lately, in films like “Sully” and “Inferno” and as part of a notorious “Saturday Night Live” election skit. The Museum of Modern Art remembers a time when he was still on his way to becoming a household name when it shows “Bachelor Party,” his 1984 comedy, on Sunday, Nov. 13, as part of “Tom Hanks: A Tribute.” Mr. Hanks played half of a couple headed toward the altar (Tawny Kitaen played his fiancée) when the event of the film’s title disrupts things. “Mr. Hanks’s suave smart-alecky manner owes a lot to Bill Murray, but he’s funny and engaging even if he isn’t doing anything new,” Janet Maslin wrote in her review for The New York Times. The film shows at 5:30 p.m. At 2:30 that same afternoon, “Big” (1988) will be screened; on Monday, at 4 p.m., comes “A League of Their Own” (1992). (Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters; moma.org.)

headline: Suzan-Lori Parks, Defying Genres
abstract: An early work by Ms. Parks, “The Death of the Last Black Man in the Whole Entire World, a.k.a. The Negro Book of the Dead,” opens Signature’s season.
lead_paragraph: How do you portray an abyss that has swallowed up a cultural past? More urgently, how do you fill it? Knotty questions abound in Suzan-Lori Parks’s “The Death of the Last Black Man in the Whole Entire World, a.k.a. The Negro Book of the Dead,” which opens on Sunday, Nov. 13. The script for this genre-defying work from 1990 specifies that the set include “an exact replica of the Great Hole in History,” into which entire chapters of the African-American experience have disappeared.

headline: Easing Thanksgiving Pressure on Hosts, Cooks and Guests
abstract: Apps to help keep preparations on track, keep guests happy and even keep the children from causing chaos as you try to cook the perfect turkey.
lead_paragraph: THANKSGIVING requires a lot of planning, but apps can help keep preparations on track, keep guests happy and even keep the children from causing chaos as you try to cook the perfect turkey.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Expectations, and Her Ultimate Campaign Missteps
abstract: On Wednesday, Democrats recognized two central problems of Mrs. Clinton’s candidacy: Her decades in Washington and her inability to tap into the anti-establishment and anti-Wall Street rage.
lead_paragraph: Last year, a prominent group of supporters asked Hillary Clinton to address a prestigious St. Patrick’s Day gathering at the University of Notre Dame, an invitation that previous presidential candidates had jumped on.

headline: How Refinancing Your Mortgage Can Pay Off Your Student Loan
abstract: A new program offers some benefits to borrowers with private loans but also carries risks, experts caution.
lead_paragraph: A new home-loan refinance program allows borrowers to swap student loans for mortgage debt at today’s low interest rates. But the move could carry risks for some borrowers.

headline: 6 Books to Help Understand Trump’s Win
abstract: Our critics and reviewers on books that analyze the shifts that drove one of the most stunning political upsets in the nation’s history.
lead_paragraph: For those trying to understand the political, economic, regional and social shifts that drove one of the most stunning political upsets in the nation’s history on Tuesday, we have some suggested reading from our critics and reviewers.

headline: Marijuana Company Prepares to Cross State Lines, as Legally as Possible
abstract: Dixie Brands wants to navigate complex laws in multiple states to sell its marijuana-infused drinks and edibles beyond Colorado.
lead_paragraph: Almost all small-business owners dream of the day when they can expand nationally. This has proved to be a unique challenge for those in the marijuana industry because the products they create are illegal under federal law, and the checkerboard of states that permit marijuana sales have complex and constantly changing regulations.

headline: Birds Can Be Drawn to the Scent of Plastic
abstract: A new study finds that plastic debris in the oceans carries a smell similar to other sources of their food.
lead_paragraph: Over the vast plains of the open ocean, where wave lines may be the only markers, seabirds, including albatrosses, manage to find food.

headline: A Time to Keep Fighting
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Minorities']
abstract: After Trump’s election, it’s tempting to give up. But this is a moment to stay engaged.
lead_paragraph: As I watched the unfolding electoral disaster on Tuesday night, a banner appeared on the New York Times website for the musical “Hamilton.”

headline: Want to Know What America’s Thinking? Try Asking
abstract: As Times editors reflect on how they (and so many others) called the election so wrong, they should look at how well they cover ordinary Americans.
lead_paragraph: It was the night that wasn’t supposed to happen, that had almost no chance of happening. Having relied on major media, and the overflow of polls it fed readers on a near-daily basis, the audience sat back and waited for a Democratic victory, possibly a rout. Could the Senate be reclaimed by Democrats, or even the House?

headline: A Stunning Failure of the Media and the Polls
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Readers critique polling and the election coverage.

headline: Goldman Sachs Selects 84 New Partners
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Women and Girls', 'Executive Compensation', 'Bonuses']
abstract: This year’s list of the chosen is the longest since 2010 and includes the largest percentage of women.
lead_paragraph: Every two years, Goldman Sachs promotes a fresh class of partners in a closely watched tradition that heralds back to the time when the company was still a private firm. This year’s list of the chosen is the longest since 2010 and includes the largest percentage of women.

headline: What Trump, Clinton and Voters Agreed On: Better Infrastructure
abstract: Both presidential candidates supported improvements, and at least 33 local or state ballot measures on public transportation appear to have passed.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a stunning and divisive election that left many Americans feeling further apart than ever, there was perhaps one area of common ground: infrastructure.

headline: New Jersey Moves to Take Control of Atlantic City
abstract: Over the objections of the city’s elected officials, the Local Finance Board in Trenton unanimously approved a five-year state takeover to ward off a bankruptcy filing.
lead_paragraph: The State of New Jersey moved on Wednesday to take control of Atlantic City, having lost patience with the financially troubled gambling resort’s inability to pay its bills.

lead_paragraph: An excerpt performed by the Calder Quartet.
