headline: Diverse Candidates Win Seats in U.S. Government
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'State Legislatures', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The elections reflected a wide range of demographics in congressional and state positions.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton made history as the first female presidential nominee on the ballot, but the 2016 election saw other, more successful attempts by candidates from several states entering uncharted territory and breaking barriers.

headline: Riding an Election Night Roller Coaster at the Wing
abstract: Audrey Gelman’s election night party goes off the rails — but not in the way she expected.
lead_paragraph: At 8:30 p.m. on Tuesday, the Wing was brimming with promise. Seated behind the club’s front desk in the Flatiron district was Audrey Gelman, 29, wearing an “I Came to Break Hearts” baseball cap and a pink T-shirt that read “Madam President.”

headline: Donald Trump, Russia, Rodrigo Duterte: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Trump Victory Could Prompt Fed to Raise Rates More Quickly
abstract: Some analysts say his plans to spur growth with a tax cut, infrastructure spending and other actions could lead the Fed to continue raising rates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve remains on course to raise its benchmark interest rate in December as investors generally reacted with equanimity to the election of Donald J. Trump as the next president of the United States.

headline: A Star Ballet Couple Take a Contemporary Turn
abstract: Natalia Osipova and Sergei Polunin will appear together in “Natalia Osipova and Artists” at New York City Center this week.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Natalia Osipova and Sergei Polunin are ballet’s wunder-couple. She is the former Bolshoi ballerina of the steel-sprung jump and artless impetuosity who has been a principal guest artist with American Ballet Theater, and who surprised the dance world by decamping, first to the Mikhailovsky Ballet in 2011, then to the Royal Ballet here. He is the Ukrainian-born, wildly gifted former Royal Ballet dancer who became a principal at 19, then caused a sensation by walking out in 2012 amid mutual allegations of ill treatment. The British press ate up the mildly salacious rumors of drug abuse, tattoos and high living that ensued, and Mr. Polunin — about whom a documentary film has recently been made — became famous beyond the dance world, hitting a viral streak (close to 17 million views to date) on YouTube in a solo filmed by David LaChapelle.

headline: Silicon Valley Reels After Trump’s Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Innovation']
abstract: For some, there was a realization that the tech industry’s relationship with government — and the public — is likely to shift in a fundamental way.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley’s luminaries woke up Wednesday morning to a darkened new global order, one that the ceaseless optimism of their tech-powered visions seemed suddenly unable to conquer.

headline: Gritting Our Teeth and Giving President Trump a Chance
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: We need to be watchdogs, not lap dogs.
lead_paragraph: Sure, if you’re in the approximately 52 percent majority of voters who supported someone other than Donald Trump, go ahead and mourn. When a former Ku Klux Klan leader like David Duke is giddily celebrating a political triumph for his values, how can we not ache for our own?

headline: Trump’s Victory, on Front Pages Worldwide
abstract: Newspapers across the globe scrambled to create front pages befitting the day’s place in history.
lead_paragraph: As Donald J. Trump emerged early Wednesday as the winner of the presidential election, newspapers across the globe scrambled to create front pages befitting the day’s place in history.

headline: The Rolling Stones Paint It Blue on Their New Album
abstract: Half a century on, playing vintage blues is an act of preservation and reclamation for the band.
lead_paragraph: Beverly Hills, Calif. — More than five decades after they started, the Rolling Stones are a rock institution still running on intuition, impulse and chemistry. “Blue & Lonesome,” their new album, arrived as a happy accident — or, as Keith Richards said with his piratical cackle, “as if we’d been ordered to do it from some higher being.”

headline: Peter Thiel’s Bet on Donald Trump Pays Off
abstract: Mr. Thiel was the only prominent person in the tech industry to support Donald J. Trump, and doubled down on the candidate when things seemed bleakest.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Peter Thiel, the billionaire investor at odds with much of Silicon Valley, will have President Trump’s ear on tech issues.

headline: Nike to Open a Huge Store in the Heart of SoHo
abstract: Eddie Borgo and Tiffany have a new jewelry line, J.W. Anderson has his first sample sale in the United States, and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Get in the game. On Thursday, Burton will open a flagship store just around the corner from its old Spring Street location. It will be stocked with superfunctional pieces for the great outdoors, like a L.A.M.B. x Burton bomber jacket with a removable quilted down vest ($399.95). At 69 Greene Street.

headline: Exploring a Cathartic Moment in a Lengthy String Quartet
abstract: The violinist Andrew Bulbrook chooses his favorite page from Morton Feldman’s String Quartet No. 2, which the Calder Quartet will perform on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A funny notion, selecting a single, favorite page from Morton Feldman’s String Quartet No. 2. After all, this 1983 opus of titanic duration and fearsome reputation can last anywhere from under four hours to over six, depending on repeats and tempo. Requiring unyielding concentration and unceasing precision to fulfill the composer’s demands, it pushes the bounds of what is physically possible.

headline: Court Rules That A.I.G. Must Pay Cosby’s Legal Fees in 3 Lawsuits
abstract: A Massachusetts federal judge ruled Tuesday that American International Group, Mr. Cosby’s homeowner’s insurance company, must cover the fees.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby’s homeowner’s insurance company, American International Group, must pay his legal fees in three defamation lawsuits brought by nine women who say he branded them liars when they accused him of sexual assault, a Massachusetts federal judge ruled Tuesday.

headline: Review: Michael Connelly’s ‘The Wrong Side of Goodbye,’ a Mystery Traveling the Freeways
abstract: In Michael Connelly’s latest Harry Bosch book, his investigator is on the hunt for a serial rapist while also searching for a billionaire’s heir.
lead_paragraph: Each of Michael Connelly’s Harry Bosch books has a way of referring to earlier ones in the series, as when his latest, “The Wrong Side of Goodbye,” brings up something about a plastic surgeon. That surgeon figured in “The Crossing,” one of the series’s better recent installments. And it came out only a year ago. Still, I had to look it up, because the characters aren’t what make Mr. Connelly’s books worthwhile. The classic mystery plotting and streamlined storytelling are what render him so readable. Of all the big-name writers who dominate this genre, Mr. Connelly is the most solid, old-school pro.

headline: Narwhals, Tusked Whales of the Arctic, See With Sound. Really Well.
abstract: Researchers tracked narwhals and found that they reconstruct their underwater world with more resolution that most other animals on the planet.
lead_paragraph: The narwhal is not an aquatic unicorn. It’s not magical, or mythical. It’s just a whale with two teeth, one of which happens to be really long on males. But it’s not just its snaggletooth — which can be up to nine feet long — that makes this Arctic sea creature unbelievable. The narwhal sees with sound — and it’s exceptionally good at it too, according to a study published Wednesday in the journal PLOS One.

headline: Sorry, ‘Twilight’ Fans, Stephenie Meyer’s Latest Is a Twisted Spy Thriller
abstract: After writing four vampire novels, Ms. Meyer seems to have grown allergic to repeating herself. “I get a little bored,” she said in an interview.
lead_paragraph: Stephenie Meyer’s millions of fans have come to expect certain supernatural flourishes from her novels, which feature shape-shifters, vampires and werewolves, even vampire-werewolf hybrids. (Her 2008 novel, “The Host,” centered on parasitic aliens that occupy human bodies, and even that was too blandly terrestrial for some readers.)

headline: Dublin Appeals $14.3 Billion Tax Charge Against Apple
abstract: The Irish government says European antitrust officials were wrong to force the iPhone maker to give up what they consider unfair concessions.
lead_paragraph: The Irish government on Wednesday filed an appeal seeking to stop efforts by European authorities to force Apple to pay the country $14.3 billion to cover what antitrust officials say are unpaid taxes.

headline: Now What? Personal Thoughts
abstract: Elections determine power, not truth.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who claims to be philosophical and detached after yesterday is either lying or has something very wrong with him (or her, but I doubt many women are in that camp.) It’s a disaster on multiple levels, and the damage will echo down the decades if not the generations. And like anyone on my side of this debate, I keep feeling waves of grief.

headline: Twitter’s Chief Operating Officer to Step Down
abstract: The departure of Adam Bain and reshuffling of his duties and aides are part of a significant shake-up under Jack Dorsey, who became C.E.O. last year.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For many months, Twitter has been trying to reshape itself as a growing social media service. That attempt now includes reshaping the company’s top ranks.

headline: Crowd Awaiting Clinton Is Stunned by Her Loss and Fearful of the Future
abstract: Supporters of Hillary Clinton who gathered outside the New Yorker hotel in Manhattan before her concession speech expressed their trepidation about the years ahead.
lead_paragraph: Under a drizzling gray sky, they arrived in droves on Wednesday to bid an anguished farewell to the woman they had dreamed of calling Madam President. The streets abutting the New Yorker hotel in Manhattan teemed with the bereft, with the emotionally and politically wounded seeking solace, camaraderie and some kind of reassurance that they could weather Hillary Clinton’s astonishing loss to Donald J. Trump.

headline: La intimidad de las Farc
abstract: Federico Rios, un fotógrafo colombiano, se ha dedicado a retratar la cotidianidad de las Farc.
lead_paragraph: Federico Rios, un fotógrafo colombiano, se ha dedicado a retratar la cotidianidad de las Farc.

headline: How to Make Your Fall Outfit Fresh in an Instant
abstract: ​It’s all about the subtle tweaks.
lead_paragraph: ​It’s all about the subtle tweaks.

headline: The Market Is Betting Trump Will Bring Higher Inflation and Interest Rates
abstract: Moves in the bond market suggest that investors see the economic ground shifting in the wake of Donald J. Trump’s surprise victory.
lead_paragraph: The bond market is, as a rule, a more reliable guide to what global investors believe the future will look like than the erratic stock market.

headline: Emeli Sandé’s ‘Long Live the Angels’ Is Uncluttered and Strong
abstract: The second album by Ms. Sandé cries from the heart, ponders spirituality, earns its big buildups and proves she is not a debutante anymore.
lead_paragraph: Longing, pain, loneliness and a need to believe pour out of “Long Live the Angels,” the second album by the Scottish singer Emeli Sandé. It’s a clear, accomplished cry from the heart, exorcising its sorrows by declaring them bluntly. “Loving you the way I do — it hurts,” she belts in “Hurts,” the album’s first single and one of its very few up-tempo songs, a burst of post-breakup rage and recrimination propelled by relentless handclaps and cinematic orchestral crescendos.

headline: A Museum Becomes a Battlefield Over Poland’s History
abstract: Poised to open in January, the Museum of the Second World War in Gdansk has become a political and cultural battlefield, pitting historians against a conservative government.
lead_paragraph: GDANSK, Poland — Conceived nearly a decade ago in a moment of pan-European optimism, the Museum of the Second World War here seeks to tell a story of devastation that transcended national boundaries. Its collection includes Soviet and American tanks; keys to the homes of Jews murdered by their Polish neighbors in the village of Jedwabne; flags from the Polish Home Army, which fought the Nazis; and an Enigma encoding machine.

headline: For Trump Voters, Uncertainty Mixes With Elation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many supporters said they hoped for great things under a Trump presidency — though many also said they had no idea what they were in for.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Coursing beneath the boisterous chanting of the president-elect’s name Tuesday night — that single syllable that will now forever conjure more than just a gilded real estate empire — were the more nuanced hopes, fears and expectations of the Americans who shocked the world, and even themselves, by electing Donald J. Trump president of the United States.

headline: The Fashion Sway of the Rolling Stones
abstract: The band’s enduring fashion influence is the subject of a show, “Exhibitionism,” that opens Saturday in New York.
lead_paragraph: The band’s enduring fashion influence is the subject of a show, “Exhibitionism,” that opens Saturday in New York.

headline: Transgender Playwrights: ‘We Should Get to Tell Our Own Stories First’
abstract: The playwrights MJ Kaufman, Basil Kreimendahl and Jess Barbagallo discuss attitudes toward transgender artists, and their own recent works.
lead_paragraph: “I would love to see more trans stories by trans people in every theater,” the playwright MJ Kaufman said. “That’d be great.”

headline: Yes, He Thought Trump Would Win. No, He Didn’t Use Hard Data.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Allan J. Lichtman, a historian, discusses how his simple method for predicting presidential elections foresaw the success of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The story of the 2016 election is one of a stunning defeat, not just for Hillary Clinton, but also for the pollsters, pundits and data-driven journalists who overwhelmingly predicted her victory.

headline: Meet America’s Favorite Satanic Sock Puppet
abstract: Puppet designers and actors talk about the zany challenges of creating and manipulating an ever-more-maniacal puppet onstage in productions of “Hand to God.”
lead_paragraph: There are two main characters in “Hand to God,” the irreverent Tony Award-nominated comedy by Robert Askins. One is a shy and slightly repressed teenager named Jason. The other is Jason’s sock puppet, Tyrone, an “Elmo-y” figure (as described in the script) who may be possessed by the Devil. He spouts profanities, terrorizes Jason’s churchgoing friends and mother and grows more demonic as the play goes on.

headline: How the Rolling Stones Became Fashion Icons
abstract: A new show on the Rolling Stones, “Exhibitionism,” opens in New York, and makes clear that Mick, Keith and company invented the very image of the modern rock star.
lead_paragraph: On May 4, 1963, the Rolling Stones, then a scrappy quintet known mostly for banging out Chuck Berry covers, gathered for their first official photo shoot on the streets of London’s Chelsea district.

headline: Donald Trump, Republican Party, Marijuana: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Trump and Trudeau Policy Differences
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']

lead_paragraph: President Trump and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada will need to work together despite vast differences on climate change, trade and migrants.

headline: Maggie Hassan Unseats Kelly Ayotte in New Hampshire Senate Race
abstract: Governor Hassan upended Senator Ayotte, a rising star in Washington, in a race that cost about $120 million, a jaw-dropping sum for such a small state.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — New Hampshire Gov. Maggie Hassan, a Democrat, has unseated Senator Kelly Ayotte, a Republican, in one of the most competitive and closely watched races of this election cycle. The race was called Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Rezoning Plan for 11 Manhattan Schools
abstract: The New York City Education Department released its plan to redraw school zones in Community School District 3 in Manhattan, which encompasses the Upper West Side and part of Harlem.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Education Department released its plan to redraw school zones in Community School District 3 in Manhattan, which encompasses the Upper West Side and part of Harlem.

headline: Rezoning Plan to Remake 3 Upper West Side Schools Will Proceed, City Says
abstract: New York City’s Education Department said on Wednesday that the move to redraw zone lines for 11 schools would reduce overcrowding and increase racial and economic integration at three of them.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Education Department said on Wednesday that it would proceed with a fiercely contested plan to redraw elementary school zones on the Upper West Side of Manhattan in an effort to reduce overcrowding while increasing racial and economic integration at three schools.

headline: Arnold Mesches: 1923-2016
abstract: Mr. Mesches was a painter whose political activities were recorded by the F.B.I. for more than 25 years in a thick dossier that he later used for his series “The F.B.I. Files.”
lead_paragraph: Mr. Mesches was a painter whose political activities were recorded by the F.B.I. for more than 25 years in a thick dossier that he later used for his series “The F.B.I. Files.”

headline: In New York, Deep Confusion Stands in Contrast to Elation After Donald Trump’s Win
abstract: Thousands of people, their faces illuminated by Times Square’s advertisements, stood watching and waiting as Mr. Trump steamrollered over Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Times Square, the famed Manhattan crossroads, is where Americans often mark moments of great change, and so, too, as Wednesday dawned. But instead of its usual buzz and bustle, it was filled with an eerie silence.

headline: Student Protests Break Out Nationwide
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Protests developed at high schools and colleges across the country after the election of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Protests developed at high schools and colleges across the country after the election of Donald J. Trump.

headline: Arnold Mesches, Artist Who Was Recorded by the F.B.I., Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Mesches was a scenic artist in Hollywood when his work for the Communist Party came to the attention of the bureau in 1945.
lead_paragraph: Arnold Mesches, a socially conscious painter whose political activities were recorded by the F.B.I. for more than 25 years in a thick dossier that he later used for his series “The F.B.I. Files,” died on Nov. 5 at his home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 93.

headline: Museum Explores Arafat’s Legacy but Leaves Unanswered Questions
abstract: The Yasir Arafat Museum treads a fine line, honoring the Palestinian narrative while dealing dispassionately with some of the movement’s more awkward periods.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Much about Yasir Arafat remains an enigma, in death as in life.

headline: Yaffa Eliach, Historian Who Captured Faces of the Holocaust, Dies at 79
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Professor Eliach, who survived the Nazi massacres of Jews in her Lithuanian town, went on to document their lives in a canyon of photographs at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.
lead_paragraph: Yaffa Eliach, who as a 4-year-old survived the Nazi massacres of Jews in her Lithuanian town, and went on to document their daily life in a kaleidoscopic book and a haunting, three-story canyon of photographs at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 79.

headline: Teaching Students That Judge Judy Is Not a Supreme Court Justice
abstract: Two federal judges in Manhattan have started a program to educate students, and adults, about the judicial system.
lead_paragraph: The divide between the criminal justice system and much of the public has become an urgent topic of conversation in recent years, with voices rising from all sides.

headline: South Carolina Identifies Bodies Found on Suspect’s Property
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: The victims, a married couple, had been reported missing in December and were found on the land of a man linked to several murders.
lead_paragraph: A Spartanburg, S.C., couple who were reported missing last year have been identified as the people whose bodies were found on the property of a South Carolina man linked to seven murders, officials said on Wednesday. It appears that both people had been shot to death, officials said.

headline: State Voters With Minds of Their Own
abstract: Citizens supported some progressive measures at the ballot box, even as they were electing Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Frustrated by a do-nothing Congress, voters took policy matters into their own hands on Tuesday by passing state ballot proposals to legalize marijuana, approve new transportation projects, raise state minimum wages and strengthen gun control laws. That these progressive measures won is an indication that voters are moving left on many issues, despite Donald Trump’s victory.

headline: Rest Assured: The Mets Are Focusing on Young Pitchers’ Health
abstract: With its rotation ravaged by injuries last season, the team is looking at measures such as a six-man rotation to protect its most important resource.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The Mets made it as far as the National League wild-card game in October, but the dominant theme of their 2016 season was the crippled state of the team’s once-fearsome starting rotation.

headline: Zoltan Kocsis, Pianist and Conductor, Dies at 64
abstract: Mr. Kocsis revamped the Hungarian National Philharmonic Orchestra and played with orchestras in New York, Berlin, Chicago, London, San Francisco and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Zoltan Kocsis, a pianist and conductor who revamped the Hungarian National Philharmonic Orchestra and was internationally known for his incandescent renditions of Schubert, Beethoven and other composers, died on Sunday at his home in Budapest. He was 64.

headline: Could You Please Page My Son?
abstract: A young medical intern at a hospital in Queens is annoyed to hear his name called over and over, until finding out who is behind it.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Raoul Coutard, Cinematographer of the French New Wave, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Coutard, known for his mobile camera on films like “Breathless,” was said to have had the “rare ability to realize the very different objectives of each of the major directors he has worked with.”
lead_paragraph: Raoul Coutard, whose innovative camera work for Jean-Luc Godard and François Truffaut made him the leading cinematographer of the French New Wave, died on Tuesday in Labenne, near Bayonne, France. He was 92.

headline: White Women Helped Elect Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Whites', 'Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: While black and Hispanic or Latino women voted overwhelmingly for Hillary Clinton, 53 percent of white women who voted picked Mr. Trump, exit data show.
lead_paragraph: More than half of the white women who voted in the presidential election cast their ballot for Donald J. Trump, according to exit poll data collected by The New York Times.

headline: Being American in the Trump Years
abstract: After the graceful concession of Hillary Clinton, we must turn our attention to causes that still need fighting for.
lead_paragraph: The system is rigged, folks, he kept saying. But the rigging seems to have failed on Tuesday, when it made Donald Trump the president-elect, and again on Wednesday, when his rival, Hillary Clinton, and President Obama publicly congratulated him, wished him all success and pledged to get out of his way.

headline: Republicans in Congress Plan Swift Action on Agenda With Donald Trump
abstract: Stunned by their good electoral fortunes, Republicans said they were eager to repeal the Affordable Care Act, cut taxes and confirm conservative judges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans, stunned by their own good, if complicated, fortune, said on Wednesday that they would move quickly next year on an agenda that merges with President-elect Donald J. Trump’s, repealing the Affordable Care Act, cutting taxes, confirming conservative judges, shrinking government programs and rolling back regulations.

headline: Trump Rides a Wave of Fury That May Damage Global Prosperity
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The election of Donald J. Trump joins Brexit as part of a middle-class and blue-collar insurrection against global free trade that could ultimately backfire.
lead_paragraph: A populist insurrection is gaining force in much of the world, drawing middle-class and blue-collar recruits who lament that they have been left behind by globalization. This upheaval threatens to upend the economic order that has prevailed since the end of World War II.

headline: Donald Trump Was Essentially a Third-Party Candidate on a G.O.P. Ticket
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Third-Party Politics (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Casting himself as an outsider, he not only savaged leaders in both parties but he refused to bow to the pieties of the American political system.
lead_paragraph: He breezily passed along falsehoods, trafficked in outlandish conspiracy theories, and more or less asked for the scorn he received from the fact-checking guardians of probity in public life.

headline: Trump Expected to Seek Deep Cuts in Business Regulations
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Trump administration is likely to seek vast cuts in regulations across the banking, health care and energy industries.
lead_paragraph: The unwinding of Dodd-Frank. The firing up of shuttered coal plants. The rollback of rules that increase overtime pay for low-wage workers.

headline: New Iron in the Fire: Studio Aims to Hook Hipsters on Golf
abstract: Brooklyn Greens, just over the Brooklyn border in Ridgewood, Queens, is seeking to serve gentrifying neighborhoods now attracting young professionals and artists.
lead_paragraph: Nick Teodosio pointed to the retro-style brown wall paneling at Brooklyn Greens, his new golf instructional studio.

headline: For Donald Trump, the Transition After the Triumph
abstract: The president-elect cloistered himself with a handful of aides and family members as he turned toward the enormous task of assembling a government.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, the president-elect, was subdued in his triumph on Wednesday, cloistering himself in New York City with a handful of aides and family members as he turned toward the enormous task of assembling a government.

headline: General Managers Revisit Picking Up the Pace on the Field
abstract: The length of games crept up this season after falling in 2015, and the game’s leaders are looking for ways to reverse the trend.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The seventh game of the World Series was compelling theater with late lead changes, debatable managers’ decisions and a brief rain delay adding to the drama of a winner-take-all, extra-inning game for the championship.

headline: Ten-Step Program for Adjusting to President-Elect Trump
abstract: Here are some practical considerations to help cope.
lead_paragraph: Well, wow. We’ve got a president-elect who a great many Americans regard as the spawn of Satan. A dimwitted, meanspirited spawn embodying the nation’s worst flaws, failings and nightmares.

headline: U.S. Says It Has Killed 119 Civilians in Iraq and Syria Since 2014
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In each case, officials said, the American military followed the proper procedures and did not violate laws of armed conflict.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has killed 119 civilians in Iraq and Syria since it began military operations against the Islamic State there in 2014, military officials said Wednesday.

headline: Their Leadership Lean, Democrats Turn an Eye to Rebuilding
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s defeat laid bare the Democratic Party’s weaknesses, and the party prepared for arguments over its future and mission.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton began her second bid for president, much of the Democratic Party rallied around her. Party leaders, campaign contributors and elected officials — including President Obama — sought to clear the field and ensure her an easy road to the White House.

headline: Election Ratings Are Second-Highest in Broadcast History
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Television', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: An average of 71.4 million viewers tuned in to the major networks during prime time coverage of the presidential election results.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday night’s stunner of an election notched an audience to match: Television coverage of Donald J. Trump’s surprise victory tied for the highest-rated election night in broadcast history, according to Nielsen figures released on Wednesday.

headline: News Outlets Wonder Where the Predictions Went Wrong
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Newspapers']
abstract: After projecting a relatively easy victory for Hillary Clinton with all the certainty of a calculus solution, major outlets scrambled to provide candid answers.

headline: 42 States Shifted to the Right in 2016

headline: World Is About to Find Out What Donald Trump Really Believes
abstract: Many of his closest supporters have long cautioned that his most headline-grabbing proposals should not be taken literally — they are guideposts, not plans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Donald J. Trump’s private conversations and public commentary, one guiding principle shines through: The world is a zero-sum place, and nations, like real estate developers, are either on the winning side of a deal or the losing side.

Hillary Clinton would be president, they told increasingly uneasy crowds on Tuesday night at what would have been her victory party in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 3, Episode 5: Fight Club
abstract: After a two-week hiatus, the Lyons are back. They’re still fighting.
lead_paragraph: “Fighting is your family’s way of life,” Councilman Angelo Dubois tells Cookie Lyon. “It’s like it’s in your blood.” Normally a statement like this would be considered an insult. Angelo, however, means it as a heartfelt insight, if not an outright compliment. After witnessing the latest public throw-down involving Cookie’s kin, he’s become enlightened about her needs: He’s going to fight on her behalf just as ferociously as the members of her family fight among themselves.

headline: Bob Cranshaw, Bassist From Jazz to Pop to Broadway, Dies at 83

lead_paragraph: Bob Cranshaw, a versatile bassist heard in Broadway pit bands, on television and on thousands of jazz recordings — but probably best known as a longtime anchor in bands led by the eminent saxophonist Sonny Rollins — died on Nov. 2 at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

They trailed the Brooklyn Nets by 5 points at halftime and were on their way to a defeat that would only compound their early season tumult. Their defense, newly restructured and with a newly named maestro, remained shaky. Worst of all, they were trailing their crosstown rival — an organization that is using this season to rebuild and is stocked with little-known players.

headline: In London, Blue Plaques Mark the Noted and Notorious
abstract: More than 900 plaques offer the historically inclined London rambler a useful means of navigating the sprawling city and its layered history.
lead_paragraph: Head south: past the gas station, the chicken shop and the bodybuilder gym, through a thicket of enormous public housing estates, constructed in varying shades of beige and beiger and brown. It’s quiet on this stretch of Vallance Road in London’s East End, a concrete artery connecting disparate neighborhoods. A short walk northwest brings you to Bethnal Green Academy, from which three British schoolgirls fled to Syria to join the Islamic State last year. An equal distance southwest lands you at Fournier Street: home to a different kind of enfant terrible — the British artist Tracey Emin, whose most famous work, “My Bed” (1999), featured Ms. Emin’s own authentically unmade bed, strewn with cigarettes and used condoms.

By the time the result had been determined, Anthony’s son had already fallen asleep. It left Anthony with what he said was a difficult task Wednesday morning: explaining to his 9-year-old son that Donald J. Trump had been elected.

headline: Doors Slam Shut for Afghan Refugees
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Editorials']
abstract: The international community is failing to address Afghanistan’s worsening refugee crisis.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan is turning them back. Thousands who spent their life savings on a bid to resettle in Europe are being told it’s time to head home. Inside Afghanistan, tens of thousands have become internally displaced in recent months as fighting between the Taliban and government security forces rages in several provinces. The refugee crisis could reach unprecedented numbers, with as many as 1.5 million returning home, many involuntarily, by the end of the year, according to humanitarian organizations.

headline: Erick Erickson: Eating Crow on Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: I opposed Donald J. Trump but accept him as my president. That doesn’t mean I’ll accept everything he does.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta — Donald J. Trump will be the next president of the United States. I got it absolutely wrong. I have been writing since February that he would not win. The great paradox of this election for me is that I never saw Mr. Trump as a legitimate contender in the primaries because I believed the polling was wrong, but it was right all along. In the general election, I presumed he would never win because the polling was right, but it was wrong all along.

Putin of Russia congratulated the victor and looked forward to “constructive dialogue.” China’s president, Xi Jinping, waited a little longer, sending Mr. Trump a similarly measured message of hope and appealing for “cooperation for mutual gain.”

headline: A Taxi Driver’s Photos of New York
abstract: Ryan Weideman, a photographer who took a taxi shift to make ends meet, turned his camera on his fares during the 1980s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: The inside of a New York taxicab is a place where the public realm blurs with the private, especially on the overnight shift. People fight, make love, eat takeout, throw up, fall asleep, concoct plans for world domination or a good night’s sleep. Many act as if the driver is not there. Ryan Weideman, a photographer who drove a taxi shift to make ends meet, decided to let them know that he was. It was 1980, four years after the movie “Taxi Driver” was released, and Mr. Weideman had a master’s degree in fine arts and a tenuous grasp of New York City geography. He also had a camera and the best studio he could ask for: a roomy old Checker cab that was his from 5 p.m. to 5 a.m. on weekends, when traffic thinned and tips were not always something he could count on. Turning the camera on his fares was a way to displace his rage at the inequities that come with a taxi, where the customer holds all the power and the driver does all the work. Sometimes he snapped people at the beginning of a ride, sometimes after he reached their destination. He mounted a strobe light onto the cab’s sun visor using rubber bands. He wasn’t fancy. Usually he asked permission, but at least once he said simply, “Don’t move, I’m a photographer,” and started shooting.

headline: The Democratic Coalition’s Epic Fail
abstract: It was death by a thousand cuts. Everything that could go wrong did.
lead_paragraph: The outcome Tuesday night — Hillary Clinton’s popular vote victory of 59,916,932 to Donald Trump’s 59,690,096 (so far), coupled with her sizable Electoral College defeat — demonstrated not only how hard it was for her to try to steer an unwieldy Democratic coalition to the White House but also the particular danger posed by the accumulation of what sociologists call  “small disadvantages.”

headline: Are Self-Driving Vehicles the Wave of the Future?
