headline: In Once-Tolerant Mosul, a Social Unraveling That Feels Permanent
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Kurds', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: As exiled residents watch the battle for Mosul unfold, many recall a city where religions coexisted peacefully until the American-led invasion.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — More than two years ago, a Christian farmer in his 70s named Mosa Zachariah fled his village near Mosul with, as he put it, only the pants he was wearing. He left behind his house, “tons of wheat” and a BMW.

headline: Trump and Obama Hold Cordial 90-Minute Meeting in Oval Office
abstract: President Obama met with President-elect Donald J. Trump, saying about the Trumps: “We want to make sure that they feel welcome.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, President Obama said that Donald J. Trump was unqualified, temperamentally unfit and a threat to the republic who should never be president.

headline: Why Netflix Lets Movie Lovers Down, and What to Do About It
abstract: Sure, there’s choice via streaming. But, really, how much?
lead_paragraph: Almost half a century ago, if you had enough disposable income and a certain amount of technical agility, you could have your own YouTube channel. Sort of. You could share your videos with friends who came over to your place to watch them, or you lend them to pals who had hardware similar to yours.

headline: For Europe, Trump’s Election Is a Terrifying Disaster
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: From the economy to relations with Russia and everything in between, the new president could spell big trouble for the Continent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No one in Europe truly believed Americans would elect someone who seems so obviously unfit to lead the most powerful nation in the world. And yet, that is precisely what has happened, and now, across the Continent, people are trying to figure out what this will mean. Many fear that Donald J. Trump’s election might mean the end of the West as we know it.

headline: Russian Officials Were in Contact With Trump Allies, Diplomat Says
abstract: The Foreign Ministry said the deputy foreign minister was referring to contacts with senators who backed Mr. Trump, not campaign representatives.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian government maintained contacts with members of Donald J. Trump’s “immediate entourage” during the American presidential campaign, one of Russia’s top diplomats said Thursday.

headline: Campuses Confront Hostile Acts Against Minorities After Donald Trump’s Election
keywords: ['Muslim Americans', 'Hate Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Minorities', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Several episodes suggest that the election of Donald J. Trump is provoking a backlash against efforts to promote cultural diversity on campuses.
lead_paragraph: The fliers depicting men in camouflage, wielding guns and an American flag, appeared in men’s restrooms throughout Texas State University: “Now that our man Trump is elected,” they said. “Time to organize tar and feather vigilante squads and go arrest and torture those deviant university leaders spouting off that diversity garbage.”

headline: Donald Trump Could Put Climate Change on Course for ‘Danger Zone’
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Coal', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: President-elect Trump has vowed to cancel the Paris climate accord, jeopardizing what scientists say is a critical 3.6-degree irreversible temperature target.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a look at how sharply policy in Washington will change under the administration of Donald J. Trump, look no further than the environment.

headline: 1916: Montana Elects a Woman to Congress
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Montana elects a woman, Jeannette Rankin, to Congress for the first time in U.S. history, in November 1916.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Miss Jeannette Rankin, Independent candidate, has been elected Representative from Montana. This is the first time in the history of the United States that a woman has been elected a member of Congress. Miss Rankin is the suffrage campaigner through whose untiring efforts the women won the fight for the ballot in Montana. The Representative-elect had a strong lead on both the Democratic and Republican candidates. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 10, 1916

headline: A One-of-a-Kind Pendant, From a Fashion Favorite
abstract: Two gold-sculpted medallions rotate in ebony surrounded by precious stones.
lead_paragraph: Great jewels are made to be noticed, but in the hands of the young French designer Elie Top, the art becomes one of concealment. The elegant and mustachioed Top, who had for years designed Lanvin’s fashionable baubles, engineers much of his own namesake haute joaillerie with a mechanical precision that allows the wearer to change personalities as vividly as a peacock. Two round medallions that stud this one-of-a-kind Makassar ebony pendant are sculptured from gold. With the opening of a clasp, they rotate into the wood to reveal an intricate underside set with diamonds and colored stones like malachite, lapis, topaz and amethyst. Part of a collection called Desdémone, after the wife of Shakespeare’s passionate Moor, this substantial necklace evokes a warrior’s shield or delicate medieval stained glass.

headline: 1 Police Officer Dead, 1 Wounded After Western Pennsylvania Shooting
abstract: Officers were responding to a domestic dispute in Canonsburg, just south of Pittsburgh, when they were “ambushed,” a state trooper said. A man and a woman were later found dead.
lead_paragraph: One police officer was killed and another was wounded when they were “ambushed” while responding to a domestic dispute in western Pennsylvania, the authorities said on Thursday. Hours later, a man and a woman were found dead inside a home nearby.

headline: Are There Limits to Trump’s Power?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: With G.O.P. majorities in Congress, his authority is great.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump takes office on Jan. 20, he will have immense but not unlimited power at his disposal. Back in June, I wrote that he could — even without congressional consent — execute much of his vision. He could, for example, shift enforcement priorities against unauthorized immigrants, probably bar Muslims from entering the country, raise tariffs, withdraw forces from the Middle East, and tear up trade treaties and military alliances.

headline: Business Leaders Examine a Post-Election World
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: “Forget the Pepsi brand — how dare you talk about women that way?” Indra Nooyi said at the annual DealBook conference in New York.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Andrew Ross Sorkin talked to the nation’s top business leaders for the first time since the election results. The annual DealBook conference, held this year in the Time Warner Center in Manhattan, featured conversations with chief executives and other thought leaders, who gave their reactions to the election of Donald J. Trump.

headline: Giving Newlyweds Tools for Entertaining
abstract: Most people who are getting married already have basic dishes and flatware, so consider giving unusual serving tools.
lead_paragraph: Most people who are getting married already have basic dishes and flatware, so consider giving unusual serving tools.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the Post-Election News
abstract: “Don’t give up.” The Opinion Columnist Andrew Rosenthal on the election and related news. Susan Lehman is host.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t give up.” The Opinion Columnist Andrew Rosenthal on the election and related news. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: Trump Victory Alarms Gay and Transgender Groups
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: The president-elect has shown no history of personal animus toward gay people, but the Republican platform and his running mate both oppose gay rights.
lead_paragraph: The election of Donald J. Trump to the presidency sent panic through much of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community, which for the first time in eight years will face an administration hostile to its civil rights goals and a president-elect who has expressed a desire to reverse many of its political gains.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the Post-Election News
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: “Don’t give up.” The Opinion Columnist Andrew Rosenthal on the election and related news.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

headline: Martin Shkreli Releases Parts of Wu-Tang Clan Album After Trump Victory
abstract: Mr. Shkreli said in October that he would play parts of the album he exclusively owns if Mr. Trump was elected president.
lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli, the pharmaceutical executive who was denounced for raising the price of a prescription drug by more than 5,000 percent, has released music from the only known copy of a Wu-Tang Clan album he owns exclusively. He had promised to do so if Donald J. Trump was elected president.

headline: Trump’s Policies May Bring Fresh Wave of Deals
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: A conciliatory victory speech by Donald J. Trump, combined with a turnaround in the markets on Wednesday, bodes well for mergers and acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: With a man who is co-author of “The Art of the Deal” as president-elect, deal making can be expected to increase.

headline: Jerry Seinfeld Extends Beacon Residency Into 2017
abstract: The comedian has been playing the Upper West Side theater once a month; next year it will be twice a month through June.
lead_paragraph: Care for a second helping of nothing? Jerry Seinfeld is extending the comedy residency he began at the Beacon Theater this year and will be doubling up on shows, with 12 more planned performances in the first half of next year, the Madison Square Garden Company announced on Thursday.

headline: The 10.30.16 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: KESHA

headline: Resort Fashion in the Spanish Badlands
abstract: The country’s desert terrain provides a dramatic backdrop for the season’s elemental pieces.
lead_paragraph: The country’s desert terrain provides a dramatic backdrop for the season’s elemental pieces.

headline: Thousands Mourn Police Sergeant Fatally Shot in the Bronx
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Scores of officers arrived at a church on Long Island on Thursday for the funeral of Sgt. Paul Tuozzolo, the first member of the New York Police Department to die on duty in just over a year.
lead_paragraph: MASSAPEQUA, N.Y. — On a street lined with split-level homes, small storefronts and trees in fall colors, thousands of New York City police officers stretched out for blocks, standing in formation as they waited in the morning chill for the hearse carrying their fallen colleague to arrive.

headline: Spain’s Most Inhospitable Landscape — as Dramatic Fashion Backdrop
abstract: Shaped by wind and untouched by man, the Bardenas Reales is at once natural wonder and cautionary tale.
lead_paragraph: PICTURE, IF YOU WILL, SPAIN.

headline: ‘The Art of the Qur’an,’ a Rare Peek at Islam’s Holy Text
abstract: This exhibition of 60 lavishly illuminated books is the first major United States display of handwritten copies of the text.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “The Art of the Qur’an: Treasures From the Museum of Turkish and Islamic Arts,” at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery here, is the first major United States display of handwritten copies of Islam’s holy text. It’s a glorious show, utterly, and like nothing I’ve ever seen, with more than 60 burnished and gilded books and folios, some as small as smartphones, others the size of carpets.

headline: Zadie Smith’s New Novel Takes on Dance, Fame and Friendship
abstract: As two girls grow up, and apart, in Zadie Smith’s “Swing Time,” subtle distinctions in family structure and class magnify over time.
lead_paragraph: SWING TIMEBy Zadie Smith453 pp. Penguin Press. $27.

headline: Crowds Line Up at India’s Banks to Exchange Banned Rupee Notes
keywords: ['Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Black Markets', 'Currency']
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s surprise ban on 500 and 1,000 rupee bills, aimed at tax avoidance and money laundering, is making life difficult for the average Indian.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Thousands of security forces were deployed on Thursday to keep the peace at India’s banks, where crowds of people had formed jittery, snaking lines in the early morning, desperate to exchange now-useless currency notes.

headline: Daily Report: The Valley Awakens to Trump
abstract: More than most, the tech industry was unready for the election of Donald J. Trump. Now it faces the prospect of feeling like a wary outsider. Is it?
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley loves disruption — just not, it turns out, disruptions of a certain kind.

headline: Recognize Callers and Texters by Sound
abstract: Most modern smartphones allow you to assign individual alert noises to each contact who calls or sends you a text message.
lead_paragraph: Q. On an iPhone, is there a way to assign specific text alert sounds to different people so that you can tell who is texting without looking at the screen? The Sound settings let you assign only one text tone and one ringtone for everyone.

headline: Russia Prepares to Block LinkedIn After Court Ruling
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Privacy', 'Censorship', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The social network for professionals was found to have violated a law requiring it to store local users’ data within the country.
lead_paragraph: LinkedIn, the social networking site for professionals that will soon be bought by Microsoft, is to be blocked in Russia after a local court ruled on Thursday that it had breached the country’s data protection rules, a sign of growing tensions for American tech companies operating in the country.

headline: With Trump’s Election, a Bonanza for Washington Lobbyists
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Businesses and corporations hopeful that gridlock will end in Washington have started turning to lobbying firms on K Street to help them navigate the change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trent Lott, the former Republican senator from Mississippi, had gleefully flown back from Florida, where he had been working for the campaign of Donald J. Trump. Now a powerful lobbyist, his phone had been buzzing nonstop and he was busy helping to organize a briefing Thursday morning for dozens of corporate clients.

headline: President of Boxing’s Governing Body Knew of Loan, Documents Show
abstract: After The Times reported on AIBA’s financial problems last week, the federation said the loan was largely the work of a deputy who was fired in 2015.
lead_paragraph: The president of boxing’s international federation was closely involved in guiding a $10 million loan to the organization, a transaction that ultimately led to such financial disarray that investigators from an auditing firm recommended that the group find a criminal lawyer, according to documents recently obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Trump’s Victory Bodes Well for Investors — for Now
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Defying expectations, the stock market rebounded as investors cheered the changes a Donald Trump administration was likely to bring.
lead_paragraph: To the long list of pundits who called the election all wrong — as well as its likely consequences — add Wall Street analysts.

headline: My Liberal University Cemented My Vote for Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: It was what I was taught at Wesleyan that persuaded me.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, Conn. — As the needle on the New York Times presidential predictor swung from a certain victory for Hillary Clinton to an upset win for Donald J. Trump on Tuesday, I began to think about how my campus, Wesleyan University, would react to the news.

headline: High Triglycerides Tied to Pancreatitis Risk
abstract: High triglyceride levels, which may increase the risk of a heart attack, are tied to a potentially fatal inflammation of the pancreas as well.
lead_paragraph: People are often advised to keep levels of triglycerides, a type of blood fat, in check to lower the risk of a heart attack. But high triglyceride levels may be linked to another problem as well: acute pancreatitis, a sudden and potentially fatal inflammation of the pancreas.

headline: Thursday Kitchen
abstract: Glowing cocktails and a Korean-leaning menu designed for sharing in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Glowing cocktails and a Korean-leaning menu designed for sharing in the East Village.

headline: At Thursday Kitchen, Cocktails Glow and Korean Food Relaxes
abstract: A chef engineers treats for her young East Village audience.
lead_paragraph: The soju cocktails come in plastic pouches with straws thrust in, like debauched Capri Suns. The cubes inside look like ice but glow. In the long, dark dining room, they double as votive candles, lighting faces from below: dinner as séance.

headline: Clicks to Bricks: Online Retailers Find the Lure of a Store
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'E-Commerce', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants']
abstract: An age of online shopping has, surprisingly, led to an exciting time for shoppers to get back out onto city streets to explore new, innovative shops.
lead_paragraph: Online shopping gets all the attention these days. But sometimes, there’s still no beating a physical store.

headline: Thomas Ricks on the Season’s Military History
abstract: New books about military history include looks at firearms and Native Americans, Pax Romana, Pearl Harbor and more.
lead_paragraph: A good measure of a work of history is whether it changes the way we understand its subject. By that measure, David J. Silverman succeeds admirably in THUNDERSTICKS: Firearms and the Violent Transformation of Native America (Belknap/Harvard University, $29.95).

headline: Hillary Clinton, a Woman Dogged by Men’s Misdeeds
abstract: In the end, even the most powerful female politician in America couldn’t escape the shadow of the male libido.
lead_paragraph: When millions of women cast their votes for Hillary Clinton on Tuesday, they may have been thinking about male power as much as female equality — about the sleazebags who never heard “no,” or the male bosses who lowballed them in salary negotiations, or those men in positions of authority who patronized them or ignored them altogether. There was a sense of collective curiosity and anticipation: Would having a woman serve in the most powerful role in the country make any of those scenarios less likely for women going forward?

headline: Over 50 Reusable Activity Sheets to Teach Any Day’s Times
abstract: A collection of organizers, games, discussion starters, maps and more to use as warm-up activities, curriculum extensions, skill-builders, substitute lessons, or just for fun.
lead_paragraph: Warm-up activities, curriculum extensions, skill builders, literacy games, substitute lessons, or just for fun: this collection of reusable activity sheets in PDF is one-stop shopping for all of these purposes and more.

headline: Oh, for the Joy of a Tickled Rat
abstract: Brain recordings show rats are much like humans in their love of being tickled, especially when they’re in a good mood.
lead_paragraph: There’s just something about a rat jumping for joy when it’s been tickled that can change your whole outlook on rats, and neuroscience.

headline: What Are Some Period Dramas With Diverse Casts?
abstract: Are you trying to figure out what to watch next? Watching is here to help.
lead_paragraph: Are you trying to figure out what to watch next? (Or maybe what TV show to give up on completely?) Watching is here to help. Send your questions to watching@nytimes.com.

headline: Rosamond Bernier, Art Insider Who Turned Lectures Into Theater, Dies at 100
abstract: Ms. Bernier’s long life of journalism, famous friends and other encounters gave her talks an uncommonly wide sweep.
lead_paragraph: Rosamond Bernier, who transformed the museum art lecture into a dazzling entertainment by blending scholarship, a flair for the dramatic and tales of her days as a free-spirited journalist and friend to Picasso, Matisse and other 20th-century artists, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 100.

headline: Squirrel Nutkin Could Have Had Leprosy, Study Finds
abstract: Genetic analyses of 25 squirrels in Britain showed that they were infected with M. leprae, a cause of leprosy in humans.
lead_paragraph: Some British red squirrels — cute and pointy-eared, like Beatrix Potter’s Squirrel Nutkin — carry a medieval form of human leprosy, scientists have learned.

headline: Denis Villeneuve of ‘Arrival’ Leans In to Strong Heroines
abstract: Mr. Villeneuve loves heroines, as “Arrival,” like many of his previous films, demonstrates.
lead_paragraph: “Arrival,” the new aliens-have-landed film with Amy Adams (which opensFriday), is the first science-fiction picture directed by Denis Villeneuve, and, despite its ominous overtones and the heartbreak at its core, it also counts among Mr. Villeneuve’s lighter fare.

headline: Venezuelan Soccer Official Pleads Guilty; Promises to Repay Millions in FIFA Case
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Copa Libertadores (Soccer)', 'Copa America (Soccer)', 'Racketeering and Racketeers']
abstract: Rafael Esquivel, a former top South American soccer official, was convicted of racketeering conspiracy, wire fraud conspiracy and money laundering conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department announced on Thursday the 21st conviction in its world soccer corruption case focused on FIFA, the sport’s governing body, and affiliated regional soccer organizations. With 42 defendants publicly charged to date, the conviction marked a halfway point.

headline: Should Designers Trust the Wisdom of the Crowd?
abstract: New Zealand issued an open call for flag-redesign ideas, joining what has become a quiet trend.
lead_paragraph: New Zealand issued an open call for flag-redesign ideas, joining what has become a quiet trend.

headline: How Furniture Makers Are Catering to Millennials
abstract: A new wave of companies is trying to win over younger consumers — by considering their emotional needs as much as their material ones.
lead_paragraph: A new wave of companies is trying to win over younger consumers — by considering their emotional needs as much as their material ones.

headline: Inside the 21st-Century Craze for Redesigning Everything
abstract: For today’s designers, any object, symbol or pool of information is just another problem awaiting a new solution. Is that a good thing?
lead_paragraph: For today’s designers, any object, symbol or pool of information is just another problem awaiting a new solution. Is that a good thing?

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Make a Website for the Government?
abstract: When a team of young idealists tried to make a website for California’s food-stamp system, they learned just how complicated it can be to redesign the public sector.
lead_paragraph: When a team of young idealists tried to make a website for California’s food-stamp system, they learned just how complicated it can be to redesign the public sector.

headline: Six Designers Take On Some of the World’s Toughest Redesign Challenges
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Luggage and Packing', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Design', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Reimagining the cell tower, the hospital gown, the toilet, the airport baggage-delivery system, the bike lock and the prescription-medicine label.
lead_paragraph: Reimagining the cell tower, the hospital gown, the toilet, the airport baggage-delivery system, the bike lock and the prescription-medicine label.

headline: Our New Urban Oases
abstract: American cities have embraced a host of inventive new methods to create public spaces. But are they as public as they should be?
lead_paragraph: American cities have embraced a host of inventive new methods to create public spaces. But are they as public as they should be?

headline: How an Indian Innovator Reverse-Engineered the Making of Sanitary Pads
abstract: A health care revolution in developing nations started with some uncomfortable trial and error.
lead_paragraph: A health care revolution in developing nations started with some uncomfortable trial and error.

headline: Make It New
abstract: An examination of our current obsession with redesigning everything.
lead_paragraph: A little-known fact about The New York Times Magazine is that it is printed on the weekend before the one on which it is distributed. This means that the contents of this week’s issue were finalized several days before Election Day. You will find no direct reflections on the results of the voting in these articles. And yet, the uncertainty of the outcome at the time we published them suits the theme of this special issue: our current mania with redesigning, tweaking, optimizing, improving, refreshing and updating everything. In the age of branding, the quadrennial choosing of an American president has come to feel like an exercise in product relaunch, and both candidates — Hillary Clinton and the eventual victor, Donald Trump — each represented a new and unprecedented proposal for the face we would show the world.

headline: Law Firm Arnold & Porter to Merge With Rival Kaye Scholer
abstract: The combination was not a surprise. Each firm brings complementary expertise, and revenue has suffered in the changing legal landscape.
lead_paragraph: Two prominent law firms, Arnold & Porter and Kaye Scholer, winding up months of talks, announced on Thursday that they would combine to become a firm with more than 1,000 lawyers effective Jan. 1. The new firm will be called Arnold & Porter Kaye Scholer.

headline: An Outerwear Brand Finds Its Place in Fashion — and in SoHo
abstract: Canada Goose, spotted on runways of late, is opening a flagship in New York.
lead_paragraph: Lately Canada Goose, the 59-year-old outerwear brand best known for its fur-trimmed black parkas, has been found not just in wintry climes but on runways. In February, Marc Jacobs paired one of his floor-grazing sequined skirts with a men’s Manitoba coat, adding feathers, while Vetements deconstructed and puffed up two classic styles. Opening Ceremony’s (slimmer) takes were eye-catching for their use of color and print — think purple paisley. This month, Canada Goose becomes a full-fledged member of the downtown scene with the inauguration of a SoHo flagship. (It opens on the heels of a Toronto outpost, the company’s first stand-alone store.) Amid raw marble detailing sourced from British Columbia, shoppers can rest on soft maple benches by the Ontario millworker DB Johnson and other seating from the Montreal-based Montauk Sofa company. They’ll also find a celebration of soapstone-carved polar bear sculptures by the contemporary Aboriginal artist Jason Carter. “Storytelling was a crucial part of the design,” says chief executive officer Dani Reiss. “Stories like how we were there when Laurie Skreslet was the first Canadian to summit Mt. Everest.” Add to that tales of the brand’s fashion-world ascent.

headline: Review: ‘They Can’t Kill Us All’ Tallies the Unarmed Black Men Shot by Police
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Wesley Lowery, one of the Pulitzer-winning Washington Post reporters covering the rash of police shootings in 2014 and 2015, tells his story.
lead_paragraph: The reporters who covered the civil-rights struggle in America in the 1950s and ’60s were said to be working the race beat. A new generation of reporters has risen to cover a grim and new-seeming iteration of that beat: police shootings of unarmed black men.

headline: Interpol Names Chinese Police Official as Its New President
abstract: The election of Meng Hongwei, the first Chinese official to lead Interpol, set off alarm bells among rights activists over the potential misuse of the police organization.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Interpol has chosen a top Chinese security official as its new president, raising alarms from human rights groups concerned that the appointment will lead to abuse of the global police organization’s powers to issue international arrest warrants.

headline: R. A. Dickey Isn’t Done; Signs One-Year Deal With Atlanta Braves
abstract: Dickey, 42, the knuckleball pitcher who won a Cy Young Award with the Mets in 2012, had contemplated retirement.
lead_paragraph: R. A. Dickey, the 42-year-old knuckleball pitcher, signed a one-year free-agent deal to pitch for the Atlanta Braves, a team with a rich history of knuckleballers.

headline: For Locally Owned Stores, Head to NoLIta
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Restaurants', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Start with coffee from Cafe Integral and start wandering. You’ll find books, vintage clothing, discounted designers and modern jewelry.
lead_paragraph: Start exploring NoLIta with a little fuel from Café Integral at 149 Elizabeth Street. Nicaraguan coffee is roasted in New York, and nut milks like almond, cashew and coconut are made in-house. The Almond Milk Latte ($6) has been life changing, tasting not like store-bought almond milk, but like warm, creamy almonds. You’ll also rarely find a line here, which makes starting your day that much better.

headline: Yahoo’s Breach Gives Verizon Leverage in Deal Talks
abstract: The latest assault on Yahoo’s reputation gives Verizon extra firepower to snag a better deal.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo is providing more wiggle room for Verizon Communications.

headline: Highlights of Rick Owens’s and Michèle Lamy’s Furniture
abstract: The couple has collaborated on structural pieces which will be the focus of a new show at MOCA in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: The couple has collaborated on structural pieces which will be the focus of a new show at MOCA in Los Angeles.

headline: Rick Owens’s Monumental — if Not Entirely Cozy — Furniture
abstract: The designer’s pieces will be the focus of an upcoming show at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles. He talks to T about craftsmanship, fashion — and comfort.
lead_paragraph: Plenty of people don’t realize that Rick Owens creates furniture, as well as fashion, and that he’s done so since 2007. That’s partly because Owens consciously keeps the pieces out of most of his stores; and partly because, even in situ, it doesn’t look like furniture. Instead, they resemble angular, faceted rocks made of materials as diverse as Carrara marble or plywood, maybe embedded with a moose antler. Owens’s own bed — one of an edition of three — is a monumental tomblike structure of alabaster slabs which, when combined with its matching daybed, weighs two tons.

headline: Low-Key Greenpoint Has a Little of Everything
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Restaurants', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The neighborhood blends old and new, with millennials living next door to decades-long residents. The shopping scene reflects a little of both, too.
lead_paragraph: Adaptations (109 Franklin Street) is a vintage furniture store that focuses mostly on pieces from the 1970s: boxy wooden cabinets, platform sofas, macramé wall hangings and eight-track-friendly stereo receivers. Arranged like a home, with a bedroom nook in back, the store has an unintimidating atmosphere and prices that are not astronomical for items that are in excellent condition. To pair with the vintage finds there are new, plush upholstered ottomans, which the shop makes to order in a variety of fabrics.

headline: Aaron Schock, Ex-Illinois Congressman, Is Indicted
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Mr. Schock, who resigned in 2015, was indicted by a federal grand jury on 24 counts, including wire fraud and theft of government funds.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Schock, the former Republican representative from Illinois whose taste for first-class travel and a “Downton Abbey”-themed office design led to questions about his judgment and adherence to spending rules, was indicted on Thursday by a federal grand jury on 24 counts, including wire fraud and theft of government funds.

headline: Chuck Schumer Prepares for His Next Challenge: Leading Senate Democrats
abstract: The New York senator, the new minority leader, will need the conciliatory skills he has developed over the years, faced with Republican control of Congress and the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2012, Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York, made an arresting offer to Senator Scott Brown, the Massachusetts Republican whose 2010 special-election victory had upended President Obama’s agenda. Help Democrats pass legislation to blunt the force of money in politics, he said, and they would not mount a serious challenge to Mr. Brown’s re-election.

headline: Lower East Side, Effortlessly Cool
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coffeehouses', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Full of small and alluring independent boutiques, it’s a must-see for anyone who likes to shop at locally owned stores and experience the heart and charm of New York City.
lead_paragraph: Start south of Delancey Street on Orchard and slowly make your way north. It’s easy to spend a full day here, as there are also numerous galleries. The Tenement Museum (103 Orchard Street) is also not to be missed. It offers excellent tours of the neighborhood that provide an even more immersive experience.

headline: Clinton Hill, a Welcome Stroll
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Restaurants', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: While it’s a bit spread out, a vibrant retail scene includes dynamic stores popping up on blocks that are otherwise either residential or industrial.
lead_paragraph: Joya Studio (19 Vanderbilt Avenue), near the Navy Yard, produces scented candles for more than 100 brands, from tastemaker designer labels to Nike. Since February, the front section of its manufacturing facility has been transformed into a boutique that’s evocative of a high-end art gallery, with hanging oak display cases backed with slabs of hot-rolled steel. (Periodically, the cases slide aside, making room for the delivery trucks that pull into the cavernous space.) Joya’s owner, Frederick Bouchardy, fills the store with personal picks, including the Claude Galien cologne his grandfather wore, Le Baigneur beard and face oil, thick leather coasters and a selection of art books.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: However you feel about the results of this week’s election, there’s no arguing that it was a long and brutal campaign season. Let’s take refuge in stories, and in the long view of history.

headline: A Wriggle in Time: Historical Artifacts of Belly Dancing
abstract: A New York teacher is keeping alive his mother’s collection of costumes, ornaments and other objects.
lead_paragraph: The belly dancer Serena Wilson was so fascinated with the dance form that she wrote books about it with her husband, Alan. In their 1994 study, “The Legacy of Little Egypt: A History of the Belly Dance in America,” they described how Middle Eastern and North African performers drew crowds at Chicago and New York theaters in the 1890s and early 1900s, and how entrepreneurial Americans started learning the moves.

headline: ‘It Is America. But I Want to Play in Mexico.’
abstract: Soccer prospects near the United States-Mexico border face an early decision about their careers that comes with long-term consequences.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — Night fell, and the thick, heavy air was cut by a sharp, chilling breeze, the sort of West Texas wind that made it feel as if the whole city had a fever. Was it hot out, or cold? The children on the field at Pico Norte Park — little more than a bumpy, narrow strip of grass lined for soccer — wore uniforms and quickly broke a sweat; the parents ringing the sideline wore jeans and long sleeves as they watched and cheered and occasionally shivered.

headline: Mending Fences (Even When You Really Don’t Want To)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Also, my brother’s wife won’t come to my wedding, saying she’s afraid to fly. I don’t accept that.
lead_paragraph: My problem? You and idiots like you, full of straight white male privilege, who never understood the life-or-death stakes of sexism, racism and homophobia in our recent election. I heard you on the radio last week, sounding like a fool, telling people who had fought over the presidential election (and cut ties with family and friends) to look for the best in each other and talk it out. Why is it always on the victims to explain ourselves to straight men and white people? I’ve had it! After this election, I want nothing to do with any jerk who voted for Trump or limousine liberals like you. Why should I?

headline: Taliban Strike German Consulate in Afghan City of Mazar-i-Sharif
abstract: At least two people were killed and 84 wounded when the insurgents struck with a suicide car bomb near a hotel being used by German diplomats, Afghan officials said.
lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents struck at the German Consulate in the northern commercial hub of Mazar-i-Sharif late Thursday night, killing at least two people and wounding at least 90, Afghan officials said.

headline: The Divide Between Red and Blue America Grew Even Deeper in 2016
abstract: Sixty percent of all voters in the nation live in a county that was won in a landslide in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Sixty percent of all voters in the nation live in a county that was won in a landslide in 2016.

headline: A Guide to Exploring Four Dynamic New York Neighborhoods
abstract: Get out of your usual shopping habits and follow our tips on where to shop and what to eat in Greenpoint, NoLIta, the Lower East Side and Clinton Hill.
lead_paragraph: New York offers some of the world’s most famous stores, but if you want to break the chain habit, it’s also home to many locally owned businesses. It’s worth going to neighborhoods just a bit off the usual path. If you want to spend the day exploring, with a mix of stores and great food, these four neighborhoods will keep you satisfied.

headline: How to Deter the Deer
abstract: A reader recounts her father’s clever solution in his Bay Area garden.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In China-U.S. Trade War, Trump Would Have Weapons
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Customs (Tariff)', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: If he chooses, the new president could move on steel to back up his campaign rhetoric. China has fewer options but could aim at jetliners and carmakers.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As a candidate, Donald J. Trump aimed some of his most blistering words at China, declaring that “we already have a trade war” and suggesting ominously that “we have the power over China, economic power.”

headline: Comparing Health Systems: The U.S. and the Rest
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Readers discuss an Upshot article about access to care in the United States, Canada and other countries.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Juilliard’s Fast Takes on French Baroque
abstract: Led by William Christie, Juilliard415, the school’s period-instrument band, and singers from its vocal arts program performed sprightly works by Jean-Philippe Rameau.
lead_paragraph: “If Italy sang,” the early-music guru William Christie said in a master class at the Juilliard School’s Paul Hall on Tuesday afternoon, “Paris and France danced.” The comment seemed germane to the moment, with an excellent group of period-instrumentalists from the school’s historical performance program poised to play Jean-Féry Rebel’s “Les Caractères de la Danse,” a madcap tour of 18th-century French dance forms.

headline: A Study Tests the Safety of Women Using Abortion Pills Sent by Mail
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Researchers are trying to determine whether medical abortions can be done safely through an online consultation with a doctor and drugs shipped to a woman’s home.
lead_paragraph: When the abortion pills arrived in her mailbox this summer, she felt anxious but also in control, knowing she could end her pregnancy entirely in the privacy of her own home.

headline: A Pasek and Paul Primer
abstract: A look at this duo’s songwriting, told through videos.
lead_paragraph: The history of musical theater is rich with collaborations between lyricists and composers, who jointly write the songs that power the shows. Over the last decade, Benj Pasek and Justin Paul have established a strong reputation for the versatility and intelligence of their work, and now, with their first original musical opening on Broadway (“Dear Evan Hansen”) and a major Hollywood movie for which they wrote the lyrics opening around the country (“La La Land”), they have fully emerged as a significant new creative force. Here is a video sampler of material from their growing songbook:

headline: What Impact Will Trump Have on Tourism?
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'United States International Relations', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: After the election, reading the travel tea leaves.
lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump set to become the 45th president of the United States, the spirit of openness that has permeated everything from our increasingly global economy to how we travel may be poised to change.

headline: What It’s Like to Make It in Showbiz With Your Best Friend
abstract: Meet the songwriters Benj Pasek and Justin Paul of “Dear Evan Hansen” and “La La Land.”
lead_paragraph: They met at 18, the worst dancers in a college ballet class, and sought refuge in a basement practice room, taking a first stab at songwriting with a tune about adolescents playing hooky and footsie at a suburban diner.

headline: Review: ‘Uncle Kent 2,’ How’s Your Tolerance for Hipster Milquetoasts?
abstract: Kent Osborne returns as the starring character in this sequel to the 2011 film “Uncle Kent.”
lead_paragraph: “Nobody Saw the First One. So He’s Back for a Second.” That tag line appears on a poster for “Uncle Kent 2,” and it’s not entirely accurate. As it happens, I  saw the somber and weirdly self-congratulatory 2011 film “Uncle Kent,” directed by Joe Swanberg and starring Kent Osborne as the title character. “Uncle Kent 2,” directed (for the most part) by Todd Rohal from Mr. Osborne’s script, is a funnier and more imaginative film than its predecessor, but it’s still what you might call a niche proposition.

headline: Video Review: Buick Envision, a Crossover With a Chinese Heritage
abstract: Although engineered in America, the Envision is assembled in China and embodies Buick’s mission of coddling passengers in a quiet, comfortable cocoon.
lead_paragraph: THE new Buick Envision might seem like any other two-row crossover sport utility vehicle available in the United States, but for a crucial distinction. It is the first mainstream vehicle to come to this country from China.

headline: Donald Trump, Shinzo Abe, Interpol: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Photographs from Carla Sozzani’s Personal Collection
abstract: For more than 40 years, the founder of 10 Corso Como has built a collection of over 650 photographs representing 70-plus artists.
lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, the founder of 10 Corso Como has built a collection of over 650 photographs representing 70-plus artists.

headline: Stunning, Rare Images Collected by a Fashion-World Force
abstract: Carla Sozzani of 10 Corso Como never planned to exhibit her collection of 650-plus photos — but then Azzedine Alaïa called.
lead_paragraph: As a longtime editor and the creator of 10 Corso Como, Milan’s high-end retail and dining complex, Carla Sozzani is a well-known figure in the fashion world; and as the founder of the gallery there that bears her name, she’s been a longtime force in the art world as well. What many don’t know is that she is also a passionate collector of photography. For more than 40 years, she has built a collection of over 650 works, mostly in black and white, representing more than 70 artists from the 19th century to today: big names like Helmut Newton, Alfred Stieglitz, August Sanders and Irving Penn, but also lesser-known photographers like Xanti Schawinsky, an experimental artist from the 1920s.

headline: Review: ‘U.S.S. Indianapolis,’ a War (Yawn) Catastrophe
abstract: Nicolas Cage stars in the movie, which manages to make one of World War II’s great disasters dull going — even with the shark attacks.
lead_paragraph: The lack of subtlety in its title tells you what you need to know about “U.S.S. Indianapolis: Men of Courage,” a dramatization of an almost unbelievable World War II catastrophe. The film, directed by Mario Van Peebles, brays the story in broad strokes and clichés as if the horror of it didn’t speak for itself, which it most certainly does.

headline: Review: In ‘Lazy Eye,’ Yakking Ex-Lovers Reconnect
abstract: After a graphic designer in California invites his ex-boyfriend to spend the weekend, lovemaking and much talk ensue.
lead_paragraph: The title of “Lazy Eye” is the common name for amblyopia, an ocular problem afflicting Dean (Lucas Near-Verbrugghe), a successful Los Angeles graphic designer with a second home in the Mojave Desert. As a child, he recalls, his condition was diagnosed, but he never bothered doing the recommended eye exercises to correct it.

headline: An American Muslim Woman’s Heartbreak, and Hope, After the Election
abstract: “Betrayal. Sadness. Heartbreak. Numbness. Disbelief.” Despite these feelings, a reader says she will keep fighting to overcome hate and bigotry.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Dinosaur With a Beak and Feathers Unearthed in China
abstract: Construction workers dynamiting rock for a new school unearthed the fossil of an “alien-looking” dinosaur.
lead_paragraph: It had feathers and a beak.

headline: Review: ‘Disturbing the Peace’ Profiles Israelis and Palestinians United Against Violence
abstract: Combatants for Peace, a group of individuals including many former military enemies in the Middle East, seeks solutions to the region’s agonized convulsions.
lead_paragraph: How much bloodshed can a divided populace stand? In Stephen Apkon and Andrew Young’s documentary, “Disturbing the Peace,” we meet Combatants for Peace, an advocacy-activist group comprising Israelis and Palestinians who have reached their limit and renounced violence. Most are former military or paramilitary personnel seeking a two-state solution to Israel’s agonized convulsions. Their stories are compelling — and persuasive.

headline: Review: ‘Come and Find Me.’ Then Again, Maybe Not.
abstract: Aaron Paul of “Breaking Bad” and Annabelle Wallis star as a couple torn asunder in this thriller, which Zack Whedon wrote and directed.
lead_paragraph: During his tenure on the television series “Breaking Bad,”  the actor Aaron Paul, as the foil to Bryan Cranston’s Walter White, showed an adroit skill at portraying the haplessness that can lie just below the surface of a brash game face. Mr. Paul’s role in the thriller “Come and Find Me,” as a man befuddled by the unexplained disappearance of his girlfriend (Annabelle Wallis), does not expand his performing parameters.

headline: Review: To Sam Kim, One Is the Most Narcissistic Number That You’ll Ever Know
abstract: With “Fear in Porcelain,” Ms. Kim challenges the very notion of a solo, which she regards as part of a narcissistic tradition.
lead_paragraph: The contemporary choreographer Sam Kim believes that the dance solo is, well, gross. (Take that, Anna Pavlova and all your dying swans.)

headline: The Rage of White, Christian America
abstract: This anxious minority swarmed to the polls to elect as president the candidate who promised to turn back the tide of cultural and economic change.
lead_paragraph: Between Barack Obama’s 2008 election and 2016, America has transformed from being a majority white Christian nation (54 percent) to a minority white Christian nation (43 percent).

headline: Moving On, After a Rancorous Election
abstract: “The burden is on Mr. Trump to show us he can change,” one reader writes. Another urges him to begin reconciliation by supporting Merrick Garland.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: In ‘Iron Moon,’ Poets Who Know What Work Is
abstract: In this documentary, four poets in China work in hard, sometimes dangerous, jobs, while nourishing themselves by writing poems. They are not alone.
lead_paragraph: The Qin Xiaoyu and Wu Feiyue documentary “Iron Moon” has a slowly mounting, but lingering, impact. The film concerns poets in Southern China who, while enduring arduous, sometimes hazardous conditions in working-class occupations, preserve their spirits with verse. Its inspiration is Xu Lizhi, the 24-year-old poet and laborer at a Foxconn electronics factory in Shenzhen, Guangdong Province, who leapt to his death in 2014. Mr. Xu was one of the countless workers from the countryside who travel to China’s growing cities seeking employment, only to be eaten alive by the tedious, pitiless demands of industry.

headline: Giving Today’s Car a Well-Tuned Interior
abstract: Automakers are using sensors and audio systems to diminish engine noise — or enhance it — for the driver and passengers.
lead_paragraph: IT can make engines sound like purring pussycats — or growling tigers.

headline: Put That Punt a Little to the Left of the Flutists
abstract: Amid the chaos of pregame pageantry on N.F.L. fields, kickers and long snappers use trial and error to select spots where they can warm up. It’s not always pretty.
lead_paragraph: When Lachlan Edwards punts during Jets games, he tries to give the opposition poor field position. When he punts during those final few moments before kickoff, Edwards has a different objective.

headline: Workout Gear for When You’re Not Breaking a Sweat
abstract: High-performance sportswear has moved from the gym to the street to the world of high fashion. The mecca is in the Flatiron district in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Athleisure, the high-performance sportswear originally designed for workouts but now worn everywhere, represents a populist, street-up phenomenon that got its start like this: Women loved wearing comfortable and sleek leggings to the gym. Sweat-eliminating wicking fabrics allowed them to add layers before heading to brunch. And sometimes, they didn’t even work out at all.

headline: T’s New Travel Issue: Editor’s Letter
abstract: Most of us will never take these trips. But I feel improved for having read about them.
lead_paragraph: In her “Sign of the Times” essay, Sadie Stein writes about how we rarely take the kind of holidays many of our parents enjoyed — to a resort where we are coddled like children and the most taxing activity is deciding between reading and napping. Instead, now we strive for self-improvement at every opportunity, even in our down time. We cleanse, do yoga, climb mountains and so on.

headline: Review: A Pianist Adrift Encounters a Cougar in ‘Dreamland’
abstract: Robert Schwartzman’s understated sex comedy, his first feature, is a bittersweet study of a man who hasn’t yet taken control of his life.
lead_paragraph: “Dreamland” might look from its credits like a vanity project, but it certainly doesn’t play like one. It’s a smart, understated sex comedy, a description that suggests a certain maturity. You’d never suspect it was the first feature from its director, Robert Schwartzman.

headline: Review: ‘Asperger’s Are Us’ Delivers Smart, Perplexing Humor
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Comedy and Humor', "Asperger's Syndrome", 'Movies']
abstract: The quartet of comics in this documentary met at a summer camp for people with Asperger’s syndrome.
lead_paragraph: “Asperger’s Are Us” rarely stretches to be funny or poignant or touching, and that makes this documentary all the more of each. There’s plenty of emotion in this story of four young men who sometimes have trouble expressing their feelings.

headline: Who Is Chuck Schumer?
abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer, who will take over as the leader of the Senate Democrats after the retirement of Harry Reid, is known as a hard-charging Brooklynite.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, who will take over as the leader of the Senate Democrats after the retirement of Harry Reid, is known as a hard-charging Brooklynite.

headline: Review: ‘The Anthropologist’ Tells a Mother-Daughter Story, With Rising Seawater
abstract: This documentary from the makers of “The Linguists” uses subtle juxtaposition to meditate on change and adaptability.
lead_paragraph: At this point no documentarian can possibly have a fresh take on climate change, right? Wrong. “The Anthropologist,” a stealthily insightful film by Seth Kramer, Daniel A. Miller and Jeremy Newberger, improbably mixes that topic with a mother-daughter story to produce a distinctive study of change and human adaptability.

headline: Constipation May Increase Risk of Kidney Disease
abstract: People with constipation had an average 13 percent higher risk of kidney disease and a 9 percent increased risk of kidney failure.
lead_paragraph: Constipation may increase the risk for kidney disorders, new research has found.

headline: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 10
abstract: Players like quarterback Carson Palmer and running back Jay Ajayi have favorable matchups this week.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: ‘Picasso’s Picassos’ Unpacks Paintings From the Family Vault
abstract: Pablo Picasso’s daughter and granddaughter bring different perspectives to an exhibition of his work at the Gagosian gallery.
lead_paragraph: Diana Widmaier-Picasso is used to hearing that she physically resembles her grandmother Marie-Thérèse Walter, Picasso’s muse and mistress.

headline: Review: ‘Almost Christmas,’ a Home-for-the-Holidays Comedy
abstract: David E. Talbert’s film is often disarmingly entertaining, with an appealing and talented cast that includes Danny Glover, Gabrielle Union and Mo’Nique.
lead_paragraph: The family comedy-drama “Almost Christmas” is an often disarmingly entertaining picture, in spite of its being a not particularly well-thought-out cinematic contrivance. After a brief opening montage showing the history of the Meyerses, a middle-class household in Birmingham, Ala., the movie alights on the five days before Christmas 2016. We soon learn that one of its main characters is running for Congress. Even though it’s the middle of December. This is a little distracting.

headline: Canada’s Big Dams Produce Clean Energy, and High Levels of Mercury
keywords: ['Hydroelectric Power', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Mercury (Metal)', 'Indigenous People', 'Levees and Dams', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: There have been protests near a project in Labrador, and researchers say problems loom at 22 major dams proposed or under construction close to other indigenous communities.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Protests. Hunger strikes. Sit-ins that disrupt construction. At the immense Muskrat Falls hydroelectric dam project in a remote and rugged part of Labrador, the indigenous people who live nearby have been raising louder and louder alarms.

headline: Cooper Hewitt Museum: A Mommy-and-Me Hot Spot
abstract: In a city tight on outdoor spaces, the garden of the Cooper Hewitt has become an oasis for children and their minders.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Carlson called out homework instructions across a large lawn to her first grader, who was leaving with a babysitter after having practiced cartwheels on the grass, and then turned her attention to her 3- and 4-year-old sons. The two boys, with matching white-blond hair and blue polo shirts, were clambering up a low stone wall and leaning on a painstakingly restored early-1900s ornate iron fence.

headline: Review: ‘National Bird’ Follows Whistle-Blowers in America’s Drone War
abstract: Sonia Kennebeck’s elegantly unsettling documentary explores the United States’ reliance on aerial combat drones and the emotional and collateral damage.
lead_paragraph: If we can eliminate enemy threats without placing boots on a battlefield, then why not do so? That’s one of the unspoken questions raised, and largely unanswered, by  “National Bird,” Sonia Kennebeck’s elegantly unsettling documentary about the United States’ reliance on aerial combat drones.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: “Black Pulp!” shows positive racial images, young Arab artists go New Age, and Werner Büttner is back — all within a block of one another in Chelsea.

headline: Calder and Picasso in Parallel, and as They Diverge
abstract: The first show at the Almine Rech gallery’s plush new Upper East Side location draws on private collections to match up Calder and Picasso.
lead_paragraph: Almine Rech Gallery

headline: Haunting ‘Ruins and Rituals’ Begins ‘A Year of Yes’ at Brooklyn Museum
abstract: This show of Beverly Buchanan‘s work has sculptures, earthworks, photographs and more inspired by the rural South, its architecture and its legacies of injustice.
lead_paragraph: A stirring show of the African-American artist Beverly Buchanan kicks off “A Year of Yes: Reimagining Feminism at the Brooklyn Museum,” a rallying cry of events and exhibitions devoted to art by women. In some ways, this ruminative exhibition, “Beverly Buchanan — Ruins and Rituals,” is an odd fit for this powerfully affirmative program; Ms. Buchanan (1940-2015) made haunting sculptures, earthworks, photographs and drawings inspired by the architecture of the rural South and its deeply embedded histories of injustice, poverty and loss.

headline: Review: Watch the Road, and the Driver, Too, in ‘The Monster’
abstract: Zoe Kazan plays a mother driving into the night with her daughter (Ella Ballentine) in this chiller written and directed by Bryan Bertino.
lead_paragraph: Aliens may attack while serial killers rev their chain saws, but few monsters seem as reliably scary as mommy dearest. Whether she’s slumped (and dead) in her rocking chair, as in “Psycho,” or pulling a knife on her daughter, as in “Carrie,” there’s just something about mothers that brings out the worst and sometimes the best shivers. For Freud, Medusa’s head, with its writhing snakes, represents the mother’s genitals. The terror of Medusa is the terror of castration, which occurs when a boy sees that his mother doesn’t have a penis — voilà, anxiety!

headline: A Vehicle’s Sound System Can Be a Matter of Life and Death
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Noise']
abstract: For safety’s sake, auto acoustics are tweaked to help drivers distinguish between warning sounds, and let drivers and passengers converse safely.
lead_paragraph: Adjusting the acoustics of modern automobiles is not only about comfort or pizazz. There are safety considerations, too.

headline: Review: A Lost Folk Musician’s Haunted Dreamland in ‘A Star Has Burnt My Eye’
abstract: Elizabeth Eaton Converse’s story and heartbreakingly fragile songs form the backbone of Howard Fishman’s play with music.
lead_paragraph: Popular music is rife with one-album wonders and oddball trajectories, but Elizabeth Eaton Converse, known as Connie, is a textbook cult artist. When her lone record, “How Sad, How Lovely,” came out in 2009, she had been gone for 35 years. One day in 1974, she got into her VW Beetle and left her Ann Arbor, Mich., home. She had recently turned 50, and was never heard from again.

headline: A ‘Nasty Woman’ of Contemporary Art Fearlessly Renders the Body
abstract: “Marilyn Minter: Pretty/Dirty,” an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, regularly fulfills its contradictory subtitle; many works are ravishingly beautiful.
lead_paragraph: After a presidential campaign that underscored various women’s rights issues, what better art exhibition to review than one devoted to provocative images of female independence at its most intimate, centering explicitly on the body.

headline: A Lesson for India in a Fog So Thick It Could Kill a Cow
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Medicine and Health', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: In 1873, London was blanketed in a fog so dense that people could not see their feet. Still, it took 83 years before clean air rules were introduced.
lead_paragraph: In December 1873, London was blanketed for a week in a yellow fog so thick that people could not see their feet. “Ladies & gentlemen,” Mark Twain said in a public lecture at the time, “I hear you, & so know that you are here — & I am here, too, notwithstanding I am not visible.”

headline: Review: In ‘Elle,’ Isabelle Huppert Subverts the Role of Rape Victim
abstract: Paul Verhoeven’s film is a psychological thriller, a strangely dry-eyed melodrama, a kinky sex farce and a savage comedy of bourgeois manners.
lead_paragraph: The opening scene of “Elle” is a shocker: a brutal sexual assault witnessed by a house cat and filmed with pitiless detachment. “The opposite of a trigger warning,” as a friend of mine said. Everything that follows is, in some ways, even more shocking, as the movie — a masterpiece of suave perversity, directed by Paul Verhoeven — leads its audience through a meticulously constructed maze of ambiguity, scrambling our assumptions and expectations at every turn, dispensing discomfort and delight and daring us to distinguish one from the other.

headline: Review: Aliens Drop Anchor in ‘Arrival,’ but What Are Their Intentions?
abstract: In Denis Villeneuve’s film, Amy Adams plays a linguist struggling to understand interplanetary visitors checking in at 12 spots around the globe.
lead_paragraph: In what’s perhaps the first science-fiction film — Georges Méliès’s 1902 marvel “A Trip to the Moon” — a group of astronomers lands in the Man in the Moon’s eye. They’re soon taken prisoner by moon men, but a quick-witted astronomer clobbers the king and they escape, with one earthling vanquishing moon men with an umbrella. Humans have been zapping extraterrestrials ever since. It’s so easy to fight the unknown, at least in movies.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Nov. 11, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Arrival,” “Elle” and “Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Arrival,” “Elle” and “Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk.”

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 11-17
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Spinning Goes to the Movies at ImaxShift
abstract: At a fitness studio in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, cyclists work out in front of a huge movie screen.
lead_paragraph: Jaclyn Cohen, a sales director for a wedding dress and footwear designer, had no desire to join her peers in the spinning fad.

headline: Charles Wolf Jr., Who Clashed With Pentagon Papers Leaker, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Wolf, who worked at the RAND Corporation, was the supervisor of Daniel Ellsberg and tried to oust him in 1969 before he leaked the secret documents.
lead_paragraph: Charles Wolf Jr., an economist, a founding dean of the RAND Corporation’s graduate school and the supervisor who tried to oust Daniel Ellsberg in 1969 before he leaked the secret Pentagon Papers, died on Oct. 24 in Los Angeles. He was 92.

headline: High Class Geometry
abstract: The elegant furniture of the French designer Hervé Van der Straeten.
lead_paragraph: The elegant furniture of the French designer Hervé Van der Straeten.

headline: One Designer’s Unexpected, Powerfully Lyrical Furniture
abstract: Hervé Van der Straeten transforms heavy metals into works of surprising delicacy.
lead_paragraph: Hervé Van der Straeten transforms heavy metals into works of surprising delicacy.

headline: Donald Trump, Marijuana, Rolling Stones: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Boerum Hill Bar Where the Old Days Live On
abstract: Everybody at Hank’s Saloon in Brooklyn may not know your name, but Jeannie probably does.
lead_paragraph: Everybody at Hank’s Saloon in Brooklyn may not know your name, but Jeannie probably does.

headline: Honky-Tonk Brunch Spot for Brooklyn’s Hellbound
abstract: Hank’s in Boerum Hill, successor to the Doray Tavern, where Mohawk ironworkers once hung out, is a grimy but endearing contrast with its neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday afternoon, holiday lights strung from the tin ceiling of Hank’s Saloon  shone on Jeannie Talierco as she grabbed a cigarette and hustled toward an open door. She planted one foot indoors and one on the sidewalk, keeping an eye on the bar while taking a break.

headline: J.K. Rowling Says ‘Fantastic Beasts’ Grew Out of World Events
abstract: The author and first-time screenwriter said the story involves wizards in the 1920s but “I was partly informed by a rise in populism around the world.”
lead_paragraph: Hours before the premiere of “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them,” the author J. K. Rowling, acknowledged that she ground through several revisions of the screenplay, her first, and said the rise of populism around the world in recent years had influenced the story’s direction.

headline: RZA Accompanies ‘The 36th Chamber of Shaolin’
abstract: RZA estimates he’s seen this martial arts movie 300 times, and he’s performing his original score for it, live, at Town Hall in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: RZA watched the Shaw Brothers’ martial arts classic “The 36th Chamber of Shaolin” for the first time on television when he was 12 years old. Two years later, he saw the 1978 movie on the big screen “in a seedy Times Square theater on 42nd Street,” he recalled. He went with his cousin Russell Tyrone Jones, who would grow up to become the rapper Ol’ Dirty Bastard.

But this weekend the Brooklyn Museum will celebrate a pioneering but probably lesser-known borough species: children’s book creators.

headline: Cuomo Strikes Deal to Revive Affordable Housing Program
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Property Taxes']
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, developers and unions hope to renew the 421-a program to give tax breaks to builders who include subsidized units in luxury projects in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in three months, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has forged a deal with developers and union construction officials to revive a program designed to create apartments for poor and working-class New Yorkers.

headline: Review: Megyn Kelly Tells Tales Out of Fox News in Her Memoir, ‘Settle for More’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'News and News Media', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The anchor has emerged as this presidential election’s unlikely feminist heroine, pressing Donald J. Trump about his disrespectful comments about women, and paying the price for those questions.
lead_paragraph: Even had there been no news in Megyn Kelly’s new memoir, “Settle for More,” the book would have drawn a considerable audience. Ms. Kelly, the 45-year-old anchor on Fox News, has emerged as this presidential election’s unlikely feminist heroine and Hildy Johnson, the intrepid gal reporter who made herself indispensable to the brass and resisted the herd mentality of the men around her. She was the hen in the Fox house, taking it upon herself to ask at nearly every turn: Shouldn’t we be concerned that the Republican nominee for president is profoundly disrespectful of women in his public discourse? And accused of being a sexual predator at that?

headline: Subway Sticky Notes Offer Post-Election Therapy
abstract: New Yorkers are finding catharsis for their post-election emotions in an unexpected place: a subway station. The street artist Matthew Chavez took sticky notes and a pen into the Sixth Avenue station at 14th Street and told passers-by to write messages to stick on the wall.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers are finding catharsis for their post-election emotions in an unexpected place: a subway station. The street artist Matthew Chavez took sticky notes and a pen into the Sixth Avenue station at 14th Street and told passers-by to write messages to stick on the wall.

headline: U.N. Warns of Starvation Peril in Rebel Side of Aleppo
abstract: Without a pause in fighting to permit emergency food replenishment, a United Nations official said, eastern Aleppo’s 250,000 residents could starve.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations implored all sides in the Syria conflict on Thursday to allow food deliveries to rebel-held eastern Aleppo, where roughly 250,000 residents, under siege for months, just received their last rations.

headline: White Women Voted Trump. Now What?
keywords: ['Whites', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Discrimination']
abstract: White feminists have some work to do among their own.
lead_paragraph: Around the country women weep, wondering how the glass ceiling still stands. But now is not the time to bury our faces in our hands. For white women in particular, now is the time to look in the mirror.

headline: Tajik Police Commander, Trained in U.S., Appears to Rise in Islamic State Ranks
abstract: Unconfirmed accounts say Gulmurod Khalimov has been promoted to military commander of the group, and the State Department reward for his capture appears to confirm his high status.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a propaganda video released last year, an Islamic State militant wearing a black bandanna and cradling a sniper rifle made the usual grim threats against the United States. Now, there may be a new twist to his warnings.

headline: David Bowie’s Seal of Approval Bolsters Art at Auction
abstract: Several pieces from the avant-garde pop star’s collection of mostly Modern British art drew bids well above pre-auction estimates.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — One of the most influential musicians and style icons of his generation, David Bowie, who died in January, was less well known as an art collector. But as he told Michael Kimmelman, The New York Times critic, in 1998, “Art was, seriously, the only thing I’d ever wanted to own.”

headline: As Ratings Plummet, N.F.L. Considers Reducing Ads and Length of Games
abstract: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said the league was looking at several options to shorten game broadcasts, including trimming advertising and speeding up video reviews by officials.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said on Thursday that the league was looking at a variety of ways to shorten game broadcasts, including trimming some advertising, to keep the action moving.

headline: Online, Everything Is Alternative Media
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Social Media']
abstract: As witnessed in the presidential election, social networks and alternative media represent a new platform leveling the playing field with traditional news media.
lead_paragraph: Breitbart, the website at the center of the self-described alternative online media, is planning to expand in the United States and abroad. The site, whose former chairman became the chief executive of Donald J. Trump’s campaign in August, has been emboldened by the victory of its candidate.

headline: Trump Wants to ‘Drain the Swamp,’ but Change Will Be Complex and Costly
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump promised to shrink the sprawling federal government, but doing so will likely be more difficult than his supporters believe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After President-elect Donald J. Trump promised to “drain the swamp” that he sees in the nation’s capital, his millions of supporters are expecting vast changes in the sprawling federal bureaucracy, and conservative activists are drooling at the chance to remake, resize or reduce the reach of government.

headline: Manhattan Subway Passage Becomes Emotional Outlet After Election

headline: Mets’ Jeurys Familia Pleads Not Guilty in Domestic Violence Case
abstract: Familia, baseball’s saves leader last season, made his first court appearance in connection with an Oct. 31 altercation with his wife.
lead_paragraph: Dressed in a light blue suit and occasionally speaking through an interpreter, Jeurys Familia, the Mets’ top relief pitcher, made his first court appearance Thursday in connection with a domestic violence incident last month in which he was charged with scratching the chest and bruising the right cheek of his wife.

headline: Roy Cooper Holds Thin Lead Over Gov. Pat McCrory in North Carolina
keywords: ['Elections, Governors', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: If Mr. Cooper’s lead holds, it would be a bright spot for Democrats in a race dominated by the state’s transgender bathroom law.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Roy Cooper, a Democrat, held a razor-thin lead on Thursday in North Carolina’s bitterly contested race for governor. If it holds, it would be a rare bright spot for his party this week, one that has much to do with Mr. Cooper’s call for repealing a state law limiting transgender bathroom access that has subjected North Carolina to a gale of international criticism, boycotts and cancellations.

headline: Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic: Old Friends in a Role Reversal
abstract: Athletes who first played each other as 13-year-olds enter the finals in a race for the year-end No. 1 ranking.

headline: Female Clinton Supporters Are Left Feeling Gutted
abstract: Clinton supporters across the country are just starting to process their feelings about the long roller coaster ride that in their view ended in disaster.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — It was visceral. Women felt gutted, shocked, appalled, afraid. The prospect of celebrating the election of the nation’s first female president had been crushed by a man whom many women viewed as sexist.

headline: Leonard Cohen, Epic and Enigmatic Songwriter, Is Dead at 82
abstract: Mr. Cohen was an unlikely and reluctant pop star, but his lyrics captivated other artists and gave him a reputation as “the master of erotic despair.”
lead_paragraph: Leonard Cohen, the Canadian poet and novelist who abandoned a promising literary career to become one of the foremost songwriters of the contemporary era, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 82.

Trump in the election on Tuesday, there were still some districts — working-class areas in the southeast Bronx, Mr. Trump’s childhood neighborhood in Jamaica Estates, Queens, and most of Staten Island — that did not go Mrs. Clinton’s way.

headline: Trump’s Economic Prescription. First: Do Harm.

abstract: Plans for tariffs, tax breaks and immigration could push up inflation, shift more money to the wealthy, increase deficits and cost blue-collar jobs.
