headline: Voters Drive Sheriff Arpaio Out of Town
abstract: Voters in Maricopa County, Ariz., rejected Joe Arpaio after years of abusing inmates, insulting immigrants and helping to lead the birther movement.
lead_paragraph: Some good news from Tuesday, a point of sanity on a day when the nation’s electoral judgment went catastrophically astray: Voters in Maricopa County, Ariz., sent Sheriff Joe Arpaio packing. He lost his bid for a seventh term. After 24 years, “America’s Toughest Sheriff” is done.

headline: Resist Much
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When steel mills fail to return, and new trade deals produce no magic, the white working class will wonder how it got betrayed.
lead_paragraph: This is a very dangerous man, our next president. Dangerous in his certitude about what he doesn’t know. Dangerous in his ignorance of history, his antipathy toward reading, his inability to sort fact from fiction. The last man to play things by the gut while in control of the world’s most powerful military left a mortal mess.

headline: America Needs a War on Terror Veterans Memorial
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: The men and women who have fought for 15 years — with no end in sight — deserve their nation’s recognition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fifteen years ago, I heard the explosion and saw smoke billowing from the Pentagon. This was the beginning of a war, I thought. Maybe most of us did. It was, and after all this time, after thousands of service members have been killed and tens of thousands wounded, there is still no end in sight.

headline: The View From Trump Tower
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: We should learn from the vote, work to mend society and build a political movement for the post-Trump era.
lead_paragraph: If your social circles are like mine, you spent Tuesday night swapping miserable texts. Not all, but many of my friends and family members were outraged, stunned, disgusted and devastated. This is victory for white supremacy, people wrote, for misogyny, nativism and authoritarianism. Fascism is descending.

headline: The Wrong People to Drain the Swamp
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Newt Gingrich, Chris Christie and Rudy Giuliani would be poor choices for high-profile roles involving cleaning up corruption.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s ethics proposals didn’t get much notice when he unveiled them late in the campaign. (At the time, his claims that the election was rigged were dominating the news.) Now that President-elect Trump is assembling an administration, his plan deserves attention. It goes well beyond existing restrictions to slow the revolving door to riches for government insiders.

headline: Thoughts for the Horrified
abstract: Tuesday’s fallout may last decades, but we must still stand up for American values now.
lead_paragraph: So what do we do now? By “we” I mean all those left, center and even right who saw Donald Trump as the worst man ever to run for president and assumed that a strong majority of our fellow citizens would agree.

abstract: I wanted to look smarter, more chic and more fun; younger wouldn’t hurt.

abstract: Stores are turning into galleries, with retailers installing paintings and sculptures. “Shopping can be stressful but the art uplifts and makes you smile,” said one architect.

headline: On Staten Island, Pantsuit Nation Met Its Match

abstract: Excitement at Donald J. Trump’s victory was confined not merely to the distant, vast American territory of the Waffle House.
lead_paragraph: For a certain kind of woman in Manhattan or Brooklyn, or Santa Monica or Minneapolis, for that matter, Tuesday began with a bright spirit, a pantsuit — a popular show of sartorial support for Hillary Clinton — and a promise to children brought into voting booths that the next morning they would wake up in a country that had elected its first female president.

headline: Trump Floats an Olive Branch: Might Keep Parts of the Health Law
abstract: The president-elect said that, after talking with President Obama this week, he might be willing to leave in place two popular provisions of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump overhauled his transition team from top to bottom on Friday, expanded his outreach to more establishment Republicans, and even offered an olive branch to President Obama — albeit a narrow one.

headline: Jerusalem’s Latest Argument Over History Is About Fried Innards

lead_paragraph: In Jerusalem, where arguments about history are a municipal pastime, a debate has been revived about the origins of a local delicacy.

headline: Hard Choice for Mitch McConnell: End the Filibuster or Preserve Tradition

headline: The Closet as Workspace, Bedroom or Bar
keywords: ['Closets', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: Creative New Yorkers are discovering space they did not know they had in their closets.

With a little work and a lot of vision, they’ve discovered that the smallest and most unassuming space can become a bedroom, a work space, even a secret cocktail bar.

headline: With a Cuckoo’s Journey From China, a Mystery Is Solved, and Cheers Go Up
abstract: Chinese and British bird groups began tracking two cuckoo subspecies found near Beijing to unravel the puzzle of their winter getaways.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Flappy McFlapperson and Skybomb Bolt sprang into the sky for their annual migration from wetlands near Beijing, nobody was sure where the two cuckoos were going. They and three other cuckoos had been tagged with sensors to follow them from northern China.

headline: In Southern California, Hot Steaks With a Cool Vibe
abstract: The Arthur J in Manhattan Beach gives you a fine steakhouse experience.
lead_paragraph: When David LeFevre set out to develop his third restaurant in Manhattan Beach, just south of Los Angeles, he focused on steak. The inspiration is both personal and refreshingly simple. “I wanted a great American neighborhood steakhouse,” Mr. LeFevre said. “Food that is soulful makes me remember growing up in the Midwest.” The result is the Arthur J, which opened in June 2015.

headline: Family Travel in a Time of Fear
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Nice, France, Attack (July 2016)', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: The Bataclan theater was a part of our history, and we wanted our daughters to know that no tragedy is ever truly distant or foreign.
lead_paragraph: My 7-year-old daughter scampered over the cobblestones of a narrow Paris street, proudly holding a bag of fresh cherries. She had asked for them herself: “Des cerises, s’il vous plaît!” Meanwhile, a few steps away, my 4-year-old was offering her finest “Merci” to the carousel attendant collecting tokens for the next ride. She squealed every time she caught sight of the Eiffel Tower in the distance, convinced she had stepped into the pages of a “Madeline” story. At that moment, my husband and I felt fortunate and happy to be in France as a family, to be able to share with our girls a place that has been formative to us.

headline: A Year After Paris Attacks, Challenges for Hotels and Restaurants
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Restaurants', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: Hotel occupancy is down and a tour operator says business is off, but there are some signs that tourists may be returning to the city.
lead_paragraph: Nov. 13 marks one year since the terrorist attacks in Paris, which left 130 people dead.

headline: An American Rain Forest and Its Charming Neighbor
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Budget Travel', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Exploring (and saving money in) Washington’s Hoh Rain Forest, and the small, quirky coastal town of Port Townsend.
lead_paragraph: I was motoring along Route 101 in northwest Washington State in my little rental car, getting a kick out of the fact that I frequently drive the same highway in Southern California, where I live. There were few other similarities, though: The air in Washington had a refreshing bite to it, cold and clean. The sweet smell of wet earth seemed to follow me wherever I went, indoors or out. And soon after I left Port Angeles — a small town on the 101 that’s a quick 90-minute ferry ride to Victoria, British Columbia, across the Strait of Juan de Fuca — and entered Olympic National Park, it began to rain and didn’t stop until I left the park seven hours later.

headline: Advocates for New York’s Working Poor Push for Discounted Transit Fares
abstract: At a time when the city can seem unbearably expensive and the price of a subway ride is set to increase again, attention has turned to a cost that many struggle to afford: a MetroCard.
lead_paragraph: At a time when New York City can seem unbearably expensive, advocates for the poor are targeting a rising cost that many people struggle to afford: a MetroCard.

headline: London Bridges Are Lighting Up
abstract: The “Illuminated River” project aims to transform the Thames into a glowing spectacle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — London’s bridges will slowly fill with light as the tide rises. Luminous colors will wash across their surfaces. Beams will shoot out from each bridge, pierce the sky and then drop, connecting with a beam on a neighboring bridge to trace the path of the Thames. The bridges’s underbellies will glow gently; the banks will offer floating stages for performances; waterfalls will create a screen for projections; a weave of projected light planes will hover over the surface of the Thames, creating a ghostly river of light.

headline: The Risks of France’s Big New Database
abstract: Merging biometric information, I.D. photos and addresses and even marital status in one place could invite abuses.
lead_paragraph: The government of President François Hollande has moved to combine existing information on at least 60 million French citizens into a single sprawling  database. The government says the goal of merging data from French passports and national identity cards is to prevent identity fraud. But the measure risks opening the door to mass government surveillance of the entire country and increases the danger that private information about citizens could be hacked.

headline: World (or at Least Brooklyn) Stops for Lost Dog

lead_paragraph: Bailey, a 2½-year-old goldendoodle, lived a placid, largely uneventful life on a block of handsome brownstones in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, until 7:15 on the morning of Oct. 24.

headline: After Trump, Fear and Gloating in Pakistan
abstract: Everything we already knew about ugly America just got a chest-thumping confirmation from Americans themselves.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — There is dread, and fear and loathing. But mostly there is gloating. Those who are gloating here in Pakistan have a convincing enough narrative: Everything we already knew about ugly America just got a chest-thumping confirmation from Americans themselves.

headline: Stella McCartney Presents Her Men’s Wear Line
abstract: Abbey Road Studios was the venue. And the designer said there was “a great deal” of the studios and her father, the ex-Beatle Paul McCartney, in the collection.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Stella McCartney has long been defined by fashion, music and her family name. So it was fitting that for the introduction of her first men’s wear collection last week, the 45-year-old British designer chose Abbey Road Studios, made legendary as the recording venue of choice for her father, Paul McCartney, and the rest of the Beatles during the 1960s.

headline: The Glass Ceiling Holds
abstract: Women are still marching on the long road toward the White House.
lead_paragraph: It took Hillary Clinton a while to talk about the first-woman-president idea. She didn’t stress it early in her 2008 campaign. But people kept coming up to her with pictures of their grandmothers who got to vote for the first time in 1920. Others begged her to get the job done so they could see a woman in the White House before they died.

headline: Zadie Smith on Dance: ‘It Brings Such Intense Joy’
abstract: The British writer — whose new novel, “Swing Time,” features two girls who dream of becoming professional dancers — discusses her love of the form and Fred Astaire.
lead_paragraph: Among the weighty subjects pondered by literary intellectuals, dance seldom rates very high. The dance critic Arlene Croce once started an essay with the quip, “World’s thinnest book: ‘English and American Literary Men Speak About the Dance.’” So it might come as a surprise that dance is at the heart of “Swing Time,” the fifth novel by one of today’s most prominent literary figures, the British writer Zadie Smith.

abstract: Embark on a home improvement project — or binge-watch HGTV — and you can easily get a little overwhelmed.

headline: Chatting With Bowie
abstract: A collection of interviews with David Bowie finds the rock star talking about literature, flashy clothes and Scientology.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, David Bowie published a widely circulated list of his 100 favorite books. William Burroughs was not among them, but the Beat writer did make an impression on the rock star. In 1974, Rolling Stone published a talk between the two at Bowie’s home in London. It’s one of several interviews collected in the recently published “David Bowie: The Last Interview and Other Conversations.” Bowie told Burroughs that his novel “Nova Express” “blew my head off,” noting similarities between it and his own futuristic creation, the concept-album character Ziggy Stardust: “Maybe we are the Rodgers and Hammerstein of the ’70s, Bill!”

headline: Some Review! Adam Gopnik on an E.B. White Biography for Kids
abstract: Melissa Sweet’s “Some Writer!” is a middle-grade biography of E.B. White, the New Yorker writer who was the author of classics like “Charlotte’s Web.”
lead_paragraph: An illustrated book for children about a writer who wrote children’s books with illustrations seems an oddly special and self-enclosed genre, but “Some Writer!,” Melissa Sweet’s book about the life and work of E.B. White, is still a pretty good one. Despite a title that feels a bit too coyly obvious — mirroring, as it does, the most famous line in White’s book “Charlotte’s Web,” where Charlotte the spider writes “Some Pig!” in her web to promote the doomed Wilbur — “Some Writer!” certainly will fulfill kids’ natural curiosity about the author of a “classic” that, unusual thing, still really works for them.

headline: Handouts With a Twist: Rebuilding America’s Infrastructure
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Income Tax', 'Income', 'Poverty', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Unemployment', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)']
abstract: Cash grants would fight poverty, but they are politically unpalatable. Tying them to jobs repairing infrastructure could sway voters to support them.
lead_paragraph: Describing the relentless pace at which machines were replacing horses a century ago, the economic historian Gregory Clark noted that if horses could have been hired at a certain price, they would have remained competitive. Unfortunately, he said, that price had dropped “so low that it did not pay for their feed.”

headline: Lush Morsels From an Artist’s Erotic Imagination
abstract: Marilyn Minter is a risk-taker who revels in depicting the range of our human desires.
lead_paragraph: “If I paint a glass of water, people think it’s erotic,” the artist Marilyn Minter said during a recent visit to her studio in New York’s Garment District. She laughed ruefully, but they’d have reason. Outrageously beautiful and irresistibly disturbing, Ms. Minter’s increasingly monumental paintings invoke a spectrum of human desires: for sex, food, affection and, hardly least, for being seen.

headline: Vice President-Elect Pence to Take Over Trump Transition Effort

abstract: Mr. Pence will take the reins from Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, who had been in charge of the transition for the past several months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President-elect Mike Pence will take over as the leader of Donald J. Trump’s transition effort, pushing aside Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey, as Mr. Trump moves quickly to assemble a government after his stunning upset victory, the transition team said on Friday.

headline: Bingo? Pass. Bring on Senior Speed-Dating and Wine-Tasting.
abstract: Senior centers have undergone profound changes in recent years to appeal to baby boomers who are living longer and expect more — much more.
lead_paragraph: NOTHING about Mather’s-More Than a Cafe looks as if it’s aimed at people over 50. But the Chicago cafe, which could easily be mistaken for a large Starbucks, is much more than that, serving as a community hub, mostly for older people, with dozens of classes on topics like flower arranging, Egyptian history and digital safety.

headline: 1964 | ‘Rightists Buoyed by the Election’

abstract: A front-page article 52 years ago predicted the rise of a strong conservative movement from what looked like a humiliating defeat.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

headline: Building a Cross Platform 360-degree Video Experience at The New York Times
keywords: ['3-D Devices and Effects', 'Android (Operating System)', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Open-Source Software', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: This month, we added support for 360-degree videos into our core news products — and today, we’re open sourcing our 360 video framework for iOS and 360 presets.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few months, 360-degree videos have gained a lot of traction on the modern web as a new immersive storytelling medium. The New York Times has continuously aimed to bring readers as close to stories as possible. Last year we released the NYT VR app with premium content on iOS and Android. We believe VR storytelling allows for a deeper understanding of a place, a person, or an event.

headline: David Plouffe: What I Got Wrong About the Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: I ran Obama’s 2008 campaign. Should I have known better this time?
lead_paragraph: Like many people around the world, I expected a comfortable Hillary Clinton victory on Tuesday. But I’m not a random pundit when it comes to understanding presidential races and the electorate — I managed one Obama presidential campaign and oversaw another from the White House. So of all the forecasts that got it wrong, my prediction that Mrs. Clinton was a 100 percent favorite was a glaring miss.

headline: The Election Highlighted a Growing Rural-Urban Split
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Urban Areas', 'Rural Areas', 'Voting and Voters', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The polarization between the prosperous urban regions and the rural areas where people feel left behind was sharply clear in Tuesday’s vote.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump fared very poorly in American cities in Tuesday’s election. Hillary Clinton did just as badly among rural voters. The political divide between the two groups has been growing more stark in America for years, and 2016 showed an even sharper split than 2012.

headline: The Long Haul
abstract: Retracting my recession call and more; this will take a while.
lead_paragraph: As I said in today’s column, nobody who thought Trump would be a disaster should change his or her mind because he won the election. He will, in fact, be a disaster on every front. And I think he will eventually drag the Republican Party into the abyss along with his own reputation; the question is whether he drags the rest of the country, and the world, down with him.

headline: Michelle Dockery Used to Be a Lady, Now She’s a Con Artist
abstract: The ‘Downton Abbey’ actress will take on the role of Letty Dobesh in ‘Good Behavior,’ which has its premiere on Nov. 15 on TNT.
lead_paragraph: For every “Downton Abbey” fan who longed for Lady Mary to let her bodice rip once and for all, Michelle Dockery has a series for you.

headline: Grappling With the Language of Love
keywords: ['ARABIC LANGUAGE', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: For an American woman falling in love with an Iraqi doctor in Syria, Arabic provides both a bridge and a source of frustration.
lead_paragraph: We often hear about how hard it is to be articulate in a foreign language, but when I began to study Arabic, what took me a long time to learn was not how to speak but how to listen.

headline: A Chirp From Under the Logs: The Fall Field Cricket
abstract: In all five boroughs, the little creature is often easier to identify with your ears than with your eyes.
lead_paragraph: As common as they are, field crickets often defy identification. Even experts resort to the plebeian measures any hiker might employ to recognize one; the plain fact is, crickets are often easier to identify with your ears than your eyes. So listening to a merry band of chirpsters singing from under a log in an empty field is often a simpler way to determine who’s calling than catching one, killing it and tacking it to a board for examination.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Trevor Noah
abstract: “Homegoing,” “Long Walk to Freedom,” “The Little Prince” and more.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is “The Daily Show” host Trevor Noah, whose new book, “Born a Crime: Stories from a South African Childhood” is out next week. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: ISIS Is Massacring Mosul Civilians as Troops Advance, U.N. Says
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The United Nations cited witness reports of the sporadic use of chemical agents and stepped-up killings, with bodies strung up around Mosul.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Islamic State militants have summarily killed scores of civilians in the Iraqi city of Mosul in recent days, sometimes using children as executioners, and have used chemical agents against Iraqi and Kurdish troops, United Nations officials said on Friday.

headline: A Time for Refusal
abstract: On the necessity of resisting the new normal.
lead_paragraph: It is a Sunday afternoon in a provincial town in France. Two men meet at a cafe. One of them, Berenger, is half-drunk. He is being berated by his companion, Jean. All of the sudden, they hear a great noise. When they and other townspeople crane their necks to figure out what’s going on, they see a large animal thundering down one of the streets, stamping and snorting all the way. A rhinoceros! Not long after, there’s another. They are startled. It’s outrageous. Something must be done. What they begin to do is argue heatedly about whether the second rhino was the first one going past a second time or a different one, and then about whether the rhinos are African or Asiatic.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: It could be a good time for pasta Bolognese — and maybe even a pre-Thanksgiving deep clean.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Glenn Beck: Don’t Move to Canada. Talk to the Other Side.

lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Our country is in trouble — we all feel it. The pendulum of division and hate is swinging faster. I think, in many ways unfortunately and regretfully, I am uniquely qualified to provide this message of warning and hope.

headline: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers
abstract: Michael Connelly, whose “The Wrong Side of Goodbye” is No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list, says: “I really wanted to go back to my elders with this book — the private eye novels and writers that inspired me.”
lead_paragraph: The Crime Beat: With his Harry Bosch detective novels, Michael Connelly has always harked consciously back to the glory days of Los Angeles crime writing. Once, he even rented the apartment where Raymond Chandler’s hero Marlowe lived in the 1973 film version of “The Long Goodbye.” So if you hear an echo of that title in the latest Bosch book, “The Wrong Side of Goodbye” (new at No. 2 in hardcover fiction), you’re not mistaken. “I really wanted to go back to my elders with this book — the private eye novels and writers that inspired me,” Connelly said via email. “The title, the opening in Pasadena, the missing-heir case, much of the book is a tip of the hat to writers like Chandler and Ross Macdonald.”

headline: Bartolo Colon Leaves Mets; Agrees to a Deal With the Braves
abstract: After three solid seasons of pitching for the Mets, Colon, 43, will continue the final stages of his logic-defying career in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: Late in January 2006, Bartolo Colon received the plaque for the American League Cy Young Award. At the time, the Dominican-born Colon was 32 and playing for the Los Angeles Angels, and the man who presented the award to him was Juan Marichal, the first Dominican player to be selected to baseball’s Hall of Fame.

headline: Trump and the Presidential Look
abstract: How the sheer weight of the office affects those who seek it.
lead_paragraph: The president-elect walked onto the stage before a crowd of euphoric supporters. It was his first public sighting since the networks called the election for him. Gone were his hoarse pleadings for support. His face bore a heaviness I had not seen from him before. Now he had won, and this was a different face.

headline: How Letting Bankers Off the Hook May Have Tipped the Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: When Donald J. Trump said the financial system was rigged, he tapped into a sentiment among many voters that powerful executives were being protected at their expense.
lead_paragraph: There are many facets to the populist, anti-establishment anger that swept Donald J. Trump into the White House in Tuesday’s election. A crucial element fueling the rage, in my view, was this: Not one high-ranking executive at a major financial firm was held to account for the crisis of 2008.

headline: Clarence M. Ditlow III, Auto Safety Crusader, Dies at 72
abstract: As head of the Center for Auto Safety, Mr. Ditlow exposed hundreds of automotive defects and was instrumental in forcing the recall of millions of vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Clarence M. Ditlow III, widely regarded as America’s foremost advocate for automotive safety, who championed seatbelts, airbags, electronics to avert crashes and campaigns to force the recall of millions of dangerously flawed motor vehicles, died Thursday night in Washington. He was 72.

abstract: At a tasting of 14 Barolos from the legendary 1964 vintage, the wines offer a snapshot of a region in transition.
lead_paragraph: To drink one 50-year-old wine as it evolves in the glass over the course of a meal can be an intensely personal, emotional journey. To taste 30 old bottles is overwhelming and, in the end, perhaps, a dreadful disservice to the wines and their long-departed makers.

headline: Stream the Debut Film From the Director of ‘Moonlight’ on Netflix
abstract: Monica Castillo looks at “Moonlight” director Barry Jenkins’s feature film debut, “Medicine for Melancholy.”
lead_paragraph: “Moonlight” has been rapturously received by audiences. The Miami-based drama about Chiron, a young, gay African-American boy, and his maturity into manhood has earned high marks from several critics, including The New York Times’s A. O. Scott, who called it “about as beautiful a movie as you are ever likely to see.” Only the second feature film from the director Barry Jenkins, the movie is filled with vibrant color, gorgeous uses of light and deep wells of emotion — fear, love and betrayal.

headline: Trump’s Climate Contrarian: Myron Ebell Takes On the E.P.A.
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has vowed to dismantle President Obama’s climate change policies. In Mr. Ebell, he may have found his man.
lead_paragraph: The mug-shot posters, pasted on walls and lampposts around Paris by an activist group during the United Nations climate talks last year, were hardly flattering. They depicted Myron Ebell, a climate contrarian, as one of seven “climate criminals” wanted for “destroying our future.”

headline: Before U.S. and Mexico Play, Fans Push for Respect in a Charged Atmosphere
abstract: Unusual feelings surround this World Cup qualifier, the most significant sporting event involving an American national team since the charged presidential election.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — On Friday night, just before the kickoff of a World Cup qualifying match against Mexico, the most ardent fans of the United States men’s national soccer team unveiled a giant graphical display, known as a tifo, at one end of Mapfre Stadium to show their support for the Americans.

headline: The Story So Far: Fiction Podcasts Take Their Next Steps
abstract: A young medium is learning a more sophisticated way to tell tales.
lead_paragraph: On one long August day, Eli Horowitz camped out in a cramped studio in Gowanus, Brooklyn, with Oscar Isaac, Catherine Keener, a microphone and a solitary Betta fish named Young Hollywood swimming laps around its little bowl. Mr. Horowitz was there to direct Ms. Keener and Mr. Isaac as they acted out the story of a strange and intimate relationship between a therapist and an army veteran who come together as part of a secretive — maybe even sinister — government program. Mr. Isaac played the vet, Ms. Keener the therapist. Young Hollywood served as scenery.

headline: Friday Mailbag: Politics, Politics, Politics
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Newspapers', 'News and News Media', 'Discrimination', 'Academic and Scientific Journals', 'Genetic Engineering']
abstract: With inaugurations on everyone’s mind, here’s another one: our new, weekly sampling of readers’ views.
lead_paragraph: In this new weekly feature, we will surface some of the more thoughtful and provocative concerns that come into our office. The public editor’s column can only address so much and, though we’ll reply to many of your comments, we unfortunately aren’t unable to reply personally to everything that lands in our inbox. By giving a weekly glimpse into our mailbag, we hope to give exposure to the fluctuating concerns of The Times’s audience — and in doing so, help facilitate a better conversation between the Gray Lady and her readers.

headline: Painful Steps Help Egypt Secure $12 Billion I.M.F. Loan
abstract: The loan is intended to avert the collapse of the economy, which has been crumbling since the 2011 uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The International Monetary Fund approved a $12 billion loan for Egypt on Friday, in a move intended to stave off economic collapse in the Arab world’s most populous nation as it grapples with a plunging currency, soaring inflation and shortages of staple foods.

headline: What Is Donald Trump’s Foreign Policy?

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump will enter the White House having promised to radically alter United States foreign policy, with ramifications for Americans and the world.

headline: How Tiffany Warren, an Executive at Omnicom Group, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The 42-year-old’s approach is all about self-care and having great conversations with friends.
lead_paragraph: As senior vice president and chief diversity officer of Omnicom Group, one of the biggest marketing, communications and advertising companies in the world, Tiffany R. Warren is the head of a team focused on advancing the careers of women, minorities and L.G.B.T. employees. And as founder and president of ADCOLOR, a nonprofit she started in 2005 to promote diversity in creative fields, she leads a community of professionals dedicated to helping one another and mentoring others. She is also a board member of GLAAD, the American Advertising Federation and the Ghetto Film School. On Sundays, Ms. Warren, 42, says, she is all about self-care. She lives in a five-bedroom house in the Claremont section of the Bronx.

headline: Two Would-Be Yankees Reacquaint Themselves With Baseball
abstract: After injuries, first baseman Greg Bird and pitcher James Kaprielian are using the Arizona Fall League to salvage a mostly lost year and prepare for 2017.
lead_paragraph: PEORIA, Ariz. — When Greg Bird gathered his equipment, getting a grip on his batting helmet, bat, batting gloves and a baseball proved a bit elusive. When he dropped a glove, he bent over to pick it up. As he did, he dropped a ball.

headline: Robert Vaughn, Who Starred as Napoleon Solo in ‘Man From U.N.C.L.E.,’ Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Vaughn reached the peak of his fame in the 1960s playing a debonair international agent.
lead_paragraph: Robert Vaughn, the cleft-chinned actor who reached the peak of his fame in the 1960s playing Napoleon Solo, the debonair international agent tasked with saving the world each week on the hit television series “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.,” died on Friday in Danbury, Conn. He was 83.

headline: The Fix | Small Spaces

abstract: How some have made the most of their tiny apartments.
lead_paragraph: How some have made the most of their tiny apartments.

headline: Getting Organized in a Tiny Apartment
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Storage', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Tips on making optimum use of small spaces.
lead_paragraph: As anyone who lives in a big city knows, space is a valuable commodity. Whether you’re in a minuscule studio or a Classic 6 with too few closets, there is rarely enough of it. Most of us try to make the best of what we’ve got, embracing our tiny kitchens and eking out storage where we can. But what do designers who specialize in small spaces — and those who have made an art form of living in them — know that the rest of us don’t? Below, some tips and tricks.

headline: Donald Trump Could Move From Deal Maker to Deal Slayer
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Mr. Trump has criticized AT&T’s planned merger with Time Warner and the merger of Comcast and NBCUniversal, and he may have a beef with big banks.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s election as the next president risks turning an era of mega-mergers into one of deal breakups by command.

headline: Owner Was Target, but Restaurant Workers Are Swept Up in Immigration Raids
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'Restaurants', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Immigration Detention', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Deportation']
abstract: Workers and their advocates fear that a workplace sweep in Buffalo last month could be a blueprint for future raids under President-elect Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Immigration enforcement agents were supposed to be targeting the restaurant owner. But Antonio Ramos Salazar, a cook, was the one with guns pointed at his head.

headline: Home Sweet Warehouse
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Small Business', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Vinicius Vieira de Vieira, 33, and Carolina Monteiro Vieira, 20, run a business out of their bedroom in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers who run home businesses seldom have the luxury of a spare room, let alone a garage, but all Vinicius Vieira de Vieira has is a 225-square-foot bedroom.

headline: Review: In Liz Gerring’s Latest, Words Dance, Too
abstract: In ‘(T)here to (T)here,’ language projections draw they eye away from the dancing and prompt reflection on split attention and changing relationships.
lead_paragraph: Liz Gerring’s “(T)here to (T)here” begins with what seems at first to be an eye exam for the audience. We enter the Jerome Robbins Theater at the Baryshnikov Arts Center to find the letters “DVSBLT” projected on the back wall. As two dancers arrive leaping, more letters fade in, spelling “DIVISIBILITI.”

headline: Rodrigo Duterte Takes Karaoke Diplomacy to Malaysia
abstract: Mr. Duterte, president of the Philippines, and Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia found time for a few songs at a state dinner, including “Wind Beneath My Wings.”
lead_paragraph: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines has a reputation for salty language. But at a state dinner in Malaysia on Friday, the leader — who once called President Obama a “son of a whore” — displayed a penchant for sappy melodies and dulcet tones.

headline: Parents Navigate Tears and Cheers as Kids React to Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Education (K-12)', 'Women and Girls', 'Parenting', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Parents on both sides of the vote try to find teachable moments in the sometimes unpleasant aftermath of a divisive election.
lead_paragraph: In the Roethle household in Leawood, Kan., the children woke up on Wednesday to a family celebration. Donald J. Trump was the new president. But the excitement came with an admonition “to be a good winner” and not to gloat about his win at school.

headline: 11 Fiction Podcasts Worth a Listen
abstract: As fiction podcasts increase in number and creativity, the medium has already produced several series worth hearing, including “The Truth,” “Limetown” and “Fruit.”
lead_paragraph: The fiction podcast is having a moment. But modern audio dramatists have been turning out intriguing scripted podcasts for several years, and they’re showing no signs of slowing down. Take a guided tour through the past, present and future of audio drama with these fictional standouts.

headline: Bidding to Own a Piece of David Bowie
abstract: The scene at a Sotheby’s auction of the musician’s art collection was filled by fans and memories.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Waiters held trays of Champagne-filled glasses on the landing. Enormous photographs of David Bowie stared or smiled out from the walls. The soundtrack from “Ziggy Stardust: The Motion Picture” played, and a dim blue light filled Sotheby’s auction rooms in London as guests strolled in on Thursday night for the first of three eagerly anticipated sales of some 350 works from Bowie’s art collection on behalf of his estate. (The auction, called “Bowie/Collector,” had two more sales on Friday.)

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there’s much more where these came from.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Some are facing a backlash after remarks that appeared to oppose or support his election.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s victory in the presidential race has presented some companies with a new challenge: how to find the right balance in their postelection messages to employees and customers.

headline: ‘Shooter’ Was Delayed After Real-Life Violence. As Shows Increasingly Are.
abstract: USA’s series, now making its debut, was postponed twice by gun killings in the news. How does a TV network make that decision? There’s no playbook.
lead_paragraph: In the opening scene of the USA drama “Shooter,” the barrel of a sniper’s rifle is pointed right at the viewer.

headline: Amid Tide of Red on Electoral Map, West Coast Stays Defiantly Blue
abstract: The region, which has prospered compared with much of the rest of the country, embraced Hillary Clinton and a slew of liberal policies on Election Day.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The West Coast has long prided itself as an engine for reinvention and progressive ideals, distinct from the rest of the country. But after Tuesday’s election, the states bordering the Pacific Ocean feel increasingly like an island unto its own.

headline: Johnny Cash, the Poet in Black
abstract: A collection of poems by Mr. Cash, edited by the poet Paul Muldoon, means to establish the country singer as a significant American literary figure.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before he died, Johnny Cash scrawled down eight short lines in a shaky hand, mortality clearly on his mind.

headline: Religious Right Believes Donald Trump Will Deliver on His Promises
abstract: Evangelical leaders said they are confident Mr. Trump will appoint a conservative Supreme Court justice, defund Planned Parenthood and stop requiring insurers to cover birth control.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump rarely goes to church, said he’s never sought forgiveness for his sins, and in his acceptance speech early Wednesday morning, never mentioned God.

headline: Why Did Facebook Say I Was Dead?
abstract: On Friday afternoon, Facebook started telling users that their pages had been memorialized. Then things got awkward.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever wondered what it would be like to attend your own funeral? On Friday, Facebook gave me that option by telling me that I was dead. Things got weirder when it also told me that most other people I knew were dead, too.

headline: Facebook Will Stop Some Ads From Targeting Users by Race
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Social Media']
abstract: Housing, employment and credit ads will no longer be able to use Facebook tools to exclude certain races. But other types of ads can still use them.
lead_paragraph: As Facebook has grown, so too has its ability to slice and dice the habits of its hundreds of millions of users, and offer them up to advertisers that want to reach specific groups for specific reasons.

headline: At Army, Winning Is No Longer a Jolt to the System
abstract: The 5-4 Cadets have sensed a shift in the program’s culture under their third-year coach, Jeff Monken, and they’ve set their sights on defeating Notre Dame on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — According to Edgar Allen Poe — the wide receiver from Tucson, not the macabre poet — a much brighter aura surrounds the Army football team this season, and not just because the Black Knights are finally winning more games than they lose.

lead_paragraph: Last week’s galas: Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering, Natural Resources Defense Council, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Apollo Circle and the Aspen Institute.

headline: November Nights
abstract: Last week’s galas: Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering, Natural Resources Defense Council, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Apollo Circle and the Aspen Institute.
lead_paragraph: News of the Trump victory was still sinking in as the black-tie circuit carried on. The Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering held its fall party, sponsored by Valentino, Nov. 9 at the Metropolitan Club. The Natural Resources Defense Council had its Night of Comedy benefit that night, with Seth Meyers and John Oliver offering comic relief. Also that night, the Metropolitan Museum of Art hosted its Apollo Circle benefit for younger supporters in the Temple of Dendur gallery. And on Nov. 3, the Aspen Institute honored Melinda Gates and Robert K. Steel at the Plaza Hotel.

headline: Review: ‘The Killing Season’ Examines Long Island Case
abstract: This eight-part documentary series looks at serial murders involving prostitutes, starting at Gilgo Beach on Long Island, but ranging far.
lead_paragraph: It was only a matter of time before the television trend of turning real-life murders into immersive docu-series found its way to the Long Island serial-killer case.

headline: Canada Today: Dams, Fiddles and That New Leader Next Door
abstract: Canadians like their hydroelectric power, but while it may address climate change concerns, it is not without its own issues.
lead_paragraph: Because many parts of Canada rely on electricity produced by dams, “hydro” is often synonymous with electrical power and electrical utilities. The country’s efforts to cut emissions linked to climate change have, not surprisingly, renewed interest in hydroelectricity. But demonstrations in Labrador last month and research led by a Nova Scotia native now at Harvard that was published this week highlighted an often overlooked consequence of hydro dams — mercury buildup in the water behind them. Without costly and time-consuming remediation, they can poison indigenous people who live downstream.

headline: Aileen Mehle, Gossip’s Grande Dame Known as ‘Suzy,’ Dies at 98
abstract: Millions of people read her column in newspapers across the country and knew her face from her regular appearances on the game show “What’s My Line.”
lead_paragraph: Aileen Mehle, who titillated readers with her rapier wit for five decades as “Suzy,” the glamorous, nationally syndicated grande dame of tabloid society gossip columnists, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 98.

headline: Dreaming Up a Mahler Symphony That Never Was
abstract: Leading the Berlin Philharmonic in pieces by Schoenberg, Webern and Berg, Simon Rattle invited the audience to imagine that the whole was a Mahler creation.
lead_paragraph: Mahler’s 11th Symphony? There is no such thing. Mahler didn’t really finish his 10th Symphony, which, aside from its great opening Adagio, was left in various states of sketchiness when he died in 1911.

headline: After Trump Win, Parallel Path Is Seen for Marine Le Pen of France’s Far Right
abstract: “It’s the emergence of a new world,” said Ms. Le Pen, the leader of the National Front party. “It’s the end of the 20th century.”
lead_paragraph: HÉNIN-BEAUMONT, France — It was a moment of intense French patriotism on a sunny Friday, Armistice Day. A band blared “La Marseillaise,” the national anthem. Shouts of “Vive la France!” filled the chilly November air. And there, too, was Marine Le Pen, leader of the far-right National Front party, beaming.

headline: Minorities Worry What a ‘Law and Order’ Donald Trump Presidency Will Mean
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Racial Profiling', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: His election was seen by many as a repudiation of the Black Lives Matter and similar protests and left questions about what policing would look like under him.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, Gwen Carr stood before a throbbing crowd at the Javits Center in Manhattan and talked about all the change Hillary Clinton would usher in.

headline: The American Thanksgiving: Hmong Egg Roll Stuffing

lead_paragraph: In Junction City, Wis., Diane Yang and her family cook Thanksgiving dinner for a large Hmong community and use egg roll filling to stuff their turkey.

lead_paragraph: In Nashville, the Tayyar family makes eprax, an elaborate layered Kurdish casserole, to go with the roast turkey and stuffing.

headline: Russia Isn’t Actually That Happy About Trump’s Victory
abstract: Even if Trump meant everything he said about Putin during the campaign — and that’s doubtful — repairing relations is unlikely.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Donald J. Trump’s shocking triumph in the American presidential election will have some unusual foreign-policy repercussions. During the campaign, Democrats frequently tried to damage Mr. Trump’s standing by claiming that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was working for and supporting the Republican nominee. Now many may believe that America’s huge political upset could even be described as a victory for the Kremlin.

abstract: Maggie Velasco, a resident of Miami, has created a pumpkin flan as a reminder of her childhood in Havana.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Velasco, a resident of Miami, has created a pumpkin flan as a reminder of her childhood in Havana.

abstract: In Canaan, N.Y., Francine Turone brines her turkey with cinnamon, cloves, allspice and juniper berries, a recipe inspired by her upbringing in Kingston, Jamaica.
lead_paragraph: In Canaan, N.Y., Francine Turone brines her turkey with cinnamon, cloves, allspice and juniper berries, a recipe inspired by her upbringing in Kingston, Jamaica.

abstract: For Thanksgiving, Nicole Ponseca makes bibingka, a Filipino cake with cheese and salted eggs baked in a banana leaf.
lead_paragraph: For Thanksgiving, Nicole Ponseca makes bibingka, a Filipino cake with cheese and salted eggs baked in a banana leaf.

lead_paragraph: Raghavan Iyer makes a vegetarian alternative to turkey for his Thanksgiving in Minneapolis: dudhi kofta curry, crisp Indian squash dumplings in a bright, ​gingery sauce.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Carolyn Ling, a physician in Carmel, Ind., prepares her Thanksgiving turkey in a rich glaze of fermented soybean paste, garlic, ginger, soy sauce and alliums galore.

lead_paragraph: In Manhattan, Maren Waxenberg makes blotkake, an airy Norwegian cream cake, layered with cloudberry preserves and whipped cream.

lead_paragraph: In Austin, Tex., Martha Beltrán makes a pan de jamón that reminds her of her time in Venezuela. She serves it alongside the turkey and roast vegetables.

lead_paragraph: Every Thanksgiving, Debbie Himmler, who lives in Cincinnati, makes her grandmother’s German rotkraut: red cabbage with red wine and apples.

lead_paragraph: Ayaan and Idyl Mohallim’s grandmother taught them to cook Bariis iskukaris, an elegant Somali rice dish flavored with a mix of sweet brown spices and turmeric.

lead_paragraph: In New Jersey, Lisa and Carmela Conte make a spinach stuffing at Thanksgiving that is adapted from traditional Italian fillings for pasta and game birds.

lead_paragraph: In Atlanta, Erika Council makes a stockpot of pork neck bones as a reflection of the food cooked in the kitchens of enslaved Africans.

headline: An Appraisal: Leonard Cohen, Master of Meanings and Incantatory Verse
abstract: With every line Mr. Cohen shared, implicitly and in his lyrics, there was a humbling knowledge of mortality.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Cohen, who was 82 when he died on Monday, was young once. That can be hard to remember after his years of public, silver-haired eminence: touring arenas while he was in his 70s and playing leisurely three-hour-plus shows that seemed to slow down time itself. He intoned his songs with serene gravity, revealing once again how carefully chiseled every one of his quatrains is. And with every line he shared, implicitly and in his lyrics, there was a humbling knowledge of mortality: one that grows even more significant on Mr. Cohen’s final studio album, “You Want It Darker,” which was released less than a month ago.

headline: Republicans Expand Control in a Deeply Divided Nation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)', 'Governors (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Elections, Governors']
abstract: The nation may be almost evenly split between Democrats and Republicans, but Republicans now control almost every level of government
lead_paragraph: SOMERS, Wis. — It is the stunning paradox of American politics. In a bitterly divided nation, where Tuesday’s vote once again showed a country almost evenly split between Democrats and Republicans, one party now dominates almost everything in American governance.

headline: Why ‘Def Comedy Jam’ Gets No Respect
abstract: As HBO presents “All Def Comedy,” it’s time to set the record straight on its 1990s predecessor. A lot more was happening than just four-letter words.
lead_paragraph: Before “Veep,” “Curb Your Enthusiasm” and “Sex and the City,” there was “Def Comedy Jam,” one of the first hit comedies on HBO, often beating its network competition in ratings on Friday nights throughout much of the 1990s.

headline: Review: Judy Collins’s Clear, Pure Brook of Song
abstract: Ms. Collins’s latest engagement at Café Carlyle emphatically shows that her pristine soprano is undiminished.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost unheard-of for a pop soprano in her 70s to surpass her younger self in stamina, precision of intonation and vocal command. But that was what Judy Collins, 77, did at Thursday’s opening-night show of her latest engagement at Café Carlyle. The evening was particularly intense because of the death of her friend Leonard Cohen, which she only acknowledged after a performance that culminated with a somber rendition of his love song “Suzanne.” Her 1966 recording put him on the songwriting map.

headline: Donald Trump, Leonard Cohen, Mosul: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘Shut In’ (Naomi Watts Should Really Get Out More)
abstract: Ms. Watts plays a widowed child psychologist in a big, rambling house with one boy in a vegetative state and another who may be a ghost.
lead_paragraph: If you’re in any doubt as to the dearth of decent movie roles available to women of a certain age — certain never to see 40 again, at any rate — then buy a ticket for “Shut In.” In this achingly inept thriller, you will see Naomi Watts do what she can to sell a plot of such preposterousness that the derisory laughter around me began barely 20 minutes in.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors. Today, stories from our political team about the rise of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: A Reporter Who’s ‘Not in Kansas Anymore’ Suddenly Is
abstract: There are those who stay and those who go. My friend Sheree wanted to stay and I wanted to go. It could easily have been the other way around.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Anemona Hartocollis, a higher education reporter for The Times’s national desk, shares what it was like for her to return to Topeka High School — a journalist now, on assignment — for the first time since she graduated.

headline: ‘We Couldn’t Believe Our Eyes’: A Lost World of Shipwrecks Is Found
abstract: Archaeologists have found more than 40 vessels in the Black Sea, some more than a millennium old, shedding light on early empires and trade routes.
lead_paragraph: The medieval ship lay more than a half-mile down at the bottom of the Black Sea, its masts, timbers and planking undisturbed in the darkness for seven or eight centuries. Lack of oxygen in the icy depths had ruled out the usual riot of creatures that feast on sunken wood.

headline: Letter From Gwen Carr, Eric Garner’s Mother, to Loretta Lynch
abstract: On Tuesday night, Ms. Carr began writing a letter to Ms. Lynch, the attorney general, pleading with her to quickly decide how to proceed with the case of her son, who died in July 2014 after being placed in a chokehold by a police officer in Staten Island, before Mr. Trump takes office. “Please hear my cry, don’t allow my son’s words and our tears to be in vain,” Ms. Carr wrote before sending it off Friday morning.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, Ms. Carr began writing a letter to Ms. Lynch, the attorney general, pleading with her to quickly decide how to proceed with the case of her son, who died in July 2014 after being placed in a chokehold by a police officer in Staten Island, before Mr. Trump takes office. “Please hear my cry, don’t allow my son’s words and our tears to be in vain,” Ms. Carr wrote before sending it off Friday morning.

headline: No, Birth Control Coverage Won’t Go Away
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Women and Girls', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The new administration could make it harder to get low-cost contraception. But there’s no need to panic about the short term.
lead_paragraph: Hours after Tuesday’s election results were final, tweets, Facebook messages and articles began bouncing around the internet urging women to go seek birth control right away. “Get an IUD Before It’s Too Late,” advised a Daily Beast headline. “Here’s Why Everyone Is Saying to Get an IUD Today,” explained a popular New York Magazine piece.

headline: Chuck Schumer Backs Minnesota Liberal for Democratic Party Chairman
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The presumptive incoming Democratic Senate leader threw his weight behind Representative Keith Ellison as the party enters a period of postelection jockeying.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After his party’s brutal Election Day loss, Senator Chuck Schumer, the presumptive incoming Democratic minority leader, threw his support on Friday behind a liberal member of Congress to be the next chairman of the Democratic National Committee.

headline: In a Further Blow to Democrats, Republicans Increase Their Hold on State Governments
abstract: Republicans will control the governor’s office and both chambers of the state legislature in four more states — Iowa, Kentucky, Missouri and New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Republicans will control the governor’s office and both chambers of the state legislature in four more states — Iowa, Kentucky, Missouri and New Hampshire.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Fractures Arm, Putting Her World Cup Season in Question
abstract: Vonn announced on her Facebook page that she had “severely fractured” the humerus bone of her right arm in a training crash on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: For the fourth time in the last five winters, a serious injury will interrupt Lindsey Vonn’s ski racing season. Vonn announced Friday on her Facebook page that she had “severely fractured” the humerus bone of her right arm in a training crash on Thursday.

headline: Trump’s Changes to the Tax Codes May Encourage Dynastic Wealth
keywords: ['Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Philanthropy', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Donald J. Trump has proposed repealing much of the estate law and the tax benefits of philanthropy, giving wealthy families incentives to hold on to their money.
lead_paragraph: If Donald J. Trump follows through on his campaign promises, a host of taxes that affect only the very richest Americans may be eliminated, along with almost all tax incentives to be philanthropic. As a result, wealthy families may find it much easier to amass dynastic levels of wealth.

headline: You Must Serve Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: For public servants who fear how Trump might govern, there is a moral responsibility to serve.
lead_paragraph: Of all the conservatives who opposed Donald Trump during his campaign for the presidency, his most vehement opponents were the men and women who had served in past Republican administrations, and particularly in the departments of state and of defense. One hundred and twenty-two Republican foreign policy hands signed a letter denouncing Trump as a menace to American values and world peace. George W. Bush’s C.I.A. director, Michael Hayden, suggested that Trump was a useful idiot for Russian interests. Both neoconservatives and realists — Robert Kagan and Paul Wolfowitz, Brent Scowcroft and Richard Armitage — indicated that they would vote for Hillary Clinton.

headline: South Korean President’s Leadership Style Is Seen as Factor in Scandal
abstract: Officials who have raised alarms about President Park Geun-hye’s adviser have paid a price, and opponents of the leader point to similarities to her father’s dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A police detective who worked in the South Korean president’s office filed a report in 2014 accusing relatives and associates of an unofficial presidential adviser of meddling in state affairs.

headline: Season Is Almost Over, but Marin Cilic’s Work Is About to Begin
abstract: After big wins and tough losses, his year ends with the ATP World Tour Finals in London and then the Davis Cup final at home in Croatia.
lead_paragraph: This year, it is Marin Cilic’s turn to push his limits in November.

headline: Civic Masterpieces, and Nightmares, Unrealized
abstract: A new book presents a catalog of dashed dreams and dodged nightmares once planned for the New York landscape.
lead_paragraph: Most nonfiction books these days are emblazoned with audacious titles that demand an explanatory underline. “Never Built New York” (Metropolis Books, $55) doesn’t need one.

headline: Bernie Sanders: Where the Democrats Go From Here
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Trump’s victory is saddening, but not surprising.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans registered a protest vote on Tuesday, expressing their fierce opposition to an economic and political system that puts wealthy and corporate interests over their own. I strongly supported Hillary Clinton, campaigned hard on her behalf, and believed she was the right choice on Election Day. But Donald J. Trump won the White House because his campaign rhetoric successfully tapped into a very real and justified anger, an anger that many traditional Democrats feel.

headline: After Election, Commander in Chief Soothes White House Workers
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Mr. Obama told his dejected staff members: “You don’t need hope when things are going well. You need it when things are not going well.”
lead_paragraph: There has been weeping at West Wing staff meetings and a series of presidential pep talks, a tear-jerker of a Rose Garden gathering and anguished conversations about what will happen to President Obama’s legacy and the job prospects of his aides.

headline: Mike Pence Emerging as a Commanding Figure in Trump Administration
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Mr. Pence, a former congressman, is also emerging as the chief conduit between Capitol Hill and the White House. Comparisons with Dick Cheney are already being made.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President-elect Mike Pence made his name as a relentless conservative critic of the federal government. Soon he will essentially be running it.

headline: Megyn Kelly’s Book Sheds New Light on Fox Inquiry Into Roger Ailes
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Sexual Harassment', 'News and News Media', 'Television']
abstract: Ms. Kelly writes about how she may have ensured that the investigation into Mr. Ailes’s behavior was a genuine one that he was not able to impede.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that Megyn Kelly played a role in Roger Ailes’s ouster as the chief executive of Fox News after she, and others, accused him of sexual harassment.

headline: Corey Lewandowski, Donald Trump’s Former Campaign Manager, Leaves CNN
abstract: Mr. Lewandowski joined the cable news network in June in a deal denounced by some as a violation of journalistic ethics. He is reportedly interested in a job in the Trump administration.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s former campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, resigned on Friday from his role as a CNN political commentator, ending a television deal that had attracted scrutiny and harsh criticism about the cable channel’s journalistic ethics.

headline: Donald Trump Likely to End Aid for Rebels Fighting Syrian Government
abstract: He said that the United States should focus on defeating the Islamic State, and find common ground with the Syrians and their Russian backers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump said Friday that he was likely to abandon the American effort to support “moderate” opposition groups in Syria who are battling the government of President Bashar al-Assad, saying “we have no idea who these people are.”

headline: World Chess Championship Kicks Off With V.I.P. Treatment
abstract: The 12-game match pits the champion, Magnus Carlsen of Norway, against the Russian challenger, Sergey Karjakin. And Woody Harrelson was there too.
lead_paragraph: The long recovery of Lower Manhattan from Hurricane Sandy advanced a step on Friday with the start of the World Chess Championship, the first championship in the United States since 1995, at the Fulton Market Building. The 12-game match, which is scheduled to run until the end of the month, pits the champion, Magnus Carlsen of Norway, 25, against the Russian challenger, Sergey Karjakin, 26, who disheartened many American chess fans by defeating two higher-rated American players in the qualifying tournament in March.

headline: A Newcomer Fits Rangers’ Prototype for the Fast Track
abstract: Michael Grabner, speedy winger, has enabled the Rangers to become the highest scoring team in the league.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers used to have another player just like Michael Grabner. His name was Carl Hagelin.

headline: Reports of Bias-Based Attacks Tick Upward After Election
abstract: Civil rights groups say their inboxes and call centers are lighting up with reports of abuse, but caution that it’s too soon to say whether the trend will last.
lead_paragraph: In New York, men shouted, “You’re next!” at a black policewoman, making shooting motions with their hands. In California, a high school student told a classmate, “You support Trump? You hate Mexicans!” before throwing her to the ground and hitting her. Online, anonymous users wrote on Twitter, “Just reported you to ICE. Expect a van at your door tomorrow” to illegal immigrants.

headline: Donald Trump Prepares for White House Move, but His Tower May Still Beckon
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: As Mr. Trump prepares to assume the presidency, an open question remains about the capital he spurned: Just how much is he willing to become a part of it?
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump won the White House with an outsider’s populist promise to “drain the swamp” of Washington.

headline: I’m Muslim, but My Roommate Supports Trump
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Did she really expect me to respect her choice when it undermined my presence in this country, in this university, in my very own dorm room?
lead_paragraph: When she outed herself to me as a Trump supporter, I realized I had finally found the “silent majority.” I looked at her, this suddenly strange girl who sleeps a few feet away from me, my college roommate. The silent majority has seen me put on my head scarf in the morning and take it off at night. The silent majority has touched my face, done my makeup, watches “Gilmore Girls” religiously. The silent majority occasionally enjoys sliced mango before bed.

headline: Cella Irvine, Digital Media Pioneer Who Led About.com, Dies at 59
abstract: She broke ground in a male-dominated field in corporate roles and as a founding board member and chairwoman of the nonprofit New York New Media Association.
lead_paragraph: Cella Irvine, a Silicon Alley pioneer who led About.com and other new media companies in New York starting in the early 1990s, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 59.

headline: Phil Jackson’s Role for a Night: Film Critic
keywords: ['Movies', 'Basketball', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: The president of the Knicks said that “Chinatown,” “Hoosiers,” “Rear Window” and “The Searchers” were his four favorite films.
lead_paragraph: As he walked onto a darkened stage Thursday night with that bone-sore amble of his, Phil Jackson, the president of the Knicks, might as well have been trailed by angry producers waving critical notices.

headline: How Federal Ethics Laws Will Apply to a Trump Presidency
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s financial dealings and vast web of businesses pose a number of potential conflicts as he prepares to lead the country.
lead_paragraph: Over the next few weeks, Donald J. Trump will be deep in the throes of selecting cabinet members, reviewing potential Supreme Court justices and deciding on the top priorities for his new administration.

headline: What Trump Exposed About the G.O.P.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The party’s appeal has been based on identity over ideology.
lead_paragraph: The election of Donald J. Trump will bring as sharp a turn to the right as this country has seen since at least the election of Ronald Reagan — thanks mainly to the rare conservative control of Congress, the presidency and, before long, the Supreme Court.

headline: What Europe Needs to Hear from Trump
abstract: America’s strongest allies expect a clear commitment to the trans-Atlantic security partnership.
lead_paragraph: Munich — America owes Donald J. Trump an open mind and a chance to lead, Hillary Clinton said on Wednesday. So does Europe.

headline: Trump’s Racial Time Machine
abstract: Black Americans woke to a world they hoped they’d never see again.
lead_paragraph: On Election Day, while Americans were at the polls putting democracy to work, a black graduate student came to my university office to talk about race and time travel. This young man grew up in a fairly disadvantaged neighborhood, in a fairly disadvantaging city, in a very disadvantaging nation — all the result of our shared history of slavery and institutional inequality that allows American cops to choke blacks on Youtube and go home and play with the kids.

headline: Solemnity and Defiance Dominate England-Scotland World Cup Qualifier
abstract: Fans of the bitter soccer rivals grew quiet to remember war dead on Armistice Day, but the before and the after was anything but reverent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As soon as the bugle picked out the first, plaintive note of the Last Post, Wembley Stadium seemed to freeze.

headline: The World Waits and Wonders About Donald Trump
abstract: The president-elect would do well to recognize the profound concern of Western democracies used to seeing America as a beacon for progress and stability.
lead_paragraph: The forces that brought Donald Trump to victory were largely American. The repercussions of his election, however, have rocked Western democracies accustomed to seeing the United States as a beacon for democracy, progress and stability. If the president-elect wants to take seriously his responsibilities as head of the free world, he should waste no time in making clear how much of his campaign bluster was just that.

headline: Duet
abstract: David J. Kahn sets a cruciverbal trap for us.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If you found yourself floundering in the center of today’s puzzle, there’s a good reason for it. All I’ll say, in the interest of not giving it away here, is that punctuation matters.

headline: Schoolchildren Left Behind
abstract: In 23 states, school funding is effectively lower now than in 2008, when the recession ravaged budgets. For many children, the harm will be permanent.
lead_paragraph: Politicians and voters often say they want better schools, but that doesn’t mean they’re willing to pay for them. Voters this week largely rejected attempts to increase school spending through ballot initiatives.

headline: Leonard Cohen, Vital to the End
abstract: How wondrous to have known a singer so literate, a writer so musical.
lead_paragraph: News of the death of Leonard Cohen, musical poet and great Canadian, hit on Thursday like a punch to the gut, an early blast of winter. We can do the Leonard Cohen thing and brood. Or we can heed this spontaneous eulogy from another of our most admired songwriters, Rosanne Cash. “Rolling through Iowa,” she said on Twitter on Friday afternoon, “in wonder and awe that we had such a man.”

headline: The Supermoon and Other Moons That Are Super in Their Own Ways
abstract: To the casual observer, the coming week’s supermoon won’t look that special. Here’s a look at what causes the supermoon and other lunar phenomena.
lead_paragraph: Shrug off the supermoon.

headline: Protests of Trump’s Election Continue Into Third Day
abstract: Thousands took part in demonstrations across the country that often blocked traffic.
lead_paragraph: For the third day in a row since Donald J. Trump was elected president, thousands of people took part in protests that bloomed across the country, venting their frustration at the election results.

headline: 2016 Election Thank You Notes
abstract: To James Comey, Anthony Weiner and all my friends in the media: We couldn’t have done this without you.
lead_paragraph: Such a surprise! So many people to thank!

headline: Quotation of the Day

Almost 1,200 of you responded. Here are some of your stories.

He did not stay up to see Barack Obama win the presidency in 2008, or watch in 2000 as the margin of votes separating George W. Bush and Al Gore in Florida shrank to the vanishing point.

headline: Petworth, Washington, D.C.: A Place of Porches
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Petworth, a neighborhood in the District of Columbia, is popular with young families — and flippers.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, Robert H. Mandle and his wife, Maria, were living in an apartment in Arlington, Va., and shopping for a single-family home. They were shown a 1919 three-bedroom townhouse in Petworth, a centrally situated neighborhood in the District of Columbia. The 1,775-square-foot house on Rock Creek Church Road NW was at the end of a row of attached buildings, which meant it had abundant light. And then there was the charming fact that President Lincoln had spent his summers across the road. But the property, which was listed at more than $400,000, needed cosmetic improvements and seemed expensive for the amount of space.

headline: Recalling the Horror at the Bataclan
abstract: Ninety people were killed in a terrorist attack at the Paris concert hall on Nov. 13, 2015. Daniel Psenny heard the shots and leaned into the street. Listen as he describes the chaos that night.

headline: What Is a TinyLetter? Like Ye Olde Blog, but Less Public
abstract: Remember that yearly update you used to get from your aunt? Now it’s from your friends and colleagues, every week, and they can see if you’ve read it.
lead_paragraph: “If there’s one silver lining in this whole thing: Donald Trump has cured my Impostor Syndrome,” Maris Kreizman, the editorial director of the Book of the Month Club, wrote this past week in her personal email newsletter, “The Maris Review.” “If he thinks he’s qualified to run this country, I can do whatever I want.”

headline: Is Fashion’s Love Affair With Washington Over?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For the last eight years, designers have had a seat at the White House power table. The Trump administration may herald an end to all that.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, when Hillary Clinton stood in the New Yorker Hotel for her farewell speech, she did so in one of her signature Ralph Lauren pantsuits. Dark gray, with purple lapels and a matching purple shirt (and a matching purple tie for Bill Clinton), it underscored, as so many of her fashion choices did in the run-up to the election, a point: the way two colors/factions — red and blue — can unite to make something new.

headline: Cold in Your Hotel Room? By Voice or Tablet, You Can Change That
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Tablet Computers', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: With voice commands and tablets, you can close the drapes and turn out the lights in your hotel room without getting out of your bed or chair.
lead_paragraph: Need to dial down the thermostat in the middle of the night? Want to open the curtains at daybreak? How about turning out the hall light at bedtime? These are some of the tasks that no longer require you to get out of bed in the new generation of automated hotel rooms.

Trump pulled off an upset win, it would create a classic panic reaction: a drop in stocks and other risky assets and a rally in bonds and other safe-haven assets.

keywords: ['Detainees', 'Interrogations', 'Torture', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Doctors', 'Series']

Shay Rosecrans crossed into the military detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, she tucked her medical school class ring into her bra, covered the name on her uniform with tape and hid her necklace under her T-shirt, especially if she was wearing a cross.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: When the Tech Industry Lives in a Bubble
abstract: The presidential election underscores a problem for the tech industry: that a small group of people designs products the entire world uses, perhaps stifling diversity of thought.

headline: Pet Allergies in a Pet-Friendly Building
abstract: Can those allergic to cats and dogs expect accommodations in buildings where pets are welcome?
lead_paragraph: Q. I live in a pet-friendly co-op in Riverdale, in the Bronx. Unfortunately, I am highly allergic to dogs and cats. When pet owners wash their pets’ clothes and bedding in the common laundry room, some of them do not clean out the hair from the lint catchers in the dryers, leaving me to clean it out. This has triggered several allergic reactions. When I asked the board to set aside specific washers and dryers for the pet paraphernalia, it refused, saying pet owners should have unlimited access to all machines. Do any city rules address this problem? And what can be done to mitigate my problem?

He sometimes sees dolphins swimming in the waters below, which he considers “pretty cool.” He also likes to check in with peers back home who are preparing for classes as college freshmen.
