headline: Paris: One Year On
abstract: This is the story of the Paris attacks by those who lived through them. “I will always live with the fact that I saw ringing cellphones that said ‘Papa,’ ‘Maman,’ on the dead.”
lead_paragraph: The night of Nov. 13, 2015, Islamic State militants attacked eight places in and around Paris, killing 130 people and wounding nearly 500. It was the most lethal attack in France since World War II. Confusion gripped the city as two teams of attackers struck nearly simultaneously. One struck at the Stade de France, just outside Paris, while the other shot up cafes and bars in the hip 10th and 11th Arrondissements. About 20 minutes later, a third team of attackers entered the Bataclan concert hall in the same neighborhood, taking hostages and killing scores.

headline: With Federer and Nadal Sidelined, Some See the End of an Era
abstract: Both say they will return to play in January, but injuries to top players give tennis fans a glimpse of what’s to come.

headline: Why You Should Always Lock Your Hotel Room Door!
abstract: How my day began, with an intruder in my hotel room.
lead_paragraph: My wife Sheryl WuDunn and I are in Philadelphia for a meeting of the American Philosophical Society, and this morning at about 7 I went down to the Franklin Hotel lobby to grab a cup of coffee. Sheryl was sleeping, so to reduce the sound I closed the door but didn’t quite let it lock. A man emerged from somewhere at about the same time and also seemed to be waiting for the elevator, but when it came he said that he was waiting for his wife and I should go ahead.

headline: The Varieties of Anger
abstract: We are a divided country, but we are united by rage.
lead_paragraph: Bitterness. Hostility. Rage. The varieties of anger are endless. Some are mild, such as grumpiness, and others are powerful, such as wrath. Different angers vary not only in their intensity but also in their purpose. It’s normal to feel exasperated with your screaming infant and scornful of a political opponent, but scorn toward your baby would be bizarre.

headline: When Borders Close
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Protectionism (Trade)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: An extraordinary period of globalization has ended. The period from World War I through World War II offers lessons for what might come next.
lead_paragraph: The age of globalization generated great prosperity. As the flow of goods, money and people across borders surged, millions benefited. But the elite gained the most. And as inequality rose, it stirred pockets of fierce resentment among those left behind. When the great shock came, the discontented turned to nationalist firebrands, who promised to impose controls on free trade, global banks and immigrants. Globalization stalled. A new age of deglobalization hit full stride.

headline: He Made America Feel Great Again
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2020']
abstract: Scenes from a triumphant Trump first term.
lead_paragraph: While I cannot verify its provenance, the following appears to be my Sunday column from Nov. 8, 2020, which slipped through a small rift in the space-time continuum while I was writing a panicked, “It’s the Trump Apocalypse!” column this week.

headline: When Republicans Take Power
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How does a party that views government as the enemy actually begin to govern?
lead_paragraph: Washington — On the morning of Nov. 8, Republicans in the nation’s capital were grim-faced and resigned to Hillary Clinton’s impending triumph, hoping only that Donald J. Trump wouldn’t lose so badly as to cost the party the Senate. By midnight they were in ecstasy, as it became apparent that Mr. Trump would take the presidency and Republicans would maintain majorities in both houses of Congress. A few months from now, it’s all but certain that Mr. Trump will nominate, and the Senate will confirm, a new conservative Supreme Court justice. At that point, Republicans will control all three branches of government.

headline: A Better Way to Safe Cosmetics
abstract: Readers respond to “Selling Shampoo, Eye Cream and a Chemical Crackdown” (Oct. 9).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What’s the Use of Regret?
abstract: We can’t change past actions, but we can change ourselves.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago I was sitting poolside in Florida with a friendly retiree who was standing in the warm aqua water, beaming with friendliness. We started chatting, first about his hometown, Pittsburgh, and the many great athletes from there. Soon the conversation pivoted to Vietnam and his experiences as a draftee there. Embarrassed because I was spared from that jungle and moral crucible, I just listened. First it was a few madcap stories about his arrival in ’Nam, but then his thoughts swam along a darker current.

headline: The Danger of Going Soft on Russia
abstract: Will Donald Trump, who has been Vladimir Putin’s apologist, change his tune in the White House?
lead_paragraph: Among the first world leaders to congratulate President-elect Donald Trump was Vladimir Putin. And why shouldn’t he?

headline: What Whiteness Means in the Trump Era
abstract: Being white is no longer the assumed default; it is a conscious racial category.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump campaigned on the slogan “Make America Great Again,” a phrase whose “great” was widely heard as “white.” Certainly the election has been analyzed as a victory for white Christian Americans, especially men. Against Mr. Trump were all the rest of us: professionals with advanced degrees and the multiracial, multiethnic millions.

headline: Gretchen Carlson: My Fight Against Sexual Harassment
abstract: Since my story went public, I’ve heard from many women about their painful experiences.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never been a good sleeper, but now more than ever, after having lost my job as a news anchor this past summer, I find myself lying awake at night thinking about my daughter — and your daughters, too. I’ve been asking myself this simple question: Will our girls finally be the ones to have workplaces free from sexual harassment? This question became even more compelling during the presidential race, where offensive comments about women were dismissed as “locker room talk.”

headline: Obama Lobbies Against Obliteration by Trump
abstract: How can Barack Obama not understand the Obama revolution?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — YOU know how desperate President Obama is — as he contemplates all his accomplishments going down the drain at the hands of a man he has total contempt for — when he is willing to do something so against his nature.

headline: What About the Customers?
abstract: Readers respond to “An $85 Billion Bet That an Empire Can Rise Again” (Oct. 30).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Doll in the Blue Pantsuit
abstract: When a girl is too little to understand what happened, but big enough to create another reality.
lead_paragraph: We got the Hillary Clinton doll sometime last spring. My wife saw it in the window of a toy store in our neighborhood and thought it would be amusing to give to our 2-year-old daughter, Sami.

headline: After a Fraught Election, Questions Over the Impact of a Balky Voting Process
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters', 'Voting Machines', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: The first presidential election after parts of the Voting Rights Act were struck down in 2013 left analysts to wonder whether a different process might have changed the outcome of the race.
lead_paragraph: So few Americans cast ballots that a new president was elected by barely a quarter of Americans eligible to vote. Some of those who did vote waited in line for hours. Others were told they needed an ID to vote under a law the courts had nullified months ago — and sometimes, under laws that never existed to begin with.

headline: In Brazil, Inward-Looking Investors Eye Opportunities Outside
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Investments', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Spurred by the country’s worst recession in decades, some investors are looking to Silicon Valley, India and beyond.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — It is said that “Cariocas,” people from Rio de Janeiro, like to think that the world comes to them, and that was certainly the case over the last several years as Brazil commanded the global stage like never before.

headline: Protesters Take Anti-Trump Message to His Doorstep, and Plan Next Steps
abstract: Beyond the commotion in the streets, liberal activists are preparing legislative challenges and getting ready to support social services they assume will be gutted.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators filled public squares, parks and streets in the country’s three largest cities on Saturday to protest President-elect Donald J. Trump, part of a wave of dissent that has swelled since the presidential contest last week.

headline: Hillary Clinton Blames F.B.I. Director for Election Loss
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton said on Saturday that the announcement by James B. Comey 11 days before the election that he had revived the inquiry into her use of a private email server caused her to lose.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton on Saturday cast blame for her surprise election loss on the announcement by the F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, days before the election that he had revived the inquiry into her use of a private email server.

headline: A Global Investor, Concerned by World Politics
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Foreign Investments', 'Science and Technology', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Nicolas Berggruen, once known as the “homeless billionaire,” sees opportunity in emerging markets and technology, shadowed by populist movements.
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Berggruen is a German-American investor and philanthropist. For years, he was known as the “homeless billionaire,” for his peripatetic life in which he lived in fine hotels around the world but did not own a home.

headline: Bombing at Sufi Shrine in Pakistan Kills Dozens
abstract: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack, which killed at least 52 people and wounded at least 100, though some Pakistani officials were skeptical that the group had been involved.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A powerful bomb blast ripped through a Sufi shrine in southwestern Pakistan on Saturday evening, killing at least 52 people and wounding at least 100 others, officials said.

headline: South Koreans Rally in Largest Protest in Decades to Demand President’s Ouster
abstract: Hundreds of thousands gathered in central Seoul to call for Park Geun-hye’s resignation after a scandal involving an unofficial adviser.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In one of the largest anti-government protests in recent decades, hundreds of thousands of South Koreans filled central Seoul on Saturday to demand the resignation of President Park Geun-hye, whose administration has been paralyzed by a scandal involving an unofficial presidential adviser.

headline: Brain Implant Eases Communication by Late-Stage A.L.S. Patient
abstract: A system that links neural signals to computer software allows a woman from the Netherlands to spell out two or three words a minute and convey immediate needs.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have designed a system that lets a patient with late-stage Lou Gehrig’s disease type words using brain signals alone.

headline: Canada Is in an Economic Slump, but Some Investors Are Hopeful
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: For a nation dependent on natural resources, the global downturn around oil and other commodities hurt, but Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s plan to spur growth has buoyed optimism.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — An array of factors makes Canada seem like a less-than-attractive place to invest these days.

headline: Obama’s Policies and Broader Vision Face Reckoning With History
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The president’s place in history looks considerably different than a week ago. Can the transformation he envisioned survive his administration?
lead_paragraph: As he raced across the country before the election, President Obama warned supporters about the stakes. “All the progress we’ve made over these last eight years,” he said, “goes out the window if we don’t win this election.”

headline: Conor McGregor Delivers Knockout in U.F.C.’s New York Debut
abstract: McGregor became the first man to hold two Ultimate Fighting Championship belts at the same time when he unseated lightweight champ Eddie Alvarez at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Conor McGregor, the brash Irishman who is the world’s biggest mixed martial arts star, became the first man to hold two Ultimate Fighting Championship belts at the same time when he unseated lightweight champ Eddie Alvarez at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

headline: In Murky Russia, One Investor Finds Value in Thinking Small
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Nationalization of Industry', 'Private Equity', 'Small Business']
abstract: Aleksei Kozlov said the shifting risk picture has prompted his private equity firm to invest in smaller businesses not so easily seized by the state.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — There’s no doubt Russia is a country with grandeur in its scale, sweeping across 11 time zones and home to gargantuan oil, gas and mining companies.

headline: Trump Camp Refuses to Close Door on Campaign Pledge to ‘Lock Her Up’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail']
abstract: A decision on whether to further investigate Hillary Clinton will indicate whether Donald Trump intends to look ahead or look back and settle political scores.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as President-elect Donald J. Trump vows to unify a divided nation, he faces a momentous decision over whether to make good on his oft-repeated campaign pledge to have a special prosecutor “lock up” Hillary Clinton.

headline: Clothes That Fit
abstract: In which the term “Casual Friday” takes on a whole new meaning, thanks to Joel Fagliano.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you work for a company that has a “Casual Friday” policy, you know that the extent to which you can dress casually is largely dictated by the company. You’re never going to come to work in your favorite sweats, but you’re also freed from the more binding forms of corporate wear.

headline: How Nandan Nilekani, an Infosys Billionaire, Invests His Money
abstract: Mr. Nilekani, finally free to focus on investments, fears an increase in anti-globalization sentiment but is betting on India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Nandan Nilekani, a co-founder of one of India’s biggest information technology services companies, is an older billionaire but a young investor. In his nearly 30 years of starting and then building up Infosys, he did not have the time to focus on investing anywhere else, he said. Not to mention that most of his wealth was tied up in the company.

headline: Trump and Identity
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Muslim Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Minorities', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Voters discuss what comes next for white, black and brown Americans.
lead_paragraph: (Race/Related is a weekly newsletter exploring race and ethnicity. Scattered throughout this edition are views of some Brooklyn voters in artwork by Cari Vander Yacht. These illustrations are juxtaposed against extended conversations with a handful of white Trump voters about race, identity, and politics. Sign up. Tell us what you think racerelated@nytimes.com.)

headline: Fund Chief Capitalizes on China’s ‘Split Personality’ Economy
abstract: Weijian Shan of the fund management firm PAG is focusing his money on companies that can benefit from China’s rising consumerism.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Weijian Shan, chief executive of the Hong Kong fund management firm PAG, says the global economy is dangerous for investors these days. Years of easy money from central banks have helped inflate the prices of just about everything an investor can buy, like stocks or property.

headline: Sea of Uncertainty
abstract: It’s a stormy, turbulent market for the world investor. Here are 15 charts and graphs to help clarify your financial thinking in a time of global market confusion (or at least amuse and calm you down a bit).

headline: Colombia Reaches New Peace Deal With Rebels
abstract: Negotiators made changes to an agreement rejected by voters, and the nation’s president urged quick ratification, saying, “The cease-fire is fragile.”
lead_paragraph: The Colombian government and the nation’s main rebel group said on Saturday that they had reached a “new final accord” to end their longstanding conflict, potentially reviving a deal that was rejected last month in a referendum.

headline: U.S., in Deal With Australia, Agrees to Take Some Refugees
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States International Relations', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration Detention']
abstract: Australia had sent the refugees to a detention center on the impoverished island of Nauru. The United Nations has called such holding camps inhumane.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The Australian government said Sunday that it had reached a one-time agreement in which the United States would take in refugees who had been banished to a detention center on the tiny impoverished Pacific island nation of Nauru.

headline: To Our Readers, From the Publisher and Executive Editor
abstract: After such an erratic and unpredictable election there are inevitable questions.
lead_paragraph: When the biggest political story of the year reached a dramatic and unexpected climax late Tuesday night, our newsroom turned on a dime and did what it has done for nearly two years — cover the 2016 election with agility and creativity.

headline: Dave Chappelle Hosts ‘S.N.L.’ and Addresses the Protests Against Trump
abstract: Kate McKinnon, as Hillary Clinton, sang the Leonard Cohen song “Hallelujah,” including the lyric, “I told the truth, I didn’t come to fool you.”
lead_paragraph: In its first episode since Donald J. Trump won the 2016 presidential election, “Saturday Night Live” embraced the tension that many of its viewers surely feel, satirizing Mr. Trump, his controversial campaign and the uncertainty that surrounds him as president-elect, but also mocking the bewilderment of liberals who did not consider the possibility that Hillary Clinton could lose — or the conditions that gave rise to his victory.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Thanksgiving is just around the corner. Give yourself a break in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. By this time next week you’ll be knee-deep in Thanksgiving preparations, so give yourself a break today and keep things in the kitchen simple. Hit the market for groceries that can take you through the week, then build a snack tray to accompany Gabrielle Hamilton’s ace recipe for celery toasts and settle in to watch President-elect Donald J. Trump be interviewed by Lesley Stahl on “60 Minutes” — it’s scheduled for 7 p.m. in the East, on the CBS television network.

headline: After Schizophrenia Diagnosis, a Sense of Clarity and a Place of His Own
abstract: Lavelle Lockett, 26, had been homeless when he was hospitalized at a psychiatric center. Two years later, he has an apartment and hopes to attend college.
lead_paragraph: The visions started when Lavelle Lockett was 18. They came in the form of blurry, silent figures, and when they arrived, he knew to stay away. He avoided them like the people he had seen in the alleys where he lived on and off for much of his life, until November 2014. That is when, at 24, he was hospitalized and told he had schizophrenia.

headline: N.F.L.: The New England Patriots Are Beatable. The Cowboys? Maybe Not.

headline: Donald Trump Shouldn’t ‘Put His Children Out of Work,’ Giuliani Says
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani said it would be ‘unrealistic’ for Mr. Trump to remove his children from his business empire. Ethics experts said the remarks were misguided.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rudolph W. Giuliani, a top adviser to President-elect Donald J. Trump, said on Sunday that it would be “unrealistic” to remove Mr. Trump’s children from their roles in running his business empire and place the assets into a strict blind trust like the ones used by previous presidents.

headline: Jakarta Protest, Tied to Faith, May Have Deeper Links to Secular Politics
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Religion and Belief', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Elections, Governors']
abstract: Analysts say politicians are exploiting religious fervor to challenge the capital’s governor and his close ally, President Joko Widodo.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — The sight of tens of thousands of Islamists marching through the Indonesian capital this month, demanding that its Christian governor be jailed for blasphemy — some even calling for his death — brought back recurrent fears of “creeping Islamization” in the world’s most populous Muslim-majority nation, where a more tolerant brand of Islam has been the norm.

headline: Red, Blue and Divided: Six Views of America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Reporters for The New York Times spoke with people across the country to understand the issues that split voters before the election, and today.
lead_paragraph: Red, blue, optimistic, fearful. Here are six takes on a divided America, in the wake of Donald J. Trump’s narrow election victory.

headline: Violence Escalates Between Myanmar Forces and Rohingya
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Buddhism', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: After two soldiers were killed by attackers, troops of the Buddhist-majority government burned villages in Rakhine State close to the Bangladesh border.
lead_paragraph: SITTWE, Myanmar — Violence between the Rohingya, a persecuted Muslim population, and Myanmar’s security forces escalated over the weekend as two soldiers were killed by crudely armed attackers, said government officials and Muslim residents. In retaliation, troops of the Buddhist-majority government used helicopters to fire at the attackers in dense forest in northwestern Myanmar, a government spokesman said.

headline: In Troubled Newark Archdiocese, Hoping Its New Leader Is a Pastor, Not a Prince
abstract: Archbishop Joseph Tobin faces many challenges in his new post in Newark, including shifting demographics and criticism drawn by his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Bishop Manuel A. Cruz opened with a head count. “Four,” he said, looking out at the four parishioners in a small chapel behind the soaring Gothic sanctuary of the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart here. “The perfect number, because it is the number we are here.”

headline: ‘Arrival’ Comes On Strong in a Generally Robust Box Office Weekend
abstract: The Amy Adams film beat expectations, buoyed by reviews. Over all, North American ticket sales were up 47 percent compared with the same weekend in 2015.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Whether because of Veterans Day school closings, a postelection need to escape into fantasy or an unusually wide range of multiplex offerings, Hollywood had a very good weekend at the box office: Ticket sales in North America were up 47 percent compared with the same weekend last year, according to comScore.

headline: UConn’s Geno Auriemma Looks Into a Mirror and Sees Gregg Popovich
abstract: Auriemma dropped in on San Antonio during training camp to learn from the culture that Popovich has created for the Spurs.
lead_paragraph: STORRS, Conn. — Two of the most successful coaches in basketball history had admired each other only from afar, from across the amateur/professional and gender divides. They decided to do something about it.

headline: From Bataclan to Street Cafes, Paris Is Quiet but Resolute as It Mourns on Anniversary of Attacks
abstract: A penetrating silence enveloped Paris on Sunday as thousands of people massed under a leaden sky to remember the victims of the Nov. 13, 2015, attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — No bells tolled. No fists were raised. No sirens blared.

headline: Chinese Coaches Take Lessons in Hardwood Diplomacy in America
abstract: Junior high and high school coaches from China participated in a three-month residency as part of a partnership involving the Chinese government, the Pac-12 and the University of Utah.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — About 15 coaches filed onto the mezzanine-like balcony overlooking a basketball practice court. They wore warm-up apparel and sneakers. As the Utes men’s team began its practice, some took notes in small Moleskine notebooks; others consulted printouts of set plays.

headline: Canada’s Gay Curling Leagues Take Pride on Ice
abstract: Gay players have added campy humor and flamboyantly themed tournaments to a winter sport’s traditions of friendly competition and drinking.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — It happens all the time: Young gay people leave their small towns and head to the big city, where they can find love, acceptance and, in Canada at least, a curling league to call their own. Yes, the winter sport that involves ice, round rocks and a good deal of sweeping has a passionate following among those who have come out of the closet, taking their brooms with them.

headline: Pro-Russia Candidate Appears Likely to Win Bulgarian Presidency
abstract: Rumen Radev, a former air force commander with no previous political experience, seemed headed for a decisive victory in a runoff election.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — A pro-Russia former air force commander with no previous political experience appeared headed for a decisive victory on Sunday in a runoff election to become Bulgaria’s president. The results prompted the current governing party’s prime minister to say he would resign, setting the stage for early elections in the spring.

headline: A Coach Is Forging a New Path in Danish Soccer
abstract: Jakob Michelsen is thriving at SonderjyskE as teams in Denmark, amid a downturn, adopt changes in their hiring practices, their approaches and even the league structure.
lead_paragraph: HADERSLEV, Denmark — Neither parallel tells quite the whole story, in truth, but both seem to have stuck.

Trump on Sunday chose Reince Priebus, the chairman of the Republican National Committee and a loyal campaign adviser, to be his White House chief of staff, turning to a Washington insider whose friendship with the House speaker, Paul D. headline: Review: ‘Mars’ Blends Fact and Fiction, but Has a Bumpy Liftoff
abstract: National Geographic’s new series is a hybrid of documentary and space drama. It’s an interesting attempt but feels ill-timed to the moment.
lead_paragraph: Timing is everything, and “Mars,” a six-episode experiment in hybridization that begins Monday on the National Geographic Channel, feels as if it is landing at a particularly inopportune moment.

headline: Genetic Heart Disease Risk Eased by Healthy Habits, Study Finds
abstract: Even people who are at the worst risk can benefit by not smoking, exercising moderately and eating a healthy diet, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Is genetics destiny when it comes to heart disease?

headline: Celebrex Is Found to Be No Riskier for Hearts Than Other Pain Drugs
abstract: A question has long hung over Celebrex: Did it cause heart attacks? Now, a clinical trial suggests it may be safer than drugs like ibuprofen and naproxen.
lead_paragraph: The drugs seemed miraculous when they were introduced in 1999, and they soon became blockbusters, with billion-dollar sales. Vioxx, made by Merck, and Celebrex, made by Pfizer, could quell pain and inflammation just as well as drugs like ibuprofen and naproxen, but they did not cause ulcers and gastrointestinal bleeding.

headline: Which Big Drug Companies Are Helping the Poor? Here’s the List
abstract: GSK does more than its competitors to make important drugs available in developing countries, according to an updated ranking.
lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical giant GSK, which has held first place in the Access to Medicine Index ever since its introduction in 2008, was ranked first again this week.

headline: Obama Heads Overseas, Where Topic of Trump Will Follow Him
abstract: On Monday, the president will begin a trip that will take him to Greece, Germany and Peru. At every stop, he is sure to be asked how he got the election so wrong.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On his last foreign trip while in office, President Obama will have a lot of explaining to do.

headline: Review: ‘Close to the Enemy’ Is One Cryptic Postwar Drama
abstract: There’s plenty to like in the new Acorn TV series, which takes place in 1946 England, but the show would have done better to rely more on actual history.
lead_paragraph: Judging from “Close to the Enemy,” a new drama from the streaming service Acorn TV, an outbreak of coyness swept England in the difficult year after World War II ended. It’s a well-made, deftly acted period drama, but one built on an irksome plotting philosophy: Why be direct when you can be cryptic?

headline: Review: Jonah Bokaer’s ‘Rules of the Game,’ a Collaboration at Odds With Itself
abstract: The choreographer turned to the visual artist Daniel Arsham and the musician Pharrell Williams for this venture. It’s admirably ambitious, yet confused.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Jonah Bokaer has written that “Rules of the Game,” his latest collaborative venture, “is about how to ‘tag’ deeply creative minds into (never onto) the very fluid medium of choreography.” Those minds belong to him, the visual artist Daniel Arsham and the musician Pharrell Williams, who came together to produce the admirably ambitious yet confused work that had its New York premiere at the Howard Gilman Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday.

headline: Review: Natalia Osipova and Artists Stick to the Familiar at City Center
abstract: Sadler’s Wells London Production was behind this uninspiring evening, comprising works by Arthur Pita, Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui and Russell Maliphant.
lead_paragraph: The ballerina Natalia Osipova has celebrity. But when it comes to choosing repertory to express another side of her artistry through contemporary dance — that all-too-familiar code for extending a career — she needs help.

headline: Donald Trump Appears to Soften Stance on Immigration, but Not on Abortion
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'ABORTION', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The president-elect said his immigration priority was to deport up to three million undocumented immigrants rather than 11 million and that his border wall might be a fence in places.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump appeared to soften some of his hardest-line campaign positions on immigration on Sunday, but he also restated his pledge to roll back abortion rights and used Twitter to lash out at his critics, leaving open the possibility that he would continue using social media in the Oval Office and radically change the way presidents speak to Americans.

headline: Review: ‘Bolshoi Confidential’ Peers Down the Centuries and Past the Pirouettes
abstract: Simon Morrison’s new book serves as a backstage pass to the past and present of the renowned ballet company.
lead_paragraph: Simon Morrison’s “Bolshoi Confidential: Secrets of the Russian Ballet From the Rule of the Tsars to Today” delivers what its title promises: struggles and intrigues, crimes and punishments, imperial jewels and Soviet medals. Based on extensive research in libraries and archives, and conversations heard at Russian kitchen tables, Mr. Morrison’s book gives a historical tour behind the scenes of one of the world’s most glorious ballet institutions, from 1776, when the Bolshoi was founded by Michael Maddox, an English adventurer in Russia, to the attack with acid on Sergei Filin, the Bolshoi’s artistic director, in 2013.

headline: Bryce Petty Shows Promise, but Rams Deal Jets More Disappointment

headline: European Leaders Gather to Grapple With Donald Trump’s Victory
abstract: European Union foreign ministers met on Sunday to discuss potential ramifications of Mr. Trump’s win. Many of his statements have left some European nations vulnerable.

headline: Edgar Oliver, Actor and Raconteur, Hews to His East Village Past
abstract: Mr. Oliver, who stars in “Attorney Street,” the latest installment of his solo trilogy, takes a melancholy stroll around his former neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The actor Edgar Oliver doesn’t often find himself on the block of East 10th Street, in the East Village, where he lived for 34 years. But one weekend this month he went there twice — on Saturday, hoping to see a homeless friend who used to rent a room next door, and on Sunday to meet me for a ramble around the neighborhood.

lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — Journalism may be the first draft of history. But on Friday, a group of scholars gathered here for what might be an editing session on the second.

headline: The Art Market’s Reaction to Trump? Sales This Week Offer First Test
abstract: The sales of Impressionist, Modern and contemporary art that start Monday offer the first test of how the art market will react to a Trump presidency.
lead_paragraph: At Rockefeller Center on Sunday, milling outside Christie’s sales rooms — where private clients sipped mimosas as they took in one of Monet’s grainstacks — people in the art world sounded guardedly optimistic about how the auctions will perform this week, after a period of uncertainty exacerbated by the contentious American presidential election, Britain’s “Brexit” vote in June and China’s slowing economy.

headline: Windmills or Reactor Cores? Inside South Africa’s Energy Clash
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Solar Energy', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: The country is experiencing a boom in renewable energy, but some government officials are pushing instead for nuclear power to wean the nation off coal.

Tracking the sun throughout the day, the mirrors, called heliostats, redirect the sun’s rays into the tower, where water is heated to generate steam — and electricity.

headline: Ocean Conservation Series Coming to Animal Planet
abstract: “Ocean Warriors” will have its premiere on Dec. 4 and aims to reveal the crime and violence that often go unpunished in international waters.
lead_paragraph: Robert Redford and Paul Allen are the executive producers of a new Animal Planet series on ocean conservation. Entitled “Ocean Warriors,” the series traces activists, journalists and scientists working to fight poachers and organized crime in oceans across the globe.

headline: Bill to Legalize West Bank Settlements Advances in Israel
abstract: If approved by Parliament, legislation would transfer the rights for the use of private land into Israeli hands and force Palestinian landowners to accept compensation.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli ministerial committee on Sunday approved a contentious bill that would allow for the retroactive legalization of Jewish settlement outposts built on privately owned Palestinian land in the occupied West Bank. The measure breaks a longstanding taboo, and in the view of many experts, it defies international law.

headline: For Le Pen, the Impossible Now Seems Possible

Trump’s electoral triumph, France’s far-right leader Marine Le Pen was up early, already commenting on Twitter. Even before the American president-elect gave his victory speech, she rushed to congratulate him and “the free American people.” This was hardly surprising, since Ms. Le Pen, the leader of the National Front, is hoping to become the next French president.

lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Voice quivering, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday dramatically countered criticism of his surprise ban on most currency in circulation in India, a bold attack on corruption that crippled business at stores and markets around the country as millions scrambled for cash to meet even basic needs.

headline: Teslas in the Trailer Park: A California City Faces Its Housing Squeeze
abstract: Most Californians agree that it costs too much to live in the state. Mountain View, Google’s hometown, is trying to do something about that.

Over the last few years, the price of buying a home or renting an apartment has become so burdensome that it pervades almost every issue, from the state’s elevated poverty rate to the debate about multimillion-dollar tear-downs to the lines of recreational vehicles parked on Silicon Valley side streets.

headline: Raccoons in Central Park Draw Crowds, and Warnings to Stay Away

headline: Chelsea Manning Asks Obama to Cut Sentence to Time Served

headline: Why Japan’s Economy Posted Surprisingly Strong Growth
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Demand for its exports provided the lift that neither government nor consumers have offered. But Donald Trump’s anti-Japan talk has put trade under a cloud.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese economic growth accelerated strongly in the third quarter. Japan has the world’s third-largest economy, but it has been struggling to lift a lackluster growth rate and escape the trap of deflation — sagging consumer prices associated with weak output and declining living standards. So what went right last quarter? And will it last?

headline: Review: ‘The Death of the Last Black Man,’ a Nightmare Hypnotically Retold
abstract: Suzan-Lori Parks’s phantasmagorical theater piece is a sepulchral parade of images that have distorted and swallowed up the history of African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: Surely no fruit has ever been heavier than the watermelon now on display at the Pershing Square Signature Center. Make that watermelons, plural, though for all intents and purposes (and those are myriad), they are one oppressive entity.

headline: Review: Daniel Kitson’s ‘Mouse’ Tells Its Tales Over a Speakerphone
abstract: This one-man show revolves around a man who has apparently simply dialed a wrong number and then stays on the line to talk. And talk.
lead_paragraph: Try tracking all the conversations going on in Daniel Kitson’s “Mouse: The Persistence of an Unlikely Thought,” which opened on Sunday at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, and your mind will probably short-circuit. There is, to start with the obvious, the dialogue between the title creature (of unknown gender) of this solo performance piece and the woman (of unspecified name) who discovers it on her staircase.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Season 1, Episode 7: They Cannot See
abstract: The truth regarding a popular fan theory comes to light, as do the lengths Dr. Ford will travel to protect his vision.
lead_paragraph: And so a popular fan theory comes to fruition: One of the park’s behind-the-scenes engineers is an android, and that android is Bernard, the head of Westworld’s programming division. Bernard won’t likely be the last, but he was always the most obvious, given his close association with Ford, his surreptitious exchanges with Dolores, and the circumstances surrounding his son’s death, which have been shrouded in vagueness, like a half-completed memory. Jeffrey Wright specializes in playing intense, introspective characters, but the slight lack of affect he’s brought to Bernard has long hinted at the synthetic hardware within. The story about his son, like Maeve’s memories of her daughter, has given Bernard the dimensionality of a human, but not quite the authentic depth.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Reveals a Big Twist, but Little Heart
abstract: In the seventh episode, “Trompe L’Oeil,” a big twist reveals another piece of its narrative, yet the show’s characters remain mysteries.
lead_paragraph: Well? Did you call it?

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 7, Episode 4: Negan Takes Over
abstract: On Sunday Rick and his group learned what life would be like under the Saviors.
lead_paragraph: This week on “The Walking Dead,” Rick and the rest of the Alexandrians were forced to reckon with the reality that a crude brute they once underestimated was now in charge.

headline: Just How Powerful Was the ‘Mule Lobby’? (Yes, There Was One)
abstract: The host Stephen J. Dubner and panelists consider mules, their defenders and other wonders of the natural world, including marine animals that will either live forever or kill you — or both.
lead_paragraph: In 1885, a 5-year-old Douglas MacArthur spotted a certain African animal roaming across the American Southwest. That’s because 50 years earlier, Army officers wanted to test out the animal as an upgrade to the typical mules and horses they used as pack animals. The replacements worked out extraordinarily well — but then the Civil War intervened, and the program was abandoned. (Plus, the mule lobby wasn’t too thrilled about these outsider animals coming to take over what they argued the mules were doing perfectly well.)

headline: ‘Insecure’ Season 1, Episode 6: A Real One
abstract: Issa and Molly deal with the aftermath of their own mistakes in starkly different ways.
lead_paragraph: A powerful, even overwhelming, feeling comes with recognizing yourself in a TV show. As the medium grows more diverse, there is greater opportunity for this. Recently, I’ve found myself in various conversations about whether the lead characters of “Insecure” are “relatable.” As a black woman, I actually don’t relate to Issa and Molly at all. We come from drastically different cultural backgrounds, our goals take on different shapes and our romantic pitfalls exist on opposing wavelengths.

headline: Atlantic City, Symbol of Big Bets Gone Bad
abstract: State overseers are taking over a vast amount of the city government’s power.

But the city, ravaged by the excesses of the casino industry, had to be taken over by state officials last week. The city is suffocating under $500 million of debt, unable to pay its bills or close a $100 million budget deficit.

keywords: ['Rural Areas', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Urban Areas', 'Whites', 'Baby Boomers', 'Youth', 'Presidential Election of 2016']

headline: My Friend Leonard Cohen: Darkness and Praise
abstract: He was the poet laureate of the flawed, who made imperfection gorgeous.
lead_paragraph: “Dear Uncle Leonard,” the email from the boy began. “Did anything inspire you to create ‘Hallelujah’”? Later that same winter day the reply arrived: “I wanted to stand with those who clearly see G-d’s holy broken world for what it is, and still find the courage or the heart to praise it. You don’t always get what you want. You’re not always up for the challenge. But in this case — it was given to me. For which I am deeply grateful.”

headline: Donald Trump Is Now Hiring

abstract: Mr. Trump, who has no experience in the workings of government, just named his chief of staff and chief strategist. He’s got 4,000 more jobs left to fill.
lead_paragraph: Staffing his administration is the first test of Donald Trump’s sales pitch to Americans: that his career running companies will make him a better president than any politician. Whom he hires and how he goes about it will be an early sign of his skill at managing the most consequential “company” in the world, and its millions of employees.

headline: ‘They Will Have to Die Now’
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Kurds']
abstract: With the Kurdish pesh merga on the road to Mosul.
lead_paragraph: Before dawn on a Sunday late last month, a battalion of pesh merga soldiers — about 600 Kurdish men, along with a few women — gathered in the shadow of Bashiqa Mountain, on the western edge of the autonomous region of Iraqi Kurdistan. They were sons, daughters, fathers, grandfathers. They wore an assortment of camouflage fatigues and traditional Kurdish flowing pants, waist sashes and head scarves. They carried antique Kalashnikovs and new assault rifles. Few had helmets, and fewer had body armor. Strapped to their backs and belts and legs were daggers, revolvers, axes. Some of them had received the call to duty only the day before and were driven to the front by family or rode overnight in taxis.

headline: Who Owns the Street in Mexico City?
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Bicycle riders fight a daily battle for space with cars and drivers.
lead_paragraph: Mexico City — To get about on a bicycle in Mexico City is an experience ranging from complicated to downright scary. The cracked and broken paving makes it torture to ride anywhere, specially if you’re constantly dodging hostile cars and trucks. It’s frequently said that “Mexico City is not Amsterdam.” Drivers in Amsterdam share the streets with bicycles and pedestrians as a matter of course; here, it seems we do so because we’re forced to. Nevertheless, we inhabitants of Mexico City have the same right as any Dutch citizen to enjoy a complete network of bike lanes to get around the city.

headline: A Poll Tax by Another Name
abstract: Long waits at polling places disparately impact poor and minority voters.
lead_paragraph: Tuscaloosa, Ala. — Many people, of all partisan stripes, are still wondering, “How did this happen?” The fact is that a very small difference in net votes — around 100,000 votes in Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin — would have turned Hillary Clinton’s popular vote victory into an Electoral College victory as well. As people try to process what happened on Election Day, we need to consider carefully whether the difficulty of voting in our nation’s urban centers, in places like Detroit, Milwaukee and Philadelphia, might have played a decisive role.

The industry leaders had traveled from cities like New York, Chicago and San Francisco, and any political conversation seemed to be premised on the assumption that Hillary Clinton would win.

headline: Review: Kathleen Battle Returns to the Met After 22 Years. It Was Worth the Wait.
abstract: The soprano performed a powerful program at the Metropolitan Opera that focused on the Underground Railroad, and rewarded the audience with five encores.

That year, Joseph Volpe, then the Met’s general manager, in an extraordinarily blunt statement, dismissed her from a production of Donizetti’s “La Fille du Régiment” for “unprofessional actions” during rehearsals that were “profoundly detrimental” to artistic collaborations among cast members. She was dropped from the Met’s roster for good, it seemed.

abstract: The latest wave of new titles provides us with time-efficient high-mindedness.

Often stopping short at a breezy 150 pages, they make a point of being concise, and are meant to be dispatched in one or two sittings. As soon as you have finished beginning, you begin ending.

When corporate executives get in trouble, it is common for them to claim that their lawyers said it was permissible to act that way.

headline: Portrait of Czar Nicholas II Discovered Beneath Portrait of Lenin
abstract: The double-portrait will be displayed beginning Nov. 29 at the Stieglitz Art and Industry Academy in St. Petersburg.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of the centennial of the 1917 October Revolution, restoration experts at the Stieglitz Art and Industry Academy in St. Petersburg have uncovered a “double portrait” reflecting Russia’s diametrical history under both Imperialism and Communism: A full-size portrait of Vladimir Lenin from 1924 painted on the back side of a 1896 Imperial portrait of Czar Nicholas II. The portraits will be displayed, on opposite sides of the same canvas, beginning Nov. 29 on a stand in the Stieglitz academy’s entrance hall.

headline: Leon Russell, From Rising to Resurgent
abstract: Six performances, including a festive 1970 jam session, recall several aspects of the musician’s career.
lead_paragraph: There’s some remarkable footage of Leon Russell from late 1970, the year he released his self-titled debut solo album. Taken from an hourlong special, “Homewood,” originally broadcast on Los Angeles public television, it circulated in bootleg editions for decades before the audio surfaced on CD this year in what appears to be a sanctioned release.

Trump to reach out to minority groups, women and others who were alienated by his campaign, during the president’s first news conference since Mr. Trump won the election in a stunning upset that has imperiled Mr. Obama’s legacy.

headline: Donald Trump Trolled Us All. We Should Learn From It.

It was not a strategy that any digital campaign expert would ever advise. Often, it felt more like a reality-show stunt than a real campaign.

headline: Review: Ballet and Modern Dance Meet, and Ultimately Embrace

That track record gives the success of the collaboration between Sara Mearns and Jodi Melnick the freshness of a minor miracle.

headline: Samsung Takes Sensible Course in Bid for Harman International
abstract: The $8 billion price looks fair for a company that will jump-start Samsung’s presence in the connected-car supplier market.
lead_paragraph: Samsung is riding a stallion instead of a unicorn into the driverless revolution. Despite no stated cost savings, the 28 percent premium the Korean electronics group agreed to pay for Harman International, a connected-car supplier, is reasonable. Companies like Google are investing heavily to invent the automotive future as General Motors and others bet on risky start-ups. This deal suggests there are safer ways to play a mega-trend in the making.

headline: Ah, Finally, Ancient Clay Tablets for Dessert

headline: In Michael Chabon’s ‘Moonglow,’ Deathbed Stories Illuminate an Era
abstract: A grandfather’s tales connect the dots of a family’s life and make sense of the past in Mr. Chabon’s latest novel.
lead_paragraph: Storytelling matters desperately to Michael Chabon’s characters. It’s a way to remake an unhappy reality and exert control (“Werewolves in Their Youth”), a means of grappling with personal or historical disaster (“The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay”), or, in the case of his elegiac and deeply poignant new novel, “Moonglow,” a tool for connecting the dots of a family’s life and making sense of the past.

headline: A Radical Feminist Hair Salon With Serious Cool-Girl Cred

lead_paragraph: Johanna Fateman is most famous as a musician — she was the founder, with Kathleen Hanna, of the germinal feminist dance-punk band Le Tigre — but she has always worn multiple hats. A mother, business owner and art critic, Fateman recently picked up the title of New Yorker columnist when the magazine invited her to write regularly for its “Goings On About Town” section. “The majority of my time and mental energy is definitely spent in writing,” Fateman says. “Of course, Le Tigre will always be something people want to talk about.”

headline: Vast and Pristine, Russia’s Lake Baikal Is Invaded by Harmful Algae
abstract: Untreated sewage fuels algal blooms in the world’s largest freshwater lake, home to scores of unique plant and animal species.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BAIKAL, Russia — Yury Azhichakov set out early by bike for Senogda Bay, his favorite beach, on the northwestern shore of Lake Baikal in Siberia. The world’s oldest, deepest and most voluminous lake, Baikal holds 20 percent of the planet’s unfrozen freshwater. It is often described as the world’s cleanest lake.

headline: Health Care Issues Loom in Politics, Payments and Quality

A Trump administration, coupled with a Republican Congress, is likely to lead to a reversal of many of the policies put into place by President Obama, and could mean a repeal of his signature health care law.

headline: Ryan Phillippe Talks Guns, Stunts and ‘Shooter’
abstract: He stars in that conspiracy thriller, beginning Tuesday on the USA Network. It is adapted from the 2007 Mark Wahlberg movie and the Stephen Hunter novel “Point of Impact.”

headline: The Next Generation of Hedge Fund Stars: Data-Crunching Computers

headline: An Ecosystem’s Lifeblood, Flowing Through Gravel

headline: Same Opera, Different Role: Karita Mattila Returns to the Met

abstract: Other financial regulators are expected to follow suit, giving the Trump administration an opening to shift the government’s approach to policing the industry.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street regulators began an exodus from Washington on Monday as Mary Jo White, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced plans to leave the agency.

headline: Iran, Spending, Defense: Areas to Watch as Congress Reconvenes
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: Congress will try to finish the last of its business, including a spending bill to keep the government open, before the Trump administration comes in.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress returns this week to finish the last of its business before a new year and era begin in Washington. Ebullient Republicans are eager to put some remaining legislation behind them and to try to fund the government through the rest of the year. Here are some areas to watch.

headline: Review: A Tennis Rivalry That Just Might Sabotage a Friendship
abstract: With girlfriends acting as ironic courtside commentators, Andy Bragen’s play examines a highly charged pastime for two men entering middle age.
lead_paragraph: At a pivotal moment of a heated tennis match between Brian and Russ, obsessive rivals whose entire season of amateur competition has been building toward this day, an obscenity-spiked command erupts from Brian’s mouth. “Don’t you _______ say a word,” he barks, all aggression and rage. Instantly and irreparably, the men’s relationship implodes.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

headline: Russian Jet Crashes Off Syria While Trying to Land on Carrier Kuznetsov
keywords: ['Aircraft Carriers', 'Military Aircraft', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: The Russian Defense Ministry blamed a technical failure for the crash of the jet, a MIG-29.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian fighter jet crashed off the Syrian coast on Monday while trying to land on an aging aircraft carrier in the Mediterranean, Russian military officials said.

headline: A Merger Lawyer Sounds Off on the Short-Term Quest for Profits
abstract: Martin Lipton, 85, a founder of Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, discusses his work to promote alternatives to what he calls “short-termism.”
lead_paragraph: Martin Lipton, a founding partner of the New York law firm Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, specializes in advising major corporations on mergers and acquisitions. Mr. Lipton, 85, has been instrumental in shaping corporate deal making for decades; he is particularly well known for his efforts to bolster management defenses against hostile takeovers.

headline: John Alexander Skelton’s Fall Collection
abstract: The British designer has crafted a unique collection by sourcing vintage fabrics.
lead_paragraph: The British designer has crafted a unique collection by sourcing vintage fabrics.

headline: Person to Know: The Designer Making One-of-a-Kind Pieces From Sustainable Fabrics
abstract: John Alexander Skelton sources vintage materials from around England and then hand-dyes them before sewing them into men’s garments.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to finding inspiration, the designer John Alexander Skelton is more likely to turn to museums and archives than the internet. After all, he got the idea for his MA collection at Central Saint Martins — which earned him the school’s prestigious L’Oreal Prize earlier this year — from the archives of Mass Observation, an extensive anthropological survey in the mid-20th century. “The British Library is an amazing resource,” Skelton says. “I love research because you enter different worlds and it’s so enriching. It’s interesting how intertwined textiles has been with politics and social history.”

headline: Stephen Bannon and Breitbart News, in Their Words
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: A look at the words of Stephen K. Bannon, the new chief White House strategist to President-elect Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The appointment of Stephen K. Bannon as chief White House strategist for President-elect Donald J. Trump has been condemned by civil rights groups, Democrats and some Republicans, because of Mr. Bannon’s record as chairman of Breitbart News, the hard-right news and opinion site.

headline: How Narendra Modi of India Plans to Wipe Out ‘Black Money’
abstract: Prime Minister Modi has banned 500- and 1,000-rupee bills, or about 86 percent of India’s currency, in an effort to combat corruption and tax avoidance.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — In one of the most audacious experiments in India’s modern history, Prime Minister Narendra Modi banned the two largest bills — of 500 rupees, or about $7.50, and 1,000 rupees — which account for about 86 percent of the currency in a country where 78 percent of financial transactions are done in cash.

headline: Putin and Trump Talk on Phone and Agree to Improve Ties, Kremlin Says
abstract: The leaders discussed trade and combating terrorism, with the Russian president saying he hoped for “noninterference in the other’s internal affairs.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President-elect Donald J. Trump spoke by telephone for the first time on Monday, agreeing to review what both consider the poor state of relations between the two countries, according to a statement from the Kremlin.

headline: Shock Waves a Week After the Vote
abstract: Donald Trump make a controversial appointment; Hillary Clinton blames the F.B.I. director for her loss.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Global Warming']
abstract: President-elect Trump has indicated he will look for a quick exit from America’s commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: Of all the climate policies the Trump administration has promised to undo, auto emissions standards could be the most consequential.

headline: Georgia Father Is Convicted of Murder in Toddler’s Death in Hot Car
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: A jury convicted Justin Ross Harris on eight counts, including malice murder, more than two years after his 22-month-old son died in a hot car.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — With local television programming interrupted and a camera trained on the defendant’s emotionless face, an Atlanta-area father was convicted of murder on Monday for causing the death of his young son by deliberately leaving him in a hot car more than two years ago.

headline: Trump, Obama, Gwen Ifill: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: When Reportage Turns to Cynicism
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Trump listened to the media’s drumbeat of problems without remedies and turned it into a winning narrative of doom that only he could fix.
lead_paragraph: The election of Donald J. Trump has led to considerable soul searching in the news business, as journalists confront the role we played in his triumph. Much has been written about the billions of dollars of free media coverage Trump received, journalists’ lapses in challenging his outrageous falsehoods, and our clumsy grappling with how to treat his unconventional candidacy.

headline: Neil Walker Accepts Mets’ Qualifying Offer; Yoenis Cespedes Rejects It
abstract: General Manager Sandy Alderson has made clear that the Mets remain serious about re-signing Cespedes, who becomes one of baseball’s most attractive free agents.
lead_paragraph: Second baseman Neil Walker informed the Mets just before a 5 p.m. deadline on Monday that he would accept a $17.2 million qualifying offer for 2017, a decision that keeps one of the team’s two most important free agents in Queens.

headline: Marvel’s ‘Inhumans’ TV Series Will Arrive via Imax Theaters
abstract: An ABC series based on Marvel’s characters will debut next year on Imax screens, before a re-edited version heads to TV.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of Marvel Entertainment’s most sprawling superhero mythologies, the Inhumans, is headed to the small screen in a major way.

headline: ‘Unprecedented’ Work Required to Open 2nd Avenue Subway by Year’s End, Officials Say
abstract: Transportation officials said construction delays at new stations on the Upper East Side could postpone the long-awaited opening in December of the new line.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s race to open the Second Avenue subway by the end of the year will require an “unprecedented” push by workers, officials said on Monday.

headline: What Could Be Worse Than Repealing All of Obamacare?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: By keeping only the most popular parts, Donald Trump would leave patients worse off than they were before the law was passed.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump made headlines on Friday by saying he would like to keep two components of the Affordable Care Act: allowing young people to stay on their parents’ insurance until age 26, and continuing the ban on the exclusion of pre-existing conditions by insurers.

headline: Ahead of Trump Presidency, Global Investors Sell Bonds and Grab Stocks
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Sovereign wealth funds and hedge funds, as well as retirees’ accounts, restructure portfolios to profit from what they expect will be a free-spending administration.
lead_paragraph: Global investors have rendered their verdict on Donald J. Trump as president: Sell government bonds and pile into stocks that will benefit the most from a resurgent United States economy.

headline: U.K.’s Bridge to Trump? Nigel Farage, Who Pushed ‘Brexit,’ Posits Himself
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Mr. Farage was the first foreign politician to meet with President-elect Donald J. Trump, and on Monday, a photograph of the two inside Trump Tower dominated front pages in Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain has long been anxious about its “special relationship” with the United States, but after some choice remarks about Donald J. Trump by members of the governing Conservative Party during the presidential campaign, the relationship needs a bit of nurturing. And who better to tend to that, in his own mind at least, than Nigel Farage, the beer-loving commodities-trader-turned-populist-leader of the U.K. Independence Party.

headline: Nasdaq Names a New Chief Executive: Adena Friedman
abstract: Adena T. Friedman, whose promotion comes at a time of consolidation of market operators, will replace Robert Greifeld on Jan. 1.
lead_paragraph: Nasdaq on Monday named Adena T. Friedman its new chief executive, in the first changeover at the stock market operator in nearly 14 years.

headline: 76 Experts Urge Donald Trump to Keep Iran Deal
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: A report signed by scholars and former officials asked the president-elect to use the deal, which he has called a disaster, to further ease tensions with Iran.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-six national security experts urged President-elect Donald J. Trump on Monday to reverse his hostility to the nuclear agreement signed with Iran last year and to use it as a tool to ease other tensions with the country.

headline: Israel’s Right, Cheering Donald Trump’s Win, Renews Calls to Abandon 2-State Solution
abstract: Rightist politicians see Mr. Trump’s victory as a chance to reverse course on contentious policies like building new settlements and accords with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Emboldened by the Republican sweep of last week’s American elections, right-wing members of the Israeli government have called anew for the abandonment of a two-state solution to the conflict with the Palestinians.

headline: With His Idol Looking On, Kristaps Porzingis Shines in a Knicks Win
abstract: With Dallas’s Dirk Nowitzki on the sideline with an injury, Porzingis scored 24 points and grabbed 11 rebounds as the Knicks dispatched the Mavericks.
lead_paragraph: In the off-season, as the budding star Kristaps Porzingis prepared for his second season with the Knicks, his new coach, Jeff Hornacek, called his Dallas Mavericks counterpart. He wanted to arrange a meeting between Porzingis and Dirk Nowitzki.

headline: Dear John: Brooklyn Bridge Discourages Token of Love, With a Smile
abstract: Engineers say the sheer weight of so-called love locks — padlocks placed on the bridge by lovers to signify their bond — could damage the structure.
lead_paragraph: To some they are emblems of delight, reminders in steel of unbreakable connections. To others they are barnacles encrusting a beloved landmark. They are the so-called love locks, padlocks placed on the Brooklyn Bridge by lovers to signify their bond.

headline: NBC Takes Over Thursday Night Football Amid Promising Signs in TV Ratings
abstract: Strong ratings for Sunday’s Patriots-Seahawks and Cowboys-Steelers games provide hope in an N.F.L. season that has seen prime-time viewership plummet.
lead_paragraph: NBC Sports will take over the “Thursday Night Football” franchise this week at a suddenly promising point in an N.F.L. season that has seen viewership plummet by double-digit percentages in prime-time games.

headline: Google and Facebook Take Aim at Fake News Sites
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Social Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Online Advertising', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: After criticism that they might have allowed fake news to influence the 2016 election, the companies are banning such sites from using their advertising services.
lead_paragraph: Over the last week, two of the world’s biggest internet companies have faced mounting criticism over how fake news on their sites may have influenced the presidential election’s outcome.

headline: U.S. Hate Crimes Surge 6%, Fueled by Attacks on Muslims
abstract: A report expanded on findings by experts who have noted an alarming rise in some types of hate crimes tied to the vitriol of the presidential race and recent terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. reported Monday that attacks against American Muslims surged last year, driving an overall increase in hate crime against all groups.

headline: The Grace of Gwen Ifill
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Editorials', 'Editorial Appreciation', 'Women and Girls', 'Television']
abstract: As a black woman in journalism, she had spent her entire career proving people wrong.
lead_paragraph: Those of us who worked even briefly with the journalist Gwen Ifill, who died on Monday at the age of 61, can attest to her deeply held sense of fairness, the preternatural grace she showed under pressure and the way she kept her composure in the face of both personal and professional slights that would have left many of us breathing fire and brimstone.

headline: Colombia’s Revised Peace Accord
abstract: After marathon negotiations, the Colombian government and the FARC struck a new deal that serves as a road map to officially end five decades of war.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks after Colombian voters narrowly rejected a peace agreement between the government and the country’s largest guerrilla group in a plebiscite vote, President Juan Manuel Santos over the weekend unveiled a revised accord that is a testament to what can be achieved through dialogue and compromise, even in a deeply polarized society.

headline: Mayor de Blasio, Seeking Re-election, Secures Backing of 2 Unions
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio received a significant boost with the endorsements of the Uniformed Sanitationmen’s Association and the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union. Neither union initially backed him in 2013.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Mayor Bill de Blasio, a Democrat, has shifted into re-election mode, holding campaign events and fund-raisers, using separate Twitter accounts for political talk and mayoral messages.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, November 15, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I’m personally offended that you think I would manage a campaign where that would be one of the going philosophies.”

headline: Bobby Wood and Jozy Altidore Step Forward as U.S. Team Is Set Back
abstract: Wood, an emerging star, and Altidore, a veteran, stood out for their complementary efforts in the Americans’ loss to Mexico in a World Cup qualifier on Friday.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica — With about 15 minutes remaining in the United States’ game against Mexico on Friday night, Jozy Altidore settled under a looping pass at the top of the penalty area and, without even needing to look, chested the ball right into the path of Bobby Wood, who turned and whipped a blistering shot that the Mexican goalkeeper beat away.

headline: What Donald Trump’s Vow to Deport Up to 3 Million Immigrants Would Mean
abstract: By placing the number that high, the president-elect raised questions about which immigrants he planned to target and how he could achieve removals at that scale.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump’s promise to deport two million to three million immigrants who have committed crimes suggested that he would dramatically step up removals of both people in the United States illegally and those with legal status. If carried out, the plan potentially would require raids by a vastly larger federal immigration force to hunt down these immigrants and send them out of the country.

headline: Donald Trump’s Far-Flung Holdings Raise Potential for Conflicts of Interest
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The conflicts are in many ways as complex as his business empire, adding a heightened degree of difficulty for Mr. Trump to separate his official duties from his private business affairs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just a few blocks down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House sits the Trump International Hotel, one of the newest luxury additions to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s real estate empire, and perhaps the most visible symbol of the ethical quandary he now confronts.

headline: Billy Miller, Curator and Historian of Fringe Music, Dies at 62
abstract: Mr. Miller and his wife, Miriam Linna, revived the reputations of several bands through their efforts to distribute rockabilly and garage band music.
lead_paragraph: Billy Miller, a rock ’n’ roll archivist and collector whose record label, Norton, gave new life to forgotten rockabilly artists and garage bands of yesteryear, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 62.

headline: Claire Labine, Soap Opera Writer and Co-Creator of ‘Ryan’s Hope,’ Dies at 82
abstract: Ms. Labine’s story lines on “General Hospital” heightened public awareness about breast cancer, cardiac transplants and the AIDS epidemic.
lead_paragraph: Claire Labine, a nine-time Daytime Emmy Award winner whose dramatic plots and cliffhanger climaxes kept millions of television viewers returning day after day to “Ryan’s Hope,” “General Hospital,” “Love of Life” and other soap operas, died on Nov. 8 at her home in Somers, Conn. She was 82.

headline: Michael Fulmer and Corey Seager Named Rookies of the Year
abstract: Fulmer, whom the Tigers acquired in the deal that sent Yoenis Cespedes to the Mets, routed the Yankees’ Gary Sanchez in the A.L. Seager, of the Dodgers, was a unanimous choice in the N.L.
lead_paragraph: In Michael Fulmer’s first full professional season, with the Mets’ organization in 2012, he learned a changeup from the pitching coordinator Ron Romanick. Fulmer wrapped three fingers around the seams and started making his way up the Mets’ farm system, but it was not the changeup carrying him.

headline: Review: ‘Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812,’ on the Heels of ‘Hamilton’
abstract: Dave Malloy’s pop opera is both the most innovative and the best new musical to open on Broadway since the hit musical about one founding father.
lead_paragraph: The Imperial Theater, where the rapturous musical “Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812” blazed opened on Monday night, has never looked more imperial — or felt more intimate. Who would have guessed that Dave Malloy’s gorgeous pop opera, adapted from a slice of Tolstoy’s “War and Peace,” would land on Broadway with all its signal virtues intact, and in some ways heightened?

headline: Targets of Close Shaves
abstract: David Kahn reminds us that miracles do happen.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes the universe sends you a reminder that there is still pleasure to be had and that miracles occasionally still happen, even in unsure times.

headline: Hillary Clinton Wins New Hampshire
abstract: The Democratic nominee’s losing campaign picks up four electoral votes.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has won New Hampshire’s four electoral votes, The Associated Press reported on Monday night, nearly one week after she lost the presidential race to Donald J. Trump, the Republican candidate.

headline: Rebuilding Our Infrastructure

headline: Giants Edge Bengals as Eli Manning Passes for Three Touchdowns

lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Instead of cheers, a nervous ripple coursed through the crowd at MetLife Stadium. The kicker had not left the sideline. Yes, the Giants were going for it. From the 3-yard line.

headline: Edvard Munch Brings $54 Million Amid ‘Thinner’ Sales at Sotheby’s

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘Good Behavior’ and ‘Shooter’
abstract: Michelle Dockery, after “Downton Abbey,” plays a con artist in “Good Behavior.” And Ryan Phillippe stars in the USA Network’s “Shooter.”
lead_paragraph: Michelle Dockery does a 180 from her best-known role, Lady Mary in “Downton Abbey,” to play a con artist who takes up with a hit man in “Good Behavior.” And Ryan Phillippe steps into Mark Wahlberg’s shoes in the USA Network’s long-delayed conspiracy thriller, “Shooter.”

headline: Ever Wanted to Back a Start-Up? Indiegogo Opens the Door to Small Investors
abstract: Starting on Tuesday, the crowdfunding site will give entrepreneurs the option of offering backers an equity stake in their projects and creations.
lead_paragraph: Armchair venture capitalists will soon have a new place to hunt for intriguing start-ups: Indiegogo, the popular crowdfunding site for developers of creative ventures like movies, games and gadgets.

headline: In a Late-Night Move, Russia Arrests a Top Economic Official in a Bribery Case

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russians awoke to an extraordinary scandal on Tuesday with the minister of economic development detained on charges of soliciting a $2 million bribe — the highest-level official arrested in Russia in decades.

headline: Hong Kong Court Bars 2 Pro-Independence Politicians From Office
abstract: The ruling effectively ended a case in which Beijing had taken extraordinary steps to influence local politics in the semiautonomous city.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A court in Hong Kong ruled on Tuesday that two pro-independence politicians who inserted an anti-China snub into their oaths of office could not take their seats in the city’s legislature, effectively ending a case in which Beijing had taken extraordinary steps to influence politics in Hong Kong.

headline: Why Keeping Only the Popular Parts of Obamacare Won’t Work
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Keeping the pre-existing conditions piece while removing others might seem like a political win for Donald Trump, but it would result in a broken system.
lead_paragraph: Before Obamacare, it could be hard to buy your own insurance if you’d already had a health problem like cancer. An insurance company might have decided not to sell any insurance to someone like you. It might have agreed to cover you, but not cover cancer care. Or it might have offered you a comprehensive policy, but at some incredibly high price that you could never have paid.

headline: Protect Democracy First
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: There are two kinds of issues: those worthy of passionate, ideological debate, and those that must unite everyone who believes in democratic values.
lead_paragraph: The most fragile part of the country right now is our democratic values. Yes, we face other serious problems — the physical condition of our planet, above all. But the fate of those other problems will be decided in the months and years to come. The condition of our democracy is acute.

headline: The Life and Example of Gwen Ifill
abstract: She has left a chasm, which nobody else can fill up and which nobody has a tendency to fill.
lead_paragraph: Smartphones change death. When I heard that Gwen Ifill had died on Monday I pulled out my phone and scrolled through the photo album.
