abstract: White nationalism has no place in the West Wing.
lead_paragraph: Anyone holding out hope that Donald Trump would govern as a uniter — that the racism, sexism, anti-Semitism and nativism of his campaign were just poses to pick up votes — should think again.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Is in Denial
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: From fake news stories to ideological bubbles, Facebook is having a corrosive effect on our society. It needs to be fixed.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — Donald J. Trump’s supporters were probably heartened in September, when, according to an article shared nearly a million times on Facebook, the candidate received an endorsement from Pope Francis. Their opinions on Hillary Clinton may have soured even further after reading a Denver Guardian article that also spread widely on Facebook, which reported days before the election that an F.B.I. agent suspected of involvement in leaking Mrs. Clinton’s emails was found dead in an apparent murder-suicide.

headline: There Are No Permanent Victories in Politics

lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: Hi, Gail. So just when we thought that 2016 couldn’t get any more shocking, it did, with a Trump victory. I told you last week that strange happenings were afoot in the universe, what with the Cubs winning the World Series and all.

abstract: In an interview on “60 Minutes,” President-elect Donald Trump said he had not decided whether to prosecute Hillary Clinton.

headline: ‘I Was Terrified’: Inmates Say They Paid a Brutal Price for a Guard’s Injury
abstract: Prisoners at Mid-State Correctional Facility near Utica, N.Y., say they were punched and kicked and had their heads slammed in a door and through a wall by officers who blamed two inmates for the injury.
lead_paragraph: The inmates were just starting their day on July 6 when dozens of corrections officers burst into their dormitory, shouting for everyone to get down on the floor. The raid at Mid-State Correctional Facility, outside Utica, N.Y., officials said, was a surprise search for weapons made urgent after a bloody injury to a guard three days earlier.

headline: Breathing and Stress

headline: A New Look at August Sander’s ‘People of the Twentieth Century’
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art has enlisted scholars and artists to take a deeper look at Sander’s ambitious effort to catalog the German people.
lead_paragraph: When August Sander conceived of the structure of his ambitious portrait series, “People of the Twentieth Century,” his goal was to document the German people in a way that rejected the era’s social divisions. Starting in the mid-1920s and through the rise of Nazism, he became keenly aware that the notion of cataloging a people sometimes took on different meanings.

headline: Yemeni Bankers Get in Trouble Over a Customer, Al Qaeda

The event was a potential Final Four preview, five months early. It was also a vivid reminder that the sport remains an oligarchy.

headline: Gems, Hidden in Plain Sight in Macedonia
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Eco-Tourism', 'Caves and Caverns', 'Hikes and Hiking']
abstract: Hundreds of millions of dollars are going toward transforming Macedonia’s capital. But there are already jewels off the beaten path.
lead_paragraph: Every tourist to the Balkans has probably heard about the dramatic remaking of  Macedonia’s capital, Skopje. Twenty-five years after the country peacefully won independence from the former Yugoslavia, its capital is in the midst of a huge face-lift: the construction of some 40 monuments, sculptures, facades and buildings.

headline: Secret Back Door in Some U.S. Phones Sent Data to China, Analysts Say
abstract: Security contractors recently discovered preinstalled software in some Android phones that monitors where users go, whom they talk to and what they write in texts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For about $50, you can get a smartphone with a high-definition display, fast data service and, according to security contractors, a secret feature: a backdoor that sends all your text messages to China every 72 hours.

headline: Biggest Spike in Traffic Deaths in 50 Years? Blame Apps
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Mobile Applications', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Highway deaths have surged in the last two years, and experts put much of the blame on in-car use of smartphones and dashboard apps.
lead_paragraph: The messaging app Snapchat allows motorists to post photos that record the speed of the vehicle. The navigation app Waze rewards drivers with points when they report traffic jams and accidents. Even the game Pokémon Go has drivers searching for virtual creatures on the nation’s highways.

headline: In Charleston, Coming to Terms With the Past
abstract: The compulsion to engage the Charleston area’s complex history as a slave-trading center was, for the writer, a visceral thing, akin to the urge to revisit a crime scene.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1862, cloaked in the predawn darkness of Charleston Harbor, 23-year-old Robert Smalls stood aboard the C.S.S. Planter, a Confederate transfer and gunboat, and plotted his escape.

headline: Mexico Awaits Trump’s Next Move
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Mexican-Americans', 'North American Free Trade Agreement']
abstract: Even without a wall, his border-bashing could backfire on the United States.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — On Nov. 8, this mountain capital was soaked by a ferocious off-season thunderstorm, the type of tempest that can lead to jokes about the Aztec rain god Tlaloc being angry. At the same time, over the Rio Grande, a political storm raged worthy of the deity’s fury: The United States elected a president who promised to build a border wall and make Mexico pay for it, deport millions of immigrants and rewrite or rip up a trade deal that Mexico depends on for almost a third of its income. Within hours, an economic storm also seemed to be brewing, with the peso losing value at the fastest rate since the “tequila crisis” of 1994.

So Booker would rub the sleep from his eyes and then go about the unpleasant business of becoming a better basketball player.

The artist and museum administrator spent a year and a half there, scrupulously overseeing the display of antiquities from the nearby archaeological sites of Hatra, Nimrud and Nineveh.

headline: How Germany Soured on Obama
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Unfulfilled promises, wiretapping and a disregard for Europe have disgruntled Germans.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When Barack Obama visited here as a senator in 2008, he was greeted by a crowd of 200,000 as a man in the image of John F. Kennedy, who in 1963 assured Berliners  that he was one of them. After eight years of George W. Bush, Mr. Obama seemed to promise not just a course correction, but a new enlightened era in American global leadership. The decision to award him the Nobel Peace Prize at the start of his presidency reflects the Continent’s initial high hopes that he would prove a more “European” president.

headline: Trump Campaign’s Easy Answers Confront Hard Reality

lead_paragraph: The harvest had just begun when agents from the Immigration and Naturalization Service stormed across the onion fields of Vidalia, Ga., in 1998, sweeping up 21 immigrants who were trudging behind tractors without legal authorization to work in the United States, pulling onions out of the ground for 75 cents per 50-pound bag.

lead_paragraph: EL PASO, Tex. — General Francisco Gonzales, Carranzista commander of the Juarez garrison, has refused to release three American prisoners who are being held as spies in that town. The Carranzista leader persists in his refusal in spite of direct demands made by the United States Government.

headline: A Reporter’s Lesson: Giving a Voice to the Ignored
abstract: For decades, young reporters and news assistants at The Times have begun their careers on the Neediest Cases beat.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a quarter-century ago, as a junior reporter in our newsroom, I received one of the most significant assignments of my career: writing stories about the many people helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

headline: After a Lifetime of Instability, Hoping for a Place to Touch Down
abstract: Gregory Manson, 43, knows the importance of having a roof over his head after bouncing around shelters and transitional living facilities in the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Manson has moved so many times that he struggles to remember all of the dates, the neighborhoods and the family members he has stayed with. There was his stepmother in Canarsie, Brooklyn, a sister in Jamaica, Queens, and his grandmother’s apartment in the Farragut Houses in Brooklyn. It is all blended and blurred.

headline: Hartford Kicks Open Its Doors to Innovators
abstract: A new state grant program is aimed at creating urban settings to support entrepreneurs and attract younger workers.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — After Lelaneia Dubay developed an intolerance for the gluten and chemical additives in many alcoholic beverages, she went looking for a way to salvage her cocktail hour. Already skilled at making cranberry liqueur, which she bottled and gave as gifts at Christmas, she came up with a formula for a lavender liqueur, using sprigs from her garden. When she shared it with friends at a holiday party, their response was emphatic: Get this to market.

headline: Everyone Shoots 3s Now. Even Brook Lopez.
abstract: After taking a total of seven 3-point attempts in his first six N.B.A. seasons, the Nets center has hoisted up 38 this season, in only eight games.
lead_paragraph: Brook Lopez is not the stereotypical 3-point shooter. A 7-foot Nets center, he is thought of as a classic inside player, looking to create easy buckets.

lead_paragraph: Veronica Garcia, who lives in Houston, makes arroz con leche, a creamy and sweet Mexican rice pudding.

lead_paragraph: Maura Passanisi, who lives in Alameda, Calif., makes Sweeney potatoes, a cheesy, creamy mainstay of her Irish grandparents’ Thanksgiving table.

headline: Dwayne Johnson, a.k.a. the Rock, Is People’s Sexiest Man Alive
abstract: At 6-foot-5 and 245 pounds, Mr. Johnson is the first Samoan and one of the most muscular men ever chosen by the magazine.
lead_paragraph: People magazine has named Dwayne Johnson, a.k.a. The Rock, its “Sexiest Man Alive” for 2016, ushering him into an elite group of physically appealing men that over the years has included George Clooney, Matt Damon and David Beckham.

headline: Study Shows Promise for Expensive Cholesterol Drugs, but They Are Still Hard to Obtain
abstract: A study of so-called PCSK9 inhibitors showed they can reduce the size of plaques in arteries that may cause heart attacks, a signal that they will show benefit in reducing heart attack risk.
lead_paragraph: If there is one thing decades of studies with tens of thousands of heart disease patients have revealed, it is that lowering cholesterol can reduce the risk of heart attacks and deaths. Now, with new drugs on the market that can plunge cholesterol levels lower than ever thought possible, researchers are eagerly waiting for an answer to the next question: Is there a limit to the benefits in high-risk patients? After a certain point, do benefits level off or even reverse?

headline: Leaked ‘Brexit’ Memo Says U.K. Is Unsure How to Proceed
abstract: A report in the British media whose origins were not revealed said 30,000 additional civil servants would be needed to negotiate departure from the E.U.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The government of Britain could need six more months to settle on a plan for negotiating the country’s exit from the European Union and an extra 30,000 civil servants to deal with the complexities of the task, according to a memo of uncertain parentage leaked to The Times of London on Tuesday.

headline: At an Old Racetrack, a New Place to Get Away
abstract: Saratoga Springs boasts a growing number of visitors — and now, a chic place for them to stay.
lead_paragraph: Much attention has been given in recent years to the small-town charms of New York’s Hudson Valley, where city folks have been escaping in droves on the weekends. But just a little farther north (about an hour from the town of Hudson itself), Saratoga Springs is starting to get a second glance by urbanites looking for something different. Known primarily for its famous racetrack (home to the Travers Stakes — one of the biggest Thoroughbred horse races in the country), the town also has a surprisingly rich cultural calendar, with a performing arts center that hosts several opera, ballet and symphonic acts throughout the year; and a spectacular collection of perfectly preserved Victorian, Federal and neo-Classical buildings that line its streets.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Addresses Troll Problem. Again.

lead_paragraph: The news reports filled the city with gloom. From out of a big Manhattan real estate firm had come a change that few locals expected or wanted. Reactions were apocalyptic. There was a shared fear that we were moving in the wrong direction, that the values of our community were being trampled by dark, hostile forces.

Trump and top Republicans in Congress embracing proposals that could leave millions of poorer Americans without health insurance and jeopardize a major element of President Obama’s legacy.

Trump’s election last week, on Tuesday warned against the rise of nationalistic tribalism, apparently a reference to Mr. Trump’s decision to appoint Stephen K. Bannon, a hard-right nationalist, to a top position.

headline: Presidential Forecast Post-Mortem

headline: Trump Won the Election, but 3 Manhattan Buildings Will Lose His Name

abstract: Hundreds of tenants at the buildings on Riverside Boulevard, which contain 1,325 apartments, signed a petition to “Dump the TRUMP name” last month.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump will not be sworn in for two more months, but as of next week, the big gold letters spelling out his name will be removed from three large apartment buildings on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, tenants were told on Tuesday.

headline: Wagamama, Serving Asian-Influenced Dishes, Opens in NoMad
abstract: A pop-up sets down roots in the East Village, and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: WAGAMAMA It’s easy to understand why Asian restaurant groups that have come to New York — like Sugarfish from Los Angeles, Ootoya from Tokyo and now Wagamama from London — do not want to be called chains. These places are well designed, with interiors handsomely finished in fine materials. Wagamama, which started in 1992 and has 150 locations worldwide, has opened a two-story space in the NoMad area that seats more than 200, mostly at counters and communal tables. Some seats face the kitchen, though with a no-reservations policy, snaring one may be a challenge. The food, made fresh, is basically Asian, highlighting ramen but also offering soba noodle dishes, donburi rice bowls and curries, which the executive chef of the group, Steve Mangleshot, thinks will have special appeal for New Yorkers. This is the only location where spirits are poured and brunch will be served: 210 Fifth Avenue (26th Street), 212-920-6233, wagamama.us.

headline: The Dream — and the Myth — of the ‘Women’s Vote’
abstract: We used to imagine women would naturally vote together. Then we imagined they could be persuaded to. It has yet to happen.
lead_paragraph: When Victoria Woodhull ran for president of the United States, she couldn’t even vote for herself. “If the women can be allowed to vote,” The New York Herald claimed when Woodhull announced her bid in 1870, “Mrs. Woodhull may rely on rolling up the heaviest majority ever polled in this or any other nation.” After all, the paper said, “women always take the part of each other.” The Herald called for passage of a women’s suffrage amendment, and then “victory for Victoria in 1872.”

headline: Mourning Its King, Thailand Respectfully Cheers Its Soccer Team to a Tie
abstract: A World Cup qualifier against Australia was nearly canceled, and cheering was discouraged, by a host country still coming to terms with its longtime monarch’s death.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Many expected there would be tears at the Rajamangala National Stadium on Tuesday when Thailand played Australia in a World Cup qualifier only a month after the death of the host country’s much-loved king. But it was a little surprising that they came at the end of the 90 minutes.

headline: Congressional Republicans Project Unity While Democrats Scramble
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: House Speaker Paul D. Ryan, who was unanimously renominated, spoke of a new G.O.P. government focused on turning President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory into progress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans, donning “Make America Great Again” hats on Tuesday, celebrated their impending control of government, sidestepping questions about disarray in President-elect Donald J. Trump’s transition efforts while Democrats struggled to unify behind their leadership after a brutal election defeat.

headline: Warren Buffett, in a Switch, Warms to Airline Industry
abstract: Mr. Buffett’s holding company, Berkshire Hathaway, is sinking more than $1.3 billion into the four largest American carriers.

headline: Canada Takes Steps to Address Discriminatory Policies Against Gays

lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canadian lawmakers introduced legislation to make the age of consent 16 for all forms of sexual intercourse, one of two overtures the government of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau took on Tuesday to combat a history of discrimination against sexual minorities.

headline: As a Noxious Smog Descends, Tehran Tries to Ignore It
abstract: A winter-long miasma of smoke and dust is the new normal in Tehran and many other cities, so much so that fatalistic Iranians simply pretend that the sky is blue and the air is clean.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — This week, as a yellow blanket of smog settled in for what is typically a winter-long stay, Reza Shajiee, a prominent hipster socialite, posted a picture of himself on Instagram wearing a gas mask under his motorcycle helmet. The text reads, “My city is better than yours, its air is better than yours,” and is accompanied by an emoticon wearing a gas mask.

headline: Stream This Documentary About Filmmaker Hayao Miyazaki

lead_paragraph: During the filming “The Kingdom of Dreams and Madness,” a 2013 documentary about the Japanese animation house Studio Ghibli, the beloved animator Hayao Miyazaki announced he would retire. Now Miyazaki, the creative mind behind “Spirited Away,” “Princess Mononoke” and “My Neighbor Totoro” has announced that he is working on a new film.

headline: Gardnar Mulloy, a Tennis Champion Who Later Championed Senior Tennis, Dies at 102
abstract: Mulloy, a brilliant doubles player inducted into the Hall of Fame in 1972, was ranked No. 1 in the U.S. in 1952 and won more than 125 national tournaments, most of them in senior play.
lead_paragraph: When Gardnar Mulloy was 9 years old or so, his father and uncle built a clay court in the backyard of the family home in Miami. The boy swatted tennis balls with them, then found players his own age at a local park. He was still at it in his 90s, playing senior tournament tennis, having long outlasted his opponents from the days when he was one of the most brilliant doubles players of his time.

headline: Two Men and a Show
abstract: A new exhibition combines works by Willem de Kooning and Zao Wou-Ki.
lead_paragraph: To coincide with the expansion of her Madison Avenue gallery next month, Dominique Lévy is mounting an exhibition of side-by-side works by Willem de Kooning and Zao Wou-Ki (currently the subject of a solo show at the Asia Society). The two very different expressive painters were both restless experimenters. Frustrated with the formal limitations of the Chinese academy, Zao left for Paris in 1948, while de Kooning, born in the Netherlands and also classically trained, arrived in New York in 1927. The artists found their signature styles around the same time: de Kooning’s infamous “Woman” canvases, exhibited in 1953, broke his association with Abstract Expressionism, and his aggressive dismantling of the female body still unsettles. A year later, Zao changed brushes and technique to create his signature chaotic landscapes. His swirling “4-6-62” has the feel of a tornado, or an atom bomb. Lévy describes the show as “a combat between two giants.’’

headline: A Tribe Called Quest Returns to a Changed World With Joy and Grief
abstract: One of the essential 1990s hip-hop groups is back with its first album in 18 years, an often stunning work that interweaves social and political truth-telling.
lead_paragraph: In the music business, when you disappear for a long stretch of time, you abandon your right to grouse about how things have changed in your absence. Nostalgia is a cheap crutch and a lame weapon. When the whole world is changing, though, disappearing and then re-emerging in different circumstances can be more deeply destabilizing. The things you held dear might be missing, or under attack. Adjusting is a full-time job.

headline: For Composer Lei Liang, Technology Brings a Different Transcendence
abstract: Mr. Liang, who has a coming Composer Portrait concert at the Miller Theater, transformed his composing process after research involving high-resolution scans of Chinese paintings.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon, the composer Lei Liang looked on silently as the ensemble Loadbang made its second pass through his “Lakescape V.” For seven years a commission from the busy Mr. Liang had been on a wish list kept by the group, an unusual quartet consisting of trumpet, trombone, bass clarinet and baritone voice. It became a fixed point on the calendar nearly three years ago, when a concert of Mr. Liang’s music was scheduled for Thursday, part of the Miller Theater’s Composer Portrait series.

headline: Faye Driscoll’s Tingling Force Field With the Dance Audience
abstract: In “Thank You for Coming: Play,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, her dancers are delving into the social experience of storytelling.
lead_paragraph: In a studio at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on a recent afternoon, a few dancers stood around chatting, as if catching up before rehearsal. Yet the conversation, upon closer listening, sounded warped, like a script chopped up and scrambled. Gestures, words and facial expressions didn’t quite match up, tricking the mind into seeking a clear, coherent message that never arrived.

headline: Sketchbook Attributed to van Gogh Pits Scholars Against a Museum

headline: Review: Puppets Are the Stars in ‘Il Ritorno d’Ulisse’
abstract: With poignant singing by Romina Basso, Jeffrey Thompson and others, the cast and musicians help the tale and the puppets come alive at the White Light Festival.
lead_paragraph: The most wrenching moment in Monteverdi’s opera “Il Ritorno d’Ulisse” (“The Return of Ulysses”), based on Homer, comes when we first meet Penelope, Ulysses’ wife. She has been waiting for what feels like an eternity for her husband to return from the Trojan War; she is unsure if he is even still alive.

headline: TransPerfect Is Threatened by Owners’ Petulance
abstract: The successful language translation company may end up being sold because the owners seem to be acting like spoiled children, wreaking havoc on it.
lead_paragraph: A Delaware court decision to require the sale of TransPerfect, the big, profitable language translation company, has employees howling. They fear their employer will be pushed into the hands of a private equity buyer who would cut jobs. But the real fault lies with the owners who seem to be acting like spoiled children, wreaking havoc on the company they founded.

lead_paragraph: Shoddy oversight and ineffective management at the City University of New York have created a system “ripe for abuse” that has potentially siphoned money away from needy students and crucial campus projects, according to a report released on Tuesday by the New York State inspector general.

headline: Megyn Kelly’s Cautionary Tale of Crossing Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Books and Literature']

lead_paragraph: The Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly has spent the better part of the last year living in the main gladiator pit of 2016, becoming as much a target for Donald J. Trump as any of his opponents and emerging as a pivotal figure in the forced resignation of the Fox News Channel chairman Roger Ailes, whom she accused of sexual harassment.

headline: New York City Helps to Keep Police Records Secret
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Editorials']
abstract: The de Blasio administration should instead be promoting transparency by supporting the public’s right to know about officers’ misconduct.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who promised an open government, has been far from transparent when it comes to the conduct of police officers. Last year, his administration appealed a well-reasoned state court decision that ordered it to release summaries of misconduct findings against the officer who used a choke hold in the 2014 arrest of Eric Garner. More recently, under a narrow reading of state law, it shut down access to Police Department records containing routine personnel information that had been open to the news media for decades.

headline: Catholic Bishops Challenge Donald Trump on Immigration
abstract: In their annual conference, Catholic bishops elected new leaders and said they are preparing to defend immigrants and refugees against a wave of anger.
lead_paragraph: Two nights after Donald J. Trump won the presidential election, Archbishop José H. Gomez convened an interfaith prayer service at the Roman Catholic cathedral in Los Angeles and gave an emotional homily vowing not to abandon children and parents who are living in fear that Mr. Trump will follow through on his promise to deport millions of immigrants.

headline: Dick Oliver, Reporter for ‘Good Day New York,’ Dies at 77
abstract: A longtime reporter and editor who was at the scene as planes hit the World Trade Center on 9/11.
lead_paragraph: Dick Oliver, an award-winning reporter and editor for The Daily News who became familiar to New York television audiences as a longtime correspondent for the local morning show “Good Day New York,” died on Nov. 11 in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: The American Thanksgiving

headline: College Football Playoff Rankings: Ohio State, at No. 2, Is in a Tough Spot
abstract: With Alabama safely No. 1, the Buckeyes jumped ahead of Michigan (No. 3) and Clemson (No. 4) but face a tough road to the Big Ten championship game.
lead_paragraph: Following a weekend in which three of the top four teams lost, the expected shake-up in the College Football Playoff rankings was made official Tuesday night. After No. 1 Alabama (10-0), the sole undefeated major-conference team, Nos. 2 through 4, representing the teams that would complete the playoff bracket if the season ended Tuesday, were Ohio State (9-1), Michigan (9-1) and Clemson (9-1).

headline: Statement on Trump Puts New Balance Shoe Company in Cross Hairs
abstract: A comment by an official from the shoemaker about the president-elect’s opposition to a trade deal prompted strong reactions from Trump friends and foes.
lead_paragraph: Before this month, New Balance was lucky if it generated a few hundred reactions to posts on its Facebook page. Now, the sneaker company’s page is flooded with impassioned commentary, and it has found itself compelled to make a statement distancing itself from white supremacists.

headline: Midweek Pick-Me-Up
abstract: Jim Peredo gets us singing a familiar refrain.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes you really need a pick-me-up, especially when it is midweek and the weekend is not really on the horizon yet.

headline: Review: ‘Party People,’ a Nostalgic Look at 1960s Radicalism
abstract: This semidocumentary play at the Public Theater, from the spoken-word collective Universes, may be the most frightening and exciting piece of theater now up.
lead_paragraph: There were shouts and moans and finger snaps at a weekend performance of “Party People” at the Public Theater. Tears and laughter joined together; so did sympathy and rage. Commissioned by the Oregon Shakespeare Festival for its “American Revolutions” cycle, developed by the director Liesl Tommy and written by the spoken-word collective Universes, this semidocumentary work is a disjointed exploration of two 1960s radical groups, the Black Panther Party and the Young Lords Party. In the current political climate, it may be the most frightening and exciting piece of theater now up.

headline: Truffles in Paradise. (And It’s Not Italy.)
abstract: The Istrian truffle is premium grade and its culture is free of the snobbery, intrigue and high prices found in Italy’s Piedmont or France’s Perigord.
lead_paragraph: “Go Nero!” Nikola Tarandek, a truffle hunter, urged on his black Labrador, who scratched furiously at the moist soil of Motovun Forest in Croatia. We were in the hinterlands of Istria, a diamond-shaped peninsula that juts into the Adriatic Sea, exploring one of the richest grounds for premium white truffles — long overshadowed in fame but not quality by the truffle mecca of Alba in the Piedmont region of Italy. Nero had caught the scent at the roots of an oak, sending up clumps of dirt as Mr. Tarandek twisted a spade into the black earth.

headline: Want America First? Try Free Trade
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The best way to advance the interests of American workers and consumers is to negotiate better and stronger international agreements.
lead_paragraph: IF you bought yourself or someone you love medicine, a smartphone, new clothes or a child’s toy today, your purchase was most likely made from a mix of components from many countries. The same was true for the meal you bought, the car you drove, the plane on which you recently flew and the carpet where your feet rest as you read these words.

headline: Obama in Trumpland
abstract: Behold the president’s wishful bid to tame the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: If Election Day seemed to be a dream (or, rather, nightmare) devoid of logic, the week since has done little to render the world more coherent.

headline: Can Trumpism Survive a Trump Administration?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The new president’s revolution is short on the revolutionaries required to implement it.
lead_paragraph: Even before he won the presidency, Donald J. Trump had a strong claim to being the most ideologically disruptive presidential nominee of modern times. From the Bush family to Paul Ryan, the Iraq war to entitlement reform, Trump arrayed himself against the personalities and policies of the Republican Party, and his campaign took a wrecking ball to many of his adopted party’s orthodoxies, proposing a vision of right-wing politics far more mercantilist, nationalist and statist than anything we’ve seen from the post-Reagan, post-Goldwater G.O.P.

headline: Bullying in the Age of Trump
abstract: Will the moral values that schools and parents have instilled in young people erode during a Trump presidency?
lead_paragraph: Kids who are in religious or ethnic minorities, or are gay or disabled, are more likely to be bullied in school than other kids. Their point of difference can be a point of vulnerability. In the last decade, schools have put more energy into preventing bullying, to the benefit of these kids and others (girls, too, are more frequent targets). And they’ve often had the authority of the courts, state legislatures and the federal Department of Education behind them.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Elections in Bulgaria and Moldova offer more evidence of growing disenchantment in Eastern Europe with Western liberal attitudes.
lead_paragraph: After Brexit and the election of Donald Trump, it seems alarming that Bulgaria and Moldova, two states formerly under the Kremlin’s yoke, both elected pro-Russian presidents on Sunday. The reasons may have been largely domestic, but the outcome is bound to further fray European cohesion.

headline: Should the Electoral College Be Abolished?
abstract: Once again, the U.S. is faced with a president-elect who has won the electoral votes but not the popular vote.

headline: Overtime With American Football in Russia
abstract: Vasiliy Kolotilov was so taken by American football in Russia that he immersed himself in its world, where an opening-day game might attract only a handful of spectators.
lead_paragraph: Vasiliy Kolotilov found out about an American football league in Russia where most people discover bizarre, out-of-the-ordinary things: the internet. After a bit of investigation, he pitched a piece on the Spartans — a local football team in Moscow — to a newspaper. In March, he attended some training sessions and published the article. But that wasn’t enough.

headline: The Latest Piece of Alexander McQueen Memorabilia: A London Penthouse
abstract: A duplex in the Mayfair neighborhood, decorated in homage to Mr. McQueen, is on the market for $10.6 million — even though he never lived there.
lead_paragraph: The enduring fascination with the life of Alexander McQueen shows no signs of slowing, more than six years after his death and five years after “Savage Beauty,” the blockbuster retrospective exhibition of his work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute.

headline: Finding a Rich Vein of Humor in China’s Past
abstract: Christopher Rea, a literary historian, discusses the flowering of comedy, farce and satire in early 20th-century China, and the parallels to be found today.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Rea is a literary and cultural historian at the University of British Columbia. A 39-year-old native of Berkeley, Calif., he has written on major figures in modern Chinese literature, including Qian Zhongshu and Yang Jiang. His new work, “The Age of Irreverence: A New History of Laughter in China,” shows how the early 20th century inspired a flowering of comedy, farce, cursing and satire. In it, one finds interesting parallels to today, especially in how people stick it to authority.

headline: Pennies
abstract: Should the United States get rid of the penny? What are your arguments for and against this idea?
lead_paragraph: Canada stopped making pennies in 2012, and with good reason. Coining pennies is a money-losing proposition, and people don’t really need them anymore.

headline: Questions for: ‘Eye Injuries in Youth Sports Are Surprisingly Common’
abstract: New data from hospital emergency room visits reveals frequent eye injuries during basketball, baseball, softball, soccer and cycling.
lead_paragraph: Article: “Eye Injuries in Youth Sports Are Surprisingly Common”

headline: Am I Obliged to Support My Elderly Mother?
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Elderly', 'Privacy', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Families and Family Life', 'Letters', 'Doctors', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what a child owes an aging parent, who is entitled to read a found letter and more.
lead_paragraph: I recently graduated from college — the first person in my family to do so — and am trying to make a life for myself in New York. My father passed away several months ago, and my mother, who is in her 70s, is incapable of financial independence. She has never been financially responsible, and now the burden has fallen on my shoulders, because she has no family and I’m an only child. In my view, she lives way beyond her means; each time I suggest that she cut out a few expenses (fewer trips to the beauty parlor, shopping at a discount market), she breaks down and often lashes out at me. I fear that if I continue to support her, I’ll never be able to save enough money for my own future.

headline: Escape From East Berlin
abstract: Greg Mitchell’s “The Tunnels” recounts how, in 1962, a group of Germans tunnelled under the new wall — with help from NBC.
lead_paragraph: THE TUNNELSEscapes Under the Berlin Wall and the Historic Films the JFK White House Tried to KillBy Greg MitchellIllustrated. 382 pp. Crown. $28.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Bogs
abstract: Often associated with murk and evil spirits, bogs are actually quite vibrant — a whole ecosystem laid bare.
lead_paragraph: Bogs, never the most cherished of landscapes, got a particularly bad rap when I was growing up in the 1980s. There were the fantasy films, of course — perhaps you remember the “Bog of Eternal Stench” from “Labyrinth,” one of many obstacles standing between a young Jennifer Connelly and David Bowie’s Goblin King. But my youthful preconceptions were perhaps shaped more by Boglins, a series of grotesque rubbery puppets released by Mattel. Mine was named Dwork, a slime-green monstrosity with hooded eyes, and for years thereafter it remained my physical reference point for bogs, a land type whose very name, with its double plosive, became a byword in my mind for murk and monsters.

headline: What’s the Matter With College Basketball?
abstract: It isn’t the low scoring or the quality of play.
lead_paragraph: In the moments after Villanova’s Kris Jenkins hit a game-winning shot to beat North Carolina in the final of last season’s N.C.A.A. tournament, I was lying on my couch with my phone held a few inches from my face. The Crying Jordan meme was all over my social-media feeds, and although I had drifted from my Tar Heels-obsessed childhood, I felt unusually bummed out. Two powerhouse programs with huge followings had just played a game that featured a furious comeback in the final minutes; a magic game-tying shot by Marcus Paige, North Carolina’s senior guard; and, of course, Jenkins’s buzzer beater. After the game, Paige choked up at the news conference and Carolina’s fan base let out a long sigh for a player it had cheered on for four years. The game felt as if it had been scripted to hit all the nerve endings of what makes us care about college sports, and if the quality of the actual play was not up to par, no one but the most hardened sports wonk would have noticed.

headline: Seeing the Diversity of Jewish Thought in 18 Classic Texts
abstract: In “The People and the Books,” Adam Kirsch summarizes classic texts and finds surprising cultural differences over thousands of years.
lead_paragraph: THE PEOPLE AND THE BOOKS18 Classics of Jewish LiteratureBy Adam Kirsch407 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $28.95.

lead_paragraph: Have you seen an increase in hate speech where you live? Have you noticed any increase in bullying, threats or other hateful actions? What can we, as individuals and as a nation, do about hate crimes directed at people because of their ethnicity, gender, race or religion?

headline: Squash, Rice and Roadkill: Feeding the Fighters of Standing Rock
keywords: ['Native Americans', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Pipelines', 'Food', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: As they resist a vast oil pipeline, protesters need their own kind of fuel. They get it via a chaotic yet robust network of what amounts to free restaurants.
lead_paragraph: CANNON BALL, N.D. — On any given night, supper lines here at the dusty prairie camps near the Missouri River where the last piece of a 1,170-mile pipeline is set to be placed might include young Navajo women from Arizona who have never camped in the cold, and older white women for whom chaining themselves to a fence for a cause is nothing new.

headline: Feeding the Fight at Standing Rock
abstract: Step into a kitchen at Oceti Sakowin camp, where Winona Kasto prepares daily meals for hundreds of Native Americans and supporters who have mobilized to block the Dakota Access pipeline project.
lead_paragraph: Step into a kitchen at Oceti Sakowin camp, where Winona Kasto prepares daily meals for hundreds of Native Americans and supporters who have mobilized to block the Dakota Access pipeline project.

headline: Glen Ridge, N.J.: Neighborly and Close to Midtown
abstract: This cozy, residential borough 20 miles from Midtown Manhattan has gas lamps, historic homes and great schools, but property taxes run high.
lead_paragraph: When Becky and David Middleton, both 41, needed more space for their family of four children, ages 6 to 11, they moved just 10 blocks, paying $840,000 last April for an 1887 Victorian farmhouse with five bedrooms in Glen Ridge, N.J. A kitchen and bathroom renovation is underway.

lead_paragraph: A view of two imaginary nations created by slicing the country along the sharp divide between Republican and Democratic Americas.

headline: Review: A Decade On, Wayne McGregor Continues to Energize the Royal Ballet
abstract: A triple bill in London celebrates the choreographer’s nontraditional approach to classical dance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It has been 10 years since the cool white minimalism and electric-current physicality of Wayne McGregor’s “Chroma” first thrilled Royal Ballet audiences here, and led to his appointment as the company’s resident choreographer. It was a daring choice by Monica Mason, then the director of the Royal Ballet, since Mr. McGregor was a contemporary dance choreographer who did not come from a ballet background.

headline: A Call to Prayer, or Noise Pollution? Israel Targets Mosque Loudspeakers
abstract: In response to noise complaints, a proposal backed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu would ban the use of loudspeakers by mosques summoning the faithful.
lead_paragraph: LOD, Israel — It would be easy to miss the mosque in a temporary building with a concrete floor and corrugated roof. But it is impossible to miss the constellation of six loudspeakers atop a giant metal structure resembling the Eiffel Tower.

headline: Presidential Transition, Snapchat, Frank Ocean: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Julio Le Parc and Art That Won’t Stand Still
abstract: The Paris-based artist Julio Le Parc is one of Latin America’s foremost proponents of Kinetic art. Now, his work is finding a new audience in the United States.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The suburban Paris home studio of the Argentine artist Julio Le Parc, widely considered a pioneer of Op Art and Kinetic Art, is a circus of hands-on — sometimes anarchic — delights. In one of a series of rooms surrounding an overgrown courtyard, the artist’s motorized “contorsions” come to life when a switch is flipped, and their rotating arms and reflective metal ribbons refract light into patterns on the wall. Nearby, mirrored sculptures from his “Déplacements” series produce disorienting optical illusions as a viewer moves around them, while the projected-light installations in yet another room create disco-ball effects of shifting color.

headline: Morning Agenda: Snap Listing, Ackman’s Fortune, Ex-Goldman Executive Joins Evercore
abstract: Snapchat’s debut could bring an end to a relative drought in initial public offerings.
lead_paragraph: There is an end in sight to the drought in major initial public offerings.

headline: How to Use Uber and Other Ride-Shares
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Budget Travel', 'Mobile Applications', 'Tips and Tipping']
abstract: Some ride-share tips for the uninitiated, and some pointers for the casual user.
lead_paragraph: Ride-sharing has become a multibillion-dollar business over the last several years. The traditional taxi industry has been upended and is now forced to compete with drivers using their own automobiles, sometimes as a side job, summoned by the tap of a smartphone.

headline: How Exercise Might Keep Depression at Bay
abstract: Three new studies involving more than a million men and women strongly suggest that regular exercise makes us resistant to despair.
lead_paragraph: Exercise may be an effective treatment for depression and might even help prevent us from becoming depressed in the first place, according to three timely new studies. The studies pool outcomes from past research involving more than a million men and women and, taken together, strongly suggest that regular exercise alters our bodies and brains in ways that make us resistant to despair.

headline: Social Media’s Globe-Shaking Power
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The election of Donald J. Trump is perhaps the starkest illustration yet that social networks are helping to rewire human society.
lead_paragraph: As the technology industry came to grips in the last week with the reality of a presidential election that did not go its way, many in Silicon Valley landed on the idea that widespread misinformation spread online was a primary factor in the race’s outcome.

headline: In Burkina Faso, Rebuilding With a Local Touch
abstract: The award-winning architect Francis Kéré continues to focus on West Africa, where he has designed schools, medical centers and cultural spaces.
lead_paragraph: The architect Francis Kéré was born in a poor village in Burkina Faso where there was no school, no electricity and no access to clean drinking water. His father, the village chief, decided that his son should be the first in the family to learn how to read and write, so he sent him at age 7 to live with an uncle in a distant city, where he sat with 150 other students in an unventilated classroom in 110-degree heat. During his free time, like many of his peers, Mr. Kéré had to work, spending hours fixing crudely built homes, which were in a perpetual state of disrepair. “In my heart, I felt even then that I wanted to build things better one day, so that kids like me would be free to learn,” he said.

headline: New York Today: Hints of the Holidays
abstract: Wednesday: Festive market stalls return to the city, a former mayor on the rise and the Astor Place Cube.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:16 a.m.

headline: India Bans Organization Run by Controversial Televangelist Preacher
abstract: The organization, the Islamic Research Foundation, was banned after accusations that the preacher, Zakir Naik, promoted terrorism through his speeches.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian government has banned a nongovernmental organization run by a popular televangelist preacher, Zakir Naik, after accusations that he promoted terrorism through his speeches.

headline: Why Ukraine Is Losing the War on Corruption
abstract: I know from Georgia the challenges of reforming a post-Soviet state, but the leadership in Kiev is failing to rein in its kleptocrats.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Few politicians in the world have had to undergo the same experience twice in their career and in different countries. Yet this is exactly what happened to me in Ukraine and Georgia.

headline: Turkey’s Populists See an Unlikely Ally
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Muslims and Islam', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Donald Trump’s Islamophobia isn’t enough to turn off President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his supporters.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The election of Donald J. Trump as the next president of the United States came as an unpleasant shock to much of the world. But in Turkey, my country, it was applauded — not by everyone, for sure, but by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his enthusiastic supporters.

headline: How to Be Mindful at Airport Security
abstract: Long, slow-moving lines don’t have to be a time for anxiety.
lead_paragraph: “Long lines at airport security can induce anxiety, especially if they are slow-moving and you are cutting it close to boarding time,” says Melissa Eisler, a meditation teacher in San Diego and author of MindfulMinutes.com.

headline: Confronting Racism in Berlin, One Offensive T-Shirt at a Time
abstract: Isaiah Lopaz, a black, college-educated artist and writer living in Berlin, was frequently assumed to be a drug dealer. Then he had an idea for how to respond.
lead_paragraph: Isaiah Lopaz is a black American living in Berlin. On a regular basis Germans ask him where he comes from. No, no, where he really comes from. He’s a college-educated artist and writer — who is frequently mistaken for a drug dealer.

headline: Attacks on Hindus in Bangladesh
abstract: Prime Minister Hasina must rigorously investigate her own party, the Awami League.
lead_paragraph: Over almost two years, radical Islamists have carried out a string of brutal attacks in Bangladesh, killing scores of bloggers, foreigners and members of religious minorities. A Hindu tailor was killed in April, and a Hindu priest was hacked to death in July. A terrorist attack in Dhaka in July left 22 people dead. Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and her governing Awami League party have accused the Islamist opposition of fomenting this terrorism. In this context, the news that Awami League politicians may be implicated in recent attacks on Hindu homes and temples is profoundly disturbing.

headline: ‘Amélie,’ Reborn as a Broadway Musical Starring Phillipa Soo
abstract: With a book by Craig Lucas and music by Daniel Messé, “Amélie” is expected to begin previews at the Walter Kerr Theater in March.
lead_paragraph: A Broadway season overflowing with new musicals is about to get another one: “Amélie,” adapted from the film of the same name and starring Phillipa Soo of “Hamilton,” is heading to the Walter Kerr Theater.

headline: Facebook’s Damage to Democracy
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Media']
abstract: Information sources need to provide “reason and facts,” neither of which is partisan.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Still Running at 119? Not So Fast
abstract: Dharam Pal Singh, a farmer from India, credits herbal chutney and fruit for his sustained fitness. Sports officials do not believe his age.
lead_paragraph: PERTH, Australia — For this competition, the most astonishing name on the start list for 100 meters did not belong to Usain Bolt. But what Dharam Pal Singh of India lacked in renown, he more than made up for as an international man of mystery.

headline: California Today: Did Trump Really Have a Shot at California?
abstract: Wednesday: Trump country in the Golden State, a long-shot bid to end the Electoral College, and a new book on the McDonald’s empire.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Reporter to Trader Joe’s: Are We Having Fun Yet?
abstract: Who among us hasn’t wondered how it’s possible that every flavor of kosher hummus you buy just happens to also be the favorite of your checkout clerk?
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the reporter Noam Scheiber, who covers labor issues, mulls whether working at the offbeat grocery chain would be all fun and games or “a special form of torture.”

headline: Paris Climate Deal Is Too Weak to Meet Goals, Report Finds
keywords: ['United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Coal', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: The International Energy Agency warned that reaching the ambitious targets set forth by last year’s global climate change accord would be next to impossible.
lead_paragraph: As negotiators meet in Morocco to hammer out details of the landmark global climate change accord reached in Paris almost a year ago, the independent International Energy Agency warned that the nearly 200-nation deal was too weak to meet its avowed temperature target.

headline: What You Get for … $850,000

lead_paragraph: A house in Colorado, a condo in Miami and a midcentury modern in Illinois

headline: Syrian President Calls Donald Trump a ‘Natural Ally’ in Fight Against Terrorism
abstract: Bashar al-Assad also predicted that “opposing forces” in the U.S. government and criticism from the news media could affect Mr. Trump’s actions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, condemned by the Obama administration and much of the West for waging a brutal war of suppression against Islamist opponents in his country, said this week that President-elect Donald J. Trump could be a “natural ally” in the fight against terrorism. The comment underscored the degree to which the new administration’s approach could reverse central tenets of American foreign policy.

headline: Secret to Iceland’s Tourism Boom? A Financial Crash and a Volcanic Eruption
abstract: Two catastrophes — a 2008 crash that made the country cheap for visitors and a 2010 blast that put it on the map — transformed the island into a top destination.
lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — Iceland has discovered the secret to a booming tourist industry: First have a mammoth financial implosion, then an enormous volcanic explosion.

headline: A Victorian Home Near Belfast
abstract: The seven-bedroom house, built in 1855, is on five acres southwest of the city.
lead_paragraph: The seven-bedroom house, built in 1855, is on five acres southwest of the city.

abstract: The June referendum in which a majority of Britons voted to leave the European Union has not affected the housing market in Northern Ireland.

headline: Korean Mother Awaits a Son’s Deportation to Confess Her ‘Unforgivable Sin’
abstract: Kwon Pil-ju will soon be reunited with the son she gave up for adoption when he was a baby, confronting a shame she’s felt for 40 years.
lead_paragraph: YEONGJU, South Korea — Kwon Pil-ju is trying desperately to teach herself English before she is reunited in the coming weeks with a son she sent away almost 40 years ago.

headline: ‘American Democracy Is Bigger Than Any One Person,’ Obama Says
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Visiting Greece on his final international tour as president, Mr. Obama again discussed Donald J. Trump’s election victory.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Having warned of the risks of a Trump presidency, President Obama returned on Wednesday to a more optimistic vision of the future of the United States, as part of his final international tour while in office.

headline: ‘The Ball’s in His Court,’ Mayor de Blasio Says After Meeting With Trump
abstract: Mr. de Blasio described the 62-minute meeting at Trump Tower with the president-elect, with whom he has a history of vitriol, as respectful, substantive and “very candid.”
lead_paragraph: Of all the various cabinet hopefuls and assorted hangers-on who have come to Trump Tower to get an audience with President-elect Donald J. Trump, perhaps the least congruous might be the visitor who dropped by late Wednesday morning: Bill de Blasio.

headline: Debora L. Spar, Barnard President, to Lead Lincoln Center
abstract: Ms. Spar, who will be the first woman to run the nation’s largest performing arts center, has a strong fund-raising track record.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center, which went through a messy shake-up at the top last spring just as its long-delayed project to renovate David Geffen Hall was beginning to take shape, is turning to academia for its next leader. Debora L. Spar, the president of Barnard College, will become the arts complex’s 10th president in March, officials announced Wednesday.

headline: 1966: Gemini-12 Splashes Down; Astronauts Safe
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The Gemini-12 astronauts James Lovell and Edwin “Buzz” Aldrin splashed into the Atlantic after a four-day orbital journey, in November 1966.
lead_paragraph: CAPE KENNEDY — Gemini-12 astronauts James Lovell and Edwin (Buzz) Aldrin splashed safely into the Atlantic today after a 1.5-million mile, four-day orbital journey closing out America’s two-man Gemini flights.

headline: Inside the French Studio Where Fabienne Verdier Paints Music
abstract: The artist’s workspace was designed to accommodate her mammoth paintbrushes, which she uses suspended on tracks from the ceiling.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s workspace was designed to accommodate her mammoth paintbrushes, which she uses suspended on tracks from the ceiling.

headline: One French Painter’s Unlikely Techniques, Developed at Juilliard
abstract: Following her residency at the New York performing arts school, Fabienne Verdier paints sound and breath using vast suspended brushes.
lead_paragraph: As the first artist in residence at Juilliard, the French artist Fabienne Verdier spent a semester during 2014 in a temporary “laboratory” in New York. Working alongside jazz ensembles, classical pianists and singers, she explored ways in which sound might be given form through paint and oil stick. The work, she admits, was difficult. “I realized there that to enter into an encounter with others we must leave oneself behind,” Verdier says from her house in Le Vexin, to the north of Paris. “But where danger lies, there too grows the chance for salvation,” she continues, quoting Hölderlin.

headline: Trump Says Transition’s Going ‘Smoothly,’ Disputing Disarray Reports
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president-elect used Twitter to assure Americans that the handover of power was going well, despite accounts of infighting on his team.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that his transition was not in disarray, assailing news media reports about firings and infighting and insisting in an early-morning Twitter burst that everything was going “so smoothly.”

headline: A Car Accident Throws a Productive Life Into Turmoil
abstract: David Nublett prided himself on being self-sufficient. But after being hit by a car, he not only lost his ability to work, but also his independence and his savings.
lead_paragraph: Fresh from a promising meeting with a real estate agent, David Nublett was on his way to treat himself to a new pair of shoes when he started to walk across Westchester Avenue in the Bronx.

headline: How to Argue Fairly and Without Rancor (Hello, Thanksgiving!)
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Philosophy', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Social psychologists and philosophers have tips on avoiding the pitfalls of emotionally charged discussions, and how to make them constructive.
lead_paragraph: This story was published in November 2016 and updated in November 2017.

headline: Trump Defeated Clinton, Not Women
abstract: Admitting her flaws, and not just blaming sexism, should give women hope.
lead_paragraph: For a great many women around the world, Donald J. Trump’s defeat of Hillary Clinton feels like a painful setback not just for democracy, but for our gender.

headline: Tiny Salamanders Represent Three New Species
abstract: The specimens were collected deep in the Mexican forest and are of species that are nearly extinct.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered three new species of salamanders, and it’s no wonder no one ever noticed them before: The salamanders are about two inches long, live deep in the Mexican forest — and are nearly extinct.

headline: Dante Ferretti Goes From Cinecitta to Madison Avenue
abstract: Martin Scorsese’s favorite set designer lends his talents to a different kind of production: a Tod’s store window.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The last time the Oscar-winning production designer Dante Ferretti tackled New York City, he created the violent mean streets of a mid-19th-century Manhattan slum, a bleak, ramshackle neighborhood where blood and mud caked the ground, for Martin Scorsese’s 2002 opus, “Gangs of New York.”

headline: America’s Feast
abstract: We asked readers to tell us what dishes they put on the table each year. There was the traditional stuff, sure, but then things started to get interesting.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Subway Ride Could Cost $3 Under M.T.A. Plan for Fare and Toll Increases
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is considering two plans that would increase fares and tolls across the system by about 4 percent on average, part of a 2009 financial rescue deal.
lead_paragraph: The price of a MetroCard swipe could rise by a quarter to $3 in March, officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced on Wednesday.

headline: Mitski’s Emotional Undertow
abstract: There’s a certain gravity in Mitski’s indie-rock songs, whether stubbornly trudging ballads or distortion-laced punk.
lead_paragraph: There’s a certain gravity in Mitski’s indie-rock songs, whether they’re stubbornly trudging ballads or distortion-laced punk. Part of it is that Mitski Miyawaki is her band’s bass player and singer onstage (as well as its songwriter and multi-instrumentalist in the studio); her bass lines shadow her own voice from below, adding a constant undertow to her graceful, long-breathed melodies. And part of it is that in her songs, weighty emotional burdens are being exposed, confronted and borne, somberly and patiently. “One morning this sadness will fossilize,” she croons in a song on “Puberty 2,” her latest album, “And I will forget how to cry.” (Monday, Nov. 21, at Webster Hall in Manhattan; Tuesday at Market Hotel in Brooklyn.)

headline: In ‘Search Party,’ on TBS, the Real Quest Is for the Self
abstract: This new comedy was devised with millennials in mind. It stars Alia Shawkat.
lead_paragraph: With its Brooklyn vibe and whiff of self-absorption, “Search Party” was devised with millennials in mind, down to the way it’s meant to be binged: two episodes for five nights running, starting Monday, Nov. 21, at 11 p.m. on TBS.

headline: Juilliard’s ‘New Dances’ at the Guggenheim
abstract: Professional choreographers work with students, and both sides benefit.
lead_paragraph: When professional choreographers work with students, both sides benefit: Students are exposed to new ways of moving (and possible future employers), while artists can try out ideas on large, curious groups. The Juilliard Dance Division’s winter concert, “New Dances,” facilitates that kind of exchange, and the Guggenheim Museum presents a sneak peek of this year’s offerings — by John Heginbotham, Katarzyna Skarpetowska, Pam Tanowitz and Matthew Neenan, each working with a different class — on Sunday, Nov. 20, as part of its Works & Process series.

headline: Sweet Southern Hospitality in a New Charleston Hotel
abstract: The Dewberry is a midcentury masterpiece (and a great place to enjoy a highball).
lead_paragraph: Workstead, a rising design firm, makes its South Carolina debut with the Dewberry, a 155-room hotel built in the shell of the 1964 L. Mendel Rivers Federal Building overlooking Charleston’s Marion Square. “We wanted to explore the idea of Southern Modernism,” says co-founder Robert Highsmith. Taking cues from Milan’s Villa Necchi Campiglio, Havana’s Hotel Nacional, and Slim Aarons, they mixed midcentury Danish antiques with nods to the Lowcountry, such as oak salvaged from a tobacco barn in Georgia.

headline: A Feast of One Composer’s Dreamy Reticence and Rhythmic Irascibility
abstract: The new-music ensemble Counter)Induction devotes an evening to the work of one guy named Moe: Eric Moe.
lead_paragraph: Dramatic instinct and poetic sensibility are the hallmarks of Eric Moe’s music; his compositional voice is always distinct, whether in works of dreamy reticence or rhythmic irascibility. On Sunday, Nov. 20, the trailblazing new-music ensemble Counter)Induction dedicates an evening to Mr. Moe that is also an advertisement for the kind of composer-performer symbiosis that has proved so fertile across the New York scene. Half of the program, presented at National Sawdust, is given over to works by Mr. Moe, including a conversation for acoustic viola and electronics, “What Instruments We Have Agree,” an elegy on the death of the composer Lee Hyla, and the New York premiere of “Welcome to Phase Space,” enigmatically described as representing an eight-dimensional universe.

headline: White Hair, Don’t Care
abstract: Fashion’s fixation with frosty manes has made white locks desirable — even for those old enough to own them.
lead_paragraph: Fashion’s fixation with frosty manes has made white locks desirable — even for those old enough to own them.

headline: Nicky Silver’s ‘This Day Forward’ Kicks Off Vineyard’s Season
abstract: Mr. Silver’s latest comedy is directed by Mark Brokaw.
lead_paragraph: Nicky Silver has had a fruitful relationship with the Vineyard Theater since 1993, when his absurdist comedy “Pterodactyls” had its Off Broadway premiere there. More of his quirky works followed, including, in 2011, “The Lyons,” which starred Linda Lavin and moved to Broadway the following year. (The show marked Mr. Silver’s Broadway debut, an experience he wrote about after it closed.)

headline: Officer Who Shot Philando Castile Is Charged With Manslaughter
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Officer Jeronimo Yanez shot Mr. Castile after pulling him over in Falcon Heights, Minn. The aftermath was streamed on Facebook Live by Mr. Castile’s girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — The suburban police officer who fatally shot Philando Castile, the black driver whose last moments this summer were streamed live on Facebook, was charged on Wednesday with second-degree manslaughter and accused of escalating a mundane roadside exchange into a needlessly violent episode.

headline: Real, and Unreal: Photography by Josef Albers at MoMA
abstract: An exhibition of his collages, works discovered after his death, is opening at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: The name of the minimalist painter and theorist Josef Albers has never been on the list of form-minded photographers of the 20th century — a list that would include greats like Edward Weston, Paul Strand, Imogen Cunningham and Laszlo Moholy-Nagy. But the exclusion of Albers, who died in 1976, was a matter of his own choice. His extensive work with a camera, which began in the late 1920s during his days at the Bauhaus and continued throughout his career, was discovered only after his death.

headline: Isabelle Huppert, in All Her Glory, at the Metrograph
abstract: She stars with Kool Shen in “Abuse of Weakness,” showing as part of a short retrospective of her films.
lead_paragraph: No international star has challenged the traditional rules of female decorum more fiercely than Isabelle Huppert. A high point of the short retrospective of her films at the Metrograph is “Abuse of Weakness,” a collaboration with another French renegade, the director Catherine Breillat, to be shown on Sunday, Nov. 20.

headline: How Not to Overpay on Black Friday? Let the Web Be Your Guide
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: Despite what the ads say, the overwhelming majority of deals on the day after Thanksgiving are duds.
lead_paragraph: ATTENTION holiday shoppers, here is your annual public service announcement: The overwhelming majority of Black Friday deals are duds.

headline: Bob Dylan Will Not Attend Nobel Ceremony
abstract: The Swedish Academy announced Wednesday that Mr. Dylan, winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, would not attend the ceremony on Dec. 10.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan will not attend the Nobel ceremony in Stockholm next month to accept the Nobel Prize in Literature, the Swedish Academy, which bestows the award, announced Wednesday.

headline: Robert Longo, Refashioned
abstract: The artist discusses his new show and reflects on his filmmaking career.
lead_paragraph: The artist discusses his new show and reflects on his filmmaking career.

headline: Bringing Together Eisenstein and Black Lives Matter, in Art
abstract: A new show of work by Robert Longo pairs his recent, politically inspired drawings with slow-motion versions of the Russian master’s films.
lead_paragraph: At 63, Robert Longo has become an increasingly topical artist. Often lumped in with the three other male commercial behemoths of his generation — Eric Fischl, David Salle and Julian Schnabel, or “The Four Brushmen of the Apocalypse,” as Lynn Hirschberg called them in a cheeky 1987 Esquire story — Longo has, in the last two years, refashioned his art in a more blatantly political image. He created a modern classic with his diptych, “Untitled (Ferguson Police, August 13, 2014),” a photorealist depiction of Ferguson, Mo. police officers in riot gear, partly shrouded in a cloud of tear gas, the golden arches of a McDonald’s restaurant visible in the background. (He’d follow this thread further in 2016 with a drawing of the Baltimore police during the riots over the death of Freddie Gray.) His “Untitled (Football Players, Rams, Hands Up),” 2016, featured the St. Louis football team’s receivers entering the stadium for a game and making the “hands up, don’t shoot” gesture that has become a familiar symbol in Black Lives Matter protests. Another charcoal drawing focuses on a close-up of a bullet hole in the window of the Charlie Hebdo offices in Paris.

headline: An Italian Bar Fit for Romance in Greenwich Village
abstract: Bar Fortuna is on second floor of Casa Apicii, a quieter Italian restaurant that replaced the Lion.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this decade, there were few downtown restaurants hotter than the Lion, a celebrity-packed canteen run by John DeLucie in a Greenwich Village townhouse. But the restaurant got sold and the crowd moved on. In July, a quieter restaurant, Casa Apicii, took over in the space, and a second-floor chamber was turned into an intimate cocktail annex called Bar Fortuna with just 20 seats.

headline: Across China, Walmart Faces Labor Unrest as Authorities Stand Aside
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Workers are bypassing Communist Party unions and are appealing to nationalist ideals, though the government has long discouraged labor activism.
lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — In a one-man war room in his apartment, a laid-off Walmart employee named Wang Shishu was tapping out a message on his phone to a group of workers and plotting his next move.

headline: Rethinking Globalization | Investigating the Benefits and Drawbacks of Global Trade
abstract: Students consider: Who are the winners and losers in this story of economic change? What policy proposals would best support workers hurt by globalization?
lead_paragraph: What are the economic benefits and drawbacks of global trade?

headline: A ‘Mansplaining’ Hotline? Yes, Actually, Sweden Has One
abstract: The temporary hotline is meant to draw attention to gender discrimination in the workplace and will be staffed by gender experts.
lead_paragraph: A Swedish union has set up a hotline for workers to report instances of “mansplaining” as part of a weeklong effort to raise awareness of a certain kind of condescending elocution that men use to explain to women things they already understand.

headline: Trump’s Transition in a ‘Long History’ of Rocky Presidential Handovers
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Even under typical circumstances, the changeover from one administration to another has been compared to a giant corporate merger involving a $4 trillion budget.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The briefing materials are ready, loaded into tablet computers, secure internet sites or cloud computing applications. Officials from the White House and 100 federal agencies are on standby, waiting to meet “landing teams” from the president-elect’s staff and brief them on how things really work in government. The organizational charts have been meticulously mapped.

headline: After a Bitter Election Season, Apps to Spread Good Cheer
abstract: Motivational apps encourage you to reach a goal or “pay it forward” with good deeds, while a private messaging app can bring you closer to loved ones.
lead_paragraph: THERE are times when the world seems a cold and unfriendly place. For some people, now is one of those moments. But there are many apps out there to help improve your mood or spread some joy around.

headline: Keep Your Email Online or Off
abstract: Most web-based email services allow you to download copies of your messages to the computer with a stand-alone mail program.
lead_paragraph: Q. I thought Yahoo and Gmail messages were stored on those companies’ servers rather than on my computer. How and why do email messages get stored on the computer?

headline: Assad’s First Words on Trump Since Vote
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria called President-elect Donald J. Trump “a natural ally” in the struggle against terrorism, but said he was still dubious that Mr. Trump can live up to his promises.
lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria called President-elect Donald J. Trump “a natural ally” in the struggle against terrorism, but said he was still dubious that Mr. Trump can live up to his promises.

headline: Professor Pratfall: He Trains Actors in the Art of Silliness
abstract: Christopher Bayes, who teaches physical acting at Yale, has trained a generation of comic performers, including many in “The Servant of Two Masters.”
lead_paragraph: Christopher Bayes is not your average Ivy League professor. Likewise, the casts he assembles when he directs aren’t the typical bunch of strangers plucked from auditions and thrown together in a rehearsal room.

headline: Daily Report: The Increasingly Tectonic Force of Social Media
abstract: The election of Donald J. Trump, the rise of Bernie Sanders, and the momentum behind Brexit and ISIS all show the newly global gravity of social media.
lead_paragraph: Social media has been in the glare since the election for its perceived harmful qualities, such as the spreading of hate speech and the  false information.

headline: A Heavy Heart May Have Rolled Pluto Over
abstract: A bright, heart-shape feature on Pluto is near its equator, on the side facing away from Pluto’s largest moon. That is probably not coincidence.
lead_paragraph: The heart of Pluto is forever facing away from its largest moon, Charon.

headline: Afghan Bodyguards Targeted in Bombing Claimed by ISIS Affiliates
abstract: The attack in Kabul, which left at least six people dead and a dozen wounded, was the latest example of the Islamic State ranging beyond its base in eastern Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bombing claimed by Islamic State affiliates in Afghanistan targeted the vehicle of an elite Afghan bodyguard force in Kabul on Wednesday, leaving at least six people dead and a dozen wounded.

headline: Senate Democrats’ Surprising Strategy: Trying to Align With Trump

headline: Review: ‘Man in Snow,’ With a Lone Voice Hoping to Stay Connected
abstract: This show grew out of Israel Horovitz’s radio play of the same name, inspired by an Alaskan avalanche that buried a man in a cabin under 30 feet of snow.
lead_paragraph: From a cabin in Alaska where he’s gone to climb a mountain, a man named David calls his wife back at home in New York. Their cellphone connection is eerily clear — a fact he attributes to the northern lights, which are putting on a glorious show above him.

keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']

headline: Review: ‘The Illinois Parables’ Soothes and Inflames Feelings About America
abstract: This hourlong essay film by Deborah Stratman juxtaposes pastoral images with a chronicle of violence, dispossession and disaster.
lead_paragraph: “The Illinois Parables,” Deborah Stratman’s hourlong essay film, arrives at just the right moment. A meditation on history and landscape, it has the power both to soothe complicated feelings about America and to inflame them. Alongside pastoral images of natural beauty — Indian burial mounds; deciduous forests; fields of corn and soybeans seen from the air — is a chronicle of violence, dispossession and disaster, stretching from before the European settlement of the continent to the political turmoil of the 1960s.
