lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Russell Simmons was not happy with the wood furniture at Tantris, his soon-to-open yoga studio on Sunset Boulevard here.

headline: Aleksei Navalny, Vocal Putin Critic, Is Cleared to Run for Office
abstract: A criminal conviction of Mr. Navalny’s was overturned by Russia’s Supreme Court, formally opening the door for him to again run for office.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A criminal conviction of a key opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, was overturned on Wednesday by Russia’s Supreme Court, formally opening the door for him to run for office.

headline: Did Moderates Help Elect Trump?
abstract: A small group of relatively centrist voters who weren’t expected to vote may have put Donald J. Trump over the top.
lead_paragraph: How did Donald J. Trump win the presidency? Nearly every forecast model predicted that Hillary Clinton would be the next president of the United States. We were in disbelief — sort of.

headline: Evercore’s ‘Good’ Problem of Adding John Weinberg to the Board
abstract: The arrival of the former Goldman Sachs partner as executive chairman and C.E.O. means there will be three insiders on Evercore’s board.
lead_paragraph: Evercore’s two chairmen are an enviable problem. Wooing former Goldman Sachs partner John Weinberg is a coup for the $2.9 billion advisory firm. Making him executive chairman, though, muddies governance and creates top-heavy management.

headline: A Symphony With Powerful Champions, but Often Overlooked
abstract: The conductor Leon Botstein will lead a rare performance of Harold Shapero’s masterpiece with the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The American composer Harold Shapero’s Symphony for Classical Orchestra had languished in obscurity for some 30 years when André Previn conducted it with the Los Angeles Philharmonic in 1986. Audiences and local critics cheered. Alan Rich proclaimed the 45-minute piece “the greatest American symphony.” Martin Bernheimer, in The Los Angeles Times, wrote that Shapero revealed himself a “superb craftsman,” an “artist totally in control of the grandiose variables at hand.”

headline: U.S. Companies to Trump: Don’t Abandon Global Climate Deal
keywords: ['United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'United States Economy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Corporations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Global Warming']
abstract: “Failure to build a low-carbon economy puts American prosperity at risk,” the companies, which include Mars, Nike and Starbucks, said in a joint letter.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of American companies, including Mars, Nike, Levi Strauss and Starbucks, have urged President-elect Donald J. Trump not to abandon the Paris climate deal, saying a failure by the United States to build a clean economy endangers American prosperity.

headline: Donald Trump, Syria, International Criminal Court: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: ‘Is It Safe?’ Foreign Students Consider College in Donald Trump’s U.S.
abstract: American colleges are worried that the election result could portend a decline in international candidates, and Canadian universities have seen a surge in interest.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At a college fair on Wednesday at the Le Méridien hotel here, 20 American universities made their pitches to aspiring students, many of whom had long hoped to study in the United States. But as the students checked out presentations from colleges ranging from the State University of New York at Binghamton to Abilene Christian University in Texas, several expressed concerns about going to America under a Donald J. Trump administration.

headline: Inside College Basketball’s Most Political Locker Room
abstract: Three University of Wisconsin basketball players discuss the challenges and opportunities of being athletes agitating for change.
lead_paragraph: The Wisconsin basketball players Nigel Hayes and Jordan Hill took a step behind their teammates during the national anthem before the ninth-ranked Badgers’ season opener on Friday. It was another in a long series of visible protests from one of college basketball’s most socially aware locker rooms.

headline: 6 Family Shows to See if You’re in New York for Thanksgiving
abstract: The Rockettes are great, but there are plenty of other shows to keep the entire family entertained all weekend.
lead_paragraph: Yes, the Rockettes are a hoot. But if you’re visiting New York City over the Thanksgiving holiday, those candy-colored high kickers aren’t the only ones who can keep the whole family entertained. Here are six shows, from a neo-circus extravaganza to a fanciful play for the littlest ones in your family, that will keep young eyes wide. (Be sure to check the theaters’ websites for updated holiday schedules and ticket discounts.)

headline: Watch the Spooky SyFy Show ‘Channel Zero’
abstract: This anthology series is atmospheric, melancholy and creepy.
lead_paragraph: I’m someone who loves horror and weird stuff. But about two months ago, I looked at a poster for the SyFy series “Channel Zero,” which featured a humanoid creature made entirely of teeth, and thought, “Nah.”

headline: For David Oyelowo, the Time Has Come to Play Othello
abstract: He will play the title role in a modern-dress production of “Othello,” featuring the action star Daniel Craig.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, the British-Nigerian actor David Oyelowo didn’t want to play Othello. Years ago, before his move from London to Los Angeles, a few producers approached him. He turned them down. He loved Shakespeare, of course, but the roles that excited him were Coriolanus, Macbeth, Henry V. Not the Moor. “I don’t want to do anything that feels pedestrian or obvious,” he said.

headline: Who’s the Designer? You (Sort of)
abstract: Just about anything and everything you could want can now be customized — and in time for holiday shopping.
lead_paragraph: Just about anything and everything you could want can now be customized — and in time for holiday shopping.

headline: Herb Brooks’s Miracle in Minnesota: Spreading Division I Hockey
abstract: The coach known for the Miracle on Ice at the 1980 Olympics has a legacy that touches all five universities playing Division I hockey in the state.
lead_paragraph: ST. CLOUD, Minn. — In nearly every hockey-playing state, the name Herb Brooks elicits one memory: the Miracle on Ice, in which Brooks coached the United States to a victory over the powerful Soviet Union team at the Lake Placid Olympics in 1980.

headline: Young, Confident and Protesting Trump
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Discrimination', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Since Donald Trump’s victory, many fear his America doesn’t include them. But protesters are determined to speak up.
lead_paragraph: “My grandparents marched in the Civil Rights Movement so that hopefully their grandkids wouldn’t have to march,” said Matteo Bertoni, 16. He was walking down 5th Ave. in the rain on Tuesday afternoon with hundreds of other high school students who had left their classes to send a message to President-Elect Donald Trump.

headline: Review: ‘Bellevue’ Celebrates a Hospital Not Crazy, but Compassionate
abstract: This book by David Oshinsky, subtitled “Three Centuries of Medicine and Mayhem at America’s Most Storied Hospital,” traces a New York institution’s resilience.
lead_paragraph: Fairly or not, Bellevue is a gothic symbol of darkness and defeat: the destination for those who’ve been crushed and ground to a paste by New York City, or at least seem to have internalized its ghost population of demons and dybbuks. Bellevue is where Mark David Chapman was taken after shooting John Lennon. It is where William Burroughs was taken after deliberately snipping off part of  his left pinkie with poultry shears. It is where Norman Mailer was taken after stabbing his second wife, supposedly because she’d told him he’d never be as good as Dostoyevsky.

headline: Metallica, Still Thrashing but Comfortably Adult
abstract: With its first studio album in eight years, Metallica is reclaiming the attack of its music while jettisoning the image of a band as young, fast and out of control.
lead_paragraph: A packed, sweaty, ready-to-mosh crowd greeted Metallica in September at Webster Hall in Manhattan — a rare chance to see the band in a club rather than an arena — for a set including two songs from “Hardwired … to Self-Destruct,” the band’s first studio album in eight years.

headline: Can Yoga Help Chase the Postelection Blues?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Yoga', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: What some people did this past week, from interfaith vigils to “weaving therapy” to group meditation sessions, once the votes were counted.
lead_paragraph: They were a cheerful, if slightly dazed, group last Thursday evening at Voz, a store on Elizabeth Street that sells ethical fashion made by indigenous people — one man and seven women gathered around a garment rack and cinched to its uprights with lengths of wool. They wore back strap looms, which look sort of like belts, and they were being led in a postelection “weaving therapy” workshop by Cynthia Alberto, a master weaver and textile designer. Weaving, she explained, has long been used as occupational therapy. Its rhythms are meditative and soothing, and the tradition of a weaving circle foments community and creativity.

headline: Review: Miranda Lambert Sings of What Comes After the Heartbreak
abstract: “The Weight of These Wings” is a double album by this country star, her first record since her divorce from Blake Shelton.
lead_paragraph: Yes, “The Weight of These Wings” is Miranda Lambert’s first album since divorcing her fellow country star Blake Shelton last year. And yes, it is filled with songs about romantic skepticism and ones about how the first steps you take after an old love breaks are tentative and fragile. And yes, it is a double album, the sort of gesture intended to connote seriousness of artistic and spiritual purpose, as well as suggesting that the font of feelings serving as inspiration is a roaring waterfall that cannot easily be contained.

headline: Review: A Perfectly Acceptable Slice of Bach
abstract: Accompanying Accademia Bizantina on an all-Bach program at Zankel Hall, the violinist Viktoria Mullova was detached. But that didn’t make for a bad concert.
lead_paragraph: “Pizza is like sex,” Woody Allen may actually have said once. “When it’s bad it’s still pretty good.”

headline: House Foe of Dodd-Frank Says Overhaul Will Face Test in Senate

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A prominent Republican lawmaker on Wednesday laid out his agenda for restructuring the financial system in the next Congress, including his plan to roll back major portions of the Dodd-Frank Act.

headline: For the Mid-Manhattan Library, a Redesign for the Future
abstract: The New York Public Library’s renovation plan once called for a $1 billion overhaul, but a $200 million redesign of Mid-Manhattan was approved instead.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, the New York Public Library’s renovation plan has been a step-by-step retreat from the ambitious and controversial $1 billion overhaul — with a design by the starchitect Norman Foster — that once called for moving the circulating library at the Mid-Manhattan branch into the main Fifth Avenue flagship.

headline: Just 26, and Playing the Big House (Carnegie Hall)
abstract: It’s rare for a young artist to play Stern Auditorium solo, but Carnegie is giving the pianist Behzod Abduraimov the nod.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall’s main stage, Stern Auditorium, is generally not a place where young artists get their solo-recital sea legs. With its cream-colored walls accented with gilt, its 2,800 seats upholstered in red velvet, it is perhaps the most prestigious performance space in the world, the province of established stars like Lang Lang, Evgeny Kissin and Mitsuko Uchida.

headline: For Leonard Cohen, the End Came With a Fall in the Night
abstract: Mr. Cohen, who was known for working slowly, had picked up the pace considerably in recent years. His manager said he died in his sleep after a fall.
lead_paragraph: When Leonard Cohen’s family announced last week that he had died at  82, it gave no cause. Although the poet and songwriter had been open about his failing health in recent months, fans knew little other than what The New Yorker reported in its weekly radio show, that Mr. Cohen had been battling cancer.

headline: Trump, Syria, Schumer: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing

lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump emerged from the haze of his surprise victory in the presidential election, one of his first calls was apparently to an early supporter, a controversial radio host and conspiracy theorist with a large following.

headline: Openings All Over Town: Coach, Moncler, Canada Goose and More
abstract: Holiday pop-ups galore and sample sales at Rick Owens and Charlotte Olympia.
lead_paragraph: Baby, it’s getting cold outside! On Thursday, Moncler and Canada Goose will open United States flagships where you’ll find the Moncler Gamme Bleu designer Thom Browne’s unisex capsule of puffer jackets (starting at $2,500) and knits (starting at $400) with a stars-and-stripes motif and a Canada Goose x Opening Ceremony silk parka ($1,795). Moncler is at 650 Madison Avenue; Canada Goose is at 101 Wooster Street.

headline: U.S. Investigates Deaths of 3 Soldiers in Jordan as Possible Terrorism
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: American authorities said they have not ruled out terrorism as a motive for the killing of three American soldiers at an air base in Jordan this month.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — American officials said Wednesday that they were investigating the killing of three United States soldiers at a Jordanian air base this month as a possible terrorist attack and dismissed suggestions that the three had done anything to provoke the shooting.

headline: Surprise! Insurance Paid the E.R. but Not the Doctor
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors']
abstract: Patients who go to hospitals covered by their medical plans often receive a bill from a doctor who was not in the insurer’s network, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: Doug Moore was out of town at a Florida conference on information technology in October 2015 when he was struck with terrible abdominal pain. He tried to go to an urgent care center and called several local doctors. No one could see him. So he headed to the nearest emergency room. On the way, he called his insurance company to make sure the visit would be covered.

headline: Donald Trump’s Tangled Web
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Unless Mr. Trump divests his businesses, there will be no way to know if his actions in office are for the public good or for his own financial gain.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump refused to release his income tax returns during the campaign and now seems determined to lug every piece of financial baggage connected to his hotels, golf courses and other businesses into the White House. Unless he takes the sorts of common-sense steps past presidents have relied on to preserve the public trust, Americans will never know for certain if his actions in office are for the public good or his family’s private gain.

headline: Former Lending Club Chief Is Creating a New Lending Site
abstract: Renaud Laplanche has filed papers in several states to create Credify, a lending marketplace.
lead_paragraph: Just months after being forced out as the chief executive of the Lending Club, Renaud Laplanche is starting a new venture to lend money online.

headline: Facebook Acts to Restore Trust After Overstating Video Views
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media']

lead_paragraph: Facebook is moving to restore confidence among advertisers and publishers that it is accurately measuring how often and how long users see videos, news articles, ads and corporate messages on its social network.

headline: For a Sprained Ankle, Physical Therapy No Better Than Self Care
keywords: ['Sprains and Strains', 'ANKLES (BODY PART)', 'Physical Therapy', 'Sports Injuries', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: There were no significant differences between the physical therapy and the self-treatment groups at one, three or six months after an ankle injury.
lead_paragraph: Physical therapy for a sprained ankle may be no more effective than self-treatment at home, a randomized trial reports.

headline: Ellen DeGeneres and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar Among 2016 Presidential Medal of Freedom Recipients
abstract: The 21 recipients of the award, the nation’s highest civilian honor, also include Frank Gehry, Vin Scully, Tom Hanks and Bill and Melinda Gates.
lead_paragraph: President Obama named the recipients of the 2016 Presidential Medal of Freedom on Wednesday, a list that includes cultural, athletic and philanthropic luminaries like Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Ellen DeGeneres, Tom Hanks and Bill and Melinda Gates. It is the last time Mr. Obama will award the nation’s highest civilian honor.

headline: Cy Young Awards: Max Scherzer in N.L. and Rick Porcello in a Twist
abstract: National League voters overwhelmingly chose Scherzer. Porcello won the American League award despite receiving fewer first-place votes than Justin Verlander.
lead_paragraph: If you thought the Electoral College was confusing, consider the 2016 American League Cy Young Award vote. After five routine elections, for the rookies of the year, the managers of the year and the National League Cy Young Award, things got really, really weird Wednesday night.

headline: Rights Groups Assail Iran Over Videos of Condemned Prisoners
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Propaganda']
abstract: The slickly-produced videos, broadcast on Iranian state television, include suspects confessing to crimes that happened after they had been incarcerated.
lead_paragraph: When Iran conducted a mass hanging in August of Sunni prisoners accused of attacks in its restive western Kurdish region, the executions were widely criticized as an egregious human rights violation. But death-penalty opponents also were appalled at what came next.

headline: Dwayne O. Andreas, Who Turned Archer Daniels Midland Into Food Giant, Dies at 98
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Grain', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: With business acumen and political ties, he pushed the food products company to the front of American industry.
lead_paragraph: Dwayne O. Andreas, an executive whose mastery of the global grain trade and the levers of political power turned the Archer Daniels Midland Company into a farm products giant and pushed it to the front ranks of American industry, died on Wednesday in Decatur, Ill. He was 98.

headline: Holly Dunn, 59, Country Singer-Songwriter, Dies; ‘Daddy’s Hands’ Was a Hit
abstract: The wistful “Daddy’s Hands” won two Grammy nominations, and Ms. Dunn’s song “Maybe I Mean Yes” provoked a national conversation about date rape.
lead_paragraph: Holly Dunn, a country singer who wrote the hit “Daddy’s Hands” as a Father’s Day gift for her preacher father and whose song “Maybe I Mean Yes” provoked a national conversation about date rape, died on Monday in Albuquerque. She was 59.

headline: Stoic in Court, Patz Suspect Is Heard in Harrowing Confession
abstract: Clips of Pedro Hernandez’s interviews with the authorities in 2012 have been played in his retrial in the 6-year-old’s 1979 disappearance in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Hours after he was taken to a small interview room, surrounded by detectives, Pedro Hernandez started to sob. The investigators had sought him out for a decades-old case, the disappearance of Etan Patz, a 6-year-old who vanished as he walked to his school bus stop in Manhattan.

headline: How Students Are Responding to the Changes in Federal Financial Aid
abstract: This year, for the first time, the Fafsa was made available on Oct. 1 — three months earlier than usual — for the next academic year.
lead_paragraph: High school students appear to be responding well to recent changes in the federal student financial aid application process, an early analysis shows.

headline: Ruth Baron Ziff Dies at 92; Added Sociological Insight to Ads
abstract: A sociologist with a knack for market research, she contributed to the “Please don’t squeeze the Charmin” toilet paper ad.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, women in the advertising industry often struggled to advance, much less get their work noticed.

headline: Howard Ruff, Quirky Conservative Economist and Author, Dies at 85
abstract: An idiosyncratic figure whose roller-coaster career included stockbroker, singer, investment adviser, publisher and television host.
lead_paragraph: Howard Ruff, an idiosyncratic economist, best-selling author and political conservative best known for being bullish on gold and silver and gloomy about the economy, died on Nov. 12 in Lehi, Utah. He was 85.

headline: Jules Eskin, Cellist With Boston Symphony Orchestra, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Eskin performed with the ensemble for more than half a century.
lead_paragraph: Jules Eskin, the principal cellist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra for more than half a century and among the longest-serving orchestral musicians in the United States, died on Tuesday at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 85.

headline: Theodore F. Twardzik, Founder of Mrs. T’s Pierogies, Dies at 89
abstract: He left a job as an accountant when he saw a future in creating a frozen food company that was named for his mother and used her recipe.
lead_paragraph: Theodore F. Twardzik, who used his mother’s pierogi recipe as the foundation of a successful frozen food business, died on Nov. 10 in Pottsville, Pa. He was 89.

headline: Pessimism May Be Bad for Your Heart
keywords: ['Heart', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Pessimism', 'Optimism', 'Medicine and Health', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: But optimism had no effect on death rates one way or the other, Finnish researchers found.
lead_paragraph: A pessimistic attitude increases the risk for death from heart disease, a new study reports, while an optimistic outlook may have no effect at all.

headline: ‘Stay Calm,’ Mexican Officials Tell Fearful Immigrants in U.S.

Trump to step up deportations, announced a plan on Wednesday to provide more protection and support for Mexican immigrants in the United States and urged the Mexican population to “stay calm.”

headline: Life Is Turned ‘Upside Down’ as Jets Pound Rebel-Held Syrian Cities
abstract: Humanitarian agencies warned of growing violations of international law — particularly what they called a pattern of deliberate attacks on hospitals.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Eight hospitals bombed in the past week, five of them within the last 48 hours. Food stores running out of supplies. Scores of people killed in a single day.

headline: White House Confirms Pre-Election Warning to Russia Over Hacking
abstract: Though there is no evidence that voting was disrupted, cybersecurity experts debated whether the warning was a success, and whether Russia had paid enough of a price.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the past month, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has received two starkly different messages about hacking into American computer networks from the current and future presidents of the United States: Don’t you dare, and don’t worry, we’re not even sure it was you.

headline: Bob Dylan Says He’ll Skip Nobel Ceremony (He’s Busy)
abstract: The songwriter, who hesitated before even acknowledging his prize, said that “pre-existing commitments” would prevent him from picking up his award for literature.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Prize in Literature may be the world’s most important literary award, but not everyone who wins can make it to the ceremony.

headline: Minneapolis Fed Chief Proposes Eliminating ‘Too Big to Fail’ Banks
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: On the surface, Mr. Kashkari’s plan would seem to be a tough sell in the new Trump administration, requiring banks to boost their capital by carrying steep costs.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street banks are still too big to fail, and the hundreds of thousands of pages of regulations created in the eight years since the crisis are not adequate protection against another financial shock, says Neel Kashkari of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis.

headline: U.C.L.A. Women’s Coach Cori Close Follows John Wooden’s Example
abstract: Close, whose Bruins were the preseason favorite to take the Pacific-12 title, knew Wooden, a legendary men’s coach, for 15 years and has taken ideas like his Pyramid of Success to heart.
lead_paragraph: Every day on her way to the practice floor at Pauley Pavilion, U.C.L.A.’s women’s basketball coach, Cori Close, makes a point of walking past the 10 banners for the national championships the Bruins’ men’s team won under John Wooden.

headline: Ritual of Ever-Present Coverage May Not Pass Muster With Trump
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Reporters who thought the Obama administration was closed may be up against something much more opaque.
lead_paragraph: To understand how President-elect Donald J. Trump’s spontaneous meal this week at the “21” Club, the Manhattan nightspot, could turn into a flash point on the future of American journalism, it’s best to start with what the news media already knows about its future charge.

headline: Engineer in Hoboken Train Crash Had Undiagnosed Sleep Disorder, Lawyer Says
abstract: Thomas Gallagher, the engineer of the New Jersey Transit train that slammed into the station, killing one and injuring more than 100, believed the diagnosis might explain what happened.
lead_paragraph: The engineer of a New Jersey Transit train that crashed into Hoboken Terminal in September had an undiagnosed sleep disorder, his lawyer said on Wednesday.

headline: Melvin Laird, Defense Secretary Who Challenged Vietnam Policy, Dies at 94
abstract: By late 1968, Mr. Laird believed that diplomacy was the only way to end the war, and later pressed the Nixon White House to wind down troop involvement.
lead_paragraph: Melvin R. Laird, who as President Richard M. Nixon’s first secretary of defense quietly challenged the administration’s hawkish military policies during the war in Vietnam, prompting deep suspicion — and even spying — between the White House and the Pentagon, died on Wednesday in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 94.

headline: JPMorgan Is Said to Settle Bribery Case Over Hiring in China
keywords: ['Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Federal authorities are expected to announce a roughly $264 million settlement with the bank over charges that it hired children of Chinese leaders in exchange for deals.
lead_paragraph: After more than three years of digging into JPMorgan Chase’s hiring practices in China, federal authorities have determined that the bank hired the children of Chinese leaders as part of a quid pro quo to win business in the booming nation, clearing the way for a costly punishment.

headline: Review: ‘Othello’ Goes Hip-Hop. There’s Humor, Too.
abstract: The Q Brothers have concocted another mash-up of rap and Shakespeare. And the laughter grows, right along with the stack of corpses.
lead_paragraph: Last time I checked, there were not a lot of laughs in Shakespeare’s tragedy about a Moorish general beset by the green-eyed monster. Yet giggles abound in “Othello: The Remix,” a clever and exuberantly performed hip-hop version of the play that opened on Wednesday at the Westside Theater.

headline: The Ball Is Moving, and the Lakers Are Rolling
abstract: With its new coach, Luke Walton, emphasizing teamwork and passing, the team is off to a 7-5 start in its first season without the retired Kobe Bryant.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jordan Clarkson, a third-year guard with the Los Angeles Lakers, was explaining the virtues of good ball movement this week when he was asked about last season, when the Lakers were not known for their good ball movement. The Lakers were known for many things, like their horrible record, but ball movement was not one of them.

headline: Specter of Race Shadows Jeff Sessions, Potential Trump Nominee for Cabinet
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Accusations of racial comments doomed the 1986 court nomination of Mr. Sessions, an Alabama senator under consideration for attorney general or defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 1981, a Justice Department prosecutor from Washington stopped by to see Jeff Sessions, the United States attorney in Mobile, Ala., at the time. The prosecutor, J. Gerald Hebert, said he had heard a shocking story: A federal judge had called a prominent white lawyer “a disgrace to his race” for representing black clients.

headline: Monet’s ‘Grainstack’ Sets Record With $81.4 Million at Auction
abstract: The 1891 canvas sold at Christie’s on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: After a 14-minute battle involving five bidders — four on the phone and one in the room — a new auction high was set for the French Impressionist Claude Monet on Wednesday evening when the artist’s radiant 1891 canvas “Meule,” or “Grainstack,” fetched $81.4 million with fees at Christie’s in Manhattan.

headline: Trump Will Have Wide Latitude to Let Family Into Government’s Secret Circles
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: After days of reports that Donald J. Trump had requested a top-secret security clearance for his son-in-law, people close to him said that was not the case, but the law would not stop him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After days of reports that President-elect Donald J. Trump had requested a top-secret security clearance for his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, people close to Mr. Kushner said that was not the case. No such request has been made, they said on Wednesday, and he will not sit in on the president’s highly classified daily intelligence briefing.

headline: Bernie Sanders Says Donald Trump Must Be Held Accountable
abstract: The Vermont senator says the president-elect must be held to promises he made to the middle class.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont vowed on Wednesday to hold Donald J. Trump accountable for the promises he made to the middle class while also insisting that the president-elect rescind his appointment of Stephen K. Bannon as his chief White House strategist.

headline: Egyptian Police Officer Gets Life Term for Killing in Dispute Over Tea
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The sentence, which is subject to appeal, was a rare punitive response to police violence in the country.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian criminal court sentenced a police officer to life in prison on Wednesday for fatally shooting a man who refused to give him a free cup of tea. It was an unusual move by a court in a country where the police are generally allowed to act with impunity, human rights activists said.

headline: Not of the Buffa Style

lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — There is a Notepad in some electronic versions of today’s puzzle by Timothy Polin and Joe Krozel, which says, “In the print version of this puzzle, the five squares in 50-Across each have a small number in them, as follows: 5 | 29 | 47 | 34 | 43.”

headline: Review: ‘The Servant of Two Masters,’ and His Misfortunes
abstract: This Theater for a New Audience production of Carlo Goldoni’s 18th-century farce struggles as it tries to employ contemporary humor.
lead_paragraph: “When is the play gonna be over?” wails a beleaguered character near the close of the first act of the Theater for a New Audience production of Carlo Goldoni’s 18th-century farce “The Servant of Two Masters,” which opened on Wednesday at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 3, Episode 6: Like Father, Like Son
abstract: After several halfhearted attempts, the series has finally given Lucious a formidable foe.
lead_paragraph: As its initial installments this season have made plain, Fox’s hit show “Empire” has been losing a two-front war. On a meta level, can a show that draws much of its heat from tapping the pop-cultural and political zeitgeist keep pace with the chaos of 2016? And in terms of plot, can it keep the soap suds bubbling by simply pitting the members of the Lyon family against each other — and against Lucious, in particular — again and again?

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than a million people have signed up for 2017 health insurance coverage on HealthCare.gov, and more than 300,000 of them selected plans in the three days after Donald J. Trump won the presidential election, the Obama administration said on Wednesday.

headline: Shopping at Gucci? Tiffany’s? You May Proceed to Trump Tower

If one of those is your answer when the police officer asks your destination, you are permitted to proceed down Fifth Avenue to Trump Tower, which has a Gucci store on the first floor, and a Tiffany & Company jewelry store next door, about 600 feet below where the president-elect, Donald J. Trump, lives in a penthouse suite. Otherwise, the officers posted at the corner of the block direct passers-by to the opposite side of the street.

lead_paragraph: “Lovesick,” the British comedy formerly known as “Scrotal Recall,” resumes its humorous journey of S.T.D. notification. And “Scissored Isle” follows Alan Partridge, Steve Coogan’s fictional TV presenter, across the British divide. And “Chelsea” serves a Thanksgiving feast.

headline: Notes on Blindness: Acoustic Space
abstract: After he went blind, John Hull used sound to rediscover a rich sensory universe.
lead_paragraph: “What is the world of sound?” So begins a diary entry from April 1984, recorded on audiocassette, about the nature of acoustic experience. The voice on the tape is that of the writer and theologian John Hull, who at the time of the recording had been totally blind for almost two years. After losing his sight in his mid-40s, Dr. Hull, a newlywed with a young family, had decided that blindness would destroy him if he didn’t learn to understand it. For three years he recorded his experiences of sight loss, documenting “a world beyond sight.”

headline: Feeling My Way Into Blindness
abstract: Losing my sight in my 80s has been like entering a new country.
lead_paragraph: Blindness is enveloping. It’s beyond belief to step outside and see so little, just a milky haze. Indoors, a smothering dark. It means that you can’t shed a mood of loneliness with a brisk walk down the street because you might trip, fall and break something. Nor will you see a passing friend, the sight of whom could be as cheery as an actual conversation. Sights, like sounds, randomly evoke a surge of memories ordinarily inaccessible that lighten and brighten the day. “Who are you?” I may already have asked 10 people who have spoken to me. Their body language as well as their smiles are lost to me. Human nature is striped with ambiguities, and you need to see them, but like a prisoner, I am hooded.

headline: What You Won’t See When Talking to a Call Center Worker

headline: Why the World Needs WikiLeaks
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News and News Media']
abstract: We keep the powerful accountable — and that will be even more important in the coming years.
lead_paragraph: Berlin — My organization, WikiLeaks, took a lot of heat during the run-up to the recent presidential election. We have been accused of abetting the candidacy of Donald J. Trump by publishing cryptographically authenticated information about Hillary Clinton’s campaign and its influence over the Democratic National Committee, the implication being that a news organization should have withheld accurate, newsworthy information from the public.

headline: Israel’s Alarming Settlement Bill
abstract: An effort to legalize settlements in the West Bank is an alarming ripple effect of a president-elect who is winging it every step of the way.
lead_paragraph: Right-wing Israeli politicians see Donald Trump’s election as helpful toward  their goal of burying the prospect of a Palestinian state. On Wednesday, Israeli lawmakers gave preliminary approval  to a bill that would retroactively legalize settlements built on private Palestinian land in the West Bank. The bill is intended to prevent the court-ordered demolition of an illegal outpost by Dec. 25.

headline: Racing Toward a Better Future
abstract: The Neediest Cases Fund helps a single mother with four young children furnish their new home.
lead_paragraph: Tatiana Ricardo is a single mother of four children, including two who have special needs. Her days mostly consist of cooking, cleaning, doing laundry and taking the children to and from school. But to Ms. Ricardo, “It’s all worth it. I’d do anything for them.” Someday, she says, she would like to open her own day care center.

headline: A Trumpian Silver Lining
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: There’s someone who feels worse than you do about what’s happening in Washington.
lead_paragraph: One of Donald Trump’s big advantages now is that he has so many awful associates. No matter what appointees he foists on us, there’s always another pal who’d have been worse. If he names some federal land-grabbing oilman as secretary of the interior, people are going to sigh with relief and say, “At least it isn’t Sarah Palin.”

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — At Veronica Lopez’s Sweet 16 party, children played among the headstones. Aunts, uncles and cousins sat on lawn chairs and striped blankets on the grass. headline: Gene Luen Yang Thinks Superheroes Are for Everyone
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Asian-Americans', 'Superman (Fictional Character)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The cartoonist and MacArthur fellow on DC vs. Marvel, feeling like an outsider and what he’s going to do with all that “genius” grant money.
lead_paragraph: What got you into collecting — and then creating — comics? The first comic book I ever read was DC Comics Presents No. 57, and it had Superman and the Atomic Knights in it. Pretty soon after, I started making my own comics. Nowadays any kid can make anything — movies or music, but back then, it seemed like there was such a low bar of entry into this way of telling stories.

headline: Cheesy Mashed Potatoes for the Soul
abstract: When times are tough, nerves can be soothed by aligot.
lead_paragraph: In times of great stress, or of flickering, low-level dread, I find that canceling all my plans and staying in to make mashed potatoes generally helps. This year, there were quite a few opportunities to do so. Election-related anxiety gnawed at me for months, lighting up old networks of pain in my shoulders and back. Mold bloomed around the mysterious wet patch that appeared in my bedroom ceiling. I started a thrilling, but terrifying, new job. And as the holidays neared, I worried about my grandmother, almost 80, living alone. Still, I let about half her calls go to voice mail each week, and hated myself for it.

headline: Divorce, India Style: It’s All Up to the Judge
abstract: How can a wife be cruel to her husband? It’s entirely up to a judge’s discretion to decide whether to support claims of cruelty and approve divorces.
lead_paragraph: India’s family law was written to discourage divorce, and in that sense it has succeeded brilliantly: The last census, in 2011, showed that the number of Indians who described themselves as separated was nearly three times the number who were divorced.

headline: Review: ‘Fantastic Beasts’ Unleashes J.K. Rowling’s Magic on Old New York
abstract: Eddie Redmayne stars as a visitor to the city with a very stuffed magic suitcase in “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them.”
lead_paragraph: “Is anyone safe?” That alarmed question nearly shrieks off a newspaper in “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them,” rattling the story almost before it’s begun. A big, splashy footnote to J. K. Rowling’s Harry Potter screen series, it opens a new subdivision in the wizardry world that she created, even as it turns back the clock. Unlike Harry’s reality, which unfolds in a present that looks like ours but with dragons, “Fantastic Beasts” takes place in a 1926 New York, where dark forces cut swaths of destruction alongside chugging Model T’s. Ms. Rowling is just getting revved up, but her time frame suggests her sights are on another world catastrophe.

abstract: Once again, the Miami area is reinventing itself, this time as a cultural and culinary hot spot.
lead_paragraph: Once again, the Miami area is reinventing itself, this time as a cultural and culinary hot spot.

headline: What Changed the Way This Patient Saw the World?
abstract: It started in an ordinary way, with a headache. But before he knew it, his perception was shifting.
lead_paragraph: It started in an ordinary way, with a headache. But before he knew it, his perception was shifting.

headline: A New Payroll System Misfires, and Canadians Ask: Where’s My Pay?
abstract: More than 80,000 public servants have had trouble getting paid because of a system’s flaws, and some managers have even had to lend money to subordinates.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The government of Canada has a credit rating of AAA and a budget of over $200 billion. You would think it could meet its payroll.

headline: ‘Gilmore Girls,’ and the Rapid-Fire Repartee, Is Returning
abstract: “Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life” is a new, four-part mini-series that Netflix will release on Nov. 25.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — The Warner Bros. back lot has lent its sets and streets to some of the most storied musicals in Hollywood history: “42nd Street,” “The Music Man,” “Bye Bye Birdie.”

headline: Jeff Sessions Appears Headed to a Trump Cabinet Position
abstract: The president-elect had high praise for the Alabama senator after meeting with him and others at Trump Tower, including Henry A. Kissinger.
lead_paragraph: The lobby of Trump Tower had a frenetic pace on Thursday as a parade of current and former officeholders and others came to meet with President-elect Donald J. Trump as he works to build his nascent administration.

headline: From Iran to Syria, Trump’s ‘America First’ Approach Faces Its First Tests
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Terrorism']
abstract: As he tries to build a national security team, the president-elect will confront a series of decisions sure to flesh out his approach to world crises.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lurking behind the turmoil and the jockeying for advantage in President-elect Donald J. Trump’s effort to assemble a national security team lies the more fundamental question of how he will address the immediate and complex challenges he inherits upon taking office.

headline: Protests at Elite University Show How Egyptian Cash Crisis Tests All
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Tuition', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Students at American University of Cairo are seeking a cap on tuition, reflecting concerns the middle and upper classes have about a flailing economy.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The student leader spoke in English to the chanting crowd at the elite American University of Cairo. The leader, Amr El-Alfy, 20, told his peers that he was frustrated over the university administration’s lack of clarity about whether tuition would rise as much as 40 percent in response to Egypt’s flailing economy and floating currency.

headline: The Alabama Crimson Tide of Mexico
abstract: The Rams of Tec de Monterrey are a college football power. Ask Cam Newton.
lead_paragraph: MONTERREY, Mexico — Like many football-crazed boys, Luis Carranza grew up with a poster of Emmitt Smith, his hero, on his bedroom wall and vowed to emulate him.

headline: Questions for: ‘Social Media’s Globe Shaking Power’
abstract: How are social networks helping to fundamentally rewire human society and even alter the course of global events?
lead_paragraph: Article: Social Media's Globe Shaking Power

headline: Should Emotional Support Animals Be Allowed on College Campuses?
abstract: Students say they feel less anxious and less stressed when they are allowed to have comfort animals on campus.
lead_paragraph: What if your new college roommate showed up with an “emotional comfort dog?”

headline: The Not-So-Silent White Majority
abstract: How is it possible that the supposedly fading constituency of white working class voters played such a decisive role in the 2016 election?
lead_paragraph: Between Richard Nixon’s election by the silent majority in 1968 and Donald Trump’s stunning victory in 2016, there have been six conservative waves that swept Republicans into office. Disaffected white voters without college degrees have been the driving force in all of them.

headline: Turkey’s Free Press Withers as Erdogan Jails 120 Journalists
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: The journalists have been jailed since a failed coup in July, and news outlets have been closed or taken over by supporters of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A prominent columnist wrote recently about how President Recep Tayyip Erdogan  of Turkey hates cigarettes so much that he confiscates packs from his followers, lecturing them on the evils of smoking.

headline: Nikki Haley, Hillary Clinton, Janet Yellen: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What to See in Hawaii? Ask Auli’i Cravalho of Disney’s ‘Moana’
abstract: The actress recommends Lanikai Beach, Iolani Palace and a Koko Head hike.
lead_paragraph: Auli’i Cravalho, a native Hawaiian, is the voice of the heroine in Walt Disney Animation Studios’ “Moana,” which opens Nov. 23. The comedy adventure, which also stars Dwayne Johnson, features a daring teenager on a seafaring mission to save her people. The story is inspired in part by the oral histories of Oceania. Ms. Cravalho, a high school sophomore who turns 16 on Nov. 22, grew up singing and dancing for family and friends. Born in Kohala on the island of Hawaii, she lives with her mother in Mililani, on the island of Oahu.

headline: On Thursday Nights, N.F.L.’s Mediocrity Rears Its Ugly Head, Over and Over
abstract: Any sense of anticipation for the league’s midweek game has been lost after a string of routine matchups, contributing to lower ratings for “Thursday Night Football.”
lead_paragraph: Thursday night’s N.F.L. game has some intriguing elements. The Carolina Panthers are desperately fighting to save a bad season after their Super Bowl run last year. The New Orleans Saints have the prolific passer Drew Brees and the game-breaking receiver Brandin Cooks.

headline: A New Reason to Party: Custom Suiting for the Suitor and His Pals
keywords: ['Suits (Apparel)', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Parties (Social)', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Brides aren’t the only ones having fitting parties for wedding wear.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Charles Granatell’s house in Wyckoff, N.J., was filled with testosterone-fueled camaraderie. His best friend from college, Mike Canfora, was getting married. Mr. Canfora flew in from Seattle, others drove in from Massachusetts and Manhattan, and some lived nearby. Eight of the 10 groomsmen were there. A big-screen TV loudly projected the Giants N.F.L. game. Paper plates containing sandwiches, pasta, salad and steak, food that had been catered, were strewn about. Wine and beer were consumed.

headline: Morning Agenda: JPMorgan Said to Settle Bribery Case, Ending ‘Too Big to Fail,’ Goldman’s Pitch to the Masses
abstract: The United States authorities are expected to announce a settlement with JPMorgan Chase in a bribery case involving the hiring of Chinese leaders’ children.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s long Chinese family drama is coming to a close.

headline: New York Today: Flexing Your Workout
abstract: Thursday: Alternative workout classes to keep the holiday pounds at bay, flawless weather and a $3 subway ride.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:08 a.m.

headline: How a Donkey Became My Running Partner
abstract: We’d agreed to take this donkey because we figured he’d be fun and trouble-free. I didn’t know he’d set my life on an entirely new course.
lead_paragraph: It was nearly dark when our neighbor pulled into our driveway with a brace-yourself look in his eye. “He’s in rough shape,” he warned, as he got out of his pickup and walked back to open the trailer. “Rougher than I thought.”

headline: Tips for Shoring Up a Fragile Thanksgiving
abstract: Sam Sifton tells us the rules for peace, harmony and potluck, and suggests that gravy can unite us this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible to break Thanksgiving? And if so, could last week’s chaotically divisive election have actually broken it? A story in The Times on Wednesday explores how the war between the presidential candidates might also lead to war at family dinner. Do you take the year off? Do you put a moratorium on politics at the table? You could. Or you could let Sam Sifton show you how to make a gravy so good it heals all divides.

headline: With Fertility Rate in China Low, Some Press to Legalize Births Outside Marriage
keywords: ['Population', 'Birth Rates', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Census', "Women's Rights", 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The average Chinese woman has just 1.05 children, according to recently released findings from a government census.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Singapore government has deployed financial incentives and even Mentos mints to increase births. In Russia, more money in mothers’ pension accounts and “Conception Day,” with time off from work, have helped. Be it Germany or Japan, state-paid bonuses aim to amplify the patter of little feet in homes amid sagging fertility rates.

headline: Is the Slide Into Tribal Politics Inevitable?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Whites', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Minorities']
abstract: White vs. nonwhite and college-educated vs. not: The group dynamics Donald Trump has unleashed could be difficult to stop once set in motion.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s victory could well push the American party system toward a clash between an overwhelmingly white ethnic party and a cosmopolitan coalition of minority groups and college-educated whites.

headline: Fraction of Americans With Drug Addiction Receive Treatment, Surgeon General Says
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Surgeon General (US)', 'Addiction (Psychology)']
abstract: The report, the first from a surgeon general to address substance use disorders, calls for a cultural change in understanding that addiction is a brain disease.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Millions of Americans suffer from alcoholism or addiction to legal and illegal drugs, but only a fraction are being treated, according to a report released on Thursday by the surgeon general.

headline: Yellen: Too Soon to Predict Economic Effects of Election
abstract: In her first public comments since the election, the central bank chief also signaled that the Fed remained likely to raise interest rates next month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said Thursday it was too soon to predict the economic impact of Donald J. Trump’s election as the next president of the United States.

headline: California Today: The Rise of a Design Capital
abstract: Thursday: California as a brand, the power of social media to rewire society, and recognizing Chicano Park.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Sérgio Cabral, Ex-Governor of Rio de Janeiro, Arrested on Corruption Charges
abstract: Mr. Cabral is the latest politician to be implicated in a major graft investigation that has shaken Brazil’s establishment.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The former governor of Rio de Janeiro, who helped bring the Summer Olympics to the city, was arrested on Thursday in a scheme that the authorities said siphoned tens of millions of dollars from huge public construction projects.

headline: Salvatore Ferragamo Puts 3 Designers Atop Its Creative Team
abstract: In a move that runs against an industry trend toward consolidation, the Italian design house parceled out its men’s, women’s and shoe collections.
lead_paragraph: The fashion upheavals continue. In a move that counters a major trend in the industry toward consolidation, Salvatore Ferragamo, the Italian brand, confirmed on Thursday that it was appointing three designers to the top of its creative team.

headline: Democrats, Let Your Leaders Emerge
abstract: There is no question that the Democrats now have a thin field of national leaders — but that thinness has an upside.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: Review: Salieri’s Anguish Continues in a New ‘Amadeus’ in London
abstract: Peter Shaffer’s play about the relationship between Mozart and his rival gains a few tweaks at the National Theater.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If you’re going to direct a play suffused with music, how appropriate to come up with a production that really sings. That is just one of the achievements of the new London production of “Amadeus,” which restores Peter Shaffer’s drama to the Olivier stage at the National Theater, where it was first seen in 1979.

headline: Review: An Anti-Nazi Protest in the Guise of Opera
abstract: “Simplicius Simplicissimus,” a little-known work by Karl Hartmann, has a belated British premiere.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Unless you happened to be Aryan and write music deemed to promote Nazi ideals, Germany in the 1930s was no place for composers. It certainly wasn’t for Karl Amadeus Hartmann, whose opera “Simplicius Simplicissimus” was begun just after Hitler came to power, had no chance of performance in the Third Reich and, despite occasional postwar productions, languished at the margins of the repertoire. Hence its very belated British premiere last week at Sadler’s Wells, in a staging by the young director Polly Graham, designed by Nate Gibson, and conducted by the new-music specialist Timothy Redmond.

headline: The Contradiction at the Heart of Donald Trump’s Economic Policy
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Taxation', 'International Trade and World Market', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Policies that increase the value of the dollar would make it harder for U.S. manufacturers to compete overseas, one of many trade-offs that a president faces.
lead_paragraph: Campaign promises are easy. Governing is hard.

headline: Intensified by Climate Change, ‘King Tides’ Change Ways of Life in Florida
abstract: King tides, which frequently flood South Florida even when the sun shines, are the most blatant example of the interplay between rising seas and the alignment of the moon, sun and Earth.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — In an enclave of a city known as the Venice of America, where dream-big houses look out over a maze of picturesque canals, the comparison to the Venice of Italy no longer seems so appealing.

headline: From Wallpaper to Printed Journals and Candles
abstract: A Parisian cool kid, Antoinette Poisson launches a series of new collaborations.
lead_paragraph: Antoinette Poisson, the Parisian purveyor of spectacular handmade wallpaper, got its start when conservationists Julie Stordiau, Vincent Farelly and Jean-Baptiste Martin were renovating an 18th-century house in Auvergne and stumbled upon domino papers, or poster-size swatches that can be pieced together on the wall. With the goal of bringing back this largely forgotten process, the three friends opened for business in 2012, in a bare-bones studio in Paris’s 11th Arrondissement.

headline: Oscar Wilde, a Refugee of His Time
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration Detention', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Britain pardons men it once imprisoned for gay acts — and highlights the injustice of its detention policy for migrants today.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just days after the British government announced posthumous pardons for men convicted of homosexual acts, I sat in the chapel of Reading Prison, where Oscar Wilde was incarcerated from 1895 to 1897. I was listening to the stage and screen actor Maxine Peake read from “De Profundis,” the 50,000-word letter Wilde wrote from his cell to his lover, Lord Alfred “Bosie” Douglas.

headline: Donald Trump’s Son-in-Law, Jared Kushner, Tests Legal Path to White House Job
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Nepotism', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Such a move could violate federal anti-nepotism law and risk legal challenges and political backlash.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jared Kushner, the son-in-law of President-elect Donald J. Trump, has spoken to a lawyer about the possibility of joining the new administration, a move that could violate federal anti-nepotism law and risk legal challenges and political backlash.

headline: Zoe Kazan on Overcoming an Eating Disorder
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Movies', 'Weight', 'ANOREXIA NERVOSA', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Eating Disorders', 'Theater']
abstract: “Dragging the terrible thing into the light can strip it of its potency.”
lead_paragraph: I was 19 and had fallen in love. He was a grad student who lived in a long, narrow apartment with a room devoted solely to books. I didn’t live there with him, but my toothbrush did. I lived in a dorm a 10-minute drive away, but he and I hardly spent a night apart. When I’d finished my work for the day, he’d pick me up at the back gate of my dorm. I always ran to his car, because it was cold and because walking would not get me to him fast enough. This was first love, the real thing, the full symphony.

headline: An Anniversary Gift From Image Comics: Issues for 25 Cents
abstract: The comics company is celebrating with February issues of The Walking Dead, Invincible and Outcast, all by Robert Kirkman.
lead_paragraph: Image Comics, which will celebrate 25 years as a comic book publisher next year, is giving its fans a little gift.

headline: Automated Pro-Trump Bots Overwhelmed Pro-Clinton Messages, Researchers Say
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Media', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The purpose of the chatbots was to rant, confuse people or muddy discussions on Twitter in the days before the election, an Oxford University report found.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — An automated army of pro-Donald J. Trump chatbots overwhelmed similar programs supporting Hillary Clinton five to one in the days leading up to the presidential election, according to a report published Thursday by researchers at Oxford University.

headline: Trump-Size Idea for a New President: Build Something Inspiring
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: The right public works projects can send a message of inclusion and pride. If Donald Trump is ready to take a cue from F.D.R., here are some places to start.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how President-elect Trump could unify a bitterly divided America, provide well-paying jobs to many of the millions of disaffected workers who voted for him, and lift the economy, stock market and tax rolls.

headline: The Creators: Rob Pruitt
abstract: Immerse yourself in a 360-degree experience directed by Luca Guadagnino, best viewed on a smartphone with a Google Cardboard or a Daydream View.
lead_paragraph: Download the NYT VR app to be transported into one day in the life of a New York-based contemporary artist.

headline: Bail Reform Begins with the Bench
keywords: ['Bail', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Judges must stop relying solely on flawed police arrest reports when determining bail.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Increased scrutiny of this city’s justice system has now expanded to include its sky-high bail amounts. Those accused of a crime may spend months in jail because they were assessed bail far beyond their means, even though nearly 45 percent of all misdemeanor and 30 percent of all felony cases here are ultimately dismissed.

headline: John Lewis’s National Book Award-Winning Graphic Memoir on the Civil Rights Movement
abstract: There are few people better qualified to remind us of what democracy really looks like than John Lewis, the Georgia congressman, civil rights icon and author of a graphic memoir called “March.”
lead_paragraph: MARCH TRILOGYBy John Lewis, Andrew Aydin and Nate PowellIllustrated. 560 pp. Top Shelf Productions. $49.99.

headline: Lessons From the Battlefield
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors']
abstract: Merging civilian and military trauma care would benefit doctors and patients alike.
lead_paragraph: Like anyone living in Boston in the spring of 2013, I remember where I was when I heard that bombs had gone off at the Boston Marathon finish line on Patriots’ Day, April 15. Three people, including an 8-year-old boy, were killed instantly. More than 260 were injured, many critically — bodies crushed, limbs shattered, arteries severed.

headline: 1916: Romanian Troops Resist Offensive
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: General Falkenhayn pressed his offensive in Transylvania, but the Romanians resisted, in November 1916.
lead_paragraph: Although General Falkenhayn is pressing his offensive in Transylvania and has gained a few local successes in some of the frontier passes, there is every reason to believe that the Roumanian military situation is steadily improving.

headline: Former Drug Industry Executives Charged in Kickback Scheme
abstract: Gary Tanner, the former Valeant executive, entered into a secret relationship with Philidor’s chief executive, Andrew Davenport, federal authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A secret relationship had made the two men rich: one, the head of a mail-order pharmacy, the other, an executive at a major pharmaceutical company who had promised to funnel millions of dollars to his partner in exchange for receiving millions of his own.

headline: J.B. Blunk’s Handmade Home
abstract: California Craft meets Japanese Minimalism in the house that the sculptor built.
lead_paragraph: California Craft meets Japanese Minimalism in the house that the sculptor built.

headline: A Little House in the Big Woods
abstract: The late craftsman J.B. Blunk built his Marin County cabin by hand: a holistic expression of an artistic life.
lead_paragraph: IN THE SLEEPY Marin County town of Inverness, on a remote wooded ridge that overlooks the wide blue sweep of the Tomales Bay, sits a modest, low-slung redwood cabin that the late multidisciplinary artist-craftsman J.B. Blunk built entirely by hand.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Alexandra Hirsch and Brady Donnelly did not go looking for bells and whistles. But having seen them, they were all in.

lead_paragraph: The monochromatic labyrinth that is the Museum of Modern Art isn’t particularly known to give visitors the warm fuzzies, but on Tuesday night, the space echoed with resounding positivity.

keywords: ['Avocados', 'Butterflies and Moths', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Conservation of Resources', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Spurred by rising demand for the fruit, farmers in the Mexican state that hosts the annual butterfly migration are replacing a vital forest habitat with orchards.
lead_paragraph: APÚTZIO DE JUÁREZ, Mexico — The green volcanic hills that tower above Apútzio de Juárez have begun to fill with swarms of monarch butterflies,  which return each year for the winter stretch of their celebrated — and imperiled — migration.

headline: In Estonia, Caution but Surprising Cheers for Trump’s Victory

abstract: Leaders in the country’s capital may be terrified, but on the Russian border people hope Donald J. Trump can lower tensions between Washington and Moscow.

Trump as the next president of the United States.

headline: Actors Flock to Netflix to Satisfy Their Most Loyal Fans
abstract: Some actors are pursuing audiences where they believe they are staying.
lead_paragraph: The fashionable notion that television is better than ever and that cinema or film is battling in vain to maintain relevance is, depending on where you sit, either a potent truth or a spectacularly tedious kernel of received nonwisdom. The fact that popular streaming video services are now investing hefty sums in the creation of content in formats that fit comfortably into commonly accepted notions of TV (varied series in half-hour and full-hour episodes) and motion pictures (self-contained features averaging two hours) puts a new spin on the debate.

abstract: America has a lot of equipment on the Continent. NATO members should lease it.
lead_paragraph: HAMBURG, Germany — So far, the German response to Donald J. Trump’s election has been predictable, and predictably loud: Politicians and pundits are rattling on about how Europe needs to bolster its defenses, speeches they have been giving for years.
