headline: Ex-Valeant and Philidor Executives Complaint
abstract: According to the federal complaint, an ex-Valeant executive was secretly paid millions of dollars to promote Philidor’s interests inside Valeant.
lead_paragraph: According to the federal complaint, an ex-Valeant executive was secretly paid millions of dollars to promote Philidor’s interests inside Valeant.

headline: The New York Times Launches the Android App for Crosswords
abstract: Introducing the new Android crossword app. You know, for people who don’t do iPhones.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 2016 — The New York Times is happy to announce the launch of The New York Times Crossword app for Android users, available for download in the Google Play Store.

headline: Painterly Scarves That Celebrate the Female Form
abstract: Olivia Wendel’s first six pieces were adapted from her own black and white paintings — and launch today.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the designer Olivia Wendel yanked open the door to the Bushwick, Brooklyn, building where she lives and works, and smoothed her white blouse, printed with muddy-looking flowers — a gift from her sisters. “They always find what end up being my favorite things, and this vintage top is one of them,” Wendel, 29, says later, ensconced on her couch across from her debut collection of scarves. “Very early on in my designing process, I would think specifically of Lilly and Zoë, and what I could get them to wear.”

headline: What You Should Read About the ‘American Horror Story: Roanoke’ Finale
abstract: “A.H.S.” has always been polarizing, and critics are divided on whether the episode brought “Roanoke” to a satisfying end.
lead_paragraph: “American Horror Story” creator Ryan Murphy wasn’t kidding when he casually mentioned, weeks before the premiere of Season 6, that the seasons in his anthology horror series are all connected. Wednesday night’s finale not only culminated the show’s meta-commentary on celebrity, violence and television, it also served as the final piece tying together all six of its seasons. “A.H.S.” has always been a polarizing series, and critics are divided on whether the high-concept episode brought “Roanoke” to a satisfying end.

headline: Video Review: Kia Cadenza Offers Budget-Minded Pampering
abstract: The Cadenza does not offer the indulgences of German cars, but it looks rich at a nonrich price, staring at about $33,000.
lead_paragraph: We make deliberate choices when buying things. Shopping for a wallet recently, I briefly considered a devastatingly gorgeous Burberry billfold. However, the outlay would have left me with little money to put into it. Oh, the irony. I opted for something similar but far more affordable.

headline: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 11
abstract: Bills quarterback Tyrod Taylor has a favorable matchup in the Bengals; playing receiver DeAndre Hopkins is worth the risk.
lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

headline: Review: ‘Manchester by the Sea’ and the Tides of Grief
abstract: The film, written and directed by Kenneth Lonergan and starring Casey Affleck, finds a man quietly dealing with tragedies.
lead_paragraph: In each of the three movies Kenneth Lonergan has directed, characters move through their everyday lives under the shadow of death. The brother and sister played by Mark Ruffalo and Laura Linney in “You Can Count on Me” (2000) had, when they were children, lost their parents in a car crash, a trauma that rippled unspoken beneath their mundane adult interactions. The coming-of-age of Lisa Cohen, the New York teenager (Anna Paquin) at the center of “Margaret” (2011), was complicated by a fatal bus accident and colored by the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: Settlement on JPMorgan Bribery Charges
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Federal prosecutors, the S.E.C. and the Federal Reserve accused JPMorgan Chase of a vast foreign bribery scheme in China that may have spread to a number of Wall Street banks.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors, the S.E.C. and the Federal Reserve accused JPMorgan Chase of a vast foreign bribery scheme in China that may have spread to a number of Wall Street banks.

headline: Turn an iPad-Made Movie Into a DVD
abstract: Home videos and other clips can be copied off the tablet and recorded onto a disc for watching on a standard DVD player.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I retired from teaching, the school made a lovely tribute movie on an iPad. I would love a copy of the movie as a keepsake, but no one can figure out how to make a DVD for me. Can you help?

headline: ‘Duck Dynasty’ to End Its Run on A&E in 2017
abstract: The reality series, among the most popular on cable television, will end after its 11th season in April, the family announced.
lead_paragraph: “Duck Dynasty,” the popular A&E reality series that since 2012 has chronicled the lives of the occasionally controversial Robertson family in Louisiana, will end next year, its stars announced.

headline: How to Run Like a Girl
abstract: For nearly a decade, more women runners have been crossing the finish line than men. Here we address the big and small challenges of running while female. Grab the sports bra, lace up your sneakers and let’s hit the road.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, more women runners have been crossing the finish line than men. Here we address the big and small challenges of running while female. Grab the sports bra, lace up your sneakers and let’s hit the road.

headline: Alimentos Saludables
abstract: The hunt for great tamales ends at this small restaurant in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The hunt for great tamales ends at this small restaurant in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Tamales, for Many Meals and Courses, at Alimentos Saludables
abstract: Pulled out of their corn husks, the tamales at this tiny restaurant in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, almost seem to breathe.
lead_paragraph: In pursuit of tamales, I have lurked outside Roman Catholic churches after Spanish Mass and chased down ladies pushing blue coolers in shopping carts along the street. Even a run-of-the-mill tamale can be a glorious thing, the musty-sweet essence of corn fortified by lard and chicken broth, the sheath of corn husks impressing some lost scent of summer.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Does Some Explaining on Metrics
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: It’s been a tough week for Mark Zuckerberg’s company. First it was fake news complaints; now it’s acknowledging bad user metrics. Neither is good.
lead_paragraph: Facebook had a message for advertisers on Wednesday: Whoops.

headline: Barbra Streisand’s Not Leaving Yet; Set to Appear at Tribeca Talks
abstract: Ms. Streisand, who vowed to leave the country if Donald Trump won the election, will be there in April; Alejandro G. Iñárritu is also on the lineup.
lead_paragraph: Barbra Streisand counts among the luminaries who vowed to leave the United States if Donald J. Trump won the presidential election. But next April, at the very least, she will be in New York, interviewed onstage at the Tribeca Film Festival.

headline: Protest of U.S. Terror Listing Offers a Glimpse at Qaeda Strategy
abstract: Al Qaeda’s Syria affiliate has rebranded, claiming it’s not a threat. And a cleric accused of being in the group’s inner circle insists he’s “independent.”
lead_paragraph: American officials accuse him of being part of the “inner leadership circle” of Al Qaeda’s Syrian affiliate, most widely known as the Nusra Front, and of raising as much as $5 million for the terrorist group while signing up thousands of fighters.

headline: The New York Times N.F.L. Playoff Simulator (3rd Annual)
abstract: A new feature allows you to use the simulator backward, to see who will finish last and secure the No. 1 draft pick.
lead_paragraph: How can my team make the N.F.L. playoffs? It’s a simple question, but answering it can be devilishly complicated. At this point in the season, when teams have six or seven games remaining, the playoff picture is delightfully foggy.

headline: Target’s Turnaround Still Faces Challenges
abstract: The retailer needs more customers wandering its aisles over the holiday season and a sustainable plan to compete with Amazon.
lead_paragraph: Target’s bull’s-eye will be hard to repeat.

headline: David Yates Narrates a Scene From ‘Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence where Newt Scamander (Eddie Redmayne) loses track of one of his beasts in a bank.
lead_paragraph: A wizard (Eddie Redmayne) reveals his powers to an unsuspecting bank customer (Dan Fogler) in this scene from “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them,” the new movie from the Harry Potter universe with an original screenplay by J. K. Rowling. The film takes place in 1926 New York and centers on the magizoologist Newt Scamander (Mr. Redmayne) and the magical creatures he carries around in a suitcase.

headline: Appeals Court Blocks Release of Brendan Dassey, of ‘Making a Murderer’
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Mr. Dassey was to be freed on Friday while the state appealed a judge’s ruling overturning his 2007 conviction on murder and sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Thursday blocked the release of Brendan Dassey, one of the subjects of Netflix’s “Making a Murderer,” from a prison in Wisconsin while the state appeals a judge’s decision to overturn his conviction on murder and sexual assault charges.

headline: Suck It In, New York, It’s Party Season
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Lingerie and Underwear', 'Parties (Social)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Since I had just gotten a clingy gold cocktail dress for a fancy awards dinner, I felt a restrictive, possibly totalitarian, undergarment was necessary.
lead_paragraph: I’m a little tired today because I just went six rounds with a Spanx Extra Firm Control body suit, an undergarment constructed with the same sort of expandable concrete used in airport runways. Possibly you heard us battling it out at Saks. I knew Spanx’s reputation, of course. I’d been told by friends that putting on one of their control garments would take every ounce of strength in me, that women have gotten these items on only to pass out on the floor and never make it to their event.

headline: In Canada, a Direct Link Between Fracking and Earthquakes
abstract: Most fracking-induced quakes in the United States are related to wastewater disposal from oil and gas wells. Scientists see a different culprit in Alberta.
lead_paragraph: In the debate over fracking of oil and gas wells, opponents often cite the risk that the process can set off nearby earthquakes. But scientists say that in the United States, fracking-induced earthquakes are not common.

headline: American Institute of Architects Apologizes for Statement of Support for Trump
abstract: The industry group backpedals after a backlash from architects and says it will hold events across the country to promote dialogue.
lead_paragraph: A week after the American Institute of Architects pledged to work with President-elect Donald J. Trump, the organization walked back its statement and apologized.

headline: With an Eye on Hunger, Scientists See Promise in Genetic Tinkering of Plants
abstract: By altering photosynthesis in tobacco, researchers improved the plant’s production, a method they hope will prove successful in food crops.
lead_paragraph: URBANA, Ill. — A decade ago, agricultural scientists at the University of Illinois suggested a bold approach to improve the food supply: tinker with photosynthesis, the chemical reaction powering nearly all life on Earth.

headline: On Rivalry Weekend in Europe, the Real Battle Is for Viewers Elsewhere
abstract: The big weekend, which includes Atlético Madrid versus Real Madrid and Manchester United versus Arsenal, is a chance for four European leagues to battle globally for fans and sponsors.
lead_paragraph: Nothing, perhaps, has better captured what it means when Atlético Madrid faces Real Madrid than what Luis Aragonés uttered a few minutes before the final of the 1992 Copa del Rey.

headline: Wine That’s Not Only Natural, It’s Alive
abstract: Interest in the often esoteric natural wine category is strong as the recent RAW Wine fair in Brooklyn shows.
lead_paragraph: It may seem shocking, precious or counterintuitive to think of wine as alive. But RAW Wine billed its recent trade and consumer fair as a celebration of “wines with emotion. Wines that have a humanlike, or living, presence.”

headline: Chinese History, Writ in Stunning Stone
abstract: “Art in a Time of Chaos” at the China Institute Gallery features singular works from between the third and sixth centuries, which was a tumultuous period.
lead_paragraph: What a shock to wake up one morning and find armed men, who spoke no language you knew and looked like no people you’d ever seen, roaming the streets of your city. And more shocking still to learn that your protectors — your leaders, your army — had fled in the night. This scene repeated itself many times in China beginning in the third century A.D., when the Han dynasty collapsed and non-Chinese nomads swept down from the north and breached the Great Wall.

headline: India Offers Some Relief to Chaos It Created With Currency Ban
abstract: The government took steps Thursday to temper growing impatience with the seemingly slapdash way a ban on high-currency bills was carried out.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — As the chaos surrounding Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ban on high-currency bills entered its ninth day, the government moved Thursday to address some of the problems amid signs of growing impatience with the slapdash way the policy seems to have been carried out.

headline: After the Election, Some Women Assert Themselves With Small Gestures
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Those who feel misogyny carried the day are taking stands against a male-dominated world, from the workplace to rituals like holiday cards.
lead_paragraph: This year, Svea Vikander has decided that she and Evla, her 3-year-old daughter, will be the focal point of her family’s holiday card. She decided to relegate her husband and son to a smaller picture below.

headline: Video Shows Baltimore Teacher Using Racial Slur in Class
abstract: Baltimore City Public Schools said the teacher was no longer employed, and a school district official said she had crossed the line.
lead_paragraph: A Baltimore public-school teacher is no longer employed after a cellphone video showed her berating minority students with “abusive” language that included a racial slur, the school district said on Thursday.

headline: The Democrats’ Real Turnout Problem
abstract: Turnout did not plummet this year, as some argued. But it did change.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama’s two victories created the impression of a strong wind at the back of the Democratic Party. Its constituencies — the young, the nonwhite, the college educated — were not only growing but were also voting in increasing numbers. The age-old issue of voter turnout finally seemed to be helping the political left.

headline: Laws About Rape
abstract: A lawyer and survivor argues for no statutes of limitation on child sexual battery.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: At a moment when all eyes are glued to the tumult of escalating news headlines, let’s take a few hours, a day, perhaps even a long weekend to take refuge in the stories that transcend the news cycle and the books that more deeply explain the forces behind it.

headline: The International Criminal Court and the U.S.
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Nuremberg War Crimes Tribunal (1945-49)']
abstract: The Global Justice Center calls on the United States to join the court.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: WikiLeaks and Privacy
abstract: A reader takes issue with an Op-Ed article by an editor for WikiLeaks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump, Valeant, Yellen: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: The Transition From Obama to Trump
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: One reader says President Obama should not cooperate. Another likens the process to auditions for “The Apprentice.” A pro-Trump reader welcomes change.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
abstract: Times opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Trump’s appointments, contact with Vladimir Putin and other news. Susan Lehman is host.
lead_paragraph: Times opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Trump’s appointments, contact with Vladimir Putin and other news. Susan Lehman is host.

headline: Apollo Missions to the Moon: The Memorabilia Stage
abstract: The group Space Center Houston is helping restore the 1960s appearance of the operations room of the Mission Control Center in Houston during Apollo moon missions.
lead_paragraph: During the Apollo moon missions, tension filled the operations room at the Apollo Mission Control Center in Houston. NASA staffers’ consoles were not only piled with paperwork but also hastily removed suit jackets, American flags and uneaten snacks. And their amber glass ashtrays overflowed with cigarette butts.

headline: Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The Times opinion columnist Andrew Rosenthal on Trump’s appointments, contact with Vladimir Putin and other news. Susan Lehman is host.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this podcast, Andrew Rosenthal, a Times Op-Ed columnist, talks about the news — the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

headline: This Museum Show Explains Why New York Is So New Yorky
abstract: “New York at Its Core,” at the Museum of the City of New York, considers what money, density and diversity have wrought from 1609 to today.
lead_paragraph: “NEW YORK AT ITS CORE,” which opens Friday at the Museum of the City of New York, is the culmination of an audacious curatorial gamble: Is it possible to make a metropolis that is perpetually in flux the centerpiece of what the museum bills as its first permanent exhibition?

headline: Not a Republican Mandate
abstract: A reader points out that Democrats won the popular vote for president and made gains in the Senate and the House.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For a Welsh City, the Tides Offer Renewal
keywords: ['Hydroelectric Power', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Swansea, once a hub of industrial activity, has fallen on harder times. A project to harness tides in the nearby bay offers a chance at rejuvenation.
lead_paragraph: SWANSEA, Wales — From the brackish, brown water of the bay, Swansea’s past fortunes are plain to see.

headline: Fake News in U.S. Election? Elsewhere, That’s Nothing New
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Elections', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Social media’s political sway is a given in places like the Philippines, Indonesia and Colombia, where false news often emerges to influence the vote.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Facebook rumors force a well-known politician to publish proof of his heritage. Fake images show a prominent female leader in a hangman’s noose. A politician’s aide decries violent crime with a Facebook photo of a girl’s corpse — an image that turns out to come from another country.

headline: Drilling Into the Chicxulub Crater, Ground Zero of the Dinosaur Extinction
abstract: By studying hills that formed after an asteroid struck the Yucatán Peninsula, researchers found that materials deep in Earth’s crust were brought toward the surface.
lead_paragraph: Some 66 million years ago an asteroid crashed into the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico, triggering the extinction event that obliterated the dinosaurs and nearly extinguished all life on Earth. It struck with the same energy as 100 million atomic bombs, and left behind a 100-mile-wide scar known today as the Chicxulub crater.

headline: David Bowie and Other Artists Lead Children on a Galactic Adventure
abstract: This exhibition at the Children’s Museum of the Arts includes David Bowie’s earliest music video and other interstellar adventures for kids (and parents).
lead_paragraph: Ground Control to Major Tom: Hordes of children are invading your space.

headline: Review: ‘Magnus’ Delves Into the Life of a ‘Mozart of Chess’
abstract: Even fans of chess might struggle to connect with the cursory approach to this documentary’s subject, the prodigy Magnus Carlsen, and to the game itself.
lead_paragraph: There’s something ineffably sad about child prodigies. Tramping along an often solitary path to greatness, one that allows few detours for the innocent pleasures of childhood, these small wonders can tug at the heart. And so it is with Magnus Carlsen, the Norwegian chess champion at the center of “Magnus,” Benjamin Ree’s insipid and uninformative portrait of singularity and obsession.

headline: Review: ‘Ne Me Quitte Pas’ Takes 2 Alcoholics and Chronicles the Tedium of Their Lives
abstract: The Belgian documentary begins with a divorce, follows a man to rehab, and includes the aftermath of an alcohol-induced auto accident.
lead_paragraph: The Belgian documentary “Ne Me Quitte Pas” (“Don’t Leave Me”) begins with a bang, so to speak. A man and a woman are discussing their marriage, or soon-to-be lack thereof; the woman is leaving him. The man, drawing from a can of beer, casually requests sex from her one last time. Befuddled, she refuses. He presses the issue, wryly, or, rather, in a tone that he believes to be wry. “You’ll forget me in no time,” the woman says with firmness and equanimity.

headline: Review: ‘I Am Not Madame Bovary’ Takes Man Trouble to New Levels
abstract: A Chinese comedic melodrama, with a divorce of convenience followed by a real jilting, has situational intrigue marred by a labored approach.
lead_paragraph: There’s some intriguing social commentary in the Chinese comedic melodrama “I Am Not Madame Bovary,” an adaptation of Liu Zhenyun’s novel of the same name, directed by Feng Xiaogang. But appreciating it, and the other points of interest in the movie, requires a perhaps unusual amount of patience, or even indulgence.

headline: At the Los Angeles Auto Show, an Industry Ponders Its Digital Future
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Los Angeles Auto Show', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: Automakers promoted their high-tech bona fides and environmentally friendly conscience at the AutoMobility LA conference.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For decades, the car business has been about style, performance, image and fuel efficiency. But suddenly, the industry is in a technological and sociological upheaval that may force automobiles — and the companies that make them — to change more in the next five years than they have in the last 50.

headline: Review: ‘A Street Cat Named Bob’ Helps His Owner Detox
abstract: With Bob on his shoulder, a homeless busker, James, is able to face just about anything — a negligent father, street ruffians and drug withdrawal.
lead_paragraph: If Grumpy Cat and “Keanu” haven’t sated your appetite for screen felines, try “A Street Cat Named Bob,” a savvy exercise in inspirational feel-good cinema lightly seasoned with grit. Adapted from James Bowen’s autobiography (part of a Bob franchise), the movie, directed by Roger Spottiswoode, tells how an orange cat enters the life of James (Luke Treadaway), a homeless London busker struggling with heroin addiction. Though James has a sobriety adviser (a firm Joanne Froggatt, as a persuasive living argument for public health care) who finds him housing, it is the cat, which James names Bob, who teaches him about responsibility and what it’s like to feel loved.

headline: Tesla and SolarCity Shareholders Approve Merger
abstract: Putting the two together will yield a green-energy company whose products include electric cars and solar panels for homes.
lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — Elon Musk has succeeded in combining two parts of his business empire, as investors in Tesla Motors and in the solar panel maker SolarCity agreed on Thursday to a merger.

headline: Review: A Cross-Generational Bond, Conveyed in Dance
abstract: Brooklyn Touring Outfit’s “Co. Venture” explores the ties between the dancer Pepper Fajans, 31, and David Vaughan, 92, a former Merce Cunningham archivist.
lead_paragraph: When David Vaughan first met Pepper Fajans, it was not in Mr. Fajans’s capacity as a dancer (which he is), but as a carpenter (which he also is). Mr. Fajans was building a set for “Mondays With Merce,” a video series devoted to the work of the choreographer Merce Cunningham. Mr. Vaughan was the Cunningham company’s longtime archivist; Mr. Fajans eventually became Cunningham’s caretaker for 10 months until his death in 2009 and then, during the company’s final tour, looked after Mr. Vaughan. Despite their difference in ages — Mr. Vaughan is 92, Mr. Fajans 31 — they formed a deep bond.

headline: Dumped Moms, Gun-Toting Guests: It’s Thanksgiving
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Families and Family Life', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Gun Control', 'Parenting']
abstract: Tips on how to navigate the holiday in an especially polarized climate.
lead_paragraph: My son is my only child. When he was 4, I divorced his father and raised him on my own. I didn’t receive any financial support, so I worked full time to support us. Now my son is married with three children. But since he married, I am not included in family holidays like Thanksgiving or Christmas. For years, I invited them, but they never accepted. They spend holidays with my daughter-in-law’s family. It bothers me that my in-laws don’t seem to care that I’m left alone. I’ve had many talks with my son about this, but nothing changes. Is there anything more I can do?

headline: Obama, With Angela Merkel in Berlin, Assails Spread of Fake News
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama, appearing with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, also warned Donald J. Trump to take the presidency seriously.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In his strongest public comments since the election, President Obama on Thursday sharply criticized the spread of fake news online and said that President-elect Donald J. Trump would not remain in office for long if he failed to take the job seriously.

headline: This Phoenix Suns Reserve Calls the City’s Police Chief ‘Mom’
abstract: Alan Williams, a reserve center, is in his second season with the Phoenix Suns. His mother, Jeri Williams, is in her first month as the leader of the city’s police force.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Alan Williams and his mother, Jeri, watched on television this summer as San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick protested police brutality and racial injustice by refusing to stand during the national anthem. Kaepernick’s political statement was personal for both Williams, a second-year player for the Phoenix Suns, and his mother, who had recently agreed to become the city’s police chief.

headline: Review: A Pickpocket Is Recruited by the C.I.A. in ‘The Take’
abstract: Idris Elba and Richard Madden star in this well-executed variation of the buddy-cop formula, set in Paris.
lead_paragraph: You’ve got to love the juxtaposition in “The Take,” a tasty thriller directed by James Watkins. Tech- and media-savvy bad guys go up against that most humble of miscreants: a pickpocket.

headline: Review: ‘Uncle Howard’ Looks Back at a Filmmaker’s Work Cut Short
abstract: This documentary is a dual portrait of intertwined artists: Howard Brookner, who died of AIDS early in his career, and his nephew Aaron Brookner, now also a filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: “Uncle Howard” begins with a scene portraying its director, Aaron Brookner, as a man on a mission. Filmed with a shaky video camera, he follows the poet John Giorno into his apartment, hot on the trail of a cache of films made by Mr. Brookner’s uncle, Howard Brookner.

headline: Bloomberg to End Its Daily Politics Show
abstract: “With All Due Respect” will terminate as Bloomberg reshuffles its politics team.
lead_paragraph: With the election now in the rearview mirror, Bloomberg has decided to terminate its daily politics show “With All Due Respect” hosted by the political journalists John Heilemann and Mark Halperin and refocus its Bloomberg Politics team, according to a staff memo on Thursday.

headline: ‘The Tree of Life’ Unfurls, With a Live Orchestra and Choir
abstract: In its grandest project yet, the concert series Wordless Music will screen Terrence Malick’s film with live accompaniment at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Ronen Givony, who founded the omnivorous concert series Wordless Music, is often surprised that he’s the first to pounce on a new musical opportunity. In 2008, he faced no competition from major orchestras in vying to give the American premiere of a piece by Radiohead’s Jonny Greenwood. And several years ago, he broke out of the pops-like mold of film-soundtrack karaoke with a live performance of the magical Cajun-inspired score for “Beasts of the Southern Wild.”

headline: Review: Nederlands Dans Theater Prizes Procedure Over Passion
abstract: The troupe, visiting from The Hague, is presenting four works from its repertory of contemporary ballet.
lead_paragraph: The most technically proficient dancers aren’t always the ones who can make us feel most deeply. Take, for example, Nederlands Dans Theater, which returned to City Center on Wednesday. It appears there’s nothing that this limpid troupe can’t do, in terms of stretching the body to spectacular extremes. Yet for the most part, the choreography the dancers so impeccably master limits them to showing off.

headline: Review: ‘Life on the Line,’ a Plodding View of High-Wire Labor
abstract: John Travolta and Kate Bosworth star in a cliché-filled drama about the men who keep power transmission lines working.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood desperately needs to expand its search for working-class heroes beyond the narrow universe of police officers, firefighters and soldiers. But underappreciated occupations deserve better than the cliché-clogged, utterly predictable “Life on the Line,” a terrible movie about the workers who keep the electrical grid functioning.

headline: Here Comes the Whitney Biennial, Reflecting the Tumult of the Times
abstract: The museum has announced the 63 participants in its survey of what’s happening now in contemporary art — the new, the influential and the provocative.
lead_paragraph: FOR the first time in 20 years, the lead-up to the Whitney Biennial coincided with the presidential election, a background that could not help but inform the selection of artists and artwork that will be on view when the biennial opens on March 17, the first in the museum’s new downtown building.

headline: Review: ‘Blood on the Mountain’ Looks at the Ravages of Coal Mining
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Coal', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: This documentary about the industry in West Virginia is not well made but raises timely issues.
lead_paragraph: “Blood on the Mountain” is a clumsily made attack on the coal industry in West Virginia, but it benefits considerably from the events of the past two weeks. The film jumps around chronologically and thematically in a way that dilutes its impact, but it still provides plenty of cause to question the wisdom of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s stated intentions of reviving coal mining and reducing environmental and other regulations.

headline: Review: Merrily (and Ruefully) Recalling an Epic Broadway Flop
abstract: “Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened,” a documentary by Lonny Price, examines the buildup and collapse of “Merrily We Roll Along” in 1981.
lead_paragraph: I was one of the few to see the original production of “Merrily We Roll Along,” which opened on Broadway in 1981 and, having received mostly catastrophic reviews, closed after 16 performances. On the night I saw it, the audience response was polite but halfhearted because by then it was already a certified flop.

headline: Review: ‘Ali and Nino,’ a Love Story Set Against Majestic Backdrops
abstract: During the era surrounding World War I, in the Caucasus region, a romance is complicated by religious and political boundaries.
lead_paragraph: “Ali and Nino” aspires to epicness and comes pretty close to getting there.

headline: Review: ‘The Love Witch,’ Hell-Bent on Capturing Your Heart
abstract: Anna Biller’s new film stars Samantha Robinson as a magical seductress whose charms turn out to be lethal.
lead_paragraph: “The Love Witch” is, among other things, a study in the color red. Elaine, whose vocation is succinctly captured in the title of Anna Biller’s new film, is first seen driving north from San Francisco in a bright red convertible with a matching set of luggage in the back seat and a slightly contrasting shade of lipstick on her mouth and on the stubbed-out cigarettes in the car’s ashtray. Later on, red wine will be spilled, and there will be blood from various sources.

headline: Review: In ‘Off the Rails,’ an Eager Conductor Stalks New York’s Transit System
abstract: Adam Irving’s documentary is the story of Darius McCollum, a man with Asperger’s syndrome who borrows trains and buses for joy rides.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Off the Rails,” Adam Irving’s first film, is an assured and thoughtful debut. He presents the story of Darius McCollum, a man with a long history of taking New York City subway trains and buses for joy rides even though he is not a transit employee. But Mr. Irving’s subtext is a criminal justice system that has no way to deal with an offender like Mr. McCollum, who has Asperger’s syndrome, other than to keep throwing him in prison.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Rosemary Mayer’s works offer a trip back to a feminist cooperative gallery; the Anton Kern Gallery celebrates with a group show; and Chapter NY juxtaposes two sculptors.
lead_paragraph: Southfirst 60 North Sixth Street Williamsburg, Brooklyn Through Dec. 11

headline: Review: ‘The Edge of Seventeen’ Takes Teenage Movies to a Higher Place
abstract: In its raw honesty, “The Edge of Seventeen,” like “Clueless,” is among the best films about high school kids in years.
lead_paragraph: In the grand scheme of things, losing a trusted friendship is a painful blow, but it usually isn’t the end of the world. If you’re an unpopular teenager, however, and the interloper is a sibling, it can feel like that.

headline: Bayreuth’s Loss Is Tanglewood’s Gain, When It Comes to Andris Nelsons
abstract: This summer’s Tanglewood Festival in the Berkshires will include Mr. Nelsons conducting or participating in 11 concerts over four weeks.
lead_paragraph: Bayreuth’s loss is the Berkshires’ gain.

headline: Review: ‘Bleed for This’ Is a Boxing Movie That Gets Boxing
abstract: The film tells the true story of the brash fighter Vinny Pazienza, who fractured his neck in a car accident but earned his place back in the ring.
lead_paragraph: For its first 40 minutes or so, “Bleed for This,” the “based on a true story” boxing picture directed by Ben Younger and starring Miles Teller, follows the sports-movie-comeback-narrative playbook with extreme fidelity. It would be tiresome were it not for the casual energy of the filmmaking. Mr. Teller plays Vinny Pazienza, the Rhode Island-born-and-bred boxer who, as the film opens in 1988, seems a bit feckless. Staying up too late in Las Vegas the night before a big fight, he goes on to lose that match. His third in a row. His own manager announces in a televised interview that the fighter should hang up the towel.

headline: Trump, Obama, Abe, Merkel: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Comedy Listings for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Review: ‘Nocturnal Animals,’ Brutality Between the Pages and Among the Fabulous
abstract: This thriller, directed by Tom Ford, toggles between the life of a wealthy woman (Amy Adams) and the events in a novel she is reading by her ex-husband.
lead_paragraph: Joan Didion wrote that “we tell ourselves stories in order to live.” Sometimes, though, we tell stories to kill, to stick a stiletto in and watch the blood drain. That’s the moral of “Nocturnal Animals,” a harsh cautionary tale about love, vengeance and the divide between life and art, that shadowy space in which real people are turned into fictional characters and old hurts made into narrative grist. Here, an unhappy girlfriend becomes a happy wife, a betrayed man becomes a victim all over again, and assorted murderers take turns bringing the pain.

headline: Francis Picabia, the Playboy Prankster of Modernism
abstract: “Francis Picabia: Our Heads Are Round So Our Thoughts Can Change Direction” is the Museum of Modern Art’s first substantial show for an artist among the earliest proponents of Cubism and Dada.
lead_paragraph: Make way for Francis Picabia, one of the grandest, most mordant exemplars of early modernism, and perhaps the least familiar. The Museum of Modern Art — having for decades drummed the artistic feats of Picasso, Matisse, Mondrian and Duchamp into cultural consciousness — has finally rolled out the red carpet for this capricious, prolific, subversive fellow traveler.

headline: Review: Molly Ringwald Now Plays a Granny in ‘Terms of Endearment’
abstract: At 59E59 Theaters, a stage version of the novel and its Oscar-winning 1980s movie version includes most of the film’s memorable moments and more sexual frankness.
lead_paragraph: Say it ain’t so.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Nov. 18, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them,” “Manchester by the Sea” and “Nocturnal Animals.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them,” “Manchester by the Sea” and “Nocturnal Animals.”

headline: Making a Difference: Ideas for Giving, Service Learning and Social Action
abstract: We encourage students to think about how to give back in a way that has the most meaning to them, and makes the most impact on an issue they care about.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Dec. 17

headline: What Soft Market? Resiliency Rules
abstract: Recent activity at leading auction houses has often defied talk about a softening art market, as works by Monet and others have sold for millions.
lead_paragraph: To grasp the unpredictability of the art market, one need only look to this week of fall auctions.

headline: Review: ‘The Daily Show (The Book)’ Reveals How Jon Stewart Made News
abstract: This “oral history” seeks a serious understanding of everything about Mr. Stewart, especially the thinking that made the show what it was.
lead_paragraph: Chris Smith’s new book about “The Daily Show” in the Jon Stewart years has a theory about the events that let the show find its voice. After Bush vs. Gore in 2000 and just after the 9/11 attacks, real news became so surreal and television news so lathered that a fake news show could find its footing just by playing things relatively straight.

headline: Movie Listings for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: Read reviews of new releases and search our full database of thousands of films at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

headline: When Obama’s Gone, Who Will Stand Up for Democracy?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'International Relations']
abstract: With authoritarian leaders on the rise, democratic values are increasingly threatened.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is devoting much of the last foreign trip of his term to reassuring European allies that Washington will maintain its security commitments under Donald Trump and stay true to its democratic principles. Before leaving Washington, he met with Mr. Trump and said the president-elect “expressed a great interest in maintaining our core strategic relationships,” including “strong and robust NATO” partnerships.

headline: U.S., in Shift, Backs Arms Embargo for South Sudan as Genocide Risk Rises
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The American ambassador to the United Nations signaled the change of position to help stop the violence convulsing the world’s youngest country.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United States said Thursday that it was ready to impose an arms embargo against South Sudan, a shift in position that many rights groups called long overdue to help stop the deadly violence convulsing the world’s youngest country.

headline: Theater Listings for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

headline: Airbnb Broadens Its Business With Tours and Travel Experiences
abstract: Facing challenges in its core business of short-term rentals, Airbnb is aiming to become a fuller-service travel company by connecting travelers with local guides.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Airbnb used to let you just book room rentals. Now you can also use Airbnb to reserve dance parties in Havana, historical tours in Cape Town and stargazing outings in Los Angeles.

headline: ‘Duck Dynasty’ Legacy: Real, Fake and Upfront About It
abstract: This A&E show, which has just announced that this season will be its last, figured out early that viewers didn’t care if their chosen reality was real.
lead_paragraph: Interesting juxtaposition of the week: The A&E show “Duck Dynasty” announces that the current season will be its last, and Paul Horner, who creates fake news stories on the internet, tells The Washington Post: “My sites were picked up by Trump supporters all the time. I think Trump is in the White House because of me.”

headline: Jazz Listings for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: Yeshiva University Names Ari Berman President
abstract: Rabbi Berman, a Queens-bred alumnus who led a Manhattan congregation and has spent eight years in Israel, will take over at a time of financial stress.
lead_paragraph: Yeshiva University may not have the same high profile in New York City as Columbia and New York University, but it is the fountainhead of the Modern Orthodox Jewish movement, and enrolls about 7,000 students at colleges and highly regarded professional schools that include the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology.

headline: Classical Music Listings for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

headline: Now a Two-Time M.V.P., Mike Trout May Be the Angels’ Greatest Player Ever
abstract: A case can be made that Trout, five years in, is already the best player in franchise history.
lead_paragraph: Mike Trout landed his second Most Valuable Player Award on Thursday. He has now finished in the top two in the voting for five straight years and established himself as the game’s best player.

headline: Dance Listings for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

headline: White Plains Police Cleared in Suit Over 2011 Shooting Death
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Police']
abstract: A federal jury rejected a wrongful-death claim by the family of Kenneth Chamberlain Sr., a mentally disturbed ex-Marine killed in his apartment.
lead_paragraph: The City of White Plains and a police officer were not at fault in the death of a mentally disturbed former Marine who was shot in his apartment five years ago after a 90-minute confrontation with the police, a federal jury found in a civil case on Thursday.

headline: Kris Bryant and Mike Trout Are Worthy M.V.P.s, Regardless of Team Results
abstract: Trout won despite his Los Angeles Angels finishing 74-88 this season. Bryant was a member of the championship-winning Chicago Cubs.
lead_paragraph: Kris Bryant hit a home run to start the Chicago Cubs’ scoring in Game 5 of the World Series last month. In Game 6, Bryant did it again. In Game 7, with two outs in the bottom of the 10th inning, he fielded a grounder and lost his balance, but still made the throw that gave the Cubs their first championship in 108 years.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

headline: Around Town for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: Udacity, an Online Learning Start-Up, Offers Tech Job Trials
abstract: With a new program, Blitz, Udacity is expanding an effort to train workers in high-tech fields in which workers are in high demand.
lead_paragraph: Udacity, an online learning start-up founded by a pioneer of self-driving cars, is finally taking the wraps off a job trial program it has worked on for the last year with 80 small companies.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for Nov. 18-24
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: With Anti-Trump Advantage, Cuomo and de Blasio Vie to Be Opponent in Chief
abstract: Within the professional political class, Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo now seem to be elevating their longstanding rivalry to one for the role of progressive opponent in chief.
lead_paragraph: In the days since an election that will substantially reduce the likelihood of your going to Midtown more than three times over the next four years, the pervasive mood in New York has been grief-stricken and despairing. The city has emerged, perhaps unpredictably, as the nation’s capital of discontentment (Los Angeles, San Francisco, we know that you are trying), the frontier of enmity to the potential hardships and catastrophes Donald J. Trump’s impending presidency might produce.

headline: An Extra Layer of Dutch for New York Philharmonic
keywords: ['Classical Music', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Music']
abstract: The Dutch composer Louis Andriessen has won the Kravis prize, and the Philharmonic will debut a work of his with Jaap van Zweden, also Dutch, conducting.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic will offer its audiences a taste of new Amsterdam when the Dutch maestro Jaap van Zweden becomes its music director in the 2018-19 season.

headline: How Nilou Motamed, Editor of Food & Wine Magazine, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: From a neighborhood farmers’ market to Russian bazaar in Brighton Beach, Ms. Motamed’s day is something of an epicurean odyssey.
lead_paragraph: For Nilou Motamed, the editor in chief of Food & Wine magazine, Sundays are for exploring markets and restaurants near her home in Carroll Gardens — as well as several other neighborhoods. Ms. Motamed, 45, lives with her husband, Peter Jon Lindberg, 46, a contributing editor at Condé Nast Traveler, who also recently became director of inspiration for Conrad Hotels & Resorts. They met in 2000 while working at Travel & Leisure magazine. “Our first date was over martinis at the Royalton Vodka Bar, where we had a heated discussion about who made the best cannoli in New York,” she said. “We agreed to disagree, and three years later we were married.”

headline: Devouring (and Drinking) American History
abstract: From her tiny kitchen in Chinatown, Sarah Lohman, a self-described historic gastronome, recreates eating regimens of yore.
lead_paragraph: In the kitchen of her small apartment in Chinatown, Sarah Lohman worked a mound of pasta dough with a rolling pin.

headline: Ahmad Rahimi Pleads Not Guilty in Manhattan Bombing
abstract: Mr. Rahimi is accused of setting off a bomb in Chelsea, and planting a second device that failed to detonate. He has also pleaded not guilty to charges that stem from attacks in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Ahmad Khan Rahimi, the New Jersey man accused of setting off a bomb in Manhattan on Sept. 17 that injured more than 30 people, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to federal charges stemming from that attack and a failed attempt to explode a bomb nearby.

headline: McDonald’s Introduces Screen Ordering and Table Service
abstract: The revamped system aims to address longer wait times by seating customers rather than having them wait at a counter.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to McDonald’s! May I take your order — and bring it to your table?

headline: A Memorable Night at McSorley’s
abstract: Recalling a police officer’s unusual request that two students ask a bartender to call 911.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary,

headline: Staying in Gear for 40 Years at Frank’s Bike Shop
abstract: The crowded, grubby shop on the Lower East Side of Manhattan has amassed a fervent group of loyalists with business practices that are increasingly rare.
lead_paragraph: When the fork was stolen off Bart Michiels’s mountain bike last summer, he wheeled the frame nearly three miles from his home in Chelsea to Frank’s Bike Shop on the eastern end of Grand Street.

headline: 1942 All Over Again?
keywords: ['Racial Profiling', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Muslim Americans', 'Discrimination', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Korematsu v United States (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Japanese-Americans']
abstract: Donald Trump’s campaign vow to register Muslims is a frightening echo of the shameful treatment of Japanese-American citizens during World War II.
lead_paragraph: This is how it starts.

headline: Who Installs the New Mosaics in New York’s Subways?
abstract: Many of the artists whose works adorn the subway walls are not mosaic experts themselves. A master craftsman helps them recreate their visions.
lead_paragraph: Q. The mosaic that has gone up at the entrance to the Hudson Yards subway station on 34th Street is breathtaking. Who is responsible for selecting new artworks, and who installs them?

headline: Donald Trump Seeks to Delay Action on Spending Bills Until His Term Starts
abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan said the House would go along with the request and pass a stopgap measure that would keep the government running at current spending levels until March.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump is making his influence felt on government funding deliberations in Congress, pressing Republican leaders to postpone action on spending bills until after he takes office.

headline: Jay W. Forrester Dies at 98; a Pioneer in Computer Models
abstract: In addition to developing system dynamics modeling, Mr. Forrester, an M.I.T. professor, was an inventor of magnetic core memory for computers.
lead_paragraph: Jay W. Forrester, an electrical engineer whose insights into both computing and organizations more than 60 years ago gave rise to a field of computer modeling that examines the behavior of things as specific as a corporation and as broad as global growth, died on Wednesday at his home in Concord, Mass. He was 98.

headline: National Security Agency Said to Use Manhattan Tower as Listening Post
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Privacy', 'Movies']
abstract: An article and a documentary drawing on material provided by Edward Snowden say the federal agency conducts surveillance from an AT&T building.
lead_paragraph: On any person who desires such queer prizes, New York will bestow the gift of loneliness and the gift of privacy.

headline: India’s Strange Cash Problem
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi tries to fight corruption by calling in old rupees.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India has declared war on corruption, a big factor in perpetuating poverty in that country. But his shocking decision on Nov. 8 to remove and replace large-denomination paper money was poorly thought out and executed.

headline: Charlie Engle Runs for His Life, Once Again
abstract: Charlie Engle has run extreme distances for many reasons: to test his limits, to build his celebrity, to serve penance and to keep himself sane.
lead_paragraph: It was a warm Saturday morning in October, and on a 50-acre farm just north of Bell Buckle, Tenn. (pop. 425), 46 runners gathered at the starting line, preparing to run one of the quirkiest, yet most arduous, of races. Called the Big Backyard Ultra, the race required contestants to run a course that spanned 4.167 miles, over trails etched out of the farm, every hour.

headline: Tell Us How Narendra Modi’s Banning of Rupee Notes Affects You
abstract: We want to hear from those living in India on Mr. Modi’s move, and the impact it has had on you and your family.
lead_paragraph: We want to hear from those living in India on Mr. Modi’s move, and the impact it has had on you and your family.

headline: Donald Trump, After Fits and Starts, Focuses on Foreign Policy
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The president-elect met with the prime minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, and also held meetings with several experts and the Israeli ambassador.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump embarked on one of the rituals of the American presidency on Thursday, meeting in New York with the prime minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, as he continued his fitful adjustment to the protocols of high-level diplomacy.

headline: Yankees Trade Brian McCann to the Astros
abstract: The Yankees reportedly shed $23 million of McCann’s contract over the next two years, while paving the way for Gary Sanchez to be the everyday catcher.
lead_paragraph: Continuing their transformation into a younger and financially leaner team, the Yankees traded Brian McCann and cash on Thursday to the Houston Astros for two raw pitching prospects, Albert Abreu and Jorge Guzman.

headline: How Rudolph Giuliani, Possible Cabinet Pick, Made Millions as Ex-Mayor
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In 2006, the former New York City mayor made $10 million from 108 speeches he delivered to audiences around the world, and more money from other projects.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a golden year for Rudolph W. Giuliani, a mad dash that would take him to 11 countries on four continents, and by the time 2006 was done, earn him $16 million — a princely sum compared with the $7,000 he claimed to have in 2001, when he went through a divorce.

headline: Review: Jeremy Denk and His Piano Take a 600-Year Tour
abstract: Mr. Denk’s performance, which concluded Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival, wove a story through the ages.
lead_paragraph: The inquisitive pianist Jeremy Denk faced a challenge in planning “Medieval to Modern,” the program he presented at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday. Over some 80 minutes, with no breaks, Mr. Denk played 23 works spanning 600 years, from a lament by the 14th-century French composer Guillaume de Machaut to an obsessive 1985 étude by Gyorgy Ligeti.

headline: Diana Balmori, Landscape Architect With a Blending Philosophy, Dies at 84
abstract: Ms. Balmori’s projects included buildings, gardens and master plans that emanated from “very clear human engineering with ecology and with landscape.”
lead_paragraph: Diana Balmori, a landscape architect whose ecologically sensitive designs integrated buildings and the natural environment in projects ranging in scope from urban rooftop gardens to South Korea’s new administrative capital, Sejong City, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 84.

headline: 2 Men Charged With Murder After Buried Body Is Found in New Jersey
abstract: James Rackover, 25, and Lawrence Dilione, 28, are accused of killing Joseph Comunale, 26, in Manhattan, then burying his body on the Jersey Shore.
lead_paragraph: Two men were charged with murder in Manhattan on Thursday, a day after the body of a Connecticut man they had partied with over the weekend was found in a shallow grave on the Jersey Shore.

headline: Review: Faye Driscoll’s ‘Play’ Channels a Howl Into Fun and Games
abstract: In this dance-theater piece, the second in a proposed trilogy, adults act — and act out — like teenagers putting on a show.
lead_paragraph: Will Faye Driscoll ever grow up? At BAM Fisher on Wednesday, this choreographer presented the New York premiere of her “Thank You for Coming: Play.” The second installment in a proposed trilogy, it’s the latest in a longer line of works that expend her considerable directorial skill and creative vitality on sophomoric attitudes, ideas and sentiments.

headline: Review: ‘Dead Poets Society,’ Starring Jason Sudeikis as the Idealistic Teacher
abstract: Stripped of its cinematic distractions, this Off Broadway adaptation directed by John Doyle comes across as blunt and bland.
lead_paragraph: A lone spark of subversion brightens the generally damp proceedings of “Dead Poets Society,” which opened on Thursday night at Classic Stage Company, directed by that streamliner deluxe John Doyle and featuring the comic film star Jason Sudeikis in an advanced state of decency. This enlivening flicker occurs well past the midpoint of Tom Schulman’s tidy adaptation of his Oscar-winning screenplay from 1989, when hopes have worn thin.

headline: The Divine Comedy
abstract: Peter Wentz starts our solving weekend with a Scrabbly, crunchy puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — A terrific start to our weekend by Peter Wentz, with a central stack and intersecting long Down entry that is just awesome. How could you not like GINGERBREAD COLDHEARTED BARMITZVAHS, with CONDOLEEZZA RICE “dropping in”?

headline: The New Shapes of New York
abstract: Towers, an arena, even a salt shed: Over the past decade, the cityscape has been transformed.
lead_paragraph: The soaring spires, the sloping shores, the straitjacket of the street grid — many things give form to the great metropolis. The skyline may be our most recognizable feature, despite how unrecognizable it can often be.

headline: Report Spurs CUNY to End Its Contracts With Outside Lobbyists
abstract: The move is the latest turn in the scandal involving unauthorized spending at the City University of New York, the largest public urban university in the country.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of a scathing report from the state inspector general’s office, campuses and organizations affiliated with the City University of New York abruptly terminated their contracts with outside lobbyists this week.

headline: Leon G. Billings, Architect of Clean Air and Clean Water Acts, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Billings was the first staff director of the Senate environment subcommittee and an alter ego of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine.
lead_paragraph: Gretchen Garber grew up in Washington State but, afflicted with chronic lung disease, spent vacations with her grandparents in Montana. “By the end of the summer,” she said, “I would be able to stand up straight, finally, and go back to suffer another winter of asthma.”

headline: Capturing Gleason’s
abstract: Thierry Gourjon started photographing Gleason’s Gym, which will move from its Brooklyn waterfront address next month, as a young man in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Thierry Gourjon started photographing Gleason’s Gym, which will move from its Brooklyn waterfront address next month, as a young man in the 1990s.

headline: At Gleason’s Gym, Years of Sweat and Grime
abstract: Thierry Gourjon spent thousands of hours at Gleason’s, in Brooklyn, and his black-and-white photos portray the sport’s intoxicating swirl of violence and grace.
lead_paragraph: Gleason’s Gym, the oldest boxing gymnasium in New York, will move from its address on the Brooklyn waterfront next month. It is moving only a block away, but the relocation leaves behind an era’s worth of sweat and grime that has accumulated in this temple to the sweet science.

headline: As Trump Nears Office, Australian Deal to Move Refugees to U.S. Is in Doubt
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Detainees', 'Immigration Detention']
abstract: The deal to resettle refugees and asylum seekers held in detention camps in the Pacific might not happen now that Donald J. Trump is the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: CANBERRA, Australia — Barring some unexpected development, none of the refugees held in detention camps on the Pacific islands of Nauru and Manus are likely to be resettled in the United States before President-elect Donald J. Trump takes office, Australian and American officials said this week.

headline: Michael Flynn, Anti-Islamist Ex-General, Offered Security Post, Trump Aide Says

Flynn, potentially putting a retired intelligence officer who believes Islamist militancy poses an existential threat in one of the most powerful roles in shaping military and foreign policy, according to a top official on Mr. Trump’s transition team.

abstract: Candidate Trump promised to protect entitlements, but President-elect Trump apparently has different plans.

headline: Donald Trump’s Plan to Purge the Nation

headline: Judge John Hodgman on a Giants Fan Posing as an Eagles Fan
abstract: The swindle reeks of bad faith.
lead_paragraph: Vincent writes: Here in South Jersey, a doughnuts-and-coffee chain offers a promotion. On the day after a Philadelphia Eagles win, customers get a free iced coffee. My wife, a New York Giants fan, will often collect a free coffee, even though she roots against the Eagles. Please bar her from partaking of coffee the Eagles have earned for their fans.

headline: How to Give Yourself a Tattoo
abstract: Practice on a piece of fruit. Don’t numb the skin.
lead_paragraph: “Simplicity is really key in tattoos,” says Talia Migliaccio, a tattoo artist. “It’s about making a mark and how those marks relate to the world around us.” Migliaccio suggests starting with a couple of lines or a meaningful number, something basic, small and easy to execute. Like most people who give tattoos for a living, Migliaccio recommends going to a professional if possible. But if you’re going to do your own stick-and-poke tattoo — which is not unlike a prison tattoo — practice first on fake skin or a piece of fruit to get the feel for needle work.

headline: How Strong Is Your Faith in American Democracy?
abstract: Are you confident that the United States’s constitutional democracy is strong enough to weather whatever challenges may come its way?
lead_paragraph: For the second time in less than two decades, the United States elected a president who won the most electors to the Electoral College but lost the popular vote. Yet, Americans’ allegiance to the Constitution is so strong that in both cases, the winner of the popular vote conceded quickly and publicly so that the country could move forward with the peaceful transfer of power.

abstract: A sister returns after more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: When my sister, Maryan, came to Kenya to visit us in the Dadaab refugee camp last spring, it had been 11 years since we had seen her. Our family arrived a quarter-century ago to escape the war in Somalia and has been here since. I was born in the camp, 21 years ago. But in 2005, when I was 9, Maryan and her husband and son were accepted for resettlement in the United States.

headline: At a Danish Street Market, Flaeskesteg and Tacos
abstract: The Aarhus Street Food Market serves authentic Danish food — and food from Mexico and Italy, too.
lead_paragraph: “It’s Danish Christmas in a sandwich,” said Mads Ravn, a Danish archaeologist, about the flaeskesteg sandwiches we were devouring. Flaeskesteg, the Christmas dinner of Denmark, is pork with a rind that’s been roasted to a crispy crackling. At Stegen & Dellen, a vendor at the new Street Food Market in Aarhus, it’s served year-round on a pillowy brioche bun slathered in mayonnaise and topped with bracing red kraut and long curls of pickled cucumber, wrapped in butcher paper (and, in this case, washed down with a Midtfyns Stout from a neighboring vendor, Olfred).

He’d rather stay in his lavish New York penthouse. Policy is a headache. It requires concentration. There are annoying laws against nepotism. Trump won 4.1 percent of the vote in the District of Columbia. Washington does not pine for him.

headline: Dev Patel Tapped His Inner Alpha for ‘Lion’
abstract: Mr. Patel was determined to nail the lead role in the adaptation of Saroo Brierley’s memoir. So he learned an Australian accent and hit the gym.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Dev Patel wanted the lead role in the forthcoming film “Lion” so badly that he showed up at the Los Angeles home of the screenwriter Luke Davies in 2013 to plead for the part. From the moment the young actor heard of the project, he had been intrigued by its improbable story and conflicted hero. The director Garth Davis was there, too, and the three settled in over fresh ginger tea. But then Mr. Patel noticed a whiteboard covered in a blizzard of Post-its. He looked at the notes. “I was like, wait, you haven’t done the script yet?” he said.

headline: The End of Identity Liberalism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'News and News Media', 'Minorities', "Women's Rights", 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Our fixation on diversity cost us this election — and more.
lead_paragraph: It is a truism that America has become a more diverse country. It is also a beautiful thing to watch. Visitors from other countries, particularly those having trouble incorporating different ethnic groups and faiths, are amazed that we manage to pull it off. Not perfectly, of course, but certainly better than any European or Asian nation today. It’s an extraordinary success story.

headline: What Will a Trump Presidency Mean for New York Real Estate?
abstract: Real estate executives are hopeful that Mr. Trump’s tax plans could help New York’s flagging luxury housing market.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Pierre E. Debbas, a partner at the boutique law firm Romer Debbas, was representing a couple buying a Manhattan condominium who wanted the option to back out of the deal if Donald J. Trump won the election. After Mr. Debbas explained that no seller would agree to such a contingency, they signed the contract and took their chances.

headline: The Aging Fighter Who May Be Russia’s Favorite American
abstract: Jeff Monson, a mixed martial arts fighter known as “The Snowman,” is admired for his tenacity and his belief that Moscow is right about most things.
lead_paragraph: SUKHUMI, Georgia — He is blind in one eye and has a bad hip that makes it painful to sit, never mind endure the kicks and punches that are an essential part of his job as a mixed martial arts fighter. He is also nearly twice the age of many of his rivals at the top of his harrowingly brutal profession.

headline: Obama and E.U. Leaders Agree to Keep Sanctions on Russia
abstract: The leaders said that sanctions should stay until Moscow upheld its pledge for a cease-fire and to withdraw of heavy weapons from eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — President Obama and several European leaders “unanimously agreed” on Friday to keep sanctions in place against Russia for its intervention in Ukraine, amid concern that President-elect Donald J. Trump would soften the United States’ stance against Moscow.

headline: The Latin Grammys: A Mashup of Glitter, Rhythm and Politics
abstract: The broadcast of the awards started with a postelection statement and then continued with an honor for Marc Anthony and a broad array of performances.
lead_paragraph: The 17th annual Latin Grammy Awards broadcast started with a postelection statement: “Tu Enemigo” (“Your Enemy”). It’s a duet, originally released in 2015, by Pablo López, from Spain, and Juanes, from Colombia, with lyrics that reject the demonization of immigrants. “Don’t ask me what I came for/Better ask yourself how you got here,” Juanes sang, backed by a white-robed choir and a team of drummers while Cirque du Soleil aerialists writhed overhead.

headline: Why Surging Stocks May Not Mean the Economy Trusts Trump
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Rising share prices signify predictions of greater profits, but those profits could come at the expense of consumers if regulations are slashed.
lead_paragraph: The early stock market reaction to Donald J. Trump’s election victory was overwhelmingly positive. But that doesn’t mean a Trump presidency will be good for the economy.

headline: Amid Division, a March in Washington Seeks to Bring Women Together
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Inaugurations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Organizers of the Women’s March on Washington, scheduled for the day after Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, are facing a difficult task: gathering women who remain fiercely divided on many issues.
lead_paragraph: A movement is growing to bring together women across race, creed and political beliefs by luring them off social media and arranging for them to meet in person.

headline: Talking About Sex and ‘The Affair’ With Dominic West
abstract: As “The Affair” begins its third season, the star Dominic West confesses he can’t bear to watch himself on television for more than a few minutes.
lead_paragraph: For two seasons, Noah Solloway was the resident punisher in “The Affair,” the Showtime drama about a novelist who leaves his moneyed wife for a waitress grieving the death of her son — and spins the experience into a best seller.

headline: Julie Dash Made a Movie. Then Hollywood Shut Her Out.
abstract: Julie Dash’s 1991 film, “Daughters of the Dust,” was the first feature by an African-American woman to have a wide release. Yet many doors remained closed to her.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — One day late in April, the filmmaker Julie Dash got a phone call from her daughter. “Welcome to the BeyHive,” her daughter said. “What are you talking about?” Ms. Dash replied.

headline: Australia Has a Serious Gambling Problem
abstract: Can anything be done to rein in an industry that sucks millions of dollars out of Australians’ pockets?
lead_paragraph: Australia tops its fair share of lists, including hosting the deadliest animals on earth and, perhaps paradoxically, some of the world’s most livable cities. But the country also tops the charts on an indicator that is far more insidious: gambling losses. Last year, Australians lost $17.5 billion, or about $949 per adult. These per capita losses are among the highest in the world.

headline: Last Wish of Dying Girl, 14, to Be Frozen, Is Granted by Judge
abstract: “I want to have this chance,” the British teenager told the judge after her parents disagreed about the cryogenic preservation procedure.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — During the last months of her life, a terminally ill 14-year-old British girl made a final wish. Instead of being buried, she asked to be frozen so that she could be “woken up” in the future when a cure was found — even if that was hundreds of years later.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz: Optimists, Flu and Ankle Sprains
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: In Southern Tasmania, Great Food and Rugged Appeal
abstract: Where to eat, sleep and shop in the land down under the land down under.
lead_paragraph: It’s only a 90-minute flight from splashy Sydney, but the Australian state of Tasmania feels much farther. Part of the island’s haunted, otherworldly mien might be attributable to its geographical and atmospheric particulars: It is, after all, the country’s last defense before Antarctica, and its extreme southerly position means that for much of the year the land is shrouded in a crepuscular light.

headline: Will the Carolina Panthers Survive Their 1-5 Start? Uh, No
abstract: The Panthers are now 4-6, and while four of their six remaining games seem winnable, they face long odds to make the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: After a horrible 1-5 start, the Carolina Panthers have won three out of four, capped by Thursday night’s 23-20 victory over the Saints.

headline: I Wish We All Could Be Californian
abstract: Our secessionary mood is an emotional reaction to the election of Donald Trump and a reflection of the power of our own brand of liberalism.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco — THIS is going to sound very California, but here goes: I drowned my election sorrows by surfing. It didn’t help, but I was struck by something afterward. All my life, I’ve seen strangers on California beaches — bearded bodysurfers drinking local Bourbon, Republican volleyball players eating vegan energy bars — trade warm glances that say, “I salute your lifestyle choices and respect your privacy.” After the election, those furtive nods implied nausea, terror and a compassion born of confidence that others felt much the same. Within that compassion, I sensed the emergence of something new in California public life: an awareness that we Californians are bound together as one people by the shared values of our increasingly tolerant and pluralistic society.

headline: A Lesson in Emotional Geography
abstract: Thinking about the war in Syria reminds me of my grandmother in the 1980s, who tried to make sense of Lebanon’s scarred landscape from her porch.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child, I spent most summers at my grandparents’ home in the Lebanese mountain village of Roumieh, overlooking Beirut and the Mediterranean coast. From the swing on the veranda, an expanse of umbrella pines and terracotta-roofed villages tumbled steeply toward the sea.

headline: How Could You? 19 Questions to Ask Loved Ones Who Voted the Other Way
abstract: A guide to facilitate conversation between Trump voters and Clinton voters.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what we learned after the ugliest presidential campaign in modern times.

headline: I Voted Clinton. You Voted Trump. Let’s Talk.
abstract: A gay actor in California and his father in Kentucky talk at length about how they feel about each other’s votes.
lead_paragraph: “O.K., Craig,” the father asks, “you ready?”

headline: New Historical Novel Imagines the Life of an Irish Martyr
abstract: Sabina Murray’s “Valiant Gentlemen” imagines intense relationships between the Irish martyr Roger Casement and his closest friends.
lead_paragraph: VALIANT GENTLEMENBy Sabina Murray489 pp. Grove Press. $27.

abstract: After a car crash, a guilt-racked heroine heads to New York in Alice Hoffman’s “Faithful.”
lead_paragraph: FAITHFULBy Alice Hoffman258 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.
