headline: Counterfeiting Trade Settles Into a New York Standby: Self-Storage Units
abstract: The police say that, like many New York City residents with little space and lots of stuff, vendors and suppliers of fake handbags are stashing their wares in inexpensive storage compartments.
lead_paragraph: Time was, if you wanted a knockoff purse, you went to Canal Street in Chinatown and looked for a store with a back room. The police raided these stores and took the bags, but more always arrived. Finally, the handbag companies began to sue the landlords of the buildings, who in turn drove out the purse vendors.

headline: Trump Turns Staid Process Into Spectacle as Aspirants Parade to His Door
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump hinted strongly that he was considering picking James N. Mattis, a retired Marine Corps general, to be defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — President-elect Donald J. Trump has turned the vital, but normally inscrutable, process of forming a government into a Trump-branded, made-for-television spectacle, parading his finalists for top administration positions this weekend before reporters and the world.

headline: Forced to Leave Odessa as a Girl, and Yearning for the Life She Knew Then
abstract: Lyubov Bilik, an 87-year-old woman who lives in Brooklyn, thinks often of her childhood in Ukraine before her family fled during World War II.
lead_paragraph: Lyubov Bilik fled the only home she knew in 1941. With her mother and two older sisters, she boarded a ship from Odessa, Ukraine, and eventually wound up near the northern foothills of the Caucasus Mountains, fleeing the slaughter of Jews by the Nazis and the Romanians. She was 12 at the time. Her father, who had been conscripted into the Soviet Army, was forced to stay behind.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: The time to prepare is now — for the Thanksgiving feast, and the days leading up to it.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: How Fake News Goes Viral: A Case Study
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Social Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: How a misinformed Twitter post the night after the presidential election fueled a nationwide conspiracy theory and became a talking point — even as it was being proved false.
lead_paragraph: Eric Tucker, a 35-year-old co-founder of a marketing company in Austin, Tex., had just about 40 Twitter followers. But his recent tweet about paid protesters being bused to demonstrations against President-elect Donald J. Trump fueled a nationwide conspiracy theory — one that Mr. Trump joined in promoting.

headline: N.F.L.: There’s Dallas’s Dak Prescott and Then All the Other Rookie QBs
abstract: Prescott withstood a tough Ravens defense as the Cowboys’ win streak hit nine, while others went in the wrong direction. Week 11 scores and highlights.
lead_paragraph: Not all rookie quarterbacks are the same. Here’s what else we learned in Week 11 in the N.F.L.:

headline: As American as Apple Pie? The Rural Vote’s Disproportionate Slice of Power
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Electoral College', 'States (US)', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: Rural America, even as it decries its economic weakness, has retained electoral strength beyond its numbers.
lead_paragraph: In 1920, for the first time, the Census Bureau counted more people living in urbanized America than in the countryside. This hasn’t been a rural nation ever since.

headline: Netanyahu Faces Conflict-of-Interest Scrutiny in Submarine Deal
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is facing questions over a billion-dollar deal with Germany in which his personal lawyer was involved.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Dogged for decades by scandals ranging from the funding of family trips  to enormous ice cream bills, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is again under scrutiny, this time over a billion-dollar deal with Germany for the acquisition of three new submarines.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Duel: Addressing the President-Elect on His Own Blunt Terms
abstract: In delivering his plea to Mike Pence after the show, the Broadway actor Brandon Victor Dixon was also speaking to Donald J. Trump, meeting directness with directness.
lead_paragraph: “The theater must always be a safe and special place.”

headline: Villager’s Execution in China Ignites Uproar Over Inequality of Justice
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Some say the Communist Party is imposing harsh punishments on the most vulnerable members of society while coddling the well-connected elite.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Zhou Yunfei, a technology executive who owns a villa in eastern China, did not have much in common with an impoverished farmer more than 500 miles away who was convicted of murdering a village chief with a nail gun.

headline: Indians Rush Frantically to Launder Their ‘Black Money’
abstract: Jewelers, high-end boutiques and other businesses are being inundated with buyers trying to purchase expensive items on backdated receipts.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Indians’ ingenuity is being mightily tested as they rush to save their “black money,” stashes of hundreds of thousands, even millions, of rupees they have accumulated without paying taxes.

headline: Aleppo, Donald Trump, Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Houston Conwill, Whose Sculptures Celebrated Black Culture, Dies at 69
abstract: Among Mr. Conwill’s best-known works are a memorial for the poet Langston Hughes in Harlem and one for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Houston Conwill, a sculptor best known for collaborative site-specific works celebrating African-American culture and spiritualism, died on Nov. 14 in the Bronx. He was 69.

headline: Kanye West Calls Out Beyoncé and Praises Trump in Onstage Tirade
abstract: After playing only three songs, the rapper cut short his “Saint Pablo” show in Sacramento following a 17-minute monologue.
lead_paragraph: Kanye West likened himself to Donald J. Trump at a concert on Saturday in California before tumbling into a 17-minute, free-associative speech addressing radio programmers, MTV, his friends and collaborators Jay Z and Beyoncé, Hillary Clinton, Mark Zuckerberg and more.

headline: ‘Fantastic Beasts’ Is a Hit for Warner Bros.
abstract: The J.K. Rowling-scripted fantasy is a boon for the studio, whose last three big-budget efforts drew cool reactions from critics.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Warner Bros. and J. K. Rowling pulled off an exceptionally difficult magic trick over the weekend. Not only did they bring the “Harry Potter” film franchise back to life, they also did it without Harry Potter.

headline: Andy Murray Beats Error-Prone Novak Djokovic to Retain No. 1 Ranking
abstract: Murray, who took over the top spot from Djokovic two weeks ago, took advantage of Djokovic’s 30 unforced errors to capture his first ATP World Tour Finals title.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Andy Murray closed in this fall on Novak Djokovic’s run of more than two years at No. 1 and then overtook him this month, one thing was missing: a punctuating win over Djokovic, his toughest and longest rival.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 21
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Donald Trump and the Bieber Doctrine
abstract: The new American foreign policy seems to be to tell allies they “should go and love yourself.”
lead_paragraph: Sofia, Bulgaria — It seems no matter what happens with American politics, the 19th-century French thinker Alexis de Tocqueville has something to say about it. In his classic “Democracy in America,” he suggested that democratic politics was in need of drama; as an election nears, “intrigues become more active, agitation more lively and more widespread. The entire nation falls into a feverish state.” But, once the election has passed, “everything becomes calm, and the river, one moment overflowed, returns peacefully to its bed.”

headline: Landon Collins’s Development Keeps the Giants on the Rise
abstract: The Giants looked lifeless on offense, defense and special teams early on but still won their fifth straight and improved to 7-3 as Collins made a game-sealing interception.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A year ago, Landon Collins would stand at the back of the Giants’ secondary looking confused and fretful. A rookie safety, he was the Giants’ last line of defense and the last person the team could rely on. His head was swimming, even drowning, in the details of a playbook full of mystifying schemes and signals.

headline: A Look at Apple’s Sprawling New Campus in Texas
abstract: The tech giant’s rapid growth in Austin provides a window into the vast constellation of jobs at the company and their economic impact.
lead_paragraph: The tech giant’s rapid growth in Austin provides a window into the vast constellation of jobs at the company and their economic impact.

headline: How Apple Empowers, and Employs, the American Working Class
abstract: The tech giant probably won’t bring all production to the United States, as Donald Trump has suggested, but it provides diverse opportunities for thousands of Americans, along with a ladder to climb.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — During the presidential campaign, President-elect Donald J. Trump complained that America had lost too many manufacturing jobs and promised to force big companies like Apple to bring that work home. “I’m going to get Apple to start making their computers and their iPhones on our land, not in China,” he said.

headline: Review: Brahms at the Boston Smphony, With Hélène Grimaud
abstract: If conductors can be divided into those who excel at Brahms’s First and Third symphonies and those who do best with the Second and Fourth, Andris Nelsons is the former.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The British critic Richard Osborne once wrote that, when it comes to Brahms’s symphonies, there are First and Third conductors, and Second and Fourth conductors. The scheme is loose and doesn’t apply to everyone, particularly not to visionaries or stoics, but it captures the difficulties in maintaining consistency across the cycle. Musicians who excel in the personal, odd-numbered statements are often challenged, relatively speaking, by the formalistic, even-numbered works.

headline: Review: ‘Search Party’ Turns Up Clueless Sleuths of Brooklyn
abstract: A cure for millennial malaise? Maybe, at least for the sleuths who pursue this mystery, and the humor it exudes.
lead_paragraph: In a television season full of nonconformist new comedies, TBS’s “Search Party,” beginning Monday, is one of the odder ducks.

headline: Heng on Democracy in Hong Kong
abstract: Beijing’s unilateral move to block two politicians from taking their seats in the Legislature is seen as an attempt to silence democratic voices.
lead_paragraph: Beijing’s unilateral move to block two politicians from taking their seats in the Hong Kong Legislature is seen as an attempt to silence democratic voices.

headline: Review: ‘Marathon: The Patriots Day Bombing’ Focuses on the Struggle to Recover
abstract: An HBO film about the 2013 terror attack during the Boston race has its feel-good moments, but it’s really about physical and emotional pain.
lead_paragraph: Survivor documentaries are common, and many come with a triumph-over-adversity element that might make viewers tingle at the resilience of the human spirit. “Marathon: The Patriots Day Bombing,” airing Monday night on HBO, is no exception.

headline: Laurent Hilaire Named Artistic Director of Stanislavsky Ballet
abstract: The former Paris Opera Ballet star dancer will assume that role at the Stanislavsky and Nemirovich-Danchenko Moscow Music Theater on Jan. 1.
lead_paragraph: Laurent Hilaire, a former Paris Opera Ballet star dancer, who has been a contender for the artistic director job at both that company and La Scala Ballet, finally has a company to call his own. The Stanislavsky and Nemirovich-Danchenko Moscow Music Theater announced on Sunday that Mr. Hilaire would become artistic director of its 120-member ballet company on Jan. 1.

headline: Luciano Benetton Presents Art Collection in China
abstract: The apparel company co-founder has amassed more than 20,000 paintings by artists from 120 countries through his “Imago Mundi” project, with postcard-sized works now showing in China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — More than 30 years ago, the United Colors of Benetton released a series of provocative advertisements about race and multiculturalism. But in recent years, Luciano Benetton, 81, the co-founder of that Italian apparel company, has sought a different medium through which to promote his feel-good, internationalist ideals: art.

headline: Richard Rorty’s 1998 Book Suggested Election 2016 Was Coming
abstract: In this book, “Achieving Our Country,” Mr. Rorty predicted an electoral shift that would leave an opening for a Trump-like figure to emerge as a savior.
lead_paragraph: Three days after the presidential election, an astute law professor tweeted a picture of three paragraphs, very slightly condensed, from Richard Rorty’s “Achieving Our Country,” published in 1998. It was retweeted thousands of times, generating a run on the book — its ranking soared on Amazon and by day’s end it was no longer available. (Harvard University Press is reprinting the book for the first time since 2010, a spokeswoman for the publisher said.)

headline: Review: Innocuous Remarks Double as Cutting Commentary in ‘Abigail’s Party’
abstract: This deft revival of a Mike Leigh play, set at a drunken suburban soiree, lays bare the disappointment behind seemingly self-satisfied guests.
lead_paragraph: “Abigail’s Party” may be the most uncomfortable comedy in New York right now, and I’d sit through it again in a second. Here, humor and unpleasantness are intertwined, and that leads to laughs — many, many laughs — that are part gleeful and part appalled.

headline: Jessica Chastain’s ‘Miss Sloane’ Echoes Campaign Rhetoric
abstract: This film about a ruthless lobbyist and gun control might be a box-office gamble after the victory of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: In the new political drama “Miss Sloane,” Jessica Chastain’s titular lobbyist explains how to win in Washington. You have to play your last trump card, she says, right after your opponents play their last trump card.

headline: Review: Ballet Hispanico Adds Style and Bounce to an Apollo Homecoming
abstract: This 46-year-old troupe, directed by Eduardo Vilaro, continued its November tradition in a festive show with excellent dancing.
lead_paragraph: Eduardo Vilaro, the artistic director of Ballet Hispanico, looked out from the Apollo Theater stage and told the excited crowd, “This is home.” Since 2011, his company has appeared at that Harlem theater annually around this time of year, and these performances have offered the best expression of how Mr. Vilaro, at the helm since 2009, has been maintaining and transforming this 46-year-old troupe. The show on Friday evening continued that tradition. While not quite living up to the claims of reinvention and originality in the printed program, it was a festive affair with excellent dancing.

headline: How an Extreme Underdog Wins
abstract: Even John Lieb is back.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — John Lieb is back, and his Monday puzzle has a theme element that cannot be reproduced in the online versions or the apps. If you are a print solver, however, you will see a bonus theme feature, which I discuss below. If not, this is still a very smooth and enjoyable Monday solve.

headline: Anthem-Cigna Proposed Deal Goes to U.S. Federal Court
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Durable Goods (Economic Indicator)']
abstract: What’s ahead this week: The Justice Department is challenging the deal between two of the nation’s health largest insurers, saying it would be bad for customers.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

abstract: For the N.F.L.’s first trip to Mexico City since 2005, it is exporting a marquee matchup, with two teams that entered the weekend in first and have connections to Derek Carr.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

headline: American Music Awards Red Carpet 2016
abstract: See what celebrities wore to one of music’s biggest award shows.
lead_paragraph: See what celebrities wore to one of music’s biggest award shows.

headline: Indian Business Partners Hope to Exploit Their Ties to Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A meeting last week with Indian developers highlights the potential for conflict stemming from his businesses and his role as president.
lead_paragraph: PUNE, India — It is a daunting proposition to put $2 million apartments on the market in Pune — a quiet industrial city in the west of India, where even the fanciest neighborhoods are lined with squat housing blocks.

headline: American Music Awards Red Carpet 2016
abstract: See what celebrities like Gigi Hadid, Selena Gomez, Taraji P. Henson and more wore to one of music’s biggest award shows.
lead_paragraph: See what celebrities like Gigi Hadid, Selena Gomez, Taraji P. Henson and more wore to one of music’s biggest award shows.

headline: Forget Filling Ad Breaks; Some Marketers Make the Podcasts
abstract: Companies like G.E. are working with podcast networks to produce original series — a kind of twist on “native ads” that are crafted to resemble editorial content.
lead_paragraph: FOR a brand seeking to reach the podcast-listening public, there is one thing better than sponsoring a hit series: creating your own. General Electric pulled it off last year with its quaintly named GE Podcast Theater. Its eight-part science-fiction thriller “The Message,” produced with the Panoply podcasting network, hit No. 1 on the iTunes podcast chart and had nearly five million downloads.

headline: Microsoft Spends Big to Build a Computer Out of Science Fiction
abstract: The computer giant says it’s ready to start planning a prototype quantum computer, a superpowerful device that relies on subatomic particles instead of transistors.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft is putting its considerable financial and engineering muscle into the experimental field of quantum computing as it works to build a machine that could tackle problems beyond the reach of today’s digital computers.

headline: Milt Okun, Who Turned John Denver Into a Pop Star, Dies at 92
abstract: A music producer and arranger who founded Cherry Lane Music Publishing, Mr. Okun also worked with Peter, Paul and Mary, Plácido Domingo and Harry Belafonte.
lead_paragraph: Milt Okun, a producer and arranger who helped turn acts as diverse as Peter, Paul and Mary, John Denver and Plácido Domingo into pop sensations, and who founded Cherry Lane Music Publishing, one of the world’s largest independent music publishers, died on Nov. 15 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 92.

headline: The Penguins’ Steady Ascent Shows the Way for the Rest of the N.H.L.
abstract: After getting demolished by the Penguins in the first round of last season’s playoffs, the Rangers followed their lead by getting younger and faster.
lead_paragraph: Sidney Crosby had three weary Islanders right where he wanted them early in overtime on Friday at Barclays Center.

headline: As U.S. Soccer Weighs Jurgen Klinsmann’s Future, He Says, ‘I’m Not Afraid’
abstract: Klinsmann, whose tenure as the men’s national team coach could end this week, says calls for his firing are “disrespectful.”
lead_paragraph: Jurgen Klinsmann, whose status as coach of the United States men’s national team is under intense scrutiny, said Sunday night that he was “very comfortable” with his position and that he believed those calling for him to be fired were “being disrespectful” and “ignoring the facts” about his tenure as the team’s leader.

headline: The Future of Health Care Mergers Under Trump
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Legal experts say Donald Trump’s election could change how vigorously the federal government handles two giant deals and others in the industry.
lead_paragraph: The proposed health insurance mega-merger between Anthem and Cigna heads to court on Monday, as the companies face off against a Justice Department seeking to block their $48 billion deal. It will be followed in just a few weeks by the trial for another proposed insurance mega-merger, between Aetna and Humana.

headline: Trump, Though Critical of Nuclear Deal, Could Offer Opportunities for Iran
abstract: Many analysts point to Donald J. Trump’s remarks that the United States should stop backing rebels in Syria, whose president is an ally of Iran’s.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — At first blush, the election of Donald J. Trump would seem to be bad news for Iran. But there is a chance that on balance, things could work out surprisingly well for the clerics.

headline: The Old Ways Are Sometimes the Only Ways
abstract: A farmer’s market transaction on the Upper West Side is resistant to modern technology.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary,

headline: Estonia’s New Premier Comes From Party With Links to Russia
abstract: The Center Party had long been shut out of power because it had brokered a pact with Vladimir Putin’s party. A change in its leadership changed all that.
lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia — Juri Ratas, the new leader of a party whose strongest support comes from the country’s ethnic Russians, has been named the next prime minister of Estonia.

headline: Knicks Patch Things Up, Then Fix Some Problems Against the Hawks
abstract: The Knicks aired their grievances in a team meeting on Saturday and then put together the kind of defensive performance that had been a rarity for them.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks came together Saturday for a team meeting, which offered them an opportunity to air their grievances. Although they had played only 12 games, their patchy start had left them in need of introspection.

headline: Nicolas Sarkozy Is Out as François Fillon Takes Surprise Lead in French Primary
abstract: Mr. Fillon, a tradition-minded former prime minister, won the first round among the Republicans, advancing to face Alain Juppé and knocking out former President Nicolas Sarkozy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A taciturn, tradition-minded former prime minister, François Fillon, emerged as the surprise front-runner in the first round of presidential primary voting among center-right candidates in France on Sunday, advancing to the second round next week against another former prime minister, Alain Juppé, who came in second.

headline: Perseverance Pays Off for Andre Ward, an Old Hand and a New Champion
abstract: Ward, 32, staged a come-from-behind victory against Sergey Kovalev in a light-heavyweight title bout that may position him as the sport’s next big star.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The lights were back on at T-Mobile Arena. The ring ropes had been taken down, cables for the vast broadcast apparatus had been disconnected, and almost all of the crowd, announced at more than 13,000, had cleared out.

headline: How to Avoid Drug Testing in Russia: Radio Silence and Secure Perimeters
keywords: ['Doping (Sports)', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Olympic Games (2014)', 'Tests (Drug Use)', 'Olympic Games', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: The president of the World Anti-Doping Agency said he was eager to restore Russia to good standing, but athletes remain elusive to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: GLASGOW — Russian athletes, under intense scrutiny after revelations of widespread doping, remain elusive to antidoping authorities, failing to provide updates on their whereabouts and training inside military areas that are inaccessible to drug-testing officials, according to the global watchdog for sports doping.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg and Facebook Must Defend the Truth
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Newspapers']
abstract: As the mainstream news media work to separate fact from fiction, Facebook — which has gobbled up much of the online ad market — must do its part.
lead_paragraph: Friday night, the Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg went on his vast social network to convince an expanding chorus of critics — including the departing president of the United States — that he honest-to-goodness wants to combat the “fake news” that is running wild across his site and others, and turning our politics into a paranoiac fantasy come to life.

headline: Many in Milwaukee Neighborhood Didn’t Vote — and Don’t Regret It
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting and Voters', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: As Democrats pick through the wreckage of the campaign, one lesson is clear: The election was notable as much for the people who did not show up, as for those who did.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Four barbers and a firefighter were pondering their future under a Trump presidency at the Upper Cutz barbershop last week.

headline: What You Didn’t Know About Things That Go In Your Mouth
abstract: The host, Stephen J. Dubner, and panelists consider a Depression-era menu, a nutty fact about the Iran nuclear deal, a surprisingly versatile musical instrument and more.
lead_paragraph: In 1933, in the midst of the Great Depression, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt sat down to a meal that cost less than 8 cents. The first lady, Eleanor Roosevelt, wanted to provide an example for hungry Americans, to demonstrate how a family could survive on a pittance. It was a carefully chosen combination of calories and nutrients. The meal marked the start of the first government program that distributed food to the hungry.

headline: Phil Jackson Perches Atop the Knicks, and a Soapbox
abstract: The Knicks’ president, back in the public cross hairs, has not hesitated to expound on other teams’ issues even as he and his players have stumbled.
lead_paragraph: Like the guy behind you in a theater, chattering away during a movie, Phil Jackson seems to have lost the ability to hear himself.

headline: Melania and Barron Trump Won’t Immediately Move to White House
keywords: ['White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: They will remain in New York for at least another six months after the inauguration, transition officials said, out of concern for uprooting him in the middle of the school year.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s wife, Melania, and their 10-year-old son, Barron, will not immediately move to the White House after Mr. Trump takes office in January, out of concern for uprooting Barron in the middle of the school year, transition officials said on Sunday.

headline: Jimmie Johnson Ties Record With Seventh Nascar Championship
abstract: Johnson went from last place to first in the Ford EcoBoost 400 and joined Richard Petty and Dale Earnhardt as the only seven-time series champions.
lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD, Fla. — Jimmie Johnson pulled off an improbable last-place-to-first-place drive in Sunday’s Nascar Sprint Cup season finale at Homestead-Miami Speedway to claim a record-tying seventh series championship.

headline: On These French Ski Slopes, You’re on Your Own
abstract: Around this 12th century village, there is no avalanche control, snow grooming or man-made slopes. And the ski patrol tells you that it is dangerous.
lead_paragraph: LA GRAVE, France — As I lowered myself by rope down a 100-foot cliff into Trifides 1, a marquee ski run here, I remembered the words of the mountain guide Joe Vallone: “Skiing in La Grave will change your life.”

headline: Dallas Stares Down a Texas-Size Threat of Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Police', 'Government Employees', 'Bankruptcies', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Decades of faulty assumptions by pension officials have left the city struggling with more pension debt, relative to its resources, than any major American city except Chicago.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Picture the next major American city to go bankrupt. What springs to mind? Probably not the swagger and sprawl of Dallas.

headline: In Amsterdam, the Story of Jewelry’s Beginnings
abstract: An exhibition at the Sieraad International Jewelry Fair included 75 items from three museums.
lead_paragraph: The story of jewelry’s beginnings was told in a 75-item exhibition at the Sieraad International Jewelry Art Fair Nov. 10-13 in Amsterdam.

headline: Donald Trump’s Swamp Gets Murkier
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Editorials']
abstract: A disturbing number of lobbyists and special interest players are joining the transition team.
lead_paragraph: Now that he is president-elect, Donald Trump’s anti-corruption promise to “drain the swamp” of Washington lobbyists and powerful insiders seems to be rapidly dissolving in the swamp itself. An untold number of lobbyists and special interest players have been helping the Trump team’s transition to the White House, their path made easier, according to news reports, by vague and porous ethical standards.

headline: Alt-Right Gathering Exults in Trump Election With Nazi-Era Salute
keywords: ['Whites', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The alt-right, an extremist fringe popular with white supremacists, has celebrated the election of Donald J. Trump, and now hopes to have the ear of his White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time Richard B. Spencer, the leading ideologue of the alt-right movement and the final speaker of the night, rose to address a gathering of his followers on Saturday, the crowd was restless.

headline: In Lebanon, a Jeweler Modernizes a 19th Century Setting
abstract: Selim Mouzannar has stopped using silver under gems, taking the tricks out of the Falamenk Ottoman style.
lead_paragraph: As a boy in Beirut, Lebanon, Selim Mouzannar roamed the incense-scented halls of the souk, where members of the city’s Christian community ran its hundred jewelry workshops — Mr. Mouzannar’s father and grandfather among them.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, November 21, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “America was until this last generation a white country designed for ourselves and our posterity. It is our creation and it belongs to us.”

headline: Aleppo Bombs Leave Quarter Million ‘Living in Hell’ and Without Hospital Care
abstract: Bombs launched by the Syrian government seriously damaged two general hospitals providing trauma care in the war zone and hit the only children’s hospital.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The remaining hospitals on the rebel-held side of Aleppo, Syria, have been badly damaged and forced to stop providing care amid an intensifying bombardment, according to the World Health Organization.

headline: Custom Jewelry, Mini Size
abstract: Bespoke pieces for children are becoming a significant part of the market, especially in India.
lead_paragraph: Tarang Arora, president of Amrapali Jewels, described how he pored over a set of charcoal and colored pencil sketches of an anklet and a headpiece for an 11-year-old girl. He said it was late, well past store hours, and his many workers, including 12 designers, had left the 3,500-square-foot showroom for the day.

headline: Deciphering Jewels From the Maghreb
abstract: An exhibition sheds light on materials and designs used in Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A couple visiting Morocco in the 1970s gave in to the temptation of the Marrakesh bazaar and bought a silver brooch, never dreaming that the purchase would lead to many more over the years in other North African souks or from dealers in Paris. Now, the collection of the Swiss couple, Jean-François and Malou Bouvier, is being shown for the first time at “Wearable Treasures: Jewelry and Accessories,” an exhibition through Jan. 8 at the Institute of the Arab World in Paris. The museum’s director, Eric Delpont, spoke recently about the exhibition curated by Djamila Chakour. This interview has been condensed and edited.

headline: Opportunities Create ‘Quite a Wild Month’ for Bangkok Jewelers
abstract: Kavant & Sharart are debuting at Jewelry Arabia and Saks Fifth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: The second half of 2016 has been busy — and especially globe-trotting — for Kavant & Sharart.

headline: At De Grisogono, It’s All Gems and Glamour
abstract: Fawaz Gruosi ensures the house’s watch and jewelry creations have allure.

headline: Rally in Brooklyn Park Condemns Swastikas and ‘Go Trump’ Graffiti
abstract: At Adam Yauch Park, elected officials and Adam Horovitz of the Beastie Boys spoke out against hate crimes, reports of which have risen in New York City this year.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, swastikas and the words “Go Trump” were discovered in graffiti on a jungle gym in Brooklyn Heights. By Sunday, the scrawl had been erased and in its place was a pile of marigolds, chrysanthemums and tiny paper hearts as a rally echoed across the playground, condemning the failure of President-elect Donald J. Trump to address a rash of hate crimes linked to his name.

headline: In the Emirates, Traditional Wedding Jewelry is Back in Style
abstract: Some jewelers, who melted down old pieces, are using photographs to recreate the designs.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Tassels hung from the disc-like headpiece, called a tassa, tinkling like wind chimes when they touched and looking something like a golden waterfall, interspersed with pearls and flashes of red and green stones. The pearls are real, and important gems, Ayesha Al Khoori, 25, said — but the stones, she added with a smile, “don’t have to be real, because no one cares about these.”

headline: Review: A Thoroughly Modern ‘Sweet Charity’ Who Abandons Hope

lead_paragraph: In keeping with the dominant mood of New York City these days, the dance hall hostess known as Charity Hope Valentine has finally shed her middle name. As compellingly portrayed by Sutton Foster, in an archetype-shattering performance, the title character of the 1966 musical “Sweet Charity” has never before seemed so hopeless.

headline: ‘Westworld’ Season 1, Episode 8: Maeve Plays God
abstract: For one sequence, the show offers a taste of the delicious (and fun) entertainment that might have been.
lead_paragraph: With the few fragments of brain we have left this deep into the first season of “Westworld,” let us try once again to remember the source of Jonathan Nolan and Lisa Joy’s series, the starting point of the maze in which we currently find ourselves. Because for as much as Michael Crichton tried to suggest the dangers of technology and the hubris of resurrecting a world lost to history, his original “Westworld” was also a diverting piece of genre entertainment. Mr. Crichton always wanted to advance big, alarmist ideas — about viral plagues, about Japanese business tactics, about the true nature of sexual harassment — but his instinct for pleasing his audience is why he had a career as a best-selling author, rather than another penniless purveyor of hard sci-fi.

headline: Policing Flint
abstract: Step inside the Police Department of Flint, Mich., to see how officers in this struggling city confront budget cuts and public distrust.
lead_paragraph: As filmmakers, we’ve always been interested in exploring different mediums to combine intimate, character-driven stories with a strong sense of place. We employed this approach while making our first feature documentary, “T-Rex,” about the two-time Olympic gold medal boxer Claressa Shields, who is a native of the once thriving, now struggling, city of Flint, Mich. After spending four years in the city and getting to know its residents, we felt there was more that needed to be told about the challenges Flint is confronting. So last fall, we began production on an episodic documentary series about an institution at the core of the city, the Flint Police Department.

headline: A Dreamer’s Deportation Nightmare
abstract: With Donald Trump headed to the White House, my future as a working community college student is uncertain.
lead_paragraph: PORTAGE, Ind. — I was working the night of the election — helping ship merchandise to convenience stores around Indiana — so I kept up on the news by texting a friend. “Should I worry?” I asked around 10 p.m. Not yet, he said. An hour later, the response had changed: “Pressing the worry button now.” I got off work at midnight, and listened to the radio as I drove home. It was by then Nov. 9, and the election was coming to an end. But it didn’t hit me until I saw my mom.

headline: A Foolish Power Grab in Congo
abstract: President Joseph Kabila’s move to stay in office beyond his term could lead to renewed war in his troubled country.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Kabila, the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, is the latest power-hungry leader to try to extend his rule beyond his elected term, which ends next month. His obstinacy is putting an already battered country at risk.

headline: Build He Won’t

abstract: Don’t fall for the Trump infrastructure scam.
lead_paragraph: Steve Bannon, Donald Trump’s chief strategist, is a white supremacist and purveyor of fake news. But the other day, in an interview with, um, The Hollywood Reporter, he sounded for a minute like a progressive economist. “I’m the guy pushing a trillion-dollar infrastructure plan,” he declared. “With negative interest rates throughout the world, it’s the greatest opportunity to rebuild everything.”

headline: Trump: Making America White Again
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Women and Girls', 'Minorities']
abstract: The president-elect aims for a country by and for white men.
lead_paragraph: This may well be the beginning of the end: the early moments of a historical pivot point, when the slide of the republic into something untoward and unrecognizable still feels like a small collection of poor judgments and reversible decisions, rather than the forward edge of an enormous menace inching its way forward and grinding up that which we held dear and foolishly thought, as lovers do, would ever endure.

headline: A Retreat From TPP Would Empower China
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: If Donald Trump walks away from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, China will be handed a chance to dominate the region more than ever before.
lead_paragraph: The limits of President Obama’s ability to reassure the world about America’s future role in the international sphere was apparent at the summit meeting of Asia-Pacific leaders in Lima, Peru, on Sunday. There is no way to ease the concerns of those leaders about America’s retreat from the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership trade pact, a casualty of anti-globalization fervor, American politics and, in particular, the objections of President-elect Donald Trump, who has called it a “disaster.”

headline: Finding Hope in the Flint Police Department
abstract: We are the only representatives of government that citizens feel they can hold to account.
lead_paragraph: Flint, Mich. — I joined the Flint, Mich., police force nearly 20 years ago because I believed I could make a difference. Police officers are problem solvers. But sometimes it seems as if the problems have no end. How can a city fall so far that we lose sight of the possibility of solutions?

headline: The Identity Politics of Whiteness
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Whites', 'English Language', 'Minorities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: White Americans are starting, once again, to see themselves as a distinct identity group — and to wield power as one.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, I read “Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” to my daughter. She smiled as she heard about Huck’s mischief, his jokes, his dress-up games, but it was his relationship with the runaway slave Jim that intrigued her most. Huck and Jim travel together as Jim seeks his freedom; at times, Huck wrestles with his decision to help. In the end, Tom Sawyer concocts an elaborate scheme for Jim’s release.

headline: Glenn Beck Is Sorry About All That
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The media personality on learning from his mistakes and why Donald Trump could be one of the most dangerous presidents to ever come into the Oval Office.
lead_paragraph: You’ve recently been talking a lot about wanting to warn liberals, based on your experience, now that Donald Trump is president-elect. I don’t imagine that many liberals listen to your show, but here you are on the back page of The New York Times Magazine. Here is your liberal audience. What do you want to say to them? Please be better than I was. Please learn from my mistakes. Let’s just take it from 2000: George W. Bush was called an idiot, among other things. It got so bad that Republicans and conservatives just stopped listening to the media, because we made everything about jingoism. And so what happened? The pendulum swung back so far the other way that the next guy who was elected president offered hope and change, but all a lot of people saw was that he, for a while, wasn’t wearing a flag pin. They stopped listening to people on the left. Now we’re here in crazy town. What we need now is for reasonable people to sit down with each other and say: O.K., your guy wasn’t the end of the world. My guy wasn’t the end of the world. How can we talk to each other?

headline: The Passion of Martin Scorsese
keywords: ['Movies', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Books and Literature', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: In his new film, “Silence,” he returns to a subject that has animated his entire life’s work and that also sparked his career’s greatest controversy: the nature of faith.
lead_paragraph: A man was on a train in Japan, reading a novel set in Japan. The train slid past the mountains, bound for Kyoto, where the man, bearded, bright-eyed, was headed. The year was 1989. The train was a bullet train.

headline: Reince Priebus, Normalizer in Chief
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: As Trump’s new chief of staff, the lifelong G.O.P. loyalist will have to guide an outsider president and his band of radicals through a city they’ve pledged to upend.
lead_paragraph: Ten days removed from the still-fresh shock of Donald Trump’s election, around lunchtime on a Friday, I navigated the jagged lines of steel barriers, police officers and Secret Service battalions with big dogs and big guns surrounding Trump Tower. The glass-and-marble shopping mall, tourist trap and TV set had been transformed into the unlikely plotting ground for the nation’s immediate future. It was anybody’s guess what was taking shape inside the gilded bunkers. Clots of media people, passers-by and protesters crowded the lobby and nearby streets for the occasional clue, or at least glimpses of Marla Maples and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan. Kellyanne Conway posed for a selfie with a few lucky cops.

headline: A List of Priorities From Trump, and Kris Kobach Tips His Hand
abstract: The stream of job candidates visiting the president-elect continued as transition officials began turning their focus to their economic and domestic policy teams.
lead_paragraph: With Thanksgiving approaching, the transition team is putting the last touches on President-elect Donald J. Trump’s national security leadership even as Mr. Trump pivots to his domestic and economic policy cabinet posts. One visitor to Trump Tower on Monday is of note: a Democrat, Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii. Another, Secretary of State Kris Kobach of Kansas, let the world see part of his plans for the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: Medical Marijuana Is Legal in California. Except When It’s Not.
keywords: ['Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Marijuana']
abstract: A Santa Rosa medical marijuana company says it came out into the open and tried to follow the rules — only to be raided by local and federal police officers.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ROSA, Calif. — California’s multibillion-dollar marijuana industry, by far the nation’s largest, is crawling out from the underbrush after voters opted to legalize cannabis in this month’s election. In Sonoma County alone, an estimated 9,000 marijuana cultivation businesses are operating in a provisional gray market, with few specific regulations, and are now looking to follow the path of the wine industry, which emerged from its own prohibition eight decades ago and rose to the global prominence it enjoys today.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For the last six years, Instagram has been a repository for users’ most picturesque moments. But 2016 has been a year of reinvention for the photo-sharing social network, which has broadened what it lets people do with their images.

headline: London’s New Design Destination
abstract: One museum reopens with a new look — and a free exhibition.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a busy year for London’s design world. Fall marked the city’s inaugural Design Biennale, and now the Design Museum is entering an ambitious era in its new home on Kensington High Street, on the edge of Holland Park. The interior of the former Commonwealth Institute building, reimagined by John Pawson, will triple the museum’s exhibition space. Despite the soaring, vast scope of the space (crowned with a dramatic paraboloid roof), Pawson aimed to create a welcoming environment. “I used lots of warm wood and made sure there were benches and seating areas to encourage people to stay for a while.”

headline: Special Diets Can Heighten Tensions at the Holiday Dinner Table

abstract: When a child who has decided to go vegan won’t eat just a sliver of Grandma’s famous pie, feelings can be hurt.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Yates has a 13-year-old who cannot eat nuts and an 18-year-old who will not eat gluten. When the family hops on a train on Thursday to visit relatives for Thanksgiving, Ms. Yates will be carrying nut-free chocolate, gluten-free banana bread and two containers of stuffing – a nut-free version and a gluten-free version.

lead_paragraph: Though Melissa Ferrer moved into her new home in July, she has refused to paint her sons’ bedroom walls blue. She does not dare get too comfortable, a symptom of her years of homelessness.

headline: 1916: A Series of German Defeats
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A report from the French front in November 1916 summarizes the situation during the Battle of the Somme, as the Germans are beaten back.
lead_paragraph: Following the official report issued yesterday of the military situation on the French front: November 13 to November 17: In the course of the past week the Germans made a powerful attempt to counteract our successes north and south of the Somme. The enemy’s attack opened the 15th, in the morning, on the Ablaincourt-Chaulnes Wood front, end in the afternoon was extended on the north bank from Lesboeufs to Bouchavesnes.

headline: New Feature of the College Tour: First-Class Campus Hotels
abstract: Universities like Oberlin have decided that campus guest quarters, instead of cheap and perfunctory, can promote the school’s brand.
lead_paragraph: Before Christian Bolles decided on Oberlin College in Ohio three years ago, he and his parents traveled to Oberlin from their home in San Francisco to visit the campus and the town.

headline: U.S. Dementia Rates Are Dropping Even as Population Ages
abstract: Despite fears that dementia rates were going to explode as the population grows older, a large study of Americans has found the opposite.
lead_paragraph: Despite fears that dementia rates were going to explode as the population grows older and fatter, and has more diabetes and high blood pressure, a large nationally representative survey has found the reverse. Dementia is actually on the wane. And when people do get dementia, they get it at older and older ages.

headline: Michael Sherwood, Goldman Sachs’s Co-Head of Europe, to Step Down
abstract: Mr. Sherwood, who had been with the Wall Street Firm since 1986, had been seen as a potential successor to Lloyd Blankfein, the bank’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Michael S. Sherwood, a Goldman Sachs vice chairman and co-head of its European division, will retire from the Wall Street firm at the end of the year.

headline: N.B.A. Schedule: Here’s What to Watch This Week
abstract: Luke Walton’s Lakers meet Steve Kerr’s Warriors in a home-and-home series this week.
lead_paragraph: Don’t look now, but it seems as if the enthusiasm for small ball may pall in the N.B.A. this fall.

headline: The AIDS Fight: Andrew Sullivan on a History of the Movement
abstract: David France’s remarkable “How to Survive a Plague” is the prose version of France’s Oscar-nominated documentary of the same name.
lead_paragraph: HOW TO SURVIVE A PLAGUEThe Inside Story of How Citizens and Science Tamed AIDSBy David FranceIllustrated. 640 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

headline: Which Supplements, if Any, May Be Worth Your Money
keywords: ['Vitamins', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: Solid scientific evidence on most vitamins, minerals and herbs is lacking.
lead_paragraph: Hardly a day goes by that people don’t tell me that one or more dietary supplement has cured or prevented an ailment of theirs or suggest that I try one to treat a problem of my own. And I am not immune to wishful thinking that an over-the-counter vitamin, mineral or herb may help to keep me healthy or relieve some distress without having to see a doctor.

headline: We Are Thanksgiving Adjacent
abstract: You’re going big elsewhere. It’s time to keep it simple.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: 6 Ways Pretend Investors Differ From the Real Ones
abstract: Like children, some adults seem convinced that they can pretend to be investors, but that can be dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember playing pretend when you were little? Maybe you were a superhero, a dinosaur or a princess. It’s normal when you’re little, and it’s usually harmless. Most children know the difference between pretending to be a superhero and jumping off the roof thinking they can fly.

headline: Into the Dead Zone: A Sports Writer Heads for Obits
abstract: After years on the Sports desk, the reporter Richard Sandomir heads for the Obits desk.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Eidelberg’s journalism class at John Bowne High School in Flushing, Queens, convened in September, 1972, our first assignment was to write an obituary about ourselves. We were all about 15 years old, without much life experience (I was months from my first paying job at a supermarket), so the task was to invent our futures.

headline: France Detains 7, Saying It Has Thwarted a New Terrorist Attack
abstract: After the arrests in Strasbourg and Marseille, investigators were looking into whether the plot involved a “coordinated attack” on multiple targets.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Seven men who French authorities say were planning a terrorist attack have been arrested in France, the government announced on Monday, sounding an alert about the continuing threat from terrorism barely a year after the attacks that killed 130 people in and around Paris.

headline: Kanye West Cancels the Rest of His ‘Saint Pablo’ Tour
abstract: At two concerts last week, Mr. West voiced support for President-elect Donald J. Trump; then, he canceled the rest of his shows.
lead_paragraph: After two bizarre concerts last week during which Kanye West came out in support of President-elect Donald J. Trump and ended a set early after a fiery but discursive 17-minute monologue, the rapper has canceled the rest of his tour dates for 2016.

headline: Diamond Jewelry With Everyday Appeal
abstract: The extravagant stone feels modern and wearable with an emerald cut and simple, linear settings.
lead_paragraph: The extravagant stone feels modern and wearable with an emerald cut and simple, linear settings.

headline: 16 Arrested at North Dakota Pipeline Protest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Native Americans', 'Pipelines', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The demonstration occurred a day after hundreds clashed with the police, who used water cannons against protesters.
lead_paragraph: Tensions continued in North Dakota on Monday afternoon as law enforcement officials arrested 16 people at a demonstration, one day after hundreds clashed with the police over the Dakota Access Pipeline.

headline: Brazil’s Surfers Lament Demise of Amazon’s Mighty Waves
abstract: People used to flock to the Araguari River to catch the Pororoca, which once brought waves over five feet high, but surfers last rode it in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The thundering waves of the Pororoca were legendary: Adventurers from the world over flew, drove, trekked, Jet-Skied and canoed to Brazil’s remote Araguari River to ride the Amazon’s stunning tidal bore that formed when water flowed in from the Atlantic.

headline: Italy’s Last Bastion of Catalan Language Struggles to Keep It Alive
abstract: The lingering use of Catalan in Alghero, Italy, is a reminder of how Mediterranean cultures have blended for centuries. But the language is fading there today.
lead_paragraph: ALGHERO, Italy — The first Catalans reached Sardinia in the 14th century, when troops sailed from the eastern coast of what is now Spain as part of an expansion into the Mediterranean.

headline: Making Movies With Windows 10
abstract: Microsoft’s Windows Movie Maker app is headed for retirement next year, but an updated version is promised and other programs may fill the void.
lead_paragraph: Q. Microsoft hasn’t updated Windows Movie Maker in years. I have it on my Windows 10 PC from when I upgraded the computer from Windows 8, but will there ever be a proper app version for Windows 10?

headline: William Trevor, Writer Who Evoked the Struggles of Ordinary Life, Is Dead at 88
abstract: Irish by birth and upbringing but a longtime resident of Britain, Mr. Trevor focused his mournful, darkly funny short stories and novels on “the sadness of fate.”
lead_paragraph: William Trevor, whose mournful, sometimes darkly funny short stories and novels about the small struggles of unremarkable people placed him in the company of masters like V. S. Pritchett, W. Somerset Maugham and Chekhov, died on Sunday in Somerset, England. He was 88.

headline: Jeff Koons Is Giving Sculpture to Paris to Remember Terror Victims
abstract: His sculpture “Bouquet of Tulips” will be permanently installed next year in the plaza in front of the Museum of Modern Art and the Palais de Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Inspired by the Statue of Liberty, the American contemporary artist Jeff Koons is donating a monumental sculpture of a fistful of tulips to the City of Paris and the people of France to commemorate victims of the recent terrorist attacks here.

headline: Daily Report: At Apple, U.S. Jobs That Go Beyond Manufacturing
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Apple makes one product domestically: the Mac Pro, in Austin, Tex. But in addition to the manufacturing jobs that it has created, Apple employs 6,000 at its own Austin campus.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump said during the campaign that he would push companies to bring manufacturing jobs back to the United States. He named one tech company in particular — Apple — which is the world’s largest public company and makes many of its gadgets overseas.

headline: ‘Hot and Unhappy in Unwise Shoes’: A William Trevor Sampler
abstract: Excerpts from three of his short stories.
lead_paragraph: “Each character is somebody that I know very well — as well as I know myself,” William Trevor once said. Here are excerpts from three of his short stories, originally published by the Bodley Head in Britain and Viking in the United States.

headline: #HereIsMyAmerica: Your Perspective
abstract: A collection of images from across our country that helps create a more nuanced portrait of the increasingly diverse American experience.
lead_paragraph: A collection of images from across our country that helps create a more nuanced portrait of the increasingly diverse American experience.

headline: Olympics History Rewritten: New Doping Tests Topple the Podium
abstract: Officials retesting urine samples have found scores of violations from the 2008 and 2012 Games, and medals are being stripped from dozens of athletes.
lead_paragraph: After disclosures of an extensive, state-run doping program in Russia, sports officials have been retesting urine samples from the 2008 and 2012 Summer Olympics, in Beijing and London. Their findings have resulted in a top-to-bottom rewriting of Olympics history.

headline: Cooking Up Conversation as Martha’s Vineyard Quiets Down
abstract: The women of the island’s Cookbook Club warm the off-season by sharing dishes and opinions.
lead_paragraph: WEST TISBURY, Mass. — The November meeting of the Martha’s Vineyard Cookbook Club offered saffron-infused gin cocktails, a table of food, a tray of something called “strong ginger cookies” — and a few strong opinions.

headline: Three Big American Banks Pose Greater Systemic Risk, Regulator Says
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Citigroup, Bank of America and Wells Fargo each moved up a notch in the annual risk rankings of banks deemed to be globally important.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Three of America’s biggest banks potentially pose a greater risk to the global financial system than they did last year if they were to fail, global regulators said on Monday.

headline: This Thanksgiving, Be Thankful for Science
abstract: We're not saying you can't talk about politics on Thanksgiving. But here are some conversation starters about science and medicine for your dinner table.
lead_paragraph: Look, we’re not saying you can’t talk about politics at the Thanksgiving dinner table. But it’s been quite a November so far, following a seemingly never-ending campaign, and the anxiety in the air is thicker than your mom’s gravy. Some people are sitting out Thanksgiving with their loved ones altogether. Others are preparing themselves for acts of civil disagreement.

headline: As Obama’s Tour Ends, He Says U.S. Involvement Abroad Must Not
abstract: In his final news conference on his last foreign trip as president, he argued for a foreign policy in which America continues to take on major global problems.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — President-elect Donald J. Trump, with his “America First” campaign slogan, sees an America that has for years been taken for granted by weaker nations and is too quick to intervene in intractable conflicts far away.

headline: Dinner and James Joyce in New Adaptation of ‘The Dead’
abstract: In this production, the audience will join the performers in eating a turn-of-the-century feast.
lead_paragraph: The centerpiece of “The Dead,” a novella by James Joyce, is a family dinner in 1904 to celebrate the Epiphany. At the Irish Repertory Theater’s staged adaptation, “The Dead, 1904,” presented with Dot Dot Productions, the audience joins in the meal. They mingle with the performers, including Kate Burton and Boyd Gaines, and are then seated for a multicourse feast during the performance. On the menu are beef tenderloin with fig sauce, honey-glazed ham, potatoes, bread pudding and drinks. It takes place at the American Irish Historical Society, a Victorian townhouse, and the meal is catered by Great Performances: “The Dead, 1904” by the Irish Repertory Theater, through Jan. 7 at  991 Fifth Avenue (East 80th Street); $300 including dinner, $500 for premium seating ($1,000 after Dec. 7), 212-727-2737, irishrep.org.

headline: A Tribe Called Quest’s Comeback Album Debuts at No. 1
abstract: The rap group’s first record in nearly two decades opens with 135,000 album-equivalent units.
lead_paragraph: A Tribe Called Quest’s comeback came at just the right time: Released the Friday after the election, the emotional and political “We Got It From Here … Thank You 4 Your Service” (Epic), the first album from the storied hip-hop group in nearly two decades, has topped the Billboard chart.

headline: Broths to Restore and Revive at Brodo
abstract: The latest outpost of Marco Canora’s bone broth chain offers flavor customization and frozen broths for home use.
lead_paragraph: No doubt about it, Marco Canora really started something when he opened his first Brodo takeout window at Hearth, his East Village restaurant. That was two years ago, and now bone broth, spruced up with the Brodo label, is everywhere. Mr. Canora has expanded with a kiosk in Bryant Park, and he’s just opened a shop in the West Village where some basic broths are mixed and sometimes frothed with freshly milled herbs, Asian condiments, bone marrow, seaweed, butter and even cocoa. There are 11 preset seasoning combinations, $6 to $11, though customers can devise their own. Tom Yum, a combo with chicken broth, coconut milk, curry and chile oil, is becoming a favorite. The shop also sells basic broths, frozen, for home use: Brodo, 496 Hudson Street (Christopher Street), 212-366-0600, brodo.com.

headline: Kickback Case Questions Whether Valeant Was Victim or Participant
abstract: The case appears to be a straightforward tale of avarice, but the Justice Department may have a difficult time proving the charges.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International is a onetime Wall Street darling that has become a punching bag for how pharmaceutical firms drove up drug prices and engaged in questionable sales practices, in the process losing 90 percent of its market value. The first case to emerge from multiple federal and state investigations of its conduct, however, portrays it as a victim, not a perpetrator.

headline: Pope Francis, Trump, Japan: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Explaining the Other Side of Autumn Leaves
abstract: As the leaves change color, one side gets the gloriously bright reds, yellows and oranges. The other? Not so much.
lead_paragraph: Q. As the autumn leaves change color, why is the top of a leaf the most colorful, sometimes bright red, while the underside is comparatively drab?

headline: Your Money Weekly: Solving the Mystery of the Stockbrokers
abstract: A look at stockbrokers with career black marks; claims payouts by auto insurers; and charges of discrimination in a senior community.
lead_paragraph: I love a good mystery, but it’s rare that we get to solve one in the world of personal finance.

headline: Cinematic Watering Holes
abstract: These bars are themed for sleeper hits and cult favorites.
lead_paragraph: These bars are themed for sleeper hits and cult favorites.

headline: These Bars Want to Be in the Movies
abstract: Décor and drinks that evoke films from “The Shining” to “Anchorman.”
lead_paragraph: The Overlook Lodge, a bar in the Pleasant Ridge neighborhood of Cincinnati, looks cozy enough at first, with wooden rafters and a fireplace big enough to sit inside.

headline: Travel Coloring Books for Grown-Ups
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Books and Literature', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Business Travel', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: Coloring books for grown-ups, with drawings inspired by travel and Champagne wishes, aim to capture the imaginations of tourists.
lead_paragraph: Forget coffee in the lobby and chocolates at turndown. Coloring books for grown-ups — where the illustrations are inspired by travel, fashion and Champagne wishes — are among the latest amenities being offered at hotels around the world.

headline: A Kit to Make Restaurant Pizza at Home
abstract: Laurent Tourondel’s Dough to Go kit will make one margherita pie in a home oven.
lead_paragraph: The chef Laurent Tourondel, who makes pizza in the wood-fueled ovens of L’Amico, is sharing the recipe with home cooks. With this kit you can nearly replicate the classic 12-inch pizza margherita from his Chelsea restaurant in a gas or electric oven. The dough is a breeze to handle, and =buffalo mozzarella, basil a tomato sauce with personality are included. Add a drizzle of good olive oil, chile flakes and whatever else you like on your pie with ingredients from your larder: Dough to Go, $14 for pickup only, L’Amico, 849 Avenue of the Americas (West 30th Street), 212-201-4065, lamico.nyc.

headline: Jurgen Klinsmann Fired as U.S. Soccer Coach
abstract: Mounting criticism and recent defeats in World Cup qualifying, including a 4-0 thrashing at Costa Rica last week, led U.S. Soccer to change course.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national men’s soccer team, dined with President Obama, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, a number of Nobel laureates and a couple of astronauts at a gala in Berlin. The sausages were “excellent,” he said.

headline: Breakfast, Lunch and Dessert in Jars
abstract: Ancolie serves breakfast fare, layered salads and desserts in returnable glass jars.
lead_paragraph: Food served in jars is not new, but Chloe Vichot, who fled finance for food and studied at culinary schools in New York along the way, has opened a shop dedicated exclusively to it. Ms. Vichot prepares and sells breakfast fare, bright lunch salads, soups, stews and desserts in glass jars, $5 to $14. Her specially made wide-mouth containers are more convenient than the usual Mason jars that some restaurants use to serve pâtés, desserts or even cocktails. The idea is to cut down on trash, and customers get a $1 discount for each jar they return (there is no jar deposit). The salads, in compact layers, are generous 22-ounce portions: Ancolie, 58 West Eighth Street (Avenue of the Americas), 646-524-5929, ancolie.co.

headline: Jeff Sessions’ Other Civil Rights Problem
abstract: How he fought to preserve Alabama’s long history of separate and unequal education.
lead_paragraph: In 1986, the Republican-dominated Senate Judiciary Committee torpedoed Ronald Reagan’s nomination of Jeff Sessions to the federal bench. As sworn testimony there revealed, Mr. Sessions, then the United States attorney for the Southern District of Alabama, had referred to the N.A.A.C.P. and the Southern Christian Leadership Conference (founded by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.) as “un-American” and “Communist inspired.” He had joked that he thought the Ku Klux Klan was “O.K.” until he discovered some of its members smoked pot, and had accused a white attorney who supported voting rights of being a race traitor.

headline: A New Magazine Focuses on Food Preservation
abstract: Cured features the writers Betty Fussell, Jessica B. Harris, William Woys Weaver and Fuchsia Dunlop.
lead_paragraph: Cured, a periodical about preserving food, is definitely a niche publication. An impressive roster of writers, including Betty Fussell, Jessica B. Harris, William Woys Weaver and Fuchsia Dunlop, covers a wealth of topics under the editorial direction of Darra Goldstein, an author and a founder of Gastronomica. Learn about a Swedish tradition of fermenting fish that dates back 9,000 years; making persimmon vinegar; the allure of stinky Chinese food; pickles in the Nishiki Market in Kyoto, Japan; and zur, a fermented Polish rye soup. As Ms. Goldstein put it, preserving is as important a development for humankind as cooking, a means of “hedging our bets against hunger.” The magazine is published by Zero Point Zero, the company that produces “The Mind of a Chef” and Anthony Bourdain’s “Parts Unknown”: Cured, $20 at some food shops, bookstores nationwide and from curedmagazine.com.

headline: Where Donald Trump Stands on School Choice, Student Debt and Common Core
keywords: ['Education', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Charter Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Student Loans', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Endowments']
abstract: The president-elect has sent mixed signals on education policy, but here is an overview of what schools and universities might expect from his administration.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to predicting how President-elect Donald J. Trump’s administration will affect America’s schools and universities, education experts say they are struggling to read the tea leaves.

headline: Fully Buzzed, This Coffee Helps Veterans
abstract: Bomb Coffee will donate a portion of its sales this month to help treat veterans with PTSD.
lead_paragraph: Detonate this new full-bodied coffee in your mug in the morning, and you’ll be fueled for the day. Bomb Coffee was founded by four friends, two of them veterans, and through the end of November, 22 percent of all sales will go to the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder and suicide prevention among veterans. The coffee, which they claim is high in caffeine, is grown in India and roasted in Rockford, Ill. The original is balanced, and the bourbon-infused variety has more complexity with a hint of booze: Bomb Coffee, whole bean or ground, $17.99 a pound or $19.99 a pound for bourbon-infused, $15.99 for 12 Keurig pods, bombcoffee.com.

headline: ‘We Shall Overcome’ Copyright Case Moves Closer to Trial
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Music']
abstract: A federal judge declined to dismiss the copyright claims in a lawsuit that challenges the validity of the song’s copyright.
lead_paragraph: “We Shall Overcome” may be headed for a trial.

headline: Four Women’s Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
abstract: A by-no-means exhaustive list of items we like.
lead_paragraph: These pendants from Catherine Weitzman caught my eye among the endless pieces of jewelry and clothing I see every day in market appointments. The flowers within them are collected during trips around the world in places like the Canary Islands, Sri Lanka and Japan. And at Weitzman’s studio in Hawaii, the dried blooms are then protected in glass, sealed with either gold vermeil or recycled silver, and strung onto necklace chains — all one of a kind. $100-$205, available at catherineweitzman.com — ANGELA KOH

headline: Watch This 2006 Documentary About Rudy Giuliani
abstract: The former mayor of New York remains in the running for a post in Donald Trump’s cabinet. This documentary on Amazon chronicles Giuliani’s controversial ascent.
lead_paragraph: For those who didn’t live in New York City under the two-term mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, you might know him only as one of the heroes of 9/11. The man who held together a shattered metropolis. America’s Mayor. After a long stint out of the spotlight, Giuliani was back in the public eye on the campaign trail for Donald J. Trump. And now he’s one of President-elect Trump’s many candidates for a cabinet position.

headline: Mercury Is Shrinking, a ‘Great Valley’ Shows
abstract: The canyon is about the size of Montana and twice as deep as the Grand Canyon, and the planet’s cooling may have led to its formation.
lead_paragraph: A colossal canyon on Mercury may provide evidence that the tiny planet is shrinking.

headline: New Victory for World War II PT Boat: Restored and Museum-Ready
keywords: ['Museums', 'Boats and Boating', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A painstaking effort is turning the vessel into an interactive exhibit at the National WWII Museum in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — There was one hairy moment during PT 305’s slow-motion jaunt through downtown here on Saturday morning.

headline: Review: Lyon Opera Ballet Showcases Beethoven and Female Choreographers
abstract: The ballet’s “Trois Grandes Fugues” offers pieces by Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, Maguy Marin and Lucinda Childs, with three renditions of Beethoven’s “Grosse Fuge.”
lead_paragraph: LYON, France — Three dances. Three major choreographers. Three renditions of Beethoven’s “Grosse Fuge.” That’s the simple yet audacious idea behind the Lyon Opera Ballet’s “Trois Grandes Fugues,” which offers two pieces, by Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker and Maguy Marin, already in its repertory, and a new work by the American choreographer Lucinda Childs.

headline: Bayer’s Essure Contraceptive Implant, Now With a Warning
keywords: ['Medical Devices', 'Women and Girls', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Implants']
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration has ordered a so-called black box warning on the package regarding the potentially painful side effects for women.
lead_paragraph: Kim Myers used to compete in rodeo-style barrel horse races, but after being sterilized with an implantable device called Essure, the pain was so intense that she had to stop.

headline: Market Reaction to Deal May Bode Ill for Energy Transfer Partners
abstract: Shares of Sunoco Logistics Partners and Energy Transfer Partners fell nearly 10 percent early Monday, before recovering some of their losses.
lead_paragraph: Energy Transfer investors are in another tangle. The pipeline partnership Sunoco Logistics Partners wants to buy Energy Transfer Partners for $21 billion, based on Friday’s closing prices. Energy Transfer Partners’ parent, Energy Transfer Equity, tied itself in knots trying to buy rival pipeline operator Williams Companies last year, before walking away on a technicality. The sour reaction to the latest deal suggests E.T.P. may also be headed for trouble.

headline: ‘Made in Sporting’: Lisbon Club’s Youth Academy Sets It Apart
abstract: The story of how Cristiano Ronaldo made it to Sporting Lisbon is a case study in how to recruit and develop players.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — The way they tell the story at Sporting Lisbon, they did not even have to watch Cristiano Ronaldo play to know he was special. Seeing him with a ball at his feet, the quiet, skinny 12-year-old’s every effortless touch proof of his masterly control, was enough.

headline: Truman Capote’s Black and White Ball
abstract: Scenes from the iconic party of the 1960s, held at the Plaza hotel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the iconic party of the 1960s, held at the Plaza hotel.

headline: 50 Years Ago, Truman Capote Hosted the Best Party Ever
abstract: The guests wore black tie and couture dresses. But with its unlikely mix of attendees, the Black and White Ball helped to break down the old order.
lead_paragraph: What if you gave a party and everybody came? That is precisely what occurred on the drizzly night of Nov. 28, 1966, when 540 of Truman Capote’s nearest and dearest turned out for what the writer insisted on calling his “little masked ball for Kay Graham and all of my friends.”

headline: Earthquake Off Fukushima, Japan, Triggers Tsunami
abstract: Fears of a nuclear accident were raised as a cooling system in a reactor near the site of the 2011 disaster shut down, but it was restored without incident.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A powerful earthquake triggered a tsunami off the coast of Japan early Tuesday, near where three nuclear reactors melted down at a plant in Fukushima after a quake and tsunami in 2011.

headline: Jason Moran, From the Venice Biennale to the Village Vanguard
abstract: The portfolio of this pianist and composer has expanded to include collaborations with visual artists, choreographers and filmmakers.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, when Jason Moran released “Artist in Residence,” it might have been possible to see that album as an outlier. Made up of selections from several large commissioned works — with a percussive cameo by the performance artist Joan Jonas, and a spoken-word sample of the conceptual artist Adrian Piper — it framed Mr. Moran as not only a pianist and composer but also a fluent traveler in the realm of contemporary art.

headline: What You Should Watch Monday Night
abstract: Tonight is the premiere of a quirky new mystery series from TBS.
lead_paragraph: ‘Search Party,’ 11 p.m., TBS (New Series)

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Music, Movies and More
abstract: From “Pioneers of African-American Cinema” and “Freaks and Geeks” to the sounds of Kris Kristofferson and assorted Bad Boy artists, these gift ideas may enlighten, invigorate or simply stir up nostalgic memories.
lead_paragraph: From “Pioneers of African-American Cinema” and “Freaks and Geeks” to the sounds of Kris Kristofferson and assorted Bad Boy artists, these gift ideas may enlighten, invigorate or simply stir up nostalgic memories.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Technology
abstract: It is often daunting to sort through the newest technology products to find something fitting for your gadget-savvy family and friends. Fret not: Here are some of the most useful and entertaining tech gifts of the year.
lead_paragraph: It is often daunting to sort through the newest technology products to find something fitting for your gadget-savvy family and friends. Fret not: Here are some of the most useful and entertaining tech gifts of the year.
