abstract: Delightful presents big and small from the editors of T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Delightful presents big and small from the editors of T Magazine.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Wirecutter
abstract: We put in thousands of hours researching and testing products each year so we can make our readers' lives easier. Here we've collected a few of our favorites to make your gift giving just as simple, whether the people you love appreciate the practical or the whimisical.
lead_paragraph: We put in thousands of hours researching and testing products each year so we can make our readers' lives easier. Here we've collected a few of our favorites to make your gift giving just as simple, whether the people you love appreciate the practical or the whimisical.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Style
abstract: Buying gifts for your most stylish friends is harder than trying to get your teenage sister a Kylie Jenner lipkit. We got you, though. Here is a selection of items that will satisfy the women who has (nearly) everything and the man who is up on the latest trends.
lead_paragraph: Buying gifts for your most stylish friends is harder than trying to get your teenage sister a Kylie Jenner lipkit. We got you, though. Here is a selection of items that will satisfy the women who has (nearly) everything and the man who is up on the latest trends.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Kids
abstract: A retro sled, a cozy hat, a build-it-yourself Bluetooth speaker — these are just a few of the fun, creative gifts we picked out for your little ones this holiday season. A selection of toys for children up to 12 years old.
lead_paragraph: A retro sled, a cozy hat, a build-it-yourself Bluetooth speaker — these are just a few of the fun, creative gifts we picked out for your little ones this holiday season. A selection of toys for children up to 12 years old.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Home
abstract: Gifts for the home are especially fitting during the holidays, as many of us open our doors to welcome family and friends. The following 15 new products go beyond the ordinary to offer equal parts functionality and delight — and, hopefully, a little extra joy throughout the year.
lead_paragraph: Gifts for the home are especially fitting during the holidays, as many of us open our doors to welcome family and friends. The following 15 new products go beyond the ordinary to offer equal parts functionality and delight — and, hopefully, a little extra joy throughout the year.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Food and Cooking
abstract: Food and the holidays go hand in hand, with everyone spending time happily eating or cooking or both. These gifts — from a sous-vide cooker for the tech-savvy gourmand to an adorable radish baby rattle for the teething future chef — celebrate those delights.
lead_paragraph: Food and the holidays go hand in hand, with everyone spending time happily eating or cooking or both. These gifts — from a sous-vide cooker for the tech-savvy gourmand to an adorable radish baby rattle for the teething future chef — celebrate those delights.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Travel
abstract: From a portable tea set to a sketchpad that saves your in-flight doodles, these gifts are guaranteed to become indispensable for your jet-setter friends.

headline: Find the Whale and the Bathroom With the Natural History Museum App
abstract: This free app, Explorer, offers facts, videos and teaching tools for some 70 of the most compelling items on display.
lead_paragraph: We’ve never camped out on its floors, as some people do, but my family has long had a fascination with the American Museum of Natural History. When I was 8 and 9 years old, I lived 21 blocks north of the fortresslike structure on Central Park West in Manhattan. And in those days, when not everyone had a television set, it became a delightful source of entertainment and what passed at that tender age for enlightenment.

headline: Exxon Mobil Accuses the Rockefellers of a Climate Conspiracy
abstract: The company, accused of scheming to deny the threat of climate change, has directed its fiercest return fire against the descendants of the company’s founder.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil, under fire over its past efforts to undercut climate science, is accusing the Rockefeller family of masterminding a conspiracy against it. Yes, that Rockefeller family.

headline: 2016 Holiday Gift Guide - Books
abstract: Books can transport us to exotic lands or ground us in sobering truths. Here, we have art catalogs, nonfiction books and novels, one of which might just be the right fit for someone on your list.

abstract: In a new version of William Burke’s play, at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn, Elmo hates the Naked Cowboy, and the Cookie Monster has a box cutter.
lead_paragraph: The young woman onstage is nervously glancing at the hulking Cookie Monster, who is standing way too close. He silently reveals a box cutter. The blade comes out: Click, click, click. He makes a stabbing motion. She lets out a profanity under her breath.

headline: Review: ‘Absolutely on Music’ Gives a Maestro a Stage for Ideas
abstract: The conductor Seiji Ozawa and Haruki Murakami had conversations between November 2010 and July 2011, generally while listening to recordings.
lead_paragraph: “If there’s anything good about a major illness,” the Japanese conductor Seiji Ozawa writes in an afterword to the oddly titled “Absolutely on Music,” “it’s that it gives you more time than you know what to do with.” He is referring to physical ailments that have plagued him since 2010, when he underwent surgery for esophageal cancer.

headline: Slain San Antonio Detective Was Targeted, Police Chief Says
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Benjamin Marconi was apparently killed just for being on the force, the chief said. He was one of four officers shot nationwide over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: A San Antonio police detective who was shot to death while sitting in a squad car was apparently killed just for being on the force, the city’s police chief said on Monday, a day after the detective and three officers were shot in separate episodes around the country.

headline: New York Seeks to Jump-Start College Savings by Giving Cash to Kindergartners’ Parents
abstract: A pilot program focused on low-income families will give 3,500 children a year an initial $100 to be deposited into a college savings account.
lead_paragraph: Starting next fall, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio will create college savings accounts for thousands of New York City kindergartners, in a three-year pilot program intended to increase the number of low-income children who go on to attend college.

headline: Trump Foundation Won’t Pay Any of $25 Million University Settlement

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s charitable foundation will not be paying any of the $25 million settlement to resolve a series of lawsuits concerning Trump University, the president-elect’s defunct for-profit education venture that drew customer complaints about price gouging.

headline: Judges Find Wisconsin Redistricting Unfairly Favored Republicans
abstract: A federal panel called the 2011 redrawing of Wisconsin Assembly districts an unconstitutional gerrymander, ruling in a case that could go to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: A panel of three federal judges said on Monday that the Wisconsin Legislature’s 2011 redrawing of State Assembly districts to favor Republicans was an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander, the first such ruling in three decades of pitched legal battles over the issue.

headline: Telling Mosquitoes Apart With a Cellphone

abstract: Calling their project “Shazam for Mosquitoes,” Stanford students showed that common mobile phones could distinguish the hums of beating wings, which could prove useful in fighting diseases.
lead_paragraph: Simple cellphones can tell one type of mosquito from another by their hums, which may be useful in fighting mosquito-borne diseases, according to new research from Stanford University.

Trump on Monday released a two-and-a-half-minute infomercial-style video, turning to social media to deliver a direct-to-camera message in which he vowed to create jobs, renegotiate trade agreements, end restrictions on energy production and impose bans on lobbying.

headline: ‘A Rude Shock’: Indians Describe Life After Narendra Modi’s Currency Ban
abstract: We asked Indians to tell us how Mr. Modi’s surprising move, intended to crack down on corruption and tax avoidance, affected them and their families.

abstract: If Americans hate the direction their next president takes, they have the right to demonstrate peacefully. Here’s how protesting has succeeded.
lead_paragraph: Poland has one of the strictest abortion laws in Europe. Recently, a government-backed bill sought to go further, punishing women who had abortions with up to five years in prison. Last month, Polish women responded with a one-day strike. On Oct. 3, tens of thousands of people, most of them women dressed in black, protested in major cities.

headline: Brooklyn Man Arrested, Accused of Supporting Islamic State

lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man who tried to join the Islamic State and later told an informer that the group wanted to stage an attack in Times Square similar to the one that killed 86 people in Nice, France, last summer was arrested in New York on Monday, the authorities said.

lead_paragraph: Faced with a Republican president-elect willing to draw hard lines on immigration, policing and funding for social programs, Mayor Bill de Blasio in a formal address on Monday drew some of his own, presenting New York City as a national model of resistance and “a better way.”

Trump met with the British politician Nigel Farage in recent days, he encouraged Mr. Farage and his entourage to oppose the kind of offshore wind farms that Mr. Trump believes will mar the pristine view from one of his two Scottish golf courses, according to one person present.

abstract: The envoy, Staffan de Mistura, said he feared that eastern Aleppo could be obliterated before Donald J. Trump is even inaugurated.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Nations special envoy to Syria offered unsolicited advice on Monday to President-elect Donald J. Trump: Pay attention to what happens between now and January in Syria, particularly in Aleppo, the storied city at risk of obliteration by Russian-backed Syrian forces.

headline: Brooklyn Woman Is Found Guilty of Cruelty to 100 Rabbits
abstract: Dorota Trec, who was acquitted of 25 cruelty counts, faces fines and a maximum of two years in jail. The 90 rabbits she has amassed since the others were seized will also be confiscated.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn woman charged with abusing the residents of her sprawling rabbit colony was convicted on Monday of 100 counts of animal cruelty — one for each rabbit the jury found to have suffered under her care.

headline: Myanmar’s War on the Rohingya
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: To preserve her reputation as a human rights champion, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi needs to allow an impartial investigation into the violence.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar has long persecuted the country’s Rohingya Muslim minority, denying it basic rights to citizenship, to marry, to worship and to an education. After violence unleashed in 2012 by Buddhist extremists drove tens of thousands of Rohingya out of their homes, many risked their lives to escape in smugglers’ boats; more than 100,000 others are living in squalid internment camps. Now, a counterinsurgency operation by Myanmar’s military is again forcing thousands of Rohingya to abandon their villages.

headline: Stars to Remember, Even if First Time on Hall of Fame Ballot Is Their Last

headline: Moving Jewelry Sales Online in India
abstract: Indian women still love traditional jewelry for special occasions but the website Melorra wants to provide their daytime jewelry needs.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — When Sushma Sonty wanted to buy herself some jewelry for her birthday, she didn’t head to a traditional jeweler, as is the custom in India, or even to a local store. Instead, she turned to Melorra, a new website that marries Western fast-fashion trends with wearable fine jewelry.

headline: Boghossian Keeps Jewelry in the Family
abstract: Generations of gem dealing has produced a high jewelry company that focuses on novel materials and dazzling technique.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — From their small, unmarked headquarters, the Boghossian family looks out over the Rhône River, directly facing the globally recognized jewelers of Geneva and their logo-emblazoned waterfront towers. The competition, though colossal, seems to mean little to them and their young high-jewelry brand.

headline: Review: ‘This Day Forward,’ a Weird Wedding Night and What Comes After
abstract: At the Vineyard Theater, Nicky Silver shows a pair of newlyweds, their damaged gay son almost a half-century later and growing empathy for mothers.
lead_paragraph: Nicky Silver is driving with the brakes on in “This Day Forward,” his bumpy and tentative new comedy, which opened on Monday night at the Vineyard Theater. Usually, for better or worse, this mordant playwright can be relied on to go tearing through the barricades of good taste, good manners and sane plotting into his own ecstatic no man’s land of misery.

headline: But So Delicious
abstract: Andrew Zhou gets to the meat of the matter.

headline: Lack of Protocol Added to Chaos During J.F.K. Scare, Inquiry Finds
abstract: A task force that reviewed false reports of shots being fired at the airport in August said poor communication and blurred lines of authority contributed to a wave of panic.
lead_paragraph: A joint New York State and federal investigation into how false reports of gunfire at Kennedy International Airport in August led to mass panic found security protocols seriously lacking, with poor coordination between agencies and widely divergent levels of training for security personnel exacerbating the chaos.

headline: A Jolt of Blue-Collar Hope
abstract: How to create better working-class jobs and fight the Great American Stagnation.

headline: Fellow Trump Critics, Maybe Try a Little Listening
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Let’s take a break and see what’s going on.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been thinking a lot about the best imaginable Trump voter. This is the Trump supporter who wasn’t motivated by racism or bigotry. This is the one who cringed every time Donald Trump did something cruel, vulgar or misogynistic.

headline: Not Your Grandmother’s Wisconsin
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'News and News Media']
abstract: How my home state became Trump country.
lead_paragraph: Milwaukee — I love telling people I’m from Wisconsin. Maybe it’s my defense mechanism for when people accuse me of being a coastal elite, out of touch with Real America. I like fulfilling all the Wisconsin stereotypes. I love cheese and cheese curds, of course. I love our sports teams out of a vague sense of homerism. And my accent (all hard A’s) comes out in full force after ah coupl’ah beers.

headline: Don’t Retreat Into Fortress America
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Farsighted leaders put America in a position to lead the world for decades. Will Donald Trump cede that responsibility to Moscow, Beijing or Tehran?
lead_paragraph: Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson’s memoir, “Present at the Creation,” is a classic account of how a durable and productive Atlantic alliance, based on common values and a cleareyed judgment of America’s strategic interests, rebuilt Europe after World War II and produced international institutions responsible for the security and expanding economic opportunities that have been of such benefit to the United States.

lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans are justifiably frightened by the tide of racism, anti-Semitism and xenophobia that has swept the country since the election of Donald Trump, whose campaign stoked these views and who named Stephen Bannon of Breitbart News his chief strategist in the White House.

headline: Daimler Executive Is Removed After Accusations of Insulting Chinese
abstract: Chinese news reports said the German head of a truck and bus division used bigoted language and pepper spray in a parking dispute, setting off a furor on social media.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A single spark can start a prairie fire, Mao Zedong said. And being accused of a bigoted outburst can start a wildfire on the internet in China, as a manager for Daimler, the German automaker, has learned to his regret.

headline: Rarely Seen Photos by Jack London
abstract: A new book features the photography of Jack London, along with his words, chronicling poverty in London and the aftermath of the San Francisco earthquake.
lead_paragraph: One hundred years ago today, Jack London died in Sonoma County, Calif., at the age of 40. He was famous for novels, like the “The Call of the Wild,” which were based on his adventures, trekking through the Klondike or sailing the South Pacific. He was the archetype of the macho writer — before Ernest Hemingway — having been, among other things, a Socialist, a hobo, a sailor, a war correspondent and an oyster pirate.

headline: A New Look at Civilian Life in Europe Under Hitler
abstract: In “An Iron Wind,” Peter Fritzsche wants us to see how even apparently peaceful moments during World War II were inflected by war raging elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: AN IRON WINDEurope Under HitlerBy Peter Fritzsche356 pp. Basic Books. $29.99.

headline: Should Parents Be Expected to Donate to a Public School?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether parents must contribute to a public school’s fundraising program and whether to call out a nephew for his multiple marriages.
lead_paragraph: Our granddaughter is in kindergarten at a highly ranked elementary school: Test scores average in the top 1 percent of the schools in the state. Only 1.2 percent of the students are on a free or low-cost lunch. A sheet is passed out to parents of all students in the school from the parents’ organization at the beginning of the school year. Last year they pressured parents to donate $600 per year per student enrolled. This year the amount has been raised to $1,000. The parents’ organization keeps the books and clearly knows which parents have paid in full and which have not.

headline: Is Social Media Disconnecting Us From the Big Picture?
abstract: We’ve heard about its power to help us empathize with others. But what if, instead, it’s just cocooning us with our friends?
lead_paragraph: Maybe I shouldn’t have been surprised that Donald Trump could be elected president, but I was. I live in Brooklyn and work in Manhattan, two of the most liberal places in the country. But even online, I wasn’t seeing many signs of support for him. How did that blindness occur? Social media is my portal into the rest of the world — my periscope into the communities next to my community, into how the rest of the world thinks and feels. And it completely failed me.

headline: Amaro for Everyone
abstract: It’s difficult to define but easy to enjoy.
lead_paragraph: Don’t be bitter, we’re told. But in American cocktail culture — especially its most rarefied, la-di-da precincts — bitterness has become a signifier of sophistication and discernment. A decade ago, bar patrons who wished to make it clear that they weren’t into the sweet stuff might have requested something on the dry side or the sour side. Now they’re as likely to want it bitter.

headline: Steven Johnson on How Play Shaped the World
abstract: Steven Johnson’s “Wonderland” looks at the few degrees of separation between fun and progress.
lead_paragraph: WONDERLANDHow Play Made the Modern WorldBy Steven Johnson322 pp. Riverhead Books. $30.

headline: Billionaires vs. the Press in the Era of Trump
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Libel and Slander', 'News and News Media', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: A small group of superrich Americans — the president-elect among them — has laid the groundwork for an unprecedented legal assault on the media. Can they succeed?
lead_paragraph: In 2005, Tim O’Brien, then a financial reporter at The New York Times, published the book “TrumpNation: The Art of Being the Donald.” O'Brien talked to sources with an up-close view of Donald J. Trump’s finances, who concluded that the real-estate developer’s net worth was $150 million to $250 million, rather than the $2 billion to $5 billion Trump had variously claimed. Trump, who had courted O’Brien by taking him for rides in his Ferrari and private jet, sued O’Brien for libel in New Jersey in 2006. Trump called O’Brien a “wack job” on the “Today” show — while, O’Brien says, continuing to curry favor with him privately. O’Brien’s publisher, Warner Books, was also named in the suit and hired top lawyers who put Trump through an unsparing two-day deposition. Asked about his finances, Trump was caught lying or exaggerating 30 times. “He thought he’d get a friendly judge, and we would roll over,” says O’Brien, who is now the executive editor of Bloomberg View. “We didn’t.” The case went through four judges and was dismissed in 2009.

headline: The Message of Thomas Friedman’s New Book: It’s Going to Be O.K.
abstract: Thomas Friedman’s new book, “Thank You for Being Late,” gives you a much better idea of the forces that are upending your world.

headline: How Conservative Sites Turn Celebrity Despair on Its Head
abstract: Conservative news outlets are busy cataloging the reactions of aggrieved celebrities who are inadvertently energizing the opposition.
lead_paragraph: Throughout this bitter election campaign, liberal celebrities like Lady Gaga, Jennifer Lawrence, Lena Dunham and Lin-Manuel Miranda used their powerful media platforms to sing Hillary Clinton’s praises. Now they’ve invited their online followers to join them in processing her loss and protesting the impending administration of Donald J. Trump.

lead_paragraph: As a ferocious, record-breaking blizzard pummeled our windows, ushering in yet another month of Moscow’s winter, we began a sudden, frantic search for a sunny refuge, someplace to both defrost on the beach and absorb a little culture over the course of four days.

lead_paragraph: If you are looking to reclaim a coherent sense of America after this nervous breakdown of an election season, let me suggest that eating your way through Philadelphia is a fine way to start.

headline: For Deaf Tennis Player, Sound Is No Barrier

His name was Lee Duck-hee, and he had first caught the coach’s eye when he was in elementary school.

headline: Zika Looms in Asia, Tempered by a Fuller View of Its Dangers
abstract: The Zika scare in Latin America has prompted a recent surge in awareness and monitoring of the virus in Asia.
lead_paragraph: The Zika virus caught the world’s attention last year after experts noticed that a small percentage of women carrying the virus in Latin America were giving birth to children with microcephaly, a defect that causes malformed heads and severely stunts brain development. The virus is now endemic there, and scientists fear that caseloads may spike again during the hot, wet months of the Southern Hemisphere’s summer, which begins in December.

headline: Jogging the Brain
abstract: There may be a way to counter what alcohol does to your neurons: Go for a run.
lead_paragraph: The holiday season is a good time for a reminder that alcohol can do bad things to the brain. Studies on animals suggest that it reduces the number of neurons in the hippocampus, the brain’s memory center, and weakens mitochondria there. Because mitochondria help produce energy within cells, their impairment can damage or kill brain cells. But two new animal studies offer some succor: Aerobic exercise, it turns out, may meliorate some of the impacts of heavy drinking on the brain.

headline: Art for East Germany’s Secret Police Is for Sale in Miami
keywords: ['Stained Glass', 'Cold War Era', 'Art', 'Art Basel Miami Beach']
abstract: A stained glass screen created for the headquarters of the Stasi has an asking price of $21.4 million.
lead_paragraph: An art historian in Germany has unearthed a three-ton, 65-foot-wide stained glass mural that was created in the early 1980s for the headquarters of the East German secret police, or Stasi, and had been forgotten in a shipping container for 24 years. It will go on sale at a temporary exhibition space in Miami to coincide with the Art Basel Miami Beach contemporary art fair next week, with a price tag of $21.4 million — which some historians said was out of line with its value.

headline: Mexico Doesn’t Have to Appease Trump. It Can Fight Back.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The Mexican government has no reason to cooperate with a hostile administration in Washington.
lead_paragraph: This year, for the first time since Ronald Reagan assailed the Soviet Union in 1980, an American presidential candidate actively campaigned against another country’s national interests. By threatening to deport all undocumented immigrants, about half of whom are Mexican; to build a wall on the Mexican border; and to rip up the North American Free Trade Agreement, which is far more important for Mexico than for the United States, Donald J. Trump made Mexico one of the central issues of the campaign.

headline: The States That College Graduates Are Most Likely to Leave
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Urban Areas', 'States (US)', 'Youth', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Educated younger people in the less densely populated parts of the nation tend to move to the big coastal cities, because that’s where the jobs are.
lead_paragraph: This year’s election has forced Americans to take notice of class divisions between workers. And while these divisions may at first ring of lazy stereotypes — the rural Rust Belt worker without a college degree and the coastal urban college-educated worker — they’re rooted in a real dynamic. Many of the most skilled workers — young people with college degrees — are leaving struggling regions of America for cities, specifically for cities in Southern and coastal states.

headline: A 150-Year-Old British Footwear Factory, Through the Lens of Martin Parr
abstract: To celebrate a century and a half in business, the suddenly-cool-again heritage brand Grenson enlisted the famously unsparing photographer to capture its essence.
lead_paragraph: Long the preserve of fusty country gents, the venerable British footwear brand Grenson has enjoyed a renaissance in the hands of the designer Tim Little; its sturdy handmade shoes and boots are now prized by footwear fetishists from Hackney to Tokyo. This year, the label is celebrating its 150th birthday — in understated British fashion. It has re-editioned eight styles from the last century, including an awkward-looking orthopedic Oxford from the 1930s named the “Grenson Joy Step” and a 1940s infantryman’s boot.

headline: The Great Big World of a Minimalist Lighting Designer
abstract: Michael Anastassiades shares personal images — and his passions and inspirations — with T.
lead_paragraph: Michael Anastassiades’s lighting and furniture are the very picture of minimalism, but the designer dislikes the limited nature of the word. “I like to start broadly with my research and take information away,” says the London-based Cypriot. “It’s a distillation process.” His uncompromising aesthetic — a blend of clever functionality and spare organic beauty — has earned the 49-year-old a loyal following. His Calder-inspired mobiles and spheres are sold in such design meccas as the Future Perfect and Ralph Pucci, and he has collaborated with FlOS and the Parisian fashion boutique Colette.

Trump said on Tuesday that he had no intention of pressing for an investigation into Hillary Clinton’s use of a private email server or the financial operations of her family’s foundation, dropping the “lock her up” pledge that became a rallying cry for his campaign for the White House.

headline: Land Mine Casualties Jump 75% as Funding for Their Removal Declines
abstract: An annual report on the treaty banning land mines showed that casualties hit 6,461 last year, a sharp rise from 2014 and the highest level in a decade.
lead_paragraph: Despite a global treaty that bans land mines, casualties from those weapons and other unexploded munitions lurking in current and past war zones rose sharply last year to the highest point in a decade, a monitoring group said Tuesday in its annual report.

headline: What Will Trump Trade Policy Actually Look Like? Three Possibilities
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Customs (Tariff)']
abstract: It’s possible that there will be only minimal disruptions to world economies, and better deals for American companies. Or not.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, through decades in public life, has been consistent on one core policy idea: that the United States has gotten a raw deal from its major trading partners in the agreements that bind their economies. Renegotiating those terms will surely be a top priority for his administration.

headline: Your Phone Carries Chemical Clues About You, but There Are Limits to Using Them
abstract: Researchers could make inferences about people from the chemicals they left on their phones, but there could be problems with using them in criminal investigations and court cases.
lead_paragraph: Your phone is pretty much a high-tech bucket of germs. Thousands of microscopic bugs crawl around on its surface. Remnants of dirty, old skin cells smudge its cover. Tiny hairs stick inside its buttons. And your hands have smeared hundreds of chemicals across its surface. The foundation on your face, the antidepressants you take, the shampoo in your shower and even the hard-core mosquito repellent you applied down in Panama four months ago: All of these things leave traces on your hands and phone. That’s why scientists say they can use your phone to learn a lot about your lifestyle.

headline: In Turnaround, Raiders Close In on Winning Season, Maybe More
abstract: Defying expectations, Oakland is 8-2 after beating the Texans on Monday night in Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: Oakland Raiders fans got a dose of hope last season when, under a dynamic new coach, Jack Del Rio, their long-moribund team finished at 7-9, a sharp improvement after 4-12, 4-12 and 3-13 seasons. Still, it was their 13th straight year without a trip to the N.F.L. playoffs.

headline: David Hockney to Design Stained-Glass Window for Queen Elizabeth

headline: At a School of Immigrants, Challenges Reach Far Beyond the Classroom
abstract: At Public School 160, a South Brooklyn school where most of the students come from poor, immigrant families, life marched on, despite anxiety over the election of Donald J. Trump as president.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes during assemblies at Public School 160, in South Brooklyn, the principal, Margaret Russo, will ask, “Who was born in another country?” Many hands will go up.

headline: How to Upgrade Your Thanksgiving Road Trip
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Automobiles', 'Families and Family Life', 'Road Trips', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: From a plug-in espresso machine to an organizer for toys and gadgets, accessories to make your trip go smoother.
lead_paragraph: While talk of Thanksgiving travel often centers around the cost and tribulations of flying, during the holiday weekend more Americans actually hit the road.  AAA estimated that nearly 90 percent of Thanksgiving travelers will go by automobile this year, with about 48.7 million people driving 50 miles or more from home. That’s up nearly 2 percent over 2015, and the most Thanksgiving travelers since 2007. So why not make the journey more enjoyable? After all, you could spend hours sitting in traffic. Or maybe dinner at your cousin’s house wasn’t as tasty, er, filling, as you had hoped. Everyone knows to bring along the usual accessories, like phone chargers and tablet mounts. But certain extras can help shift a ho-hum road trip into the next gear. Below, a guide.

headline: 1916: Emperor Francis Joseph of Austria Is Dead
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: After a long illness, the Central European ruler dies in the Schönbrunn Palace in Vienna in November 1916.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, Switzerland — A special edition of the “Weiner Zeitung,” says a Vienna dispatch, states that Emperor Francis Joseph died at nine o’clock this evening in Schönbrunn Palace.

headline: Stepping Out on Faith, a Blind Man Counts His Blessings

headline: James Corden to Host 2017 Grammys
abstract: Mr. Corden, well known for hi “Carpool Karaoke,” hosted the Tonys this year and takes over from LL Cool J, who was the Grammys host for five years.
lead_paragraph: James Corden’s stock continues to rise at CBS. This late-night host has been tapped to host the Grammy Awards in February, the network and the Recording Academy announced Tuesday.

headline: Chinese Museum Mounts an Anselm Kiefer Show, Over the Artist’s Objections
abstract: The artist said organizers did not obtain his consent for the exhibition, which draws on works held by private collectors.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One of China’s top art academies is facing criticism for moving ahead with a major exhibition of work by Anselm Kiefer, even after the blue-chip German artist expressly disavowed the show, which he said was organized without his consent.

headline: Here’s Why You Should Call, Not Email, Your Legislators
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Activists and lawmakers say a phone call can have more weight and be harder to ignore than an email or social media post.
lead_paragraph: Kara Waite, an English teacher at Bunker Hill Community College in Charlestown, Mass., made a rule for herself: For every political rant she posts on Facebook, she must pick up the phone and call a legislator.

headline: Anti-Clinton Fake News Casts Pizzeria as Front for Crime
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A Washington pizzeria has been the victim of a barrage of false articles on social media and fake news sites saying their pizzeria was a front for a child trafficking ring led by Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of fake news online has roiled the American presidential election, politicians around the world and internet companies including Facebook and Google.

headline: Fabled London Nightclub Fabric Will Reopen
abstract: The venue was shuttered in September after the deaths of two teenage clubgoers; its closure was lamented as a blow to the city’s night life.
lead_paragraph: London — The party isn’t over, after all.

headline: Art for the Holidays: A New York Visitors’ Guide
abstract: You want art? We have some.
lead_paragraph: More than five million people are expected to travel to New York City in the next 40 days. If you’re one of them, you might want to see some art.

headline: Feast in New York City
abstract: A restaurant chef knows how to squeeze a personal gathering into the precious off-hours — and how to nourish family and friends.
lead_paragraph: A restaurant chef knows how to squeeze a personal gathering into the precious off-hours — and how to nourish family and friends.

headline: Are Domestic Responsibilities at Odds With Becoming a Great Artist?
abstract: Siddhartha Deb and Dana Stevens discuss whether family life restricts the ability to do creative work.
lead_paragraph: In Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Siddhartha Deb and Dana Stevens discuss whether family life restricts the ability to do creative work.

headline: Exercise Program After Knee Replacement Need Not Be Intensive
abstract: A carefully structured exercise program after knee replacement offers no advantages over less intensive care, a randomized clinical trial has found.
lead_paragraph: A carefully structured exercise program after knee replacement offers no advantages over less intensive care, a randomized clinical trial has found.

headline: Donald Trump at The New York Times: Live on Twitter
abstract: The president-elect is meeting today with journalists and editorial columnists. Here are their tweets about the on-the-record interview.

headline: Olympic Swimmers, Past and Present, United by Views on Doping
abstract: American Olympians victimized by cheaters over the years bond at an award ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Hours after the news broke on Monday of more failed drug tests by medal-winning athletes at the 2008 and 2012 Olympics, Shirley Babashoff and two of her 1976 U.S. Olympic relay team members ascended to the stage in the ballroom of a midtown Manhattan hotel to present an award at USA Swimming’s annual Golden Goggles gala.

headline: Using Twitter’s New Expanded Mute Powers
abstract: As part of its response to online abuse, the service now allows users to mute hashtags, keywords and other material from their notifications.
lead_paragraph: Q. I thought Twitter already allowed you to mute people who were being obnoxious online, so what exactly have they done that is supposed to make it easier to fight abuse now?

headline: Trump Foundation May Have Used Money to Benefit One of Its Own
abstract: The Donald J. Trump Foundation acknowledged on its 2015 tax form that it had used money or assets for a “disqualified person,” or one of the organization’s central people.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s foundation has acknowledged that it may have run afoul of self-dealing rules that guard against using money meant for charity to benefit principals of the organization, according to its 2015 tax filing.

headline: One Holiday, and Countless Ways to Say Thanks
abstract: As Americans gather around the table this week, each family performs its own ritual of gratitude.
lead_paragraph: If you happen by Stacy Christopher’s home in Santa Barbara, Calif., early on Thanksgiving Day, you may think that her husband, her son and their guests chose an odd time for yard work. They rummage through the greenery. They cart away branches.

headline: Bruce Arena, Replacing Jurgen Klinsmann as U.S. Coach, Keeps Things Simple
abstract: Arena, who has won five M.L.S. titles and five N.C.A.A. titles, will lead the Americans for the balance of this World Cup cycle after having coached them in the 2002 and 2006 Cups.
lead_paragraph: The once and future coach — Bruce Arena — will try to make it sound simple. Even at 65, he will roll his eyes and sneer at complicated questions about strategy and formations. This masks his feel of the game, buys him time and distance.

abstract: Randy Mastro discusses his investigation of the George Washington Bridge traffic scandal.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: As Thanksgiving gatherings near, a look at how the harsh rhetoric and intense feelings of the campaign inevitably affect personal relationships.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump, in Interview, Moderates Views but Defies Conventions
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Torture', 'Global Warming', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: In a discussion at The New York Times, the president-elect was less adamant on prosecuting Hillary Clinton, the use of waterboarding and climate change.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Tuesday tempered some of his most extreme campaign promises, dropping his vow to jail Hillary Clinton, expressing doubt about the value of torturing terrorism suspects and pledging to have an open mind about climate change.

headline: Fish Cheeks
abstract: Traditional Thai seafood dishes in NoHo.
lead_paragraph: Traditional Thai seafood dishes in NoHo.

headline: Thai Food Strikes Out in a Fresh Direction at Fish Cheeks
abstract: A new restaurant in NoHo focuses on seafood and intense flavors.
lead_paragraph: In the early days of Thai cuisine in the United States, when pad Thai and spring rolls were exotic treats, Americans fell hard for the interlocking tastes of lime, fish sauce, chiles and herbs. Over the years, that love has grown lukewarm. Many of the restaurants weren’t very good to begin with, and watered-down, sloppy Americanized versions of dishes from central Thailand were the only Thai food many Americans knew.

headline: Donald Trump, Japan, Mosul: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Lithuania’s New Prime Minister Pledges to Increase Military Spending
abstract: The new prime minister, Saulius Skvernelis, supports President-elect Donald J. Trump’s call for NATO members to spend more on defense.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Lawmakers in Lithuania chose as their new prime minister on Tuesday a former police chief and interior minister who supports Donald J. Trump’s call for NATO members to spend more on defense.

headline: What 10 Actors Wore to a Spike Lee Casting Call in Brooklyn
abstract: The long line of actors and performers dressed sharply.
lead_paragraph: Few filmmakers are linked to a borough the way that Spike Lee is to Brooklyn. So when Mr. Lee, the 59-year-old director, announced that he was having an open casting call for a coming Netflix series based on “She’s Gotta Have It” last month, Brooklynites of all stripes turned out. The line of actors and performers at the Masonic Temple was so long that it wrapped around an entire block in Fort Greene. Despite the wait, the crowd was in good spirits and, naturally, smartly dressed.

headline: C.I.A. Guidelines Excerpt
abstract: C.I.A. guidelines on post-Sept. 11 detention and interrogation techniques.
lead_paragraph: C.I.A. guidelines on post-Sept. 11 detention and interrogation techniques.

headline: When Racism Comes Out in the Open
abstract: Readers discuss an alt-right gathering in Washington, which one reader called “a sad and stark reminder that racism is alive and well in America.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Eugene O’Neill in a Drill Hall: Park Avenue Armory’s New Season
abstract: The first season at the armory programmed by its new artistic director, Pierre Audi, also includes works by Ai Weiwei and Pierre Boulez.
lead_paragraph: Works by Eugene O’Neill, Ai Weiwei and Pierre Boulez are on tap for the 10th season of performances at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan — the first one programmed by its new artistic director, Pierre Audi.

headline: Gun Hill Tavern Opens in the Bronx
abstract: Sushi Kaiseki takes up residence in David Bouley’s Brushstroke, and other restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: GUN HILL TAVERN There’s a burger at this South Bronx newcomer to be sure, but with a menu that also features shrimp po’ boys, vegetable quesadillas and a pulled-pork Cuban sandwich, it’s not your everyday neighborhood spot. “We’re serving more upscale pub food so we might attract a wider market,” said Dave Lopez, an owner, along with Adam Gherardi, the manager. Mr. Lopez is also a partner in Gun Hill Brewing Company, in the north Bronx, near Gun Hill Road. The tavern will serve its own beers, with names pulled from history, given that there was a Revolutionary War battle at Gun Hill. (One of the beers, Rise Up Rye, is poured at the Richard Rodgers Theater, where “Hamilton” is playing.) Everything in a glass is from New York State, including other beers, wines, ciders and spirits. The tavern pours a kind of refined Puerto Rican moonshine called Pitorro from Port Morris Distillery next door, also a partner in the tavern. Other whiskeys include some made in-house and used to flavor homemade ice cream: 780 East 133rd Street (Willow Avenue), Port Morris, Bronx, 718-585-3192, gunhillbrewing.com.

headline: 5 Movies to See With (and Without) Family Over Thanksgiving
abstract: After dinner but before leftovers, some movie suggestions for the holiday weekend.
lead_paragraph: The Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade has finished, turkey has been consumed and football has been watched. Time for a trip to the movies. Here is a look at five films that Times editors recommend after that last piece of pumpkin pie.

headline: 3 Indian Soldiers Are Killed in Kashmir
abstract: The killings on the border of India and Pakistan occurred amid an unrelenting series of attacks there in recent months.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Three Indian Army soldiers were killed on Tuesday on the border between India and Pakistan, the army said in a statement, which promised retribution for “this cowardly act.” The body of one soldier had been mutilated, it said.

headline: Paris Highway Robbers Target Qatari Sisters in $5.3 Million Heist
abstract: The holdup is the latest in a series of robberies targeting wealthy tourists and famous visitors in and around the French capital.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Two well-heeled Qatari sisters arrived on Monday night with their family by private jet at Le Bourget airport, north of Paris, where they were met by a chauffeur-driven Bentley waiting to take them to their pied-à-terre in the French capital.

headline: 2 Workers Killed in Construction Accident in Queens
keywords: ['Derricks and Cranes', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: A steel beam fell from a crane on a construction site in the Briarwood neighborhood, where work was being done on an apartment complex, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A crane operator and a construction worker were killed on Tuesday when a steel beam fell from a crane on a gusty day in Queens, officials said.

headline: Despite Conflicts, Financial Overhaul Proposals Have Merit
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Donald Trump and Congress may eliminate some regulations introduced by the Dodd-Frank Act, relieving a burden on big banks.
lead_paragraph: The future of financial regulation is murky given the conflicting statements by President-elect Donald J. Trump, congressional Republicans and Senate Democrats. Some may panic, but looking at the whole picture, there may be some cause for optimism, a least when it comes to the big banks and the concept of “too big to fail.”

headline: Freeing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
abstract: Allowing the two mortgage agencies to keep their earnings would still leave their government bailout unpaid, but it would be a smart first step.
lead_paragraph: The election has resurrected the fiasco of how to fix Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Shares of the two bailed-out mortgage agencies have rocketed over the last two weeks on hopes that the Trump administration might end government oversight. Big political roadblocks remain, though.

headline: Northwestern Basketball Team Becomes Good Enough to Dream
abstract: After a 20-win season, the men’s program, which has never made the N.C.A.A. tournament, is eager to shed its reputation as a lovable loser.
lead_paragraph: This month, as the Chicago Cubs were celebrating their first World Series championship since 1908, Chris Collins, the basketball coach at Northwestern, envisioned what it would be like to end a similarly daunting streak. The N.C.A.A. men’s tournament was first played in 1939, but Northwestern has never made an appearance.

headline: Microcephaly Found in Babies of Zika-Infected Mothers Months After Birth
abstract: A study published Tuesday found that some babies who did not have unusually small heads when they were born still presented microcephaly months later.
lead_paragraph: It is the news that doctors and families in the heart of Zika territory had feared: Some babies not born with the unusually small heads that are the most severe hallmark of brain damage as a result of the virus have developed the condition, called microcephaly, as they have grown older.

headline: Donald Trump’s New York Times Interview in 12 Tweets
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Global Warming', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Among the topics: the prosecution of Hillary Clinton, the alt-right, climate change and the president-elect’s business interests.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump met on Tuesday with journalists from the newsroom and opinion staff at The New York Times. Several reporters, news editors and opinion writers used Twitter to report live on the interview with Mr. Trump.

headline: Review: ‘Bad Santa 2’ Works Through Mommy Issues
abstract: This sequel addresses two unnecessary questions: What if bad Santa weren’t so bad? And what if he had an estranged and equally foul mother?
lead_paragraph: In the hall of fame of ill-tempered comic characters, between wax works of W. C. Fields and Larry David, there ought to be a monument to Billy Bob Thornton’s work as Willie, the alcoholic safecracker of “Bad Santa.” As much as Terry Zwigoff’s 2003 film relied on the spectacle of Mr. Thornton soiling himself in a Santa suit or saying unspeakable things to children, the performance was a master class in timing and sly reaction shots. Only Mr. Thornton could have played the role.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $1.35 MILLION

headline: A Whale Takes Up Residence in the Hudson River
abstract: Cleaner waters and an abundance of fish have attracted at least one humpback whale to the river waters off Manhattan this month.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Rachel Dubroff and her family chose their apartment at Riverside Boulevard and 63rd Street in Manhattan, they were thrilled by its picturesque views of the Hudson River. But they did not expect to have a front-row seat to an annual whale-watching event.

headline: Review: ‘Moana,’ Brave Princess on a Voyage With a Chicken
abstract: In Disney’s new animated adventure, the daughter of a chief must prove herself while music plays and the sun shines on the sea.
lead_paragraph: Moana is the daughter of a chief and will someday inherit her father’s position, but she’s furious when Maui, a tattooed, muscle-bound demigod, calls her a princess. Moana (MWAH-nah) is not only part of a dynastic line but also a girl off on an adventure in the company of a cute animal sidekick (a dimwitted chicken named Heihei). So not just any princess, in other words: a Disney princess. She may be on a quest to save her island and restore ecological balance to the planet, but Moana (voiced by Auli’i Cravalho) is also upholding a brand.

headline: Unsustainability Shutters Socially Responsible Luxury Brand Suno
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: After eight years, the label is folding, amid talk that it was unable to attract investors.
lead_paragraph: After eight years, the socially responsible luxury brand Suno is shutting its doors.

headline: When Doctors First Do Harm
abstract: Doctors not only monitored torture by C.I.A. operatives, they helped design it. They should not lose their ethical moorings again.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Tuesday expressed reservations about the use of torture. But he did not disavow the practice, or his promise to bring it back. And if he does, C.I.A. doctors may be America’s last defense against a return to savagery. But they’ll need to break sharply with what they did the last time around.

headline: Review: ‘Rules Don’t Apply’ Features Warren Beatty as Howard Hughes
abstract: This film takes comic aim at Hollywood absurdity and at Hughes, the eccentric mogul.
lead_paragraph: It may be hyperbolic to describe Warren Beatty’s Howard Hughes movie, “Rules Don’t Apply,” as a screwball “Citizen Kane.” But that’s what it feels like. From another perspective, this serio-comic portrait of Hughes, the aeronautics mogul, movie producer and marathon womanizer, might also be a satirical cartoon that emphasizes his similarities to Donald J. Trump. Why else would Mr. Beatty name a fictional aspiring singer and actress who comes into Hughes’s orbit Marla Mabrey?

headline: Review: ‘Allied,’ With Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard, Uncorks a Favorite Vintage
abstract: “Allied” is not so much a work of art as a triumph of craft, possibly the purest and most relaxed demonstration of the director Robert Zemeckis’s mastery.
lead_paragraph: “Allied,” Robert Zemeckis’s deft and diverting World War II romantic thriller, operates a bit like “Casablanca” in reverse.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jim Rutenberg, Randy Archibold and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: In Vitro
abstract: Christopher Salerno reads his poem “In Vitro.”
lead_paragraph: Christopher Salerno reads his poem “In Vitro.”

headline: Paul Muldoon Collects His Poetic, Allusive, Satirical Thoughts
abstract: This book of selected poems from 1968 to 2014, which takes traditional verse forms and retools them, is powerful and filled with catharses.
lead_paragraph: Few people bother to memorize poems any more. Were this practice to come back into fashion, not many would turn to the work of Paul Muldoon.

headline: Lauren Graham’s Taste of Tokyo
abstract: After shopping for sake and snacks, the “Gilmore Girls” star shares sushi, and a love of Japanese culture, with her half sister.
lead_paragraph: Cradling a brown paper bag filled with sake bottles in her arms, a dismayed Lauren Graham stopped short in front of Yakitori Tora, a Japanese restaurant in SoHo. The windows were dark, the tables were empty and the chairs nowhere to be seen.

headline: Facebook Said to Create Censorship Tool to Get Back Into China
abstract: The social network, blocked in China since 2009, has developed software to keep posts from appearing in users’ news feeds in specific geographic areas, current and former employees said.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, has cultivated relationships with China’s leaders, including President Xi Jinping. He has paid multiple visits to the country to meet its top internet executives. He has made an effort to learn Mandarin.

headline: Trump Meets With The New York Times
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump met with journalists from the newsroom and opinion staff at The New York Times on Tuesday. Here are some of the issues discussed at the meeting.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump met with journalists from the newsroom and opinion staff at The New York Times on Tuesday. Here are some of the issues discussed at the meeting.

headline: Trump Reassures the Media (For Now)
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Libel and Slander', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president-elect says journalists will be “happy” about his First Amendment views. The vice president-elect has actually defended a free press.
lead_paragraph: “I think you’ll be happy, I think you’ll be happy.”

headline: Remembering a Doyenne of the Williamsburg Shop Fronts
abstract: As the Brooklyn neighborhood grew more popular, Leonora Russo, who died this month at 91, was featured in documentaries, magazines and blogs. Some referred to her as the Queen of Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: For decades, if there was an empty bench on Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Leonora Russo was there to take it. With her electric dresses, chunky jewelry and oversize, Elton John-esque sunglasses, Ms. Russo was a familiar sight in the neighborhood’s ever-changing landscape.

headline: James Simons’s Foundation Starts New Institute for Computing, Big Data
keywords: ['Research', 'Science and Technology', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Mathematics', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'Dark Matter (Astronomy)']
abstract: The new venture, the Flatiron Institute, will house programmers and scientists researching astrophysics, among other projects.
lead_paragraph: A new private research institute financed by the billionaire James H. Simons in New York will develop software tools and apply cutting edge computing techniques to science often not possible in academia and industry.

headline: Gun Owners ‘Can Breathe Again’: Trump’s Win Emboldens Advocates
abstract: Supporters of the Second Amendment, ecstatic that Hillary Clinton lost, anticipate an expansion of gun rights with a Trump administration and a Republican-led Congress.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Before the election, gun rights activists were so worried Hillary Clinton would win the presidency that some of them bought extra ammunition and guns, fearing a crackdown on certain weapons, bullets and magazines.
