abstract: The 2015 tax filing of Donald J. Trump's foundation offers new details about the president-elect’s charitable giving, which became the subject of intense scrutiny during his presidential campaign. On the filing, the charity checked “yes” to answer a question about whether its resources had been directed or used to benefit a “disqualified person” — meaning one of the organization’s central people.
lead_paragraph: The 2015 tax filing of Donald J. Trump's foundation offers new details about the president-elect’s charitable giving, which became the subject of intense scrutiny during his presidential campaign. On the filing, the charity checked “yes” to answer a question about whether its resources had been directed or used to benefit a “disqualified person” — meaning one of the organization’s central people.

headline: Investment Funds Get Millions to Stay in Connecticut
abstract: Two multibillion-dollar funds were approved for a total of $57 million in aid to expand and create jobs. One has announced job cuts.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor Cliff Asness is a staunch libertarian who has railed against government intervention in health care and finance.

headline: ISIS Operative Suspected in Paris and Brussels Attacks Is Identified
abstract: The operative, who was previously known only by the nom de guerre Abu Souleymane, is Abdelilah Himich, a 27-year-old from Morocco, the State Department said.
lead_paragraph: The United States government revealed the identity on Tuesday of an Islamic State operative believed to have been one of the overseers of last year’s attacks in Paris, as well as of the coordinated suicide bombings that tore through the international airport and a metro station in Brussels this year.

headline: New Tool Aims to Parse the Value of Online Ad Viewing
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Social Media', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Moat awards different scores depending on whether an advertisement’s audio is on or how much of it streams, a seeming leap forward in a confounding realm of analytics.
lead_paragraph: As people watch more videos on platforms like Facebook, YouTube, Snapchat and Hulu, marketers have spent more time and money trying to reach those viewers. But gauging the success of those advertisements has been a struggle, highlighted by Facebook’s recent admission that it had miscalculated video viewing metrics for years.

headline: Global Warming Alters Arctic Food Chain, Scientists Say, With Unforeseeable Results
abstract: The annual production of algae, the base of the food web, increased an estimated 47 percent between 1997 and 2015, and the Arctic Ocean is greening up earlier each year.
lead_paragraph: The Arctic Ocean may seem remote and forbidding, but to birds, whales and other animals, it’s a top-notch dining destination.

headline: Fire U.S. Soccer’s President, Too? That’s Different, and Improbable
abstract: It’s easy to envision the job of the federation’s president, Sunil Gulati, as akin to a professional general manager, but in reality the position has a much bigger scope.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a conference call on Tuesday during which he explained the decision to fire Jurgen Klinsmann as  coach of the United States men’s national team, Sunil Gulati, the president of U.S. Soccer, talked about the sport’s steep rise in popularity in this country. One result of that spike, Gulati said, is “that pressure has increased on anyone involved in the game.”

headline: Donald Trump’s Demand for Love
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: His meeting with The Times was a marvel of boasting and bending.
lead_paragraph: I had just shaken the president-elect’s normal-size hand and he was moving on to the next person when he wheeled around, took a half step back, touched my arm and looked me in the eye anew.

headline: Watching Postelection, So Much Feels Different
abstract: Wherever we fall on the political spectrum, we’re going to see our desires and fears reflected in the art we encounter, especially in theater.
lead_paragraph: Last week, overcome by anxieties about the election results, I kept hearing variations on the same phrase — at the food co-op, in the lobbies of theaters, during an interview with an actor. Great art will come out of this, people told me. Times like this make for great art.

headline: Long Before ‘Hamilton’ Brouhaha, Theater Was Anything but Polite
abstract: Attending the theater before 1850 or so in the United States was far more akin to attending a football game today than to attending contemporary theater.
lead_paragraph: In 1832, during a performance of “Richard III” at the Bowery Theater in Manhattan, 300 boisterous audience members joined the cast onstage to participate in the final sword fight and the slaying of the tyrannical King Richard. According to a newspaper account, “the audience mingled with the soldiers and raced across the stage” and during the last duel “made a ring around the combatants to see fair play, and kept them at it for nearly a quarter of an hour.” In today’s theater, where audience members are admonished to unwrap their candy in advance to avoid making a sound, such a scene is hard to fathom; in the 19th-century theater, it was of a piece (although on the rowdy side of the spectrum) with standard audience behavior.

headline: Whitney Smith, Whose Passion for Flags Became a Career, Dies at 76
abstract: Fascinated by the banners from an early age, Mr. Smith went on to coin a term for the study of flags, vexillology, and even designed one for Guyana.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Smith, who turned a childhood fascination with flags into a scholarly discipline — vexillology — of which he was the leading light, died on Thursday in Peabody, Mass. He was 76.

headline: Where Marijuana Is the Doctor’s Orders, Will Insurers Pay?
keywords: ['Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tests (Drug Use)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Workplace Environment', 'Marijuana']
abstract: As legal use of marijuana spreads, it has raised questions in the workplace, such as about drug tests and insurance coverage for medical use.
lead_paragraph: Early this year, a disabled former automobile body worker named Greg Vialpando explained to lawmakers in New Mexico how medical marijuana helped his chronic back pain.

headline: At Donald Trump’s Properties, a Showcase for a Brand and a President-Elect
abstract: Questions are being raised about whether Mr. Trump is exploiting the high profile of the presidency to conduct what could be seen as a promotional tour for the Trump Organization.
lead_paragraph: They stood in line at Trump Tower, sometimes up to half an hour, handing over their cash for mementos of the president-elect: mini, gold-wrapped chocolate bricks stamped “Trump.” Trump monogrammed sweaters, towels and glassware. Trump cologne.

headline: Notre Dame to Appeal Ruling on Academic Cheating by Football Players
abstract: The N.C.A.A. said the university must vacate its football team’s wins from the 2012 and 2013 seasons after eight players received prohibited assistance.
lead_paragraph: Notre Dame said Tuesday that it would appeal an N.C.A.A. ruling that it must vacate all of its football team’s wins from the 2012 and 2013 seasons, which included an appearance in the national championship game, after a finding that a former student trainer did coursework for players.

headline: Book Publishers Scramble to Make Sense of Trump’s Rise to Victory
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Publishing houses were caught off-guard by Donald Trump’s win on Election Day, and editors, agents and publishers are now racing to acquire works like memoirs and political analysis.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2015, Katy Tur, a London-based foreign correspondent for NBC News, got a surprising offer from the network’s head of news coverage. Would she like to cover Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign? He assured her that it would be a brief assignment — six weeks at the most.

headline: George Soros Pledges $10 Million to Fight Hate Crimes
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Philanthropy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Saying the Trump campaign awakened “dark forces,” Mr. Soros, the billionaire Democratic donor, will fund grants to community and civil rights groups and efforts to track attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a series of attacks against immigrants and minorities since Election Day, the financier George Soros says he will commit $10 million from his personal foundation to combat a rise in hate crimes that he linked to the “incendiary rhetoric” of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s campaign.

headline: How to Spot a New Yorker When You Need Directions
abstract: One way to determine whether someone knows their way around: Examine what they’re wearing.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Bronx Official Urges Odell Beckham Jr.: Skip the Strippers Next Time You’re Here
abstract: The Giants receiver’s loss of jewelry during a visit to Sin City Cabaret with the Broncos’ Von Miller inspires Ruben Diaz Jr., the Bronx borough president, to suggest other Bronx attractions.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx had a distinguished visitor last week: Odell Beckham Jr., the 24-year-old All-Pro wide receiver for the New York Giants. He made headlines after he danced so vigorously at the Sin City strip club on Thursday that his diamond-studded pinkie ring flew off. It was not recovered, or at least was not returned to Mr. Beckham, according to TMZ.

headline: Auto Safety Regulators Seek a Driver Mode to Block Apps
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Mobile Applications', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Voluntary guidelines will be issued amid a spike in traffic fatalities in the last two years.
lead_paragraph: Apple iPhones and other hand-held devices have long had an airplane mode that shuts off wireless communications to prevent interference with the vast electronics systems that control modern aircraft.

headline: Pay Cuts Jolt Women’s Pro League and Leave Its Future Uncertain
abstract: After players learned their salaries would be cut by about 38 percent to keep the National Women’s Hockey League afloat, they called for more transparency from the league office.
lead_paragraph: In early October, Yurie Adachi, a member of the Japanese women’s national hockey team, was preparing for a late-night practice in Tokyo when she met a visitor from New York. Adachi, who does not speak much English, smiled and offered a one-word greeting: “Riveters.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, November 23, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “They love hockey. They just don’t know much about it.”

headline: Obama Awards His Last Presidential Medals of Freedom
abstract: Mr. Obama has given more of the medals, the nation’s highest civilian honor, than any of his predecessors, and his last ceremony was at turns poignant and hilarious.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama gave the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian honor, to 21 artists, sports figures, scientists and philanthropists on Tuesday in a bravura performance that had the East Wing, stuffed to capacity, laughing and whooping with appreciation.

headline: Cuomo’s Commitment to Clemency Tested in 3 Murder Cases
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Governors (US)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Three men who are serving sentence for murder are seeking clemency from the governor of New York, who has pledged to give some prisoners a second chance.
lead_paragraph: One year ago, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced a “clemency project” to breathe life into a power that has withered from disuse in the state and across the country: the granting of pardons and the commuting of prison sentences for people convicted of crimes.

headline: Report Details Officials’ Emails Discovered During Kathleen Kane’s Tenure
abstract: The investigation into inappropriate communications lingered as an unwritten coda to Ms. Kane’s stormy tenure as attorney general.
lead_paragraph: The emails found on government computers were by turns pornographic, racist and homophobic, and their piecemeal release, beginning in 2014, by Kathleen G. Kane, then the attorney general of Pennsylvania, sent two State Supreme Court justices and an assortment of other officials packing amid suspicions of overly cozy relationships between judges and prosecutors in the state.

headline: At Lunch, Donald Trump Gives Critics Hope
abstract: The campaign is over, but the struggle for Trump’s soul has just begun.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was interesting … Donald Trump came to lunch at The New York Times. You can find all the highlights on the news pages, but since I had the opportunity to be included, let me offer a few impressions of my first close encounter with Trump since he declared for the presidency.

headline: Bronx Teenager Won’t Be Tried as Adult in Gang Case
abstract: In his decision, a Manhattan judge cites a young man’s traumatic adolescence and argues that he can be rehabilitated.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan judge ruled on Tuesday that federal authorities could not prosecute as an adult a teenager accused of being a member of a violent gang despite the seriousness of his alleged acts, saying his background suggested that a “significant root cause” of his crimes was “environmental.”

headline: Peter Binzen, Dean of Philadelphia Journalism for Half a Century, Dies at 94
abstract: At The Evening and Sunday Bulletin and later The Philadelphia Inquirer, he wrote about education, urban affairs and business, and his books covered workers, mayors and railroads.
lead_paragraph: Peter Binzen, a newspaperman who covered Philadelphia for more than five decades and whose books presciently explored the frustrations of working-class Americans, the rise of Mayor Frank L. Rizzo as their bellicose local political hero and the bankruptcy of the Penn Central railroad, died on Nov. 16 in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 94.

headline: After Obama Push for Clemency, Hints of Reversal Likely to Come
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: Mr. Obama is on pace to be the first president since Lyndon B. Johnson to leave office with a federal prison population smaller than the one he inherited.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is on pace to be the first president in decades to leave office with a federal prison population that is smaller than when he was sworn in, a reflection of eight years of liberal criminal justice policies, historically low crime rates and an aggressive use of presidential commutations.

headline: Questioning Donald Trump
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: It was alarming to confront how thinly thought through many of Mr. Trump’s stances actually are.
lead_paragraph: It was good to hear Donald Trump “disavow and condemn” the white nationalism of some of his supporters, in a meeting Tuesday at The New York Times.

headline: Bruce Arena Adopts More Inclusive Tone on Foreign-Born Players
abstract: Back as the coach of the U.S. men’s team, Arena distanced himself from his remarks in recent years questioning the patriotism of foreign-born players.
lead_paragraph: First, a question of clarification for Bruce Arena on the first day of his second stint as coach of the United States men’s national team: Would American soccer grow as nativist in outlook as American presidential politics? Did Arena still subscribe to his earlier remarks that most players should be homemade, like jeans and jazz?

headline: Creeping Progress in Pledge to Cut Calories in Sugary Soda
abstract: As more cities impose tax on sugary drinks, a vow from some soft drink producers to reduce calories 20 percent in 10 years advances ever so slightly.
lead_paragraph: It hasn’t been a good year for the troika that dominates soft drink sales, Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and Dr Pepper Snapple. The public’s attention on the health effects of sugary sodas has continued to increase, slowing growth and increasing political pressure.

headline: Democrats’ Leadership Fight Pits West Wing Against Left Wing
abstract: Representative Keith Ellison of Minnesota has been steadily adding endorsements, but some advisers to President Obama are urging others to enter the race.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Struggling to respond to Donald J. Trump’s victory, a group of shellshocked Democrats moved swiftly to endorse Representative Keith Ellison of Minnesota for chairman of the Democratic National Committee, hoping that he would be a fresh face for a party with a depleted bench.

headline: Kochs and Other Madoff Investors Are Winners in Fight Over Profits Held Abroad
abstract: A judge ruled that certain funds held abroad — estimated at about $2 billion — could not be made available to victims of the Madoff Ponzi scheme.
lead_paragraph: The company led by the American billionaire Koch brothers, along with dozens of banks and fund managers, kept billions of dollars in profit from Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme in accounts offshore. As it turns out, that was a good decision.

headline: The Trump Revelations
abstract: Our next president, conciliatory on policy and stubborn on potential corruption.
lead_paragraph: Politicians lie; Donald Trump dissembles more frequently than most. So no matter how clever or tough or eloquent your questions, there are limits to what an hour or so in a room with him can actually establish.

headline: Donald Trump Close to Picking Ben Carson as Housing Secretary
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The choice of the former neurosurgeon suggested that Mr. Trump was seeking diversity in an administration that has started off predominantly white and male.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ben Carson, the retired neurosurgeon who ran an outsider’s campaign for the Republican presidential nomination and later backed Donald J. Trump, is likely to be chosen as secretary of housing and urban development, according to a person close to the Trump transition, suggesting that the president-elect is seeking diversity in an administration that has started off predominantly white and male.

headline: Ex-Advisers to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo Are Indicted in Federal Bribery Case
abstract: Besides Joseph Percoco and Alain E. Kaloyeros, a federal grand jury also voted to indict six others, all executives of companies that had business with the state.
lead_paragraph: Two former advisers to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo were indicted on Tuesday on federal corruption charges, another legal milestone in a bribery and bid-rigging scandal that has struck at the highest levels of the Cuomo administration.

headline: Sentence Structure
abstract: David Steinberg hamsters it up.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Not bad for a midweek outing. David Steinberg is back, and he offers us a fresh theme that eluded me for a bit, but was very “gettable” as soon as I solved the first theme entry which, for me, was FLASH MOBSTER.

headline: Rezoning Plan for Schools on Upper West Side Is Approved After Bitter Fight
abstract: A parents’ council voted on Tuesday to shift the boundaries for some Manhattan schools, a move that appears unlikely to quell a simmering controversy over segregation in New York City’s school system.
lead_paragraph: After a yearlong debate that exposed the difficulty of taking even small steps toward integrating New York City’s schools, an elected parent council voted on Tuesday to approve a major redrawing of school zones on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Derrick Rose, in Triumphant Flash, Lifts Knicks Over Trail Blazers
abstract: Rose had 18 points and hit a crucial jump shot with 6.8 seconds left as the Knicks recorded their fifth straight home victory and evened their record at 7-7.
lead_paragraph: Courtney Lee saw the signs of Derrick Rose’s rejuvenation flickering in the summer. In workouts, Lee would be awe-struck as Rose dominated him in workouts. Lee thought he was athletic, but he could not keep up.

headline: U.S. Judge's Ruling in the Overtime Case
abstract: Ruling by U.S. District Judge Amos L. Mazzant III in Sherman, Tex., granting a preliminary injunction blocking an Obama administration rule that would have allowed more workers to qualify for overtime beginning Dec. 1.
lead_paragraph: Ruling by U.S. District Judge Amos L. Mazzant III in Sherman, Tex., granting a preliminary injunction blocking an Obama administration rule that would have allowed more workers to qualify for overtime beginning Dec. 1.

headline: Judge Suspends Rule Expanding Overtime for Millions of Workers
keywords: ['Overtime', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A federal judge in Texas issued an injunction, arguing that the Obama administration had exceeded its authority by raising the income limit so significantly.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas issued a nationwide injunction on Tuesday against an Obama administration regulation expanding by millions the number of workers who would be eligible for time-and-a-half overtime pay.

headline: Donald Trump, Brad Pitt, Mosul: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: China Arrests 3 Workers From the Australian Casino Operator Crown Resorts
abstract: Australia said it had been told of the official arrest of the three workers, who were among 18 held last month in an inquiry into the promotion of gambling in China.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — The Chinese authorities have formally arrested three Australian employees of the casino operator Crown Resorts who had been detained in mid-October in an investigation into  the promotion of gambling in China.

headline: In Hong Kong’s Kowloon, the Markets Rule
abstract: How to do wildly expensive Hong Kong on a budget? Focus on its less-touristy side.
lead_paragraph: My grandmother and I walked along Kweilin Street in Kowloon, near the Sham Shui Po rail station, where the open-air market was a scene of controlled chaos.

headline: Donald Trump’s New York Times Interview: Full Transcript
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Read the full text of the president-elect’s meeting with reporters, editors and opinion columnists from The Times.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s interview on Tuesday with reporters, editors and opinion columnists from The New York Times. The transcription was prepared by Liam Stack, Jonah Engel Bromwich, Karen Workman and Tim Herrera of The Times. More on the Trump transition here.

headline: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘20/20: The Real Designated Survivor’ and Usher in ‘Neighborhood Sessions’
abstract: “20/20” looks at what happens when disaster really strikes the federal government. And Usher performs on behalf of music and art in schools.
lead_paragraph: “20/20: The Real Designated Survivor” looks at what really happens when disaster strikes the federal government. And Usher performs in his Tennessee hometown on behalf of music and art in schools.

headline: Corrections: November 23, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Wednesday, November 23, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Word + Quiz: pliant
abstract: This word has appeared in 52 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: Fighting Intensifies Between India and Pakistan on Kashmir Line of Control
abstract: Pakistan said Indian troops fired on a passenger bus on its side of the Line of Control in the disputed region, killing nine civilians.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Shelling and gunfire intensified on Wednesday on the de facto border between India and Pakistan in the Kashmir region, killing nine civilians on a bus one day after the Indian Army promised retribution for what it said was the killing of three of its soldiers.

headline: Miss Sharon Jones, a Queen Among Dap-Kings
abstract: Even as she fought cancer, the singer Sharon Jones lived for the stage as a powerful, soulful presence.
lead_paragraph: Even as she fought cancer, the singer Sharon Jones lived for the stage as a powerful, soulful presence.

headline: Power Imbalance at the Pipeline Protest
keywords: ['Native Americans', 'Pipelines', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Water Pollution', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Editorials', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: President Obama could step in to protect everyone’s safety and pressure the sheriff’s officers to stand down in North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: When injustice aligns with cruelty, and heavy weaponry is involved, the results can be shameful and bloody. Witness what happened on Sunday in North Dakota, when law enforcement officers escalated their tactics against unarmed American Indians and allies who have waged months of protests against the Dakota Access oil pipeline.

headline: America Has Room for the Dreamers
keywords: ['Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Editorials', 'Series']
abstract: In a saner time, in a country whose politics were less poisoned, there would be no talk of punishing young immigrants.
lead_paragraph: In a saner time, in a country whose politics were less poisoned, there would be no talk of punishing young immigrants like Sofia De La Vega, Luis Roberto Ursua Briceno and Anayancy Ramos. No one would be threatening to derail their ambitions, stifle their educations, throttle their dreams.

headline: My Life With Tourette’s Syndrome
abstract: I made the choice to sacrifice social acceptability for the freedom to be myself.
lead_paragraph: When I was 17, my father took me to a juvenile treatment clinic to see if doctors could figure out what was wrong with me. I entered a room. I sat on a chair. I waited for a long while. There was a video camera trained on me. Then I heard voices, the voices of doctors behind a two-way mirror. It was like being in a police interrogation room in the movies.

headline: After Window-Washing Deaths, a Debate Over Migrants’ Rights in Hong Kong
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Domestic Service', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations']
abstract: Reports of domestic workers falling to their deaths this year have added urgency to a long-running debate about the city’s reliance on low-cost migrant labor.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Whenever the windows of her employer’s 35th-floor apartment looked dirty, Win Win Warsiating would lean halfway out of the high-rise building to clean them. Sometimes she would glance down at the ground far below and be seized with anxiety, she said. But she never complained.

headline: Miss Sharon Jones, a Queen Among Dap-Kings
abstract: Even as she fought cancer, the singer Sharon Jones lived for the stage as a powerful, soulful presence. From legendary theaters to sweltering Midwest venues, she gave it her best.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Blickenstaff has been photographing Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings since 2009. He started out documenting shows, then recording sessions, and was eventually asked by Gabe Roth, a co-founder of Daptone Records, to shoot his first album cover for the label, “I Learned the Hard Way,” depicting Miss Jones and the group in back of their studio in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Since then, Mr. Blickenstaff has worked with the label on several other album projects. After Ms. Jones’s death last week, Mr. Blickenstaff reflected on his years with the band.

headline: The Disappearing Dialect at the Heart of China’s Capital
abstract: Beijing’s distinct and colorful dialect is heard less and less as migration, development and language standardization programs reshape the city.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — To the untutored ear, the Beijing dialect can sound like someone talking with a mouthful of marbles, inspiring numerous parodies and viral videos. Its colorful vocabulary and distinctive pronunciation have inspired traditional performance arts such as cross-talk, a form of comic dialogue, and “kuaibanr,’’ storytelling accompanied by bamboo clappers.

headline: Questions for: ‘Squash, Rice and Roadkill: Feeding the Fighters of Standing Rock’
abstract: Who is feeding the hundreds of hungry protesters camped out at a Sioux reservation in North Dakota?
lead_paragraph: Article: ‘Squash, Rice and Roadkill: Feeding the Fighters of Standing Rock’

headline: Mr. Olympia
abstract: What do you imagine this man’s daily life must be like in order to keep his body in this condition?

headline: The Conflicts Along 1,172 Miles of the Dakota Access Pipeline
abstract: A detailed map showing the Dakota Access Pipeline, the site of months of clashes near the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: A detailed map showing the Dakota Access Pipeline, the site of months of clashes near the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota.

headline: With Philip Hammond’s Plan, U.K. Shelves Austerity
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: In his first Autumn Statement, the chancellor of the Exchequer laid out plans for helping those who are “just about managing.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After years of tough spending curbs, Britain’s government on Wednesday cast aside the language of austerity as it acknowledged the high economic cost of withdrawal from the European Union, and tried to placate struggling working-class families whose incomes have stagnated.

headline: Searching the Sky for Bombs in Aleppo
abstract: Residents of Aleppo, Syria, told us how they feel when they hear an aircraft overhead. Eastern Aleppo has been under heavy bombardment by Syrian and Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Aleppo, Syria, told us how they feel when they hear an aircraft overhead. Eastern Aleppo has been under heavy bombardment by Syrian and Russian forces.

headline: How to Catch a Wave
abstract: Stabilize the board before standing. Then pop up light as a cat.
lead_paragraph: “One of the biggest mistakes beginners make,” says Carol Philips, founder of the North Shore Surf Girls surf school and a pioneer of big-wave body boarding for women, “is that they equate catching a wave with standing up.” Philips says it’s more important to focus on stabilizing the board with your hands, lying prone on your stomach and then standing up. But, she says, beginners should not try to do all three of those things at the same time.

headline: The 11.13.16 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: THE DESIGN ISSUE

headline: Letter of Recommendation: High-School-Football Games
abstract: A republic of doting parents and proud siblings, supportive neighbors and sentimental alumni.
lead_paragraph: Kenny Byrd broke one tackle, then another, and soon he had nothing in front of him but end zone. The crowd roared with delight; the marching band lifted its horns and belted out a celebratory rendition of “Shut Up and Dance.” Cowbells clanged. Behind me, the superintendent of schools celebrated next to a local Republican candidate for the State Legislature. In front of me, a Latino family embraced before turning around to offer me high-fives. I obliged them. Though I hadn’t lived in Hot Springs, Ark., for more than 20 years, this was my alma mater.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Copying Checkered Vans
abstract: Marriage is a journey you must walk together. Make sure you’re not wearing the same weirdo shoes.
lead_paragraph: Ryan writes: I often wear checkered Vans slip-ons while running errands, and my wife decided to get the exact same pair. I do not want to wear the same shoes in public. Please order that she cannot copy me.

headline: In Toy Ads and on the Catwalk, Models With Down Syndrome
abstract: Advertisers say featuring models with Down syndrome helps them to communicate their values and connect with customers who value inclusiveness.
lead_paragraph: IN a new commercial for the Fisher-Price Little People Sit ‘n Stand Skyway, Lili Boglarka Havasi claps and smiles as the cars zoom down the plastic raceway. It’s a typical holiday toy ad except for one fact: Lili has Down syndrome.

headline: Would You Like to Be Cryogenically Preserved (Frozen!) Upon Your Death?
abstract: A 14-year-old dying girl’s last wish is fulfilled.
lead_paragraph: The saying goes that two things in life are certain: death and taxes. One of those, however, might be not so certain after all. Cryogenics is the scientific process by which a dead body is frozen in the hopes it will one day be thawed, bringing the person back to life. So far, the reversal process has happened only in movies, but that doesn’t stop some people from wanting the option.

headline: Running Into Danger on an Alaskan Trail
abstract: A confrontation with a wild black bear.
lead_paragraph: It happened so fast: One moment I was running trails, the next I was staring a black-bear sow in the face, so close I could smell it, wild and pungent and alarming, and I knew it could smell me, too, my fear.

headline: In Vitro
abstract: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.
lead_paragraph: Aristotle wrote that poets are those who have “an eye for resemblances,” unexpected likenesses that only by means of the poem reveal themselves to us as true. This poet sees such an unexpected resemblance between medical forms and the scalp of an “unreal child,” presumably a desired one, and through that resemblance, he is able to conjure the mixture of feelings a person might have in this awkward, hopeful, itself quite unreal-seeming situation. Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

headline: Searching the Sky for Bombs in Aleppo
abstract: Residents of eastern Aleppo describe the terror that rises in them every time they see a plane cross the sky.
lead_paragraph: Residents of eastern Aleppo have been living for more than five years under skies heavily trafficked by Syrian and now also Russian warplanes. Activists and citizens in the besieged rebel-held areas of the city have posted videos online of bombs being dropped, and have described in WhatsApp voice messages the fear that grips them every time they see an aircraft cross the sky.

headline: A Burmese Take on American Thanksgiving
abstract: Burma Superstar, a San Francisco restaurant, hosts a Thanksgiving meal for its employees and serves Burmese delicacies.
lead_paragraph: Burma Superstar, a San Francisco restaurant, hosts a Thanksgiving meal for its employees and serves Burmese delicacies.

headline: A Breakthrough in C-Section History: Beatrice of Bourbon’s Survival in 1337
abstract: Beatrice, the second wife (and second cousin) of the King of Bohemia, and her baby are believed to be the first mother and child to survive a cesarean section, new research has found.
lead_paragraph: Births by cesarean section are so common these days that it is easy to forget what they were like before the advent of modern medicine: desperate gambits to save a baby by sacrificing the mother.

headline: Two Children, One Rich, One Poor, Gasping for Air in Delhi’s Smog
abstract: How two families at opposite ends of the economic spectrum were affected when a suffocating cloud of pollution settled over the city this month.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In the dense smog that engulfed India’s capital early this month, a baby named Vaishnavi gasped through the night.

headline: Donald Trump’s Early Backers in State Government May See Rewards
abstract: In every presidential race, there are early and fierce endorsers of the winning candidate who are then viewed, postelection, as having more influence.
lead_paragraph: In Maine, where Gov. Paul R. LePage backed Donald J. Trump’s campaign for the presidency, some political observers are wondering if the state will soon see results from that. Might Mr. Trump lend his support, for instance, to reversing a recent federal parkland designation that Mr. LePage strongly opposed?

headline: In Betsy DeVos for Education, Trump Taps Into Michigan Royalty
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has chosen Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina to be ambassador to the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has reached into Western Michigan royalty to pick Betsy DeVos as his education secretary and is looking at Ben Carson to head the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Meantime, Hillary Clinton has widened her lead in the popular vote to 1.5 percentage points, a spread not seen for a losing candidate since the disputed election of 1876.

headline: Shearing Sheep at the End of the World
abstract: On Isla Grande, gauchos might not see another human for weeks, but around this time each year, they drive their sheep home to ranches for shearing.
lead_paragraph: TIERRA DEL FUEGO, Chile — Life at the end of the world can be lonely.

headline: Living in Downtown Brooklyn
abstract: Building has surged in Downtown Brooklyn, with 6,758 new apartments in the last decade alone; about 6,000 more are under construction.
lead_paragraph: Building has surged in Downtown Brooklyn, with 6,758 new apartments in the last decade alone; about 6,000 more are under construction.

headline: Downtown Brooklyn: Commercial Center to Neighborhood
abstract: Building has surged in the neighborhood, with 6,758 new apartments in the last decade alone; about 6,000 more are under construction.
lead_paragraph: Downtown Brooklyn, the civic and commercial center of the borough, is becoming a full-fledged residential community with its own identity, if not attitude.

headline: How to Be Mindful at the Holiday Table
abstract: Holidays are often filled with expectations. Take a moment to appreciate the present.
lead_paragraph: “Holidays often come wrapped in memories and expectations. Mindfulness offers the gift of being present in the moment. Just show up and be interested. At holidays, this means simply being present in the moment with compassion for yourself, and others.” — Nina Smiley, director of mindfulness programming at Mohonk Mountain House.

headline: Postelection Harassment, Case by Case
keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Discrimination', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Here is a look at five cases: Some of the people involved apologized. One denied being responsible. And another said his actions had been misconstrued.
lead_paragraph: Vandalism, offensive jokes, even criminal assault — reports of bias-based harassment have spiked since Donald J. Trump’s victory in the presidential race. Few of the perpetrators have been caught, but here is a look at five cases in which people have been directly accused. Some apologized. One denied being responsible. Another said his actions had been misconstrued.

headline: Donald Trump, Global Warming, Facebook: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What Are You Thankful For?
abstract: The Times asked readers what they were most grateful for this Thanksgiving. Responses ranged from the presidential election being over to health, family and the Chicago Cubs.
lead_paragraph: The Times asked readers what they were most grateful for this Thanksgiving. Responses ranged from the presidential election being over to health, family and the Chicago Cubs.

headline: Morning Agenda: Aid for Investment Funds, Billions in Profit for Madoff Investors, Facebook’s Censorship Tool
abstract: Connecticut’s state government is doling out funds to investment firms to persuade them not to leave the state, but not everyone is persuaded it is a good allocation of resources.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor Cliff Asness is a staunch libertarian who is very much against government intervention.

headline: New York Today: What We’re Grateful for This Thanksgiving
abstract: Wednesday: Readers share their thoughts, inflating balloons for the parade, and Cuomo aides are indicted.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:37 a.m.

headline: Taking Your Wallet on Vacation? Here’s How to Keep It Safe
keywords: ['Drivers Licenses', 'Credit Cards', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: Make sure it has just your essentials (most people carry too many credit cards), and take the time to back up your personal documents.
lead_paragraph: Losing your wallet or having it stolen is a nuisance anytime, but when you’re on vacation, it can ruin the hope of a good trip, according to Chris McGoey, a security consultant who has traveled to more than 110 countries. “People carry critical personal information like credit cards and a driver’s license in their wallet, and a lost or stolen one is a bigger headache and harder to recover from when you’re traveling,” he said.

headline: Looking for a Bargain Vacation? Don’t Rule Out Hawaii
abstract: The writer, a self-confessed travel snob traveling with her husband and toddler, wondered what quality you could get in a packaged trip.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it’s because I hadn’t been to Hawaii since I was a child, when everything seemed big. But even from 10,000 feet, the Big Island was surprisingly, strikingly large. Its volcanic peaks had vast slopes, each divided into color-coded microclimates of green and tan, and each punctuated with charcoal-hued tributaries of recently cooled lava.

headline: Who’s Likely to Make the College Football Playoff (Besides Alabama)
abstract: With a week left in the regular season plus conference championships, plenty could change. But here’s a look at categories of contenders.
lead_paragraph: With one more week’s worth of regular-season games plus the conference championships, there is still plenty more that could happen in the College Football Playoff rankings, and more still that the 12-member selection committee could do to confound, elate and enrage college football fans.

headline: In the Hudson Valley, a New Mecca for Artisans
abstract: A new energy has taken hold in Catskill on the heels of the Catskill Mill, a project by the Etsy founder Rob Kalin and a partner that includes spaces for craftspeople.
lead_paragraph: Inside the New York Restaurant in Catskill, N.Y., on a recent Sunday afternoon, a jazz band whiled away the hours as the place filled up. Fresh into town, a friend and I marveled at unusual dishes like “cauliflower wings” and brussels sprout chips, and at the sense that we’d stumbled into the clubhouse for local creatives. I’d last visited Catskill a couple of years before, and here was my first indication that since then, a new energy had taken hold in this small town of 4,000 set in the Hudson Valley, where Catskill Creek meets the Hudson River.

headline: How to Save a Donkey (It Helps to Have a Goat)
abstract: An abused rescue donkey needs more than good medical care for it to heal. It also needs a friend.
lead_paragraph: After the emergency hacksaw surgery on his hooves, Sherman barely moved.

headline: Trump Tower, the Center of the Political Universe
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A single day at Trump Tower in Manhattan provides a view of potential cabinet members and staff in the next administration.

headline: Why This Election Was Not About the Issues
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton focused on attacks on character, and the data on their campaign ads shows it.
lead_paragraph: If you think back to this year’s presidential campaign and recall a lot of articles mentioning Hillary Clinton’s email troubles and Donald J. Trump’s various controversies, you wouldn’t be wrong. If it seems there were fewer articles about jobs, the economy and taxes, that’s because there were. The temptation to blame news organizations for this imbalance is strong, but there is at least some reason to resist it. Critics have long assailed campaign coverage as focused too much on candidate personality, campaign strategy and assessments of who’s winning, instead of on policies and ideas. But this year, the candidates share the blame.

lead_paragraph: SALINAS, Calif. — As Americans gather around Thanksgiving tables, chances are that the healthier parts of their menus — the tossed salads, broccoli casseroles or steaming bowls of roasted brussels sprouts — were grown here in the Salinas Valley.

headline: A Bracelet Reissued Over 40 Years After a Designer’s Death
abstract: David Webb originally sketched the striking cuff in 1971.
lead_paragraph: David Webb helped define the audacious edge of mid-20th-century jewelry design. In an atelier above the glamorous Manhattan shop he opened in 1948, the genteel Southerner fashioned extravagant bejeweled creations — often in the shape of exotic animals — that were coveted by Elizabeth Taylor, Lana Turner and Barbra Streisand. Diana Vreeland often wore Webb’s zebra bangle with ruby eyes. Thanks to the 40,000 sketches left behind after his death in 1975, his iconic designs have continued to live on — including this recently reissued modernist gold and black enamel cuff. Designed by Webb in 1971, it juxtaposes opaque and translucent gems in a bold geometric composition of carved coral and diamonds surrounding a massive 58-carat Brazilian citrine.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump moved swiftly on Wednesday to diversify his cabinet and try to heal lingering rifts in the Republican Party, reaching out to Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina and Betsy DeVos, a prominent Republican fund-raiser, both of whom opposed him during the campaign, as well as Ben Carson, who challenged Mr. Trump for the Republican nomination.

headline: Tina Brown on the Final Two Episodes of ‘The Crown’: Love and Duty
abstract: The Netflix series ends its first season with two especially juicy episodes.
lead_paragraph: As we have seen, the struggle to become the head of state of the American republic can be ugly and brutal. One of the upsides of being a constitutional monarchy is that there’s no such struggle. No one elects the British head of state — no one but God. The monarch’s role is to be (or, at least, to appear) immutable. Queen Elizabeth II wields a delicate, unsought sovereignty that can never be eschewed (except by abdication or death) and is rarely exercised. She must evolve with change and sometimes nudge it — but never, ever demand it.

headline: The Curse of Hypercorrection in Latin America
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Latin America’s ideological pendulum is shifting from left to right, but new leaders are also repeating the errors of their predecessors.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — In the late 2000s, leftist politicians were leading countries all across Latin America. Today, most are in retreat, challenged by a new crop of would-be leaders promising to fix the problems created by the left. In Argentina, Paraguay and Peru, these challengers have won elections. In Brazil, they took office this year as a result of a presidential impeachment and, as in Chile, gained ground in municipal elections. In Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela, they are regaining electoral strength.

headline: 1891: A 10-Hour Day for Women in France
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: Lawmakers in the French Parliament disagree on a labor law limiting the daily hours of female workers in November 1891.
lead_paragraph: There is a prospect of a conflict between the two French Chambers in respect to the new law for regulating labor. The Bill as it left the Chamber provided that ten hours per day should be the maximum for youths under eighteen, boys, girls, and women of all ages. When the law reached the Senate there was an animated discussion of the portion of the clause relating to women; and eventually, on the motion of M. Berenger, the words “and women” were struck out by 109 votes to 99.

headline: A Reunion 21 Years in the Making
abstract: A couple who married in Eritrea in 1995 are living together in New York for the first time this century, and are expecting their first child in April.
lead_paragraph: He survived conscription in Eritrea, conspired to confront his country’s injustices and faked an emergency to elude the authorities when they discovered his plan. He fled across the African country’s border to Ethiopia and made his way to a refugee camp, braving horrific conditions and rationed food and water for a chance to eventually get to the United States.

lead_paragraph: Ralph Branca, the pitcher who had three consecutive All-Star seasons for the Brooklyn Dodgers but who was never allowed to forget one pitch that crushed them, died early Wednesday in Rye Brook, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: Alvin Ailey Dance Opens Season With Dizzy and Ella
abstract: The troupe’s annual engagement at City Center will also focus on social issues.
lead_paragraph: If your brand of holiday dance is “The Nutcracker,” your options are plentiful. But there’s always an alternative: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opens its City Center engagement on Wednesday, Nov. 30, with “An Evening of Ailey and Jazz.” Excerpts from works like “The Winter in Lisbon,” Billy Wilson’s tribute to Dizzy Gillespie, will share the program with “Ella,” a one-off homage to Ella Fitzgerald by the company’s artistic director, Robert Battle.

headline: If He Asks You to Be His Neighbor, Don’t Do It
abstract: “Mr. Neighbor’s House,” a Mister Rogers spoof, is coming to Adult Swim. In his neighborhood, the grass is always redder on the other side.
lead_paragraph: “Mister Rogers’ Neighborhood,” the old PBS children’s series, has spawned plenty of parodies, but “Mr. Neighbor’s House” seems determined to be darker and more demented than any of them. The show turns up on the Adult Swim late-night programming block on Friday, Dec. 2, and it’s just as well that little ones will be asleep, because this twisted version of a children’s show is unfit for actual children.

abstract: Mr. Wise, who records as serpentwithfeet, will perform at this Brooklyn venue.
lead_paragraph: The first serpentwithfeet concert in New York took place a couple of months ago in a church in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a setting both implausible and also reassuringly spiritual.

headline: David Hallberg’s Much-Anticipated Stage Return Is Just Weeks Away
abstract: The ballet dancer, who has been sidelined for two and a half years after an ankle injury, is to perform in “Coppélia” in Sydney starting Dec. 13.
lead_paragraph: David Hallberg is getting back on his feet. Mr. Hallberg — who has been called the world’s foremost paragon of the classical style in ballet, but has been sidelined for two and half years because of an ankle injury — confirmed on Wednesday that he planned to return to the stage next month in Sydney to dance with the Australian Ballet.

headline: The Flute in Dialogue, Courtesy of Claire Chase
abstract: At the Kitchen, the flutist unveils “part iv” of her “Density 2036” project, emphasizing the flute’s interaction with other musical forces.
lead_paragraph: Claire Chase, the virtuosic flutist and tireless new-music advocate, is in the midst of “Density 2036,” a 22-year project to commission works for her instrument. The plan is that each year between 2014 and 2036, the centennial of Varèse’s seminal solo “Density 21.5,” she’ll offer a new program for solo flute.

headline: ‘La La Land’ Makes Musicals Matter Again
abstract: Damien Chazelle’s film infuses Hollywood movies with a vision and energy that have been sorely missing.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The first time I watched Damien Chazelle’s musical, “La La Land,” I thought a lot about how it worked, about its form, his craft and how the lickable candy-colored costumes bring to mind both M&M’s and Jacques Demy. I thought about how Mr. Chazelle and his stars, Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, fit into the history of the film musical. When I went to see “La La Land” again, I was in a terrible state, and this time I just fell into it, gratefully. I surrendered. Afterward, I realized that this must have been what it was like to watch Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers during the Great Depression.

headline: Looking Back on a Revolution: Russian Art at MoMA
abstract: MoMA will unveil “A Revolutionary Impulse: The Rise of the Russian Avant-Garde,” a culling of nearly 270 works from its extensive holdings.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art is getting a head start celebrating the centennial of the Russian Revolution of 1917. On Saturday, Dec. 3, it will unveil “A Revolutionary Impulse: The Rise of the Russian Avant-Garde,” a culling of nearly 270 works from its extensive holdings. Everything on view was made between 1912, when European modernism was especially influential among a talented cadre of Russian artists, and 1934, when the Soviet government clamped down on avant-garde activities. The show will put on view nearly all of the museum’s Russian paintings and sculptures from these years, tracing the absorption of Cubism and Futurism and the rise of Suprematism and Constructivism. There will also be films and film posters, photographs, illustrated books, prints, drawings, utilitarian objects and magazines, including a complete run of 22 issues of Novyi Lef, or New Left, magazine, recently acquired, which reflect the design and photographic genius of Aleksandr Rodchenko. (Through March 12; moma.org.)

headline: Choke Point of a Nation: The High Cost of an Aging River Lock
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Levees and Dams', 'Freight (Cargo)', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Tugboats and Towboats', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A symbol of America’s ailing infrastructure, Lock No. 52 on the Ohio River is responsible for a shipping bottleneck that hobbles commerce far and wide.
lead_paragraph: Luther Helland stood on a platform in the middle of the river and surveyed his dam. It was in bad shape. Several of the panels that kept the water back were missing, while others were out of true. Weeks of work stretched before him, compounded by the vagaries of the river.

headline: Daily Report: Facebook Courts China With Censoring Software
abstract: China is a tempting market for Facebook, which has been banned there since 2009. But to get in, the social network may have to compromise on its mission.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has been in the spotlight for the last few weeks over issues including how fake news on the social network may have influenced American voters and for disclosing new errors in its measurement of digital ads.

headline: Pedro Almodóvar: Oscar Winner and Spanish Treasure
abstract: Mr. Almodóvar is the subject of a 20-film retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. Expect delirious sensuality.
lead_paragraph: If, among Spain’s great directors, Luis Buñuel was the bourgeoisie’s secular critic, and Carlos Saura the symbolist poet of the Franco regime’s twilight, Pedro Almodóvar initially embodied the cultural bacchanal after Franco’s death in 1975. By now, Mr. Almodóvar — the subject of a 20-film retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art from Tuesday, Nov. 29, through Dec. 17 — is an Oscar winner (“All About My Mother” took best foreign film in 2000; “Talk to Her” won for best original screenplay in 2003) and a Spanish national treasure.

headline: ‘Ride the Cyclone’ Takes the Kids Up and Down and Into Purgatory
abstract: On the heels of an extended run in Chicago, this musical about the afterlife of a school choir, comes to the Lucille Lortel Theater.
lead_paragraph: The musical “Ride the Cyclone,” which comes to New York courtesy of MCC Theater after an acclaimed, extended run in Chicago, has a premise as fanciful as it is freaky. Originally developed from cabaret performances in Canada, it’s about a group of school choir kids who meet their grisly ends when the roller coaster they are riding malfunctions. They assemble in some strange purgatory, where it is revealed that one will be granted the chance to return to life, while the others will head, well, who knows where.

headline: 8 Lines Written by Anne Frank Fetch $148,000 at Auction
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Auctions', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: A 1942 poem handwritten in a “friendship book” for the sister of Anne’s best friend was sold at auction in the Netherlands. Its original recipient found its tone irritating.
lead_paragraph: In 1970, a Dutch woman named Christiane van Maarsen took out a notebook from her childhood. She tore out a page with an eight-line poem that her little sister’s best friend had written decades earlier. The friend’s condescending tone had long rubbed her the wrong way.

headline: Review: ‘Poison,’ in Which a Death Separates a Couple and Connects Them
abstract: The loss of a young son is the central force in this work by the Dutch playwright Lot Vekemans.
lead_paragraph: “Did you know I was writing a book?” the man asks his ex-wife, though this is maybe not the time to bring it up. Alone in a room at a cemetery, face to face for the first time in years, they are here about the grave of their little boy, Jacob. Evidently a toxin has seeped into the soil. Long in the ground, the body will have to be disinterred, then reburied in a less dangerous spot.

Take Goldie’s, an unpretentious beer-and-shot joint that opened in Greenpoint. It has become an indispensable local hangout, mostly for its reliable marriage of cheap drinks and familiar faces.

headline: Five Years After Scandal, Jim Tressel Is Still a Buckeye
abstract: Now in his third year as president of Youngstown State University, the former coach reflects on his time at Ohio State.
lead_paragraph: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio — Jim Tressel greeted the servers one afternoon last week at an 89-year-old Italian restaurant with wood-panel walls. He sat in a booth and crossed his legs. He still had his familiar correct, salt-and-pepper haircut and the same glasses, worn crookedly. He wore a blazer, a tie, a blue sweater — was it a sweater? He flared open one side of his blazer to reveal that yes, it was a sweater vest he had on under there.
