headline: Weathering a Blizzard of Christmas TV Programming
abstract: Television’s avalanche of holiday fare began a few weeks ago on some outlets, and now it is really picking up.
lead_paragraph: If the supposed war on Christmas is still being waged, you’d never know it from the television listings for the next few weeks. Christmas — which conservative critics have complained has been marginalized in our cross-cultural age — is everywhere this season, often right in the titles of specials and made-for-TV movies. And one of the first examples comes Friday night on that most libertine of cable outlets, HBO.

headline: The Farmers We Forgot
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Corn', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: No one really pandered to them. Does that mean no one cares?
lead_paragraph: One cannot rule out a blizzard in Minnesota after Labor Day, and so when I travel for Thanksgiving or any time in the fall, I am careful to fly into Des Moines instead of Minneapolis, and then drive the 200 miles north to my hometown. I like to drive through Iowa during autumn because it turns back time. When I travel straight north, I traverse latitude, moving toward a place where the thaw arrives later in the spring.

headline: Snap Moving to I.P.O. Faster Than Its Peers
abstract: A market debut early next year could get Snap trading ahead of anticipated stock sales by older ventures including Airbnb, Palantir, Pinterest and Uber.
lead_paragraph: Snap wants to be sure youth is not wasted on the young. The company, which offers an app with disappearing messages and pictures, is preparing an initial public offering at the tender age of five years. That is earlier than most of its technologically minded peers, which tend to mature a little more before going public. Snap’s value, however, may yet have some growing to do.

headline: Nikki Haley’s Path: From Daughter of Immigrants to Trump’s Pick for U.N.
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. Haley, the governor of South Carolina, once criticized President-elect Donald J. Trump’s demeanor, but is now his choice for United Nations ambassador.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina is the daughter of immigrants, favors free markets and global trade, and earned international attention for speaking out against the Confederate battle flag in the aftermath of the 2015 massacre at a black church in Charleston. During Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign, she sharply criticized his demeanor and warned what it might mean for American diplomacy — even suggesting that his tendency to lash out at critics could cause a world war.

headline: Pessimistic, Very Pessimistic: Readers’ Moods Darken After Election
abstract: Election results do not have readers feeling positive.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times.

headline: Prize for Migration Project That Weaves Art and Politics
abstract: The New School honors Maria Thereza Alves, whose “Seeds of Change” traces human movement around the globe.
lead_paragraph: Maria Thereza Alves, an artist who helped found Brazil’s Green Party and whose floating-garden pieces explore human migration through the idea of seeds distributed inadvertently around the world in the holds of cargo ships, has won the Vera List Center Prize for Art and Politics. The prize is given every two years to an artist or group whose work furthers social justice.

headline: Review: John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey Compel at Café Carlyle
abstract: This couple’s new show includes songs that tug at emotions as they showcase Ms. Molaskey’s voice and Mr. Pizzarelli’s all-around musicianship.
lead_paragraph: “I come to sing a song about hope.”

headline: Jamaica’s Best New Poet Weighs In
abstract: The young poet Ishion Hutchinson looks to the fractured past and teeming life of Jamaica in “House of Lords and Commons.”
lead_paragraph: HOUSE OF LORDS AND COMMONSBy Ishion Hutchinson81 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23.

headline: A Choreographer Dancing With Ghosts, and the Future
abstract: A new incarnation of Lucinda Childs’s company is opening a two-week season at the Joyce with work both old and new.
lead_paragraph: At 76, Lucinda Childs finds herself in a position she didn’t imagine she’d be in again: running a dance company. “I sort of thought, well that was interesting, and it was great, and I had the 30 years in SoHo,” she said before a rehearsal in Brooklyn last month. “I’m sort of moving on.”

headline: Alvin Ailey’s Robert Battle on His First Real Dance Shoes
abstract: Mr. Battle, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, recalls his childhood in Miami and the works that inspired him.
lead_paragraph: I’ll never forget the impact of my first dance shoes.

headline: Are You Ready for the Biggest Shopping Weekend of the Year?
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Make it meaningful at shops that are donating to good causes, get a free ride with Uber for shopping on Small Business Saturday, and more.
lead_paragraph: Here comes the biggest shopping weekend of the year. This Thanksgiving, Apiece Apart aims to make the whole experience more meaningful by recruiting 10 women-led brands to donate 5 percent of total sales — from Black Friday to Cyber Monday — to Planned Parenthood. Support the cause from the comfort of your couch by purchasing a wrap-style blanket coat ($472.50) from the Apiece Apart website, or head to Rachel Comey, Creatures of Comfort and Maryam Nassir Zadeh if you’re out and about in the city. At apieceapart.com. Rachel Comey is at 95 Crosby Street, Creatures of Comfort is at 205 Mulberry Street, Maryam Nassir Zadeh is at 123 Norfolk Street.

headline: How to Help if Someone Is Being Harassed
abstract: Don’t assume you have to confront the harasser directly.
lead_paragraph: What would you do if you saw someone yelling at a woman on a bus, telling her to take off her hijab? If you saw someone attack an African-American man and tell him Donald Trump could deport him? If you saw a man throw a woman off the sidewalk as she walked her dogs?

headline: William Trevor, Spare Chronicler of Diminished Lives
abstract: Mr. Trevor, who died at 88 at Sunday, fondly depicted lonely Irish and English characters in a polished yet unassuming style.
lead_paragraph: The great Anglo-Irish writer William Trevor, who died on Sunday at 88, was a late bloomer.

headline: Thanksgiving Turkeys May Have Been Tamed 1,500 Years Ago in Mexico
abstract: In a clutch of intact eggs in a fortress in Oaxaca, Mexico, researchers found some of the earliest known signs of turkey domestication.
lead_paragraph: As Americans get ready to carve Thanksgiving turkeys, ponder this question: When was this famous fowl first tamed?

headline: Review: Bruno Mars Delivers Decades of Funk in ‘24K Magic’
abstract: This is the third album from Mr. Mars and his first in four years.
lead_paragraph: The Bruno Mars way-back machine has been one of pop’s most reliable tools in the last few years, and it rarely falls short of complete, uncanny accuracy. His skill for manipulating the past has made him something of an outlier: a retro-minded soul singer, songwriter and producer interested not in strict nostalgia, but in illuminating old styles so they shimmer in a way that’s appealing to a listener not much interested in looking backward.

headline: A Brooklyn Party Where Thankgiving Dinner Is Served on Nude Bodies
abstract: Lust straddles the worlds of sex, performance art and food: “This is a sexy party, not a sex party.”
lead_paragraph: Lust straddles the worlds of sex, performance art and food: “This is a sexy party, not a sex party.”

headline: Does Cranberry Sauce Come With That Flogging?
abstract: Lust straddles the worlds of sex, performance art and dining in Bushwick, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: “Just because someone is wearing lingerie doesn’t mean you can touch them,” said Ellen Robin, the consent guardian at a risqué party held last Thursday in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

headline: Airline Used by Amazon Wins Order to End Cargo Pilots’ Strike
abstract: About 250 pilots for the carrier, ABX Air, went on strike on Tuesday, accusing their employer of forcing them to work an excessive number of flights.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A federal judge on Wednesday ordered striking airline cargo pilots who transport packages for Amazon and other customers to immediately resume work.

headline: Review: ‘Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life’ Revives a Snow Globe Town
abstract: This Netflix mini-series returns viewers to the fictional town of Stars Hollow, Conn., and lets the show’s creator end the show as she had originally planned.
lead_paragraph: Stars Hollow, Conn., would make a great “Twilight Zone” setting.

headline: Soccer in the Philippines Scrambles for a Toehold, With an American Leading the Way
abstract: The Azkals, the national team coached by Thomas Dooley, are competing in the Suzuki Cup. A strong showing could help their sport compete with basketball.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Thomas Dooley has bad memories of the 1998 World Cup. He was a player with the United States back then, when the team lost all three of its games in France. After the tournament, FIFA ranked the 32 participants; it put the Americans last.

headline: Mortgage Rates’ Rise Catches Home Buyers — and Lenders — Off Guard
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Interest Rates', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: Since the election, rates have climbed roughly half a percentage point, adding hundreds, sometimes thousands, of dollars to a buyer’s yearly payments.
lead_paragraph: When Jared Rutledge called his mortgage broker one morning last week after putting in an offer on a home in Glendale, Ariz., just west of Phoenix, he discovered that the 3.8 percent rate he had been quoted a couple of months ago had already gone up to 4.125 percent. That afternoon, it had inched up to 4.25, and by evening, when he finally called back to finalize the deal, it was 4.375 percent.

headline: How Fifth Avenue Is Coping
abstract: Along Fifth Avenue, the luxury stores adjacent to Trump Tower adjust to the none-too-jolly presence of police barricades and bomb-sniffing dogs.
lead_paragraph: It is the beginning of the holiday shopping season on Fifth Avenue, even if the festive spirit is dampened a bit by the long guns of stationed police officers and the regular presence of bomb-sniffing dogs.

headline: Review: ‘If Venice Dies’ Examines a City Sinking, and Not Only Into Water
abstract: A book by Salvatore Settis, an art historian and chairman of the Louvre Museum’s Scientific Council, sounds the alarm about Italy’s fabled metropolis.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, Venice has a been a gorgeous shell — the colorful, fragile remains of its former imperial past. It is a stop on an itinerary, not a final destination. “There is no use pretending that the tourist Venice is not the real Venice,” Mary McCarthy wrote in “Venice Observed,” published in 1956.

headline: Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra Strike Is Resolved
abstract: The strike was resolved after its musicians agreed to freeze their defined benefit pensions and management settled for an initial 7.5 percent wage cut.
lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra settled a 55-day strike on Wednesday, just in time for Thanksgiving. The strike was resolved after its musicians agreed to freeze their defined benefit pensions and management settled for an initial 7.5 percent wage cut, half of what it had been seeking.

headline: Your Dog Remembers
abstract: Researchers are investigating whether dogs share a more complex kind of memory like humans and a few other animals.
lead_paragraph: Researchers are investigating whether dogs share a more complex kind of memory like humans and a few other animals.

headline: Your Dog Remembers More Than You Think
abstract: Researchers are investigating whether dogs share the more complex kind of memory like humans and a few other animals.
lead_paragraph: Once again, science has confirmed the suspicions of dog owners that their beloved pets know more than they are letting on. In this case, it has to do with memory, a favorite subject of researchers who study the mental abilities of other animals.

headline: Outfits Our Brides Have Worn
abstract: A selection of wedding day looks from brides recently featured in our announcements.
lead_paragraph: A selection of wedding day looks from brides recently featured in our announcements.

headline: 5 Ways to Wear Your Work Boots to Work
abstract: For fashion that’s practical but cool, construction workers have some answers.
lead_paragraph: For fashion that’s practical but cool, construction workers have some answers.

headline: 100 Notable Books of 2016
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Two Thousand Sixteen', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: The year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: The year’s notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review. This list represents books reviewed since Dec. 6, 2015, when we published our previous Notables list.

headline: A Holocaust Historian Digs Into His Own Life
abstract: In “Where Memory Leads,” Saul Friedländer writes about his personal, political and scholarly sides.
lead_paragraph: WHERE MEMORY LEADSMy LifeBy Saul Friedländer283 pp. Other Press. $24.95.

headline: No, Trump, We Can’t Just Get Along
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Discrimination']
abstract: You don’t get a pat on the back for ratcheting down from rabid.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump schlepped across town on Tuesday to meet with the publisher of The New York Times and some editors, columnists and reporters at the paper.

headline: From ‘Pitch Perfect’ to Broadway, He’s Vocal About A Cappella
abstract: Deke Sharon discusses his work on “In Transit,” an a cappella musical about the intertwining lives of New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: “You can hear a whoosh of air as the train approaches,” Deke Sharon said, breaking down the cacophony on a subway platform into its component parts. “There’s the high screech of the tires, and underneath it all there’s a low rumble.” For good measure, he emulated each sound.

headline: ‘Economic Tsunami’: Fearing Donald Trump, Immigrants in New York Spend Less
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The city is already starting to feel the effect of Mr. Trump’s election. Immigrants in Latino neighborhoods who face an uncertain future say they have curbed their shopping.
lead_paragraph: In Jackson Heights, Queens, days after the presidential election, an Indian-American jeweler was left holding an order of two custom men’s gold rings worth $3,000. The customer told him he could not pay; he had to go back to his home country before he could be deported.

headline: Donald Trump, Nikki Haley, Jo Cox: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: My Chance to Interview Trump Was Nearly Derailed by a Tweet
abstract: The interview gets canceled in the morning, as do the train tickets. Then it’s back on, and everybody scrambles in a race from D.C. to New York.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times.

headline: Amos Oz: By the Book
abstract: The Israeli author, whose most recent novel is “Judas,” would like to meet Chekhov, if only to gossip with him.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli author, whose most recent novel is “Judas,” would like to meet Chekhov, if only to gossip with him. Gossip, after all, is “a distant cousin of stories and novels,” although they are “embarrassed by this member of their family.”

headline: Jailed by Egypt, Honored for His Photojournalism
keywords: ['vis-photo', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Mahmoud Abou Zeid, known as Shawkan, has been in a Cairo prison for over three years. He has now received an International Press Freedom Award.
lead_paragraph: Photographs capture mere fractions of seconds, but a series of them taken by an Egyptian journalist has cost him more than three years of his life.

headline: A Healthy Serving of Love
abstract: For Shelby Stevens and Chris Long, working together as chefs in the same kitchen helped them to perfect their recipe for marriage. The couple were married on Oct. 30 at the Danforth Inn in Portland, Me.
lead_paragraph: For Shelby Stevens and Chris Long, working together as chefs in the same kitchen helped them to perfect their recipe for marriage. The couple were married on Oct. 30 at the Danforth Inn in Portland, Me.

headline: A Chef-Tested Recipe for Marital Success
abstract: Ferris Bueller had his day off, but for these chefs, finding a time away from work to marry was a tall order.
lead_paragraph: For those ready to wed, setting the date is typically the easy part — that is, unless the couple in question work at the same job and place, and their days off align so rarely that one might encounter a lunar eclipse nearly as often.

headline: Under President Trump, Will the Press Still Be Free?
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Threats and Threatening Messages']
abstract: American journalists see a more urgent need than ever to defend press freedoms at home.
lead_paragraph: The Committee to Protect Journalists, a New York-based advocacy group, usually focuses on the fight for press freedoms overseas. In the past, the group has condemned the persecution of reporters and photographers in Turkey, Egypt, Iran and China, among other countries.

headline: A Less Frenzied Black Friday as Millennials Opt to Stay In
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Millennial Generation', 'E-Commerce', 'Youth']
abstract: Millennials go online for their shopping, leaving a somewhat older crowd at the stores. Discounters like dollar stores may benefit.
lead_paragraph: If you’re in the retail business in the United States, you probably really care about these two things: millennials and Black Friday.

headline: Why Betsy DeVos Won’t Be Able to Privatize U.S. Education
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Vouchers', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Charter Schools']
abstract: Any effort to promote vouchers from Washington would run up against structural realities.
lead_paragraph: We’re resurfacing this article after the narrow confirmation of Betsy DeVos as education secretary on Tuesday. As we noted in November, she will be highly constrained in trying to voucherize American K-12 education.

headline: Met Opera Guild Moves to Sell Memorabilia to Raise Money
abstract: The guild is seeking permission in court to sell off a memorabilia collection with an estimated value of more than $1 million; it wants to divide the proceeds with the Met.
lead_paragraph: When opera companies feel the pinch, it can lead to some pretty interesting rummage sales. The Metropolitan Opera Guild is seeking permission in court to sell off a memorabilia collection — with an estimated value of more than $1 million — that includes a gold cigarette holder that belonged to the bass Ezio Pinza; a jeweled baton owned by the composer Richard Wagner; and a silver, ivory and diamond pen that was used by the composer Giacomo Meyerbeer.

headline: Notable Children’s Books of 2016
abstract: The best in picture books, middle grade and young adult fiction and nonfiction, selected by the children’s books editor of The New York Times Book Review.
lead_paragraph: The best in picture books, middle grade and young adult fiction and nonfiction, selected by the children’s books editor of The New York Times Book Review.

headline: How Ben Carson Could Undo a Desegregation Effort
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Minorities', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A long-debated rule to carry out a neglected provision of the 1968 Fair Housing Act faces an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s civil-rights legacy looked on track, not long ago, to include a major push against America’s deeply entrenched housing segregation. In 2015, his administration rolled out a rule requiring local communities to assess their own patterns of racial and income segregation and make genuine plans to address them.

headline: Trump to Accept Inauguration Funds From Corporations and Big Donors
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Inaugurations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The move represents a continued march back from standards set in 2009 and complicates the president-elect’s pledge to eliminate influence from special interests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump will allow corporations and wealthy individuals to make large donations to fund the activities surrounding his inauguration, complicating his promise to eliminate special interests from influencing his government.

headline: Latest Fed Discussion Reflects More Confidence in Raising Rates
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Inflation (Economics)']
abstract: Officials emphasized that the Fed was planning a slow retreat. And it sounded a cautionary note about the strength of growth in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Federal Reserve officials convened just before the presidential election, they talked like people who were ready to raise interest rates, although they decided to wait a little longer.

headline: Kitten Nursery Provides A Second Chance
abstract: On the Upper East Side of Manhattan, caregivers tend to newborn orphans around the clock. The orphans happen to be kittens, and the A.S.P.C.A. has saved scores of them from being euthanized in overwhelmed city shelters.
lead_paragraph: On the Upper East Side of Manhattan, caregivers tend to newborn orphans around the clock. The orphans happen to be kittens, and the A.S.P.C.A. has saved scores of them from being euthanized in overwhelmed city shelters.

headline: Trump’s Election? Some Students Are Too Busy to Worry
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s victory may have paralyzed some elite campuses, but students at LaGuardia Community College in Queens remained focused on studies and jobs.
lead_paragraph: On a blustery afternoon this past week, the Atrium, a gathering place at LaGuardia Community College, arguably the most ethnically diverse college in the most ethnically diverse quarter of the world — western Queens — seemed especially worn. There was little light streaming in from the windows that overlook a small interior courtyard, the only suggestion of greenery amid a drab array of buildings, and an offering of concession foods that did not put you in mind of Alice Waters’s ministrations in the dining halls at Yale.

headline: Would Trump Have Won Trump University Cases? Evidence Says He Faced Hard Fight
abstract: Sworn statements described a scheme to cheat customers, and sales playbooks called for tapping into “the roller coaster of emotions” to get people to sign up.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump had repeatedly vowed he would not settle the fraud claims facing his defunct for-profit education program, Trump University. But after his election on Nov. 8, the president-elect made a surprising reversal and agreed to pay $25 million to bring the matter to a close — while claiming he would have prevailed at trial.

headline: Two Rooms, 300 Kittens
abstract: At a bunkerlike space in Manhattan, workers and volunteers have tended to 3,500 strays and orphans. At the city’s shelters, kitten euthanasias are down by more than 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: When you’re a kitten, there’s a lot to learn. In a room lined with cages on the Upper East Side of Manhattan one recent afternoon, Imando was getting a lesson in eating solid food.

headline: 142 Years of Sweat, Crafts and Culture at the 92nd Street Y
abstract: The community center dedicated to Jewish life offers a gym, a prestigious nursery, a vast array of classes, and is one of New York City’s premier cultural institutions.
lead_paragraph: Looming above Lexington Avenue, the 92nd Street Y is one of the premier cultural institutions in New York City. It was here that Emma Lazarus taught English to immigrants; here that the Nobel Prize winner Elie Wiesel gave 180 lectures; here that the cellist Yo-Yo Ma made his New York City debut; here that the choreographer Alvin Ailey first presented “Revelations” and that the writer Truman Capote introduced “In Cold Blood.” It is also a great place to swim, throw a clay pot and hear a talk about the women of the Supreme Court.

headline: Hillary Clinton Supporters Call for Vote Recount in Battleground States
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Social Media', 'Electoral College', 'Voting Machines', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: Her supporters have seized on reports by experts suggesting that Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin should manually review paper ballots.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s lead in the popular vote is growing. She is roughly 30,000 votes behind Donald J. Trump in the key swing states of Michigan and Wisconsin — a combined gap that is narrowing. Her impassioned supporters are now urging her to challenge the results in those two states and Pennsylvania, grasping at the last straws to reverse  Mr. Trump’s decisive majority in the Electoral College.

headline: Kenya Drops Doping Charges Against a Top Manager
abstract: Federico Rosa, a leading manager of distance runners, had been accused of abetting the doping of Rita Jeptoo of Kenya, once a top marathoner.
lead_paragraph: As he prepared to board a flight in Kenya for his home in Italy on Wednesday, Federico Rosa, a leading manager of distance runners, said it was one of the happiest days of his life.

headline: How Jon Batiste, Bandleader on ‘Late Show With Stephen Colbert,’ Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Batiste gets up late, prays, meditates, looks at art, plays piano at his teacher’s home and cooks dinner with his girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: Between leading impromptu street parades, performing as the bandleader on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” and fulfilling his duties as an artistic director of the National Jazz Museum in Harlem, Jon Batiste is busy enough. But this year, the Louisiana-born musician and composer also released his first holiday album, “Christmas With Jon Batiste,” a mix of original compositions and remixed classics. Mr. Batiste, 29, who lives alone in Midtown Manhattan, said Sundays offered him a “day of freedom and a time when I take a breather from rehearsals and performing.” SHIVANI VORA

headline: Jared Kushner, Cast as Potential Player on Israel, Is Little Known There
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Palestinians']
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump said this week that Mr. Kushner, his son-in-law, could play a key, if undefined, role in Middle East peace efforts.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — He is friends with the mayor and once tried to buy an Israeli insurance company. His parents’ names are emblazoned across a hospital campus, a tribute to generous donors. But to many Israelis and Palestinians, Jared Kushner is a mystery.

headline: Joakim Noah Is Still Finding His Way With the Knicks
abstract: Noah, who signed a four-year, $72 million deal during the summer, has struggled early on, but his value to the team cannot be weighed on statistics alone.
lead_paragraph: During their last two games, both victories, the Knicks have played some of their most resilient basketball of this still-emerging season. In defeating two possible playoff teams, the Knicks have generally looked cohesive and fluid and, for the most part, defensively stout. Coincidentally, they have done it without Joakim Noah, their marquee off-season signing.

headline: Seaside Goldenrod, a Late Bloomer
abstract: Where conditions are right, masses of the plant’s yellow flowers can be found well into late November.
lead_paragraph: There are still days in late November that manage to slip past 60 degrees. For all of their warmth, the angle of the sun is unmistakable; not as low as it will be as we move toward winter, but well on its way. Shadows stretch for yards by 3 p.m., and by 5, the cold returns and the reprieve from winter is over.

headline: Japanese Superstore in New Jersey Offers Exotica, From Katsu to Kitsch
abstract: Mitsuwa Marketplace in Edgewater, less than a mile from Manhattan, offers food like crabstick croquettes, pop culture items and even a corset face band.
lead_paragraph: Incalculable hours vanish in exploring Mitsuwa Marketplace, a Japanese superstore in Edgewater, N.J. There are aisles of curious condiments, sake and novelties like a corset face band, which belts around the head and purportedly slims it, for $19.99.

headline: Moderate Drinking Tied to Lower Stroke Risk
abstract: Heavier drinking, however, increased the risk of stroke.
lead_paragraph: Having one or two alcoholic drinks a day is associated with a lower risk of stroke, a review of studies has found. But drinking more than that increases the risk.

headline: Overtime Rule Is but the Latest Obama Initiative to End in Texas Court
keywords: ['Federal Courts (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Overtime', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: In the last two years, federal judges in Texas have chipped away at President Obama’s legacy by striking down or suspending no fewer than five regulations and executive orders.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump promised to undo many of the Obama administration’s most ambitious regulations. But even before he takes office, federal courts in Texas are doing some of the work for him.

headline: All the Clamor? Trump’s Palm Beach Neighbors See an Upside
abstract: A security cordon and news trucks descended on the area around the president-elect’s Florida resort, but many residents were blasé about the activity.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — There will be no skinny-dipping this weekend outside the Borislow family’s oceanfront home here: They live across the street from Mar-a-Lago, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s winter resort, and now a Coast Guard patrol boat is parked right outside their window.

headline: Emails Released by Mayor de Blasio’s Office Detail Reliance on Outside ‘Agents’
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'E-Mail', 'Consultants', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The emails, totaling more than 1,550 pages, reveal a City Hall going over the minutiae of press strategy with public relations firms.
lead_paragraph: After months of wrangling with reporters and in court over the disclosure of emails, the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday released a third batch of its correspondence with outside advisers that it has designated as “agents of the city.”

headline: Up for Grabs on Thanksgiving: A Top N.F.C. Spot
abstract: The Lions and the Vikings will duel on Thanksgiving for first place on top of the N.F.C. North. Here’s a look at several Thanksgiving Day matchups and who we think will win.
lead_paragraph: The Thanksgiving Day lineup of N.F.L. games should be fairly appetizing. Here is a look at the matchups and who we think will win them:

headline: 26 Seconds in 1963
abstract: Abraham Zapruder’s film stands as the most famous bystander documentation of a crime.
lead_paragraph: Standing in a choice and sunlit spot along the Dallas parade route that day in November 1963, Abraham Zapruder put his Bell & Howell 414PD to his eye and filmed the 26 seconds that shook Americans to their core.

headline: Edgar Chase Jr., Purveyor of Creole Cuisine, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Chase, a jazz trumpeter known as Dooky, ran his family’s Creole restaurant, which also served as a gathering place for civil rights activists.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Chase Jr., known as Dooky, who with his wife, the chef Leah Chase, turned his family’s New Orleans restaurant into a showcase for Creole cuisine and a gathering spot for activists during the civil rights era, died on Tuesday in New Orleans. He was 88.

headline: Credit With the Coffee Man
abstract: A regular customer is momentarily flummoxed when a street vendor refuses a request to pay the next day.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Ben Zion Shenker, Rabbi Who Wrote Prayer Melodies, Dies at 91
abstract: The rabbi’s music flavored the religious life of Orthodox Jews and influenced klezmer bands.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Ben Zion Shenker, regarded as perhaps the leading composer of Hasidic prayer melodies, whose music flavored the religious life of Orthodox Jews and influenced popular klezmer bands, died on Sunday in Brooklyn. He was 91.

headline: Betsy DeVos, Trump’s Education Pick, Has Steered Money From Public Schools
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education', 'Vouchers', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Charter Schools', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. DeVos, a philanthropist, activist and Republican fund-raiser, has worked to give families vouchers to attend private schools and pressed to expand charter schools.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to find anyone more passionate about the idea of steering public dollars away from traditional public schools than Betsy DeVos, Donald J. Trump’s pick as the cabinet secretary overseeing the nation’s education system.

headline: ‘Why Me?’ Echoed in Ralph Branca’s World, Even Before a Doomed Pitch
abstract: Before giving up the home run that would haunt his career, Branca often wondered aloud at his physical blessings.
lead_paragraph: In 1902, a seamstress named Katherine Berger married a trolley-car conductor named John Branca and spent half of the next 26 years pregnant, giving birth 17 times. One of her children, Ralph Theodore, grew taller than the others. And he was a teenager, the only Branca to reach 6 feet, when he began to wonder why he alone had been so physically blessed.

headline: More Than Coffee: New York’s Vanishing Diner Culture
abstract: With the number of restaurants that call themselves diners and coffee shops dwindling in the city, a devotee wonders how New Yorkers will get along without these antidotes to urban loneliness.
lead_paragraph: For the past 25 years — since the divorce — I’ve lived a good part of my life in diners. Without them I might be slimmer, but also crazier and more unhappy. Judging by the crowds at the Metro Diner, on 100th Street and Broadway, my current haunt, I suspect that other New Yorkers feel the same way.

headline: Obama Lets Bad Puns Fly at Turkey Pardoning Tinged With Sadness
abstract: “I know there are some bad ones in here, but this is the last time I’m doing this, so we’re not leaving any room for leftovers,” he said to some laughter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama officially pardoned two turkeys on Wednesday, in an oddly mournful replaying of a White House Thanksgiving ritual that not even his daughters attended.

headline: Robert Morgenthau on His Years as District Attorney: ‘I Don’t Look Back’
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Series', 'Crime and Criminals', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: Mr. Morgenthau, now 97, saw crime and the city change during his decades as a top prosecutor. As for any mistakes along the way, he says he doesn’t revisit closed chapters.
lead_paragraph: In his early years as a prosecutor, Robert M. Morgenthau was once asked about the most effective way to fight organized crime. At the time, Mr. Morgenthau had made a name for himself as a United States attorney by indicting more than 100 Mafia figures.

headline: Lawyer for Ex-CUNY President Addresses College Officials
abstract: A letter from a lawyer for Ms. Coico, who resigned amid an investigation, placed blame for her legal troubles on top CUNY administrators.
lead_paragraph: A letter from a lawyer for Ms. Coico, who resigned amid an investigation, placed blame for her legal troubles on top CUNY administrators.

headline: Cuomo Seizes On City College Scandal to Revive Push to Revamp CUNY
abstract: A letter on behalf of the recently departed president of the school blaming top administrators for a scandal she is ensnared in seems to have energized the governor’s ethics campaign.
lead_paragraph: When Catherine Leahy Scott, the New York State inspector general, criticized the financial and management practices at the City University of New York in a report last week as “ripe for abuse,” she urged that “significant steps are immediately taken.”

headline: Bus in Crash That Killed 6 in Chattanooga Had Strayed From Route
abstract: The announcement of a sixth death came hours after the chief executive of the school district’s busing contractor offered an emotional apology.
lead_paragraph: The National Transportation Safety Board said Wednesday that the school bus that crashed on Monday in Chattanooga, Tenn., killing six students, was not traveling along its regular route when it wrecked.

headline: Successfully Brings Around
abstract: A debut by Brian J. MacDonald.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — As we close in on my favorite food holiday of the year, I’d like to take the time to wish Wordplay readers a happy and peaceful Thanksgiving.

headline: The Farmers of Delaware County
abstract: In 2015, the photographer Tess Mayer sought to document “how farming shapes people” in Delaware County, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, the photographer Tess Mayer sought to document “how farming shapes people” in Delaware County, N.Y.

headline: Crops of Old and New Farmers in Delaware County
abstract: The photographer Tess Mayer, interested in “how farming shapes people,” documented new farmers with urban ties and the deeply rooted farm families in New York’s Southern Tier.
lead_paragraph: Tess Mayer, 21, grew up among farmers’ children in Delaware County, in the Southern Tier region of New York. “I had chickens but nothing beyond that,” she said. She graduated high school early and, eager for cosmopolitan life, moved to New York City to attend New York University. But she went home on breaks, and upon returning to her small town of Bovina, Ms. Mayer recalled, she became interested in “how farming shapes people.”

headline: Penguins Pay Back the Rangers With a Rout
abstract: Two days after the Rangers beat the Stanley Cup champions on their own ice, the Penguins asserted themselves with a stunning second-period flurry.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers have been impressive, particularly at home, for the first six weeks of the season. First place in the Metropolitan Division is theirs, at least for the moment, giving their fans reason to ponder their playoff possibilities in the spring.

headline: Nikki Haley, Martin Schulz, Black Friday: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Kate Bush Is Running Up That Concert Stage for a Giant Live Album
abstract: The influential love-her-or-hate-her British art-pop singer releases “Before the Dawn,” a set based on her 2014 London shows.
lead_paragraph: For three days at Pinewood Studios in London, Kate Bush strapped on a life preserver, plunged into a tank of water and sang to a camera. The first day, she stayed immersed so long that she ended up with mild hypothermia; she hadn’t yet been advised to take breaks. And at least part of the time, she said in a cheery telephone interview earlier this month from her home in England, she was thinking, “My God, what am I doing?”

headline: Corrections: November 24, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, November 24, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, November 24, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I think e-commerce has allowed for Black Friday to start whenever Amazon wants it to start.”

headline: Iraq Told Civilians to Stay in Mosul. Now They’re Paying With Their Lives.
abstract: With more and more civilians caught up in the battle to take Mosul from the Islamic State, some military officials are second-guessing their initial strategy.
lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq — By the time little Amira, just a year old, reached the field clinic near the front line in Mosul, she was already dead. All her father could do was bundle her up in a golden blanket, carry her to a nearby mosque and bury her.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday: Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade and ‘The Simpsons 600 Marathon’
abstract: Turkey Day television for almost any palate, from the 90th edition of the Macy’s parade to a marathon of “The Simpsons.”
lead_paragraph: Turkey Day television caters to almost any appetite — from the 90th edition of the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade to a marathon of “The Simpsons” perfect for the overindulgent who can’t raise themselves from the couch.

headline: In the History of U.S.-China Relations, a Pattern of Enchantment and Despair
abstract: The journalist John Pomfret discusses the subject of his new book: the complex history of interactions between the countries, from 1776 to the present.
lead_paragraph: For his second book, John Pomfret, a journalist with extensive experience in China, has taken a microscope to an enormous subject: the relationship between the United States and China, from 1776 to the present. With growing stress points in that relationship and the emergence of strongman leaders in both nations, the book, “The Beautiful Country and the Middle Kingdom,” arrives during a precarious inflection point. It is peppered with characters that Mr. Pomfret uses to trace a long historical arc, from Howqua, a Cantonese tycoon, to Herbert Yardley, a prominent American cryptographer, and Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former United States Treasury secretary.

headline: Construction Collapse in Southeast China Kills Dozens at Power Plant
abstract: Rescuers were searching for survivors after a scaffold collapsed on Thursday inside a cooling tower being built at a coal power plant in Jiangxi Province.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Dozens of workers were crushed to death under an avalanche of scaffolding, cement and steel rods in southeast China on Thursday after a platform in an unfinished tower of a coal power plant collapsed.

headline: The First Amnesty
abstract: America’s first illegal-alien amnesty wasn’t the biggest in our history, but it was the most influential.
lead_paragraph: America’s first illegal-alien amnesty wasn’t the biggest in our history, but it was the most influential, since we’re still talking about it.

headline: Mr. Trump: I Am an Immigrant With a Criminal Record
abstract: I made a mistake, but I have paid for it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I arrived in the United States on Nov. 12, 1981, when I was 1. My parents had fled the Pol Pot genocide in Cambodia, in which over two million people were murdered. I was born in a refugee camp in Thailand before moving to California, and then Virginia.

headline: Carving Donald Trump
abstract: Pass the stuffing and wave the olive branch.
lead_paragraph: On Thanksgiving, Americans sat down to dinner, looked at the big turkey and thought about Donald Trump.

headline: Chasing Abortion Rights Across the State Line
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: Donald Trump’s support for leaving abortion to the states resonates with a dark period when “separate but equal” was the law of the land.
lead_paragraph: Half slave and half free. The last time the United States split into two countries, it didn’t work out at all well.

headline: No Experience, No Problem
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Editorials']
abstract: The president-elect’s transition has drawn a crowd of job seekers of varying ideological hues and experience levels.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald Trump’s transition has been a circus, to say the least, with a colorful and eclectic crowd of job seekers of varying ideological hues and levels of experience ascending to the 26th floor of Trump Tower to audition for some of the most consequential jobs in the country. The man who spent years saying “you’re fired” is now saying “you’re hired” to all sorts of people, though it’s not at all clear whether his choices result from a carefully thought-out strategy or are being made on the fly.

headline: This Merciful Year
abstract: Did you miss the pope’s Extraordinary Jubilee Year? It’s not too late.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in a big Irish Catholic family, I knew the liturgical seasons of the year — Advent, Christmas, Lent, Triduum, Easter and Ordinary Time. But I don’t remember hearing much about Jubilee Years, which occur about every 25 years, let alone about Extraordinary Jubilee Years, which are called out of that cycle to commemorate a special moment in the Roman Catholic Church’s history or highlight an important issue. Since the church began celebrating Jubilee Years in 1300, only a few Extraordinary Jubilees have been called — including the one that ended this week.

headline: Warning Russia on Hacking Isn’t Enough
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Because Mr. Trump, an outspoken admirer of Mr. Putin, is unlikely to act, it is up to Mr. Obama to hold the Russian president to account.
lead_paragraph: After the stunning disclosures last month that Russia had tried to interfere with the election by hacking the Democratic National Committee, the Obama administration hinted at some kind of retaliation. So far, however, its only known response has been to publicly identify the Russians as the culprits and warn them against interfering again in America’s democratic processes.

headline: ‘Mock Duck’ and Other Depression Thanksgiving Delights
abstract: An era when canned vegetables and lemon gelatin with cranberry-tinted mayonnaise were extolled for their convenience and chic.
lead_paragraph: Eighty-five years ago this month, President Herbert Hoover followed tradition and proclaimed the final Thursday of November a day of national Thanksgiving, an unenviable task given the circumstances. America was two years into the Great Depression, the unemployment rate was more than 15 percent, and millions more despaired for the future. The president’s rhetorical strategy was to bob and weave, extolling the country’s “abundant harvests” and downgrading the Depression to a “passing adversity.”

headline: Trump Won. Still Moving to Canada?
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Families and Family Life', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Restaurants', 'Celebrities']
abstract: Also, when blended families are too big to blend in one house, and revisiting holiday food clashes.
lead_paragraph: I live in Los Angeles, but I am spending Thanksgiving week with my parents in the heartland. My brother lives near them. Unfortunately, before the election, I threatened to move to Canada if Trump won. Cut to: Trump won, and I have no plans to move. My brother (32 going on 16) has seized on this, asking me (literally) every time he sees me: “So, when will you be moving to Montreal? Or is it Toronto?” This is getting really annoying. So far, I have ignored him. How should I deal with his foolishness — and mine?

headline: At Home With the Macabre
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Ghosts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: With the New York real estate market so competitive, people are now less fazed by apartments with ghoulish histories.
lead_paragraph: On the way to show an apartment in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, the real estate agent turned to the prospective renters and said something unnecessary.

headline: A Tiny Home That Floats
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Boats and Boating', 'Sailboats and Sailing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: About 30 people live year-round on their boats at the 79th Street Boat Basin.
lead_paragraph: As far as places to live go, Jane Clegg considers hers nearly perfect.

headline: 36 Hours in Delhi
abstract: Explore the city’s innumerable charms — ruin-studded gardens, a growing contemporary art scene, diverse regional cuisines.
lead_paragraph: Explore the city’s innumerable charms — ruin-studded gardens, a growing contemporary art scene, diverse regional cuisines.

headline: New York Buys Last Tract for Williamsburg Waterfront Park for $160 Million
abstract: The city said this week it had acquired the outstanding portion of Bushwick Inlet Park, a green space meant to transform an industrial stretch along the East River in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A patchwork of weeds, rusted refineries, dilapidated warehouses and pollution-soaked land along the East River in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn has long held the unfulfilled dream of local residents.

headline: Has a Start-Up Found the Secret to Farming the Elusive Truffle?
abstract: The American Truffle Company has a new technique that it says can expand the range of the Perigord truffle in North America, but success is proving costly.
lead_paragraph: NAPA, Calif. — Gig the truffle dog zigzags with her nose to the ground among hundreds of oak and filbert trees. Her goal is to sniff out the Perigord truffle, a fungus so prized by chefs it is called the diamond in the kitchen.

headline: A Macy’s Parade Balloon Comes to Life
abstract: Stand curbside as the parade balloons are inflated the day before Thanksgiving. Watch as the newest character is revealed.
lead_paragraph: Stand curbside as the parade balloons are inflated the day before Thanksgiving. Watch as the newest character is revealed.

headline: Perils of Climate Change Could Swamp Coastal Real Estate
keywords: ['Floods', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Flood Insurance', 'Coastal Areas', 'Global Warming', 'Mortgages']
abstract: Homeowners are slowly growing wary of buying property in the areas most at risk, setting up a potential economic time bomb in an industry that is struggling to adapt.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Real estate agents looking to sell coastal properties usually focus on one thing: how close the home is to the water’s edge. But buyers are increasingly asking instead how far back it is from the waterline. How many feet above sea level? Is it fortified against storm surges? Does it have emergency power and sump pumps?

headline: In the Chamber of Secrets: J.K. Rowling’s Net Worth
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Harry Potter (Fictional Character)', 'Movies', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The author’s wealth is a closely guarded secret, but she is most likely a billionaire. She’s also a role model, and no one seems to resent her success.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, Forbes dropped J. K. Rowling after eight years on its authoritative billionaires list, saying high British taxes and large charitable contributions had eroded her fortune.

headline: Mark Oldman, Wine Writer, on His Favorite Destinations
abstract: Surprisingly great wine region? Tasmania. And consider the Shenandoah Valley in Virginia and southern England too.
lead_paragraph: According to the wine writer Mark Oldman, 47, drinking wine is only a part of its enjoyment. “In order to truly appreciate a good wine,” he said, “you need to make a pilgrimage to its source.”

headline: Review: A Chilly ‘Miss Sloane’ Makes a Lecture Out of Lobbying
abstract: Jessica Chastain stars as a win-at-all-costs lobbyist in this Washington-based political thriller.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Chastain rules the Washington-based political thriller “Miss Sloane” with such steely authority that you are hard pressed to imagine another actress playing the imperious, largely unsympathetic title character. In the opening moments, Elizabeth Sloane, a formidable Washington lobbyist, legendary for her deviousness and determination to win at all costs, impassively describes her professional modus operandi. “Lobbying,” she declares, gazing straight into a camera, is about “foresight.” It involves anticipating an opponent’s next move and calculating your response ahead of time so that nothing takes you by surprise.

headline: Review: ‘Lion’ Brings Tears for a Lost Boy, Wiped Dry by Google
abstract: Saroo’s journey begins when he accidentally travels more than 1,000 miles from his home in central India to the streets of Calcutta.
lead_paragraph: The first part of “Lion,” Garth Davis’s unabashedly tear-jerking movie about a remarkable real-world incident, has some of the scary, wondrous feeling of a fairy tale. The audience is invited to imagine a long-ago time — 1986, to be precise — before social media or smartphones or Google. In those days, a person could get lost, which is just what happens to a little boy named Saroo (Sunny Pawar), who accidentally travels more than 1,000 miles from his home in central India to the streets of Calcutta.

headline: ‘It Was Very Exciting, You Know, for a Schoolboy’
abstract: Tom Leimdorfer describes the trip over the Austrian border.
lead_paragraph: Tom Leimdorfer describes the trip over the Austrian border.

abstract: He felt hesitance to run from circumstances that seemed to be on the cusp of change.
lead_paragraph: He felt hesitance to run from circumstances that seemed to be on the cusp of change.

abstract: Harrowing memories from what started out as a quiet day at a shop.
lead_paragraph: Harrowing memories from what started out as a quiet day at a shop.

abstract: The souring of the relationship is one consequence of Turkey’s political crackdown after a failed coup in July.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Parliament voted on Thursday to suspend talks with Turkey on European Union membership, the most forceful response yet to the crackdown by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan against political opponents.

headline: ‘The Whole Focus of Western Politics Has Shifted Away From Hungary’
abstract: The Soviet Union was seen to have the “perfect excuse” to crack down on the rebellion, and other world powers’ priorities were elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union was seen to have the “perfect excuse” to crack down on the rebellion, and other world powers’ priorities were elsewhere.

lead_paragraph: In London, a culture of tolerance mixed with the notion that “aliens were aliens.”

headline: As Wildfires Rage, Israel Suggests Arson and Asks for Foreign Help
abstract: Areas of the northern port city of Haifa were ablaze, with homes damaged, dozens of people slightly injured and tens of thousands evacuated.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Parts of the port city of Haifa in northern Israel were ablaze on Thursday as wildfires raged through the country for a third day, devouring forests, damaging homes and prompting the evacuation of tens of thousands of people.

headline: ‘The Refugee Feeling Begins to Drop Away’
abstract: He and a friend from Hungary are brought along for a summer experience with new peers.
lead_paragraph: He and a friend from Hungary are brought along for a summer experience with new peers.

headline: ‘How Can Hungary Build a New Iron Curtain?’
abstract: Discomfort with the stark contrast seen in the migrants’ experience with Hungary today.

headline: ‘This Is What Europe Was Meant to Be’
abstract: His multinational family is a symbol of the welcome he feels migrants should still receive.
lead_paragraph: His multinational family is a symbol of the welcome he feels migrants should still receive.
