abstract: Living a teenager’s life, but picking up on apprehensions in the air.
lead_paragraph: Living a teenager’s life, but picking up on apprehensions in the air.

headline: What to Do When the Turkey’s Done
abstract: Two movies and one art show to see this holiday season.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving is overrated. Or maybe it’s just mischaracterized. The food is important, but eating it takes, what, 20 minutes? What about the rest of your holiday? What about the rest of your weekend?

headline: A Video Project Reconnects Homeless People With Families
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Social Media', 'Families and Family Life', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Miracle Messages has recorded more than 130 videos, delivered 43 and reunited 26 families.
lead_paragraph: When Isaac Avila stopped sending his mother birthday and Christmas cards, his family knew something was wrong.

headline: An Exercise to Sift for Sources Amid a Blitz of Fake News
abstract: A web-sifting exercise that helps students of all ages figure out how facts or fakery flow online.
lead_paragraph: Something tells me you may have noticed that fake news is in the headlines, most recently through the blitz of fact-free web fare during the presidential campaign and a new Stanford University study showing, as NPR put it, that “Students Have ‘Dismaying’ Inability To Tell Fake News From Real.”

headline: Martin Schulz, President of European Parliament, Will Return to German Politics
abstract: Mr. Schulz might challenge Chancellor Angela Merkel in next year’s elections. In another scenario, he might become foreign minister.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Martin Schulz, the president of the European Parliament since 2012, announced on Thursday his return to German politics, fueling speculation that he might challenge Chancellor Angela Merkel, who plans to seek a fourth term in elections next year.

headline: American Is Killed in First Casualty for U.S. Forces in Syria Combat
abstract: The service member was killed by an improvised explosive device on Thursday, the United States military said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United States military suffered its first combat death in Syria on Thursday when a service member was killed in the northern part of the country, an area where the Americans are helping to organize an offensive against the Islamic State.

headline: What You Should Watch on Thanksgiving With a Disparate Group, Including Kids
abstract: Margaret Lyons has four recommendations for your Thanksgiving television viewing.
lead_paragraph: It’s Thanksgiving, which means that people need to be able to come and go from the TV area and still follow what’s happening, which is why any reality-contest show will fit the bill. But above all, you seek “The Great British Baking Show.” This is the most earnest and enjoyable of any reality-contest show in living memory, and the skills and passion on display are significant and inspiring. (“Masterclass” episodes, with Paul and Mary, are free to stream on PBS; three seasons are available for members of Thirteen and other participating PBS broadcasters.)

headline: What You Should Watch on Thanksgiving With a (Child-Free) Group
abstract: Thanksgiving often means a lot of together time. Here are some TV recommendations to please disparate tastes.
lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving not the time to finally watch “The Wire,” or anything too dialogue-rich: People chitchat, someone gets up to stir something — you don’t want to be shushing people or asking everyone to pause stuff while you check on the pies. It’s time for solid shows that still don’t require tremendous brainpower. Go with “Prison Break,” Fox’s big, twisty, drama answer to “Lost” from 2005. Season 1 is a solid action soap, although the show grows exhausting after that. (Netflix)

headline: The Sugar Plum Fairy: An Enigma Wrapped in a Beautiful Dance
abstract: This character in “The Nutcracker” is well known, but hardly understood.
lead_paragraph: Few characters in ballet are more renowned than the Sugar Plum Fairy. People who’ve never been to any ballet, let alone “The Nutcracker,” have heard of her. Yet who is she? And why does she dance? When she enters to dance a grand pas de deux with her cavalier, what’s going on between them? Is he her consort or her squire? Is this supposed to be love? Why is Tchaikovsky’s music for their grand adagio so unsugary, so imposing, so colossal? What choreography can catch its essence?

headline: Settle in for These Thanksgiving TV and Movie Marathons
abstract: Seven suggestions for Thanksgiving bloc viewing.
lead_paragraph: If you want to just turn today to a single channel and let something wash over you and your family, here are a few ideas for movie and TV marathons on this Thanksgiving.

headline: From a House to a One-Bedroom, for Family’s Sake
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Lien and Tam Nguyen wanted to be closer to their family. So their son bought them an apartment.
lead_paragraph: Lien and Tam Nguyen left Vietnam for the United States in 1975, just before the fall of Saigon. They settled near Richmond, Va., where Lien Nguyen worked as a hairdresser and Tam Nguyen in a chemical plant, often on the night shift.

headline: One Money Question to Rule Them All: How Much Is Enough?
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Retirement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy']
abstract: We can get an idea of what to us feels like enough money by getting a baseline on spending and quantity, then homing in on quality.
lead_paragraph: As we enter this season of contemplation and reflection, we all have more than the usual number of everyday financial questions weighing on us.

headline: Paint Your Nails With Patriarchy!
keywords: ['Nails (Body Part)', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: How in the world did nail polish become so sexist?
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — I’ve never really understood the point of meticulously painting your nails, but even so, I’m surprised by how hard cosmetic companies work to make it sound interesting. From Russia to Brazil, many women have faced tough choices between colors like “Rose Petal,” “Wedding Pearl” and “Pink Champagne.”

headline: House-Hunting in Hong Kong With the App That Sees Dead People
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Superstitions', 'Haunted Houses', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: A hand-held search tool that shows where someone has died unnaturally can aid the fearful — or the skeptic looking for bargains in a sky-high housing market.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Ship Street is quintessentially Hong Kong, even serving as the backdrop to several local movies.

headline: How Can Latin America Move to Low-Carbon Energy?
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Solar Energy', 'Wind Power', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: The region displays both troubling and encouraging trends in energy policy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Climate negotiators convened in Morocco, this month to discuss how to turn the Paris climate accord into action. The accord, signed by almost 200 countries last year, came into force on Nov. 4. Many questions persist about how each country can move toward the zero carbon-energy target that experts say is necessary to avoid destructive climate change. Some parts of the world are better positioned than others to take this test. Latin America is a good example.

headline: Review: A New ‘42nd Street’ Opens in Paris
abstract: With precise dancing and ingenious special effects, Stephen Mear’s production offers a diversion from reality.
lead_paragraph: “Musical comedy — the most glorious words in the English language!” So intones the character Julian Marsh midway through the musical “42nd Street,” which opened Nov. 17 at the Théâtre du Châtelet here in a new production directed by Stephen Mear.

headline: The Gift of Grace
abstract: Is it possible to find grace in the context of a cancer death?
lead_paragraph: An email I received from a reader some time ago has begun to haunt me. The reader’s sister was dying of cancer. How, she asked me, would I respond to the word “grace” in the context of a cancer death?

headline: She’s the Hollywood Power Behind Those Seeking a Voice
abstract: The entertainment lawyer Nina L. Shaw is adept at striking deals for those whose mission it is to be both artist and advocate.
lead_paragraph: Lupita Nyong’o calls her “badass.” Ava DuVernay says, “She’s a big part of my creative process.” The ballerina Misty Copeland has her to thank, in part, for the ads that made her a household name, not to mention her namesake Barbie doll. And Raoul Peck, the director of the bold documentary “I Am Not Your Negro,” says that he couldn’t have made his film, a current awards season contender, without her.

headline: 1916: Pirates Sank the Britannic
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: A German submarine torpedoes the British hospital ship Britannic off the coast of the Island of Zea in the Aegean Sea, during World War I, in November 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Despatches from Athens agree that the British hospital ship Britannic, of 50,000 tons, was torpedoed by a German submarine between eight and nine o’clock on Tuesday morning, a trifle more than two miles off the Island of Zea, while en route for Mudros, the port of Lemnos, in the Aegean Sea, where she was to take on board sick and wounded. She sank about fifty-five minutes after being struck.

headline: He Fished Every Morning of Summer. And Was Home by 7 A.M.
abstract: An angler’s daily pursuit of striped bass leads to lessons, and puzzle-solving, about wildlife and nature.
lead_paragraph: BOWDOINHAM, Maine — The striped bass arrived with a bang this spring on Maine’s Kennebec River, a melee of swirling currents, careening gulls and breaking fish. After several years of disappointing action, their annual migration north from the Chesapeake stirred in me an excitement I hadn’t expected.

headline: The Glorious Achievement of Zipping Up a Sweatshirt
abstract: Kenerly Alvarez, 4, has Down syndrome, and her father is disabled, but the Manhattan family is making progress with the assistance of a center that helps children with developmental delays.
lead_paragraph: Jose Alvarez has trouble sleeping. It is the pain from his back injury. It is the stress of paying the bills. It is the worry that his daughter will never live a normal life.

headline: Black Friday Shopping: Tales From the Front Lines
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: We’re capturing the scene with reporters around the country showing what it looks and feels like at American shopping malls, retailers and discount stores.
lead_paragraph: The unofficial start of the holiday shopping season began this week, when many national retailers opened their doors and offered major sales.

headline: Happy Thanksgiving
abstract: These are some stressful affairs, these dinners. Take a little time for yourself.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Moonlight’
abstract: Barry Jenkins narrates a swimming sequence from “Moonlight” featuring Alex Hibbert and Mahershala Ali.
lead_paragraph: Barry Jenkins narrates a swimming sequence from “Moonlight” featuring Alex Hibbert and Mahershala Ali.

headline: Barry Jenkins Narrates a Scene From ‘Moonlight’
abstract: The director discusses a swimming sequence from his film featuring Alex Hibbert and Mahershala Ali.
lead_paragraph: A man teaching a boy how to swim turns into a powerful moment of communion in this scene from “Moonlight,” directed by Barry Jenkins. The film explores a young black man’s coming-of-age in Miami.

headline: 1964 | A President on The Times’s Lunch Menu
abstract: The Times is often visited by V.I.P.s, but Donald J. Trump was the first president-elect. And Lyndon B. Johnson was the last sitting president.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

headline: The Risk with Betsy DeVos
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Education reform has had some big successes — but the version that DeVos favors has been more worrisome.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

headline: With a Fixer-Upper in the Nets, Kenny Atkinson Starts by Building Rapport
abstract: Atkinson, in his first year as a head coach, learned the importance of conversation as an assistant. He envisions his team as a democracy, though he holds veto power.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After the Nets lost their second game in two days last week, Kenny Atkinson, the team’s first-year coach, met with his staff in a small room next to the visiting locker room at Staples Center. The primary topic of conversation: What did they want to do with the players the next day?

headline: Parading on Thanksgiving Day in Manhattan
abstract: Before the holiday meal, it was a feast of balloons, floats and marching bands.
lead_paragraph: Before the holiday meal, it was a feast of balloons, floats and marching bands.

headline: Indian Vendors See Empty Stores and Blame a Rupee Ban
abstract: When Prime Minister Narendra Modi banned the 500- and 1,000-rupee bills, his goal was to spur the economy. But the move seems to be having the opposite effect.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In the winding lanes of Chawri Bazar, one of Delhi’s oldest wholesale markets, paper merchants sat slumped in their stores, pondering how to make the transition to the new economic order ushered in by the Indian prime minister two weeks ago.

headline: Knife-Wielding Man Shot After Pepper Spray Fails to Subdue Him, Police Say
abstract: Shamel Jones, 19, was critically wounded in the confrontation with officers in the Bronx. He was expected to recover.
lead_paragraph: A man wielding a footlong kitchen knife was shot by a police officer in the Bronx this week after the man refused to drop the weapon and could not be subdued with pepper spray, the authorities said.

headline: Movie Trailers: ‘Rogue One,’ ‘Fantastic Beasts’ and the Franchise Challenge
abstract: In less than three minutes, trailers must make the case for a movie and its overall saga.
lead_paragraph: “Rogue One: A Star Wars Story,” set for release Dec. 16, occupies a challenging place in the “Star Wars” universe. Though it’s billed as a stand-alone story, the movie takes place between earlier trilogies of the “Star Wars” saga, managing to be both prequel and sequel in a franchise that already has plenty of them. And past extensions of “Star Wars” haven’t always been well received, even by die-hard fans.

headline: ‘Something Is Wrong’: Fresh Fish Vanish From Beijing Stores, Raising Suspicions
keywords: ['Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Food', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Shortages']
abstract: Freshwater fish like carp have disappeared from tanks at supermarkets in the capital, with little explanation to wary Chinese consumers bruised by food safety scares.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In supermarkets across the Chinese capital, shoppers have been staring, baffled by empty fish tanks and asking: Where have all the fish gone?

headline: Ida Lupino, a Woman of Spine on Both Sides of the Lens
abstract: Ms. Lupino proves her mettle as an actress in “Road House” (1948) and “On Dangerous Ground” (1952). In other films, she was equally impressive as a director.
lead_paragraph: Of all the actresses associated with film noir, Ida Lupino (1918-1995) seems the most complex. Ms. Lupino could be as sultry and sassy as Lauren Bacall while projecting an aching vulnerability. As world-weary as Gloria Grahame, she never came across as fragile, particularly in her subsequent work as a director.

headline: ISIS Bomb Aimed at Shiite Pilgrims in Iraq Kills at Least 80
abstract: The pilgrims, who were returning to Iran after a journey to observe Arbaeen, were killed by a truck bomb at a roadside service station.
lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — At least 80 people, many of them Shiite pilgrims on their way home to Iran, were killed on Thursday when an Islamic State suicide bomber detonated a truck filled with explosives at a roadside service station in southern Iraq, local officials said.

headline: Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago Plans $16 Million Renovation
abstract: The redesign by the Los Angeles architects Johnston Marklee is expected to be completed by June 2017.
lead_paragraph: While many art museums have pursued big-budget expansions in their bids for larger and more loyal audiences, the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago is rethinking and reconfiguring its public spaces without altering its basic footprint downtown. This week the museum revealed plans for a $16 million renovation by the Los Angeles architects Johnston Marklee, led by Sharon Johnston and Mark Lee.

headline: Trump Signs, Trees and Accusations That a New York Agency Is Biased
abstract: When his signs supporting Donald J. Trump for president were stolen or vandalized at his home in Queens, Michael Ricatto tried to catch the perpetrator. What happened next was a surprise.
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to the presidential election, New York City was hardly Trump territory.

headline: Disney’s ‘Moana’ Surpasses ‘Frozen’ in Pre-Thanksgiving Box Office
abstract: The studio’s new animated movie did better on Wednesday, its first day of release, than Disney’s blockbuster did upon its debut in the same period in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Disney looks like it is beating itself going into this Thanksgiving weekend. The studio’s latest animated offering, “Moana,” about a defiant Polynesian princess on a heroine’s quest to save her people and restore the planet’s ecological balance, took in $15.6 million at the box office Wednesday, its first full day of release, running ahead of the studio’s smash hit “Frozen,” which drew $15.16 million on Thanksgiving Eve in 2013. While “Moana” is projected to earn more than $80 million over the five-day holiday weekend, that wouldn’t melt “Frozen,” which still holds the Thanksgiving five-day opening record, of $93.6 million. With runaway hits like “Finding Dory” and “Zootopia” under its belt, and “Rogue One: A Star Wars Story” looming, Disney is having a banner year. “Moana” is also holding a 97 percent fresh rating on the review-aggregation site Rotten Tomatoes, a hair behind “Zootopia,” at 98 percent.

headline: Colombia and FARC Sign New Peace Deal, This Time Skipping Voters
abstract: After a previous deal was rejected last month in a referendum, the president signed modified accords that will instead go to Congress, which his governing coalition controls.
lead_paragraph: The Colombian government and the country’s main rebel group signed a new peace deal on Thursday, hoping to salvage the accords and skip the ballot box after voters rejected the agreement in a referendum the month before.

headline: Trump Cites Progress in Keeping Carrier Air Conditioning Plant in Indiana
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Donald J. Trump, who had made coming job losses at a Carrier plant a campaign issue, said he had reached out to the company.
lead_paragraph: Following up on a campaign promise that appealed directly to his Rust Belt base, President-elect Donald J. Trump said Thursday that he had reached out to the Carrier air conditioner company in Indiana to ask it not to move more than 2,000 factory jobs from Indiana to Mexico.

headline: Wilbur Ross, Billionaire Investor, Is Said to Be Trump’s Commerce Pick
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: After choosing national security hard-liners for some of his earliest appointments, the president-elect is turning to ultrawealthy conservatives.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump is expected to select as commerce secretary Wilbur Ross, a billionaire investor who became known as the “king of bankruptcy” for buying, restructuring and selling off steel makers and other fading industrial companies, officials on the transition team said on Thursday.

headline: Review: Alton Brown, a Mad Culinary Scientist in a Broadway Laboratory
abstract: In “Alton Brown Live: Eat Your Science,” the Food Network personality serves up a menu of challenging fare. Tequila and pumpkin spice liqueur with mouthwash, anyone?
lead_paragraph: If Alton Brown, the Food Network celebrity, offers you a cocktail, refuse it. Maybe you are parched. Maybe you are in alcohol withdrawal. Maybe you have thought that clinking glasses with the host of “Good Eats” and “Cutthroat Kitchen” would be a fine thing. Even so, don’t do it. Never forget that this is the man who coined the term “evilicious.”

headline: Review: ‘Mifune: The Last Samurai’ Celebrates a Fearless Actor
abstract: The documentary, narrated by Keanu Reeves, interviews directors, actors and others to gain insights into Toshiro Mifune’s sword-fighting bravado and stoicism.
lead_paragraph: “Mifune: The Last Samurai” is a celebration of the originality and influence of the Japanese star Toshiro Mifune (1920-1997), shown as a rare actor capable of the subtlest stoicism and the wildest bravado. It’s a brisk and energetic primer for those who don’t know his movies or are ready to watch them again. And it doubles as a history of the chanbara (sword fighting) genre, providing an opportunity to sample clips from seldom-seen or partially lost silent films.

headline: Review: In ‘Tank 432,’ on the Run, but Stuck in a Morass
abstract: This British thriller concerns a band of people in combat gear trying to avoid attackers.
lead_paragraph: “No animals were hurt during the production of this film — only humans,” reads a line toward the end of the closing credits of “Tank 432.” That’s a good hook for an exploitation film, but it deserves a snappier movie than the one it’s attached to. This British thriller is a high-concept tease that slogs its way through a morass of barely differentiated characters and visuals before reaching an unsatisfying conclusion.

headline: Review: The Nature Documentary ‘Seasons’ Looks at Land Animals
abstract: Jacques Perrin and Jacques Cluzaud, whose projects include ‘Winged Migration’ and ‘Oceans,’ explore the fate of the forests that once covered Europe.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in edenic tranquillity and ending in death and destruction, “Seasons,” the mesmeric nature documentary from Jacques Perrin and Jacques Cluzaud, doesn’t make you feel particularly proud to be human.

headline: One by One, ISIS Social Media Experts Are Killed as Result of F.B.I. Program
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'Propaganda', 'Social Media', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)']
abstract: American officials say a secretive campaign of surveillance and drone attacks has cut the Islamic State’s ability to inspire attacks in the West.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the summer of 2015, armed American drones over eastern Syria stalked Junaid Hussain, an influential hacker and recruiter for the Islamic State.

headline: Review: ‘Evolution’ Goes to a Magical Place You Wouldn’t Want to Live In
abstract: A young boy’s creepy childhood in a picturesque seaside village with an unsettling goings-on.
lead_paragraph: The opening shots of “Evolution,” the long-awaited new feature from Lucile Hadzihalilovic, show a sumptuous underwater environment. (Her last full-length film, the eerie and provocative “Innocence,” came out in 2004.) The sea is so clear one might be tempted to breathe it in; the colors of the undulating forms of plant and animal life are psychedelic and virtually tactile. A young boy swimming in these waters is startled by the sight of another boy, drowned, a garishly red starfish covering his navel.

headline: Cause of Severe Injury at Pipeline Protest Becomes New Point of Dispute
abstract: The police and protesters both deny causing an explosion at the Dakota Access Pipeline protest site that may cost a 21-year-old woman her arm.
lead_paragraph: Sophia Wilansky, 21, who grew up in the Bronx, rested in a Minneapolis hospital bed, her father by her side, recovering from surgery to try to save her left hand and arm after an explosion at a pipeline protest in North Dakota this week.

headline: Review: A Free Spirit Remains Undaunted in ‘Baden Baden’
abstract: This Rachel Lang film is light on narrative, but features a worthy performance by Salomé Richard.
lead_paragraph: “Despite your ugly clothes and your ugly hair, you’re really cute,” an errant boyfriend, attempting to be charming, says to Ana, the heroine of “Baden Baden.” It’s true that Ana is almost perpetually dressed down, in jean shorts and tank tops, and she keeps her dark hair in a pixie cut that she doesn’t tend to much. But she is more than cute. Played by Salomé Richard, she exudes an energy that some might call coltish.

headline: Review: Two Friends Take a Trip, Heavy Baggage in Tow, in ‘Always Shine’
abstract: Actresses try to renew their friendship during a weekend visit to Big Sur, Calif., but jealousies and old resentments bubble up.
lead_paragraph: “Always Shine” opens with a title card quoting the modeling agency founder John Robert Powers as saying that a woman is “the bowl of flowers” at the table of life. It then cuts to the actress Caitlin FitzGerald, in the role of Beth, in medium close-up and terribly upset. Not to worry. Beth is an actor, and here she’s auditioning for what seems to be a cruddy horror movie. Unseen bro-dudes behind the camera tell her that the role requires “extensive nudity” and answer one of her questions with “whatever, sweetheart.”

headline: Billy Kelly Does Stand-Up You Can Take Your Kids To
abstract: Mr. Kelly, who performs stand-up that some have found offensively clean, is celebrating his latest project, “My First Comedy Album,” in shows this weekend.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Billy Kelly was participating in what he called a “very edgy” open-mike event when he did something that outraged and offended the audience: He told a clean joke.

abstract: Works by Arthur Jafa, Carol Bove, Denzil Forrester, Julia Rommel, Rita Ackermann, Benny Andrews and Sondra Perry are on view at galleries around the city.
lead_paragraph: Hauser & Wirth548 West 22nd StreetChelseaThrough Jan. 14

headline: Pop Artist Tom Wesselmann’s Estate Will Be Represented by 2 Dealers
abstract: Both Gagosian and Rech will handle Wesselmann’s work; a David Smith show is coming to Storm King; and Lee Seung-taek has a new American dealer.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Sidney Janis Gallery closed in 2000, the work of the pop artist Tom Wesselmann, who died in 2004, has been without representation. “He wanted the latitude to continue working with whomever he wanted,” said Lane Wesselmann, one of the artist’s three children and a director of the estate. “He didn’t want to be hemmed in.”

headline: Where the Wild Things (and Narrators) Are, on Television
abstract: Nat Geo Wild’s “Savage Kingdom” looks at wild animals in Botswana, and the Smithsonian Channel’s “Polar Bear Town” chronicles those animals in Canada.
lead_paragraph: “Savage Kingdom,” a three-part nature documentary that begins Friday on Nat Geo Wild, is hard to watch and even harder to listen to.

headline: Video Review: A New Porsche Cayman, and Still a Driver’s Dream
abstract: Porsche remakes the Cayman in a very stealthy fashion, subtracting two cylinders and adding a turbocharger.
lead_paragraph: Porsche is adamant that it doesn’t sell transportation; it’s in the experience business. The automotive industry practically invented the hype machine, but Porsche has turned it into an art. The teenage memory of my first ride in a Porsche (a 911 Turbo, no less) is up there with my wedding day.

headline: A Joyful Thanksgiving Parade, Beyond the Barricades
keywords: ['Thanksgiving Day', 'Parades', 'Terrorism', 'Nice, France, Attack (July 2016)', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Perhaps three million people and 3,000 police officers were at the annual Macy’s spectacular in Manhattan amid stepped-up security measures.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Roma stood with her two young sons at Columbus Circle on Thursday, straining to see the Hello Kitty float in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade. It was hard to get a good look: Parked between her family and the parade’s marching bands, cheerleaders, clowns and floats were dump trucks, creating a temporary but substantial barricade at the Manhattan roundabout.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mild-mannered, lawyerly and with a genius for trivia, Richard Cordray is not the sort of guy you picture at the center of Washington’s bitter partisan wars over regulation and consumer safeguards.

headline: Rangers Hit the Road the Day After Thanksgiving, as Usual
keywords: ['Hockey, Ice', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Thanksgiving Day']
abstract: Since NBC began presenting an N.H.L. game billed as the Thanksgiving Showdown each Black Friday, the Rangers have appeared in all but the first one.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — After an unsightly home loss to the Penguins on Thanksgiving eve, the Rangers were back on the ice for practice at noon sharp on Thursday, with a flight to Philadelphia and a team dinner at their hotel to follow. Thanksgiving felt like a normal work day for the Rangers — just as it has been for the last few years.

headline: A Bronx Librarian Keen on Teaching Homeless Children a Lasting Love of Books
abstract: Every Wednesday, Colbert Nembhard visits the Crotona Inn shelter, serving as a model for a New York City literacy effort geared toward boys and girls living in transient conditions.
lead_paragraph: Colbert Nembhard looked more like a traveling salesman than a librarian in his dark suit with his rolling suitcase on a recent Wednesday morning in the Bronx.

headline: Republicans Divided Between Romney and Giuliani for Secretary of State
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The leading candidates are both high-profile politicians with their share of detractors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rival factions of Republicans are locked in an increasingly caustic and public battle to influence President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice for secretary of state, leaving a prominent hole in an otherwise quickly formed national security team that is unlikely to be filled until next week at the earliest.

headline: Immersive Experience

lead_paragraph: Just what you would expect of a Patrick Berry themeless: clean, crunchy and fun to solve. And, of course, here are a handful of new entries to enjoy.

headline: Manchester United Keeps Its Europa League Hopes Alive With Rout
abstract: Wayne Rooney scored in United’s 4-0 win over Feyenoord, leaving him one goal short of tying Bobby Charlton’s franchise record.
lead_paragraph: Wayne Rooney surpassed Ruud van Nistelrooy as Manchester United’s career top scorer in European competitions on Thursday, leading the English club to a 4-0 win over visiting Feyenoord and keeping it alive in the Europa League.

headline: U.S. Men’s Soccer Has an Ally in Misery: England
abstract: As crisis has engulfed soccer on both sides of the Atlantic in recent months, there remains some common ground between the two nations.
lead_paragraph: A humbling defeat at the hands of a nation a small fraction of your size. A manager briskly fired, hastily replaced on a messy temporary basis by pretty much the only guy anyone could think of at the time. Question marks that linger not just about whether the team is good enough, but about whether the players care enough about representing their country.

headline: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life’ and ‘Lang Lang’s New York Rhapsody’
abstract: Lorelai and Rory go home again to Stars Hollow in “Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.” And the Chinese pianist Lang Lang caresses the ivories in a New York state of mind.
lead_paragraph: It’s déjà vu all over again when Lorelai and Rory head back to Stars Hollow in “Gilmore Girls: A Year in the Life.” And the Chinese pianist Lang Lang caresses the ivories in a New York state of mind.

abstract: An electric company in Washington is offering incentives to cannabis growers to upgrade their operations — a high-stakes experiment in energy conservation.
lead_paragraph: TUMWATER, Wash. — Behind the covered windows of a nondescript two-story building near the Olympia Regional Airport, hundreds of marijuana plants were flowering recently in the purple haze of 40 LED lights.

headline: Florence Henderson, Upbeat Mom of ‘The Brady Bunch,’ Dies at 82
abstract: Her career began with stage musicals, but Ms. Henderson’s touchstone role as the perky matriarch of a 1970s blended family made her an enduring TV presence for decades.
lead_paragraph: Florence Henderson, who began her career as an ingénue soprano in stage musicals in the 1950s but made a more lasting impression on television as the perky 1970s sitcom mom on “The Brady Bunch,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 82.

headline: Race and Marijuana Arrests

abstract: Despite progress on cutting down on unfair arrests, there is still a racial disparity for those charged in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who took office in 2014, has made some progress in cutting back on the unfair and sometimes illegal police practices under which thousands of New Yorkers are arrested every year for possessing trivial amounts of marijuana.

headline: Does Decision-Making Matter?
abstract: Why are you interested in the things that interest you?
lead_paragraph: Danny Kahneman grew up Jewish in occupied France during World War II. Once in Paris, after curfew, he was nearly captured by an SS officer. His family traveled from town to town through rural France, hiding and hoping people wouldn’t recognize them as Jews. As Michael Lewis writes in his forthcoming book, “The Undoing Project,” Kahneman survived the Holocaust by keeping himself apart.

headline: The Populism Perplex
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Whites', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: What does the white working class want?
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton won the popular vote by more than two million, and she would probably be president-elect if the director of the F.B.I. hadn’t laid such a heavy thumb on the scales, just days before the election. But it shouldn’t even have been close; what put Donald Trump in striking distance was overwhelming support from whites without college degrees. So what can Democrats do to win back at least some of those voters?

headline: A Farewell to the Comedian in Chief
abstract: I already miss Obama’s wit. Trump can’t take a joke, and neither can he tell one.
lead_paragraph: I miss him already. Miss his steady rationality, his I-got-this mien, the eight years without a hint of personal scandal. And not to be overlooked, I miss the wit of Barack Obama. No president has had a better comic sensibility.

headline: No Extra Pay for Extra Work
abstract: An outdated salary threshold in a law has left many employees without overtime, but a judge has blocked rules that would have fixed the problem.
lead_paragraph: If all had gone according to plan, as many as 4.2 million additional workers in the United States would have started earning time and a half for overtime, effective Dec. 1. But that plan, developed by the Obama administration’s Labor Department in an exemplary rule-making process over the past two years, was blocked on Tuesday by a federal judge in Texas.

headline: As Foreign Students Worry About Trump
abstract: A college president, a governor and a teacher discuss the case of foreign students in a postelection America.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Trump Won the Troops
keywords: ['Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The regions and classes that send their children off to war were the same ones that voted for the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: In one of the early Democratic presidential debates, the candidates were asked which enemy they were the proudest of making. Tellingly, most offered a political response: Hillary Clinton singled out Republicans; Martin O’Malley, a former Maryland governor, mentioned the National Rifle Association; Senator Bernie Sanders turned his ire on Wall Street; and Lincoln Chafee, a former Rhode Island governor, discussed the coal lobby.

headline: Donald Trump and the Lawsuit Presidency
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Tax Evasion', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Editorials', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: The $25 million settlement of the Trump University fraud cases is only the tip of the iceberg.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump will take office as president facing a tsunami of litigation over his business practices and personal behavior. He may have settled the fraud suits involving Trump University, but at least 75 other lawsuits are underway against him or his companies, according to USA Today. Its investigation found more than 3,500 lawsuits over the past three decades, ranging from contract disputes to real estate battles to harassment and discrimination claims.

headline: White-Collar Supremacy
abstract: There’s nothing new about the alt-right’s intellectual aspirations.
lead_paragraph: Tallahassee, Fla. — Richard B. Spencer is one of the main figures of the alt-right movement, a former doctoral student from Duke whose movement supports the creation of “an ethno-state” for white Europeans and “peaceful ethnic cleansing.” The Southern Poverty Law Center describes him as “a suit-and-tie version of the white supremacists of old, a kind of professional racist in khakis”; a recent Los Angeles Times profile ran with a photo of him in sunglasses and a black shirt, looking more like a hipster academic than a Klansman.

headline: The Thin Gene
abstract: The body of a woman whose mutation keeps her on the brink of starvation may hold the secret to treating obesity.
lead_paragraph: Abby Solomon suffers from a one-in-a-billion genetic syndrome: After just about an hour without food, she begins to starve. She sleeps in snatches. In her dreams she gorges on French fries. But as soon as she wakes up and nibbles a few bites, she feels full, so she ends up consuming very few calories. At 5 feet 10 inches tall, she weighs 99 pounds.

headline: Wild and Free With British Bikers
abstract: In British Bikelife, Dan Giannopoulos has captured bikers at rest and at play, in standoffs with the police, but above all doing the thing they love most.
lead_paragraph: Dan Giannopoulos was cycling to work sometime back when he heard the sound of engines whining near the O2 Arena in southeast London.

headline: Sandboarding in Peru
abstract: Peruvian teenagers dream of snowboarding. There’s only one problem: There’s no snow. Watch how they make do with sand instead.
lead_paragraph: Peruvian teenagers dream of snowboarding. There’s only one problem: There’s no snow. Watch how they make do with sand instead.

headline: Catfishing Strangers to Find Myself
keywords: ['Online Dating', 'Hoaxes and Pranks', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: A young boy in Finland pretends he’s a woman on an online gaming website to get the attention of other players. Then the game changes.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, when I was growing up in Finland, my model of an attractive woman was Pamela Anderson from “Baywatch.” She was my father’s favorite. Whenever the boys at school asked me who I Googled when my parents weren’t home, I said, “Pamela,” and the name was greeted with a unanimous nodding of heads.

headline: Which Language Uses the Most Sounds? Click 5 Times for the Answer
abstract: Taa, spoken by a few thousand people in Botswana and Namibia, is believed to have the largest sound inventory of any language in the world.
lead_paragraph: With five distinct kinds of clicks, multiple tones and strident vowels — vocalized with a quick choking sound — the Taa language, spoken by a few thousand people in Botswana and Namibia, is believed by most linguists to have the largest sound inventory of any tongue in the world.

headline: Mikaela Shiffrin, Slalom’s Young Queen, Tests Borders of Her Territory
abstract: Shiffrin, a 21-year-old gold medalist in the slalom, is determined to prove herself as a champion in other events, as soon as she possibly can.
lead_paragraph: KILLINGTON, Vt. — Mikaela Shiffrin won her first World Cup race when she was 17, was an Olympic gold medalist a year later at the 2014 Sochi Games and was a two-time world champion by the time she was 19. Each title came in her specialty event, the slalom.

headline: In Scotland, Trump Built a Wall. Then He Sent Residents the Bill.
abstract: The president-elect left a trail of unmet promises on one of his golf courses, and lashed out at homeowners who stood in his way.
lead_paragraph: BALMEDIE, Scotland — President-elect Donald J. Trump has already built a wall — not on the border with Mexico, but on the border of his exclusive golf course in northeastern Scotland, blocking the sea view of local residents who refused to sell their homes.

At his latest Chicago restaurant, Leña Brava, the chef aims to showcase a relatively unsung region of Mexico — the state of Baja California in the northern Baja Peninsula, where the food roots are shallower but innovation is exploding.

headline: Mumbai Xpress, a Good Reason to Stray for a Snack

lead_paragraph: The fritters look armored, torpedoes sheathed in tapioca pearls. The outside crackles, but inside the tapioca has gone gooey, clinging and pulling like mochi. It’s a delightful trap: crunch, then sink. The flavors, too, give and take, pulverized peanuts leavened by ginger, sunny lemon pulled down to earth by cumin with its whiff of broken husks.

headline: Calvin Trillin on the Scariest Word
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'English Language', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The author on the word that fills him with dread.
lead_paragraph: I was disappointed when the website of Oxford Dictionaries called off its search for the worst word in the English language before I got a chance to have my say. When the survey was halted — the Oxford folks said that too many people were sending in offensive or insulting words — the word “moist” was in the lead. If a sort of yucky association was the criterion for what the survey officially called “your least favorite” word, I would have gone for “membrane” over “moist.” I can think of some pleasant uses for “moist” — a moist chocolate cake springs to mind — but I never encountered a membrane that didn’t make me shudder.

headline: A Warlord’s Reality Show

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: The artist Charlotte Moorman (1933-91) was a classically trained cellist who became a catalytic figure in the international avant-garde. As a musician, she collaborated frequently with the video pioneer Nam June Paik. As a charismatic organizer, she produced the Annual Avant Garde Festival of New York from 1963 to 1980 and persuaded city officials to let it happen in such places as Grand Central Terminal and Shea Stadium. A great spirit, she gets her due in this retrospective, which is closed until Tuesday but will continue through Dec. 10. A not-to-be-missed concurrent show, “Charlotte Moorman: Don’t Throw Anything Out,” runs through Dec. 9 at the Fales Library & Special Collections. HOLLAND COTTER

Gabrielle’s Angel Foundation for Cancer Research raised nearly $3.7 million at its annual ball on Nov. 21. More than 700 guests attended the American Museum of Natural History’s gala on Nov. 17. And the Humane Society of the United States honored Hugo Boss and Georgina Bloomberg at its annual gala on Nov. 18.

headline: Michigan’s Jim Harbaugh, an Update From the Bo Schembechler Line

headline: Inside a Fake News Sausage Factory: ‘This Is All About Income’
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: A computer science student in a former Soviet republic found there was money to be made in mixing real and made-up stories, as long as they were pro-Trump.
lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia — Jobless and with graduation looming, a computer science student at the premier university in the nation of Georgia decided early this year that money could be made from America’s voracious appetite for passionately partisan political news. He set up a website, posted gushing stories about Hillary Clinton and waited for ad sales to soar.

headline: A Latina Disney Movie Princess? The Wait Isn’t Over
abstract: “Moana” is a step toward diversifying the world of animated princesses. But it’s still exceedingly rare to see dark-skinned heroines in such films.
lead_paragraph: I’m not part of Disney’s target audience for its latest princess movie, “Moana,” but I don’t care. I’ve been excited about this film since Dwayne Johnson previewed it last year at the D23 Expo for all things Disney. As much as the new Lin-Manuel Miranda music sounds promising, what’s really exciting is the chance to see a Disney princess who doesn’t look like those we have already.

keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Capital Punishment']

lead_paragraph: Dylann S. Roof, the self-avowed white supremacist who is accused of killing nine black parishioners at a Charleston, S.C., church in June 2015, is competent to stand trial, a federal judge ruled Friday.

headline: How Cassini Will Begin Its Date With Death on Saturn
abstract: On Wednesday, the spacecraft that has studied Saturn for a dozen years will commence a series of maneuvers that will graze the planet’s rings.
lead_paragraph: It’s the beginning of a spectacular, almost circuslike end for NASA’s Cassini mission. For 12 years Cassini has been buzzing about Saturn, its rings and its moons. As a result we know that there are methane lakes on Titan and jets of water shooting from Enceladus, and the rings themselves have warps, ripples, hills twists and braids.

headline: College Towns Can Be Attractive Later in Life
abstract: University communities have advantages like intellectual stimulation, cultural amenities and a healthy economic base without a high price tag.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM RIFFER, 70, hopscotched around the country during a career in the Navy and later as a manager in the nuclear power industry, moving 19 times. So it’s not surprising that it took him a little time to figure out where he wanted to retire about a decade ago.

headline: From Putin’s Hands: A Russian Passport for Steven Seagal

lead_paragraph: Steven Seagal, the American actor whose career peaked in the 1990s with movies like “Under Siege”  and whose specialty was portraying action figures who spoke softly but blew up buildings and assassinated bad guys, has taken on a new role off screen: that of a Russian citizen with the passport to prove it.

headline: Auburn’s Iron Bowl Hopes Are on Firm Footing
abstract: Some call Auburn’s Daniel Carlson the best kicker in college football. His grandfather, an Alabama alumnus, calls him Turncoat.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Ala. — It is the season of non-offensive touchdowns for No. 1 Alabama. The Crimson Tide have scored 12 of the so-called NOTs, those touchdowns by the defense or by special teams. The wish of many Alabama football fans heading into Saturday’s Iron Bowl is to add a particular NOT to the Crimson Tide portfolio: the return for a touchdown of a short Auburn field-goal attempt. It would offer not only 6 points, but also some cathartic payback.

headline: Review: In ‘Dear Zindagi,’ a Conflicted Woman in Search of a Truer Life
abstract: Gauri Shinde’s sharply observed film depicts a young cinematographer torn between various impulses who finds guidance from a psychologist.
lead_paragraph: The issues in Gauri Shinde’s sharply observed drama “Dear Zindagi” are suggested in its opening scene: A woman walks with her boyfriend, disgusted with his infidelity, while he pleads for forgiveness, professing his love. A director calls cut, and we realize we are watching actors on a Mumbai movie set. The young cinematographer Kaira (Alia Bhatt) suggests shooting another take, this time with the woman surreptitiously checking out a passing male bicyclist. Her director approves.

headline: Girl Power? For Lara Croft, It’s a Complicated Legacy
abstract: She remains a polarizing figure among gamers, a paradox regarded as either a digital pinup girl or a feminist role model — or sometimes both.
lead_paragraph: Lara Croft set off on her first Tomb Raider adventure in 1996, traveling the globe in search of ancient artifacts amid dark and dusty ruins. She pushed that video game into a multibillion-dollar franchise that included several sequels, two feature films (starring Angelina Jolie), an animated series, apparel and merchandise. Now, the Academy Award-winning Swedish actress Alicia Vikander is set to  portray Lara Croft in a reboot of the series.

headline: The Two Putin Problem
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: One is confident, the other defensive. Trump will have to deal with both.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With a single phone conversation this month, Donald J. Trump and Vladimir V. Putin have started talk of another “reset” in ties between Russia and the United States. A new president, of course, has every reason to seek improved relations. But what could make this “reset” work? Mr. Trump rightly believes there may be opportunities in the relationship. They’re just not the ones he thinks.

headline: A Navajo Chef Looks to History in His Homage to Native Cuisine
abstract: The executive chef at the National Museum of the American Indian’s cafe researched oral histories to showcase indigenous food from across the Americas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It took 12 years for the nation’s pre-eminent Native American restaurant to hire its first Native American executive chef. Yet the chef, Freddie Bitsoie, is feeling a more particular pressure.

headline: A Filmmaker’s Belief in Himself Pays Off
abstract: Determined to gain critical respect, Shawn Levy, director of family comedies, built the production company behind the hit film “Arrival.”
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Shawn Levy quickly made a name for himself in Hollywood. Maybe too quickly.

headline: Betsy DeVos and the Wrong Way to Fix Schools
abstract: Donald Trump’s choice for education secretary was an architect of school reforms in Michigan. The results were terrible.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — President-elect Donald J. Trump’s selection of Betsy DeVos as secretary of education has sent shock waves through the educational establishment. Understandably so, since this is a clear sign that Mr. Trump intends a major national push to direct public funds to private and charter schools. But this is more than just a political or financial loss for traditional public schools. It will also most likely be a loss for students.

headline: Cliff Barrows, Billy Graham’s Longtime Musical Director, Dies at 93
abstract: Mr. Barrows and Mr. Graham met by chance in 1945 and began a professional association that lasted more than 70 years.
lead_paragraph: Cliff Barrows, a farmer’s son and ordained Baptist minister who for more than 70 years was the musical voice and program manager of the Rev. Billy Graham’s global Christian evangelistic crusades, died on Nov. 15 in Pineville, N.C. He was 93.

headline: Donald Trump’s Caldron of Conflicts
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Editorials', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s business interests will threaten the integrity of the government.
lead_paragraph: In the short time Donald Trump has been president-elect, he’s already shown that he will freely mix his business affairs with his activities as president. Federal ethics rules are not a deterrent, since they cannot be enforced against him. The situation practically invites foreign governments and businesses to try to influence American policy by currying favor with him through his business empire.

headline: A Hard Journey Toward Independence
abstract: A young woman with cerebral palsy receives furniture for her new bedroom, with help from The Neediest Cases.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t until she was 3 years old that Shatiana Vanterpool received a diagnosis. Unable to walk or talk, she was taken by her mother, Shayntte Johnson, to three different doctors, and finally it was discovered that she had cerebral palsy, which affected her muscle tone and motor skills. She didn’t learn to walk until she was about 5. And doctors said she would never be able to speak.

headline: Taiwan as a Same-Sex Marriage Pioneer

headline: Stalking Black Friday Bargains
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: Even as more people shop online, millions, including two sisters from New York and New Jersey, still rely on Black Friday discounts in stores.

She and her sister, Erica Renaud, who brought her 7-week-old son, were on the hunt for holiday gifts for the 11 children they have between them.

headline: U.S. Officials Defend Integrity of Vote, Despite Hacking Fears
abstract: Some opponents of Donald J. Trump are seeking recounts in Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania, states where his margin of victory was extremely thin.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Friday that despite Russian attempts to undermine the presidential election, it has concluded that the results “accurately reflect the will of the American people.”

headline: Long Island Village Votes to Disband 6 Years After Incorporating

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, November 26, 2016.

lead_paragraph: GARDEN CITY, N.Y. — When Casey Cizikas and Calvin de Haan of the Islanders meet up off the ice, there is much running, stick throwing and shouting — with nary a puck in sight.

headline: Ukraine’s Ex-Leader Regrets Not Breaking Up Protests That Led to His Fall
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'International Relations']
abstract: Viktor F. Yanukovych, the former president of Ukraine, said that his “main mistake” was not declaring martial law, but that he did not want to cause a civil war.
lead_paragraph: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — In a rare public appearance, Viktor F. Yanukovych, the former president of Ukraine, said Friday that he regrets he did not impose martial law and order troops to disperse the mass protests that toppled his government and forced him into exile in Russia.

headline: Paul Sylbert, Oscar-Winner Who Gave Movies Their Look, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Sylbert, whose twin brother was in the same field, began his career painting backdrops for the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sylbert, an Oscar-winning production designer who created the look of films as various as Alfred Hitchcock’s “The Wrong Man,” Robert Benton’s “Kramer vs. Kramer” and Warren Beatty’s “Heaven Can Wait,” died on Nov. 19 at his home in Jenkintown, Pa., near Philadelphia. He was 88.

headline: ‘Vulture’ or ‘Phoenix’? Wilbur Ross, Risk-Taker, Is Eyed for Commerce Post
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump is turning not to a cautious corporate chieftain, but to somebody usually considered either a hero or a villain.
lead_paragraph: Wilbur L. Ross, the billionaire investor expected to be nominated as the next commerce secretary, has made his fortune through the tricky business of buying deeply troubled companies.

headline: Putting a Skyscraper on a Pedestal
abstract: A 995-foot tower rising west of Pennsylvania Station will balance on an enormous steel pedestal overhanging the rail yard below.
lead_paragraph: In the city within a city rising west of Pennsylvania Station are many astonishing sights.

headline: Snackable Treat on a Stick
abstract: Paolo Pasco brings us a fresh and fun Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — What an interesting looking grid we have today. It’s a 66-word puzzle by Paolo Pasco and lots of fun to solve, as long as you keep pushing at it.

headline: Records Show Complaints About Driver in Deadly Tennessee Bus Crash
keywords: ['Buses', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Education (K-12)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Reports by students and school staff members said the driver drove too fast, cursed at students and deliberately slammed on the brakes to make students fall.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The 10-line report, written on wide-ruled notebook paper by an elementary school student in Chattanooga, Tenn., arrived on Nov. 16.

headline: Shining a Light on Cities’ Abandoned Buildings, From the Inside Out
abstract: An art installation is drawing attention to urban blight in three upstate New York cities by illuminating the windows of vacant properties.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — On a recent evening, Cameron Payne found himself walking along a row of empty and deteriorating homes and businesses in his neighborhood, but suddenly their windows were lighted.

headline: Carmelo Anthony’s Game-Winner Serves Notice That Knicks Are Still His Team
abstract: Anthony scored a season-high 35 points and grabbed 14 rebounds, carrying the Knicks past the Hornets in overtime at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony has been a star in the shadows this season. He remains one of the N.B.A.’s marquee players and the face of the Knicks, but Anthony has been pushed off center stage often enough this month by the emerging Kristaps Porzingis. It has not been an unruly exchange, and Anthony seems to appreciate his new co-star after so many years of toiling away in New York with much acclaim but few wins.

headline: Scott Dayton Identified as First American to Die in Syria Combat
abstract: Chief Dayton, who lived in Virginia and was assigned to a bomb-disposal unit, was killed in northern Syria on Thursday by an improvised bomb.
lead_paragraph: A 42-year-old Navy sailor whose many decorations included the Bronze Star has been identified as the first member of the American armed forces to be killed in combat in Syria, the Defense Department said on Friday.

headline: Double Points in Racing? Not After What Happened Last Time
abstract: Trying to build suspense, the series changed the points system at Abu Dhabi in 2014. No one seemed to like the result.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix was the only race in Formula One history in which the teams and drivers contended for double points. It quickly became apparent that the rule was one of the worst ideas the series ever had, and it was immediately discarded.

headline: A Final Contest for Two of Racing’s Most Experienced Drivers
abstract: Felipe Massa and Jenson Button have similar records, though only one of them won a drivers’ series. The Abu Dhabi Grand Prix is their final race.
lead_paragraph: For two of Formula One’s oldest, most experienced and successful drivers, the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix is a series farewell.

headline: A Roller Coaster of a Track That Demands Precision
abstract: Abu Dhabi Grand Prix offers a challenging course that does not favor any style of driving. And there is racing under the stars.
lead_paragraph: A lap of the Yas Marina Circuit in a road car is enough of a thrill to imagine what it must be like for the fastest drivers on earth.

headline: Formula One Turns the Corner on a Troubled Era
abstract: The Abu Dhabi Grand Prix marks the end of a formula that brought quieter, more efficient and faster cars, and a steady stream of complaints.
lead_paragraph: The Abu Dhabi Grand Prix on Sunday marks not only the end of the 2016 Formula One season — it is also the final race in a three-year formula that has changed the sport.

headline: At Mercedes, Racing Is ‘Business on Steroids’
abstract: The team chief has a passion for the blend of finance, the races and the challenge of beating other teams.
lead_paragraph: Toto Wolff, 44, is the chief executive, team principal and part-owner of the Mercedes Formula One team. He is also the director of the Mercedes motor sport program.

headline: The Mercedes Saga: From the Top, to Out, to Back at the Top
abstract: The Formula One team has known victory, tragedy and a long withdrawal. But as this season ends, the road car manufacturer has earned a unique record.
lead_paragraph: At the end of this year’s season, the Mercedes Formula One team has cemented its reputation like no other road car manufacturer before it. It won a third constructors’ and drivers’ title, more than any major road car manufacturer in the series’ history.

headline: Owner of a Brooklyn Brownstone From ‘Crooklyn’ Sees Herself Caught in Airbnb Crossfire
abstract: Liz Mandarano, the owner of the brownstone that was the backdrop for Spike Lee’s film, believes she’s being unfairly targeted. But the city said her building violated the housing code.
lead_paragraph: The doorbell rang. On the steps of the brownstone in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn were two police officers, two firefighters and two Buildings Department inspectors. The one who did the talking said to get out immediately, not because there was a gas leak, not because anyone was suspected of selling illegal drugs, but because the brownstone was being used as a bed-and-breakfast.

headline: Stan Huntsman, Track and Field’s Mentor and Passionate Defender, Dies at 84
abstract: Huntsman coached at the college level, led United States Olympic teams and fought financial reductions that threatened the very existence of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Stan Huntsman, who coached outstanding college track and field teams for 39 years, led a dominant United States men’s team at the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, and fought tirelessly against cuts in financial support for the sport, died on Wednesday in Austin, Tex. He was 84.

headline: My Three Days With Fidel
abstract: Richard Eder, a former New York Times foreign correspondent, recalls interviewing the Cuban leader.
lead_paragraph: Richard Eder, a former New York Times foreign correspondent, recalls interviewing the Cuban leader.

headline: Fidel Castro, Cuban Revolutionary Who Defied U.S., Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Castro brought the Cold War to the Western Hemisphere, bedeviled 11 American presidents and briefly pushed the world to the brink of nuclear war.
lead_paragraph: Fidel Castro, the fiery apostle of revolution who brought the Cold War to the Western Hemisphere in 1959 and then defied the United States for nearly half a century as Cuba’s maximum leader, bedeviling 11 American presidents and briefly pushing the world to the brink of nuclear war, died on Friday. He was 90.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: Batman, Superman and an ‘S.N.L.’ Star
abstract: “Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice” arrives on the small screen, and Netflix presents a comedy special by Michael Che of “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: “Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice,” Zack Snyder’s bloated and sober comic-book mash-up, arrives on the small screen and streaming services. And Michael Che, a co-host of “Weekend Update” on “Saturday Night Live,” flies solo with his own Netflix comedy special.
