abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, November 26, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Fidel Castro, Cuban Revolutionary
abstract: Mr. Castro was seen as a ruthless despot by some and hailed as a hero by others.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Castro was seen as a ruthless despot by some and hailed as a hero by others.

headline: Fidel Castro, Cuban Revolutionary
abstract: Mr. Castro was seen as a ruthless despot by some and hailed as a hero by others.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Castro was seen as a ruthless despot by some and hailed as a hero by others.

headline: The Times’s Coverage of Fidel Castro
abstract: Articles include an exclusive Times interview with the young guerrilla leader in 1957 and coverage of the revolution, the Bay of Pigs invasion and the 1962 missile crisis.
lead_paragraph: Articles include an exclusive Times interview with the young guerrilla leader in 1957 and coverage of the revolution, the Bay of Pigs invasion and the 1962 missile crisis.

headline: Castro’s Revolution, Illustrated
abstract: Thousands of posters were commissioned by the government to promote his vision of a socialist society.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of posters were commissioned by the government to promote his vision of a socialist society.

headline: Fidel Castro: 1926-2016
abstract: A master of image and myth, Mr. Castro believed himself to be the messiah of his fatherland, an indispensable force with authority from on high to control Cuba and its people.
lead_paragraph: A master of image and myth, Mr. Castro believed himself to be the messiah of his fatherland, an indispensable force with authority from on high to control Cuba and its people.

headline: Solving a Mystery Behind the Deadly ‘Tsunami of Molasses’ of 1919
abstract: Researchers say they have figured out a piece of the puzzle of why a 2.3 million-gallon spill of molasses from a storage tank in Boston was so deadly, killing 21 people and destroying buildings.
lead_paragraph: It was January. The place was Boston. And when 2.3 million gallons of molasses burst from a gigantic holding tank in the city’s North End, 21 people were killed and about 150 more were left injured. The wave of syrup — some reports said it was up to 40 feet tall — rushed through the waterfront, destroying buildings, overturning vehicles and pushing a firehouse off its foundation.

headline: For Interracial Couples, Growing Acceptance, With Some Exceptions
abstract: Five decades after the Loving ruling, intolerance is still sometimes an issue for interracial couples.
lead_paragraph: When I was a new mother living on the Upper West Side of Manhattan in 2010, I often forgot that my infant son, Harper, didn’t look like me. As I pushed him around the neighborhood, I thought of him as the perfect brown baby, soft-skinned and tulip-lipped, with a full head of black hair, even if it was the opposite of my blond waves and fair skin.

headline: Enter the Ring at Gleason’s
abstract: Gleason’s, the oldest boxing gym in New York, is moving at the end of this month. Visit the gym where Muhammad Ali and Mike Tyson trained.
lead_paragraph: Gleason’s, the oldest boxing gym in New York, is moving at the end of this month. Visit the gym where Muhammad Ali and Mike Tyson trained.

headline: Raúl Castro’s Inner Circle
abstract: Who will really call the shots in Cuba in the years to come? Here is a glance at some civilians and military figures who have Mr. Castro’s ear.
lead_paragraph: Who will really call the shots in Cuba in the years to come? Here is a glance at some civilians and military figures who have Mr. Castro’s ear.

headline: A 98-Year-Old Yoga Celebrity Tells All
abstract: “She said they helped elevate her consciousness,” a photographer says of the high heels preferred by Täo Porchon-Lynch.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Monday, Täo Porchon-Lynch was teaching her 90-minute yoga class in Hartsdale, N.Y., combining elements of Iyengar, meditation and vinyasa for a dozen or so regular students.

headline: Where Beauty Means Bleached Skin
keywords: ['Skin', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Women and Girls', 'Beauty (Concept)', 'Social Media', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: A multibillion-dollar industry of skin-whitening products dominates the West African cosmetics market, creating a world of mixed messages for the women who live there.
lead_paragraph: ACCRA, Ghana — Semiratu Zakaru was standing in the hot sun on a crowded noontime street explaining why Ghana’s new ban against certain skin-bleaching creams was unlikely to work, when her friend, Desmond Kwamina Odonkor, walked up and interrupted our conversation, oozing confidence and game.

headline: From Moguls to Mortals
abstract: After a fall from power in Hollywood, is there a path back?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Some out-of-work Hollywood moguls handle the transition from general to civilian with grace.

headline: In Havana, Castro’s Death Lays Bare a Generation Gap
abstract: In hearing about Fidel Castro’s death, many older Cubans went into mourning, but younger people were generally indifferent.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — At the Salon Rojo, one of Havana’s most popular nightspots, where the reggaeton usually blares into the early hours, the music stopped abruptly.

headline: With One Castro Gone, Questions About What the Other Castro Will Do
abstract: Fidel Castro’s death comes at a time of great uncertainty for Cuba, and about how Raúl Castro will steer the country.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — For half a century, as Fidel Castro transformed Cuba into a Communist state and sparred with the United States, his brother Raúl worked in his shadow, the authoritarian leader’s disciplined, junior partner.

headline: Protest Against South Korean President Estimated to Be Largest Yet
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of people in central Seoul denounced President Park Geun-hye, who faces the possibility of impeachment within weeks over an influence-peddling scandal.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Hundreds of thousands of South Koreans filled central Seoul on Saturday to demand President Park Geun-hye’s resignation, in what appeared to be the largest turnout yet in a series of weekly protests against the embattled leader.

headline: Trump, and Great Business Ideas for America
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Executives and Management (Theory)']
abstract: With the proper approach, modern business could improve the work of government institutions.
lead_paragraph: A businessman with a lifetime of experience in management has been elected president of the United States. Donald J. Trump’s administration may be viewed as an experiment — an opportunity to discover whether one particular businessman’s perspective and skills will be assets in governing a nation.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Officials to Close Standing Rock Protest Campsite
abstract: A North Dakota site has been the location of demonstrations against the construction of a crude oil pipeline.
lead_paragraph: Citing public safety concerns, federal officials plan to close access to a campsite where demonstrators have protested the construction of a crude oil pipeline near the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota and create a “free speech zone.”

headline: Vagrants in the Building Lobby
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Homeless Persons', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: How do you permanently remove vagrants from a rental building lobby?
lead_paragraph: Q. Two people who appear to be drug addicts regularly sleep in the lobby of my rental building in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. They sneak in every afternoon behind someone who leaves the door open and stay out of the view of the cameras. The super, who lives nearby, clears them out in the morning. They are generally amiable and accommodating, but when they are high they become agitated and accost me, threatening harm  if I call the police. I am scared to report them, especially because I know they will probably be back the next day. What’s the best way to handle this?

headline: Chipping Away at a List of Goals, and Bonding Over Cupcakes
abstract: Being uprooted from her home amid domestic violence did not stop Andie Gratereaux, 12, from crossing things off her to-do list with a mentor’s help.
lead_paragraph: Andie Gratereaux sat under the autumn leaves at DeSalvio Playground in Manhattan a year ago, peeled away the wrapper from a salted caramel cupcake and started to put her life back together.

headline: Anger Rooms: A Smashing New Way to Relieve Stress
abstract: The Anger Room in Dallas and other businesses that let people break things to release their rage have gained customers, especially during the election season.
lead_paragraph: When she was a teenager on the South Side of Chicago in the late 1990s, Donna Alexander fantasized about setting up a space where stressed-out people could relieve their tension in a safe, nonviolent way — by smashing mannequins, televisions, furniture and other objects. She was confident in her idea, but she wasn’t sure how to turn it into a business.

headline: U.S. Seeks Death for Charleston Shooting Suspect. Victims’ Families Prefer Mercy.
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Capital Punishment', 'Hate Crimes', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: In the coming trial of Dylann S. Roof, who is accused of killing nine black churchgoers last year, no issue is more disputed than whether he should face execution.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The Rev. Sharon Risher often thinks these days about what she calls her “humanness”: the passing impulse to crave the execution of the white supremacist accused of killing her mother and eight other black churchgoers last year.

headline: A Donald Trump-Led Trip Back to the Gold-Plated ’80s
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The wealth culture of today, in contrast to the excesses of the 1980s, emphasizes staying under the radar. The election of Mr. Trump could change that.
lead_paragraph: The American wealthy are about to enjoy a giant back-to-the-1980s party, hosted by the new billionaire in chief, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Pakistan Names New Military Leader
abstract: Lt. Gen. Qamar Javed Bajwa was selected to take over the command of Pakistan’s army when Gen. Raheel Sharif retires on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan on Saturday chose Lt. Gen. Qamar Javed Bajwa, a military commander with a solid soldierly reputation and a firm belief in civilian supremacy, to lead the country’s powerful army.

headline: Keeping the Electricity Grid One Step Ahead of the Storm
abstract: A senior preparedness administrator for Baltimore Gas & Electric plans out how to get the lights back on after wind, snow, rain and ice have done their worst.
lead_paragraph: Chuck Willis, 60, is a senior emergency preparedness administrator at Baltimore Gas & Electric.

headline: Variety: The Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon win me over once again.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Today’s acrostic has nothing to do with my beloved Monty Python’s Flying Circus (a shame, in my opinion), but our constructors have lovingly planted an entry that is of great interest to me, even if, as they say below, it’s not in the dictionary.

headline: Miami’s Cuban Exiles Celebrate Castro’s Death
abstract: For many Cuban-Americans, still bitter over the revolution that tore their families from their homes, it was a celebration long in coming.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It did not matter that it was the middle of the night, or that it began to drizzle. When this city’s Cuban-American residents heard the news, they sprinted to Little Havana. They banged pots and pans. They sang the Cuban national anthem and waved the Cuban flag. They danced and hugged, laughed and cried, shouted and rejoiced.

headline: Betty Bui and David Purcell: Instant Chemistry With a Brief Plot Twist
abstract: Their love story involved a spy in a San Francisco restaurant, or did it?
lead_paragraph: Betty Uyen Bui, a daughter of Huong N. Bui of San Jose, Calif., and the late Phuong V. Bui, was married Nov. 26 to David Elliott Purcell, a son of Carol Burke Purcell of McLean, Va., and the late Francis E. Purcell. The Rev. Timothy Mills, an American Baptist minister, officiated at a nondenominational ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton in San Francisco.

headline: Grammar Lesson on the Upper East Side
abstract: A teenager raising money for his basketball team proves to be a quick learner on the subject of object pronouns.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Jenna Kauffman and Jonathan Grinberg: Don’t Send Flowers. Pizza Will Do.
abstract: Somehow the groom knew the key to her heart was found in a Domino’s pizza with extra cheese and ranch dressing.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Shane Kauffman, a daughter of Janis Rosenthal Kauffman and Robert J. Kauffman of Philadelphia, was married Nov. 26 to Jonathan Grinberg, a son of Sima Davidson and Dr. Isaac Grinberg of Huixquilucan, Mexico. Cantor David F. Tilman led the ceremony in the planetarium at the Franklin Institute, the science museum in Philadelphia.

headline: In Madagascar Test, Drone Delivers Medicine by Air
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Philanthropy', 'Rural Areas', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Drones, mainly associated with missiles, are poised to deliver medicines in Madagascar.
lead_paragraph: When drones are in the news these days, the context is typically war or surveillance or the speedy deliver of packages to impatient consumers. Here, Heidi Hutner of Stony Brook University offers a “Your Dot” contribution on a recent test in a roadless region in Madagascar that could signal an exciting new frontier for this technology – helping deliver health care to some of the world’s poorest, most isolated communities.

headline: Fate of U.S.-Cuba Thaw Is Less Certain Under Donald Trump
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: The president-elect has been critical of the détente, and sent mixed signals during the campaign about his intentions toward the island nation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Saturday that the death of Fidel Castro was an occasion for Americans to “extend a hand of friendship to the Cuban people” and acknowledge the “powerful emotions” the revolutionary leader had evoked in both countries, seeking to use Mr. Castro’s fraught legacy to underscore his own efforts to bury decades of bitterness between the United States and Cuba.

headline: One City. Two Soccer Clubs Split by War.
abstract: Depending on whom you ask, either KF Trepca or FK Trepca is the rightful owner of the decades of soccer history that came before war tore apart the former Yugoslavia.
lead_paragraph: MITROVICA, Kosovo — Even among the flags and the sponsored jerseys and all the other trappings of the modern game, Bardhec Seferi could close his eyes and still see the waist-high grass.

headline: As Soda Taxes Gain Wider Acceptance, Your Bottle May Be Next
keywords: ['Soft Drinks', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Obesity', 'Referendums', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Following successful measures on Election Day, advocates believe more cities will consider them, not just to fight obesity, but also to bring in more money.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Coca-Cola, Pepsi and other beverage companies have fought mightily against efforts to tax sugary sodas, defeating more than three dozen such proposals around the country.

headline: Trump’s Next Battle: Keeping These Republican Senators Happy
abstract: Lindsey Graham. John McCain. Jeff Flake. They are just a few of the lawmakers the president-elect may sometimes find himself having to win over.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While much of the attention in Washington is on who will fill the Trump cabinet, it is already clear who some of the most important people will be when it comes to fulfilling the Trump agenda.

headline: The Strip
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Plight of Houthi Rebels Is Clear in Visit to Yemen’s Capital
abstract: After seizing Sana in 2014, a formerly provincial movement faces bombardment by a Saudi-led coalition, struggles in governing and no clear endgame.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Before the war, the Officers Club in downtown Sana was a prime recreation destination, known for its pool and garden cafe.

headline: After Stops and Starts in College, a Rookie Receiver Latches on With the Jets
abstract: Robby Anderson temporarily quit Temple’s football team and later was ruled academically ineligible. But he has thrived in the N.F.L. as an undrafted rookie.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Just two years ago, Robby Anderson had been dismissed from college and was back home in Florida. He applied for jobs at Walmart and a rental car company, without much luck. This, in his words, represented rock bottom.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Team to Join Wisconsin Recount Pushed by Jill Stein
abstract: The campaign also said it would participate in potential recounts in Pennsylvania and Michigan, though it saw no “actionable evidence” of vote hacking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly three weeks after Election Day, Hillary Clinton’s campaign said on Saturday that it would participate in a recount process in Wisconsin incited by a third-party candidate and would join any potential recounts in two other closely contested states, Pennsylvania and Michigan.

headline: Potential Conflicts Around the Globe for Trump, the Businessman President
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: In many of the president-elect’s international development ventures, his business partners have close ties to foreign governments.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — On Thanksgiving Day, a Philippine developer named Jose E. B. Antonio hosted a company anniversary bash at one of Manila’s poshest hotels. He had much to be thankful for.

headline: David Gray
abstract: A singer-songwriter on the parallels between today’s politics and the court of Henry VIII, avoiding social media, and walking in the wilds of Britain.
lead_paragraph: David Gray is a British singer-songwriter  currently on tour in North America, where he has been playing his eclectic folk-rock and experimental repertoire at sold-out shows.

headline: Why Not Smart Guns in This High-Tech Era?
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Firearms', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Science and Technology', 'Editorials', 'Children and Childhood', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The technology exists to prevent children from firing guns, but under gun lobby pressure, the industry has not used it.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice has issued official guidelines for the manufacture of smart guns — weapons that, like smartphones, have technology to allow only the rightful owners to use them. The guidelines aim to “shape the future of gun safety technology,” as called for under an executive order issued in January by President Obama, in the face of Congress’s refusal to deal with the nation’s horrendous toll of gun deaths.

headline: Definitions of America
abstract: Readers discuss identity politics and the ways in which it can promote or impede Americans’ coming together.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss identity politics and how it promotes or impedes our coming together.

headline: The Soldier Donald Trump Called a Traitor
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Desertion (Military)', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Editorials']
abstract: The president-elect’s campaign crusade against Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl makes it unlikely that the former Taliban hostage can get a fair trial.
lead_paragraph: The case of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, an American soldier who, after leaving his post, was held hostage by the Taliban for five years, became a recurring theme of Donald Trump’s unruly campaign speeches.

headline: The Privileged Immigrant
abstract: My Indian family’s comfort is built on the work of other immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Berkeley, Calif. — “Girls,” Mrs. Danilewitz called to her daughters, “Girls, I want you to meet this extraordinary lady!” My mother stood unsuspecting in the foyer, hardly taller than the two children who gazed at her now. I’d been studying for a biology test with their older brother, Justin. “Did you know,” Mrs. D. went on, “that this lady arrived in this country with no more than $6 in her pocket? And look what she’s made of herself today!” She clasped my mother’s hand. “Nimmu, what an inspiration!”

headline: His Holiness Declines to Answer
abstract: Questions without answers in Catholicism’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: “This is not normal” — so say Donald Trump’s critics as he prepares to assume the presidency. But the American republic is only the second-oldest institution facing a distinctively unusual situation at the moment. Pride of place goes to the Roman Catholic Church, which with less fanfare (perhaps because the papacy lacks a nuclear arsenal) has also entered terra incognita.

headline: Will Guys With Guns Replace the Agency Elizabeth Warren Created?
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Credit and Debt', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: Someone has to police the consumer debt industry. If Trump disbands the C.F.P.B., it’s going to be this guy.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Wilson is a former armed robber who, after serving roughly a decade in prison, reinvented himself as a successful debt broker. Basically, he makes a living buying and selling old, unpaid debts.

headline: Election Therapy From My Basket of Deplorables
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: I had an unyielding week, scolded by Donald Trump at The Times and my conservative family at Thanksgiving.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — First I had to deal with the president-elect scolding.

headline: Actually, Let’s Not Be in the Moment
abstract: Mindfulness is supposed to ease the stress of modern life, not add to it.
lead_paragraph: I’m at the kitchen sink, after a long day of work and kids and chores and the emotional exhaustion of a toxic election season, attempting to mindfully focus on congealed SpaghettiOs. My brain flits to the Netflix queue. I manhandle my thoughts back to the leaky orange glob in front of me. My brain flits to the president-elect.

headline: The Saloon, America’s Forgotten Democratic Institution
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Bars used to be a hub for working-class politics. We could use them again today.
lead_paragraph: Frothy lager on tap. A communal “mustache towel” hanging by the bar. Partisan debate rattling the glassware. America’s saloons once served as boisterous “poor man’s clubs,” where 19th-century laborers could make their political voices heard. In the wake of the 2016 election, with both parties struggling to connect with a disaffected working class, and just about everyone in need of a drink, Americans might want to belly up to the once-maligned saloon.

headline: Can Senate Democrats Save the Party?
abstract: As the party seeks a unifying message, it also must decide how to best use its power in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Having had more than two weeks to ponder one of the most humiliating presidential defeats in its history, the Democratic Party is moving to apply its lessons to the legislative battles ahead, as well as to the daunting but essential task of rebuilding the party’s fortunes.

headline: What Unions Got Wrong About Trump
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Working-class whites delivered three Rust Belt states to the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: For the nation’s labor unions, the day after Election Day was going to be a victory lap. They planned to boast to the world that their vaunted get-out-the-vote operation had delivered the White House to Hillary Clinton by winning three crucial Rust Belt states for her: Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. But the unions, to their shock and horror, failed to deliver those states — or victory — to Mrs. Clinton.

headline: Memories of Another Mosul
keywords: ['Assyrian Civilization', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Long before the Islamic State — or the campaign to expel it — my beloved hometown was a place of music, culture and unity.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The ancient Assyrians considered the Tigris River the division between East and West, and the city I come from in Iraq is called Mosul — connection point, in Arabic — because it connects these two sides. Nineveh, which lay on the eastern bank of the Tigris, was a capital of the great Assyrian empire. When Arabs arrived in the seventh century, they preferred to live at a distance from it, on the western bank, where the modern city of Mosul is today.

headline: An Indian Protest for Everyone
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Native Americans', 'Pipelines', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Water', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: March. Fight. But go to planning meetings, too.
lead_paragraph: Every protest contains a contradiction: people stand up — through speech, demonstration, violent or nonviolent action — and urge the state to change. They break the rules in order to convince the rule-makers that they need to change the rules, which is itself a kind of state-approved process. However, at Standing Rock in North Dakota, Indians from all over North America have been protesting for seven months in some ways never before seen.

headline: Why I Left White Nationalism
keywords: ['Whites', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Minorities', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: I grew up in a family that embraced extreme views. I’ve moved on. The country can, too.
lead_paragraph: I could easily have spent the night of Nov. 8 elated, surrounded by friends and family, thinking: “We did it. We rejected a multicultural and globalist society. We defied the elites, rejected political correctness, and made a statement millions of Americans have wanted to shout for decades.”

headline: The Pretend Populism of Donald Trump
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The “blue-collar billionaire” is looking plenty regal so far.
lead_paragraph: For a politician who won the White House by railing against the elites and demonizing the establishment, Donald Trump presented an odd argument for why Americans should believe, as he does, that his adviser Steve Bannon is no racist, anti-Semitic ally of the alt-right.

headline: For Democrats, a Last Faint Hope to Gain a Senate Seat
abstract: Foster Campbell, a Democrat, is not expected to beat Republican John N. Kennedy in Louisiana, but that hasn’t stopped Democrats from around the country from one final push.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The punk club was dark and packed, the lead singer of the band Hurray for the Riff Raff warming up a crowd of the young, the bearded and the well-tattooed. A little after 9 p.m., in came the headline act: a necktie-wearing cattle rancher, public service commissioner and United States Senate candidate from Elm Grove, La., who owns a half dozen hunting dogs and five times as many shotguns.

headline: U.S. Statement on Reliability of Election Results
abstract: A senior administration official responded to The Times’s questions about the federal government’s investigation into the integrity of the Nov. 8 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Following is the full text of a statement from a senior administration official, issued to The New York Times on Friday in response to questions about the federal government’s investigation into the integrity of the Nov. 8 presidential election. The government issued the statement to The Times on the condition that it be attributable only to a senior official.

headline: Finger Pointed at Russians in Alleged Coup Plot in Montenegro
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A detained mercenary is slowly spilling his guts on what he says were efforts to sow mayhem in the Balkans and undermine NATO.
lead_paragraph: PODGORICA, Montenegro — After multiple but unproven accusations that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is working hard to destabilize America’s friends in Europe, a pro-Russian mercenary detained in Montenegro is slowly spilling his guts — and providing the first insider’s account of what the authorities in this tiny Balkan nation say were Russian efforts to sow mayhem.

headline: Talks to Heal Catholic Rift in China Gain Momentum Under Francis
abstract: The pope’s apparent determination to bring the “underground” church out of the shadows has caused some to worry that he might give too much away to the hard-line president, Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Pope Francis has spoken of his admiration for Chinese culture. He has greeted a delegation from China, accepting a silk imprint of an ancient inscription about Christianity. And he had his picture taken with a Chinese bishop in St. Peter’s Square last month.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: No. 2 Ohio State Defeats No. 3 Michigan in Overtime Thriller
abstract: After two overtime periods and a close fourth-and-1 play, the Buckeyes had a victory that made them a prime candidate for the four-team College Football Playoff.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Generations of Ohio State and Michigan fans will debate the latest episode of one of college football’s most impassioned rivalries, a 30-27 Ohio State victory in two overtimes on Saturday, the Buckeyes’ fifth straight win over the Wolverines.

headline: The Election and the Market Rally
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Readers comment on “You Can’t See the Future in a Stock Surge” (Nov. 20).
lead_paragraph: “You Can’t See the Future in a Stock Surge,” by Sendhil Mullainathan of Harvard (The Upshot, Economic View, Nov. 20), said the market rally that followed the presidential election was not necessarily an indicator of how the economy would perform under Donald J. Trump.

headline: Tessa Worley of France Wins Giant Slalom in Vermont
abstract: Worley has now won nine World Cup giant slaloms. Mikaela Shiffrin, the hometown favorite, finished fifth.
lead_paragraph: KILLINGTON, Vt. — The World Cup of skiing returned to the Eastern United States for the first time in 25 years Saturday and was greeted by a clambering sea of fans who had hiked a quarter of a mile up the hill next to the racecourse to glimpse the world’s fastest female skiers.

headline: An Unimaginable Day Arrives in Miami
abstract: The phone kept ringing. Castro really was gone.
lead_paragraph: Miami — The first time Fidel Castro died was around my birthday in 2006. I was in Miami when the announcement went out that Castro had had an operation and was temporarily ceding power to his brother. This being the first time Castro had voluntarily stepped away from his dictatorship, speculation ran wild. Miami Cubans took to the streets to celebrate the death of a tyrant, a symbol of death and loss for Cubans of all races and faiths.

headline: Mixology
abstract: Matt Ginsberg pulls off some additional wordplay.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Everyone has a special purpose in life, as Steve Martin was told in the movie “The Jerk,” and crossword constructors are born to recognize odd patterns in words and phrases, then point them out for our entertainment.

headline: Justin Trudeau Criticized for Praising Fidel Castro as ‘Remarkable Leader’
abstract: The Canadian prime minister’s statement on the Cuban leader’s death was condemned by political observers in both the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada would like the world to know that he was rather fond of Fidel Castro. Or at least, that is the message that many people took from his unusually warm statement on the death of the Cuban dictator, whom he hailed on Saturday as “a remarkable leader.”

headline: Half a Million Children Are Trapped in Syria, United Nations Says
abstract: A report by Unicef said the children were among hundreds of thousands of people in besieged areas who were cut off from humanitarian aid and basic services.
lead_paragraph: With violence escalating in Aleppo and elsewhere across war-ravaged Syria, the United Nations said Saturday that the number of children trapped in besieged areas had doubled in less than a year to half a million.

headline: Magnus Carlsen and Sergey Karjakin in Dead Heat in Chess Championship
abstract: Karjakin continued to show himself as equal to Carlsen, the reigning champion and the heavy favorite, as he forced a draw in the 11th game of the match.
lead_paragraph: With one game remaining in their World Chess Championship match, Magnus Carlsen and Sergey Karjakin are in a dead heat, after a quick but tense draw on Saturday.

headline: South Carolina Romps Over No. 18 Syracuse in Brooklyn
abstract: In another college basketball game, Duke routed Appalachian State even with Grayson Allen leaving early because of an injury.
lead_paragraph: Sindarius Thornwell scored 16 points, and South Carolina never trailed in its 64-50 victory over No. 18 Syracuse on Saturday in the Brooklyn Hoops Holiday Invitational at Barclays Center.

headline: London — and Paris and New Delhi — in Silk Scarves
abstract: A love affair with maps inspired the British textile designer Helen Chatterton to expand her designs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nearly five years ago, the textile designer Helen Chatterton was searching for a way to celebrate London. She had been fashioning men’s and women’s scarves with materials like tweed from Scotland and velvet from France but needed a way to create pieces with more of a London DNA for an exhibition of handmade British crafts that the OXO Tower gallery planned.

headline: Gems Between Book Covers
abstract: Publishers’ lists include several new books on jewelry and design subjects.
lead_paragraph: Jewelry books are having a sparkling moment: More titles, more vivid illustration and easier than ever to find.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, November 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “There was such sadness to think of all the people, and what everyone went through, and the people who aren’t here today to celebrate and witness this.”

headline: A Glittering Ride
abstract: One gift suggestion: A rocking horse covered in Swarovski crystals.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It took more than 200 hours to create: For sale this Christmas, a rocking horse sparkling with 82,000 Swarovski crystals.

headline: Joy of Giving
abstract: Creative executives at some of the world’s most influential, fashion-centric stores describe what they consider the best gifts they’ve ever given.
lead_paragraph: Creative executives at some of the world’s most influential, fashion-centric stores describe what they consider the best gifts they’ve ever given.

headline: More Than Just a Suitcase
abstract: Improvements in design and functionality are driving growth in luggage sales.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — If you’ve ever felt a tinge of embarrassment when picking up your old suitcase from the carousel, now is a good time to upgrade. And when it comes to a good gift, luggage might not be what immediately comes to mind — but as companies re-evaluate the potential of the sector, things are changing.

headline: Experiences, With a Bow on Them
abstract: Sometimes a hotel stay or a charitable donation can be the most memorable presents.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Gretchen Smelter wanted to surprise her husband, Frédéric Lagrange, when he returned after a monthlong assignment in the remote northern reaches of Afghanistan — and to make the most of their time together before his next trip.

headline: Going Beyond Time
abstract: The charitable projects supported by Swiss watch companies range from protecting the oceans to fighting illiteracy.
lead_paragraph: Every year has its new watches and novelties that wow with good looks and mechanical wizardry. But among those timepieces are a few that give a little more, their brands pledging to donate a portion of sales to good causes, such as helping impoverished communities or protecting the environment.

headline: The Art of the Arctic
abstract: Rime-encrusted trees on the high fells of Lapland look like surreal sculptures.
lead_paragraph: Rime-encrusted trees on the high fells of Lapland look like surreal sculptures.

headline: In Lapland, Nature’s Outdoor Sculpture Park
abstract: Trees on the high Arctic fells here are so coated in frosty rime that they look like towers of shaving foam, or maybe a giant column of popcorn.
lead_paragraph: AKASLOMPOLO, Finland — I strapped on snowshoes and wriggled into multiple layers of spandex and fleece to trek up Kukastunturi, a 1,555-foot-high Arctic fell, a word derived from the Old Norse fjall, for a high, barren landscape.

headline: In Jewelry, the Personal Connection
abstract: Custom and customized jewelry is becoming increasingly popular. As one wearer said, “So many people have all the same jewelry.”
lead_paragraph: Julie Pellerin lives with her boyfriend at his stud farm in Normandy, has an apartment in Paris and adores New York.

headline: Paper Cuts
abstract: The Swiss art of Scherenschnitt tells stories in silhouette.
lead_paragraph: WENGEN, Switzerland — My husband, Paul, surprised me with a special gift this year: a handmade Swiss Scherenschnitt, or “scissors cut.”

headline: The Plush Pleasure of Velvet
abstract: Sometimes in an uncertain world, you just need the feel of this luxurious fabric.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — ’Tis the season for wearing velvet — or so it would seem during a browse through the Notting Hill branch of the high-end boutique Matches.

headline: Amulya Nagarur, Muthu Vaduganathan
abstract: The couple met in 2013 during their internal medicine residencies at Massachusetts General Hospital.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Amulya Nagarur and Dr. Muthu Vaduganathan were married Nov. 25 in Atlanta. Srinivasa Sarma, a Hindu priest, performed the ceremony at the Grand Hyatt Atlanta in Buckhead, with Manicka Bhattar, also a Hindu priest, taking part.

headline: Stacey Kmetyk, Michael Burke
abstract: The couple, who met at a Cajun dance party, have married at the Prince Hall Lodge and Masonic Temple in New York.
lead_paragraph: Stacey Christine Kmetyk and Michael Francis Burke were married Nov. 25 at the Prince Hall Lodge and Masonic Temple in New York. Celine Robinson, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Noelle Kenel-Pierre, Michael Frisbie
abstract: The couple were introduced through the OkCupid website in January 2013.
lead_paragraph: Noelle Kenel-Pierre and Michael Thomas Frisbie were married Nov. 26 at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Jamaica Estates, Queens. The Rev. Christopher Cleary performed the ceremony.

headline: Marixa Dygico, Michael Kaplan
abstract: The couple met through Plenty of Fish, a dating website, in December 2015.
lead_paragraph: Marixa Cada Dygico and Michael Louis Kaplan were married Nov. 26 at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York. The Rev. Dr. Joseph G. Marabe, the bride’s great-uncle and a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Norberto Eyule, another priest, taking part.

headline: Melissa Marrero, Gustavo Camilo
abstract: The couple met at school in Santo Domingo, and reconnected in New York.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Michelle Marrero and Gustavo Jose Camilo were married Nov. 26 at Parroquia San José de Calasanz, a Roman Catholic church in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. Peter Garrido, a friend of the couple and a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jessica Hof, Yaniv Soha
abstract: The bride is a procurement manager for Coty; the groom is a senior editor at Doubleday.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Rose Hof and Yaniv Eitan Soha were married Nov. 26 at the Green Building in Brooklyn. Rabbi Marc Katz officiated, with Cantor Shanna Zell taking part.

headline: Kimberly Dixon, Gregory Kirschenbaum
abstract: The bride and groom attended the University of Delaware but didn’t meet until after graduation, when both were at a party in New York.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Rebecca Dixon, a daughter of Sherry L. Seeney of Dover, Del., and Gregory A. Dixon of Smyrna, Del., and a stepdaughter of Kimm L. Dixon, was married Nov. 26 to Gregory William Kirschenbaum, the son of Sherryl D. Kirschenbaum and George A. Kirschenbaum of New York. Rabbi Sue Levi Elwell officiated at the Carriage House at Rockwood Park, an event space in Wilmington, Del.

headline: Aditi Maliwal, Jacob Stern
abstract: The couple met at Stanford, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Aditi Maliwal, the daughter of Srividya Maliwal and Rajiv Maliwal of Singapore, was married Nov. 24 to Jacob Josephson Stern, the son of Nancy Josephson Sanitsky and David B. Stern, both of Los Angeles.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: 2016 Soul Train Awards and ‘Divorce’

lead_paragraph: Erykah Badu gets her groove on as host of the 2016 Soul Train Awards. “The Affair” flashes back a year in the life of Noah Solloway. And Season 1 of “Divorce” threatens to end on a high note.

headline: Little Havana Reacts to Castro's Death
abstract: On Saturday night, hundreds of Cuban-Americans took to the streets of Miami to celebrate the death of Fidel Castro, who had ruled Cuba for nearly half a century.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, hundreds of Cuban-Americans took to the streets of Miami to celebrate the death of Fidel Castro, who had ruled Cuba for nearly half a century.

headline: One Family. Six Decades. Myriad Views of Fidel Castro’s Revolution.
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Families and Family Life', 'Shortages', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The clash of emotions common in Cuban families is reflected in a grandfather’s loyalty to Mr. Castro and a granddaughter’s glum view of conditions in her country.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — When Fidel Castro rode victoriously into Havana on Jan. 8, 1959, Juan Montes Torre rushed into the streets to cheer. A poor, uneducated laborer from the eastern countryside of Cuba, he had arrived in the capital a few years earlier and, like most of his neighbors, could hardly believe what was happening.

headline: Fidel Castro, Donald Trump, Cyber Monday: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Subdued Cuba Prepares Memorial for Castro
abstract: A two-day memorial and a period of “Duelo Nacional,” or national mourning, will offer Cubans a chance to pay their respects to the longtime leader.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Cuba is preparing for Fidel Castro’s final public appearance: a two-day memorial offering Cubans a chance to pay their respects.

headline: Invoking Radicals of America’s Recent Past in a Politically Fraught Present
keywords: ['Theater', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The outcome of this year’s election gives “Party People,” a play now at the Public Theater that draws on the ideas and activism of groups like the Black Panthers and Young Lords, a special urgency.
lead_paragraph: Shadows dissolved as the stage lights went up at the Public Theater in Manhattan, revealing Malik, a young man with a beret and an attitude to match. Alone, he summoned the spirit of the Black Panthers as he repeated his best defiant declaration: a gut-punching, all-purpose curse, practiced in anticipation of arrest.

headline: Final Departure for 111-Year-Old Hudson Ferryboat
abstract: The Binghamton, after more than 60 years as a ferry and decades as a floating restaurant in New Jersey, will be demolished despite its historic status.
lead_paragraph: EDGEWATER, N.J. — The ferryboat Binghamton, a workhorse that served on the Hudson River for more than a century, will soon make its final departure.

headline: Israel Defense Forces Kill 4 ISIS-Linked Attackers in Golan Heights
abstract: The firefight, near Syria, appeared to be the first deadly exchange between Israeli forces and fighters associated with the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military said it killed four militants linked to the Islamic State on Sunday after they attacked Israeli forces in the Golan Heights.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: It’s been a heck of a run, but what’s next?
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Trump Claims, With No Evidence, That ‘Millions of People’ Voted Illegally
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The president-elect made the unsubstantiated claim as part of a storm of Twitter posts voicing anger about a three-state recount push.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he had fallen short in the popular vote in the general election only because millions of people had voted illegally, leveling the baseless claim as part of a daylong storm of Twitter posts voicing anger about a three-state recount push.

abstract: Reaction to the death of the Cuban revolutionary leader.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Afghan Vice President Seen Abducting Rival
abstract: The vice president, Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, is accused of having a political rival beaten “in a barbaric way” at a sporting event, before kidnapping him.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — As heavy snow fell on the muddy arena in northern Afghanistan where a traditional game of buzkashi — two teams of horsemen fighting for a dead goat — was underway on Friday, a scuffle broke out near the stands.

headline: ‘Moana’ Has the Second Best Thanksgiving Weekend Opening of All Time
abstract: Disney Animation Studios, and its corporate sibling, Pixar, now hold the top six spots for opening weekends over the Thanksgiving holiday period.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With the mega-arrival of “Moana” over the holiday weekend, the reinvigorated Walt Disney Animation Studios cemented its status as cartoon-dom’s reigning powerhouse for non-sequel films.

headline: South Korean Leader Digs In Against Rising Calls for Impeachment
abstract: A bizarre scandal and an escalating backlash could make President Park Geun-hye the first South Korean leader to be removed from office since 1979.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — She is facing impeachment and prosecution over allegations of corruption and influence-peddling. One of her advisers is being likened to Rasputin by a shrill South Korean news media. Increasingly large crowds of protesters have taken to the streets, demanding her resignation.

headline: Fidel Castro, François Fillon, Narendra Modi: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Nico Rosberg Takes Formula One Drivers’ Title Despite Lewis Hamilton’s Win in Abu Dhabi
abstract: After racing, and losing to, Hamilton when they were children, and after finishing second to him in the drivers’ competition the past two seasons, Rosberg finally came out on top.
lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Lewis Hamilton may have won the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix on Sunday, and he may have won 10 races this season compared to nine victories for his Mercedes teammate, Nico Rosberg.

headline: Marianne Elliott to Direct Sondheim and Furth’s ‘Company,’ With a Gender Twist
abstract: As part of her theater company’s slate of offerings, the director will make the lead character of this 1970 musical a woman in a London staging.
lead_paragraph: The Tony-winning director Marianne Elliott’s new theater company will feature a gender-twisting production of Stephen Sondheim and George Furth’s 1970 musical “Company,” in London.

headline: Monday’s N.F.L. Matchup: Green Bay Packers (4-6) at Philadelphia Eagles (5-5)
abstract: Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers has to overcome both the Eagles’ tough defense and his ragged one.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

headline: Obama Expands War With Al Qaeda to Include Shabab in Somalia
abstract: The administration’s move to stretch a 2001 war authorization will strengthen Donald J. Trump’s authority to combat thousands of Somali militants, and has drawn objections from some experts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The escalating American military engagement in Somalia has led the Obama administration to expand the legal scope of the war against Al Qaeda, a move that will strengthen President-elect Donald J. Trump’s authority to combat thousands of Islamist fighters in the chaotic Horn of Africa nation.

headline: Gunfire Kills 1 in French Quarter of New Orleans
abstract: Two men were arrested on illegal gun possession charges after a shooting on Bourbon Street that also wounded nine people.
lead_paragraph: One man was killed and nine others were shot early Sunday morning on Bourbon Street in New Orleans, a teeming tourist destination that was more crowded than usual after the conclusion of a major college football game.

headline: Giants Add to the Winless Browns’ Misery
abstract: The Giants sent the Browns to 0-12. Four more losses, and Cleveland will become the second 0-16 team in N.F.L. history, joining the 2008 Detroit Lions.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Like pushing on an open door, the Giants handled the winless Cleveland Browns on Sunday afternoon, with wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. overcoming a thumb injury early on to catch six passes for 96 yards and two touchdowns in a 27-13 victory.

headline: At World Chess Championship, Familiar Overtones of East-West Politics
abstract: A Russian and a Norwegian are battling in a contest that is once again taking place during escalating tensions among Russia, the United States and Western Europe.
lead_paragraph: A Cold War battle has been playing out in Lower Manhattan for the last three weeks, in a soundproof glass chamber watched by partisans around the world. When the contest ends this week, victory will belong either to a resurgent Russia or to Norway, a wary neighbor along Russia’s increasingly militarized border.

headline: As She Fights Cancer, a Woman Strives for Normalcy
abstract: Patricia Lewis, 68, is focused on enjoying her grandchildren after losing her health and career to breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Patricia Lewis toiled as a security guard for NYC Health & Hospitals, a duty she performed along with a second, and sometimes a third, job.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 28
abstract: The following tax-exempt, fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: ‘By Women Possessed,’ a Remix of a Flawed Eugene O’Neill
abstract: This book by Arthur and Barbara Gelb expresses a professional admiration for Mr. O’Neill but goes into great detail about the unflattering parts of his life.
lead_paragraph: The night that Eugene O’Neill’s five-hour drama “Strange Interlude” opened on Broadway in 1928, the anxious playwright stayed away. He sent in his stead not his wife, Agnes, but a woman with whom he had lately grown obsessed and for whom he would soon abandon Agnes — the glamorous actress Carlotta Monterey.

headline: In College Football, Getting the Right Coach Is the Top Priority
abstract: The sport’s playing field has been leveled by the amount of money more and more universities are willing to spend. So choosing a competent leader has become critical.
lead_paragraph: The eminent college football program puttered along for a decade. There were a couple of 10-win seasons, but mostly inferior ones. Over 10 seasons, the team had four interim and permanent head coaches and, not accounting for N.C.A.A. sanctions, went 67-82. The punishment did not help, but neither did a general feeling of malaise and inconsistency — in short, the effects of suboptimal coaching.

headline: To Save Punk’s Soul, a Bonfire of Some of Its Vanities on the Thames
keywords: ['Pop and Rock Music', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs', 'Music', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Joe Corré, son of the Sex Pistols’ former manager, set fire to music memorabilia to protest Punk London, an event he considers too mainstream.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Joe Corré, the son of Malcolm McLaren, the Sex Pistols manager who defined the band’s direction in its brief heyday in the late 1970s, set fire to what he claimed was £5 million (about $6.25 million) worth of punk memorabilia aboard a boat on the Thames River here on Saturday.

headline: Review: Pick a ‘Nutcracker,’ One From Balanchine, the Other Reimagined
abstract: The Cincinnati Ballet performed this holiday staple at the Kennedy Center while New York City Ballet opened its seasonal tradition with “George Balanchine’s ‘The Nutcracker.’”
lead_paragraph: Tchaikovsky’s music for “The Nutcracker” is and isn’t familiar. You think you’ve known it forever — it’s quoted all across popular culture — and yet you have only to listen to the overture, where the sprightly melody is soon irregularly punctuated by staccato chords, to hear how multilayered it is and how unpredictable. No single version has all the answers — not even “George Balanchine’s ‘The Nutcracker,’” which opened with New York City Ballet in 1954 and today is a holiday staple for multiple companies from Copenhagen to Seattle.

headline: Combative, Populist Steve Bannon Found His Man in Donald Trump
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Mr. Bannon courted politicians who share his dark, populist worldview of a ruling class preying on working Americans and “the Judeo-Christian West” in a “war against Islamic fascism.”
lead_paragraph: When Julia Jones arrived at her office in Santa Monica at 8 a.m. — by Hollywood screenwriter standards, the crack of dawn — she found Stephen K. Bannon already at his desk, which was cluttered with takeout coffees. They were co-writers on a Ronald Reagan documentary, but Mr. Bannon had pretty much taken it over. He had been at work for hours, he told her, writing feverishly about his political hero.

headline: Whitney Biennial to Miami Artists: It’s Not Us, It’s You
abstract: For the fourth Biennial in a row, no Miami artist was chosen; a Biennial adviser said the determining factor was art that addressed social upheavals.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — As the art world’s eyes turn toward this week’s Art Basel Miami Beach fair, you might imagine its homegrown artists relishing the moment. Yet more than a little grumbling can be heard here, much of it over the recent announcement of the 63 artists selected for the Whitney Museum of American Art’s 2017 Biennial.

headline: Children’s Game
abstract: Kristian House starts our solving week on the run.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Everyone needs a reason to get out of bed on a Monday morning, and that’s precisely what Kristian House has in store for us today.

headline: The Lasting Legacy of a Fighter for the Amazon
abstract: Chico Mendes’s murder in 1988 became a turning point in Brazil’s environmental consciousness, and after it, a global movement to save the Amazon gained impetus.
lead_paragraph: Chico Mendes was hard to kill. No one knew that better than his enemies in Brazil’s Amazon rain forest. They had failed in half a dozen assassination attempts.

headline: Nintendo’s New Console May Feed Your Nostalgia, if You Can Get One
keywords: ['Black Friday and Cyber Monday (Shopping)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Toys']
abstract: The NES Classic Edition, a smaller version of a 30-year-old game system, is one of the year’s hottest gifts. But the trip down memory lane isn’t without headaches.
lead_paragraph: When she heard that Nintendo was planning to reproduce its iconic Nintendo Entertainment System video game console for the holiday season, Emily Bradbury put a note on her calendar and set an alarm on her phone.

headline: Even as Trudeau Reaches Out to First Nations, Mercury Rises
abstract: The Canadian prime minister has made reconciliation with native peoples a critical goal. But an environmental threat could scuttle his mission.
lead_paragraph: Billy Gauthier, an Inuk artist who lives in Labrador on Canada’s remote northeastern coast, began his hunger strike on Oct. 13 after a plate of salmon. The meal was highly symbolic.

headline: In India, Black Money Makes for Bad Policy
abstract: Demonetization will put only a temporary dent in corruption, if even that, and it may rock the entire economy.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On Nov. 8, the Indian government announced an immediate ban on two major bills that account for the vast majority of all currency in circulation. Indians would have until the end of the year to change those notes for other bills, including newly minted ones.

headline: The Little Fidel in All of Us
abstract: Who would any of us be if he hadn’t rearranged our destinies and caused this rupture in our lives?
lead_paragraph: Oakland, Calif. — THE headline scrolled through the corner of my computer screen sometime after 10 on Friday night. Fidel Castro had died. It was news I’d been waiting to hear my entire life, and yet I hesitated.

headline: François Fillon Wins Center-Right Nomination for French Presidency
abstract: Mr. Fillon, a former prime minister who pledged to limit immigration and control Islam, handily defeated Alain Juppé in a Republican Party runoff.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French voters chose a socially conservative, budget-cutting former prime minister on Sunday to lead the center-right Republican Party in next year’s presidential election. Once again, the outcome upset pollsters’ initial predictions, and it paved the way for a likely face-off with the country’s far-right party in 2017.

abstract: A toxic political war over money, jobs and globalization killed the complex trade deal that was supposed to be a signature legacy of President Obama.
lead_paragraph: A toxic political war over money, jobs and globalization killed the complex trade deal that was supposed to be a signature legacy of President Obama.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Here in Los Angeles, where nearly half of the city’s residents are Latino, Mayor Eric Garcetti has vowed to do everything he can to fight widespread deportations of illegal immigrants.

abstract: Ratings are, once again, down across the board for NBC, ABC, CBS and Fox, but each network can make the claim that it has a new show with a strong pulse.
lead_paragraph: Well, it could be worse.

lead_paragraph: Ever since Uber showed up in Europe in late 2011, the American ride-booking service has faced vocal opposition.

abstract: A researcher who co-wrote a paper in the 1990s on a crucial artificial intelligence technique feels overlooked by today’s stars in the field.
lead_paragraph: LUGANO, Switzerland — Jürgen Schmidhuber may be the Rodney Dangerfield of artificial intelligence research.

headline: South Korea’s Impeachment Process, Explained
abstract: Lawmakers say they will try to force President Park Geun-hye out of office. Here is how the process works.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korean lawmakers will vote on Friday on the impeachment of President Park Geun-hye, who is accused of helping a friend commit extortion. If she is forced from office, it will be a first for South Korea, but the process is long and uncertain. Here’s how it works.

headline: Fritz Weaver, Tony-Winning Character Actor, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Weaver won a Tony for his role in Robert Marasco’s “Child’s Play” about the malevolent environment at an exclusive Roman Catholic school for boys.
lead_paragraph: Fritz Weaver, a Tony Award-winning character actor who played a German Jewish doctor slain by the Nazis in the 1978 mini-series “Holocaust” and an Air Force colonel who becomes increasingly unstable as the nation faces a nuclear crisis in the 1964 movie “Fail Safe,”  died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

abstract: A passer-by on the Lower East Side informs a man headed to a gala event that all is not quite right with his attire.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Animosity in a Burmese Hub Deepens as Chinese Get Richer
abstract: The Chinese dominate the economy in Mandalay, Myanmar, a trading town known for dealing in minerals, timber and drugs.
lead_paragraph: MANDALAY, Myanmar — From damp and drizzly London, the siren of British imperialism, Rudyard Kipling, wrote a poem that captured the palm trees, pagodas and temple bells of Burma during colonial rule.

headline: Pauline Oliveros, Composer Who Championed ‘Deep Listening,’ Dies at 84
abstract: Ms. Oliveros also addressed the theme of gender inequality repeatedly and tenaciously.
lead_paragraph: Pauline Oliveros, a composer whose life’s work aspired to enhance sensory perception through what she called “deep listening,” died on Thursday at her home in Kingston, N.Y. She was 84.

headline: Can Oil Help Mexico Withstand Trump’s Attack on Trade? It’s Hard to See How
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The country’s state-owned oil company, Pemex, is saddled with debt and struggling with production. As a Donald J. Trump presidency looms, fixing it is a top priority.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD DEL CARMEN, Mexico — The town that oil built is emptying out.

headline: East or West, Hometown Favorite Mikaela Shiffrin Draws Cheers in World Cup Race
abstract: Shiffrin, who won her 10th consecutive World Cup slalom on Sunday, has ties to both sides of the United States.
lead_paragraph: KILLINGTON, Vt. — Pauline Condron, the 95-year-old grandmother of the Olympic champion Mikaela Shiffrin, had never seen her 21-year-old granddaughter ski in a World Cup race until Sunday. Condron lives in western Massachusetts, and since 1991, skiing’s World Cup circuit had avoided the Eastern United States.

headline: A Child Forged in Loss and Fury, in a City Far From Havana
abstract: A reporter born after her family was exiled from Cuba reflects on growing up in Miami, in Fidel Castro’s shadow.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — I did not meet Fidel Castro in a history book like most American children. I met him in my house surrounded by “early exile” furniture, a term my mother favored. I bumped into him at the dining room table over a meal or in the living room while the grown-ups drank tumblers of whiskey or at the beach when my mother cursed him, toes in the sand, as she remembered Cuba’s idyllic beaches.

headline: So Much More Than Laughing Out Loud
abstract: This week: when a text doesn’t mean what you think it means, stories of marine regurgitation, and a group of opera singers that no longer exists.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the most commonly texted acronyms: “LOL.” In fact, from a collection of more than 44,000 text messages sent by teenagers in New York City, “LOL” came up about 5,000 times. It ostensibly means “laughing out loud” — or “lots of love” if you’re Winston Churchill — but a linguistics researcher from Columbia University challenges both of those meanings on this week’s episode of “Tell Me Something I Don’t Know.”

headline: Review: ‘The Pigeon in the Taj Mahal,’ With a Bride-to-Be and a Trailer Park
abstract: Rural Ireland is the backdrop for this story of an unusual man named Pigeon and a woman dumped on his doorstep.
lead_paragraph: The actor John Keating is a tall bag of bones with fright-wig hair and frightened-deer eyes, a look built for character parts. That he nabs the lead role in Laoisa Sexton’s “The Pigeon in the Taj Mahal” at the Irish Repertory Theater is reason enough to see it, even if the play’s protracted execution wears out the prickly charm of its premise.

headline: Ron Glass, Who Played a Dapper Detective on ‘Barney Miller,’ Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Glass was nominated for an Emmy Award for supporting actor in 1982 for his performance on the series. He also played a mysterious preacher on “Firefly.”
lead_paragraph: Ron Glass, who portrayed Ron Harris, the dapper and intellectual detective on the ensemble television comedy series “Barney Miller” and who appeared in numerous television shows and films, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 71.

headline: That Special Present
abstract: You always remember some gifts, the ones somebody really thought about. Or the ones you wish would appear. Here, some well-known figures in the art and business world talk about great presents.
lead_paragraph: You always remember some gifts, the ones somebody really thought about. Or the ones you wish would appear. Here, some well-known figures in the art and business world talk about great presents.

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick’s Steady Hand Is Upended in Jets’ Loss to the Patriots
abstract: Fitzpatrick, attempting to rally the Jets with two minutes remaining, was stripped of the ball. New England recovered and went on to win, 22-17.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Jets decided to introduce the offensive starters before Sunday’s game against the New England Patriots, and the final player announced was quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick. One of their most popular players last season, Fitzpatrick may now be one of their least.

headline: Under Fidel Castro, Sport Symbolized Cuba’s Strength and Vulnerability
abstract: Success in baseball and boxing infused Cubans with a sense of pride and helped give Mr. Castro grounds to taunt and defy the United States, but also exposed financial problems and led to defections.
lead_paragraph: On July 24, 1959, months after coming to power, Fidel Castro took the mound at a baseball stadium in Havana to pitch an exhibition for a team of fellow revolutionaries known as Los Barbudos, the Bearded Ones.

headline: ‘I Remember Her’: Questions Persist After Break in ’70 Killing of Harlem Woman
abstract: The police recently found a match for the fingerprints of a woman whose body was found in upstate New York. Then state troopers visited a man, now 65, who said he saw her leave with two “goons” one summer day.
lead_paragraph: A rabbit hunter found the body. But he went home to Queens and waited a day before calling the police because he feared trouble — it was not rabbit season.

headline: Sexual Abuse Claims in English Youth Leagues Prompt Wider Inquiry by Authorities
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Soccer', 'Coaches and Managers']
abstract: England’s Football Association announced an internal investigation into the claims after several former players came forward with accusations that they were molested as boys in youth programs.
lead_paragraph: England’s Football Association, which remained largely silent for almost two weeks as former players came forward with accusations of sexual abuse by coaches in the country’s soccer development system, announced Sunday that it was broadening an internal investigation into the claims.

headline: Lawsuit Aims to Hold 2 Contractors Accountable for C.I.A. Torture
abstract: The suit, filed by two former detainees in C.I.A. secret prisons and the representative of a third who died in custody, centers on two psychologists.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 15 years after the United States adopted a program to interrogate terrorism suspects using techniques now widely considered to be torture, no one involved in helping craft it has been held legally accountable. Even as President Obama acknowledged that the United States “tortured some folks,” his administration declined to prosecute any government officials.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 7, Episode 6: Hey Look, Another New Group!
abstract: It was fringe character week, as we left the main group behind entirely to spend an hour with Tara and Heath.
lead_paragraph: It was fringe character week on “The Walking Dead” on Sunday, as we left the main group behind entirely to spend an hour watching Tara and Heath scavenge, frolic in a zombie sandbox and negotiate post-apocalypse morality.

headline: ‘Insecure’ Season 1 Finale: Great Expectations
abstract: For all its comedic trappings, the finale traffics in a new level of heartbreak and honesty.
lead_paragraph: “I miss you,” Lawrence says over the phone to Issa toward the end of this week’s episode. This statement suggests that maybe Lawrence isn’t all that interested in the single life his friends introduce him to, full of easy sex, nights at gaudy strip clubs and a startling lack of empathy for the black women they take on as romantic partners. His phone call provides enough of a glimmer of hope to prompt Issa to leave Kelli’s birthday trip and travel home in the middle of the night. But their phone call proves to be more of a wistful goodbye than anything else, proving once again that, for all its comedic trappings, “Insecure” is far more brutal than it originally appeared.

headline: ‘The Affair’ Season 3, Episode 2: Helen, Alison and Furkat
abstract: “The Affair” got back to multistranded business as usual following its Noah-centric season premiere.
lead_paragraph: “The Affair” got back to multistranded business as usual following its Noah-centric season premiere. On Sunday night we got an episode that was about two-thirds Helen and one-third Alison, a ratio I think most of us here at recap central can live with.

headline: With Shifts in National Mood Come Shifts in Words We Use, Study Suggests
keywords: ['Language and Languages', 'Archives and Records', 'English Language', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: A new analysis of Google Books and The New York Times archives suggests that when things get bad, the words do, too.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the election, it’s clear American society is fractured. Negative emotions are running amok, and countless words of anger and frustration have been spilled. If you were to analyze this news outlet for the ratio of positive emotional words to negative ones, would you find a dip linked to the events of the past few weeks?

headline: Argentina Rallies Against Croatia to Win First Davis Cup Title
abstract: After Juan Martín del Potro beat Marin Cilic to even the match, Federico Delbonis defeated Ivo Karlovic in straight sets.
lead_paragraph: Argentina won its first Davis Cup title on Sunday when Federico Delbonis beat Ivo Karlovic in straight sets to complete a stunning 3-2 comeback win over Croatia. It was Argentina’s fifth appearance in the final.

lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: Bob Dylan in ‘Dont Look Back’ and HBO Visits Cuba
abstract: D.A. Pennebaker’s 1967 film of Bob Dylan on tour chronicles a poet in the making. And two HBO documentaries capture Cuba on the brink of change.
lead_paragraph: In “Dont Look Back,” D. A. Pennebaker captures a poet in the making as he follows Bob Dylan on tour. And just days after the death of Fidel Castro, two HBO documentaries capture Cuba on the brink of change.

headline: Fidel Castro’s Sister, an Outspoken Critic, Takes No Joy in His Death
abstract: Juanita Castro, who fled Cuba decades ago and became a vocal critic of her brother’s regime, expressed disdain for those who rejoiced over his death.
lead_paragraph: CORAL GABLES, Fla. — Juanita Castro considered her brother Fidel a traitor and had not spoken to him in 52 years, but, even so, she feels that a piece of her is missing now that he is dead.

headline: What Castro’s Death Means for a Child of Mariel
abstract: We left Cuba and our extended family behind in 1980. Nothing can bring those lost years back.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, I’d break into a cold sweat anytime the rumor circulated that Fidel Castro was dead. To me that meant returning to the island that was supposed to be home, but that I barely remembered. “I don’t know anyone there,” I’d think. “Where will I go to school? Where will we live?”

headline: ‘Westworld’ Season 1, Episode 9: You Broke My Mind
abstract: Maeve continues to move forward while everyone else moves inward.
lead_paragraph: Among other things, “Westworld” is a metaphor for the act of creation — which, in essence, makes it a show about its own creation. We may have been promised the same thing as the guests: an Old West adventure, loaded with the sex and violence that we’ve come to expect from an HBO show. But the show has devoted itself to defying those expectations at every turn, by making pleasure another component to be analyzed, like a cold body on a slab. “Westworld” has a story to tell, but it’s also about storytelling, constantly forcing us to recognize the falseness of the stories that are given to us and the stories that we tell ourselves. Somewhere at the bottom of it all is the truth — “the center of the maze,” to use the show’s expression — but not even that feels like terra firma at this point. It could be just another rug for the show’s creators to pull.

headline: Retired Coal Miners Losing Their Safety Net
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Coal', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Mitch McConnell should help retirees who worked in a dangerous industry and deserve what was promised by contract.
lead_paragraph: The troubled coal industry, which stirred such great political concern during the presidential campaign, is about to take on a decidedly human dimension in the Senate. A bipartisan push is underway there to rescue the failing pension and health benefits of thousands of retired union coal miners. Their benefit plans have become severely underfunded during the industry’s downturn, as coal companies declare bankruptcy and renege on obligations to workers at a time when there are fewer young miners to contribute support.

headline: Pentagon: Looking for a Few Good Hackers
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Computer Security', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: The last thing the Pentagon would seem to need is more hackers. But Defense Department officials are inviting them in.
lead_paragraph: In June 2015, the Office of Personnel Management announced that foreign hackers had stolen the personnel records of millions of federal employees, one of the most damaging cyberattacks in history. Just weeks later, the office of the Joint Chiefs of Staff shut down its unclassified email system for several days after officials detected that it had been breached.

headline: Why Corruption Matters
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s not the money, it’s the incentives.
lead_paragraph: Remember all the news reports suggesting, without evidence, that the Clinton Foundation’s fund-raising created conflicts of interest? Well, now the man who benefited from all that innuendo is on his way to the White House. And he’s already giving us an object lesson in what real conflicts of interest look like, as authoritarian governments around the world shower favors on his business empire.

headline: An Auction That Could Transform Local Media
abstract: Billions of dollars could result from an auction of public airwaves — money that could be invested to counter the decline in local journalism.
lead_paragraph: With the demand for wireless broadband growing, the Federal Communications Commission is auctioning off a big chunk of the public airwaves. Billions of dollars are likely to change hands, a windfall that could transform local media across the country.

headline: Divisions in My Dorm Room
abstract: Liberals and conservatives, on campus and off, have spent too much time in their own political bubbles.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election was the last thing on my mind on Nov. 8. I had essays to write and Italian vocabulary to learn. Sure, I kept New York Times and Wall Street Journal tabs open on my laptop, but I was uninterested in indulging in conversation about an election that most everyone could agree was a time bomb.

headline: The G.O.P. and Health Care Chaos
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: Donald Trump and Congress want to repeal the Affordable Care Act, but they have no good ideas for replacing it.
lead_paragraph: What will happen if President-elect Donald Trump and Republicans in Congress carry out their pledge to repeal the Affordable Care Act, the 2010 health reform law? By most estimates,  up to 22 million people, many of them poor or older Americans, will lose their health insurance.

headline: Fake News and the Internet Shell Game
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Philosophy']
abstract: Even as others deceive us, we deceive ourselves.
lead_paragraph: Only a few days after the presidential election, the Oxford English Dictionary crowned its international word of the year: post-truth. The dictionary defined it as “relating to or denoting circumstances in which objective facts are less influential in shaping public opinion than appeals to emotion and personal belief.” To say that the term captured the zeitgeist of 2016 is a lexigraphical understatement. The word, the dictionary’s editors explained, had “gone from being a peripheral term to being a mainstay in political commentary.”

headline: Keeping Guatemalan Immigrants at Home
abstract: After almost being killed in New Jersey, a Guatemalan immigrant returned to his hometown to help provide jobs and training so people won’t have to leave.
lead_paragraph: There’s a predictable narrative about immigration that assumes people would rather live in the United States than wherever they came from and that they don’t look back unless we send them back. We rarely hear about the immigrants who choose to go home voluntarily. Eduardo Jimenez is one such person.
