headline: Trump’s Promises Will Be Hard to Keep, but Coal Country Has Faith
keywords: ['Coal', 'Mines and Mining', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Though experts say out-of-work miners are likely to be disappointed by Donald J. Trump’s economic plans, his supporters in West Virginia believe he can bring jobs back.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSON, W.Va. — If a single moment captured coal country’s despair this year, it was when Bo Copley, a soft-spoken, out-of-work mine maintenance planner, fought tears as he asked Hillary Clinton how, having dismissed coal’s future in language that came back to haunt her, she could “come in here and tell us you’re going to be our friend.”

abstract: Shopping for groceries or walking the dog can be more helpful than offering false optimism.
lead_paragraph: What do you think is the most commonly asked question of a person who has, or has had, cancer? If you guessed, “How are you?” you got it right.

abstract: President Park Geun-hye’s government is backing away from insisting on the use of only state-issued textbooks that critics say play down darker aspects of recent history.

headline: When Having Insurance Still Leaves You Dangerously Uncovered
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: More Americans are insured, but many are still underinsured — meaning that they are exposed to significant financial risk from out-of-pocket payments.
lead_paragraph: One of the few things that Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton seemed to agree on was that high out-of-pocket spending on health care was a problem. One of Mrs. Clinton’s most popular health care proposals during her campaign was to reduce out-of-pocket spending to more “manageable” levels for many Americans. President-elect Trump said he could fix this problem by repealing Obamacare and replacing it with something better.

headline: Oscars 2017: Presidential Politics and Hollywood’s Big Races
abstract: The field is dotted with possibilities, but no critical or box office heavy hitters. The season gets started with the Gotham Independent awards.
lead_paragraph: Ready for some distraction? Chances are the national events of recent weeks have left you somewhere on the spectrum from despairing to agog to pleased as punch, and at the very least weary of all that the past year’s political campaigning has drummed up and drawn out.

headline: On the Road
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Families and Family Life', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: I may miss the old disconnection of travel, but as a parent, I love staying in touch with my children as they go off adventuring.
lead_paragraph: I’m writing this from Madrid. I last visited this beautiful city during a 1970s year off from college; my boyfriend and I were on a long trip through Europe, the kind with backpacks, a tent and battered paperback books that you traded with other travelers when you finished reading them. Franco had died fairly recently, and Spain was in the midst of its first elections in decades. We had taken slow, unmodernized trains from Barcelona down south to Granada, then on to Seville and Cordoba. And when we got to Madrid, the first thing we did, of course, was head to American Express, where we exchanged our carefully stashed traveler’s checks and picked up our mail.

headline: Aquarium on Ice, a Lure for Skaters in Japan, Appalls Them Instead
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Ice Skating']
abstract: A Japanese theme park tried to draw visitors by freezing 5,000 fish beneath its ice rink, but a public outcry forced it to close the attraction after just two weeks.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The Japanese are known around the world for turning fish into centerpieces of culinary art. But an amusement park’s recent effort to pair frozen fish and ice-skating proved less enduring.

headline: Fidel in All His Facets
abstract: It’s feeble for Obama to say history will judge Castro. There’s been plenty of history in Cuba since 1959, much of it deplorable.
lead_paragraph: Napoleon is said to have remarked that if only a cannonball had hit him when he was riding into Moscow in 1812, he would have gone down in history as the greatest man who ever lived. In similar fashion, Fidel Castro outlived the moment of his greatness, if not the romance of his appeal.

headline: Venus Flytraps Need Protection From Poachers in North Carolina
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Black Markets']
abstract: North Carolina is more aggressively protecting the plants, which grow in the wild only in a 75-mile radius near Wilmington, as fears of extinction increase.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina has a long and colorful bond with Venus flytraps, the carnivorous plants that grow in the wild only in a 75-mile radius around Wilmington.

headline: Space’s Trash Collector? A Japanese Entrepreneur Wants the Job
abstract: A start-up company called Astroscale is dedicated to cleaning up some of humanity’s hardest-to-reach rubbish, and its plans include a small satellite with an adhesive glue.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Sitting in a drab industrial neighborhood surrounded by warehouses and factories, Astroscale’s Tokyo office seems appropriately located for a company seeking to enter the waste management business.

headline: CNN Brings In the Social App Beme to Cultivate a Millennial Audience
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Social Media', 'Cable Television', 'Millennial Generation', 'Youth']
abstract: The cable news network will shut down the social media app and absorb its 12 employees, who will work to persuade younger, more skeptical viewers to tune in.
lead_paragraph: With millions of people regularly tuning in to his YouTube video blogs every morning, Casey Neistat has a millennial fan base coveted by both marketers and media companies. Now, one of those big media outlets is bringing Mr. Neistat — and, it hopes, his youthful audience — in-house.

headline: U.K. Independence Party Picks Paul Nuttall to Replace Nigel Farage as Leader
abstract: Mr. Nuttall, a European Parliament member for the conflicted, anti-immigration party, is taking a job that many others have been unwilling or unable to hold.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The spectacle surrounding the U.K. Independence Party continued on Monday, as the party named Paul Nuttall as its leader after the previous one resigned last month after less than three weeks in charge, citing internal squabbles and rivalries.

headline: California Today: Fretting Over the ‘Netflix Tax’
abstract: Monday: Cities mull a tax on video streaming services, sanctuary cities vow to fight Donald J. Trump on immigration, and a look back at a rebellion for California secession.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Germany Gleefully Leads List of World’s Top Recyclers
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: According to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Germans sort 65 percent of their waste into an array of color-coded bins.
lead_paragraph: The praise from a German friend was the first sign that I had gone native.

headline: Professor Watchlist Is Seen as Threat to Academic Freedom
abstract: The new website names nearly 200 professors who it says “advance a radical agenda in lecture halls.”
lead_paragraph: A new website that accuses nearly 200 college professors of advancing “leftist propaganda in the classroom” and discriminating against conservative students has been criticized as a threat to academic freedom.

headline: Is Digital Connectedness Good or Bad for People?
abstract: People of all ages are spending more and more time online. Does this trend improve lives or hurt them?

headline: Dylann Roof to Represent Himself at Trial in Charleston Church Shootings
keywords: ['Charleston, SC, Shooting (2015)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: A federal judge called the request by Mr. Roof “strategically unwise,” but allowed him to have lawyers present as backup.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A federal judge on Monday granted Dylann S. Roof’s request to represent himself in his hate crimes trial on charges of killing nine African-American parishioners at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., raising the possibility that the avowed white supremacist could cross-examine survivors and family members of the deceased.

headline: Everyone Has an Opinion After Broncos’ Overtime Gamble Fails
abstract: On a fourth-and-10 near the end of overtime, Coach Gary Kubiak could have punted or gone for it, but he opted for a 62-yard field-goal attempt.
lead_paragraph: As a rollicking game drew to a close Sunday night, Coach Gary Kubiak and the Denver Broncos had a decision to make. They had the ball on fourth-and-10 at the Kansas City 44-yard line with three options: punt, go for it or try a field goal. There was just more than a minute left in overtime, and the score was tied, 27-27.

headline: 1891: The ‘Times’ Must Tell
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The London “Times” newspaper is summoned by the Lord Chief Justice to state the detail of its circulation in November 1891.
lead_paragraph: In the Queen’s Bench Division today, [Nov. 28] Mr. Lumley Smith appeared in the case of Romney v. Walter and another, in support of an appeal by the defendants, the proprietors of the Times newspaper, against an order in Chambers that they should give a better answer to an interrogatory as to the circulation of their newspaper by stating approximately what the circulation was on September 25, 1891. The defendants answered that the Times had a large and extensive circulation, but could not say the exact number without a troublesome and expensive inquiry from people having no interest in the matter.

headline: Holocaust-Themed Ice Dance in Russia Draws Condemnation
keywords: ['Ice Dancing', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Movies', 'Television', 'Ice Skating']
abstract: The televised act, performed by Tatiana Navka, a skater married to an aide of President Vladimir V. Putin, was based on the film “Life Is Beautiful.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Dressed as concentration camp inmates, each wearing a striped uniform with the yellow Star of David sewn on, the couple glided in harmony, moving to a song from the 1997 Holocaust film “Life Is Beautiful.” Barking dogs can be heard. The routine ends with simulated machine-gun fire and the woman, looking stunned and stricken, standing alone on the ice.

headline: A Baby Court Offers Hope for Families
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Children and Childhood', 'Domestic Violence', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Families and Family Life', 'Family Courts', 'Human Trafficking', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Poverty', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A court thinks big to address poverty.
lead_paragraph: As a family court judge in Flint, Michigan, I see poverty flood my courtroom in a vicious cycle of cases in dependency, delinquency, criminality, and then back to dependency. The mantra in family court is that no one should lose their kids because they’re poor. The sad reality is that this happens all too often when generational poverty creates what Nicholas Kristof calls a “broken class.”

headline: A New Biography of Joan Rivers
abstract: Leslie Bennetts’s “Last Girl Before Freeway” revisits milestones in Joan Rivers’s life, like her childhood, marriage and famous break with Johnny Carson.
lead_paragraph: LAST GIRL BEFORE FREEWAYThe Life, Loves, Losses, and Liberation of Joan RiversBy Leslie BennettsIllustrated. 419 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $28.

headline: Suspect Is Killed in Attack at Ohio State University That Injured 11
keywords: ['School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A man veered his car onto the sidewalk at the campus, leaped out, and stabbed several people with a butcher knife, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: A student at Ohio State University intentionally rammed a car into pedestrians on a busy campus sidewalk on Monday morning and then began slashing passers-by with a butcher knife, the authorities said, injuring 11 students and faculty and staff members, and setting off panic at one of the nation’s largest public universities.

headline: Stuck at the Bottom in China
abstract: After decades of breakneck economic growth, the country’s wealth has ceased trickling down, bringing social mobility to a standstill.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In the early 1980s, China’s top leader, Deng Xiaoping, is said to have issued his now-famous rallying cry in defense of a market economy. “Let some people get rich first,” he reportedly said, making the case that the Communist Party’s embrace of a freer market would generate new wealth that would eventually spread to all strata of society.

headline: Thousands Flee Aleppo, Syria, as Government Forces Advance
abstract: Troops loyal to President Bashar al-Assad drove rebels out of parts of the city, sending thousands of people fleeing for their lives.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of people were sent fleeing for their lives on Monday as rebel fighters lost a large stretch of territory to government forces in the northern Syrian city of Aleppo, in what could prove to be a turning point in the conflict, both militarily and psychologically.

headline: Ukraine Has Made Great Progress, but We Need Our Allies
abstract: Our country’s adolescent democracy needs the support of America — and its new president, the foreign minister of Ukraine writes.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — In the two years since the Revolution of Dignity, Ukraine has made more progress as a country than it had since declaring independence in 1991. We are finally tackling corruption in a meaningful way, and we have introduced a raft of reforms that will help the state to function better. After our economy contracted for two consecutive years, we now expect to see it grow again. And we have achieved all of this under the most challenging of circumstances: while fighting a Russian-led war that has cost thousands of lives, and with a Russian occupation of the Crimean peninsula and the Donbas region crippling our economy.

headline: A Dutch Architect Offshores the Future of Housing
abstract: Koen Olthuis has built more than 200 floating homes and offices, and says the concept is a solution to rising sea levels.
lead_paragraph: RIJSWIJK, The Netherlands — Early next year when a converted cargo container on a floating foundation of plastic bottles opens on the flood-prone shores of Korail Bosti, Bangladesh’s largest slum, few of its users are likely to celebrate the 320-square-foot space as a revolution. Yet, according to Koen Olthuis, the lead architect on the project, it is part of the greatest transformation in urbanism since Elisha Otis built the safety brake that gave rise to the modern elevator, skyscrapers and ultimately urban density.

headline: Take a Break
abstract: It’s O.K. to stop and catch your breath. We’re still here for you, recipes in tow.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: N.B.A. Schedule: Here’s What to Watch This Week
abstract: In an exciting television doubleheader on Thursday night, the Rockets visit the Warriors after the Clippers visit the Cavaliers.
lead_paragraph: The first full month of N.B.A. action will end this week. As if to celebrate, the league has given us a schedule filled to the brim with good games. I want to spend some extra time talking about them, and to point out an exciting statistic that suggests the improved quality of basketball throughout the league.

headline: Stop Spending Based on Other People’s Wealth
abstract: Trying to keep up with the Joneses, when the Joneses’ real finances are unknown, is unwise, a financial planner reminds us.
lead_paragraph: You know what’s worse than judging a book by its cover? Judging a book by its cover, and then making financial decisions based on what you assume the book might tell you.

headline: When It Comes to Clams, the More Broth, the Better
abstract: These Thai-style clams are made in a broth that is sweet, salty, sour and herbaceous.
lead_paragraph: After the feasting — or between feasts, at any rate — there is solace and sanity in a bowl of soup. This has long been my strategy for counteracting the annual bouts of overindulgence and aiming once again for moderation in all things, edible and otherwise.

headline: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie Talks Beauty, Femininity and Feminism
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The award-winning author, most recently of “Americanah,” is now the face of No7, the makeup brand owned by the pharmacy chain Boots.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most unexpected fashion icon of the year has just added another glossy credit to her name. Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, the Nigerian-born novelist and feminist known for novels like “Americanah” and “Purple Hibiscus”; recipient of a MacArthur “genius” grant, the O. Henry Prize and the National Book Critics Circle Award (among others); and author of a viral TED Talk, “We Should All Be Feminists,” which has been viewed over three million times since its delivery in 2012 as well as sampled by Beyoncé, is now the face of No7, the makeup brand owned by the pharmacy chain Boots.

headline: Daily Report: Uber Wants to Avoid ‘Transportation’ Label in Europe
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The ride-hailing service goes to court Tuesday to explain why it is a digital platform that would not be as heavily regulated as a traditional taxi service.
lead_paragraph: Uber abandoned its land war in China. Can it win a legal fight in Europe?

headline: How Google Knows When Your Bills Are Due
abstract: Gmail attempts to make life easier by scanning your messages and reminding you of pending events, but you can pick what you want to be nagged about.
lead_paragraph: Q. This week my smartphone received an alert from Google listing the balances due on my credit cards. My response was “never” do it again, but I have to wonder about my personal financial/identity security. How did they get this information? Is it legal?

headline: Illustrated Interview | Mariah Carey
abstract: The Grammy Award-winning, melismatic-voiced music icon, whose new reality series, “Mariah’s World,” airs on E!, sketched her answers with a Pilot fountain pen in her kitchen.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy Award-winning, melismatic-voiced music icon, whose new reality series, “Mariah’s World,” airs on E!, sketched her answers with a Pilot fountain pen in her kitchen.

abstract: A reader offers his ideas, including public-private partnerships, community service projects and drafting young adults into national service.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: California Official Says Trump’s Claim of Voter Fraud Is ‘Absurd’
abstract: Alex Padilla, the secretary of state in California, replied to Mr. Trump’s allegation on Twitter, saying claims of “voter fraud in California and elsewhere are absurd.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When President-elect Donald J. Trump claimed on Twitter that he was losing the popular vote because of major fraud by millions of voters, one of the states he pointed to was California, where the latest voting returns showed Hillary Clinton, the Democrat, crushing Mr. Trump.

headline: Spinach Salad With Fried Eggs
abstract: Flavorful pancetta and crispy fried eggs make this spinach salad a meal all by itself.
lead_paragraph: Flavorful pancetta and crispy fried eggs make this spinach salad a meal all by itself.

headline: A Warm Spinach Salad, Wearing Pancetta and Egg
abstract: This hearty main course salad pairs mature spinach — not baby leaves — with rich adornments.
lead_paragraph: When boxes of washed baby spinach first hit the stores so many years ago, my intake of the iron-rich vegetable soared.

headline: France Returns 16th-Century Portrait to Descendants of Jewish Couple
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: The painting’s owners, Henry and Hertha Bromberg, sold the work in Paris in 1938 as they fled Nazi Germany; it was returned to their grandchildren.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France on Monday officially returned a 16th-century portrait, attributed to Joos van Cleve or his son, to the descendants of Hertha and Henry Bromberg, a German-Jewish couple who were forced to sell the work of art in Paris when they fled Germany before World War II.

headline: Supreme Court Agenda in the Trump Era? A Justice Seems to Supply One
abstract: At an energized conservative legal gathering, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. suggested that only resolve on the right could rescue free speech, religious liberty and gun rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A week after the presidential election, the leaders of the conservative legal movement gathered here for the annual convention of the Federalist Society. The mood was by turns somber and giddy.

headline: Chocolate With a Buzz
abstract: These truffles pair coffee and chocolate deliciously.
lead_paragraph: Coffee and chocolate are a delicious pairing, as evidenced by this small box of truffles made by Delysia Chocolatier in Austin, Tex., using coffee from King’s Row in Hanover, N.H. King’s Row coffees come in blends devised by Craig Shelton, a James Beard Award winner who was the chef at the Ryland Inn in Whitehouse Station, N.J. The truffles have three flavors: dark chocolate with rum and orange; dark chocolate spiced with African seasonings; and milk chocolate, creamy and sweet, like Vietnamese iced coffee: Coffee Truffles by Delysia and King’s Row Coffee, $24 for a box of nine, kingsrowcoffee.com/confections.

headline: Summer Project Turns Into Leukemia Testing Breakthrough
abstract: What began as a student effort at a lab in Seattle produced a test for chronic myeloid leukemia that works with a few spots of dried blood on a paper card.
lead_paragraph: A rare but treatable form of cancer can now be diagnosed cheaply and easily with dried blood spots instead of whole blood, scientists in Seattle announced last week.

headline: Under Trump, Will NASA’s Space Science Include Planet Earth?
keywords: ['Earth', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Global Warming', 'Science and Technology', 'Space and Astronomy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Advisors to President-elect Trump see little merit in NASA emphasizing “Earth-centric” science.
lead_paragraph: Update | Here’s my ProPublica article on NASA and President-elect Trump’s advisors.

headline: For the Cheese Lover, the Ultimate Reference Book
abstract: “The Oxford Companion to Cheese” covers history, regional styles, local purveyors and more.
lead_paragraph: This new guide to cheese from Oxford University Press is authoritative, but what is surprising is how local it gets. Calandra’s Cheese on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx is listed, along with such revered fromageries as Androuet in Paris. And just to show how American cheesemakers are at the forefront of the artisanal resurgence, the book was edited by Catherine Donnelly, a professor of nutrition and food science at the University of Vermont, with a foreword by Mateo Kehler, a founder of Jasper Hill Farm in Vermont. Hundreds of writers from 35 countries contributed to this 888-page doorstop of a reference book, with entries arranged alphabetically and covering topics like regulations, techniques, history, cuisines, types of rinds, Mexican cheeses (there are some 60 varieties), Chinese cheeses and cheese museums: “The Oxford Companion to Cheese,” edited by Catherine Donnelly (Oxford, $65).

headline: Manresa’s Bread Without a Trip to California
abstract: The freshly made loaves now ship nationwide.
lead_paragraph: The bakery adjacent to Manresa, the acclaimed restaurant in Los Gatos, Calif., specializes in grain-to-flour breads. The flour is milled on-site the same day it’s used for whole wheat, sourdough and dense pumpernickel-buckwheat-rye breads, in addition to rounds stippled with fruit and nuts and an airy Pullman loaf. These breads are now shipped fresh nationwide. Warm them for 10 minutes in a 300-degree oven before serving: Manresa Bread, starting at $40 for four loaves with two-day shipping, manresabread.com.

headline: Rubell Family Collection Makes a Move
abstract: The private museum will leave Wynwood, in Miami, for the Allapattah district; Annabelle Selldorf’s architecture firm will design the new space.
lead_paragraph: After 23 years in Miami’s Wynwood district, in 2018 the Rubell Family Collection will move to a new museum designed by Selldorf Architects, on a 2.5-acre campus in Miami’s Allapattah District, the family announced on Monday.

headline: Porchetta as a Holiday Centerpiece
abstract: This Berkshire pork roast from a San Francisco butcher is a fragrant, delectable dish for a celebration.
lead_paragraph: This ready-to-roast porchetta, a boneless, rolled and seasoned piece of lean pork swaddled in pork belly, comes from a third-generation butcher, Thomas Odermatt, whose RoliRoti porchetta sandwich regularly sells out at the Ferry Plaza market in San Francisco. Mr. Odermatt, whose heritage is Swiss, ships his Berkshire pork frozen. Let it thaw for a day or so in the refrigerator, and you’ll be ready to go, with a hefty roast that emerges from the oven crackling, bronzed and succulent. The stunning centerpiece is certain to impress your holiday guests, and as it cooks, it will surely perfume your kitchen like nobody’s business: RoliRoti porchetta, $150 for five to six pounds, shipped frozen, 718-389-0985, heritagefoodsusa.com.

headline: Congress May Hold Key to Handling Trump’s Conflicts of Interest
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: If divestment or a blind trust does not solve the issue, Congress could approve actions in advance, adding transparency.
lead_paragraph: The election of a billionaire businessman as president has created a host of extreme challenges, not the least of which is how Donald J. Trump will govern while dealing with the web of real estate and other investments he has built up over a long career.

headline: A Holiday Market in the Kitchens of Food52
abstract: Tastings, cooking demonstrations and hundreds of products greet shoppers at this pop-up sale.
lead_paragraph: The products Amanda Hesser, left, and Merrill Stubbs offer on their Food52 website combine practicality with the kind of tasteful style that whispers “heirloom.” The kitchen and household goods are often exclusive to their company. For the holidays, the founders are flinging open the doors of their Manhattan offices and test kitchens for shoppers to peruse and purchase from hundreds of products. There will be tastings, cooking demonstrations, cocktails and snacks. Shipping will be free: Food52 Holiday Market, Friday to Sunday, noon to 8 p.m., 122 West 26th Street, eighth floor, food52.com.

headline: Purple Garlic From the Heart of Spain
abstract: The chef José Andrés is importing ajo morado, a milder garlic for gazpacho.
lead_paragraph: The city of Cuenca is the heart of central Spain’s garlic-growing region, providing an essential ingredient for dishes like gazpacho and garlic shrimp. Ajo morado, cultivated in the region, is the garlic of connoisseurs. It has plump bulbs holding clusters of purplish cloves with a distinctive flavor: less sharp, with an almost citrusy complexity. It is now being imported by the chef José Andrés: Ajo morado from José Andrés Foods, $6.95 for four bulbs, tienda.com.

headline: Curtis Granderson Is a Man on a Generous Mission
abstract: The veteran outfielder and three-time All-Star is a tireless worker for charities and youth programs in the Chicago area, where he grew up, and in New York.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Curtis Granderson, a very professional outfielder, gives me a walking tour of his old haunts at the University of Illinois at Chicago. He points out the baseball stadium with a backdrop of the soaring downtown skyline, and two new Little League fields with artificial turf and light towers.

headline: The Season’s Most Delicate Pastels
abstract: In a palette of pale petal, sky and sun, underpinnings peek through silk blouses and soft knits.
lead_paragraph: In a palette of pale petal, sky and sun, underpinnings peek through silk blouses and soft knits.

headline: Metallica’s ‘Hardwired ... to Self-Destruct’ Earns 3rd-Biggest Opening Week of 2016
abstract: The band’s first studio album in eight years debuted at No. 1, followed by new records by Bruno Mars and Miranda Lambert.
lead_paragraph: Metallica leads a crop of new releases on the latest Billboard album chart, as the veteran metal band topped Bruno Mars and Miranda Lambert to score its sixth consecutive No. 1 debut this week.

headline: Belgium and the Netherlands Swap Land, and Remain Friends
abstract: The discovery of a headless corpse in the Netherlands helped Belgium and its bigger Dutch neighbor resolve a property squabble that began in 1961.
lead_paragraph: From Cyprus to Ukraine, Israel to the Balkans, conflicts over land have long turned bloody. But on Monday, the Netherlands and Belgium managed to settle a festering territorial problem, without firing a single bullet and with an unlikely spur: a headless corpse.

headline: The Rise of Glam Rock
abstract: Simon Reynolds’s “Shock and Awe” covers the glory days of glam rock and its pioneers, including T. Rex, David Bowie, Alice Cooper and Roxy Music.
lead_paragraph: SHOCK AND AWEGlam Rock and Its Legacy, From the Seventies to the Twenty-First CenturyBy Simon ReynoldsIllustrated. 687 pp. Dey Street/William Morrow Publishers. Paper, $18.99.

headline: Single Mother Seeks to Give Daughter the Peace That Eluded Her
abstract: As a child, India Wayman was abused and bullied, and carried that trauma into adulthood. Now she hopes to set her child on the right path.
lead_paragraph: Above the simple gray churches along a dimly lit section of Detroit, the brooding eyes of Lil Wayne, who was covered in chains and holding a bottle of Hennessy, peered from a billboard in the rough neighborhood where India Wayman grew up.

headline: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa Faces Leadership Challenge
abstract: The African National Congress’s national executive committee introduced, for the first time, a motion urging the embattled Mr. Zuma to step down.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Weakened by scandals and electoral losses in August, President Jacob Zuma of South Africa faced a challenge to his leadership for the first time at a meeting on Monday of top officials of the governing African National Congress.

headline: A Forgotten Step in Saving African Wildlife: Protecting the Rangers
keywords: ['ANIMALS', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Many park personnel, responsible for fending off poachers, go without basic necessities like boots, tents and health insurance. Some groups are trying to change that.
lead_paragraph: ISIOLO, KENYA — Anna Phiri was 15 when her mother, a park ranger in Zambia, was murdered by poachers.

headline: C. Megan Urry, Peering Into Universe, Spots Bias on the Ground
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Black Holes (Space)', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Physics', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: The first woman to head the Yale physics department — she specializes in the study of black holes — has continued to combat gender inequities in science.
lead_paragraph: C. Megan Urry is a former president of the American Astronomical Society and the first woman to head the physics department at Yale University. Recently inducted to the National Academy of Sciences, she has published pioneering studies on the role of black holes in the formation of galaxies.

headline: Despite His Own Protests, Eric Clapton Will Return to the Road, Briefly
abstract: The guitarist has scheduled two shows at Madison Square Garden for March 2017.
lead_paragraph: The semiretired guitarist Eric Clapton, now 71, has settled upon a slate of live shows for 2017: two at Madison Square Garden in New York on March 19 and 20, and two at the Forum in Los Angeles on March 25 and 26. And that’s all, according to an announcement on Monday.

headline: My Three Days With Fidel
abstract: Richard Eder, a former New York Times foreign correspondent, recalls when he interviewed Fidel Castro in 1964.
lead_paragraph: Richard Eder, a former New York Times foreign correspondent, recalls when he interviewed Fidel Castro in 1964.

lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: A Failed Bid for Time Inc. May Be Only a Start
abstract: The bid by Edgar Bronfman Jr. and Len Blavatnik carried a 30 percent premium, and many shareholders might be glad to get out of a fading investment.
lead_paragraph: Time Inc. owners may yet send a note of thanks to Edgar Bronfman Jr. Mr. Bronfman, the Seagram heir, teamed up with the Warner Music owner Len Blavatnik to make a bid for the $1.4 billion magazine company — an offer that was rejected, according to The New York Post.

headline: Delta Air Lines Bans Disruptive Donald Trump Supporter for Life
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']

lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines has banned a disruptive passenger who shouted pro-Donald Trump and anti-Hillary Clinton remarks at fellow passengers on a flight from Atlanta to Allentown, Pa., last week, the airline’s chief executive said on Monday.

headline: Your Money Weekly: Considering the Biggest Money Question
abstract: When making financial choices, the most cosmic question of all is one that applies to nearly any situation: How much is enough?
lead_paragraph: We here on the Your Money team have a handful of essential questions that cut to the core of most any financial choice. What is the definition of success? What is the system here, and how do I beat it?

headline: ‘Trump Effect’ Is Already Shaping Events Around the World
keywords: ['Israeli Settlements', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s election is influencing markets, currencies and government policies as the world bets on how he will rewrite international rules.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Within days of Donald J. Trump’s election to the presidency, Jerusalem’s city planning chief declared an end to the era of holding up new housing for Jewish residents in contentious neighborhoods out of deference to American objections.

headline: Jimmy Carter: America Must Recognize Palestine
abstract: The two-state solution is on life support, but there is one thing Obama can do to keep the hope of a peace deal alive.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — We do not yet know the policy of the next administration toward Israel and Palestine, but we do know the policy of this administration. It has been President Obama’s aim to support a negotiated end to the conflict based on two states, living side by side in peace.

abstract: At the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, cooks tell the story of the African diaspora through food.
lead_paragraph: At the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, cooks tell the story of the African diaspora through food.

headline: Museum Cafeteria Serves Black History and a Bit of Comfort
abstract: Sweet Home Café’s mission is a tricky one: educate and nourish visitors to the new National Museum of African American History and Culture.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chefs talk about pressure all the time: brutal shifts when the wait for a table is an hour long, an important critic is in the restaurant and your best sous-chef just sliced her finger to the bone.

headline: Donald Trump’s Threat to Close Door Reopens Old Wounds in Cuba
abstract: In a post on Twitter, he said he would “terminate” the pact President Obama made if Cuba is unwilling to make “a better deal for the Cuban people.”
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — It seemed like a new chapter in a long and troubled history.

headline: With the Wines of Montsant, It’s All in the Drinking
abstract: The shortcomings of tasting versus drinking become clear with these red wines from the Catalonian region of Spain.
lead_paragraph: Tasting a wine for evaluation is something wine professionals are compelled to do. But it’s not the best way to assess a wine. It’s a compromise.

headline: Your Next Lesson: Dolcetto
abstract: These juicy wines are among the everyday reds of the Piedmont region of northwestern Italy.
lead_paragraph: In past months, we’ve sampled nebbiolos  and barberas from the Piedmont region of northwestern Italy. Next, we’ll turn to the last of the three leading Piedmont red grapes, dolcetto.

headline: ‘Born a Crime,’ Trevor Noah’s Raw Account of Life Under Apartheid
abstract: His memoir provides a harrowing look, through the prism of Mr. Noah’s family, at life in South Africa under apartheid, and the country’s entry into a postapartheid era.
lead_paragraph: As host of “The Daily Show,” Trevor Noah comes across as a wry, startled and sometimes outraged outsider, commenting on the absurdities of American life. During the presidential campaign, the South African-born comic remarked that Donald J. Trump reminded him of an African dictator, mused over the mystifying complexities of the Electoral College system and pointed out the weirdness of states voting on recreational marijuana.

headline: Why Gunshot Victims Have Reason to Like the Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Firearms']
abstract: The expansion of state Medicaid programs under the health care law has brought coverage, and necessary treatment, to previously uninsured shooting victims.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Berry can feel the bullets in his body move. One jiggles down his leg toward his ankle; another presses on his sciatic nerve; a third has migrated to his hip.

headline: Tres días con Fidel
abstract: El excorresponsal de The New York Times Richard Eder recuerda su entrevista con Fidel Castro en 1964.
lead_paragraph: El excorresponsal de The New York Times Richard Eder recuerda su entrevista con Fidel Castro en 1964.

headline: Local Transmission of Zika Virus Is Reported in Texas
abstract: Mosquitoes are spreading the virus outside of Florida for the first time.
lead_paragraph: A probable case of local transmission of the Zika virus has been reported in Texas, state health officials announced on Monday, making it the second state, after Florida, in which the infection is thought to have been carried from person to person by mosquitoes.

headline: How Tour Guides Abroad Learn to Cater to Exotic Americans
abstract: If you’re an American traveler fascinated by the foreign and exotic, understand this: Your tour guide probably finds you equally strange.
lead_paragraph: Don’t compliment an American’s girth. Answer their children’s questions. Fill your museum tour with fun facts.

headline: 5 Ways to Be a Better Tourist
abstract: People who train tour guides say there are some basic ways that Americans can be better guests when taking tours abroad.
lead_paragraph: American tourists are numerous, relatively affluent and culturally distinct enough that tour guides in other lands often receive special training to know how best to accommodate them.

headline: Navigating the New Airbnb
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Reservations (Airlines, Hotels, Etc.)']
abstract: The site is evolving into a full-fledged travel company with activities, audio walking tours, guides and, soon, restaurant bookings, even car rentals.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb, the peer-to-peer accommodations site where travelers book everything from single rooms to entire villas, has spent the last couple of years branching out. It has teamed up with airlines like Delta and Virgin America to give miles to travelers who book stays. And it has teamed up with travel management companies including American Express Global Business Travel on its Airbnb for Business program, which includes homes with business essentials such as Wi-Fi and laptop-friendly work spaces.

headline: At 41, Henry Burris Adds an Exclamation Point to a Great Canadian Career
abstract: The quarterback, from Spiro, Okla., was named the Grey Cup’s M.V.P. for a second time as the Ottawa Redblacks beat heavily favored Calgary for the C.F.L. title.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — When Henry Burris looks back on his high school football days in Spiro, Okla., he thinks of the movie “Friday Night Lights.”

headline: China Takes a Chain Saw to a Center of Tibetan Buddhism
abstract: In Larung Gar, the world’s largest Buddhist institute, demolition teams are cutting through an extraordinary vista of hand-built red dwellings.
lead_paragraph: LARUNG GAR, China — Atop a hill, a growling chain saw drowned out loudspeakers broadcasting a lama’s chants from a nearby temple.

headline: Hampshire College Draws Protests Over Removal of U.S. Flag
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Veterans']
abstract: Military veterans protested the decision this weekend, adding their voices to a debate on the Massachusetts campus that has seen the flag lowered, removed and even burned since the election.
lead_paragraph: A group of military veterans protested at a private Massachusetts college over the weekend, objecting to a decision by the college to allow the American flag to be removed from its main flagpole, and adding their voices to a debate on a campus that has seen the flag lowered, removed and even burned since the election.

headline: An Artful Photographer Captures a Trip to Russia
abstract: Jamie Hawkesworth documents scenes and people across the country for a new exhibition at J.W. Anderson Workshops.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Hawkesworth documents scenes and people across the country for a new exhibition at J.W. Anderson Workshops.

headline: A Resort Development Saga in Mexico
abstract: An English businessman who saw the low-key city of La Paz as an international second home destination says the going has not been easy.
lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Mexico — Jeffrey Curtiss’s obsession is a collection of 23 luxury condominiums on a secluded beach in La Paz, the old Mexican city on the Sea of Cortez. For 11 years Mr. Curtiss, who made his fortune in the trading and distribution business in Britain, has been building and marketing the project, Playa de La Paz, hoping to attract the type of high-end international home buyers who have traditionally bypassed La Paz. A first-time developer, he pored over every detail of the project and lived on site during construction, only to face the global economic crisis, Mexico’s drugs wars and countless construction delays.

headline: James C. Woolery Leaves Hudson Executive Capital Hedge Fund
abstract: Mr. Woolery, a co-founder of the activist fund, resigned for “personal reasons,” the firm said.
lead_paragraph: The veteran deal maker James C. Woolery has left Hudson Executive Capital, the activist hedge fund he co-founded, the firm said on Monday.

headline: Sunad’s Shirts
abstract: The Spanish line’s all-natural offerings.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish line’s all-natural offerings.

headline: Brand to Know: The Spanish Line Making Simple, Handmade Shirts
abstract: Sunad, which launched last year, crafts each garment by hand, using 100-percent natural fabrics.
lead_paragraph: Do one thing — and do it right. That’s the mind-set shared by the Parsons graduates Paloma Canut and Ana Marroquín, both from Madrid, who bonded over a love of shirts, and a frustration at not being able to find a high-quality one at a reasonable price point. So, when they decided to start their own line, Sunad, they knew exactly where to start.

headline: Magnus Carlsen and Sergey Karjakin Head to Tiebreaker in World Chess Championship
abstract: The two chess grandmasters finished the final regulation game in a draw, setting up a sudden-death game on Wednesday in the tournament, being held in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: After two-plus weeks of nail-bitingly close play, the World Chess Championship came down to its 12th and final regulation game on Monday, with the two talented young grandmasters, Sergey Karjakin and Magnus Carlsen, in a dead heat.

headline: Beyond Beer: Germany Goes All In for Gin
keywords: ['Gin (Liquor)', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES']
abstract: The nation of pilsner, riesling and schnapps is suddenly producing and consuming “a river” of the spirit.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Bar Convent Berlin, a sprawling trade show held in October in a former train station here, heralded every sort of spirit. There was a booth pouring a new German gin. There was a stand mixing daiquiris with rum from Cuba. Nearby was a new German gin. Around the corner, a Campari bar was handing out Negronis. Further down the aisle was a new German gin.

headline: What Changed, and Didn’t, After the 1988 Slaying of a Rain Forest Hero in Brazil
abstract: After the murder of Chico Mendes in 1988, a new brand of green governance developed on Brazil’s rain forest frontier, but political instability poses fresh threats.
lead_paragraph: I was happy to see this fresh Retro Report production on the legacy of Chico Mendes, the Brazilian rain forest defender who was slain by a ranching family in December, 1988 as land conflicts followed road building in the depths of the Amazon. Retro Report is an innovative journalism project revisiting stories long after the headlines have flowed by. The resulting videos provide an invaluable learning tool for students of all ages interested in media cycles and keeping an eye on what’s real. As I wrote a few days ago, such efforts are more important than ever given the fact-free nature of so much online discourse.

headline: Filipino Filmmakers Shed Light on the Forgotten. They Hope It Can Last.
abstract: The Philippine movie industry has made a huge comeback, but will films like “Ma’ Rosa” and “The Woman Who Left” be possible under the new president?
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Filipino director Brillante Mendoza had already presented his latest film at the Cannes Film Festival when President Rodrigo Duterte took office in the Philippines in June.

headline: How Good Is a Bad Night’s Sleep?
abstract: Sleep with disturbing nightmares is better than no sleep, researchers say, but the bad dreams can cause all sorts of other problems.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is a night’s sleep physiologically beneficial even if it includes emotionally disturbing nightmares?

headline: Facebook Runs Up Against German Hate Speech Laws
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Discrimination', 'Hate Crimes', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Cyberharassment']
abstract: The social network’s efforts to placate German authorities provide a case study for its moves to combat fake news and hate speech online worldwide.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Yorai Feinberg was going about his daily routine this month when his social media feeds and cellphone began lighting up.

headline: Ken Thompson’s Successor: A ‘Pure District Attorney’ Working Under the Radar
abstract: Eric Gonzalez says he wants to continue the work, especially in healing community relations, that Mr. Thompson championed before dying in October.
lead_paragraph: It says everything you need to know about Eric Gonzalez’s abrupt ascension to the post of acting district attorney for Brooklyn that when he was recently honored by a local public high school, the award he received was still emblazoned with his predecessor’s name.

headline: Donald Trump’s Response to Plans for a Recount
abstract: Readers differ on whether recounts should take place and how The Times reported the news.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Flamingo Mating Rules: 1. Learn the Funky Chicken
abstract: The birds with the largest repertoires of dance moves are the ones who most often succeed in finding mates, researchers have found.
lead_paragraph: Flamingos are very good dancers. They twist and preen, they scratch their heads, they march in unison. They poke a wing in one direction and a leg in another.

headline: ‘Starboy’ Places the Weeknd on the Sunny Side of Debauchery
abstract: In the last two years, this singer has tempered his subject matter only slightly, but his sonic approach drastically. He’s looked to the Michael Jackson 1980s.
lead_paragraph: “Attention,” which comes near the end of “Starboy,” the new album by the Weeknd, traverses one of his most familiar subjects: psychological antagonism pegged to sexual dominance. Or maybe it’s sexual antagonism pegged to psychological dominance. Either way. “Only thing left is the sex now,” he sings with what sounds like resignation until a couple of lines later, when he adds, “Only see me on the TV or the bed now.” He’s too busy to be sorry.

headline: Sotheby’s Tries to Block Suit Over a Leonardo Sold and Resold at a Big Markup
keywords: ['Art', 'Auctions', 'Appraisals and Valuation (Property)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: The auction house has become entangled in a dispute between a Swiss art dealer and a billionaire Russian collector.
lead_paragraph: The joy must have been palpable in 2013 when three New York art traders arranged through Sotheby’s to sell a newly discovered painting by Leonardo da Vinci, the Renaissance master, for $80 million.

headline: Howard Hughes, and His Quirks, on the Big Screen
abstract: Warren Beatty’s “Rules Don’t Apply” is just the latest film depiction of Hughes. Several others have highlighted his impulsiveness and eccentricities.
lead_paragraph: Howard Hughes was a real person. He was 6-foot-4, Texas-born, an only child and an extremely rich orphan at 19. Until his death in 1976, he lived among us (if hiding out in hotel penthouses, emerging only to be sneaked onto and off private planes, counts).

headline: Election Recount, Fidel Castro: Your Monday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Donald Trump Faces Obstacles to Resuming Waterboarding
keywords: ['Interrogations', 'Torture', 'Waterboarding', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Federal law, international pressure and resistance from inside the C.I.A. stand in the way of Donald J. Trump using brutal interrogation tactics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the first few months of Donald J. Trump’s presidency, if recent history is any guide, intelligence officials will meet to discuss a terrorism suspect living abroad. This suspect might become the next target for the nation’s not-so-secret drone force. Or maybe, Mr. Trump’s advisers could decide, he is worth trying to capture.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Hits a New High: The Most Money Grossed in a Week on Broadway
abstract: “Hamilton” is the first Broadway show to gross more than $3 million for an eight-performance week.
lead_paragraph: History is happening in Manhattan: “Hamilton” has set a record for the most money ever made in a single week by a Broadway show.

headline: Trump Officially Wins Michigan Amid Calls for a Recount
abstract: Donald J. Trump defeated Hillary Clinton in the state by 10,704 votes, or less than a quarter of a percentage point, according to official figures.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was officially declared the winner of the presidential election in Michigan on Monday amid calls for a recount there and in two other states.

headline: Cravath Bonuses for Law Firm Associates Remain Unchanged
abstract: The year-end bonuses for associates at Wall Street law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore will be $15,000 to $100,000, according to an internal memo.
lead_paragraph: The prominent Wall Street law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore has splashed some cold water on those still hoping for higher year-end bonuses.

headline: Donald Trump’s Lies About the Popular Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Electoral College', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting and Voters', 'Editorials']
abstract: The president-elect seems to feel threatened that more Americans voted for Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: One big fear in the weeks leading up to the presidential election was that Donald Trump would try to delegitimize the results by claiming rampant voter fraud — a bogus specter he had raised throughout the campaign, particularly as his polling numbers got worse.

headline: Times Insider Photo Challenge: Caption This!
abstract: We asked readers — without any context — to caption a photo that ran in The New York Times. Here’s how they responded.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. Occasionally we have some fun.

abstract: Failing to make contact against the pitcher when he was still a teenage phenom.

headline: Time Inc. Is Said to Turn Away From a Takeover by Edgar Bronfman
abstract: Mr. Bronfman and Access Industries, the owner of Warner Music, had bid at least $18 a share recently, a person briefed on the matter said.
lead_paragraph: Time Inc., the publisher of People and Sports Illustrated, has rebuffed preliminary takeover proposals from Edgar Bronfman Jr. and the owner of Warner Music, a person briefed on the matter said on Monday.

headline: Women in Canadian Military Report Widespread Sexual Assault
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A survey commissioned by the armed forces puts hard numbers on a 2015 report that showed a culture hostile toward women and other minorities.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — More than a quarter of women in the Canadian military have been sexually assaulted during their careers, according to a survey by the government’s statistical agency.

headline: News Outlets Rethink Usage of the Term ‘Alt-Right’
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Whites', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Often used to describe a far-right, white nationalist movement and criticized by some as euphemizing extreme views, the label has emerged as a linguistic flash point.
lead_paragraph: When The Washington Post published a profile last week of Richard B. Spencer, a prominent leader of the so-called alt-right, readers were quick to respond. By Monday, the article had drawn more than 2,600 comments.

headline: David Petraeus, Secretary of State Candidate, Meets With Trump
abstract: Mr. Petraeus, a retired general and former C.I.A. director, has emerged as a new contender after bitter internal feuding over the State Department post.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald J. Trump met on Monday with David H. Petraeus, the highly decorated but scandal-scarred former military commander, who has emerged as a new contender for secretary of state after days of bitter internal feuding over who will get the coveted post.

headline: Amid Flames and Suspicions in Israel, Acts of Jewish-Arab Cooperation
abstract: The wildfires that swept across Israel’s countryside last week brought claims of arson, but also an outpouring of good will.
lead_paragraph: NATAF, Israel — When Rama’s Kitchen, an earthy and much-loved restaurant in the small Israeli village of Nataf, was burned last week by one of the wildfires that raged in the area, the last civilians who stayed to fight the blaze were two Palestinian brothers from Qatana, a village nearby in the occupied West Bank.

headline: In Year of Bright and Bleak Spots, Room for Surprise in Tennis
abstract: The tennis year — an uncommon brew of the troubling and the reaffirming — included Maria Sharapova’s suspension and Juan Martín del Potro’s return to prominence.
lead_paragraph: Back in January, Juan Martín del Potro was ranked No. 1,041 and Maria Sharapova had just reached the quarterfinals of another Australian Open, with all of her sponsors in tow.

headline: Dear President-Elect Trump: Here’s How to Fix Your Conflict-of-Interest Problem
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: Consider hiring a corporate monitor, an independent overseer who will issue regular public reports about any possible instances of conflicts. We have just the person for you.
lead_paragraph: Dear President-elect Trump:

headline: Houthis, in Surprise Move, Form a Government in Yemen
abstract: The announcement angered the movement’s Saudi-backed rivals and threatened diplomatic efforts to end a conflict that has ravaged Yemen for nearly two years.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — The Houthi movement and its allies formed a new government in Yemen on Monday, a surprise that angered their Saudi-backed rivals and complicated United Nations efforts to end a conflict that has ravaged the Arab world’s poorest country for much of the past two years.

headline: AT&T Appeals to Cord-Cutters With DirecTV Now, a New Streaming Service
keywords: ['Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Offering 60 channels for $35 a month, the service will compete with Sling TV, PlayStation Vue and others to lure viewers away from cable television packages.
lead_paragraph: AT&T unveiled a streaming television service on Monday aimed at the millions of Americans who have broadband internet but no bundled TV package, offering an extensive list of channels for less than most cable plans.

headline: Trump’s Claim of Millions of Illegal Votes? There’s Simply No Evidence
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: There are many reasons Donald J. Trump’s claim doesn’t withstand scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump continues to say that there were millions of illegal votes in the November election, costing him a popular-vote victory. We’re resurfacing an Upshot article from November that debunked the claim.

headline: Back From Injury, Devils’ Mike Cammalleri Fills Hole on Offense
abstract: A long and frustrating recovery has given way to a burst of scoring from Cammalleri, who has helped the Devils hold their own in the absence of Taylor Hall.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Besides the fact that Devils forward Mike Cammalleri could not grip a hockey stick with his injured right hand, he looked and felt completely normal, and that just made everything worse.

headline: Tom Price, Obamacare Critic, Is Trump’s Choice for Health Secretary
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The six-term Republican congressman from Georgia has led opposition to the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If President-elect Donald J. Trump wanted a cabinet secretary who could help him dismantle and replace President Obama’s health care law, he could not have found anyone more prepared than Representative Tom Price, who has been studying how to accomplish that goal for more than six years.

headline: Darrell Issa Narrowly Wins Re-election in California
abstract: Mr. Issa defeated Doug Applegate, a retired Marine colonel, to retain his seat after his first truly competitive race in more than 15 years.
lead_paragraph: Representative Darrell Issa, a well-known Obama administration tormentor, has narrowly won re-election to his Southern California congressional seat.

headline: Vote Recount Push Advances, but Reversing Trump’s Win Is Unlikely
abstract: In Wisconsin, elections officials said on Monday that a recount of the state’s nearly three million votes would most likely begin on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump is well into filling out his cabinet and picking key advisers. But a move to challenge the vote tallies in three swing states — an extreme long shot to reverse his Electoral College majority — is advancing in the background, creating a noisy distraction on Mr. Trump’s Twitter feed and raising last-ditch hopes of some Hillary Clinton supporters.

headline: For Bashar al-Assad, Winning the Syrian War May Lead to New Troubles
abstract: If the Syrian president defeats the rebels, he may preside over an economic wasteland hampered by a low-level insurgency and facing a challenge to find financial aid to rebuild.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — With the Syrian government making large territorial gains in Aleppo on Monday, routing rebel fighters and sending thousands of people fleeing for their lives, President Bashar al-Assad is starting to look as if he may survive the uprising, even in the estimation of some of his staunchest opponents.

headline: $6.3 Billion Measure Aims to Cure Ailing Health Care Policies
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Cancer', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Medical Devices', 'Research', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Congress will vote this week on a measure that is the product of years of debate over health care policy issues, including the unwieldy mental health care system and opioid abuse.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In one of the most sweeping and rare bipartisan acts of this Congress, lawmakers will move this week on a $6.3 billion bill to increase funding for research into cancer and other diseases, address problems in the nation’s mental health systems and enact potentially far-reaching regulatory changes for drugs and medical devices.

headline: Challenging the Boss in Public? For Kellyanne Conway, It’s Part of the Job
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Ms. Conway’s criticism of Mitt Romney was expected to draw fury from President-elect Donald J. Trump. But she is not a typical aide.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kellyanne Conway, one of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s senior advisers, was about to board a flight back to New York on Monday morning when she caught a glimpse of the headline crawling across television screens in the terminal.

headline: ESPN Pays Top Dollar for Football, but Audience Isn’t Buying
abstract: ESPN pays $1.9 billion annually for its N.F.L. rights, nearly twice what NBC shells out, but “Monday Night Football” is not the powerhouse it once was.
lead_paragraph: With ESPN’s “Monday Night Football” viewership still falling after the presidential election, I began to think about what it meant to be the network that pays, by far, the most for its N.F.L. rights.

headline: In ‘Havana on the Hudson,’ Few Are Left to Celebrate Fidel Castro’s Death
abstract: Bitter feelings about the dictator persist in Union City, N.J., where the once large population of Cuban immigrants has dwindled.
lead_paragraph: UNION CITY, N.J. — Along Bergenline Avenue, the once-elegant Cuban commercial strip in this working-class town, the mood on Monday was subdued. But the bitterness toward Fidel Castro, the Cuban dictator who died over the weekend, remained.

headline: Artists Lay Their Fears at Ivanka Trump’s Door
keywords: ['Art', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Well-known artists staged an orderly protest outside the Puck Building, where Ivanka Trump resides, expressing objections to her father’s policies.
lead_paragraph: The contemporary art world in New York is not known for its political cohesion or conviction, at least in recent years. But more than 150 artists, curators and gallery workers turned out Monday night to march in front of a Downtown Manhattan building where Ivanka Trump, the future first daughter, has an apartment and is believed to keep some pieces of a notable contemporary collection.

headline: Samsung Electronics, Pushed by Investors, Will Consider Restructuring
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The South Korean electronics giant may create a holding company structure after an American hedge fund called for the company to shake up its operations.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Under pressure from investors, Samsung Electronics said on Tuesday it might restructure its vast operations as a way to unlock shareholder value.

headline: Classic Kitchen Volume
abstract: Jacob Stulberg feeds our puzzle craving.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — This is the time of year when it seems almost impossible to get away from food. Personally, I don’t have a problem with that, being one of those people who not only subsists on the stuff, but who revels in it.

headline: Mark Taimanov, World-Class Chess and Piano Player, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Taimanov was a classical pianist and former Soviet chess champion whose lopsided loss to Bobby Fischer in 1971 cost him his government salary.
lead_paragraph: Mark Taimanov, a virtuoso pianist and former Soviet chess champion whose lopsided loss to Bobby Fischer in 1971 in the quarterfinals of a major chess tournament cost him his government salary, died on Monday in St. Petersburg, Russia. He was 90.

headline: Joe Esposito Dies at 78; Spent 20 Years Assisting Elvis Presley
abstract: Mr. Esposito met Elvis Presley when they were serving in the Army on a base in Germany and went on to be a friend and personal organizer.
lead_paragraph: Joe Esposito, who was Elvis Presley’s right-hand man, close friend and road manager for nearly two decades, died on Wednesday at his home in Calabasas, Calif. He was 78.

headline: David Hamilton, Photographer Known for Nude Images of Girls, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Hamilton, whose soft dreamy style defined his photographs fashion and advertising assignments in the 1960s, was the target of rape allegations.
lead_paragraph: David Hamilton, the British photographer whose diaphanous images of prepubescent girls blurred the line between art and pornography, was found dead on Friday in his Paris apartment, one week after a former model accused him of raping her in 1987 when she was 13.

headline: Despite Flash of Rose’s Prime, Knicks Are Dazed by Westbrook and Thunder
abstract: Derrick Rose finished with 30 points, but his Oklahoma City counterpart, Russell Westbrook, had 27 in recording his eighth triple-double of the season.
lead_paragraph: As each Knick took his turn to talk, it became an exercise unto itself. The Knicks had been defeated, soundly, by the Oklahoma City Thunder, 112-103, at Madison Square Garden on Monday night. It was a loss in which the Knicks lacked cohesion, marksmanship and, by their own admission, fortitude.

headline: Al Jazeera Film Critical of Egyptian Army Strains Egypt-Qatar Ties Further
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The documentary, broadcast on a network owned by the Qatari government, accuses Egypt of abusing its recruits, and the country was quick to denounce it.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian soldier crawls across hot sand in his underwear while his comrades stand at attention. Other soldiers say they are subjected to almost constant verbal and physical abuse and ordered to run personal errands for their superiors.

headline: Harry Flournoy Jr., 72, Dies; a Captain of First All-Black Starting Five to Win N.C.A.A. Title
abstract: The 1965-66 Miners were the first team to win the national championship with five black starting players, defeating an all-white Kentucky team.
lead_paragraph: Harry Flournoy Jr., a captain of the first college basketball team to win the national championship with five black starting players, in 1966, died on Saturday in Atlanta. He was 72.

headline: Brooklyn Prosecutor Accused of Using Illegal Wiretap to Spy on Love Interest
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'District Attorneys']
abstract: Tara Lenich, a high-ranking prosecutor in the district attorney’s office, was arrested and fired after investigators learned she had spied on a police detective and a colleague, an official said.
lead_paragraph: A high-ranking prosecutor in the Brooklyn district attorney’s office was arrested this week on charges that she used an illegal wiretap to spy on a police detective and one of her colleagues in what a law-enforcement official described as a love triangle gone wrong.

headline: Ohio, Aleppo, Colombia: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: How Stable Are Democracies? ‘Warning Signs Are Flashing Red’
abstract: New research tries to spot the collapse of liberal democracies before they happen, and it suggests that Western democracy may be seriously ill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Yascha Mounk is used to being the most pessimistic person in the room. Mr. Mounk, a lecturer in government at Harvard, has spent the past few years challenging one of the bedrock assumptions of Western politics: that once a country becomes a liberal democracy, it will stay that way.

headline: Intel to Team With Delphi and Mobileye for Self-Driving Cars
abstract: For Intel, especially, the collaboration is an effort to catch up in autonomous vehicles, a field where some chip makers have made deeper inroads.
lead_paragraph: Today’s automobiles are often described as computers on wheels, for the scores of processors and chips they use to control everything, including the transmission, brakes, power windows and navigation system.

headline: Rebuilding a Church Crushed on 9/11
abstract: Float above the St. Nicholas National Shrine, at the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan, as a cross is installed on the dome.
lead_paragraph: Float above the St. Nicholas National Shrine, at the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan, as a cross is installed on the dome.

headline: Corrections: November 29, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, November 29, 2016.

headline: Cross Takes Its Place, Temporarily, Atop Shrine at World Trade Center
keywords: ['Crosses and Crucifixes', 'September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Greek Orthodox Church', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: It will be replaced with a permanent cross when the St. Nicholas National Shrine, in Lower Manhattan, opens in the first half of 2018.
lead_paragraph: Visiting the National September 11 Memorial on Monday, Lori Siders stopped and stared wordlessly. Ahead was something she never expected to see at the World Trade Center.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday: Lin-Manuel Miranda in ‘Drunk History,’ and Dolly Parton on ‘The Voice’
abstract: In “Drunk History,” Lin-Manuel Miranda presents a sloshed interpretation of the duel between Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr. And Dolly Parton performs on “The Voice.”
lead_paragraph: In “Drunk History,” Lin-Manuel Miranda presents a sloshed interpretation of the Alexander Hamilton and Aaron Burr duel. “Leah Remini: Scientology and the Aftermath” explores what happened after Ms. Remini left the church. And Dolly Parton and Meryl Streep sing.

headline: Park Geun-hye, Embattled South Korean President, Says She’s Willing to Resign
abstract: Opposition lawmakers rejected the offer, calling it a ploy, and said they would call for a vote on Friday to impeach Ms. Park, who is embroiled in a corruption scandal.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea said Tuesday that she was willing to resign before her term ends, in an effort to head off a pending impeachment vote over a devastating corruption scandal.

headline: ‘Thunderstorm Asthma’ Kills 8 in Australia
abstract: About 8,500 people went to the hospital after a storm last week spread ryegrass pollen fragments, so fine they could be inhaled, throughout the Melbourne area.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When David McGann left his office in Melbourne just after 5 p.m. to cycle home, a stifling heat had settled across the city, and the temperature was peaking at 95 degrees.

abstract: But on Tuesday, the National Board of Review gave its seal of approval to “Manchester by the Sea.” Is there a rivalry brewing?
lead_paragraph: “Moonlight,” Barry Jenkins’s celebrated, intimate portrait of a gay youngster growing up in a drug-ridden Miami neighborhood, rode into the awards season on a wave of momentum Monday night, scooping up four Gotham Awards, including best feature.

headline: Chapecoense Soccer Team’s Plane Crashes, Leaving Brazil Devastated
abstract: Few survivors have been found among the 77 on the chartered flight taking the team to a game in Medellín, Colombia. The crash came as fans across Brazil had been reveling in the team’s performance.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — After climbing the ranks of Brazilian soccer, the team was on its way to face one of its biggest tests yet: a chance to win the final of the Copa Sudamericana, an international competition for South American soccer.

headline: New York Poised to Get Grammy Awards Back in 2018
abstract: After months of negotiations between the de Blasio administration and the Recording Academy, the ceremony is expected to return to the city for the first time since 2003.
lead_paragraph: After a hiatus of more than a decade, the Grammy Awards are expected to return to New York in 2018, several people familiar with the city’s bid to lure the ceremony from Los Angeles said.

headline: Rare Photos Show World War II From the Soviet Side
abstract: When Arthur Bondar came across the negatives of a Soviet war photographer, he realized he had stumbled upon an important cache of images of World War II that gave an intimate look at that country’s side.

headline: When Chess Was a Battle of Superpowers
abstract: It’s hard to follow the world chess championship and not go back in time to the epic contests of the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: It’s a different world, of course, and a different rivalry, but it’s hard when following the world chess championship match between Magnus Carlsen of Norway and Sergey Karjakin of Russia, which goes into a battery of tiebreakers after the first 12 games ended in a tie, not to go back in time to the epic chess battles of the Cold War.

headline: Threatening Cuba Will Backfire
abstract: Rolling back the Obama administration’s policy of pragmatic engagement with Cuba would be monumentally misguided.
lead_paragraph: As Cubans continued either to mourn or to celebrate the death of Fidel Castro, President-elect Donald Trump issued a vague ultimatum to the Cuban government on Monday. “If Cuba is unwilling to make a better deal for the Cuban people, the Cuban/American people and the U.S. as a whole, I will terminate deal,” Mr. Trump wrote on Twitter.

headline: Facebook Shouldn’t Fact-Check
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Rumors and Misinformation']
abstract: It’s dangerous to promise that a social network will vet what’s true.
lead_paragraph: We finally got a grudging mea culpa from Mark Zuckerberg: an admission that fake news is a significant problem that his social network must help solve.

headline: Wanted: Leaders to Turn Interfaith Conflict Into Trust
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Muslim Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: With Trump aggravating religious tensions in America, a Muslim author focuses on training leaders to spread interfaith values.
lead_paragraph: This month, the F.B.I. reported that hate crimes against Muslims in 2015 reached their highest level since 2001. In New York City this year, hate crimes are tracking one-third higher than last year; against Muslims they have more than doubled.

headline: Threats of an Anti-Muslim Holocaust
abstract: These hate crimes and incidents of harassment were all reported in the last two weeks.
lead_paragraph: This Week in Hate tracks hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of Donald Trump. The Southern Poverty Law Center  and other groups are keeping detailed counts of harassment and abuse. We will regularly present a selection of incidents to show the scope of the problem. This article, the first in the series, includes incidents reported in the last two weeks.

headline: The Future of the American Center
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Donald Trump’s victory smashes traditions of party loyalty, presenting opportunities between the extremes.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few decades, party loyalty has been the defining feature of national politics. Especially in the House but even in the Senate, members deferred to their party leaders. Congress as a whole deferred to the presidency. Members of the president’s own party acted as his foot soldiers. Members of the other party acted as his opposition.

headline: Donald Trump: Be ‘Big Marco’ or Set His Own Path?
abstract: The next president will have to decide whether he is another standard Republican on taxes, spending and the economy.
lead_paragraph: Republican economic policy doesn’t have a good recent track record. The last two Republican presidents left office deeply unpopular, thanks to recessions. Ronald Reagan’s record was much better but still not as good as Bill Clinton’s.

headline: A Wrenching Choice for Alaska Towns in the Path of Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Floods', 'Hurricanes and Tropical Storms', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Eskimos']
abstract: Alaska is warming about twice as fast as the rest of the nation. So what are the dozens of villages at imminent risk of destruction to do?
lead_paragraph: Alaska is warming about twice as fast as the rest of the nation. So what are the dozens of villages at imminent risk of destruction to do?

abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, November 29, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “They do not want to move and I have to accept that. But if they want to live here, they have to have a way to get out of Dodge when getting out is required.”
