headline: Michael Flynn, a Top Trump Adviser, Ties China and North Korea to Jihadists
abstract: By appointing General Flynn, President-elect Donald J. Trump has signaled that he intends to prioritize policy on the Middle East and Islamist militants.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for national security adviser, retired Lt. Gen. Michael T. Flynn, has been much more outspoken about militant Islamists than he has about China and North Korea, the two main strategic concerns of the United States in Asia.

headline: Cities and States Lead on Climate Change
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Urban Areas', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Climate doomsday scenarios have flourished since the election. But cities and states are already moving to rein in greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY — THE wind turbines that rise out of the cornfields here reminded me on a recent drive of one postelection truth, even in the red state of Iowa.

headline: Tom Price, a Radical Choice for Health Secretary
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Medicare', 'Editorials', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Donald Trump has picked a man intent on systematically weakening, if not destroying, the nation’s health care safety net.
lead_paragraph: In picking  Representative Tom Price, President-elect Donald Trump has chosen as his secretary of health and human services a man intent on systematically weakening, if not demolishing, the nation’s health care safety net.

headline: Italy’s Turn to Vote
abstract: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi cannot undo his unwise push for a referendum, but he can mitigate its potential fallout.
lead_paragraph: Sunday will be Italy’s turn to hold one of those fateful votes — like Britain’s referendum to leave the European Union — that have spread angst through Western democracies. This one, called by Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, would impose constitutional changes that would give the government more stability and power to enact needed economic reforms.

headline: The Truth About Young Immigrants and DACA
abstract: The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, for the so-called Dreamers, is both lawful and rational.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Maybe you’ve heard this story line before. With the blithe stroke of a pen and without congressional approval, President Obama gave legal status to a vast population of immigrants who entered the country unlawfully — because he wanted to, and because he found a way.

headline: The Dawn of the ‘Tryborg’
abstract: My computerized leg makes me a real-life cyborg. So what’s with all the pretenders?
lead_paragraph: The existence of “the tryborg,” as a category of person, is so obvious that once I point it out, you will immediately recognize a dozen tryborgs you know or whose work you have read. It is possible you are a tryborg.

headline: On Castro’s Old Campus, Students Pay Tribute
abstract: Hundreds of students joined a memorial service at the University of Havana, where Fidel Castro had immersed himself in radical politics in the 1940s.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of students joined a memorial service at the University of Havana, where Fidel Castro had immersed himself in radical politics in the 1940s.

headline: Documenting the Genocide of Iraq’s Yazidis
abstract: Over the past year, Diego Ibarra Sánchez has traveled to Sinjar, Iraq, whose Yazidi population was subjected to atrocities by the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The scene Diego Ibarra Sánchez encountered in and around the Iraqi city of Sinjar was grim: a desolate town left in ruins, silent except for the crackle of gunfire. Thousands of its Yazidi residents — members of a persecuted religious minority — were able to flee to a mountain from the onslaught of the Islamic State. Still, Mr. Ibarra Sánchez found ample evidence of the terror rained down upon this region by the Islamic State in 2014.

headline: Can the Democrats Move Right?
keywords: ['Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: It’s a hard ask, but harder truths are what the buckling Democratic Party needs.
lead_paragraph: Since Election Day the great intra-Democratic debate over What Went Wrong has been dominated by two visions of how liberalism should be organized, identity politics versus economic solidarity, with writers variously critiquing or defending each tendency, or arguing that they are complements and that any tension can and ought to be resolved.

headline: Questions for: ‘Solving a Mystery Behind the Deadly “Tsunami of Molasses” of 1919’
abstract: What did a team of scientists and students, presenting at the American Physical Society this month, suggest happened that day?
lead_paragraph: Article: “Solving a Mystery Behind the Deadly ‘Tsunami of Molasses’ of 1919”

headline: Should I Call My Friend Out for Her ‘Service Dog’ Scam?
keywords: ['Service Dogs and Other Animals', 'Disabilities', 'Workplace Environment', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Spanish Language', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do when you know someone is passing off a pet as a service animal and whether to report a workplace for mandating its employees speak only English.
lead_paragraph: My friend got a service dog solely to circumvent the “no pets” policy in her building. She does have the disability this dog is trained to help with, but she doesn’t use him for this purpose and even jokes about how long it took her to “deprogram” him. But she takes full advantage of his service-dog status, taking him with her to restaurants and stores that otherwise don’t permit dogs.

headline: Why Iggy Pop Traded In His Sports Car
abstract: The musician on the new documentary on the Stooges, losing Bowie and the resurgence of “Lust for Life.”
lead_paragraph: You and your band, the Stooges, are the subjects of a new Jim Jarmusch documentary, “Gimme Danger,” and a new book, “Total Chaos.” Is it a coincidence that these two major retrospectives would happen at once? I would call it karmic. I asked Jim seven or eight years ago if he would make a movie about the Stooges. The idea was to do something surprising with it, and I was surprised when I first saw it. Imagine my horror when the film starts out and we’re all living with our mothers.

headline: How Much Disclosure About an Op-Ed Author Is Required?
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Rumors and Misinformation', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: A writer’s spouse had extensive ties to a subject of her Op-Ed essay, but readers were made aware of the potential conflict of interest only in passing.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the election, there’s been endless finger-pointing at Facebook by those who blame it for letting malicious “fake news” onto its social platform. So it must have been refreshing for opinion editors at The New York Times to have a piece that actually gave Facebook a bit of a break.

headline: How to Hide $400 Million
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Tax Shelters', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Tax Evasion', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: When a wealthy businessman set out to divorce his wife, their fortune vanished. The quest to find it would reveal the depths of an offshore financial system bigger than the U.S. economy.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks after she realized her husband was finally leaving her, Sarah Pursglove flew down to the Bahamas to figure out how much money he really had. Like many women married to very wealthy men, she didn’t know much about the family accounts. Her husband, a Finnish entrepreneur named Robert Oesterlund, had sworn to a Canadian court that his immediately calculable “net family property” totaled just a few million dollars. Pursglove was skeptical. She could come up with several family purchases worth more than that off the top of her head. There was the 165-foot yacht, Déjà Vu — that cost a few million dollars a year just to keep on the water. There was the $30 million penthouse at the Toronto Four Seasons, which was still being renovated. It wasn’t their only home. The Déjà Vu wasn’t even their only yacht.

headline: On an Island Named for Ice, the Poets Are Just Getting Warmed Up
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: In Iceland, people of all ages and every walk of life compose and publish verse. Cold, damp weather and long winter nights may be among the reasons.
lead_paragraph: Iceland, it seems, is full of hidden poets.

headline: Another Mass Grave Dug by ISIS in Iraq, and a Ghastly Ritual Renewed
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: The Islamic State has been resorting to a horrific practice that dates back to Saddam Hussein and his regime’s industrial-scale killings.
lead_paragraph: HAMAM AL-ALIL, Iraq — The battle was over in Hamam al-Alil, Iraq, an old spa resort town that the country’s security forces had wrested from the Islamic State a few days ago, but one Iraqi soldier was still on a very personal mission.

headline: Can Television Be Fair to Muslims?
abstract: Writers and showrunners — including those for “24” and “Quantico” — talk about casting, cultural gaps and the networks’ desire for stories about terrorism.
lead_paragraph: It has never been easy to put a Muslim character on American screens.

headline: Living in West Chelsea
abstract: The High Line and buildings by renowned architects have helped transform a formerly industrial area into a sought-after residential neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The High Line and buildings by renowned architects have helped transform a formerly industrial area into a sought-after residential neighborhood.

headline: West Chelsea: From Industrial to Chic
abstract: Projects from architects like Frank Gehry and Zaha Hadid, along with the High Line, have helped transform this former industrial area.
lead_paragraph: Catherine Roggero-Lovisi and her husband, Dr. Bruno Lovisi, both in their 40s, lived on Manhattan’s Upper West Side and in Paris before settling in West Chelsea. In 2014, they rented a one-bedroom apartment in London Terrace Gardens and decided to buy in the area as they grew to love it.

headline: What’s the Best Party You’ve Ever Been To?
abstract: What’s the best, most enjoyable or most memorable party you’ve ever been to, or hosted? What made it so special?
lead_paragraph: The photos above are from one of the most famous parties ever held — the Black and White Ball that the writer Truman Capote gave in New York City 50 years ago.

headline: Trump Transition, Standing Rock, MDMA: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: C.I.A. Chief Warns Donald Trump Against Tearing Up Iran Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Waterboarding', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: John Brennan told the BBC that canceling the accord would be “the height of folly” and could lead to a nuclear arms race in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The director of the C.I.A. has issued a stark warning to President-elect Donald J. Trump: Tearing up the Iran nuclear deal would be “the height of folly” and “disastrous.”

headline: Morning Agenda: The Choice for Treasury Secretary, Female Lawyers at a Disadvantage, Bridgewater Settlement
abstract: Donald J. Trump is expected to name Steven Mnuchin, a financier with deep roots on Wall Street, as Treasury secretary.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has shown that he is willing to take on big business. He plans to announce a deal for Carrier to keep about 1,000 jobs in the United States.

headline: Trying Snap’s Spectacles: Live With the Look, Enjoy the View
keywords: ['Wearable Computing', 'Sunglasses', 'Cameras', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Spectacles, the video-recording sunglasses released by the company behind Snapchat, are among the most compelling tech gadgets of recent years.
lead_paragraph: Spectacles, the first hardware product released by the company that makes the popular photo-messaging app Snapchat, are large, whimsically goofy sunglasses with a camera embedded in the frame.

headline: With an Arsenal of Apps, a Fearful Flier Faces the Skies
abstract: A longtime travel writer shares tech-based strategies that have helped calm her nerves during flights.
lead_paragraph: As a longtime travel writer, you would think that, for me, getting on a plane would be as routine as brushing my teeth. Whether it’s a long haul to Asia, a trans-Atlantic visit, or a short hop from my home in Italy to another city in Europe, barely a week goes by that I am not catching a flight, or multiple ones.

headline: New York Today: Should I Get a Dog?
abstract: Wednesday: Things to ask yourself when considering a dog, more rain and the World Chess Championship tiebreaker.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:30 a.m.

headline: While We Weren’t Looking, Snapchat Revolutionized Social Networks
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Instant Messaging', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Once known for its disappearing messages, Snap, the parent of Snapchat, has moved into news and, with Spectacles, consumer devices.
lead_paragraph: Snap Inc., the parent company of the popular photo-messaging and storytelling app Snapchat, is having a productive autumn.

headline: How Snapchat Is Shaping Social Media
abstract: Snapchat started in 2011 as an app through which people could send messages that would disappear. Now it has many features and a large user base.
lead_paragraph: Snap, the company that runs the social media service Snapchat, soared in its initial public offering, setting the company up as the most valuable American technology company to go public since Facebook. Here’s how Snap got to this point.

headline: How to Be Mindful Doing the Dishes
abstract: Household chores create an opportunity to nurture the mind.
lead_paragraph: “We can be present in any moment of life, even when we’re busy washing the dishes. Rather than put off those household chores, embrace them as another opportunity to nurture and transform the mind.” – Andy Puddicombe, co-founder of the meditation app Headspace.

headline: Bid to Impeach South Korean Leader Stalls as Lawmakers Debate Her Offer to Quit
abstract: President Park Geun-hye’s offer to step down, without specifying a date, swayed some lawmakers, who said they were willing to accept an April departure.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye appeared on Wednesday to have stalled a bid to impeach her in South Korea’s National Assembly, at least temporarily, as lawmakers debated how to respond to her surprise offer to resign.

headline: OPEC Reaches Deal to Limit Production, Sending Prices Soaring
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Production', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'International Relations']
abstract: The deal will be the first production cut in eight years, although the price increase may prove temporary.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — After years of trying fruitlessly to prop up energy markets, OPEC on Wednesday finally reached a consensus on production cuts, sending oil prices soaring. The problem is, the euphoria in the markets may not last.

headline: Should a Simple Fitness Check Be Part of Your Checkup?
abstract: Experts think your fitness level should be monitored just as your pulse or blood pressure is.
lead_paragraph: Aerobic fitness should be considered a vital sign, just as body temperature, blood pressure, pulse and breathing rates are now, according to a new scientific statement from the American Heart Association.

headline: Fidel Castro, a South African Hero
abstract: The Cuban leader will always be remembered as a great friend and ally to our national liberation movement.
lead_paragraph: DURBAN, South Africa — Nelson Mandela once wrote that “there is no passion to be found playing small — in settling for a life that is less than the one you are capable of living.” It is almost as if Mandela had Fidel Castro in mind when he wrote those words.

headline: 26 Ways That Skiing Gets Better This Season
abstract: New lodging, programs, lifts and lift-free features at North American resorts from Banff in Canada to Stowe, Vt.
lead_paragraph: In ski country, lifts will go farther and faster this year, even as more enthusiasts choose to trek uphill under their own power to ski back down. New lodging options range from rustic micro-homes to a five-bedroom staffed alternative. And winter fans will find new ways to race to the runs on the ground and in the air.

headline: Let Women Drive, a Prince in Saudi Arabia Urges
abstract: “Beyond being a rights issue, it is also an economic, developmental and social one,” Alwaleed bin Talal wrote in a four-page letter posted on his personal website.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Saudi prince and business magnate has added his voice to the debate over women’s rights in his country, urging it to abandon its driving ban for women.

headline: Indian Cinemas Must Play the National Anthem, Supreme Court Rules
abstract: The anthem, before every screening, is to be accompanied by images of the Indian flag, and the audience must stand, the ruling mandates.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s Supreme Court on Wednesday ordered movie theaters to play the national anthem before each screening, asserting that doing so would instill “a sense of committed patriotism and nationalism” in Indians.

headline: Angela Merkel’s Anti-Ideology
abstract: In order to defend liberal values, she has to act like she isn’t.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — She’s running again. Chancellor Angela Merkel has announced that she will once again lead her party, the center-right Christian Democrats, in Germany’s national election next September. If the party wins, she will capture a fourth term, running a country increasingly rived by populism and xenophobia.

headline: R.B.S. to Bolster Capital Position After Failing Stress Test
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland is the worst prepared of Britain’s biggest lenders to cope with another financial crisis, according to the Bank of England test.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Wednesday that it would further bolster its capital position after failing regulatory stress tests that measure the ability of large banks to weather a financial crisis.

headline: Sarah Palin for Veterans Affairs? A Wrestling Impresario for Small Business?
abstract: The president-elect, who continues to fill his cabinet, will travel to Indiana this week to announce the saving of 1,000 factory jobs.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump wants to keep New York’s crusading United States attorney on board, and is reportedly eyeing the professional wrestling impresario Linda McMahon for the Small Business Administration. And a new name has popped up to lead the Department of Veterans Affairs: Sarah Palin.

headline: 3 Chinese Rights Activists Vanish, Apparently in State Crackdown
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The three men vanished within days of one another in different provinces, rights groups said, and only one has been charged by the police.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Three prominent Chinese rights activists appear to have been detained in recent weeks by the police, part of a continuing crackdown on groups operating outside the umbrella of the state, advocacy groups say.

headline: California Today: A View of San Francisco’s Leaning Tower From Space
abstract: Wednesday: Mapping the undulations of the Bay Area, Nancy Pelosi takes heat for the Democrats’ troubles, and the delights of Yosemite in winter.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: What You Get for … $2,500,000
abstract: A cabin in Wyoming, a Queen Anne in Virginia and a contemporary in California.
lead_paragraph: A cabin in Wyoming, a Queen Anne in Virginia and a contemporary in California.

headline: $2,500,000 Homes in Wyoming, Virginia and California
abstract: A cabin in Freedom, Wyo., a Queen Anne in Hague, Va., and a contemporary in Malibu, Calif.
lead_paragraph: FREEDOM, WYO.

headline: U.N. Stiffens Sanctions on North Korea, Trying to Slow Its Nuclear March
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Tests', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Coal']
abstract: The key to enforcing the Security Council’s new penalties on coal exports remains in the hands of China, North Korea’s principal coal customer.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In an effort to tighten sanctions that largely failed to throttle North Korea’s nuclear program, the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday imposed a cap on coal exports, the country’s chief source of hard currency.

headline: Italian Monastery Seeks Salvation in Beer After Devastating Quake
abstract: Their basilica in ruins, monks from America believe their small brewing operation can help an entire town to recover from Italy’s worst earthquake since 1980.
lead_paragraph: NORCIA, Italy — The Rev. Cassian Folsom was preparing to celebrate morning Mass one recent Sunday when suddenly the earth started trembling. “Stones and roof tiles started raining down on our heads,” he recalled. “It was a terrifying experience.”

headline: A Four-Bedroom Loft Near Corso Sempione
abstract: The loft, with about 3,600 square feet in a former industrial building, is on the market for $2.44 million.
lead_paragraph: The loft, with about 3,600 square feet in a former industrial building, is on the market for $2.44 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Milan
abstract: Milan’s housing market is undergoing a slow recovery in the aftermath of Italy’s prolonged recession, with sales climbing since 2014.
lead_paragraph: A FOUR-BEDROOM LOFT NEAR CORSO SEMPIONE

headline: Celebrating Balanchine’s ‘Jewels’ With an International Flair
abstract: Next summer’s Lincoln Center Festival will bring together the Paris Opera Ballet, New York City Ballet and the Bolshoi Ballet for the work’s 50th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine’s pure dance masterpiece “Jewels” explores three facets of ballet: “Emeralds” evokes France; “Rubies” captures an angular, energetic midcentury American modernism; and “Diamonds” conjures the courtly grandeur of imperial Russian classicism.

headline: Brexit’s Bitter Winners
abstract: An ugly, angry mood dominates Britain, where both the government and the opposition are in disarray.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — David Bowie died, and it was all downhill from there. That’s how 2016 felt if you were on the losing side of Britain’s referendum on membership in the European Union.

headline: Thailand's National Energy Boost
abstract: The New York Times attended an exercise session that is part of a national campaign created by the prime minister of Thailand to increase the energy and improve the health of civil servants.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times attended an exercise session that is part of a national campaign created by the prime minister of Thailand to increase the energy and improve the health of civil servants.

headline: Isabelle Huppert
abstract: On a brisk fall day in New York, the actress opens up about her creative process.
lead_paragraph: On a brisk fall day in New York, the actress opens up about her creative process.

headline: 8 Reasons the Detroit Lions Won’t Win a Playoff Game
abstract: The Lions are 7-4 and lead the N.F.C. North, but haven’t won a playoff game since 1991.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Lions have a frustrating postseason history. They have made the playoffs only 11 times since they were last N.F.L. champions, in 1957. In 10 of those appearances, they lost in the first round. Their only playoff win in more than half a century was a divisional-round win over the Dallas Cowboys in the 1991 season, back when Wayne Fontes was still their coach.

headline: 1966: UN Rejects Red China
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: The UN denies Communist China a place at its General Assembly in November 1966.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. — Communist China was denied a place in the UN today by ten more votes than in a similar General Assembly decision last year. The 57-46 vote with 17 abstentions, came after approval of an American-sponsored resolution declaring any change in China representation an “important question” requiring a two-thirds majority of those present and voting.

headline: Texas Will Require Burial of Aborted Fetuses
abstract: The rule, which goes into effect on Dec. 19, mandates that tissue from an abortion must be buried or cremated regardless of how long it has been gestating.
lead_paragraph: Texas approved new rules this week requiring health care facilities that perform abortions to bury the fetal remains instead of disposing of them in a sanitary landfill like other forms of biological medical waste, ending months of contentious debate and dismaying abortion rights groups.

headline: The Enduring Allure of Isabelle Huppert
abstract: The French actress consistently chooses roles that are morally complex and sometimes hard to watch. And yet we can’t bring ourselves to look away.
lead_paragraph: There are two unexpected orgasms in “Elle,” the latest film by Paul Verhoeven, and both are achieved by Michèle, played by the French actress Isabelle Huppert as only Isabelle Huppert could play her. Michèle is a successful, no-nonsense video-game executive, daughter of a jailed serial-killer father and a sex-obsessed cougar mother, ex-wife of a failed writer, mother to a useless son and, above all, a woman who gains mastery over her rapist by finding her own pleasure in the horrifying act. If there is another actress working today who could have pulled off this role, who could have dignified, deepened and brought humor to it, I can’t think of whom it might be.

headline: Crafting, the Hermès Way
keywords: ['Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Holidays and Special Occasions']
abstract: This month, Petit h hosts pop-up shops at the brand’s Manhattan boutiques, where guests can join “the joy of inventing.”
lead_paragraph: Pascale Mussard, the artistic director and sixth generation scion of the Hermès family, insists she “can find use for anything.” Her knack for repurposing is put to the test at Petit h, a salon des refusés of sorts, where she and her team of artisans and designers give new life to reams of raw silk, strips of crocodile skin and other extras from the Hermès ateliers. Objects range from the practical (reusable leather cupholders) to the purely playful (animal masks woven from silk scarves), but all exhibit the love of material and attention to detail for which Hermès is known. In December, Petit h will host pop-up shops at the brand’s Manhattan boutiques, complete with craft tables for guests to discover what Mussard calls “the joy of inventing.”

headline: Wrapping 4 Dances Into 1 at 100 Grand Street
abstract: Bill Young celebrates the 30th anniversary of his dance space and the inaugural choreography.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, Bill Young inaugurated a new performance space at 100 Grand Street with a program of four dances bearing the overall title of “Interleaving.” To celebrate the anniversary of that space and event, he is recreating “Interleaving” with a new cast of 14 dancers for his unusual choreographic concept. The four dances have traditional beginnings, middles and ends, but instead of a linear presentation of those sections, Mr. Young has grouped them together: All four beginnings are performed sequentially, then all four middles and, finally, all four ends. Reviewing the original production for The New York Times in 1987, Jennifer Dunning wrote that all of these forming and dissolving bits of movement were like daubs of color, making “Interleaving” resemble “an activated Jackson Pollock painting.” Any way you look at it, it’s four dances in one. (Thursday, Dec. 8, through Dec. 11, at 8:30 p.m.; 212-925-6573.)

headline: For Bon Iver, a Perfectionist 10
abstract: The eccentric songwriter Justin Vernon, a.k.a. Bon Iver, has a series of 10 New York shows.
lead_paragraph: For the versatile, sometimes eccentric songwriter Justin Vernon, more fame has meant more meticulousness when it comes to how he delivers music. In the case of “22, a Million,” his third and most experimental album as Bon Iver, that attention to detail meant taking five years to finish it, as well as a carefully curated debut at his own hometown music festival, Eaux Claires, in Wisconsin.

headline: Daniil Trifonov at Carnegie Hall and ‘Salome’ at the Met
abstract: This Russian pianist returns, and the conductor Johannes Debus has a debut at the Met with the soprano Patricia Racette in a Richard Strauss work.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, when he was 20, the Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov took the top prize in two prestigious international piano competitions: the Arthur Rubinstein in Israel and the Tchaikovsky in Russia. Now 25, he continues to astonish audiences with his technically prodigious, insightful and imaginative playing. He comes to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, Dec. 7, with a rich and challenging recital program: Schumann’s “Kinderszenen,” Toccata and “Kreisleriana”; five of Shostakovich’s Preludes and Fugues; and Stravinsky’s Three Movements from “Petrouchka.” (8 p.m.; 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: Eight Elegant Magazine Racks
abstract: Modern solutions for a delightfully old-fashioned problem.
lead_paragraph: Modern solutions for a delightfully old-fashioned problem.

headline: Britain’s New £5 Note, Stronger and Safer, Isn’t Suitable for Vegetarians
abstract: The Bank of England has confirmed that tallow, a hard, fatty substance usually made from rendered beef or mutton suet, was used in the base of the new bills.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When it released a new 5-pound note in September, the Bank of England said the polymer bills were stronger, safer and better for the environment. One thing they are not, it turns out, is meat-free.

headline: Ethics Office Praises Donald Trump for a Move He Hasn’t Committed To
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: In a series of oddly informal Twitter posts, the Office of Government Ethics appeared to conclude, wrongly, that Mr. Trump had promised to divest his assets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Office of Government Ethics has informed lawyers for President-elect Donald J. Trump that only a divestiture of his financial stake in his sprawling real estate business will resolve ethical concerns about conflicts of interest as he assumes the office of the presidency.

headline: Greetings From Kandor! Capital of Krypton!
abstract: Four of the sculptor Mike Kelley’s incarnations of the mini-metropolis Kandor, from the Superman comics, will be shown at the gallery Venus.
lead_paragraph: The artist Mike Kelley may be most closely associated with the sculptures he made out of hand dolls and stuffed animals — ostensibly cheerful objects suffused with the sadness of his short life, given that he committed suicide in 2012 at 57.

headline: Back to Baltimore 1962, in ‘Hairspray Live!’
abstract: NBC broadcasts its production of the Tony-winning Broadway musical on Dec. 7.
lead_paragraph: To its ambitious live productions of “The Sound of Music,” “Peter Pan” and “The Wiz,” NBC has added “Hairspray,” with its cast of “the sugar and spice-est, nicest kids in town.” Based on the Tony-winning Broadway musical spun from the 1988 John Waters film, “Hairspray Live!” (Wednesday, Dec. 7, 8 p.m.) follows a zaftig teenager onto the dance floor in 1962 Baltimore as she dreams of racial equality while shaking and shimmying her way to stardom on the all-white “Corny Collins Show.”

headline: Yeah, He Influenced Dylan and Carlin
abstract: Jake Broder brings back a cult comedian in the solo show “His Royal Hipness Lord Buckley.”
lead_paragraph: Lord Buckley is a founding father of stand-up comedy who is often left out of history books. A contemporary of Lenny Bruce, he influenced everyone from George Carlin to Bob Dylan (who supposedly took the term “jingle-jangle” in “Mr. Tambourine Man” from a stand-up routine). His albums are filled with jazzy retellings of classic stories (“A Christmas Carol,” “The Raven”) or historical incidents (the Gettysburg Address) in eccentric slang that mixed aristocratic airs with beatnik styles. His improvisational performance was so strange and hard to categorize that it doomed him to be a cult comic. Ken Kesey once described him as “a secret thing that people passed under the table.”

headline: The Far Right Has a New Digital Safe Space
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Censorship', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Cyberharassment', 'Discrimination', 'Whites', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Gab, a social media network built like a hybrid of Twitter and Reddit, bans very little and has become a conservative bunker of sorts.
lead_paragraph: When the white nationalist leader Richard B. Spencer was suspended from Twitter recently, he hopped over to YouTube to address his supporters. “Digitally speaking,” he said, Twitter had sent “execution squads across the alt-right.” He accused Twitter of “purging people on the basis of their views,” calling it “corporate Stalinism.” Then he mapped out a path forward. “There’s obviously Gab, which is an interesting medium,” he said. “I think that will be the place where we go next.”

headline: Raising 2 Young Children by Herself, in a Space That Feels Not Big Enough
abstract: Paola Infante lives with her 4-year-old daughter, Geraliz, who has autism, and her 8-month-old son, Joshua, who needs heart surgery, in a small Manhattan apartment with the kitchen in the living room.
lead_paragraph: In her cramped apartment in Upper Manhattan, Paola Infante cooked chicken and rice on a gas stove, stirring the meal as she kept an eye on her daughter, Geraliz, racing around the room. Each time the girl came near the flames and kitchen knives, Ms. Infante used her body to gently push her away.

headline: Salad Days
abstract: After a feast, you may be looking for the opposite of excess.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: How Banza, a Chickpea Pasta Start-Up, Thrives on Attention
abstract: Two brothers took their chickpea pasta from obscurity to the shelves of national retailers, successfully demonstrating the fine art of self-promotion.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The first big blast of attention could have easily ended the Rudolph brothers’ business dreams.

headline: Thailand’s Civil Servants Urged to Take a Break to Break a Sweat
abstract: The ruling military junta has begun a voluntary program calling for government employees to exercise once a week during working hours.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — He is already prime minister of Thailand and the chief of a military junta that seized power in a 2014 coup.

headline: Got a Confidential News Tip?
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from readers who want to share messages and materials with our journalists.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times would like to hear from readers who want to share messages and materials with our journalists.

headline: How a Triathlon Helped America Ferrera Defy Her Inner Critic
abstract: Ms. Ferrera couldn’t savor her Emmy win for “Ugly Betty” because of a nagging voice that kept her from owning her successes. A competition changed that.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t a dream. I was standing onstage holding an Emmy. I’d imagined being in this room, clutching this statue ever since watching my first Emmy broadcast at 7 years old. Now, I was actually at the podium and accepting the award on national television. It was 2007, and I was 23. I had worked very hard to get this far, I was shooting 16-hour days to make “Ugly Betty,” and I was loving every minute of it.

headline: Charlotte Officer ‘Justified’ in Fatal Shooting of Keith Scott
abstract: A prosecutor said Wednesday that Officer Brentley Vinson will not face charges in the Sept. 20 shooting of Keith Lamont Scott, whose death set off days of unrest.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — There is no doubt that officers surrounded him. That they shouted at him. That they shot him. But a crucial question about the fatal confrontation between Keith L. Scott and police officers in Charlotte, N.C., has always been whether Mr. Scott was wielding a gun.

headline: Busby Berkeley’s Grand Spectacles at Film Forum
abstract: His lavishly kaleidoscopic productions will be shown in a retrospective starting Dec. 7.
lead_paragraph: An ideal Hollywood moviemaker of Depression-era escapism, Busby Berkeley, the choreographer and director of musical comedies, was also a pioneer who expanded the language of cinema. Decades before C.G.I., Berkeley constructed lavishly kaleidoscopic productions: scores of dancers and musicians; elaborate sets; and innovations like revolving stages, overhead camera shots and mirrors. And generations of homage-payers have mined his giddy, surreal imagery for inspiration (Steven Spielberg in “Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom” and the Coen brothers in “The Big Lebowski,” to name but two).

headline: From Brooklyn to Kentucky to Iran: Cookbooks for Every Taste
abstract: New cookbooks include an elaborate approach to home cooking and recipes with strong regional identities.
lead_paragraph: In the age of internet recipes, why on earth would anyone open a cookbook? And yet we do. Printed cookbooks have been defying their own death notices for years now, probably because they don’t just offer recipes, they offer relationships. There’s a person inside those covers — someone whose voice is appealing, whose guidance is reliable and whose food evokes the world you wish you lived in. Today’s culinary celebrities may be photographed far more sumptuously than their predecessors, and their recipes may be more overtly dazzling, but their books make the same promise that once lured homemakers to Mrs. Beeton, Fannie Farmer, Betty Crocker and Julia Child. Cook like me, they’re all saying. Try this recipe, try that one. Life will be much, much better. “If you follow every step in this book, you, too, will have two children, run a start-up and live in Brooklyn,” declare Amanda Hesser and Merrill Stubbs in A NEW WAY TO DINNER: A Playbook of Recipes and Strategies for the Week Ahead (Ten Speed, $35). They’re being jovial, but they’re also evoking the dream at the heart of the cookbook business.

headline: 20 More Cookbooks
abstract: “Classic German Baking,” “Dorie’s Cookies” and more.
lead_paragraph: Still in need of inspiration for the cooks on your holiday list after reading our seasonal roundup? Here are 20 more candidates:

headline: Two Sous Vide Gadgets Face Off in a Kitchen Showdown
abstract: Sous vide cooking is simple enough: Put a bag of food in hot water and wait. But two devices for doing this, the Joule and the Anova, differ greatly.
lead_paragraph: LET’S face it: Thanks to technology, we are running out of excuses for not knowing how to cook.

headline: Grant Tinker, Former Chairman of NBC, Dies at 90; Made Network a Ratings Powerhouse
abstract: Mr. Tinker, whose MTM Enterprises produced hit shows in the 1970s, revamped NBC’s prime-time lineup in the 1980s with series like “Cheers” and “Hill Street Blues.”
lead_paragraph: Grant Tinker, who produced “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” and other television hits in the 1970s and transformed NBC from a perennial ratings loser to a powerhouse of literate, sophisticated network programming that helped change America’s viewing habits in the ’80s, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 90.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Beats Back House Democratic Leadership Challenge
abstract: Ms. Pelosi, the House minority leader, survived an attempt by a fellow Democrat, Tim Ryan, to unseat her amid anxiety over their party’s setbacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats on Wednesday rejected appeals that they need new leaders to win back disaffected voters, re-electing Representative Nancy Pelosi of California to an eighth term as House leader over a Rust Belt congressman who said the party had lost its connection to the American working class.

headline: Take Your Smartphone Photography to the Next Level
abstract: Some apps mimic a single-lens reflex camera in options and complexity, while others unleash your creativity.
lead_paragraph: WITH Apple’s iPhone 7 and Google’s new Pixel phones putting such an emphasis on powerful camera technology, smartphone photography is more robust than ever. And while phones typically have great built-in photography apps, many other options can be easier or expand your range.

headline: This Season’s Books on Sports: A Roundup
abstract: People who see sports as an escape from the real world might be surprised at just how often the two overlap.
lead_paragraph: People who see sports as an escape from the real world might be surprised at just how often the two overlap. The American experience constantly darts into the western Pennsylvania town of Aliquippa in S.L. Price’s PLAYING THROUGH THE WHISTLE: Steel, Football, and an American Town (Atlantic Monthly, $27). In the 1930s, Aliquippa was a site of anti-union violence, in part ended when this company town’s company, Jones & Laughlin Steel, was on the wrong side of the 1937 Supreme Court decision confirming the New Deal’s labor protections. Aliquippa rode World War II and its aftermath — “War eats steel,” Price writes in hard-boiled style — to the point where, by 1950, the United States produced nearly half the world’s steel. Aliquippa declined with the industry and struggled with racial tensions, housing discrimination, protests. In the 1980s came crack cocaine. Today, Aliquippa is a shell.

headline: Appalachia Burning
keywords: ['Wildfires', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The flame-ravaged Gatlinburg is a place of beauty, in a region that sorely needs it.
lead_paragraph: BEREA, Ky. — My parents married in the spring of 1973, in a modest white Baptist church by a creek in a small hollow in southeastern Kentucky. My mother borrowed her sister’s wedding dress, and after the cake-and-punch reception in the fellowship hall, she changed into a baby blue minidress and set out with my father to the Smoky Mountains resort town of Gatlinburg, Tenn., for the honeymoon.

headline: Rock Lives: This Season’s Pop Music Biographies and Memoirs
abstract: New books look at the careers of Brian Wilson, Paul Simon and other music stars.
lead_paragraph: When Brian Wilson was young, another kid cracked him upside the head with a lead pipe. He was rendered almost entirely deaf in his right ear. When people talked to him, he would turn his left side toward them, “like I was tuning a radio station.” And when Wilson makes music, he says, “I make mono music. I can only hear out of one side, which means that it’s already mixed down.”

headline: Insomniacs Are Helped by Online Therapy, Study Finds
abstract: The report suggests that many garden-variety insomniacs could benefit from cognitive behavior therapy without ever having to talk to a therapist.
lead_paragraph: The same digital screens that have helped nurture a generation of insomniacs can also help restore regular sleep, researchers reported on Wednesday. In a new study, more than half of chronic insomniacs who used an automated online therapy program reported improvement within weeks and were sleeping normally a year later.

headline: ‘Instagram Face’: Is It the End of Good Makeup?
abstract: From selfies for pay to sponsored content, social media has changed the cosmetics game for good.
lead_paragraph: The day before the Rebecca Minkoff fashion show in September, the makeup artist Gato Zamora and the 17-year-old YouTube blogger Amanda Steele sat side by side examining Mr. Zamora’s work. He had transformed a model’s fair-with-some-redness complexion into glowing and even. The foundation was imperceptible. He applied a pinkish nude lipstick. Ms. Steele and Mr. Zamora leaned in, heads nearly touching. They agreed: A balm would be better. “Maybe she’ll look more like a teenager,” he said.

headline: As Auto Lending Rises, So Do Delinquencies
abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York expressed concern on Wednesday that delinquencies among auto borrowers with shaky credit had been rising.
lead_paragraph: Regulators are airing “significant concern” about the millions of Americans who are falling behind on their car loans, even as auto lending continues to boom at a near record pace.

headline: President-Elect Jovenel Moïse of Haiti Vows to Create Plan to Channel Aid
abstract: Mr. Moïse, who received 55 percent of the vote, said, “If they want to spend money, we are open to that, but we will show you exactly where to spend this.”
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — He’s often called the Banana Man, because he exports produce. Now, he will be known by another title: president of Haiti.

headline: Tunisia Seeks Foreign Investment to Cement Democratic Gains
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: The country where the Arab Spring began five years ago is trying to bolster its economy, especially in the less developed interior, as it combats terrorism.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — The emir of Qatar came in person with a pledge of $1.25 billion. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, France and other European partners promised substantial amounts, too.

headline: Steven Mnuchin Is More Pragmatist Than Ideologue
abstract: Such an approach could help Mr. Mnuchin balance competing views while pushing for some of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s major first-year goals.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has made an illogically logical choice for his Treasury secretary, Steven Mnuchin.

headline: GoPro, the Action Camera Maker, Plans 200 Layoffs
abstract: The cutbacks are aimed at reducing operating expenses and focusing on the company’s core business. The company’s president is also departing.
lead_paragraph: GoPro, the manufacturer of the wearable camera that has been a favorite of athletes, thrill-seekers and anyone else who wants to capture video of their antics, announced on Wednesday that it will eliminate hundreds of jobs to hold down costs.

headline: Mike Pence and ‘Conversion Therapy’: A History
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: The vice president-elect has denied that he supports discredited methods meant to change a person’s sexual orientation or gender identity.
lead_paragraph: Since Gov. Mike Pence was chosen as Donald J. Trump’s running mate in July, he has faced complaints from groups critical of his record on gay and transgender rights, who said he has long been an opponent of the gains made by the L.G.B.T. community in recent years.

headline: An Art World Player With a Warhol Pedigree
abstract: Casey Fremont, 33, is the new executive director of the Art Production Fund based in New York.
lead_paragraph: Name Casey Fremont

headline: ‘Victimizing Me All Over Again’: San Bernardino Victims Fight for Treatment
keywords: ["Workers' Compensation Insurance", 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Government Employees', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Physical Therapy', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Nearly a year after being shot in a terrorist attack, employees of San Bernardino County, Calif., are struggling with delayed or denied workers’ compensation claims.
lead_paragraph: A year after a terrorist’s bullets ripped through her, after so many operations and infections she has lost count, Valerie Kallis-Weber has a paralyzed left hand, painful bone and bullet fragments in her pelvis, psychological trauma and tissue damage, including a fist-size gouge in her thigh where a bullet tore away the muscle.

headline: Now, Netflix Users Can Watch Movies Offline on Their Mobile Devices
abstract: Users will be able binge watch some shows and movies on their phones and tablets without eating up their entire data plan.
lead_paragraph: Netflix announced on Wednesday that users worldwide can download some videos to their mobile devices instead of streaming them over cellular data, a feature that could keep eyeballs on the app when internet signals are spotty or unavailable.

abstract: A professor of economics calls on Trump to “prove just how effective he can be as a negotiator” by revising the TPP to his liking.

abstract: A reader wonders what promises were made to Carrier to keep 1,000 jobs in the United States.

headline: As a Distracted Brazil Mourns, Lawmakers Gut a Corruption Bill
abstract: With Brazilians stunned by the crash of a plane carrying a soccer team, lawmakers made dead-of-night changes to a bill meant to keep officials honest.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil was still mourning the victims of one of its most agonizing sports tragedies, the crash of a plane carrying the Chapecoense soccer team. But the country’s scandal-plagued Congress had its own priorities: gutting what was supposed to be a pioneering anticorruption bill.

headline: U.S. Will Ban Smoking in Public Housing Nationwide
abstract: Officials said the rule, which bars tobacco use in apartments, common areas and offices, will take effect in early 2017. It will cover the homes of more than 400,000 New York City residents.
lead_paragraph: Smoking will be prohibited in public housing residences nationwide under a federal rule announced on Wednesday.

headline: Daily Report: Twitter Struggles to Turn Prominence Into Profit
abstract: You can’t think about the 2016 presidential election without thinking about the social media service. But attention hasn’t translated into big profits.
lead_paragraph: Years from now, it could be a fascinating historical footnote: Donald J. Trump, the next president of the United States, is a steady Twitter user. Yet the company is unprofitable, recently announced layoffs and appears to still be figuring out its place in the world.

headline: Add Folders to the Mac’s Sidebar
abstract: If you do not see shortcuts to the computer’s Pictures, Music or other standard folders when you open a Finder window, you can add them yourself.
lead_paragraph: Q. My Mac does not show a Pictures folder in the sidebar window. Why?

abstract: Sampling the responses to an Op-Ed article by former President Jimmy Carter.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Snapshot Captures the Awkward Courtship Between Trump and Romney
abstract: Rain was falling outside. Young garlic soup and frog legs were on the menu. In other words, It was the perfect occasion for a photo op.
lead_paragraph: At Jean-Georges, a three-star Michelin restaurant on the first floor of his namesake hotel in New York, Donald J. Trump took time out of his Tuesday schedule to share a four-course meal with Mitt Romney and Reince Priebus, his soon-to-be White House chief of staff.

headline: Why Donald Trump Shouldn’t Fill the Cabinet With Generals
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States International Relations', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'International Relations', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Mr. Trump needs a mix of voices advising him, not just military leaders.
lead_paragraph: Based on the candidates parading through Trump Tower for job interviews in recent weeks, the president-elect could end up with generals holding the five most powerful national security offices in the country, an unprecedented concentration of military influence that deserves more public debate than it seems to be receiving.

headline: The Plight of Appalachia
abstract: A reader writes that “efforts to avoid environmental disaster have been routinely opposed not only by coal companies but also by elected officials.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Aleppo, Fidel Castro, Mosul: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning.

headline: Win a Trip
abstract: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas Kristof invites students to enter a contest for an international reporting trip in 2018.
lead_paragraph: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas Kristof invites students to enter a contest for an international reporting trip in 2018.

headline: ‘I Love N.Y.’ Signs Have a Lot to Say. The Government Says They’re Illegal.
keywords: ['Signs and Signage', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic and Parking Signals and Signs', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue']
abstract: State road signs intended to generate love and money for New York have instead set off a feud with federal officials, who say the signs are dangerous distractions.
lead_paragraph: The big blue signs — hundreds of them — crop up like crab grass along the highways and byways of New York State, enticing travelers to stop and take in the sights. The bright placards were dreamed up and placed there by the state to promote tourism, each brandishing New York’s cheerful and familiar credo: “I Love N.Y.”

headline: Gambia’s Leader Vowed to Rule for a Billion Years. A Vote Will Test That.
abstract: Enthusiasm for President Yahya Jammeh’s rival has put into question the outcome of the country’s election and prompted fears of instability and violence.
lead_paragraph: BANJUL, Gambia — Since he took over the presidency of tiny Gambia more than two decades ago, President Yahya Jammeh has made headlines by threatening to decapitate gay people, carrying out a deadly witch hunt and claiming to cure AIDS with little more than a prayer and a banana.

headline: The Freshmen: Four Art Basel Miami First-Timers to Know
abstract: Several young dealers on their decision to apply to North America's most prestigious art fair — a risky one for small, up-and-coming galleries.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, the art-fair scene has exploded on an international level — offering dealers from around the globe a chance to connect with new audiences like never before. But the decision whether to participate in the fair hustle can be a risky one for smaller, less established galleries. What it costs in booth space, shipping, personnel and time might pay off in growth and exposure — or it might not. Here, four first-time exhibitors showing in the Art Basel Miami Beach pavilion weigh in on the importance of North America’s most anticipated fair.

headline: Mind Over Body: Playing in the N.F.L. at 38
abstract: Vikings cornerback Terence Newman is a step slower, so he tries to outsmart opponents to stay on top of his game.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Terence Newman usually views film of the Vikings’ next opponent at the island in his kitchen, but on this night, three days before Minnesota was to host the Arizona Cardinals, he had relocated to a more comfortable spot. Lounging in an oversize leather chair, his legs dangling over the edge, Newman cradled a team-issued digital tablet containing hours of video clips.

headline: TED’s Science Curator Sees Hope in Earth’s Anthropocene Age
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Earth', 'Global Warming', 'Infant Mortality', 'Museums', 'TED Conference', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: TED’s new curator of science, David Biello, explains why he sees hints of hope in Earth’s emerging Anthropocene “age of us.”
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month I had a chat on the fate of the planet and humanity in a Brooklyn bookstore with David Biello, who recently became curator of science at TED (as in talks) after many years at Scientific American. The subject was his first book, “Unnatural World: The Race to Remake Civilization in Earth’s Newest Age” — a brisk, unsettling and, yes, hopeful, guide to the Anthropocene. We also touched on my recent magazine essay, “An Anthropocene Journey.”

headline: How Blue Turned to Green: Blue Man Group at 25 Years
abstract: This bald and earless troupe, which has become an institution in Manhattan and elsewhere, celebrates its silver anniversary.
lead_paragraph: They are bald, blue and earless. They do not talk. They play with their food (and their paint), perform wild music on instruments of their own devising and are the centerpiece of an international entertainment empire with 550 full- and part-time employees and annual revenues of $100 million.

headline: How One Brutal Weekend in Chicago Lives on for Times Team
abstract: Using video cameras, still cameras, audio recorders, social media and plain old notebooks, we hear the voices of a city in pain.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Julie Bosman, a national correspondent covering the Midwest, and Catrin Einhorn, a reporter and editor based in Chicago, share how a Times team’s multifaceted reporting on one weekend in one city grew into a living, continuing memorial.

headline: Paul Sevigny Reopens Sway Lounge in SoHo
abstract: The home of the popular Sunday “Smiths/Morrissey Night” party is back, this time as Paul’s Casablanca.
lead_paragraph: Last December, wistful partygoers made pilgrimages to western SoHo for the final days of Sway, a lounge whose popularity withered over the last half-decade. Now, it has reopened as Paul’s Casablanca, with a gussied-up interior and a resurrection of the beloved Sunday “Smiths/Morrissey Night” party.

headline: M.L.B. Labor Deal Is Struck, Averting a Work Stoppage
abstract: A new collective bargaining agreement, including revised free-agency rules, is expected to assure labor peace for Major League Baseball through 2021.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball and the players’ union reached an agreement Wednesday night on a five-year collective bargaining agreement, beating a midnight deadline and ensuring labor peace through 2021 for a sport once regularly entangled in work stoppages.

headline: E.U. Plans Big Increase in Military Spending
abstract: The plan comes at a time when the bloc is seeking to rely less on the security guarantees of the United States.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union officials announced plans for a big increase in military spending on Wednesday, pledging to take greater responsibility for their security at a time when the United States appears to be taking a step back in its role in the world.

headline: A Spotlight on the Season’s Top Photography Books
abstract: New books showcase the photos of Daido Moriyama, Sally Mann and others.
lead_paragraph: There is possibly no more omnivorous photographer alive than Daido Moriyama. His pictures have an identifiable look: black-and-white, grainy, off-center, tilted, high-contrast — but within those bounds he has covered an encyclopedic range of subjects and approaches in the dozens of books he has published since the early 1970s. (Note that such a figure is not unusual for photographers in Japan, where books are often small, cheap and quickly produced — conditions that favor grain and high contrast.) In his newest, DAIDO TOKYO (Fondation Cartier Pour l’Art Contemporain/Thames & Hudson, $40), he counters expectations: Half the pages are in color. His subject is Shinjuku, the neighborhood around Tokyo’s major train station, historically not unlike Times Square: filled with bars and love hotels, rife with low-level crime and lurid advertising. It has been gentrified somewhat in recent decades, and also features verdant parks and sleek skyscrapers, but Moriyama nevertheless locates all his favorite textures: fishnet, chain-link, steel tubing, tangled cables, broken glass, torn posters, cracked PVC, dust.

headline: Celebrating Shoes With Rihanna
abstract: The singer-cum-designer became the first woman to win an award for Shoe of the Year at the Footwear News Achievement Awards in New York on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: In today’s politically charged climate, even shoes can be contentious.

headline: Review: 5 Short Plays, Up-Close and Unsettled, Purposely
abstract: The anthology “In This Moment” is presented free of charge by Theater for One in a mobile booth in the Pershing Square Signature Center’s lobby.
lead_paragraph: Many thoughts swirled through my head as I watched “This Moment After,” but the main one was: Please don’t start crying in front of the actress!

headline: I Am a Dangerous Professor
abstract: My inclusion on a new ‘watchlist’ is intended to shame me into silence.
lead_paragraph: Those familiar with George Orwell’s “1984” will recall that “Newspeak was designed not to extend but to diminish the range of thought.” I recently felt the weight of this Orwellian ethos when many of my students sent emails to inform me, and perhaps warn me, that my name appears on the Professor Watchlist, a new website created by a conservative youth group known as Turning Point USA.

headline: Sundance Film Festival 2017: Four Films to Know
keywords: ['Movies', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The movies are part of the lineup of 32 features and documentaries that will compete for prizes in Park City in January.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The next Sundance Film Festival will lean into its progressive sweet spots, with topics like the environment, race relations and gender figuring prominently in the competition lineup.

headline: Ohio State Attacker May Have Been ‘Inspired’ by Al Qaeda, F.B.I. Says
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: Investigators say Abdul Razak Ali Artan, the student who wounded 11 people at the university, may have been inspired by a Qaeda propagandist, or by the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — The student who wounded 11 people this week at Ohio State University, plowing his car into a cluster of pedestrians and then slashing some of them with a butcher knife, may have been inspired by Anwar al-Awlaki, a Qaeda recruiter and propagandist, or by the Islamic State terrorist group, investigators said on Wednesday.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Jailed Immigrants’ Right to Periodic Hearings
abstract: The number of these detainees is likely to swell if President-elect Donald J. Trump follows through on his pledge to deport millions of unauthorized immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the nation on the cusp of a more assertive immigration policy under the administration of President-elect Donald J. Trump, the Supreme Court on Wednesday considered the rights of people held in immigration detention. Their numbers are likely to swell if Mr. Trump follows through on his pledge to deport millions of unauthorized immigrants.

headline: Erich Bloch, Who Helped Develop IBM Mainframe, Dies at 91
abstract: In 1964, he transformed computing with the System/360, the foundation for the modern operating system that would host various software programs.
lead_paragraph: Erich Bloch, who helped develop the IBM mainframe computer that, more than any other machine, propelled the world into the digital age, and who then shepherded the internet into broader use as director of the National Science Foundation, died on Nov. 25 in Washington. He was 91.

headline: Sure, It’s Castro and Cigars, but Cuba Is Coral and Crocodiles, Too
abstract: “¡Cuba!,” an exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History, tries to deliver the country whole — its history, culture, politics and natural environment.
lead_paragraph: In the American imagination, Cuba evokes a scant handful of trademark sights and sounds: sugar cane, rum, 1950s Fords and Chevys, the Buena Vista Social Club. Cigars, of course. And for the last half-century and more, Fidel Castro.

headline: Dying to Be Heard: Reporting Syria’s War
abstract: For the past five years, Hadi Abdullah, 29, has been reporting on the war in Syria and its devastating effects in rebel-held areas. This work has put him and his colleagues in the line of fire.
lead_paragraph: For the past five years, Hadi Abdullah, 29, has been reporting on the war in Syria and its devastating effects in rebel-held areas. This work has put him and his colleagues in the line of fire.

headline: With 28,000 LEDs, It’s Lights! Lights! Lights! Action!
abstract: Robert Lepage discusses using all those shimmering LEDs in the staging of Kaija Saariaho’s “L’Amour de Loin” at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Strung across the Metropolitan Opera’s stage on more than two dozen parallel strands, from the pit to the back wall, 28,000 colorful LEDs will create an ever-changing, sometimes tempestuous sea for the Met’s new production of the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho’s “L’Amour de Loin,” which opens on Thursday.

headline: A Look Back at Snowboarding Culture — and Style
abstract: A new book, “Snow Beach,” chronicles the look of the sport in the 1980s and 1990s.
lead_paragraph: A new book, “Snow Beach,” chronicles the look of the sport in the 1980s and 1990s.

headline: Neon Gear and Renegade Style: The Heyday of Snowboarding
abstract: A new photography book chronicles the culture of the sport from the mid-1980s to the mid-1990s.
lead_paragraph: “Before snowboarding was a ‘sport,’ before half-pipe was considered the biggest TV draw at the Olympics — to be a rider was to be part of a countercultural movement,” writes the snowboarding pro turned journalist Jesse Huffman in the introduction to “Snow Beach,” a new photo book that chronicles the snowboarding culture and style of the ’80s and ’90s. “For kids that had been left starved of expression by the neon wash of the ’80s, by jock posturing at school, by low expectations, it was a way out.”

headline: What You Should Watch Wednesday Night
abstract: If you’re looking for a show to inspire you to move to isolated rolling hills, watch “Vikings” tonight.
lead_paragraph: ‘Vikings,’ 9 p.m., History

headline: Why the Trump Team’s Economic Promises Will Be Hard to Execute
abstract: The men chosen to lead the Treasury and Commerce Departments vow to cut taxes, increase growth and hold the line on deficits, testing the limits of economic math.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The middle class will see a big tax cut, but the wealthy will not. American businesses will pay much lower taxes, and as a consequence bring back billions of dollars from overseas. All this will create sustained growth of 3 to 4 percent a year and prevent the budget deficit from exploding.

headline: What It Means for Trump to Save 1,000 Jobs in Indiana
abstract: How the president-elect’s deal measures up to U.S. manufacturing job losses.
lead_paragraph: How the president-elect’s deal measures up to U.S. manufacturing job losses.

headline: Recent College Grads Have Choices When Bills Start to Arrive
abstract: This is the time of year that a student loan grace period typically ends for spring graduates — but flexible repayment plans can help ease the burden.
lead_paragraph: THE end of the year brings the holiday season, but for many recent college graduates, it is also the start of payback time.

headline: Lufthansa Joins Germany’s List of Companies in Distress
keywords: ['Pilots', 'Strikes', 'Organized Labor', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A strike by pilots at the airline has caused travel problems in Europe and threatened to damage Germany’s longstanding cooperation between management and labor.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Lufthansa was once a proud symbol of Germany Inc., standing for the quality and smooth functionality of Europe’s No. 1 economy. But that was before the last week, when a strike by the airline’s pilots stranded more than half a million passengers.

headline: Study Suggests 3.2 Million-Year-Old Lucy Spent a Lot of Time in Trees
keywords: ['Skeletons', 'Paleontology', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Australopithecines', 'Trees and Shrubs', 'Bones', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY']
abstract: The bones of the famous fossil were pretty thick, suggesting she had a ratio of strength between her arms and legs more like a chimp than a human.
lead_paragraph: Lucy was a small one. She weighed about as much as the average 2nd grader and stood about three-and-a-half feet tall. But that lady (or pre-lady, because Australopithecus afarensis like her weren’t quite human) was strong. Her famous skeleton, a 3.18 million-year-old fossil also known as AL 288-1, tells us so. But to build arm bones as strong as hers, she, and possibly other members of her species, probably spent a lot of time in trees, suggests a study published Wednesday in the journal PLOS One.

headline: Books by Clare Beams, Hans Herbert Grimm, April Ayers Lawson and Kelly Luce
abstract: Magical realism infuses one story collection; sex and faith underpin another. And a debut novel grabs your attention.
lead_paragraph: And Other Stories

headline: Review: ‘One More Time With Feeling’ Listens to Nick Cave’s Darkness
abstract: Andrew Dominik’s 3-D black-and-white documentary focuses on the making of Mr. Cave’s 16th album, “The Skeleton Tree.”
lead_paragraph: It’s impossible not to empathize with Nick Cave as he and the Bad Seeds record his devastating song “I Need You” in Andrew Dominik’s 3-D black-and-white film, “One More Time With Feeling,” about the making of Mr. Cave’s 16th album, “The Skeleton Tree.”

headline: Fair Hopping, Parties and Shopping at Art Basel Miami Beach
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Art Basel Miami Beach']
abstract: Where to score your party-ready wardrobe needs, B12 shots, unlimited blowouts and more.
lead_paragraph: This weekend promises a marathon for Art Basel Miami Beach snowbirds of fair hopping, parties … and shopping! Prep for the action at the Armarium pop-up at the Raleigh, which has all your wardrobe needs sorted. A Christopher Kane pansy-print top ($125 rental, $895 retail) and skirt ($150 rental, $895 retail) and Rebecca de Ravenel Les Bonbons earrings ($50 rental, $275 retail) look ready to party. At 1775 Collins Avenue. The boutique fitness center Anatomy at 1220 is offering a 20 percent discount on its one-week membership package that includes a B12 shot from VitaSquad ($125, originally $160). At 1220 20th Street, Miami Beach. And the Atma salon is offering unlimited blowouts ($145) when you mention the booking code NewYorkTimes. At 1874 West Avenue, Miami Beach.

headline: Movie Awards Season Kicks Off in High Gear
abstract: The holidays are in sight, and the Hollywood awards machine is cranking into gear: Will the postelection blues affect it?
lead_paragraph: Hello again everybody! Think electioneering this year is over, and campaigns are behind us?

headline: Alvin Ailey’s ‘Revelations’: ‘Like the Phoenix Being Born Again’
abstract: In our new weekly visual exploration of dance, we focus on Glenn Allen Sims at the start of Ailey’s masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance: a new weekly visual exploration of dance. Follow us on Instagram: @nytimes.

headline: A Nigerian Artist Who Uses the Skin as His Canvas
abstract: Laolu Senbanjo, whose collaboration with Beyoncé on “Lemonade” led to his own mainstream fame, hopes to create awareness around African artists.
lead_paragraph: Laolu Senbanjo stood silently, head slightly bent to one side. Clothing and arms speckled with white paint, he studied his muse a few feet away. With a scratch of his chin and a nod, Mr. Senbanjo glided in his socks toward the actress Danielle Brooks. His ever-present white marker in hand, a combination of body paint and other materials, he resumed adorning her face with continuous patterned lines.

headline: The Films of Raúl Ruiz Come to Lincoln Center
abstract: Raúl Ruiz (1941-2011), a Chilean director who lived in France for years, was a playful man who played by his own rules.
lead_paragraph: Does it hinder an artist to be adored by a coterie? Can a filmmaker be obscured by the vastness of his output?

headline: Where Enthusiasts of the Freeze Go for a Winter Coat
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Coats and Jackets', 'Fur']
abstract: The Canadian tech labels Canada Goose and Arc’teryx operate in SoHo, if not quietly.
lead_paragraph: Late on a temperate weekday afternoon last month, about 20 people lined up outside the new Canada Goose store in SoHo behind a metal barrier, separating them — us — from the main meat of the street. The block was, apart from this cluster, empty. The store was, comparatively, empty. There were more potential customers on the street than in the store and, while we’re counting, more employees in the store than customers.

headline: OPEC, Donald Trump, Nancy Pelosi: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Cool Women Doing Cool Things
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Gifts', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: What a few trendsetting women are creating and inspiring others to create — and in time for the holiday shopping.
lead_paragraph: What a few trendsetting women are creating and inspiring others to create — and in time for the holiday shopping.

headline: Review: Decades of Lucinda Childs’s Cool Minimalism in Motion
abstract: “Lucinda Childs: A Portrait (1963-2016),” at the Joyce Theater, consists of eight works spanning nearly 54 years, all revealing the same rigid idiom.
lead_paragraph: The dances of the choreographer Lucinda Childs are polished, immaculate, empty. Their elegance seems like a clinical condition; beneath it, there’s no sign of inner life.

headline: John Legend: Love Songs That Bow to Dark Shadows
abstract: On “Darkness and Light,” Mr. Legend treats love as something far more complex than a panacea and a fount of perpetual reassurance.
lead_paragraph: A little darkness serves John Legend well. Without it, the love songs that regularly place him in the Top 10 — megahits like “All of Me” from 2013 — are anodyne enough to work as wedding songs; they’re a worthy and lucrative enterprise that can leave an unctuous, saccharine aftertaste. But “Darkness and Light,” his fifth studio album, treats love as something far more complex than a panacea and a fount of perpetual reassurance, with music to match.

headline: More, More, More: That’s How They Like It
abstract: Layer on the textures. Dial up the shine. Who doesn’t need a mood lifter this season?
lead_paragraph: “Anything goes!” Gia Ghezzi, a fashion consultant who was until recently the fashion director of Intermix, said of the many ways to wear sparkle and shine this holiday season. “If you feel comfortable in your own skin, now is the moment to have fun and play with it.”

headline: A Producer Spearheads a Collective to Help Hispanics in Theater
abstract: Jacob G. Padrón is the artistic director of the Sol Project, which has found deep pockets to finance its goal of ushering Latinos into the theater mainstream.
lead_paragraph: There were more than a dozen people in the room, and only two or three were not from ethnic minorities. That’s how Susan Bernfield, producing artistic director of the theater company New Georges, remembers the first production meeting, this fall, for Hilary Bettis’s new play, “Alligator” — a gathering that included the playwright, director and design team.

headline: Democrats See Medicare as Winning Wedge Issue
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As Republicans take on health care, Democrats are grasping at the politics of Medicare as a path to potential revival after a bruising election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republicans are talking about messing with Medicare again, and Democrats couldn’t be more enthusiastic.

headline: Battle Over an Oil Pipeline: Teaching About the Standing Rock Sioux Protests
abstract: This lesson plan asks students to weigh potential drawbacks and advantages of the pipeline project, and then to develop a fair solution to the current standoff.
lead_paragraph: For several months, Native American tribes and their allies, led by the Standing Rock Sioux, have been protesting against the Dakota Access pipeline, a project that would transport oil from the Bakken oil fields in North Dakota and Montana across the Plains to Illinois. The protesters, numbering in the thousands and including members of hundreds of different tribes, argue that completing the pipeline would desecrate ancestral lands, threaten the water supply, and unfairly burden the Standing Rock Sioux tribe, which is unlikely to benefit from any economic development that accompanies the project. Energy Transfer Partners, the corporation behind the pipeline, suggests the project will lead to greater economic development and increased safety and efficiency compared to the trains that currently carry Bakken crude oil.

headline: Win a Trip in 2017
abstract: Announcing my annual win-a-trip contest for a student to accompany me on a reporting trip.
lead_paragraph: I’m delighted to invite university students to apply for my 2017 win-a-trip contest. I’ve been holding these contests since 2006, then taking the winner along with me on a reporting trip to cover global poverty and social justice issues. My aim is to generate interest in neglected global issues with the contest, and get more people writing about these issues.

headline: Review: ‘Not That Jewish,’ but Funny Just the Same
abstract: The comic and writer Monica Piper tells stories about her life and her casual relationship with her religion in a one-woman show at New World Stages.
lead_paragraph: Monica Piper is a genial guide to her own life in “Not That Jewish,” a one-woman show at New World Stages that ranges far and wide — too far and wide, perhaps — but keeps the theme of the title always within sight.

headline: Jackie Kennedy: The First Instagram First Lady
abstract: “Jackie,” a film about Jacqueline Kennedy, reveals a first lady whose fixation on style anticipated the image-obsessed culture of the coming decades.
lead_paragraph: “All the talk over what I wear and how I fix my hair has amused and puzzled me,” Jacqueline Kennedy wrote long ago in “Campaign Wife,” the syndicated weekly newspaper column she wrote during John F. Kennedy’s 1960 campaign. “What does my hair have to do with my husband’s ability to be president?”

headline: Keo Woolford, a Detective on ‘Hawaii Five-0,’ Dies at 49
abstract: Mr. Woolford, an actor and filmmaker, also starred in a one-man show that explored his Hawaiian heritage.
lead_paragraph: Keo Woolford, a Hawaiian actor and filmmaker who played Detective James Chang in the current CBS television series “Hawaii Five-0,” died on Nov. 28 in Oahu, Hawaii. He was 49.
